column2: The Consolidated Edison Company will add a 500,000kilowatt generating unit to its Arthur Kill Station in Travis, S.I., it was announced yesterday.
Superintendent of Schools Bernard E. Donovan announced yesterday that about 24 Negroes would be among 200 assistant principals to be appointed to elementary and junior high schools Feb. 7.
Orin Lehman and Councilman Theodore R. Kupferman, who are vying for the House seat vacated by Mayor Lindsay, differed sharply yesterday over United States involvement in the war in Vietnam.
Renata Tebaldi will sing the title role in Puccini's "Tosca" at the Metropolitan Opera tonight at 8:30. George Schick will conduct.
ST. PAUL, Jan. 6 (AP) A fire early today at the Carleton Hotel killed nine persons and injured 17.

TORONTO, Jan. 6 (AP) Stuart Armour, president of the Great Lakes Waterways Development Association, proposed today a series of recommendations to the St. Lawrence Seaway Authority calling for the abolition of tolls on shipping and cargo.

Buckpasser, the champion 2year-old colt of 1965, was selected yesterday as the 3-yearold thoroughbred most likely to succeed this year on the basis of assignment of weights for the Experimental Free Handicap.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., Jan. 6 A group of Negro voters has asked a Federal Court here to order a special election this year for all Lowndes County offices.
OSSINING, N. Y., Jan. 6 Despite the transfer of 36 ringleaders, a strike by inmates at Sing Sing prison went into its fourth day today. All but about 160 convicts refused to work in the prison shops.

The 47-year-old owner of a Bronx photographic supply store died yesterday a few minutes before noon in a fire in his shop at 14 West Tremont Avenue. The fire spread to a candy store and a barber shop, and to a five-story apartment building around the corner at 1960 Davidson Avenue.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 (AP) Representative Henry S. Reuss, Democrat of Wisconsin, said today that the Justice Department had approved a compromise that he hoped would permit early House action this year on a controversial bank-merger bill.
THE clothes that actresses and show girls have worn on and off-stage always stand out in world fashion even today when it's hard to tell a star from a secretary in the front row center.

The transit strike has forced three city hopsitals Bellevue, City and Greenpoint to close all their outpatient clinics except pediatrics. The Bellevue clinics normally serve 1,500 to 2,000 patients daily, the combined total served by the two other hospitals.
FRANKFURT, Jan. 6 (Comtelburo) The Bundesbank announced an increase in interest rates for West Germany's Treasury bills and other Government paper, effective tomorrow.
Stocks moved up on heavy volume on the American Stock Exchange yesterday despite the abbreviated trading session.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 President Johnson received pledges today stating that 477,000 students in 322 universities and colleges support United States policy on Vietnam.
SAIGON, Friday, Jan. 7 The Vietcong have used heavy 120mm. mortars for the first time in the Vietnam war, a military spokesman reported yesterday.
The Transit Authority yesterday began docking some 2,500 of its 5,000 nonstriking employes who had not reported for work during the transit strike.
THEY took pictures yesterday of Edward Steichen, one of the men who raised photography to an art.

Mr. and Mrs. Boris M. Duchowny have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Marina Duchowny, to Dr. Victor Whitman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Whitman of Mission, Tex. A July wedding is planned.
MIAMI, Jan. 6 (UPI) Lash Larue, once the movies' "king of the bullwhip," was arrested for vagrancy today with 35 cents in his pockets and bitterness on his lips.

As the City Council awaited the introduction of bills reducing the budget powers of both the Mayor and the Board of Estimate, Queens Borough President Mario J. Cariello sharply assailed yesterday the idea of changing current budget procedures.

TRENTON, Jan. 6 The New Jersey Commission on State Tax Policy urged today that the deficit-ridden commuter railroads be relieved of paying taxes on their big stations and other passenger facilities in the northern part of the state.
WESTBURY, L.I., Jan. 6 A well-chilled crowd of 11,653 the smallest at Roosevelt Raceway in almost four years proved one important thing tonight: Even horseplayers know when to come in from the cold.

ALBANY, Jan. 6 Assemblyman Louis F. DeSalvio, Manhattan Democrat who has served 25 years in the Legislature, presided today over a public hearing on a nonpartisan reapportionment plan that would ruin his chances for re-election.

WARSAW, Jan. 6 (Reuters) The Roman Catholic Primate of Poland, Stefan Cardinal Wyszynski, hinted tonight that Pope Paul VI would visit Poland in May, during the celebration of her 1,000th year of Christianity.
LONDON, Jan. 6 (Reuters) The most comprehensive retrospective of Pierre Bonnard's painting ever shown opened here today. The major artistic event was marred by an "act of deliberate vandalism."
DETROIT, Jan. 6 (AP) The nation's passenger car manufacturers will turn out about 195,694 units in the first week of the new year, Automotive News said today.
NEW HAVEN, Jan. 6 An 18.8-mile stretch of superhighway was opened here today completing a 58-mile-long north-south road that runs from New Haven to the Massachusetts border.
TRENTON, Jan. 6 The Appellate Division of the New Jersey Superior Court has stopped writing opinions for at least six months in an attempt to clean up a backlog of more than 1,000 pending cases.

Rudolph Guenther, a founder of one of the first agencies to specialize in soliciting advertising from banks, brokerage houses and other investment organizations, died yesterday at the Harkness Pavilion of Columbian-Presbyterian Medical Center. He was 94 years old and lived at 1120 Fifth Avenue.
SALINA, Kan., Jan. 6 (AP) The Rev. William Davidson of Jamestown, N. D., became the sixth Bishop of the Western Kansas Missionary District of the Episcopal Church today.
ALBANY, Jan. 6 Several former legislators have turned up on the state payroll again, including Harry Kraf, the former Bronx Senator who was defeated lest September in th Democratic primary.
GREENWICH, Conn., Jan. 6 "I don't care so much what the papers write about me my constituents can't read but damn it, they can see pictures."
One-third fewer larcenies have been reported in the Times Square area, during the transit strike than in the same period last year.
MEMBERS of the French nobility who survived the terrors of the Revolution used to look back upon the Old Regime as a lost Arcadia.

Roger Maris, the man who broke Babe Ruth's home run record in 1961 and who started only 40 games last season because of a wrist injury that required surgery, signed his 1966 contract with the New York Yankees yesterday.
The Traffic Department has its problems.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 When Bill Moyers took over as White House press secretary, he had a single aim. This was to establish confidence in the integrity of the public and private statements made in the name of the President.

Dr. Arthur Freeborn Chace, president of the New York Academy of Medicine from 1942 to 1944, died at his country house in Southport, Conn., yesterday. He resided at 200 East 66th Street, New York, and was 86 years old.

HOLYWOOD, Jan. 6 The movie studios here are busily mobilizing to take advantage of a major opportunity for a sharp increase in picture production. However, some important filmmakers here wonder whether seizing the apparent opportunity may not in the end damage the industry.
WHITE PLAINS, Jan. 6 The apportionment of the Westchester County Board of Supervisors was declared unconstitutional today by State Supreme Court Justice Gerald Nolan.

Theodore C. Sorensen and David L. Wolper Productions will make a 90-minute television documentary based on Mr. Sorensen's book, "Kennedy." The author, who was special counsel and speech writer for President Kennedy, will prepare the film script.
LONDON, Jan. 6 Britain's public telephone service is threatened with serious disruptions by vandals. Last year more than half the country's 75,000 pay phones were damaged by them.
In one of the most far-reaching steps taken for the advancement of American oarsmanship, the National Rowing Foundation has been organized.
ALBANY, Jan. 6 The State Senate became a classroom today, as freshmen lawmakers sat down with a few old-timers to get some lessons on how the Legislature operates.

THE excitement of theater may often be felt by an audience, but how it is achieved is infrequently shown to the public. Last night the constantly imaginative Channel 13 invited its viewers to attend a preparation of the balcony scene from "Romeo and Juliet," and the rewards were entrancing.
The Cauldwell-Wingate Company, general contractors, has named Dominick Luciani as senior vice president, Abraham Scolnick as vice president and Albert J. Fegan as treasurer and controller.
Twenty Jersey bulls and 10 heifers will clatter aboard a freighter at 8 A.M. today to embark on a 35-day voyage to Manila.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 (UPI) The Labor Department announced today that on-the-job training program for 650 residents of the riot-torn Watts neighborhood in Los Angeles would be started.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 (UPI) Five top officials of the United States Embassy in Saigon will hold four days of talks with Administration officials at an undisclosed place "in the Washington area" starting Saturday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 Federal District Judge Stephen S. Chandler of Oklahoma, who was stripped of his judicial authority last week by the circuit's appeals judges, asked the Supreme Court today to reverse the action.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 State Department sources said tonight that the situation in the Dominican Republic was very tense but that the United States had had no reports of violence.

The indictment of Robert G. Baker, former secretary to the Senate Democrats, moves his case out of political controversy and into the courts, where it belongs. The accusations of illegal action against him can now be tested impartially on the basis of the facts and the law.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 (UPI) Indications mounted today that President Johnson will seek Congressional authority to sell an additional 200,000 tons of copper from Federal stockpiles in a bid to keep prices down.

The engagement of Miss Helen Ybanez, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Marciano Ybanez of Cebu City in the Philippines, to Richard P. Kluck has been announced here. Mr. Kluck is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Kluck of Rosholt, Wis. They plan a June wedding.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 Official Washington pondered today the possibility that the trial of Robert G. Baker might lift the curtain on the shadowy world of campaign contributions and big-money lobbying.
Devoe Reynolds Company, Inc., said yesterday it had filed a trade-secret suit against Arthus S. Burns Jr. and H.C.I. Coatings and Chemicals Corporation of Los Angeles.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 (AP) The State Department, denying charges that Soviet territory was being violated, said today that two United States naval vessels had been on a "routine voyage in international waters" in the Black Sea.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 6 George R. Packard, an insurance executive and former president of Bryn Mawr Hospital, died yesterday at the hospital. He was 61 years old and lived in Villanova.
"Attention, men on phones," the metallic voice echoed, "there has been a rumor that the Staten Island ferry is on strike; that is not true."

The election of three vice presidents of the company and a realignment of top management in the chemicals, foods and industrial products divisions or subsidiaries of Armour Co., Chicago, were announced yesterday by William Wood Prince, chairman, and Edward J. McAdams, president.

The New York Mets asked waivers yesterday on Gary Kroll, a right-handed pitcher, and sent him to the Houston Astros' Oklahoma City farm club in the Pacific Coast League for cash and a minor league player to be named later.
The price of black-and-white television sets appears to be headed upward.
The wholesale commodity price index continued its advance on Wednesday, rising to 111.2 from 110.7 on Tuesday.

The accommodation on prices reached between the steel industry and the Johnson Administration seems a perfect compromise. The United States Steel Corporation, as de facto leader of the industry, demonstrated that private management can find a way to make selective price changes without fear of Government interference or reprisal. Speaking for the White ...
The Ford Foundation announced yesterday a $10-million, five-year grant to one of its most innovation-minded subsidiaries, the Educational Facilities Laboratories.

In a move to find a wider public for their works, New York's avant-garde, or as they call themselves "underground," filmmakers have established their first midtown Manhattan showcase. Appropriately, if coincidentally, it is underground.
BUFFALO, Jan. 6 (AP) Joel Collier, a defensive specialist, was appointed head coach of the American Football League champion Buffalo Bills today, succeeding Lou Saban, his boss the last nine years.

Maneuvers just getting under way on the French left will go far toward determining France's political direction after Charles de Gaulle. The first target of these moves is not the Presidency but the 1967 parliamentary elections, and the Socialist party occupies a pivot position.

The salamis were taken down for the last time early yesterday morning at the Gaiety Delicatessen on West 46th Street. It was closing for the 43-year-old restaurant that has been a favorite of show people and workers in the Broadway area.
MIAMI, Jan. 6 (AP) A cruise schooner with 35 passengers got stuck on a Bahamas reef today. Coast Guard helicopters and civilian yachts ferried the passengers and crew 15 miles to Bimini.
PARIS, Jan. 6 Dahomey's Foreign Minister, Emile Derlin Zinsou, arrived tonight to improve relations with President de Gaulle in the wake of the two-week-old army takeover in his homeland.

NEWTOWN. Conn., Jan. 6 Mr. and Mrs. Robert Otto Muller of Newtown and Nantucket, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ingeborg Frederica Muller, to Kenneth Rolf Aalto, son of Mr. and Mrs. Johan August Aalto of Alexandria, Va.

PARIS, Jan. 6 Jean Lurcat, the French artist who was widely credited with starting the renaissance of tapestry after World War II, died today in a hotel in Saint-Paul-de-Vence in southern France at the age of 73. He suffered a stroke last night.
Budget requests submitted so far by city departments for 1966-67 point to a $816-million rise in "bare minimum" operating expenses if all the requests are granted.

CAMDEN, N. J., Jan. 6 Superior Court Judge W. Orvyl Schalick denied today a defense request for a change of venue for the trial of three men in the murder of a millionaire builder, Frank Adamucci, at his Rickshaw Inn last Aug. 27. The way is now cleared for the opening of the trial in Camden County on Jan. 17.

Sales of new automobiles in the year just ended set a record of more than 9-million cars. Final figures indicating that the previous mark was topped came from Detroit yesterday. These are subject to revision. Buyers in this country took possession of 9,298,538 cars, including 550,000 imports.
A plea made by the Norfolk Western and the Chesapeake Ohio railways designed to expedite their planned merger brought a chorus of protests yesterday.

The Beacon Theater, the 2,300-seat movie house on Broadway and 74th Street, will present legitimate attractions and films at an admission scale of $1.25 and $1.75, starting Jan. 15. The stage offering will be "Bagels and Yox." The movie has not been selected.

PARIS, Jan. 6 Mrs. Leon Cotnareanu, former publisher of Le Figaro and the co-founder with her first husband, Francois Coty, of the international perfume business, died in Paris yesterday after a long illness.

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 6--Gemini 8, the next American spacecraft scheduled to be lofted into orbit, passed its final factory test today and was turned over to the space agency by the McDonnell Aircraft Company.

The New York Telephone Company reported yesterday gains in gross revenues for the 11 months ended Nov. 30 and for November. Net income for the first 11 months also showed gains, but net income for November fell slightly behind the year-ago level.

THE uncommonly interesting program of the New York Philharmonic last night contained but two works Elgar's Second Symphony and Beethoven's "Emperor" Concerto. The Elgar was interesting because it is a novelty; the Beethoven because it received so spectacular a performance at the hands of Arturo Benedetti Michelangeli and the orchestra conducted by William Steinberg.

The nine-story DePinna Building on the southwest corner of Fifth Avenue and 52d Street, in which the DePinna, apparel specialty store has its quarters, has been sold to a group including Jerome, Henry and Myron Minskoff, office and apartmenthouse builders here.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 (AP) The Social Security Administration announced today a new proof-of-age policy to speed the handling of Medicare and cash benefit applications.

HINDELANG, Germany (UPI) Willy Favre of Switzerland had to cover the tricky giant slalom slope twice today before clinching victory in the international Silver Tree ski meet on Mount Iseler. The electric timer failed on the first run.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 Intercity truck tonnage and carloadings of rail freight for the week ended Jan. 1 showed a substantial increase over the levels of the corresponding week of last year, it was announced today.

Michael J. Quill was resting comfortably in Bellevue Hos- pital last night, but was still in serious condition after an afternoon marked by "exaggerated" reports that he had suffered serious reverses and complications.

The citywide transit crisis is causing "staggering" time and money losses in the trucking of export and import shipments, a spokesman for the Empire State Highway Transportation Association said yesterday.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Jan. 6 Ben Jack Cage, a convicted embezzeler who jumped bail in Texas, has been released by the Brazilian police after 48 hours under arrest.
President Johnson, acting at the request of Mayor Lindsay, sent Secretary of Labor W. Willard Wirtz here last night to assist in trying to settle the crippling transit strike.

A couple in Amherst, Mass., sent $15 to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund "in remembrance of the Prince of Peace." A girl of 10, Laurie Lieberman, sent "my undeserved Hanukkah money" $3 for use by the Child Adoption Service because she wants "all children to have a family which they can live with."
Miss Eve Lorraine Imberman and Arthur Charles Cohen plan to marry in March.
ROME, Jan. 6 Pope Paul VI called upon the faithful today to renew their prayers for peace.

ATHENS, Jan. 6 Tension was building up in Greek-Soviet relations tonight after it became known that a Russian physics, professor who disappeared from his ship here three weeks ago was in United States hands.
While it still leads the nation in the number of business establishments, New York State is fast losing ground to California.
Mayor Lindsay is getting a new car to replace the battered 1962 Cadillac limousine he inherited from Mayor Wagner.

WANTAGH, L.I., Jan. 6 Mr. and Mrs. James P. Griffin have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Lynne Grace Griffin, to William Henry Schroder 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Henry Schroder of Atlanta.

PRINCETON, N. J., Jan. 6 The Rev. Arthur M. Byers Jr. and Mrs. Byers have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth Jean Byers, to Theodore Heywood Scott, son of the Rev. Francis H. Scott and Mrs. Scott of Canonsburg, Pa. An April 16 wedding is planned.

Automobile travel ground through what Traffic Commissioner Henry A. Barnes called "the longest rush hour in the city's history" yesterday. The crawl lasted for six and a half hours, starting at 4:45 A.M. And later a homegoing crush built up as early as 3:15 P.M., and cars inched on until 6:45 P.M. for what Deputy Commissioner Theodore Karagheuzoff described as "the worst evening in Manhattan" in the six days of the transit strike.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 A House subcommittee investigating the Ku Klux Klan recommended today that Imperial Wizard Robert M. Shelton and six other leaders in the the United Klans of America, Inc., be cited for contempt of Congress.
Two of former Mayor Robert F. Wagner's top aides were occupying new positions yesterday, outside of government.
PARIS, Jan. 6 The stock of Machines Bull, the big electronics holding company, has been one of the most active in a broad New Year's spurt on the Paris stock exchange.
PORTLAND, Ore., Jan. 6 (UPI) Another driving rainstorm from the Pacific moved toward Oregon today while moderate temperatures in northern California began melting fresh snow in the mountains.
ATLANTA, Jan. 6 The Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee charged today that the United States Government was following a murderous policy of aggression in Vietnam.
The transit strike is costing the city government almost $6million a day in tax losses and in overtime pay, Roy M. Goodman, Director of Finance, said yesterday.
Clairol's Color Carousel from the World's Fair will take to the road in March in two huge van trucks to make 10day stands in 18 major cities across the country.
MUTTONTOWN, L. I., Jan. 6 (UPI) A horse drowned in a swimming pool here early today.

TASHKENT, U.S.S.R., Jan. 6 Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin of the Soviet Union stepped into the middle of the Indian-Pakistani talks today in an attempt to break an apparent deadlock over Kashmir's place on the agenda.
New Yorkers showed a staggering indifference yesterday to Mayor Lindsay's proposed traffic quadrants, and City Hall itself appeared to be more sinning than sinned against.

WEST ORANGE, N. J. Jan. 6 Dr. Nathan Schaffer, a specialist in allergy and mycology, died today at St. Barnabas Hospital, Livingston. He was taken there after suffering a heart attack at home at Crestridge Apartments, Mount Pleasant Avenue here. He was 60 years old.
New York University's basketball team, which had suffered two tough defeats in the recent Holiday Festival, began the new year on the right note last night in Madison Square Garden.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 The Government is searching for a "more systematic way" of limiting key price increases than public showdowns, such as the one this week with the steel industry.

Random House, Inc., and the Radio Corporation of America confirmed yesterday that they were holding talks on a possible merger. However, each emphasized that they were also talking to other companies.
The British pound strengthened in fairly busy trading on foreign-exchange markets here yesterday. The currency closed at $2.8044, up 9 points from Wednesday.

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 6 Mr. and Mrs. Frank E. Pelton Jr. have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Pamela Culver Pelton, to Peter Scott Plumb, son of Mr. and Mrs. David S. Plumb of St. Louis and Edgartown, Mass. They plan a June wedding.

PERTH, Australia, Jan. 6 (UPI) Arthur Ashe of Richmond and Tom Okker of the Netherlands advanced to the semi-finals of the Western Australia tennis championship today with victories over two American opponents.

HE CAME bounding jauntily up the steps of the hotel in Green Bay the other day, his figure still tall and trim at a hard-packed 195 pounds and with that devilmay-care look still in his eyes. Suddenly the Packer-Brown game for the championship of the National Football League became official. Johnny Blood had arrived.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 Republicans and liberal Democrats ran up battle flags today for an election year issue the campaign against poverty.

Loud boos from students at St. John's University greeted a decision of their Student Council last night not to boycott classes Monday or to hold a protest teach-in on the issue of academic freedom. Some defiantly made plans for their own boycott.
The admission as general partners of J. Peter Thompson and James D. Casey Jr. was announced here yesterday by Paine, Webber, Jackson and Curtis, members of the New York Stock Exchange.
The admission as general partners of J. Peter Thompson and James D. Casey Jr. was announced here yesterday by Paine, Webber, Jackson and Curtis, members of the New York Stock Exchange.
JENSEN BEACH, Fla., Jan. 6 Dr. Paul J. Tomlinson, assistant clinical director at New York's Creedmoor State Hospital, died here Monday while on vacation. He was 55 years old.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 6 (AP) The Greenfield Real Estate Investment Trust of Philadelphia said today it had completed its $12-million purchase of the 40-acre Northside shopping center in Miami.
NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 6 The Roman Catholic Church consecrated today a Negro bishop, the first in the United States in this century.

The election of Hugh Cullman as executive vice president for operations was announced here yesterday by Philip Morris, Inc. Mr. Cullman, 42 years old, joined the company in 1954. He was named treasurer and then vice president and assistant chief of operations in 1960. He has served since 1964 as executive vice president of Philip Morris International.

Mayor Lindsay, who has been standing terribly alone in his efforts to end New York's paralyzing transit strike, has now got top-level help from Washington. President Johnson's decision to send Secretary of Labor Wirtz here, in response to a Lindsay plea, is a recognition that the nation's welfare is directly affected by the illegal tie-up of subways and buses in this largest of American cities.

LERWICK, Shetland Islands, Jan. 6 (AP) An international air and sea search spread over the North Atlantic today after a Soviet trawler sank with 24 men aboard. Within hours all but one member of the crew had been picked up, according to radio messages from the scene.

THE ski-jumping season, unable to open last Sun- day at upstate Rosendale because of unseasonably warm weather, seems virtually certain to make its debut tomorrow afternoon since cold weather is forecast.

JACKSON, Miss., Jan. 6 Federal Bureau of Investigation sources said today that more than 20 members of the Mississippi's White Knights of the Ku Klux Klan had been subpoenaed to appear before the House un-American Activities Committee beginning Monday.
WEST FRANKFORT, Ill., Jan. 6 (UPI) More than 1,100 miners went on strike today against three southern Illinois coal mines in a dispute involving safety regulations and pay for mine examiners.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 Colin F. Stam, Congress's principal staff expert on tax legislation for 27 years, died early today at Suburban Hospital, Bethesda, Md. He was 69 years old and lived in Chevy Chase, Md., a Washington suburb.

GERMISTON, South Africa, Jan. 6 (Reuters) South Africa's strict laws on segregation in sports were smashed today by a racially mixed crowd of 1,500 that followed the national hero, Gary Player, during the opening round of the Professional Golfers' Association tournament here.
HOUSTON, Jan. 6 (AP) Six women applied unsuccessfully to become astronauts next spring, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration said today. They did not meet minimum requirements.

The International P.E.N. Congress and the International Theater Institute have received grants of $75,000 and $90,000, respectively, from the Ford Foundation. The money will be used to defray basic costs for conventions.
LONDON, Jan. 6 Prime Minister Wilson decided today to attend next week's British Commonwealth conference in Lagos, Nigeria, on the subject of Rhodesia.

PARIS President Johnson has recently filled the skies of five continents with distinguished special envoys on a massive Vietnam peace offensive. The most distinguished, far-flying and best known of these is Averell Harriman, old warhorse of United States public service.
The Mobil Oil Company, Inc., has decided to make a major shift in its advertising approach, and to accomplish this it is pulling its entire account out of Ted Bates Co., Inc.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 6 President Abdel Salam Arif of Iraq warned today that his army stood ready to crush any attempt at usurpation of Iraqi territory.
TUSKEGEE, Ala., Jan. 6 (AP) City officials met with Federal negotiators in search of a solution to Tuskegee's newly erupted racial problems today after another student street march was held.
The transit strike has given the nation's monetary authorities a special set of headaches.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 American officials believe that Israel has entered into a secret contract to purchase a large number of medium-range ballistic missiles being developed by France.
Transit strikes somehow seem to mean hard times for Fifth Avenue Coach, Inc.

SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, Friday, Jan. 7 The Dominican armed forces rebelled last night against an order by Provisional President Hector Garcia-Godoy assigning their leaders to posts outside the country.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 6 An impressive exhibition of primitive art, currently installed at the University of California, Los Angeles, is giving the public here its first glimpse of the extraordinary gift recently given to the university by the Wellcome Trust of London.
The striking Transport Workers Union originally asked for an over-all money package that the Transit Authority estimated would cost $680-million over a two-year period.

TORONTO, Jan. 6 The Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce, Canada's second largest bank, with assets of $6.2-billion, confirmed today reports that it had offered to buy the Northern California National Bank of San Mateo, near San Francisco.

One of the first commodity exchanges to report its figures for 1965, the Chicago Mercantile Exchange said recently that it had the best year in its 46-year history, with 889,026 contracts traded, covering about $5-billion of commodities. That compared with only 249,554 contracts handled in 1964.

BONN, Jan. 6 The state of North Rhine-Westphalia announced today that 18 former members of a Gestapo force that occupied the area of Stanislav, in East Galicia, during World War II would be tried in mid-April on charges of mass murder of Jews.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 7 (UPI) Accuracy at the foul line proved to be the difference tonight as the Los Angeles Lakers ended Philadelphia's spell over them with a 126-120 victory over the 76ers in a National Basketball Association game.
Negro legislators and civil rights leaders protested yesterday that a newly proposed reapportionment plan would substantially reduce New York City Negroes' representation in the Legislature.
The Rev. James V. 'O'Neill, chaplain at the House of Calvary Hospital, 1600 Macombs Road, the Bronx, since 1959, died Wednesday in Misericordia Hospital, the Bronx. He was 72 years old.

ROME, Jan. 7 The Italian movie idol Marcello Mastroianni brought his prototype of the twenties, Rudolph Valentino, back to the stage last night in a big, lavish musical comedy but failed, in the opinion of most viewers, to bring him back to life.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 (AP) Robert M. Shelton, Imperial Wizard of the United Klans of America, said today that he was not in contempt of Congress or the House Committee on UnAmerican Activities, but of "Martini-bibbing, character-assassinating and truth-twisting individuals on the staff."
CHICAGO, San. 7 The Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. announced today "a full-scale assault" against slum conditions in Chicago.
BOSTON, Jan. 7 (UPI) Sam Mele, the manager of the American League champion Minnesota Twins, was hospitalized today for treatment of a phlebitis condition in his legs.
SAIGON, Jan. 5 South Vietnam is an all but coinless country.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 (AP) Following is the text of the concluding section of a report to the Senate Foreign Relations Committee by Senator Mike Mansfiled and four other Senators, who recently visited South Vietnam, and other countries:

World-Wide (Shipping), Ltd., one of the fastest growing major fleets in the world, will sign a contract with Ishikawajima-Harima Heavy Industries Co., Ltd., in Japan for the construction of three 35,000-ton bulk carriers.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 Louis Eisenstein, a Washington lawyer and expert on Federal taxation, died Wednesday after a short illness. He was 50 years old.
JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Jan. 7 (AP) The proposed merger of the Atlantic Coast Line and Seaboard Air Line railroads will go back before a three-judge Federal court here Feb. 24.
WITH the signing this week of Steve Bowman, Alabama's "small" 200-pound fullback, the New York Giants for the second straight year succeeded in nailing down their college draft choices.

FOLEY, Ala., Jan 7 (AP) Vice Adm. Frank D. Wagner, who played a major role in Pacific aerial fighting after Pearl Harbor, was killed yesterday when his car and a truck collided on U.S. 98 at a Foley intersection. He was 72 years old.

The president of the Union of Orthodox Jewish Congregations of America sharply criticized yesterday "lavish floral displays and unholy musical extravaganzas" that violate the sanctity of funeral ceremonies.
A decision to permit transAtlantic steamship passengers to pay for bookings and shipboard expenses through one of the major American credit card establishments may be made in March.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 Secretary of Labor W. Willard Wirtz said today that the main hope of settling the New York transit strike lay in unhindered bargaining. He added that the Federal Government had no plans to intervene as long as the talks were progressing.

Channel 13 announced yesterday that it will postpone its presentation of "Neighbors," Arkaday Leokum's one-act play about race relations, which had been scheduled for Monday at 9 P.M. No other date has been set.

ARMENTA ADAMS, an excellent and notably musi cal pianist who made her New York debut in 1960 and gave a second recital in Town Hall in 1961, was presented in the Young Artists Series in Rogers Auditorium at the Metropolitan Museum last night.
PATERSON, N. J., Jan. 7 A Passaic County grand jury has called for "a thorough and complete investigation" of all state purchases of land under its Green Acres program.
TUSKEGEE, Ala., Jan. 7 (AP) A Tuskegee Negro city official said today that he was fearful renewed racial demonstrations might bring new bloodshed in the wake of the killing of a Negro student.

SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, Jan. 7 The threeman committee representing the Organization of American States and its 8,000-man InterAmerican Peace Force issued a stern warning today to the military forces that began a mutiny yesterday against the Provisional Government.

SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Jan. 7 To cushion the economic disaster that Rhodesia's prolonged drought has brought to the country's farmers, the Government is launching a vast cattle-purchase program in the stricken areas.

THE dynamic personality of Sammy Davis never had a chance to emerge last night in the spiritless and static debut of his own program over the network of the National Broadcasting Company. How in the world it owuld be possible to throttle such vitality, is hard to conceive, but the opening hour was totally lackluster and a keen disappointment.
MOBILE, Ala., Jan. 7 (UPI) Some of the wildest offense in Senior Bowl history may be generated tomorrow when two explosive teams meet in the 17th annual All-Star game.

MEDIA, Pa., Jan. 7 (AP) A Negro couple, whose move into a previously all-white neighborhood in nearby Folcroft in 1963 set off a series of race riots, filed a damage suit today against 21 persons, mostly neighbors.
NEWARK, Jan. 7 The Ku Klux Klan has placed applications for membership on windshields of 800 autos in predominantly white residential areas here, Police Director Dominick Spina said today.
WHITE PLAINS, Jan. 7 Westchester County is battling with the Post Office Department over what it considers a threat to its standing as the birthplace of the American circus.

VILA, New Hebrides, Jan. 4 Britain and France, joint rulers of the Condominium of the New Hebrides, are stepping up their efforts to develop this remote South Pacific archipelago bordering the Coral Sea.
Mrs. Elizabeth Stauffer Swaine, widow of Robert T. Swaine, a senior partner in the law firm of Cravath, Swaine Moore, died yesterday in her home at 1 Sutton Place South.
Police Commissioner Vincent L. Broderick rushed about the city by patrol car and helicopter yesterday, trying to clear up traffic jams while his own professional future remained far from clear.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 The Johnson Administration sought today to allay concern about growing manpower shortages as it reported that the nation's unemployment rate sank to 4.1 per cent last month.
A California psychologist has found evidence that the way parents treat their children may have a lot to do with their chances of rising to eminence.

Three operators of a mailorder clothing business were arrested here yesterday in connection with the fraudulent misuse of a Pitney-Bowes postage meter that may have cost the Government as much as $2million over a two-year period.
MINEOLA, L.I., Jan. 7 State Senator Edward Speno of Nassau County urged today that the Metropolitan Commuter Transportation Authority take over the New York City transit system.

OSSINING, N. Y., Jan. 7 More than 100 men defected today from an inmate's strike at Sing Sing Prison. But 80 per cent of the prison population still refused to go to their jobs, continuing a non-violent work stoppage that began last Monday.

DESIGNERS and buyers from California, Massachusetts, Texas and Illinois are advancing on New York, eager to get here in time for Corset and Brassiere Week, which begins officially Monday. One of the first to arrive from the Far West is Olga, the Polish-born designer manufacturer whose aim in life is to make the most out of the least, where under pinnings are concerned at any rate.

Political observers think Mayor Lindsay's call for White House help in the transit strike was useful in dramatizing the idea that the Mayor is searching hard for a solution, wherever it may be found. But most of them have believed all along that, realistically, the key to the crisis is much less likely to be ...
WESTBURY, L.I., Jan. 7 A crowd of 20,110 made it to Roosevelt Raceway tonight and in unfathomable ways known only to the horseplayers made Black Heath the favorite in the second race.
New York's leading retailers, troubled by the poorest business in many years, are anxiously watching the clock as negotiations limp along in the city's transit stoppage.

COLOMBO, Ceylon, Jan. 7 Prime Minister Dudley Senanayake in a broadcast tonight warned the nation against attempts by Marxist and Marxistaligned opposition parties to create unrest and civil strife on communal lines.
Transportation stocks caught the market spotlight yesterday.

SAN FRANCISCO Jan. 8 (UPI) A former Turkish Army nurse who received the Bronze Star from the United States for her work in an Army hospital in Tokyo during the Korean war is fighting to remain in this country.
MIAMI, Jan. 8 Social Song survived a foul claim by the favored Gary G. today in winning the $27,800 Dade Metropolitan Handicap at Tropical Park.

For the duration of the transit strike and until the resumption of transportation facilities, the New York Public Library's Central Building on Fifth Avenue will be open from 11 A.M. to 6 P.M., Monday through Saturday. Most branch libraries will be open from 10 A.M. to 5 P.M., Monday through Friday.

Dr. Vincent E. Smith, director of the Philosophy of Science Center at St. John's University, said yesterday he would return to teaching at the struck university tomorrow, but would resign his position in June.

EAST ORANGE, N.J., Jan. 8 Mr. and Mrs. Barney M. Larkey have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Lois Ann Larkey, to Ronald Edward Wiss, son of Mr. and Mrs. Aaron Wiss of South Orange. A June wedding is planned.

The longshoreman, whose public image still has some wrinkles, is emerging as an international goodwill ambassador, praised by the State Department and by the heads of foreign governments whose port congestion is being relieved by the cargo-handling experts.

FAIR LAWN, N.J., Jan. 8 Mr. and Mrs. John J. McFadden Jr. have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Patricia Anne McFadden, to Robert W. Dombal. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Vaclow L. Dombal of Garfield.
Mayor Lindsay made a hurried tour yesterday of three of the city's areas hurt most by the transit strike.

THE Brooklyn Botanic Garden has announced a three-session course on orchids to be given Mondays at 7 P.M., starting Jan. 17. In addition to tips on culture there will be greenhouse work and a field trip on Feb. 5 to a commercial orchid grower. Dr. Carl Withner is the instructor; fee is $12 for non-members, $8 for botanic garden members.

NEW HYDE PARK, L. I., Jan. 8 The engagement of Miss Sherry Zuckman to Richard Skolnik, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Skolnik of Long Beach, has been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. David Zuckman.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 The scene of the next act in the turbulent drama of the Storm King Mountain power plant will be decided next week.
Dr. Seward Erdman, a surgeon who practiced here for 56 years, died Thursday in his home at 70 East 96th Street. His age was 89.
A black-tie reception and preview of "Three Hundred Years of New York City Families" will be held Wednesday at the Wildenstein Galleries, 19 East 64th Street.

At 1 P.M. yesterday, the car radio voice said the temperature was 29 degrees and falling. A gusty wind out of the West swept over the frigid waters of Spuyten Duyvil and blew icy blasts across Columbia University's Baker Field.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Jan. 8 (UPI) Michigan reopened defense of its Big Ten basketball title successfully today with an 83-78 victory over Ohio State. It was Michigan's first victory here in 19 year's.
The New York Jets announced yesterday that Coach Webb Ewbank had signed an all American center, Paul Crane of Alabama, as a free agent.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Jan. 8 Ambassador Ralph A. Dungan of the United States, a freshman diplomat inclined to plain talk, stands accused by Chilean conservatives of having elbowed into the internal affairs of this controversy-wracked country.

Two sales will be held at the Parke-Bernet Galleries this week, offering in one, modern paintings, drawings and sculpture and in the other, English and French furniture, old porcelains and other decorations.

The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People said yesterday that it could not go along with a statement opposing United States involvement in Vietnam and encouraging civil rights workers to seek an alternative to the draft.

PRETORIA, South Africa, Jan. 8 R.R. of Chicago writes: "Here in the United States we now face an almost naked dictatorship largely imposed in the name of 'civil rights.' We are very close to open and declared race war with, of course, all the powers of the Federal Government mobilized against the whites."

New York's transit strike, cutting deeply into sales of the city's retail stores, will affect retailers throughout the nation in another way. The strike cut down garment production in New York's wholesale markets, and also acted as a deterrent to buyers who had planned to come to the market.

TOKYO, Jan, 8 Living in an age of television and jet transport, few Japanese believe nowadays that a girl born in the year of the fire horse will be of so violent a nature as to drive her husband to death.

GOOD landscape architectural design in recent years has placed increased emphasis on the creation of useful outdoor spaces rather than landscape "pictures." Increasing land values make it incumbent on the designer to make every inch of space contribute its full share to daily life. Merely pretty areas are an extravagance the homeowner can no longer afford.
The Federal Maritime Commision plans to initiate several legislative measures designed to aid United States domestic and foreign waterborne trade and to streamline the agency's regulatory functions.

SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, Jan. 8 Troops of the Inter-American Peace Force recovered the Government radiotelevision station and the national telecommunications center today. There was no resistance.
The nation has entered 1966 on a high level of activity, according to the latest survey of members of the National Association of Purchasing Agents. The report was issued over the weekend.
LOS ANGELES, Jan. 8 An emotional religious, movement that began in Spain in 1949 is in the midst of a strong, controversial and haphazard growth within the Roman Catholic Church.

ANTHONY BURGES has achieved prominence as a novel ist best known, I suppose, for "A Clockwork Orange." With "Re Joyce," he assumes the role of a literateur leading a peasant revolt. "My book," he writes in the Foreword, "does not pretend to scholarship, only to a desire to help the average reader who wants to know Joyce's work but has been scared off by the professors.

PABLO CASALS has had a long and fruitful association with the music of J.S. Bach. Groves Dictionary of Music and Musicians records that when Casals played Bach's Suite in C for unaccompanied cello in 1909 in London, he made the solo suites "take their true place in the repertory of living music," taking them from their academic storage.

A 6-month-old buff colored guppy, who never had been in a show ring before, gained one of the more pleasant plums available to cocker spaniels when he won the futurity stake that was yesterday's main business at the American Spaniel Clubs national speciality.

VILA, New Hebrides, Jan. 4 Whatever the tensions that beset French-British relations elsewhere, officials of the two powers continue to collaborate and compete with reasonable amity and effectiveness in joint rule of the New Hebrides.
OTTAWA, Jan. 8 (AP) The Royal Canadian Mounted Police, whose slogan is, "the Mounties always get their man," plan a $15-million expansion program to put even more pressure on criminals.
CRESSKILL, N.J., Jan. 8 Miss Alice Harriet Halperin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Halperin of Ridgefield, was married this evening to Ira Kent. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Kent of Newark.
LOS ANGELES, Jan. 8 Arnold Palmer was an amazing golfer again today as he equaled the tournament record with a 62 in the Los Angeles open after playing the back nine in 29 strokes.

PEKING Foreigners who are sick here usually go to the Peking Union Medical College, a gray structure with a curved tile front, built with funds received from the Rockefeller Foundation during the heyday of United States missionary and philanthropic activity in China.

OBERSTAUFEN, Germany, Jan. 8 (AP) Marielle and Christine Goitschel, the sisters who won a gold medal each in the 1964 Olympics, led a French sweep today in the Oberstaufen Cup special slalom, second event of the women's international ski season.

By plane, train and car, they came, One of them, Robert Schultz, a retailer from Terre Haute, Ind., drove 17 hours straight, with his wife, Rona, and two associates, on the 800mile stretch to New York.

MORE than a year ago, I reported on the life of a high-school student named Jennie ("Hard Day's Night of Today's Students," Sept. 27, 1964) and told how, after a long day at school, Jennie still had six hours of homework to do. In contrast, her mother and I, both working women, were free to spend the evening relaxing and chatting together.

A marriage of Eastern customs and Western technology has given rise to a building boom in the Far East, according to H. Adams Ashforth, a realty man who recently returned from a trip to Tokyo, Bangkok and Hong Kong.

PELHAM MANOR, N.Y., Jan. 8 (AP) Fred N. Lowe, director of sales promotion for The New York Journal-American, died of a stroke today at the Lawrence Hospital in Bronxville. He way 54 years old and lived at 1 Brier Lane.

OF all scholars, art historians are perhaps the sharpest-tongued about each other. (A famous one, learning that I had just come from visiting another famous one, inquired: "Do you still have your pock etbook?") The air around Arnold Hauser and his book on mannerism may, or may not, be thick with professional poisoned arrows; but in any case the general reader, who is immune anyway, can afford to disregard them.

GARDENERS always have great expecta tions in January for bright flowers in June and their hearts' desires will surely be filled this year. Seedsmen are introducing scaled-down plants with dwarfer forms and they have made special efforts to achieve good flower color and individual plant vigor.

MOSCOW, Jan. 8 Prof. Staughton Lynd of Yale came here from a private "fact-finding" tour of North Vietnam tonight and criticized the Johnson Administration for "the apparent failure to make direct contact" with the Vietnamese Communists in its offer of peace talks.

CHICAGO, Jan. 8 Cassius Clay said today his next heavyweight boxing title defense would be against Ernie Terrell. He ridiculed the suggestion of a match with Brian London of England and announced formation of a closed-circuit television company with exclusive rights to his fights.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 Miss Susan Elizabeth Shifley, daughter of Rear Adm. Ralph Louis Shifley, U.S.N., and Mrs. Shifley, became the bride this afternoon of Warren Jacob Cox, son of Mr. and Mrs. Oscar Cox of Washington and Kennebunkport, Me.

TEL AVIV, Jan. 8 Israel briefly interrupted her silence about a reported missile deal with France to confirm today a statement in Paris that private French companies have been helping Israeli research institutions in the missile field.

DURING a questions and answers period at a college art conference a few weeks ago, a blossoming freshman in the audience asked a fading professor on the platform just exactly what it had been, over the years, that he had found so rewarding in the study of art history that he had stuck to it for so long.

A few books cause revolutions, but all revolutions cause books. The Dominican Republic's recent strife is no exception. Among current titles is one by Juan Bosch, president of his country for a scant seven months and still a symbol of Dominican democracy.

HEWLETT, L.I. Jan. 8 Mr. and Mrs. Melvin Ellsweig have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Karen Sue Ellsweig, to Andrew F. Meyer. His parents are Dr. and Mrs. David A. Meyer of Woodmere.

MOUNTAINSIDE, N. J., Jan. 8 Miss Beth Ann Greeley, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James J. Greeley of Springfield, was married at noon today to Thomas Patrick Loftus of Mountainside. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Patrick Loftus of Cleveland.

NORWALK, Conn., Jan. 8 The Sixth Taxing District Commission, which administers the Rowayton area, has taken an option on a six-acre tract and buildings for a community center with a new library. The electors will be asked to approve the plan at aspecial meeting Jan. 17.

Clogs are the latest for very fashionable American feet. In Scandinavia, the Netherlands, West Germany, in the Middle East and in the Orient, women have long been aware of the practical value of superthick soles between the feet and hot sand, frozen ground, hard pavement or puddle. Americans will recognize the family resemblance between today's clogs and the platforms and wedges of the nineteen-forties. Backward or forward, shoe fashion moves on.

Sandy Koufax was named yesterday to receive both the Sid Mercer Memorial (player of the year) and the Babe Ruth (World Series star) Awards by the New York chapter of the Baseball Writers' Association.
JACKSON, Miss., Jan. 8 Gov. Paul B. Johnson Jr. won applause this week from the traditionally segregationist State Legislature in his war on nightriders and racial violence.
More than 200 windows were broken yesterday in large apartment buildings at 88 and 91 Central Park West by explosions in two manholes.

CURRENT trends in garden design are as difficult to predict as next year's fashion fads. For every client who insists on a well-de fined entrance court with plenty of parking near an inviting front door there are others who wish to live informally, yearn for rustic gardens and want the automobile as far away as possible.

RICHMOND, Jan. 8 Officials of Richmond Newspapers, Inc. publisher of The Times Dis patch and The News Leader here, announced today the purchase of newspaper, radio and television interests in Tampa, Fla.

THIS is Elizabeth Jane Howard's fourth novel time to ask where one of England's most talented writers is going. Miss Howard has been called "promising" so often the word must make her shudder. She has also been pinned as a "lady novelist" fit companion for such quivering stylists as Rosamond Lehmann.
The over-the-counter market started the new year in a bullish manner last week as most issues advanced in active trading.
Investors have been showing a distinct lack of enthusiasm for blue chips lately, while speculative glamour issues have all but gone through the roof.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 8 Mihajlo Mihajlov, the scholar-publicist who was prosecuted last year for writting critically about the Soviet Union, has won a court decision in his campaign to regain his teaching job in the city of Zadar.
BLANTYRE, Malawi, Jan. 8 (Reuters) Prime Minister H. Kamuzu Banda appointed two new ministers today and announced a general shuffle of his Cabinet.

THE number of holiday visitors in and around Miami Beach was so great that some tour ists who traveled South specifically to see the Orange Bowl parade and football game had to find accommodations 20 miles away.

WESTBURY, L. I., Jan. 8 Their noses pressed against windowpanes, a crowd of 17,471 watched shuddering horses fight 60-mile-an-hour gusts tonight, on the coldest evening in the history of Roosevelt Raceway.
BALTIMORE, Jan. 8 (AP) The Cincinnati Royals handed the Baltimore Bullets a 126-115 National Basketball Association loss tonight.

BARBARA TUCHMAN'S new book, "The Proud Tower," attempts "a portrait of the world before the war, 1890-1914." Recognizing that some limits must be set to so vast a theme, she has confined herself to the United States and Western Europe, and within these bounds has selected eight topics for detailed treatment. These, so she tells us, are meant to concentrate on "society," but in fact range over politics, international diplomacy, culture and art.
TEL AVIV, Jan. 8 Lady Sieff, a founder of the Women's International Zionist Organization and the wife of a noted British businessman, died here today at the age of 75.

SHIRLEY HAZZARD's writing is like some electronic mechanism, enormously intricate in design and function, charged with great power, but so refined by skill that it may be contained in a small case and exhibit a smooth and shapely surface.
Miss Maxine Lowry, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Todd E. Lowry of London, Ohio, was married yesterday to Robert L. Hermann, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leo Hermann of Evansville, Ind.

ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 8 Cupid, under 115 pounds, captured the 28th running of the $61,100 San Carlos Handicap at Santa Anita today as Native Diver faded far back in the field of 12 under his 132-pound impost.

St. John's University, led by Sonny Dove's 29 points and the cool backcourt play of Brian Hill, overcame Villanova's fullcourt press and defeated the Wildcats, 68-63, yesterday in overtime at Alumni Hall in Queens.

WARSAW, Sunday, Jan. 9 The Polish Government accused Stefan Cardinal Wyszynski early today of having harmed Polish national interests while in Rome recently and barred the Roman Catholic Primate from further travel abroad.

FOR a growing number of Americans, "tenting . on the old camp ground" endures main ly in sentiment or songfest. These are the folk who have taken to camping in traveltrailers, pick-up coaches, motorized homes and campingtent trailers, all designed to put the outdoor family a door or a wingflap away from indoor comforts.

LONDON, Jan. 8 Prime Minister Wilson is expected to go to next week's Commonwealth conference on Rhodesia with a carrot and a stick for the rebel government of Prime Minister Ian D. Smith.
CAIRO, Jan. 8 AmericanEgyptian relations began the New Year in a wedding atmosphere that appropriately included something old, something new, something borrowed, something blue.

The first round of what historians may call "the Johnson winter peace offensive of 1965-66" now is over. Washington and Hanoi both have summed up in public their gradually evolving positions which, verbally at least, are now virtually identical on many points.

ARMONK, N. Y., Jan. 8 An audience of 200 persons at a meeting here this week laughed derisively as the speaker read a letter from Mrs. Lyndon B. Johnson expressing hope that highways "can enhance the beauty of our landscape."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 (UPI) A Civil Aeronautics Board examiner ruled this week that all airlines must set a liability limit of $250 on lost, delayed or damaged baggage.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 8 Miss Louise Dorothy Majewski and J. Barry Dunleavy plan to marry in May.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 (UPI) Senator Warren G. Magnuson, criticized the Agricultural Department today for using subsidies to get more people abroad to smoke American cigarettes.
MT. HOPE, N. Y., Jan. 8 The Brae Burn Curling Club rink of West Newton, Mass., defending champion in the 31st Douglas Medal bonspiel, led the way into the semi-finals today at St. Andrew's Golf Club.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 The National Collegiate Athletic Association will be asked to recommend a return to limited substitutions in college football during its 60th annual convention at the Sheraton Park Hotel this week. This is one of the many expected attempts by the N.C.A.A. to help its membership of more than 600 colleges and universities improve their control of intercollegiate athletics.
THE Columbia Broadcasting System announced last week that its television network would add a second night of movies in prime time next fall.
BEIRUT, Lebanon (Comteburo) The Lebanese Cabinet has decided to stop granting licenses for the establishment of new banks in the country with a "view to improving the banking situation."

The work of the Plant Quarantine Division of the United States Department of Agriculture charged with guarding American crops against foreign plant pests took on a new dimension last year outer space.

A total of 244 foreign-flag ships, other than those from Communist countries, have arrived in Cuba since Jan. 1, 1963, when the Maritime Administration began compiling such figures, the agency has announced.

AFTER six hours of recording Chopin mazurkas, Artur Rubinstein was ready to unwind by talking about music. He took a quick sip of Scotch, warned the photog rapher against taking pictures "when I'm making funny faces," and then tore into some of the most sacred of music's conventions with the zest that has made him one of the coveted ornaments of the world's best dinner tables and drawing rooms.

Senator William Howard Flowers Jr. of Georgia and Mrs. Flowers of Merrily Plantation in Thomasville, and of Highlands, N.C., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Daphne Howard Flowers, to Charles Martin Wood 3d. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Wood Jr. of Greenwich, Conn.

SCRANTON, Pa., Jan. 8 (UPI) An airman and a 15year-old boy were killed today when a twin-engine C-119 Flying Boxcar crashed and set fire to three lakeshore cottages 20 miles northeast of here. Another airman was missing.

COLOMBO, Ceylon, Jan. 8 The Government of Prime Minister Dudley Senanayake tonight declared a state of emergency throughout the country in the wake of Marxist-sponsored civil disturbances that broke out in this capital and its suburbs earlier in the day. A curfew from 9 P.M. to 4 A.M. was imposed, along with emergency censorship of the press.

CHATHAM, N. J., Jan. 8 Allen S. Valk, who retired in July as general manager of the marine division of the California Texas Oil Corporation died on Thursday at St. Barnabas Hospital in Livingston. He was 65 years old and lived at 109 Colemen Avenue.

Most apparel and accessories departments have shifted almost entirely to production of of spring merchandise, reports from stores to resident buying offices indicate. However, a considerable amount of winter goods are being reordered.

NEW CANAAN, Conn., Jan. 8 Mrs. Kathrine Gordon Sanger Brinley, author and widow of Daniel Putnam Brinley, a mural artist, died yesterday at a Stamford nursing home. She was 86 years old and lived in the Silvermine section here.

YONKERS, Jan. 8 Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Lewis Hake have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Barbara Joan Hake, to Richard Mayl Herberich, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles George Herberich of Akron, Ohio. A June wedding is planned.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y. Jan. 8 In frigid, blustery weather that caused meet officials to curtail the program, Bernie Dion, a New Hampshire barber, won Class A honors in the 21st annual Torger Tokle Memorial ski-jumping tournament today.

William Jeffrey, soccer coach at Pennsylvania State University for 25 years until his retirement in 1952, died of a heart attack here on Friday. He was in New York to attend the National Collegiate Athletic Association Soccer meetings. His age was 73.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 A Federal-state study group recommended to President Johnson today the first steps to carry out his 1965 command to clean up the Potomac River Valley as a model for the nation.

PENNLYN, Pa., Jan. 8 Mr. and Mrs. Charles E. Ingersoll have announced the engagement at Mrs. Ingersoll's daughter, Miss Vivian Joan Martin, to Charles Albert Hunt. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Albert Baker Hunt of Weston, Mass.

HONOLULU, Jan. 8 (AP) Steve Juday, an all-America quarterback from Michigan State, was selected the game's outstanding back for his performance in guiding the North to a 27-26 triumph over the South All-Stars in last night's 20th Hula Bowl football clash.

The Economist, London: Events suggent, for the first time that the mental climate may be changing. In particular the Russians and the North Vietnamese have to face the fact that the hopes of an early Communist takeover. of the South are receding. The prolongation of the war will cause more harm to the North Vietnamese than to America, and it is between these two that the contests of wills chiefly lies.
West German supermarkets will soon have a new American-grown product on their shelves Family Circle magazine.

SAIGON, Jan. 8 A major effort is under way to build a 72,000-man national police force to try to exterminate the widespread and clandestine Vietcong political organization in the villages and cities of South Vietnam.
RICHMOND, Jan. 8 Virginia high school students held a conference today on the problem of cheating, reported to be widespread in many of the state's secondary schools.

ALBANY, Jan. 8 (AP) The freight tonnage shipped on the State Barge Canal System last year was up 2.4 per cent over 1964.

The taboo against talking of death to the dying may produce feelings of helplessness and isolation far more difficult to bear than the threat of death itself, according to a panel of psychologists and psychiatrists.

SAIGON, Jan. 8 Senator Jacob K. Javits and Representative Ogden R. Reid arrived in South Vietnam today for a sixday visit to study the political and military situation.

Rachel Maddux's "A Walk in the Spring Rain" is the story of "the late Indian summer of Mrs. Roger Meredith, the last flaring of the sparks before the embers die."

Mr. and Mrs. Mortimer Schwartz of Forest Hills, Queens, have announced the engagement of Mrs. Schwartz's daughter, Miss Linda Jane Neidelman, to Robert Jerrold Lawrence, son of Mr. and Mrs. James J. Lawrence of Highland Park, Ill.

The Fluor Corporation has announced it has been commissioned by Texaco, Inc., to produce oil refining equipment. Production will begin the middle of this year, with completion scheduled for early next year.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Jan. 8 -Army ended Yale's 42-meet winning streak in swimming today, holding on for a 48-47 victory at the varsity pool.

Railroad buffs who drive to Florida via U.S. 1, 23 and 301, which unite in pass ing through this town just below the Georgia line, can view a colorful collection of steam locomotives and passenger cars at the Trains of Yesterday Museum. Walt Bellamy had a big game at Madison Square Garden last night, leading the New York Knickerbockers to a 133-127 victory over the Los Angeles Lakers.
Department store sales last week rose from the level of the year-ago week but declined from the total of the preceding week, which included the Christmas holiday.

MONTREAL, Jan. 8 (AP) Jacques Lapierriere started a three-goal Montreal flurry in the second period as the Canadiens trounced the Boston Bruins, 6-0, tonight in a National Hockey League game.

Air-conditioning as a standard feature at no extra cost in single-family houses has been slow catching on in the New York area. But one New Jersey building organization is offering such equipment as a result of its experience in erecting more than 1,000 development homes in the northern part of the state.

SARANAC LAKE, N.Y., Jan. 8 Daniel V. Sullivan, District Attorney of Bronx County from 1955 to 1960, died today in Saranac Lake General Hospital. He was 79 years old and lived at 1 River Crest Road in Riverdale, the Bronx.
NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Jan. 8 Mr. and Mrs. Melvin S. Danciger have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ellen Danciger, to Herbert Buck Brandt Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Brandt.
NEWARK, Jan. 8 The leader of a drive to establish a state sales tax said this week that he was responding to an "extraordinary clamor" from people favoring the proposed levy.

LAST Sunday this column discussed our theater's usual underestimate of the audience's level of interest. As if to substantiate the point, Peter Weiss's provocative, complex "Marat/ Sade," which is note at the Martin Beck in a striking production, is being enthusiastically received.
MILWAUKEE, Jan. 8 Many delegates at a peace meeting here today looked to President Johnson's forthcoming State of the Union message with some suspicion.

Michael J. Quill, head of the Transport Workers Union, showed steady improvement yesterday for the second consecutive day at Bellevue Hospital, where he was admitted on Tuesday after collapsing at the Civil Jail.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., Jan. 8 Mr. and Mrs. George Bertrand Fargis have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Loreto Fargis of Washington, to David George Swanz of Bethesda, Md., son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph William Swanz of Buffalo.

HERE is a powerful, sealed beam lantern that will never run out of batteries. Contain ing its own rechargeable, nickel cadmium battery that never needs replacing, this portable light develops 7,000 candlepower and gives 2 hours of continuous light when fully charged. Completely waterproof, the lantern floats and can even be used underwater.
NEW IPSWICH, N. H., Jan. 8 Miss Gillian Kellogg and Edward R. Miller plan to be married on March 12.
TUSKEGEE, Ala., Jan. 8 About 500 Negroes sat on the sidewalks and blocked the entrances to seven downtown businesses here today after defying a police ban against the demonstration.
NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., Jan. 8 Miss Susan Joan Goldstone and Dr. Robert M. Charm will be married on Feb. 20.

TRENTON, Jan. 8 The incoming Democratic majority in the Senate announced today that it would make good on Gov. Richard J. Hughes's campaign pledge to kill two controversial sources of legislative power Senate blackball of a Governor's appointments and the secret majority-party caucus.
About $280-million in nickels, dimes and tokens clinked into Transit Authority fare boxes last year, but for the first time the fares failed to provide enough cash to meet the payroll.
The striking Transport Workers Union originally asked for an over-all money package that the Transit Authority estimated would cost $680-million over a two-year period.
George Bruns hit on 12 of 17 field-goal attempts and scored 29 points yesterday as Manhattan defeated Wagner, 84-63, in a Metropolitan Basketball Conference contest at the losers' court.

CHAPEL HILL, N.C., Jan. 18 (UPI) Top-ranked Duke, paced by Bob Verga and Jack Marin, got baskets when needed today to stall repeated North Carolina rallies and gain an 88-77 Atlantic Coast Conference victory.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 In the 28 months since the first outlines of Robert G. (Bobby) Baker's gaudy and improbable financial edifice became visible, the heavily beleaguered onetime secretary to the Senate Democratic majority has been directing most of his energies toward keeping his creation from coming unstuck.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 Business support for President Johnson has been "cracked but not shattered" by the President's recent successful attempts to control prices by threats and persuasion.

SHREVEPORT, La., Jan. 8 Mrs. Edward F. Neild Jr. has announced the engagement of her daughter. Miss Helene Files Neild, to Robert H. Heinbockel, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Heinbockel of Manhasset, L.I. An April wedding is planned.

SEATTLE It is more than three years since the closing of Century 21, as Seattle's World's Fair of 1962 was called. Yet today, as the Seattle Center, the 74-acre exposition site continues to thrive as a combination civic, science, culture, convention and visitor center. In fact, during last summer's tourist season, there were days when the former fairground had as many visitors as during the height of the financially successful fair.

MOUNT DORA, Fla. As winter visitors from the North come back to this picturesque little town in central Florida, they are finding an interesting transformation. The downtown area, consisting of seven business blocks, has been restored and now resembles a New England village.

CRANS, Switzerland Although ski lifts fill the sky in Crans and its neighboring village of Montana, one of the most popular pastimes here has nothing to do with skiing. It consists of sitting quietly and looking at Mont Blanc.

Astronaut Frank Borman, hurtling around the world in his space capsule, took time out to try convince Tommy Nobis to sign with the Houston Oilers. The Kansas City Chiefs signed Mike Garrett, immediately starting reports that he had been promised the franchise would be shifted so he could play in Los Angeles.

LONDON, Jan. 8 (Reuters) A flying header by Ron Yeats, a Scottish international center half, with five minutes to play today gave Liverpool, the English League First Divilion leader, a 1-0 victory over Arsenal and enabled it to keep a two-point lead at the top of the standing.
The marriage of Miss Constance Beth Singer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Singer Andrew Stein, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Stein of 176 East 71st Street, took place last evening.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Jan. 8 Mr. and Mrs. Chauncey William Cook have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Frances Ann Cook, to John Albert Cole. His parents are Mr. and Mrs. Earl E. Cole of Oklahoma City.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 8 The United States called today for new efforts by all interested countries to work for "effective measures" to keep the peace along the borders of Cambodia.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 A bleak report on the situation in Vietnam by Mike Mansfield and four other Senators appears to suggest that the United States should take the best peace settlement it can get that is consistent with honor.
ST. LOUIS, Jan. 8 Washington University here has established a new biology center to study how seriously man is contaminating his environment.

PERTH, Australia, Jan. 8 (AP) Margaret Smith of Australia, the world's top woman tennis player, routed Nancy Richey of Dallas, 6-3, 6-1, today in the women's singles final of the West Australian championships.
OTTAWA In a new Govvernment - sponsored motion picture, Buster Keaton rides again. This time the 70-year-old comic With the mournful, deadpan face is helping Canada to exploit its beauties.
The Todd Shipyards Corporation reported last week that its Los Angeles shipyard was at work on an unusually high volume of business.

BAINBRIDGE, N. Y., Jan. 8 (AP) Mrs. Alice Johnson sat and smoked cigarettes, while a freight train box car encased her in her auto. Wreckage surrounded her and a man and wife lay dead in their crushed and burning home 150 feet away.

WHITE PLAINS, Jan. 8 Mr. and Mrs. Gerald Goertzel have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Frances H. Goertzel, to Fred G. Gustavson, son of Mrs. G. Martin Gustavson of Yonkers and the late Mr. Gustavson.
The private garden as a symbol of elegance in Manhattan has been incorporated into the building of a luxury East Side apartment complex.

TAIPEI, Taiwan, Sunday, Jan. 9 (UPI) The crew of a Chinese Communist naval landing barge sailed their vessel to the Nationalist Chinese island of Quemoy early today and asked for political refuge, Nationalist Chinese military authorities announced here.

CHOLPON-ATA, U.S.S.R. Indian and Pakistani broacasts come through loud and clear on a standard pocket radio in this Central Asian lakeside resort in a remote corner of the Soviet Union. The voice of Moscow, 2,000 miles away, is weak and ridden by static.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 81 (AP) Dave Newmark, a 7foot sophomore center, scored 13 points in a 10-minute span in the second half tonight in sparking Columbia to a 75-73 Ivy League basketball victory over Harvard.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 (AP) A House subcommittee criticized tonight the National Science Foundation's administrative handling of Project Mohole the $110-million venture to drill a hole six miles deep through the ocean and earth's crust into the earth's mantles.
SYRACUSE The skyline of this busy city has begun to take on more impressive dimensions as the Syracuse urban renewal program continues to gather momentum.
DAYTON, Ohio, Jan. 8 (UPI) A new program to encourage pregnant high school girls to continue their education is being tried out in the city school system. It is already running into criticism.

SPRING LAKE, N. J., Jan. 8 St. Catharine's Roman Catholic Church was the setting this morning for the marriage of Miss Suzanne Connolly, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. John Joseph Connolly of Newark and Spring Lake, to Richard John Kinney, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Kinney of Mantoloking.
AUCKLAND, New Zealand, Jan. 8 (AP) Graham Hill of Britain scored a narrow victory in the New Zealand Grand Prix today, beating Jackie Stewart of Scotland in a duel of B.R.M. racing cars.
BLOOMINGTON, Ind., (UPI) Don Freeman scored 28 points to lead Illinois to a 98-84 Big Ten basketball victory over Indiana today.

HONG KONG, Sunday, Jan. 9 (Reuters) The Chinese Communists today criticized the United States' proposal of "negotiations before withdrawal" to end the Vietman war as an attempt to "bind the Vietnamese people hand and foot through peace talks and put off the withdrawal of U.S. forces to an indefinite future."
The Committee of European Shipowners has joined some American maritime interests in attacking a report issued by an interagency task force on Federal maritime policy.

New methods in job training and retraining unemployed youths, older workers and disadvantaged people will be explored by the Applied Research Laboratory of the New York Institute of Technology under a $76,408 contract with the Department of Education, Health and Welfare, it was announced yesterday.
BOSTON, Jan. 8 (AP) Northeast Airlines said today an application had been filed with the Civil Aeronautics Board to provide service at two Canadian cities.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Jan. 8(AP) Freedom of the press is in greater danger now than in colonial times, Eugene C. Pulliam, Arizona and Indiana publisher said today.

ATLANTA, Jan. 8 In a restaurant near the airport in Montgomery, Ala., one night this week, the manager was interrupted while watching the desegregated television series, "I Spy." Paced by a technological development that captured more public attention than any in the industry's history, men's shirt manufacturers ended 1965 and entered the new year in considerably better shape than in previous years.

HARTFORD, Jan. 8 A twoyear survey of historic structures and landmarks in Connecticut will be undertaken soon by the State Development Commission and the Connecticut Historical Commission.

Planning consultants, have proposed that a public park and recreation area be built around the disused Warren County Courthouse in Lake George, N.Y. The plan would preserve the courthouse, whose future has been in doubt.

MIAMI, Jan. 8 (UPI) The Federal Bureau of Investigation said today that raids in nine cities had broken up a gambling and bookmaking network that used telephone credit cards and electronic gadgets to speed gambling information through the southeastern United States.
New York City Community College will have its first campus grounds and double its classroom space with the completion of a 12-story downtown Brooklyn building early in 1967.
HOLLYWOOD. Fla., Jan. 8 (AP)-Ross Collins of Dallas won the national left-handers golf tournament by three strokes today.

Miss Janet Teresa Salzillo, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Peter C. Salzillo of Corona, Queens, was married yesterday afternoon to George H. Sauer Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Sauer of Waco, Tex. The Rev. Charles A. Kraus performed the ceremony in St. Leo's Roman Catholic Church in Corona.
The medical ship Hope is scheduled to sail from Pier 96 Philadelphia today for Nicaragua. She arrived in Philadelphia four months ago after a 10-month stay in Guinea, West Africa.
DES MOINES, Iowa, Jan. 8 (UPI) Gov. Harold E. Hughes announced today that he would run for a third term this year, ending speculation that he might seek a United States Senate seat.

For more than 20 years Dr. Timothy W. Costello has taught New York University business students the application of psychology to management and organization. Last week this wispy, genial man traded theory for practice, and the academic life for the less civilized environs of City Hall.

Simply being himself and doing his best in a job that has frustrated many of its occupants may not make Hubert Horatio Humphrey President of the United States. But there is no genuine alternative no surer road to the top and Humphrey aides in a panic over his poor Gallup Poll ratings should know it.

BILBOA, Spain A tall shower of incandescent sparks, like a geyser of fireworks, rises nightly over the outskirts of this ancient Spanish city, slashing the darkness and sharply etching the outlines of steel furnaces, harbor cranes, shipyards and ships.

CHICAGO, Jan. 8 A site is expected to be chosen soon in Chicago for construction of a giant produce, seafood and poultry wholesale market to serve the Middle West. The cost of the project is estimated at about $100-million.

Picking up where they left off in the early part of this National Hockey League season, the New York Rangers delighted their fans yesterday at Madison Square Garden by "getting even" with the big Chicago Black Hawks with a 6-4 victory.
