Skinner Jr., of Chestnut Hill, and the bridegroom is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Prescott B. Huntington of St. James, L.I.

NEWARK, Jan 8. Twenty years ago, an Eighth Avenue impresario prophesied, through catcalls, that the ultimate prize fight would be held in a small room filled with television equipment and canned applause. For seven weeks now, WNJU-TV a small commercial, ultra high frequency station in New Jersey, has been offering the first step toward boxing's 1984 the Studio fight.
Fifteen Nassau County agencies will benefit from the sixth Red Feather Ball, to be given on Jan. 29 at the Seawane Club in Hewlett Harbor, L.I., by the Five Towns United Fund.

Twenty-four major American Jewish groups last night termed "grave" the plight of three million Jews in the Soviet Union. They described a number of "new and disturbing incidents" that they said had affected Soviet Jews in recent months.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Jan. 8 Congress may have to settle this year the long-standing dispute over whether the Buffalo River, a picturesque little mountain stream in the Arkansas Ozarks, should be harnessed for hydroelectric power and flood control or left in its wild state.
BOGOTA, Colombia, Jan. 8 Camilo Torres, a Colombian priest who vanished mysteriously eight weeks ago, has sent word that he has joined a guerrilla movement in the mountains.

An Ohio house painter who traces his family tree back to George Washington's mother has filed a suit in the United States Supreme Court for payment with interest of $32,382 in loans he says an ancestor made to the Federal Government in 1794.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Jan. 8 A new force is emerging in Brazil's politics to the apparent discomfort of President Humberto Castelo Branco.

Mrs. Charles F. Gannon of New York has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Sally Anne Gannon, to James Robert McKinley of Irvington, N. J., son of Mrs. Grace McKinley of Buffalo and Russell McKinley of Olyphant, Pa.

SAIGON, Sunday, Jan. 9 United States forces have launched their largest offensive operation of the Vietnam war to sweep clean the Communists' Hobo Forest stronghold 20 miles north-northwest of Saigon, military officials said today.

TOKYO, Jan. 8 Premier Eisaku Sato was reported today to have asked the United States to continue the pause In the bombing of North Vietnam for at least two weeks while Japan's Foreign Minister approached the Soviet Union on peace measures.

A big serve, a punishing forehand and his speed around the court brought Benson Platt, a 17-year-old Van Buren High senior, the Public Schools Athletic League indoor singles tennis championship yesterday.

BY the year 2000 just one generation away, the population of the United States will probably be about 300 million-100 million higher than it is now and 200 million higher than it was in 1820. Taking the bewilderment out of moving to the New York area is the work of Area Consultants, Inc., a new concern that helps people find the right place to live.
Two prominent New York rabbis were sharply critical in their sermons yesterday of what one of them described as the "public be-damned" attitude of the leaders of the transit strike.
DECATUR, Ill., Jan. 8 Miss Harriet Lewe Noecker and Pete H. Beaugard plan to marry Aug. 27.

GRAND CANYON NATIONAL PARK, Ariz. The heaviest December snowstorms in recent history have placed a two-foot-deep mantle of white atop the truncated peaks and upper gorges of the Grand Canyon, thus giving sightseers an unusually spectacular view of this more-than-spectacular Western landscape.

NEFFS, Pa., Dec. 8 The marriage of Miss Kathleen Carol Muth, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alton Muth of Schnecksville, to Dr. ohn George Kauderderer, Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Kauderer of New York, took place in the Neffs Union Evangelical Lutheran Church today. NOW that it's over, the 1965 art year might be styled (among other things) the Year of the Corporate Push. The use of art for business promotion took on a new dimension.
SYDNEY, Jan. 8 Australia's second commercial oil field, at Alton, Queensland, came into production this week.

HOLLY WOOD. THIS week, to no one's surprise, Ronald Reagan, that unctuously persuasive television pitchman and movie star, formally announced his candidacy for the Governorship of California. His announcement was made amid the predictable show business trappings: his elaborately staged press conference was followed by a TV special beamed to all corners of the state.

THERE were already five complete record ings of Handel's Op6 Concerti Grossi, and there had been more before the latest catalogue deletions. Could there possibly be any reason to be excited over another set?

MIAMI, Jan. 8 Baltimore and Dallas, the runner-up teams in the National Football League conferences, loosened up a final time today in preparation for their Playoff Bowl game tomorrow.

THIS is a brief, strange, and hallucinatory novel. It is a tragedy based on an obsession: that of a Polish-German about his race. To understand the background of this, it is necessary to understand something about the nature of Nazi Germany's attitude toward the Poles.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 If Lyndon B. Johnson's fabled political antennae are as sensitive as both legend and the record suggest, he is approaching the second session of the 89th Corngress, which opens Monday, in a mood quite different from that of last January.
Inflationary pressures are becoming more visible and ominous day by day.

GREAT BARRINGTON, Mass. Another old and well-remembered landmark in this pretty Berkshire resort country, the Berkshire Inn, is about to disappear. Laborers have been razing the inn, a huge frame hostelry that has occupied the corner of Main and Taconic Streets since before the turn of the century.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 Republican National Chairman Ray C. Bliss wears bifocals and has eye trouble. But to Mr. Bliss, as to other Republican pros, the message of the accompanying table is as plain as the top-line E on the eye-doctor's chart.

IT was a sign of the times that Christmas week in New York had a crowded musical calendar. Until very recently that week was virtually empty. Musicians put their instruments in their cases and went home to spend time with wife and children.

WILKES-BARRE, Pa., Jan. 8 Mr. and Mrs. John Francis Patyk have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elaine Ann Patyk, to Lieut Thomas Beveridge Stiles 2d, U.S.A. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Ezra Martin Stiles of Ridgewood and Sea Girt, N.J.

ALTHOUGH home fruit growing receives relatively little attention from research agencies, the results of experimentation on commercial fruit crops can often be applied to fruits grown in the home garden. Great advances have been made recently in developing and making available virusfree plants, predicting tree size, grafting, pruning and the use of chemical herbicides.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 (AP) The Administration's resistance to price increases in steel, aluminum and copper was sharply criticized today by a Republican spokesman on economic matters.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 America, is now an overdeveloped urban nation with an underdeveloped system for dealing with its city problems. The paralyzing transit strike in New York is only one dramatic illustration of the point. We have reapportioned our legislatures but we have not yet reapportioned our legislation to deal with the problems of the city majority or the tyranny of the city minority.

To many public school teachers it must have looked as if the worm had turned. For years, they and their training had been sneered at by college professors. The trouble with school teachers, said the university scholars, is that they spent so much time learning how to teach that they forgot to study what to teach.
A man described as a highranking member of Cosa Nostra has been arrested in Newburgh, N. Y., and charged with conspiracy to smuggle narcotics into this country.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 8 The Friends of Stephen Girard, a new nonprofit organization, has petitioned the United States District Court for permission to intervene in the Girard College case.
TASHKENT, U.S.S.R., Jan. 8 "We must be the biggest thing to hit this city since Genghis Khan," an Indian said as he stepped off the plane at Tashkent's flag-bedecked airport Monday.
BERLIN, Jan. 8 (AP) Dr. Otto Dibelius, a critic of Nazism and Communism, will retire on March 31 as Protestant Bishop of Berlin, it was announced today.
STAMFORD, Conn., Jan. 8 The women's auxiliary of St. Joseph's Hospital is sponsoring the Mid-Winter Ball, to be held at the Stamford Yacht Club on Jan. 22.
Hofstra ended City College's five-game winning streak last Knight by routing the Beavers, 87-72, in a Tri-State League game at Wingate Gymnasium. The victory was Hofstra's eighth in 13 games.

DURING the recent United States Chess Championship at the Henry Hudson Hotel, the pre-tournament form prevailed only for the top three positions. As expected, the defending champion, 22-yearold Bobby Fischer of Brooklyn, retained his title. But this was no runaway triumph.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 9 (AP) Indoor track got off to a soaring start for the 1966 season last night with 25-yearold John Pennel's pole-vault of 16 feet 7 inches an American record.

MIAMI, Jan. 9--Peter Barrett, a 30-year-old, 205-pound artist in a 15-foot sailboat, swept the Finn-Class midwinter championships today with a break from the weather bolstering his superb sailing skill.

Manfred Malkin, a piano teacher and former concert pianist, died Saturday night in Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 81 years old and lived in the An- sonia Hotel.

TUSKEGEE, Ala., Jan. 9 (AP) Tuskegee Institute students said tonight they planned to continue demonstrations in this largely Negro community and announced a delegation would be in Washington tomorrow to stage another protest in connection with the killing of a student here last week.

Three cold but ardent unionists picketed Civil Jail yesterday in a show of support and fidelity for eight of their leaders, who were removed from their negotiating roles last Tuesday and placed in the old red-brick prison.

A golden red cocker spaniel, Ch. Artru Globetrotter, picked up where an ancestor left off when he was named best in show last night at the 49th national event of the American Spaniel Club at the Hotel Roosevelt.
WARSAW, Jan. 9 (AP) Barred from foreign travel and charged with harming Poland's national interests, Stefan Cardinal Wyszynski asked his country's Roman Catholics today to have confidence in him.

CLARK, N. J., Jan. 9 Edward Reeder Herrick of 5 Orchard Terrace, former general manager of the Heyden division of the Tenneco Chemical Company at Fords, died yesterday at Muhlenberg Hospital in Plainfield. His age was 79.

Mr. and Mrs. William Fitzhugh Whitehouse of Palm Beach, Fla., and Newport, R.I., have announced the engagement of their niece, Miss Sybil Una Millar, to Abbott Reynal, son of Mr. and Mrs. Juan Reynal of Buenos Aires and San Francisco.

As members gather for the second session of the 89th Congress which begins today, their mood is somber. The deaths of American soldiers in Vietnam and the deepening involvement in the war there subvert optimism and temper pride with prayer. But, important as Vietnam is, it would be a mistake for Congress to mark time on domestic issues.

WASHINGTON Jan. 9 Federal judges should be required to retire at the age of 70, even if they are "lovable old men with distinguished records," a former Congressman and judge of the United States Court of Appeals said today.

CHICAGO, Jan. 9 (UPI) Thomas B. Roberts Sr., who bought the "Little Brown Jug" trophy for which Michigan and Minnesota play football each year, died yesterday in Laguna Beach, Calif. He was 83 years old.

PARIS, Jan. 8 (Reuters) Cover charges were abolished in French restaurants by Government decree today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 (AP) President and Mrs. Johnson attended 11 o'clock services at St. Mark's Episcopal Church on Capitol Hill today and heard the rector offer prayers for United States military forces and particularly for prisoners of war.

SAVANNAH, Ga., Jan. 9 (AP) Lieut. Gen. Lewis B. Hershey, director of the Selective Service System, said today his plans for meeting increased manpower needs were based on the probability that requirements would not exceed those of the Korean War.

Mr. and Mrs. Stanley R. Pratt of Sault Ste. Marie, Mich., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Ann Pratt of Cambridge, Mass., to John Albert Ware. He is the son of John Ware of Westport, Conn., and Mrs. Doris Ware of New York.

The Judicial Council of the Tenth United States Circuit has stripped a Federal district judge of his duties and authority, but left him on the bench with title and salary unimpaired. This is obviously not a very satisfactory procedure, and the affected judge is now challenging the action in the Supreme Court. In any event, some better legal mechanism for dealing with judges who are accused of being unfit is certainly needed.
FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Jan. 9 (AP) Floyd Eaton Chalkley, the husband of Susan Hayward, died at his home today after an illness of six weeks. He was 56 years old.
Six measures to reduce delays and confusion at polling places will be introduced today in the State Legislature.
TAIPEI, Taiwan, Jan. 9 (AP) In swift revenge, Chinese Communist jets today shot down a Chinese Nationalist seaplane carrying three defectors to Taiwan from the Island of Matsu.

SAIGON, Jan. 9--United States and Australian troops, conducting one of the largest operations of the Vietnamese war in a long-time Vietcong stronghold, reported having killed 21 guerrillas today in light and sporadic fighting.

SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, Jan. 9 Provisional President Hector GarciaGodoy remained firm today in his determination to shake up the military leadership. At the same time he picked up important support from the church.
MOSCOW, Jan. 9 The Soviet Union made an implicit plea today for North Vietnam to recognize Moscow as the leading champion of Communist unity behind the "fraternal Vietnamese people."
Who says the advertising of an investment firm has to be dull.

Several dozen members of the Marion Freschl Alumni Club not that anyone who studies voice with Mrs. Freschl ever completely "graduates" gave a party for their teacher Saturday at the New York University Club in Town Hall.
New York City is beginning a program to help workers get better jobs so that their present ones can be filled by the unemployed.
Secretary of State Dean Rusk has won the 1966 Franklin Award for distinguished service, highest single honor of the Printing Industries of Metropolitan New York, it was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 The labor movement is looking to the forthcoming session of Congress for passage of key labor bills that were sidetracked in the previous session in favor of broad social legislation.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 9 Yeljko Vlahovic, a senior Yugoslav Communist ideologist, contends that "many" conservative members of the party are hindering the nation's economic reform. He has hinted at a purge of officials who drag their feet.

"Yoga for Health," WNEWTV's answer to Jack La Lanne's exercise program over WORTV, will make its debut over Channel 5 next Monday, at 9:30 A.M. It will be conducted by Richard L. Hittleman, an American-born yoga instructor, and his wife, Diane. WNEWTV said the program would demonstrate how one might activate "the great vital forces of the body and mind which become lazy and dormant if not correctly stimulated."
Music played a leading role over the weekend in the sale of two Chicago companies.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 (UPI) Two gas explosions rocked Mount Joy Baptist Church here tonight during services attended by 150 church members.
ARMONK, Jan. 9 Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Z. Gray have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Priscilla Adams Gray, to David Edwards Baxter, son of Mr. and Mrs. C. David Baxter of Winters, Calif.

The election of Robert M. Bacon and Alec R. Jack as directors of E. F. Hutton Co., Inc., a member of the New York Stock Exchange, was announced over the weekend by Sylvan C. Coleman, chairman and chief executive officer.
ADELBODEN, Switzerland, Jan. 9 (AP) Jean-Claude Killy of France won the opening giant slalom race of the Adelboden international ski seties today.

SAIGON, Jan. 9 (AP) United States paratroops and infantrymen, pushing into the Vietcong stronghold northwest of Saigon known as the Iron Triangle, discovered a vast enemy tunnel system today. A soldier described it as "the New York subway."

The Soviet Government newspaper Izvestia announced last week that it was inaugurating a new column on international affairs, one whose contents will not necessarily reflect the opinions or Izvestia's editors. Presumably the innovation is intended to provide a somewhat freer form for the discussion of foreign affairs problems than is usually available in the Soviet press. Strict conformity to the official foreign policy line is normally taken for granted.
DETROIT, Jan. 9 (AP) The Los Angeles Lakers led all the way today in crushing the Detroit Pistons, 111-98, and maintaining their 3 -game Western Division lead in the National Basketball Association.

CHEVY CHASE, Md., Jan. 9 Mr. and Mrs. Siert Frederick Riepma, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth Blair Riepma, to Robert Anderson Gaines. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Lee Gaines of Roanoke, Va.
MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 9 (AP) Bob Nordskog, the 52-year-old "iron man" from Tarzana, Calif., won the Orange Bowl Regatta's Nine Hour endurance race at the Marine Stadium today.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Jan. 9 Minister of Planning Roberto Campos flew to Washington today for talks on the Alliance for Progress and United StatesBrazil economic relations.
Dr. Rosemary Lauer, one of the 31 teachers dismissed by St. John's University, called yesterday for the "disassociation of all universities and colleges from the Catholic Church."
Distress calls from shivering apartment dwellers flooded the city's Housing Complaint Bureau yesterday as the mercury dropped to the lowest point so far this winter 15 degrees at 7:15 A.M.
Drivers are urged not to bring cars into the congested parts of the city unless absolutely necessary. Those who do drive are urged to carry as many passengers as possible.

THE return of Beethoven's "Fidelio" to the Metropolitan Opera Saturday night was made more notable by the appearance of James King, a young tenor from Dodge City, Kan., in his debut in the role of Florestan. The opera was last seen in the 1962-63 season.

WAYNE, Pa., Jan. 9 Mr. and Mrs. Robert Ashby Apple have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Susan Foster Apple, to Lieut. Timothy Keyes Hollander, U.S.M.C.R. His parents are Mr. and Mrs. Theodore C. Hollander of Wenham, Mass.

The New York Rangers didn't get Green last night. In fact, they didn't even get a victory over the Boston Bruins as they dropped a 3-1 decision to the only team in the National Hockey League lower in the standings than they are.
CHICAGO, Jan. 9 (UPI) Bobby Hull got his 32d goal tonight to help the Chicago Black Hawks to a 5-3 triumph over the Toronto Maple Leafs.

Individuals and families should take their cue from businesses and industries, which pause in this season to evaluate progress made in the last year and to review plans and goals formulated for the new one.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Jan. 9 Indonesia's monetary reform has failed to stem widespread inflation and has produced apparent nation-wide discontent.
GLEN COVE, L. I., Jan. 9 George H. (Pete) Bostwick Jr. won the Luckenbach Memorial handicap squash racquet singles tournament for the first time at the Nassau Country Club today.
COLOMBO, Ceylon, Jan. 9 (UPI) Communist-fomented riots swirled near the United States Embassy in downtown Colombo today and two American diplomats and a British diplomat were slightly injured.
FORT BUCKNER, Okinawa, Jan. 9 Two United States sergeants who are accused of having given aid and comfort to the Vietcong while held as prisoners have dropped from sight.

Staughton Lynd returned here last night after a 10-day visit to North Vietnam and said he was "optimistic" about the chances for peace. The Yale professor was accompanied by Thomas Hayden, a founder of Students for a Democratic Society, and Herbert Aptheker, the director of the American Institute for Marxist Studies.

It could be said that part of Elisabeth Schwarzkopf's recital in Carnegie Hall Saturday night was the completion of one she began last April 9. At that time, Miss Schwarzkopf had a freak swallowing accident that made it impossible for her to sing the concluding four songs in her program.
"The Eleanor Roosevelt Story" has been chosen as the best picture of the year by the National Board of Review of Motion Pictures.

The American Shakespeare Festival in Stratford, Conn. has already sold 130,000 of the 150,000 tickets available for the festival's 99 student matinees to be given between Feb. 28 and June 7, it was reported yesterday by William Stewart, the festival's administrative director.

PERTH, Australia, Jan. 9 (AP) Arthur Ashe of Richmond won his third tennis tournament in Australia since last October today when he captured the West Australian singles championship by beating Cliff Richey of Dallas.
Premier Castro's address on Jan. 2 provided Cubans with their first public indication of what Washington has suspected for two years a deterioration in relations between Cuba and Communist China.
PITTSBURGH, Jan. 9 Steel users may be having second thoughts about the need for in- ventory protection.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., Jan. 9 The 15th anniversary of the Junior League of Larchmont will be celebrated at a ball at the Glen Island Casino in New Rochelle on Saturday. Before 1950, the group had been the eastern Westchester unit of the Junior League of New York.

ON the night of Nov. 15, 1959, in the little town of Holcomb, Kan., Herbert W. Clutter, his wife, Bonnie, and their teen-aged children, Nancy and Kenyon, were savagely murdered in their home by blasts from a shotgun held inches from their faces. Herbert Clutter was found in the basement, his throat also slashed; Bonnie and Nancy...

ARDSLEY, N.Y., Jan. 9 Mrs. William Bruce May has made known the engagement of her daughter, Miss Penelope Ann May, to William Hunt Thompson of Denver. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. George W. Thompson of Cazenovia.
LOS ANGELES, Jan. 9 Arnold Palmer withstood a closing rush by Paul Harney today to win the $70,000 Los Angeles open golf tournament by three strokes.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 Private gold hoarding and speculation absorbed the entire output of about $1-billion of newly mined gold in the first three quarters of last year, according to preliminary figures published by the Federal Reserve Board.

The city's water supply inched above 440 per cent of reservoir capacity yesterday for the first time since the drought drained it to nearly 25 per cent last summer. The storage total was 190.9 billion gallons, or 40.1 per cent.

HONG KONG, Jan. 9 Aleksandr N. Shelepin, a member of the ruling Soviet Presidium, declared tonight that the United States had failed to demonstrate that it wanted a peaceful solution of the war in Vietnam.
Mayor Lindsay summoned the mediators and negotiators in the transit strike to City Hall yesterday for a crucial night session aimed at ending the walkout.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 (AP) A recruiting drive is under way to raise the number of United States aid workers in South Vietnam from 700 to more than 1,000.

ANOTHER television documentary on "The World of the Teen-ager" was presented last night by the National Broadcasting Company. The program had nothing particularly new to contribute to the running discussion of the tensions of the younger generation. And, as is the TV way, it concluded with the routine hope that presenting "both sides" of the subject may have helped adult and child to a better understanding.

GLEN COVE, L. I., Jan. 9 Prof. and Mrs. Gaspar E. Schweiger have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Kristina. E. Schweiger, to Arthur W. Harrigan Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Harrigan of Chatham. N. J.

LAGOS, Nigeria, Jan. 9 A rash of rioting, looting and the burning alive of political rivals has once again broken out in Nigeria, this time on the eve of a meeting here of leaders of the British Commonwealth to discuss the crisis in Rhodesia.
E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., plans to spend more than $400-million on construction this year, the highest in the company's history.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 The National Collegiate Athletic Association again asked the National and American football leagues today to conduct their draft sessions after all college post-season games had been completed.
The striking Transport Workers Union originally asked for an over-all money package that the Transit Authority estimated would cost $680-million over a two-year period.

DETROIT, Jan. 9 (UPI) Third-period goals by Paul Henderson and Norm Ullman, with stellar defense work by Roger Crozier, the goalie, gave the Detroit Red Wings a 4-2 victory over the Montreal Canadiens tonight.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Jan. 9 (AP)--Abraham Feinberg, the 34-year-old former director of the Supersol Company, was sentenced to jail for four years today after pleading guilty to arson and falsifying the accounts and stock lists of the company by $1-million.

ALTHOUGH the Baseball Writers Association of America consists mainly of nature's noblemen, not all of the brothers are endowed with each of the admirable Boy Scouts' attributes of being trustworthy, loyal, helpful, friendly, courteous, kind, obedient, cheerful, thrifty, brave, clean and reverent. Some members of the lodge have been known ah, the pity of it! to get downright ornery on occasions.
TASHKENT, U.S.S.R., Jan. 9 The Soviet Premier, Aleksei N. Kosygin, re-entered the Pakistani-Indian talks today in a last-minute effort to salvage something from an apparently hopeless stalemate.

NORMAN, Okla., Jan. 9 (AP) Fourteen persons, including 11 University of Oklahoma students, were jailed tonight after a said in which the police confiscated marijuana and material opposing the Vietnam war effort.
For two weeks, the men engaged in transit negotiations have been losing sleep, gaining weight, smoking too much and walking too little.

BOSTON, Jan. 9 Miss Susan Margot Porter, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alvin Irving Porter of Charleroi, Pa., was married today to Lieut. (jg.) Edward George Benson Jr. He is the son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Benson of Princeton, N. J. Justice of the Peace Ross Hamilton Currier performed the civil ceremony at the Somerset Hotel.
CAIRO, Jan. 9 Two American experts are secretly working on an Egyptian program to develop mediumrange rockets ahead of Israel, according to reliable sources close to the program.
Mayor Lindsay named Mathias L. Spiegel first Deputy City Administrator yesterday.
ATLANTA, Jan. 9 (AP) Butterfly McQueen, the negro girl who became famous as Prissy in the motion picture "Gone With the Wind," has appealed to a Georgia congressman for help in getting a job.
Money, money, who's got the money?

CHOREOGRAPHERS are doubtless born rather than made, but Bertram Ross, the principal dancer of the Martha Graham Dance Company, has certainly delayed his birth an unconscionably long time. On Saturday night at the Kaufmann Hall of the 92d Street Young Men's and Young Women's Hebrew Association, Mr. Ross and his Dance Company made its first New York appearance since its debut last spring.

DUNCAN SUTTLES of Vancouver, B.C., as White in a French Defense, failed by a hasty move to upset Grand Mater Robert Byrne of Indianapolis in the ninth round of the recent United States chess championship at the Henry Hudson Hotel.

VALLEY COTTAGE, N.Y., Jan. 9 Mrs. Charles Zanlunghi, 35 years old, of Helene Drive here, a well known professional figure skating instructor, and her 11-year-old daughter Vicki were instantly killed in a headon collision here early today on Route 303.

Prof. and Mrs. Lawrence S. Kennison of Hollis, Queens, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Hope Louise Kennison, to Stephen H. Goldman. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Emanuel Goldman of Merrick, L. I. The couple plan an August wedding.
The appointment of Thomas E. (Ben) Oakes as director of marketing for World Air ways. Inc., has been announced by W. A. Hardenstine, vice president-sales, for the carrier.
A survey of office space in newly constructed Manhattan office buildings shows that less than 1.1-million square feet will be available for lease during 1966.
The election of Robert E. Kirby as executive vice president of the Westinghouse Electric Corporation was announced over the weekend.
KABUL, Afghanistan, Jan. 9 For the first time, a woman has been named a Cabinet minister in Afghanistan.
SAIGON, Jan. 9 Despite violence, death and the threat of death, Saigon continues to be lively at night.

EMME'S spring hat collec- tion shown Friday at the Plaza Hotel was as topical as a spaceship, and many of the styles looked as if they could be worn in one. The bubble- shaped helmets in black and white patent leather would also look decorative on a motorcycle. Some lacy straw domes lift off to leave a snug baby cap clinging to the head.
ATLANTA, Jan. 9 The nation's civil rights organizations are being plagued by rising deficits, dwindling public support and indecision over what they should do next.
LONDON, Jan. 9 A byelection on Jan. 27 looms as the biggest test for all three of Britain's major parties since Labor narrowly won office in October, 1964.

The unbeaten University of Kentucky basketball team, ranked second in both the Associated Press and United Press International polls, continued its drive for the top ranking Saturday when it downed Florida 78-64, for its 10th victory.

The Rev. Dr. Robert J. McCracken told worshipers at Riverside Church yesterday that the war in Vietnam had become a burden that weighed heavily on both the Christian conscience and the public con science.

William D. Eckert, baseball's new commissioner, discussed the game's future and his own role in it on WHN's Sunday noon interview program, "New York Speaks Out." The questions were posed by Mike Prelee, the radio station's news director, and Mary Albert, the sports director.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 Roger W. Wilkins, the new director of the Community Relations Service, expects to concentrate on riot prevention in Northern ghettoes.
The happy shouts of Bedford-Stuyvesant youngsters trying out rugged new homemade playground equipment all but drowned out the dedication ceremonies yesterday for the area's first vest-pocket park.

Dr. William E. Robinson, administrator of medical education at the Swedish Hospital Medical Center in Englewood, Colo., near Denver, and formerly a general practitioner in Queens, died Wednesday of a heart attack in Denver. His age was 57.

It took William Warfield a long time to get to Mussorgsky's "Songs and Dances of Death" in the recital he gave at Carnegie Hall last night, but the songs gave the event special luster by bringing out the best of Mr. Warfield's artistry.
New rules to help insure that an airliner's flight recorder a valuable crash-clue device will survive an accident has been published by the Federal Aviation Agency.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Jan. 9 The Rhodesian Government is reported to be negotiating with South Africa for the delivery of oil supplies by a route that would bypass the Bechuanaland Railway.

Parochial high school students in Brooklyn and Queens will "probably" hare to go to school during some traditional holidays Washington's Birthday. St. Patrick's Day, Holy Thursday to make up for time lost in the transit strike.

St. Patrick's Cathedral was jammed with 3,000 people yesterday, despite the bitter cold and the hardships of the transit strike, as the Roman Catholic Archiocese of New York honored 350 couples celebrating their 50th wedding anniversaries this year.
An undercover police agent was pressed into emergency duty last week in the city's transit crisis, but Police Commissioner Vincent L. Broderick conceded yesterday it was probably a mistake.
MIAMI BEACH, Jan. 9 (AP) David L. Brown, former sales manager and advertising director for the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company, died yesterday at the age of 77.
ATHENS, Jan. 9 Greece has devised a plan to reactivate United Nations mediation in the Cyprus dispute and break a six-month deadlock.
GINGERBREAD is one of America's favorite desserts and one of the oldest known.

MIAMI, Jan. 9 (AP) Six youngsters sponsored by National Football League teams won trophies in the 1965 punt, place-kicking and passing national competition today in the Orange Bowl. Commissioner Pete Rozelle of the N.F.L. awarded the trophies at the Playoff Bowl game.

Municipal bond underwriting activity this week will be the largest in two months, while the corporate capital market will be dominated by two Tennessee Gas Transmission Company issues totaling $150-million.
BURBANK. Calif., Jan. 9 (UPI) Ronald Reagan suggested today a Congressional investigation of the John Birch Society to "clear the air" on whether the anti-Communist organization was subversive.

DALLAS. Tex., Jan. 9 (AP) Mrs. Earline Roberts, who operated the rooming house in which Lee Harvey Oswald lived until he assassinated President Kennedy, died today in Parkland Hospital, shortly after she suffered a heart attack in her home.

The election of Philip P. Ardery as chairman of the board of directors of the American Heart Association was announced yesterday. Mr. Ardery, a Louisville lawyer, succeeds John D. Brundage. Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower continues as honorary chairman of the association.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 9 (AP) The Baltimore Bullets staged a rally late in the third period and continued it into the fourth today to score a 130-124 victory over the New York Knicks in a National Basketball Association game that was televised nationally.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 Senator Everett McKinley Dirksen of Illinois today promised some revelations to the Senate soon about the operation of a men's Job Corps camp at Breckinridge, Ky.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 Lieut. Gov. Raymond P. Shafer will announce his candidacy tomorrow for the Republican nomination for governor of Pennsylvania.
CHARLESTON, W. Va., Jan. 5 The Charleston Job Corps Center for Women is struggling with trouble.

COLORADO SPRINGS, Colo., Jan. 9 (AP) Gail Newberry, a 13-year-old from Colorado Springs, added a victory in free skating to a victory in compulsory figures last night and won the senior women's division at the finals of the Midwestern figure skating competition.

MIAMI, Jan. 9 (UPI) Kenneth Hanna, arrested by the Federal Bureau of Investigation yesterday as part of a ninecity crackdown on a gambling scheme, is to appear before a United States Commissioner tomorrow morning for arraignment on Federal gambling charges.

Stiffened traffic fines, extra parking spaces in Central Park and school yards and the scheduled reversal of bridge and tunnel lanes were set up yesterday to cope with an expected, increase in driving today.
Lyon Mearson, editor, playwright and novelist, died yesterday of a heart ailment in his home at 530 Grand Street. He was 77 years old.
A Harlem community group, cooperating with the Police Department, announced plans yesterday for car pools to help residents of the area get to work.
PARIS, Jan. 9 "His thinking follows closely that of General de Gaulle, the only man, perhaps, whose intellectual authority he recognizes."

The Police Department has designated the following areas in Manhattan, the Bronx, Queens and Brooklyn as places where persons who have arranged car pools may pick up and discharge their passengers tomorrow. Parking will not be permitted in these areas. In addition, municipal off-street parking lots have been designated as staging areas in the Bronx, Queens, and Brooklyn.
Noah Greenberg, founder and director of the New York Pro Musica, died yesterday at University Hospital, apparently of a heart attack. He was 46 years old.

BLAIRSTOWN, N. J., Jan. 9 Dr. John I. Blair Vail of Blairstown, who had practiced medicine on Cape Cod, from 1920 until he retired in 1953, died today in Morristown Memorial Hospital. He was 76 years old.

The Democratic majority of the City Council has suggested though threatened might be the more accurate term that the Board of Education be held to a line-by-line budget, instead of getting a lump-sum appropriation as it now does. Such a backward step would wipe out important reforms in school administration introduced three years ago after much factfinding and debate.

THE $11-billion that consumers are expected to spend on housewares this year will bring few surprises into the home but many ingenious variations on previously introduced appliances, cooking utensils, bathroom and garden... accessories.
DES MOINES, Iowa., Jan. 9 A series of unusual statesponsored hearings on vehicle safety will offer a forum this week for critics of the automobile industry.

BOCA RATON, Fla., Jan. 9 Mrs. Mary Read Clark, wife of Dr. Donald Lemen Clark, professor emeritus of rhetoric at Columbia University, died in a nursing home yesterday. She was 73 years old and maintained homes here and at 90 Morningside Drive, New York.

The Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday a net loss of $1,917 on the sale of United States Government securities last year. In 1964, such transactions produced a net profit of $150,704.
PARIS, Jan. 9 President de Gaulle's Secretary of State for the Budget, Robert Boulin, won a clear victory today against his left-wing opponents in a by-election for a vacant National Assembly seat.

The first wave of about 5,000 merchants and store executives expected here this week, along with a similar number of retail buyers, converged yesterday on a New York City struggling to keep mobile despite the transit strike.

WHAT with hamster, guanaco, skunk, rabbit and squirrel jostling one another for a place in the fashion sun, there seems to be hardly an animal whose pelt has escaped the demand for new and sometimes unlikely furs.
LIVING ROOM, Second Avenue and 49th Street. Irwin Corey, comedian; Annette Saunders, singer. Held over: Bob Ferro's Trio.

HANSOM cab driver (one of the few who made it to work they usually take subways, not horses) was hired by Mrs. Clyde M. Newhouse to haul some of her guests through Central Park to the "Night in St. Moritz" ball Friday night.

STAMFORD, Conn., Jan. 9 Miss Luetta Phyllis Levine, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Harry H. Levine, was married this noon to Murray Luck, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Jacob Luck of Brooklyn. Rabbi Joseph Ehrenkrantz performed the ceremony here in the Agudath Sholom Synagogue.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N. Y., Jan. 9 Bernard Dion of Hanover, N. H., who opened the Eastern competition here yesterday by taking the Class A division of the 21st annual Torger Tokle Memorial ski jump, turned in another winning performance today before 18,343 fans.

MIAMI, Jan. 9 (AP) Tom Matte, the Baltimore Colts' converted halfback, threw for two touchdowns and set up two others with long aerials today in a passing exhibition that smothered the favored Dallas Cowboys in the Playoff Bowl. 35-3.

MOSCOW, Jan. 9 A noted Soviet rocket pioncer who helped lay the basis of the space program in the nineteen-thirties and who was presumed to be dead, has been located and interviewed by two enterprising Leningrad reporters.
Reports these past few weeks provide strong evidence of the escalation of the dangerous Middle East arms race.
OSLO, Norway Jan. 9 (AP) Reidar Hjermstad of Norway won the Monolithe cross-country ski race today while three Americans brought up the rear.
A 76-year-old man and his 72year-old wife were badly beaten in their Brooklyn apartment last night by a gang of youths attempting to rob them, the police reported.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 A new outbreak of the four-yearold feud among the Government agencies that regulate banks is threatening the ability of the Government to arrange for orderly liquidation of banks that fail.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 The 89th Congress reconvenes at noon tomorrow, its mood more somber than at any time since the Korean war.

Four hundred prospective jurors who were scheduled to appear for duty at State Supreme Court in Manhattan today and tomorrow have been told not to appear until further notice because of the transit strike.

LAKE PLACID, N. Y., Jan 9 Bjoern Wirkola, an easygoing 23-year-old Norwegian G. I, who comes from a region in which there is no wintertime daylight, led 34 rivals today in the masters' international skijumping tournament.
TOKYO, Jan. 9 Communist China, scolded Premier Fidel Castro today over his charge that Peking had broken a trade agreement with Havana.

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 9 Wilt Chamberlain scored 41 points and Bill Cunningham got 31 today as they led the Philadelphia 76ers to a 127-117 victory over the St. Louis Hawks in a National Baketball Association game.

MOUNT HOPE, N. Y., Jan. 9 The Country Club of Brookline, Mass., won the 31st Douglas Medal bonspiel today when Henry Cushing skipped his rink to a 9-6 victory over the Royal Montreal Curling Club, skipped by Ivan Ibbotson, in the 12end final at St. Andrew's Golf Club.
ALBANY, Jan. 9 Assembly Speaker Anthony J. Travia said today that the 1965 Democraticcontrolled Legislature had saved 5 per cent in operating costs over the Republican-led 1964 session.

The growing manpower shortage in the American merchant marine the object of much concern in maritime-union and Government quarters could be solved quickly, simply and effectively, in the view of some shipping industry officials.
PANAMA, Jan. 9 A United States flag was burned today in a student demonstration marking the second anniversary of rioting that took 25 lives.

TASHKENT, U.S.S.R., Tuesday, Jan. 11--India and Pakistan agreed yesterday to withdraw their armed personnel to positions they held before last fall's fighting. They pledged to complete the withdrawals by Feb. 25.
TOKYO, Jan. 10--Communist China has replaced the Soviet Union as Japan's leading trade partner in the Communist bloc following a rise of more than 50 per cent in JapaneseChinese exchanges last year.

CINCINNATI, Jan. 10 (AP)-- The East was favored by 9 points today for tomorrow night's National Basketball Association All-Star game, but Coach Fred Schaus of the West wasn't conceding anything to the opposition.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10-- President Johnson announced today the appointment of Dr. James L. Goddard, an assistant Surgeon General of the United States Public Health Service, as Commissioner of the Food and Drug Administration.
NEW DELHI, Jan. 10--New Delhi welcomed today the news of positive results at the Tashkent talks.
GUATEMALA, Jan. 10--President Gustavo Diaz Ordaz began here today the first visit by a Mexican chief of state to neighboring Central American countries.

TRENTON, Jan. 10 (AP)-- The City of Clifton cannot require licensed real estate salesmen to get police permits to do house-to-house soliciting of business, New Jersey's second highest court has ruled.

SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, Jan. 10--President Hector Garcia-Godoy said today that the military crisis in the Dominican Republic was beginning to move toward a solution. There were sporadic disorders in Santo Domingo and a partial Shutdown of business.

The Weather Bureau said yesterday that it isn't complaining but it hasn't had any snow to measure this winter. This is the first time in 97 years, the bureau said, that "no measurable snow has been observed so late in the season."
BALTIMORE, Jan. 10-- Police Commissioner Bernard J. Schmidt announced his retirement today following a blistering attack on his department by a team of law enforcement experts.
The traffic jams inside some city schools yesterday were as bad as those on the streets as thousands of pupils, unable to get to their regular classes, swamped schools near their homes.

Maurice Shapiro of 75-22 196th Street, Flushing, Queens, a partner in Vengrove, Shapiro Co., certified public accountants at 32 Broadway, died yesterday of a heart attack on a Long Island Rail Road train en route to his office. His age was 65.
TEL AVIV, Jan. 10--A spacious and attractive American library was opened without ceremony here today in an unfinished annex of the Embassy near the shore.
TOKYO, Jan. 10--Premier Eisaku Sato opened a Japanese campaign for peace in Vietnam by calling on the Soviet Union today to take "positive action" toward ending the fighting.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Jan. 10 (AP)--The United States Military Academy got its 47th Superintendent today. Maj. Gen. Donald V. Bennett, 50 years old, a 1940 West Point graduate, replaced Lieut. Gen. James B. Lampert, who takes over a new post as Deputy Assistant Secretary of Defense for ManPower.
The wholesale commodity price index rose to 111.7 on Friday from 111.6 on Thursday in its seventh consecutive day of advance.
Who is the Parks Commissioner? "I'm Commissioner, said Newbold Morris yesterday. "I sign all the official documents."

ONE of the lesser blessings accorded the outdoors writer is the flattering assumption that he knows the answers to some fairly wild questions, or rather, wild questions about wildlife. It's often a misplaced confidence.
City and state officials are studying the legal basis for possible further measures to cope with the transit emergency, including use of the National Guard to provide bus or truck service.
PRINCETON, N. J., Jan. 10 --Princeton astrophysicists have obtained evidence that stars can "die" by throwing off most of their matter into space.

WHITE PLAINS, Jan. 10-- Professor Halecki first learned of the Polish Government's ban on Cardinal Wyszynski's trip to Rome in an interview at the professor's apartment at 35 Barker Avenue here tonight.
