Daily shuttle flights between Westchester County Airport and La Guardia and Newark Airports were begun yesterday by Empire State Airlines. The same carrier began a similar service between Westchester and Kennedy Airports Dec. 1.
N. Y. STOCK EXCHANGE Stocks closed with more ad vances than declines and special situation issues showing best gains in brisk trading; volume, 7.72 million shares.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 10--Secretary General Thant convened today the initial meeting of the governing council of the United Nations Development Program, which he hailed as "the most extensive cooperative and multilateral endeavor ever under.

Alternate-side parking rules are suspended. However, other parking regulations will be strictly enforced. Extra fines are to be put into effect for obstructing fire hydrants, double parking and parking on cross walks.
ROCHESTER, Jan. 10--Mr. and Mrs. Harold M. Moll have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Eleanor Jean Moll, to William K. Kral, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles ...
SEATTLE, Jan. 10 (AP)-- Charles P. Dunn, retired vice president of the Morrison Knudsen Company, construction engineers, died today. He was 79 years old.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10--The second session of the 89th Congress assembled briefly today then quit for two days to let President Johnson have the first word on its most burning interest--the war in Vietnam.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10-- The national Republican party has invested more money so far in John G. Tower of Texas and Jack Miller of Iowa than any other of the 14 Republican Senators facing re-election this year.
TRENTON, Jan. 10--The 190th session of the New Jersey Legislature, the first since 1914 in which both houses will be controlled by the Democrats, will convene at noon tomorrow.

Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth O. Crichlow of St. Albans, Queens, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Carolyn Louise Crichlow, to David H. Snipe, son of Mr. and Mrs. David Snipe of Hollis, Queens. A wedding in August is planned.

The Transit Authority filed suit in Federal court here yesterday to recover treble damages from five major steel companies on the ground that they conspired to fix prices in the sale of wrought steel wheels for subway cars.

The New York City Opera will use the largest forces in its history for Alberto Ginastera's "Don Rodrigo," which opens the company's initial run at its new home, the New York State Theater, on Feb. 22.
The British pound, the Canadian dollar and most Continental European currencies declined in quiet trading on foreign exchange markets yesterday.

MONTREAL, Jan. 10 (Canadian Press)--The National Hockey League's board of governors will meet in New York Feb. 7 through 9 to consider applications from one Canadian organization and a dozen united States groups seeking a spot in the league's proposed expansion plans.

The development of a new picture-a-minute developing machine, announced last Friday, boosted Anken Chemical--and Film Corporation of Newton, N. J., to top spot in yesterday's dealings on the New York Stock Exchange.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Jan. 10-- President Humberto Castello Branco today replaced his controversial Minister of Education, Flavio Suplicy de Lacerda, with Pedro Aleixo, who has been leader of the Government majority in the Chamber of Deputies.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 10--William M. Jordan, one of the earliest members of the United Nations secretariat, died early this morning at his home, 84 Reid Avenue, Port Washington, L. I. He had been ill with leukemia for more than a year. He was 56 years old.
Dr. Paul Chertoff, former associate professor of Talmud at the Teachers Institute of the Jewish Theological Seminary of America, died yesterday in his home at 390 Riverside Drive. His age was 81.
The 34,800 transit workers on strike for more pay have been borrowing when they can, spending less and learning to live with no pay.

Arnold S. Penner has been appointed manager of the industrial division of Wm. A. White Sons, and William Wagner has been made manager of the firm's store leasing division. Both men will operate both locally and nationally, dealing with urban properties, industrial parks and shopping centers.
Federal funds totaling $6,448,845 for the city's Project Head Start were approved yesterday by Governor Rockefeller, the last step needed to initiate the antipoverty program.
Mayor Lindsay, asserting that the city "will not capitulate before the lawless demands of a single group." called last night for the immediate end of the subway and bus strike.

THERE have been so many horrifying real-life films. on the bestiality of the Nazi concentration camps that at first thought it would not seem likely that a documentary drama could expand significantly on the record of agonizing genocide.
Five children drowned yesterday after they tried to walk on thin ice in three accidents in Staten Island, Long Island and Northern New Jersey.
The 38-man crew of a Spanish freighter abandoned ship yesterday in an angry North Atlantic sea. Early today, four persons were picked up by rescue craft, the Coast Guard reported.

Jason Robards may appear next season in his first Broadway musical, tentatively called "Softly." Harold Arlen wrote the score, Hugh Wheeler the story, and Martin Charnin the lyrics. The show is to be put on next season by Saint Subber, producer of "The Odd Couple" and "Barefoot in the Park."

ROME, Jan. 10--Andrei A. Gromyko, the Soviet Foreign Minister, will make an official visit to Rome, probably on Feb. 7, and may become the first high Soviet Government official o call upon the Pope in the vatican.

MORGANFIELD, Ky., Jan. 10 (AP)--The acting director of the Camp Breckinridge Job Corps. Center suggested today that Senator Everett McKinley Dirksen visit the facility and "learn for himself there is no boondoggling of any kind."

The C.I.T. Financial Corporation, one of the nation's largest financing concerns, plans to expand its manufacturing activities through the proposed acquisition of All-Steel Equipment, Inc., for $35.5-million in cash.
A debut piano recital of merit was played in Carnegie Recital Hall last night by Murray Perahia, who was presented by the organization know as Young Concert Artists. Now 18, Mr. ...

A warning came over the weekend from Joseph Zaretzki, Democratic minority leader of the State Senate, that the Legislature may be having second thoughts about the wisdom of the Wagner "borrownow, pay-later" policy that substituted bond issues at the rate of $256-million a year for taxation to meet New York City's expense budget. Mr. Zaretzki said that the plan faced trouble, that there was "a great deal of upstate sentiment" against it.
DES MOINES, Iowa, Jan. 10 --A University of Michigan pathologist warned today that the Government's present safety standards would not substantially reduce automobile deaths.

FAIRVIEW VILLAGE, Pa., Jan. 10--Mrs. Gertrude Place DeChant has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Joan Place DeChant, to Malcolm McCurdy Burdett Sterrett, son of Dr. and Mrs. Raymond Arthur Sterrett of Southport, Conn.
A Good Samaritan who gave lifts to strangers stranded in the transit strike forwarded their "unwillingly accepted offering" of $4 to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.
A 30-year-old Queens motorist was stabbed last night after he picked up two youths who had signalled him to ask for a ride.
ALBANY, Jan.10--New York State could get $250-million a year by taking over wholesale liquor distribution, according to the chairman of the legislative committee that is considering the idea.

ROME, Jan. 10 (AP)--Alfredo Cardinal Ottaviani's office said today that the Cardinal had assisted the Rev. Gomar DePauw, head of the United States Catholic Traditionalist Movement, on recommendations of Cardinal Spellman of New York.
Spurred by a number of strong advanees, most stocks on the American Stock Exchange moved ahead yesterday in active trading.
Early in the quarrel between St. John's University and its faculty, the Very Rev. Joseph T. Cahill, president of the school, stated the administration's general position.

NORMAN, Okla., Jan. 10 (UPI)--An investigation of sex and marijuana parties allegedly involving 23 college-age youths resulted in the filing today of charges against 14. A raid on one of the parties had produced narcotics and anti-Vietnam war literature.
ATHENS, Ga., Jan. 10 (AP) --Unbeaten Kentucky scored 8 points in the second overtime and protected its second-place ranking with a 69-65 victory over Georgia tonight.

The annual Champagne Ball of the women's committee of the Brooklyn Philharmonia will be given Jan. 22 in the Grand Ballroom of the Granada Hotel in Brooklyn. The ball will follow the Philharmonic's second subscription concert of the season at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.
ST. LOUIS, Jan. 10 (AP)-- Waily Lemm resigned as coach of the St. Louis Cardinals today by mutual agreement with the owners of the National Football League club.
CAMDEN, N.J., Jan. 10 (AP) --A 23-year-old Camden County man, scheduled to be inducted into the Army today, shot and killed himself before dawn in a neighbor's driveway.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 10--Retail sales rose by 8 per cent last year from the 1964 level to $282.7-billion, the Commerce Department reported today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 10--The Government of North Vietnam has accepted a secret letter from the United States Government in a meeting between an American official and a Hanoi representative.
TASHKENT, U.S.S.R., Jan. 10 (Reuters)--Following is the text of the Indian-Pakistani Declaration of Tashkent on the withdrawal of troops, as distributed by Tass, the Soviet press agency:
The Melville Shoe Corporation, a manufacturer and retailer of footwear, announced here yesterday the election as vice presidents of Lawrence McGourty, Arthur B. Gold and Robert C. Kuhn.

The one consoling thought arising from the untimely death of Lal Bahadur Shastri is that it might inspire India and Pakistan to forge ahead with the reconciliation that he and President Ayub Khan had begun under Soviet auspices in Tashkent.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10--At 12:35 this afternoon. Thomas M. Rees raised his right hand as he stood in the well of the House of Representatives while the Democratic whip. Carl Albert, who is 12 inches shorter, addressed a few words to him.
Blyth Co., Inc., a major investment banking firm that became a member of the New York Stock Exchange. last year, announced major changes yesterday in its top management.
TEL AVIV, Jan. 10--Premier Levi Eshkol informed President Zalman Shazar tonight that he had succeeded in forming a new Government.

Harold Wilson finds himself in an unusual position at the conference of Commonwealth governments on the Rhodesian problem, which opens in Lagos today. This will be the first Commonwealth meeting held outside Britain, the first presided over by anyone but the British Prime Minister, the first called on the initiative of a government other than Britain.

TEL AVIV, Jan. 10--An unidentified prisoner in an Israel jail, who has become known as the "third man," ended a sixday hunger strike last weekend. He began his fast last Sunday to protest the Government's refusal to cancel the final third of his 10-year prison sentence for good behavior.

Immediate action on two marine personnel problems arising from the Vietnam emergencyrecreational facilities for American merchant seamen in Vietnam ports and steps to ease the shortage of skilled seamen --was urged here yesterday by Joseph Curran, president of the National Maritime Union.

The 36,000-acre 3-C Ranch near Oracle, Ariz., one of the state's largest, has been sold by Mrs. Theodore J. Vaitses of Boston to Mr. and Mrs. Delmar W. Rowe of Bloomington, Ill. Mrs. Vaitses bought the ranch in 1958 and had made many improvements. Mr. Rowe is a hotel owner and investor.
WINCHESTER, Mass., Jan. 10--Miss Nancy Lee Mallon and Lieut. (jg.) William C. Hetzel, U.S.N., plan to marry here in June.

BULAWAYO, Rhodesia, Jan. 10--The Rhodesian Government has closed all drought-stricken tribal areas in the country to outsiders without explanation. There were indications today that searing heat and months without significant rainfall had caused more devastation than had been generally kknown.
Drivers are urged not to bring cars into the congested parts of the city unless absolutely necessary. Those who do drive are urged to carry as many passengers as possible.

BONN, Jan. 10--The campaign by West German Catholic and Protestant churchmen for improved relations with Poland has suffered a severe setback because of the Polish Government's curbs on Cardinal Wyszynski.

RIDGEFIELD, Conn., Jan. 10 --Three youths charged with breach of the peace in connection with erecting signs on the property of Henry Luce were not prosecuted when they appeared in Danbury Circuit Court today. The charges were dropped at the request of Mr. Luce and the prosecutor, Albert Hornig.

My fellow New Yorker, I wish I could report to you that the strike against New York City's transit system has ended. Unfortunately for all of us, I cannot. The strike is not over. No settlement has been reached. As a result, the city tonight completes its 10th day without public transportation.

HELLS ANGELS will march down the stage of the Sullivan Street Playhouse this afternoon against a background of an oversize flag with airplanes flying through it and an off-stage taped voice singing "Over There."
A selected group of 20 undergraduates and recent alumni of Pratt Institute of Brooklyn have been commissioned to supply graphic ma- terials for the Repertory Theater of Lincoln Center.

David S. Jackson, who assumed the role of a self-appointed "conscience" of the American Stock Exchange in the period before its reorganization in 1962, was renominated yesterday for reelection to a second one-year term as the exchange's chairman.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 10-- W. Atlee Burpee, who retired about two years ago as vice president of the well-known mail-order seed company that bears the family name, died today at University Hospital. His age was 71.

The protracted battle over bankmerger legislation, which has been preoccupying the House Banking and Currency Committee since last summer, was as confused as ever yesterday--though there was some hope that an eventual compromise might be possible.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 10-- Morris L. Myers, a 43-year-old California lawyer, has been appointed general counsel of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service by William E. Simkin, the director.
CHICAGO, Jan. 10 (UPI)-- The Chicago Cubs of the National League acquired Wes Covington in exchange for Doug Clemens today in a swap of utility outfielders with the Philadelphia Phillies.

ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 10 (AP)--George Thomas Moore, for six years Assistant Secretary of Commerce during President Dwight D. Eisenhower's Administration, died in his sleep early today apparently of a heart attack. He was 67 years old.

Seventeen pickets paraded in front of the United States Courthouse in Foley Square yesterday in support of David H. Mitchell 3d, who was appealing his conviction for failing to report for military induction.

LINDEN, N. J., Jan. 10-- Harry J. Weiner of 1025 Hollywood Road, a lawyer for more than 50 years and a founder of the law firm of Weiner, Weiner and Glennon in Elizabeth, died yesterday at the Elizabeth General Hospital. His age was 76. was 76.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 10-- Some union officials are expressing concern privately that the New York transit strike is damaging labor's chances of legislative gains this year.

DEFENDERS are urged so insistently to play "sec- ond-hand low" that the rare exceptions are often overlooked. One class of such exceptions occurs when dummy leads a weak suit consisting of two or three small cards.

GLADWYNE, Pa., Jan. 10-- Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin J. Foster have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Patricia Jane Foster, to Richard Ford Hutchinson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Clyde B. Hutchinson of Meadowbrook.
IOWA CITY, Jan. 10 (UPI) --Chris Pervall and Gerry Jones scored 46 points between them tonight to give Iowa a 70-58 victory over Northwestern. It was the first Big Ten victory for Iowa.
WESTBURY, L. I., Jan. 10-- Bob Farrington, the leading driver during the first week of the Roosevelt Raceway meeting, was suspended tonight for five days.

The New York Telephone Company announced plans yesterday to spend $400-million on new plant and equipment this year, the second highest outlay's for capital expenditures in a year in the company's history.
Somebody has stolen the carillon from the Belgian Village at the World's Fair.
LAGOS, Nigeria, Jan. 10-- Word tonight of Mr. Shastri's death overshadowed all concern over Rhodesia at the Commonwealth leaders' conference opening here tomorrow.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., Jan. 10 --Homer Edgar Wickenden, for 37 years a leader in New York health and welfare organizational activities, died today in Lawrence Hospital after a long illness. He was 76 years old and lived for 30 years in Bronxville.
The election as vice presidents of W. Edward Boughton, Robert L. Lamphere and Arthur G. Weaver was announced yesterday in Boston by the John Hancock Mutual Life Insurance Company.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 10--Thousands of American and Australian troops have combed the South Vietnamese countryside in two large-scale sweeps, but have made little contact with the enemy. South Korean troops, however, reported killing almost 200 guerrillas.
The retirement of P. C. Spencer as chairman of the finance committee and as a director of the Sinclair Oil Corporation, effective Jan. 17, was announced yesterday.
The largest number of cars and trucks ever reported to have invaded Manhattan battled their way in during a morning crush yesterday that began at 4:30 A.M. and lasted six hours.
John G. Reed has been named president of the Lawson Manufacturing Company, a division of Amtel, Inc. He succeeds George H. Mettler, who recently became president of Amtel.

The Congress of Racial Equality began legal action yesterday to prevent the Board of Education from assigning excessive numbers of unlicensed and inexperienced teachers to predominantly Negro schools.
The Tennessee Gas Transmission Company's $150-million of bonds and convertible preferred stock, to be offered publicly today, appears headed for a quick sellout.
LOS ANGELES, Jan. 10 (UPI)--Michigan State won the Howard Jones Memorial football trophy as the nation's top college team today.

Gene Scott, the 12th-ranking player in the country and No. 1 in the East, will head the field in the Eastern indoor claycourt tennis championship starting Saturday, Jan. 22, at the Bergen Tennis Arena in Waldwick, N. J.
THE new caretaker Prime Minister of India, Gulzarilal Nanda, has been viewed by his associates as an intellectual and as something of an organizational genius who keeps things stirred up.
The steel industry weighed in for 1966 with all its heavyweight potential, with production taking a bid leap.

A San Diego saloon called Mickey Firm's, where as many as 500 persons at a time sip beer and sing Dixieland and other types of popular music played by the house band, will be the basis of a new television series over the National Broadcasting Company network. The saloon setting will be duplicated in a network studio in Burbank, Calif., where root beer will be substituted for regular beer.

BOSTON, Jan. 10 (UPI)-- Two injured Massachusetts fishermen were taken from a Russian fish processing vessel to a Coast Guard cutter 30 miles south of Martha's Vineyard today and then flown by helicopter for transfer to a Boston hospital.

Today is the second anniversary of the report of the Surgeon General of the United States Health Service that indicted smoking as dangerous to health. And today, more people are smoking more cigarettes than ever before.
Attended early morning Congressional prayer service at the National Presbyterian Church; welcomed a troop withdrawal agreement entered into by Pakistan and India; White House acknowl- ...

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 (UPI)--Representative Charles E. Bennett, Democrat of Florida, introduced a bill today to impose jail sentences of up to 10 years and $10,000 fines on persons interfering with military operations.

BABYLON, L. I., Jan 10-- Town Supervisor Gilbert C. Hanse proposed today that the Town of Babylon purchase the sprawling airfield formerly owned by the Republic Aircraft Corporation and operate it as an industrial air park.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10--The non-Communist affirmation required of certain applicants under the Medicare program was the first target of Congressional criticism today as the, second session of the 89th Congress opened.
THE search for the American past grows livelier all the time. If, as I believe, last year was an unusually rich one in the field, 1966 promises to be even better.
BECKLEY, W. Va., Jan. 10-- Earl Stafford is a slender man with iron-gray, crew-cut hair and the unmistakable "miner's mascara" of soft-coal dust in the lashes around his hazel eyes.
ADELBODEN, Switzerland, Jan. 10 (AP)--Billy Kidd of Stowe, Vt., flashed to a major skiing victory today with a triumph in the Adelboden giantslalom meeting.
Richard C. Patterson Jr. resigned yesterday his unpaid post as Commissioner of Public Events and will become an adviser to City Council President Frank D. O'Connor.

With his bold speech last night Mayor Lindsay has struck at the fiction that the paralyzing and illegal transit strike is in its essence just another normal labor dispute. As the Mayor justly contended, it contains many elements of a cynical conspiracy by New York's "power brokers" to undo the results of the municipal election and to reassert their stranglehold over the community.

Department-store sales on an annual basis are exptected to rise about $10 billion to $35 billion by 1970, with a larger percentage of total volume going to the bigger retail organizations; the country's merchants were told yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 (AP) --Forty-five representatives of the copper industry have been invited to meetings at the Department of Commerce tomorrow to discuss the copper supply situation, a spokesman said today.

PARIS, Jan. 10 (UPI)-- Jacques Marty of France landed a solid right hook in the fourth round to open a cut below Ferd Hernandez's right eye and went on to win a 10round decision over the favored Las Vegas boxer tonight.
Prime Minister Bahadur Shastri of India, who died last night in Tashkent at the age of 61, did not look like the leader of the world's most populous democracy.

A study of this country's regulation of deep-sea shipping engaged in ocean commerce is getting under way this month under the auspices of the United Nations Conference on Trade and Development. Canadian regulation will also be included.
Charles G. Moerdler, the city's new Buildings Commissioner, spent much of yesterday on the telephone with landlords whose buildings were reported low on heat during the weekend cold spell.
SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., Jan. 10--Fairleigh Dickinson withstood a Seton Hall rally to win, 83--77, tonight. It was the Knights' eighth triumph in 12 starts and the Pirates' sixth loss in nine games.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10--For fear of upsetting its current peace offensive, the Johnson Administration is deliberately refraining from any immediate punitive action against Staughton Lynd for traveling to North Vietnam.

TOTAL disaster struck the Judson Church in Wash ington Square last night. Correction: Total nothingness struck the Judson Church in Washington Square last night, struck it with the squelchy ignominy of a tomato against a pointless target.

The Rockwell-Standard Corporation, a producer of automotive and heavy duty parts, announced yesterday in Pittsburgh the appointment of Donald S. MacLeod to the new post of vice president and general counsel.

SEATTLE, Jan. 10 (API)-- A Seattle architectural firm has completed plans for a $1.2-million Pacific war memorial on Corregidor Island, designed to commemorate American World War II battles in the western Pacific.
Reg Fleming, who used to beat up the Rangers, joined them yesterday.
PARIS, Jan. 10--The "Ben Barka mystery" has suddenly come to life again, provoking new newspaper speculation and the ire of the top Gaullist officials.
Nell Rankin sang Amneris and Jess Thomas was Radames, both for the First time this season, in the Metropolitan Opera's "Aida" last night.

Bobby Winkles of Arizona State and John Winkin of Colby College were named coach of the year for baseball in the university and college divisions by their colleagues at the annual convention of the American Association of College Baseball Coaches.

KEENS, N. H., Jan. 10--Mr. and Mrs. John Patterson Wright have announced the engagement of Mrs. Wright's daughter, Miss Joslin Colony Kimball, to Richard Frank, son of Mrs. Charles W. Frank of New York and the late Mr. Frank. June nuptials are planned.

A pageant of Polish kings and queens will be staged for the 10th annual Polonaise Ball on Jan. 29 at the Sheraton-East Hotel. As before, festivities will begin with the promenade dancing of the traditional Polonaise. The Polish Mutual Assistance, Inc., will be the beneficiary.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 10 (UPI)--George Allen, the defensive coach of the Chicago Bears, was appointed head coach of the Los Angeles Rams today in a move aimed at trying to rebuild the National Football League team.
ALBANY, Jan. 10--For the first time, a Negro was named today to a leadership post in the state Legislature.
DETROIT, Jan. 10--A research engineer described today development of an experimental carburetor to cut exhaust fumes on automobiles.
There was a sudden and surprise shift to youth at the helm of the Latrobe Steel Company yesterday.

MADRID, Jan. 10 (UPI)-- Jan-Erik Lundquist of Sweden beat Manuel Santana, 7-5, 11-9, to win the inauguration trophy of the Real Madrid Sports Pavilion yesterday. Lundquist had downed Jose Luis Arilla, 10-8, 6-3, in the semi-final Saturday.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Tuesday, Jan, 11 (UPI)--President Sukarno ordered today the expulsion of all American newsmen from Indonesia.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 10--The National Crime Commission will open a two-day meeting here tomorrow to work out a detailed agenda for its study of crime problems.
NEW HAVEN, Jan. 10--Curt von Faber du Faur, retired professor and curator of Yale University's Collection of German Literature, died today at his home at 164 Linden Street. He was 75 years old.
LOS ANGELES, Jan. 10 (AP) --Both teams held their first workouts today for the 16th annual National Football League Pro Bowl game on Sunday.
CASTLE POINT, N. Y., Jan. 10--The American Air Force general in charge of treating South Vietnamese casualties of the war in Vietnam visited 56 of them today in a paraplegic ward in Dutchess County.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10--An ugly development of the nineteen-sixties is the alarming decline in the caliber of public villains. Since Nikita Khrushchev was deposed there has not been a respectable three-star villain on the international scene.

New York City is in the vanguard of American cities trying to improve conditions that have led to race riots in the Watts area of Los Angeles, Rochester and Harlem in recent years, Mrs. Constance Baker Motley, Borough President of Manhattan, declared yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 10-- President Johnson said today that the death of Prime Minister Lal Bahadur Shastri of India was "a grievous blow to the hopes of mankind for peace and progress."
The striking Transport Workers Union originally asked for an over-all money package that the Transit Authority estimated would cost $680-million over a two-year period.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 10-- Nine major manufacturers of book matches and four of their executives were indicted today on charges of engaging in a criminal conspiracy to fix prices.

WASHINGTON, Jan.--10 (UPI)--The African Kingdom of Burundi ordered today the expulsion of the United States Ambassador, Donald A. Dumont and two of his staff members for alleged contact with antiGovernment conspirators.
The Radio Corporation of America has found a partner for its avowed interest in the book-publishing business.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 (UPI) --President Johnson and Vice President Humphrey attended the annual Congressional prayer service today at the National Presbyterian church. A number of Congressmen also attended.

LAGOS, Nigeria, Jan. 10-- Prime Minister Wilson will unveil before the British Commonwealth a three-point plan to end the rebellion in Rhodesia and to direct Rhodesia on the path toward eventual rule by the black majority.
Should there ever be a sudden popular demand for a pocket guide called "How to Make a Movie in Egypt on $38,000 a Day," Julian Blaustein is ready to write it.
BOWIE, Md., Jan. 10 (UPI) --Mr. Judex won a stretch duel from Bay Hawk at Bowie today and captured the $11,000 E. Palmer Heagerty Purse by a neck.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 10-- College football coaches expressed a desire today to change a rule so that "one player be allowed to speak on the sidelines with the coach during a charged time out."
A scheduled boycott of classes at St. John's University yesterday failed to disrupt classes, the university administration said.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 (UPI)--The Senate Republican leader, Everett McKinley Dirksen of Illinois, received a big kiss, a red rose and a "Fountain of Youth" floral bouquet today from Senator Margaret Chase Smith of Maine.

LONDON, Jan. 10 (AP)-- Colin Chapman, the 37-year-old designer of the Lotus Ford racing car that won the Indianapolis 500 classic for Britain, received the Ferodo Trophy tonight as the "Commonwealth's most outstanding contributor to motor racing."

MOSCOW, Jan. 10--Soviet authorities are apparently taking a long and serious look at what Russian women have been wearing all these years. The upshot is that the fashion industry seems to be on the verge of better days in the Soviet Union.

WHITE PLAINS, Jan. 10-- Philip J. Livaccari, the Republican commissioner of Westchester County's bipartisan Board of Elections, died today at Boynton Beach, Fla. He was 51 years old and lived at 15 Bryant Crescent here. He had suffered a heart attack Dec. 23 while visiting a brother in Florida.
Thousands of striking transit Workers and their sympathizers picketed City Hall for 90 minutes yesterday and then at- tended a rally nearby, cheering their leaders and booing Mayor Lindsay.

The race for the Congressional seat vacated by Mayor Lindsay brought yesterday a nomination acceptance speech by one candidate, an opening statement by a new candidate and a legal move by a third to postpone the election because of the transit strike.

GENEVA, Jan. 10--Western Europe's exporters have gained on those of the United States in the competition for markets in the underdeveloped countries, according to a report by the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., Jan. 10 (UPI)--Defending champion Michigan scored an 88-68 victory over Indiana tonight in a Big Ten basketball game. The triumph was the Wolverines' second against no losses in conference play.

Retailers were told yesterday that it was urgent that they be in daily newspaper communication with all of their customers --indeed, with their entire communities. It seems that people have short memories.
DETROIT, Jan. 10 (AP)-- The tempo of American auto production picked up this week as the industry continued toward its goal of a new high in January output.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 (UPI)--The Senate sergeant-atarms, Joseph C. Duke, retired from his $27,500 post today. His deputy, Robert G. Dunphy, was chosen by the Democratic leadership as his successor

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10--The University of Houston received one of the most severe punishments ever handed down by the National Collegiate Athletic Association when its football program was placed on probation today for three years for violations involving recruiting, financial aid to players and out-ofseason practice.
MIAMI, Jan. 10 (AP)--Herbert Allen's Ambitious Lady was up in the final stride to win a three-horse blanket finish in the feature race today at Tropical Park before a crowd of 10,404.
Nearly 8,000 persons stepped into unemployment insurance offices in the city yesterday and filled out claims for benefits-- a 50 per cent rise over last year at this time.
A confused pattern prevailed throughout most of the stock market's abbreviated session yesterday, but at the close most indicators were up slightly. Trading was brisk.

Bennett Cerf, chairman of Random House, Inc., said yesterday he saw the merger of the book-publishing company with the Radio Corporation of America as a move fitting in "with the revolution in education that is expected in the next 10 years with audio-visual instructional aids, television and computers used to grade tests."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10-- Two names long familiar in the halls of Congress were back on the rolls today: Senator Harry Flood Byrd, Democrat of Virginia, and Representative Clarence J. Brown, Republican of Ohio.

Injuries have struck Sam Perry of Fordham and Larry Furnell of St. John's, two of the nation's leading collegiate runners. Perry probably will run this weekend, but Furnell is sidelined for a week or two.

The Police Department has designated the following areas in Manhattan, the Bronx, Queens and Brooklyn as places where persons who have arranged car pools may pick up and discharge their passengers tomorrow. Parking will not be permitted in these areas. In addition, municipal off-street parking lots have been designated as staging areas in the Bronx, Queens, and Brooklyn.
The New York and American Stock Exchanges announced yesterday that "for the duration" of the city's transit strike they will close daily at 2 P.M., one and a half hours earlier than normal.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10--The grand total of official monetary reserves in the non-Communist world rose in the third quarter of last year but remained below the level at the end of 1964, the International Monetary Fund reported today.
THE Mods and the Rockers may have shaken the British fashion establishment right out of its flowered georgette, but the children still look like children.
The H. J. Heinz Company announced yesterday a realignment of its top executive staff.
NEW HAVEN, Jan. 10--Mr. Lynd said here today that the "physical withdrawal of American troops" need not precede negotiations to end the war in Vietnam.
HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Jan. 10-- Hofstra scored its third basketball Victory in the Metropolitan Conference tonight by defeating St. Francis, 99-86.
MOSCOW, Jan. 10 (Reuters) The Communist party news paper Pravda said today that there was now a real responsibility of concluding a treaty to stop the spread of nuclear weapons.
Stock prices on the London Stock Exchange were steady yesterday at the close of a slow trading session as narrow gains predominated.
The selection of new officers and directors was announced yesterday by several banks in the United States.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y. Jan. 10--Secretary General Thant led the diplomatic community today in expressing sorrow over the death of Prime Minister Shastri.

THERE are 8,815,000 widows in the United States, almost one-third of them between the ages of 35 and 64. The wealthiest, most fashionable and influential of them congregate in New York and its environs.
In relatively quiet trading in the commodities markets, some futures contracts made new highs yesterday. Gains were especially notable in copper and soybeans during the session.

TORONTO, Jan. 10--Canadians lost control of almost all their production of canned foods, prescription drugs and surgical dressings last year as foreign companies continued their piecemeal take-over of Canadian industry.

PITTSBURGH, Jan, 10-- Lieut. Gov. Raymond P. Shafer apparently clinched the gubernatorial nomination today with an unusual display of nonstop campaigning and the endorse ment of Gov. William W. Scranton.
Record sales and earnings were reported yesterday by the PneumoDynamics Corporation for the fiscal year ended Nov. 30.
Lal Bahadur Shastri died at a pinnacle of popularity that no one in India, believed possible when he succeeded the late Jawaharlal Nehru as Prime Minister barely 19 months ago.

LONDON, Jan. 10--Barclays Bank jumped into the booming credit-card business today with the announcement that it will start its own "Barclaycard" system in competition with the British Diners' Club and American Express.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 10-- Bill D. Moyers, the Presidential press secretary, says that news conferences are designed to serve the "convenience of the President, not the convenience of the press."
Mayor Lindsay is holding up submission of his administration's requests for expanded state aid in fear of complicating the already involved efforts to settle the transit strike.
ALBANY, Jan. 10--Governor Rockefeller disclosed today that he would seek an $11.6million budget increase to expand the Mate's program for care of the mentally retarded.

LONDON, Jan. 10 (AP)-- Bryan W. Newkirk, a former Toronto stockbroker, indicted by a Federal grand jury in New York on charges of income tax evasion, died here Saturday night after a heart attack. He was 77 years old.
The economic impact of the transit strike is now being felt across the country and is expected to be felt by businessmen here long after the strike is settled.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 10-- The Treasury bill rate rose substantially at today's auction, the Treasury disclosed tonight.

STAMFORD, Conn., Jan. 10-- Miss Elizabeth Hervey Mygatt, daughter of Mrs. Royal Elting Mygatt and the late Mr. Mygatt, was married here Saturday to Dr. Ruprecht Nitschke, son of Mrs. Alfred Nitschke of Tubingen, Germany, and the late Dr. Nitschke.

Alert investors have been getting much higher yields since the Federal Reserve raised interest rates in December. But buyers of savings bonds from the United States Treasury still receive just 3 per cent on their purchases. Thus the Treasury is, in effect, shortchanging savings bond buyers, who are mainly people in the low-and middle-income brackets.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 (UPI)--Airman 3/c Patrick J. Nugent, fiance of Luci Baines Johnson, reported for duty today with the District of Columbia Air National Guard at Andrews Air Force Base, just outside Washington.

ATLANTA, Jan. 10--The Georgia House of Representatives tonight barred Julian Bond, a Negro pacifist, from its membership because of his criticism of the United States military action in Vietnam. The vote was 184 to 12.

MOSCOW, Jan. 10--The Soviet Union's economic growth rate, which has been declining steadily for a number of years, bounced back in 1964 substantially more than was originally reported, according to final figures just issued.

DARIEN, Conn., Jan. 10-- Mrs. Mercedes Crimmins Challinor, long a ranking Red Cross official, died of a stroke yesterday at her home on Long Neck Point in Noroton. She was 78 years old and was the widow of David Challinor, a real-estate man.
Thomas V. Daley, a vice president of the New York Telephone Company, died Sunday at his home, 40 Ridge Street, Eastchester, N. Y., after a short illness. He was 61 years old.
NEW DELHI, Tuesday, Jan. 11--Gulzarilal Nanda, 67-yearold Home Minister in the Cabinet of Lal Bahadur Shastri, was sworn in early this morning as caretaker Prime Minister.

CINCINNATI, Jan, 10--The Rev. Fred L. Shuttlesworth, a national leader in the Negroes' civil rights campaign, announced today that he would resign as pastor of Revelation Baptist Church here by May 1.

The Irving Trust Company. New York, reported yesterday records in assets, deposits, and loans. But net operating earnings, largely because of a 46 per cent increase in interest paid on deposits and other funds, failed by a small margin to best the earnings record set in 1960, when deposits were about 30 per cent below present levels.

MINEOLA, L. I., Jan. 10--A plan to marshal all the resources of Nassau County to fight the growing problem of narcotics addiction was announced today by Michael N. Petito, head of the County Task Force on Narcotics.
KUNGKWAN, Taiwan, Jan. 10--United States military forces based on Taiwan will expand their role from defense of this island to operational support of the Vietnam war effort in the next few weeks.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 10--The small band of Congressional Republicans returned to the 89th Congress today amid much more encouraging political conditions than those existing when the first session began.

HATTIESBURG, Miss., Jan. 10 (UPI)--Vernon Dahmer, a 58-year-old Negro civil rights leader, died late today of burns suffered when nightriders unleashed a pre-dawn firebomb attack on his home and his grocery store.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 10-- United States manufacturers have agreed, at the request of the State Department, to discontinue imports of asbestos and lithium from Rhodesia.

BOSTON, Jan. 10--Miss Nancy Ellen Coleman and A. Heaton Robertson 3d plan to marry in March. Mr. and Mrs. John Joseph Coleman have announced the engagement of their daughter to the son of Mrs. Raynham Townshend Jr. of New Haven and A. Heaton Robertson 2d of Coral Gables, Fla., formerly of Stamford, Conn.

TOKYO, Jan, 10--Initialing of a Japanese-Soviet civil aviation agreement opening the way for commercial flights across Siberia between Tokyo and Moscow was postponed today because of differences over wording of the final draft.

Duke's high-flying basketball team, riding the crest of a ninegame victory streak, maintained its No. 1 position in the United Press International's weekly college basketball ratings yesterday with 28 first-place votes.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 (UPI) --The Post Office Department announced today that it planned to raise rates charged for its money-losing money orders, insurance, and registered, certified and C.O.D. mail.

TASHKENT, U.S.S.R., Tuesday, Jan. 11--prime Minister Lal Bahadur Shastri of India died here early today of a heart attack a few hours after he had signed a troop-withdrawal accord with President Mohammad Ayub Khan of Pakistan. Mr Shastri was 61 years old.
BALTIMORE, Jan. 11 (AP) Dr. Eli Kennerly Marshall Jr., a leading medical researcher, died today at the Johns Hopkins Hospital. He was 76 years old.

Mayor Lindsay said yesterday it seemed to "make good sense" to follow former Mayor Wagner's practice in having prospective appointees examined for possible conflict of interest by the Board of Ethics before they are put to work.
Does Asphalt College represent the wave of the future?
The long-argued conversion of Fifth and Madison Avenues to one-way streets will start at 6 A.M. Friday seven weeks ahead of schedule to ease congestion caused by the transit strike.
Robert Edgar Herman of 32 East 64th Street, secretary, general counsel and a director of Tishman Realty Construction Co., Inc., died yesterday in Mount Sinai Hospital. His age was 51.

Marshall W. Acker, former vice president and director of Olin Industries, Inc., died Monday of acute leukemia in Carmel, Calif., where he maintained a winter home. He resided in East Jordan, Mich. He was 78 years old.
Only 6 of the 38-man crew of the Spanish freighter Monte Palomares were taken alive yesterday from the storm-tossed North Atlantic as an intense search for 20 others continued into the night.

ALGIERS, Jan. 11 A Vietcong source here hinted strongly today that if the United States agreed to negotiate directly with the National Liberation Front in South Vietnam, demands for the withdrawal of American troops prior to peace negotiations might be dropped.
Columbia University ran into a zone defense last night in the Fordham University gymnasium that almost, but not quite, brought down Jack Rohan's team.

Lawyers for the Transit Authority, the Transport Workers Union and the city were lined up on the same side yesterday over a taxpayer's effort to invoke provisions of the CondonWadlin Act, which prohibits strikes by public employes.

William Alfred, 43-year-old Harvard professor of English, whose play, "Hogan's Goat," is an Off Broadway hit, will have another play on the boards soon. The next is his treatment of "Agamemnon," Aeschylus's tragedy.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 Secretary of the Interior Stewart L. Udall and Secretary of Agriculture Orville L. Freeman were among 33 members of the Cabinet and Congress honored at the National Collegiate Athletic Association's annual luncheon today. Each of the 33 Government figures was a letter-winning athlete in his college days.
CHICAGO, Jan. 11 (UPI) George Halas, the owner-coach of the Chicago Bears, filed a suit today to stop George Allen, an assistant coach, from becoming head coach of the Los Angeles Rams.

The engagement of Miss Susans Salas, daughter of Hector M. Salas of Buenos Aires and Mrs. Susana Sundblad de Salas of Buenos Aires and 165 East 72d Street, to John Duncan Mackinnon, son of Mr. and Mrs. Duncan Mackinnon, of Swinbrock House in Burford, England, has been announced in London.
The Seafarers International Union of Canada announced yesterday that its new constitution had been overwhelmingly approved by the union's membership.
"Paul," I said to my son, home from Deerfield Academy for a long weekend, "I'll be in bed when you get home, but I'll call you for breakfast."
LAGOS, Nigeria, Jan. 11 Britain's handling of the Rhodesian rebellion was strongly criticized at the opening of the British Commonwealth conference here today.

SAIGON, Jan. 11--Senator Jacob K. Javits told United States combat troops today that he was confident Congress would approve an increased defense budget and that there was a "good likelihood" of a G.I. Bill of Rights for Vietnam veterans.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., Jan. 11 (A.P)--Robert Lindley Ziegfeld of Scarsdale, executive vice president of the Lead Industries Association, died today at Lawrence Hospital here after a brief illness. He was 61 years old.
OBERLIN, Ohio Oberlin College will expand its summer language sessions abroad this year to include a Russian program in Moscow for the first time.
MIAMI, Jan. 11 (AP) Blacksmiths in South Florida tracks refused today to follow the State Racing Commission's order to be fingerprinted.
Life may begin at 40 for many, but to an electrical engineer, physicist or other specialized scientist, 40 is often the age of agonizing reappraisal.
Three Ivy League institutions and a Middle Western university have joined forces to provide a summer field studies program in Latin-American culture.
A fight for control of the Crucible Steel Company of America emerged as a distinct possibility yesterday.
There are apparently no court desicions interpreting the power of a legislative body to bar or expel a member, legal experts said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11-- President Johnson said today that he was "determined to press ahead in building the Great Society" in his new budget while at the same time meeting United States commitments in Vietnam.

A ZESTY, authoritative curry powder has been packaged straight from the grinder in small foil envelopes to retain the freshness of the flavor. It comes from Lawrence Curry of Washington and is said to be made according to a Lawrence family recipe brought from Jamaica nearly 150 years ago.
Serge Varangot, manager of the stock market department of the Banque de Paris et des Pays-Bas of Paris, has been elected a director of the Madison Fund.
Paperboard production fell 1.9 per cent to 334,200 tons in the week ended Jan. 8 from the level in the corresponding 1965 week, the National Paperboard Associates reported yesterday.
The nationwide movement to unionize public school teachers went into high gear last year but ran into a number of roadblocks set up by the National Education Association.
A 21-year-old member of the Catholic Worker Movement pleaded guilty before a Federal judge yesterday to a charge of wilfully burning his draft card at a Union Square rally last Nov. 6.
The Port of New York Authority moved yesterday to hasten adoption of the much-delayed Aldene plan to speed rail service for 12,000 New Jersey commuters.

Alternate-side parking rules are suspended. However, other parking regulations will be strictly enforced. Fines for double parking at hydrants, previously $15, and for parking at crosswalks, previously $5, will be $35 beginning today.

LONDON Between now and 1980 as many young people will go to British universities as have done so in the last 800 years, according to Lord Bowden, former principal of the Manchester College of Advanced Technology.
L. Greif Bro., an apparel manufacturing division of Genesco, Inc., announced here yesterday the election of Henry M. Stern Jr. as a vice president.
Remembrance of things past, appreciation of deeds gone by and high hopes for the future marked the New York Shakespeare Festival's observance of its 12th anniversary yesterday.
ST. LOUIS, Jan. 11 Dr. and Mrs. Edward J. Becker have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Susan Thomas Becker, to Carl Alfred Chase, son of Mr. and Mrs. E. Dixwell Chase of Wilton, Conn.

LONDON, Jan. 11 The pirate radio ship Radio London, anchored about three and a half miles off Walton-on-the-Naze in the North Sea, broke her moorings in heavy seas and was reported drifting today. Later it was reported that she had succeeded in dropping an anchor.

There was a time, only a few years ago, when getting a Ph.D. was almost a lifelong project, or at least one at 10 or 15 years. But more and more universities are finding they can no longer afford this leisurely approach to graduate studies, and are devising ways to speed the process.
Plans for a $3-million, 25acre shopping center at Torrington, Conn., with Sears, Roebuck Co., as its major tenant, have been announced by the First Hartford Realty Corporation of Manchester, Conn.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 The Food and Drug Administration directed manufacturers of longacting sulfa drugs today to place a warning on the labels of these products that their use might induce possibly fatal side-effects.

MOSCOW, Jan. 11 (UPI) Tass. the Soviet press agency, contended today that more than 200 passengers were reported killed when American helicopters sank a South Vietnamese passenger ship and fired rockets at would-be rescuers ashore.
Two maverick Democrats on the City Council accused their party leadership yesterday of favoritism in committee assignments. But the Council overrode their protests and approved the assignments.
Education has entered the lull after the storm. Local crises are, of course, still erupting. But many violent national controversies have given way to reform efforts.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia Throughout Communist Europe, where large-scale economic reforms are under way, there is also talk of educational reform.
George W. Mead 2d was elected yesterday as the president and chief executive officer of Consolidated Papers, Inc., a producer of enamel printing paper, paperboard and corrugated containers.

Mrs. Inga Lohne Brauner, former president of the American Physical Therapy Association, died Sunday in Ithaca, N.Y. where she lived. She was the widow of Olaf M. Brauner, professor emeritus of fine arts at Cornell University.

BUFFALO, Jan. 11 Mr. and Mrs. George Pennock Urban Jr. have announced the engagement of their daughter. Miss Anne Louise Urban, to Edwin James Brooks Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Brooks of North Wales, Pa.

JAMES GALANOS, the inventive California-based de signer whose flair for the dramatic regularly impresses other American designers, fashion reporters, the stores and his devoted customers, showed his spring and summer collection here yesterday.

Mr. and Mrs. Hans Dahl of Copenhagen have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Susanne Dahl, to Jack Christopher Kahn. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Kahn of Longboat, Key, Sarasota, Fla.

BRUSSELS, Jan. 11 (AP) The Common Market's top leaders told the United States today that a minimum of another four more months was needed before the group could resume trade negotiations on tariff cuts.
NEW DELHI, Wednesday, Jan. 12 The body of Prime Minister Lal Bahadur Shastri of India was cremated today in Hindu rites at the holy Jumna River.

Few topics in the academic world excite more varied comment from teachers, students and parents than the highly controversial subject of homework.

DOROTHY SARNOFF breezed into the room that serves as her class at Alexander's (59th Street and Lexington Avenue) wearing a turquoise heather tweed skirt and coat from Ben Zuckerman and a matching hat in the same fabric made for her by her old friend Emme.

The Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith announced yesterday it had filed a complaint with the Justice Department against a Southern resort hotel, the Cloister of Sea Island, Ga., for "religious discrimination in violation of Title II of the Civil Rights Act of 1964."
The Consolidated Foods Corporation expects to receive about $65-million from the planned sale of its supermarket operations, William Howlett, president, said yesterday.
If winter's precipitation so far is any indication, the Northeast faces another long, dry summer in 1966.

In a nation of linguistic incompetents, attempts at bilingual education seem extraordinarily ambitious if not unrealistic. Nevertheless, converts to the cause are being won in the United States from two directions.

Finals in the annual benefit backgammon tournament for the Children's Cancer Fund of America will be held tomorrow at the Metropolitan Club, 1 East 60th Street.

Nathan P. Feinsinger, chairman of the special mediation panel, said early today that the panel would inform Mayor Lindsay late this morning of the procedures it believes should be followed to resolve the deadlocked transit dispute.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 National Airport, one of the world's busiest, will finally be b opened to some jet airline traffic on April 24.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Jan. 11 Copenhagen rejoiced today over the news that Tina Wiegels had been found alive and well. The three-month-old baby was taken four weeks ago from her carriage outside a department store.

WASHINGTON Last April 29, the Office of Education began an ambitious task the desegregation of several thousand school districts in the South. The North, like the South, has had almost 12 years to accustom itself to the idea of Negroes going to school with whites. As in the South, the actual removal of racial barriers continues at a snail's pace.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 Camp Kilmer, a Job Corps center recently accused of having "flagrant deficiencies," now has the most serious dropout problem of the entire national youth retraining program.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 The Justice Department filed its first suits today against school districts that have submitted desegregation plans for receipt of Federal funds but are allegedly failing to live up to them.
NEW DELHI The "haphazard and unplanned" expansion of India's educational system is worrying the country's educators.
DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., Jan. 11 The Daytona In ternational Speedway is preparing for its forthcoming 24hour Continental race, to be run on Saturday and Sunday, Feb. 5 and 6.
MADRID The Spanish university, rich in great traditions but long suffering from a deep academic crisis, is gradually becoming the crucible of Spain's political change.

BUFFALO, Jan. 11 Mr. and Mrs. D. King Donaldson have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Lynne Donaldson of New York, to Lieut. Lee I. Niedringhaus 3d, U.S.A. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Lee I. Niedringhaus of St. Louis and Nantucket, Mass.
November contracts for future construction in New York State totaled $330,711,000, an increase of 17 per cent over November, 1964, according to the F.W. Dodge Company, a division of McGraw-Hill.

A DECLARER who finds a defender with four trumps is often inconvenienced but not necessarily defeated. There is a tendency in the bidding for players to misjudge the playing value of four cards in the opponents' suit. With four small cards, in particular, the average player overvalues his defensive potential and undervalues his hand in attack.

A BEAUTIFUL documentary, intellectually en grossing and visually fascinating, was fashioned by the Columbia Broadcasting System's news division from Ernie Bradford's book "Ulysses Found." It was presented in color last night under the title "The Search for Ulysses" and without the slightest doubt it will stand as one of television's finest explorations of the past.

N.Y. STOCK EXCHANGE Stocks advanced slightly, with TV, airline, rail and a variety of glamour issues strongest in heavy trading; volume 8.91 million shares.

New York City, like almost every other major metropolitan center in the country, is steering a careful course between the Scylla of slow growth in its teaching force and the Charybdis of a burgeoning school population.
The New York University swimming team lost to Southern Connecticut State, 56-39, at N.Y.U.'s Quigley Pool yesterday.
The New York Rangers, who dearly need hockey players, lost one yesterday.

CLEARFIELD, Utah, Jan. 11 (AP) Fifty carloads of gifts for the South Vietnamese, originally intended as Christmas presents, are still held up at the Federal supply center in northern Utah and probably will be for some time.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., Jan. 11 Mrs. Grace Lerner Golat, coordinator of the Rutgers Human Relations Workshop for Community Leaders at Rutgers University, New Brunswick, died yesterday of cancer at Beth Israel Hospital, Newark. The wife of Solomon Golat, a Newark lawyer, she was 53 years old and lived at 2 Laurel Place here.

Standing alone at the intersection of Third Avenue and 18th Street at 4 P. M. yesterday, Policewoman Saundra Miller gestured timidly, as if she were trying to catch a waiter's eye, at the solidly packed northbound traffic.

TOKYO, Jan. 12 (AP) Premier Chou En-lai of Communist China sent a message of condolence to President Sarvepalli Radhakrishnan of India today on the death of Prime Minister Lal Bahadur Shastri, a Peking broadcast said.

The election of Meyer Melnikoff as senior vice president and actuary of the Prudential Insurance Company of America was announced yesterday in Newark.
President Johnson's State of the Union Message to a joint session of Congress will be broadcast live tonight at 9 o'clock on radio and television. The major network telecasts will be in color.

The Democratic and Republican candidates for the 17th Congressional District seat vacated by Mayor Lindsay have asked the Liberal party for its nomination.
Speculative enthusiasm again dominated trading as the stock market advanced slightly yesterday.

PARIS Harold Wilson's Lagos meeting with Commonwealth Prime Ministers hopes to find a way out of the Rhodesian impasse and, indeed, to face the fundamental problems of a disintegrating, race-conscious Africa. The meeting underscores one of the twentieth century's unexpected lessonsnamely, it is much harder to decolonize than to colonize.

HOLLYWOOD, Jan. 11 William Wyler, one of the nation's most prestigious film directors, said today he hoped he would never again have to make a picture in Hollywood, and instead would concentrate his work abroad.

BLOOMFIELD, N.J., Jan. 11 Mr. and Mrs. Murray Apfelbaum Jr. have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Lynn Carol Apfelbaum, to Michael Jochnowitz, son of Mr. and Mrs. Sydney Jochnowitz of Patchogue, L.I.
KARACHI, Pakistan, Jan. 11 The death of Prime Minister Lal Bahadur Shastri of India in Tashkent today left Pakistanis wondering about their country's future relations with India.

BERLIN, Jan. 11 Two American servicemen and three German civilians have been arrested in West Berlin for having unlawfully used United States Army uniforms to help two East Germans flee to the West, officials said today.

Macy's New York announced yesterday that it would have a major preview exhibition area and promotion in conjunction with the Universal and International Exhibition Expo '67, to be held in Montreal next year.

"MALCOLM," Edward Albee's dramatization of James Purdy's novel, which opened last night at the Shubert, is an exquisite production. The triumphs are those of the setting and lighting and costume designers, of some of the actors, and of the director. Mr. Albee's contribution predictably literate and occasionally amusing is not, in its own terms, up to the level of their work.

MOSCOW, Jan. 11 (Reuters) Premier Pham Van Dong of North Vietnam delivered an apparent rebuttal today of Chinese Communist charges that the Soviet Union was conniving with the United States against the interests of Hanoi and the Vietcong.
LONDON, Jan. 11 (UPI) Three British champions Brian Curvis, Johnny Pritchett and Alan Rudkin scored victories over foreign opponents in an all-star boxing card at Royal Albert Hall tonight.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 11 (AP) Angel Cordero proved himself a superior mud rider today as he scored a triple in a constant rain over a sloppy race track. All his winners were longshots.

TRENTON, Jan. 11 Gov. Richard J. Hughes appeared before the 190th session of the Legislature after it convened, today and put forth the most ambitious and expensive program for government in the state's history.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Jan. 11 The Pennsylvania Republican Executive Committee endorsed this afternoon a ticket headed by Lieut. Gov. Raymond P. Shafer for Governor in the May 17 primary election.
