GUATEMALA, Jan. 12 A series of kidnappings of wealthy Guatemalans by Communistleaning terrorists has aroused fear in the business community, has further undermined confidence in the Guatemalan military regime and has strengthened doubts about Guatemala's latest effort to establish constitutional government.
A law professor warned yesterday against a possible increase in crimes of violence if a proposal to compensate the victims became law.
CAMDEN, N.J., Jan, 14 (AP) (AP) Burglars chiseled their way into a Camden retail fur shop and took an estimated $100,000 worth of mink pieces the police reported today.
Hallandale, Fla., Jan. 14 (UPI) Allan Roberts, a lyricist, died of a heart attack today at a local hospital. He was 62 years old.

RICHARD Strauss's "Salome," which was newly produced by the Metropolitan opera last season, returned yesterday evening to the opera house in all its decadent Oriental splendor, with Birgit Nilsson again singing the title role.
The Fruehauf Corporation announced yesterday the sale of its Strick trailer division to the newly formed Strick Trailer Corporation for $39 million.

Peter E. Bennett, who retired in 1955 as a vice president of the Manufacturers Trust Company, died yesterday in Holy Family Hospital, Brooklyn, after a short illness. He was 76 years old and lived at 242 82d Street, Brooklyn.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 Artificial gills, as described in a patent granted this week, enable man for the first time to breathe under water like a fish. To prove

MONTE CARLO, Monaco, Jan. 14 (Reuters) Cars set out from various points in Europe today for what seemed certain to be a slip-and-slither drive to the Mediterranean in the Monte Carlo Rally. Routes from all points cover about 1,800 miles.
SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Jan. 14 The possibility that Rhodesia's high courts might be closed was raised today in a case challenging the legality of Rhodesia's independence.
ANN ARBOR, Mich., Jan. 14 (AP) Dr. Arthur Pound, author, historian and former journalist, died in an Ann Arbor hospital today after a long illness. He was 81 years old.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 Officials at Howard University said today that a computer had turned up evidence of cheating on examinations.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 Groups of Negro Democrats will meet tomorrow at opposite ends of the country to advance the nomination of more Negres for major offices in this year's state elections.
DAMASCUS, Syria, Jan. 14 Damascus, which proclaims itself the oldest continuously inhabited place in the world, is a city of conservative social habits and revolutionary governments.
Every year at this time, members of New York's film-importing community start grumbling about the rules defining eligible entries for the foreignlanguage Oscar award.
A charge that St. John's University has been engaging in illegal strike breaking activities will be investigated by the city Department of Labor, Acting Commissioner James J. McFadden said yesterday.
CHICAGO, Jan. 14 (AP) Senator Paul H. Douglas, Democrat of Illinois, announced tonight that he would be a candidate for re-election next fall.
Three New England utilities asked the Federal Power Commission yesterday for permission to build a onemillion-kilowatt, pumped-storage plant in western Massachusetts.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 The Defense Supply Agency pleaded today for voluntary cooperation from the nation's apparel makers to meet the clothing needs of the armed forces in Vietnam without reminding the industry that it had weapons to demand compliance.

The Lindsay administration, which asked Mayor Wagner to delay approving a downtown site for a new Family Court building, has decided to go along with his plan. It will begin condemnation proceedings Monday in Supreme Court.
The recent show of strength in soybeans, which has surprised some commodity analysts, continued yesterday but was blunted by a flurry of profit taking.

VLADIMIR ASHKENAZY, the young pianistic de mon out of Russia, and Malcolm Frager, the American pianistic whirlwind, are close friends. They have plenty in common: both superior pianists, much the same age, attracted to much the same things. Ever since they met they have been having fun at two keyboards, playing through the repertory and kicking up a storm.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 A paper-mill worker confessed to the Mississippi Highway Patrol that he and a group of Ku Klux Klansmen abducted and whipped two Negroes whose mutilated bodies were later found in a river, a Congressional committee was told today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 One of the few large Peter Paul Rubens paintings that were entirely his own work was recently acquired by the National Gallery of Art. It will be shown here tomorrow for the first time.

THIS is a love story, told with uncommon grace. It is a novel for adults who already know the principal biologic elementals and so are not ungovernably surprised when they fuse into the passion that is art. It is the quality of the art that matters.
Part of the mystery about Michael J. Quill, head of the Transport Workers Union, was penetrated yesterday, but much of it remained.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 The Administration feels that its pressure for noninflationary wage and price movements is working well on the whole despite what it believes is the breach made in the policy by the New York transit strike settlement.
The Kroger Company, the supermarket chain, announced yesterday record sales for 1965 as well as the election of two executive vice presidents and two new vice presidents.

LONDON, Jan. 14 (UPI) Randy Matson, Billy Mills and Gerry Lindgren received official recognition today for recordbreaking track preformances as the International Amateur Athletic Federation ratified 36 world marks set in 1965.

JAFFREY, N.H., Jan. 14 Miss Kathe Lee Chambers, daughter of Mrs. Theodore H. Lee of Peterborough and the late Richard Munsell Chambers, was married today to Edward Palmer Lincoln, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Ware Lincoln of Providence, R.I. The ceremony in the First Congregational Church was performed by the Rev. John H. Leamon and the Rev. Arthur Bradford.
The appointment of Allon Schoener as assistant director of the Jewish Museum was announced yesterday by Sam Hunter, director.

SAIGON, Saturday, Jan. 15 Secretary of State Dean Rusk and Ambassador at Large W. Averell Harriman arrived today to meet with Vietnamese leaders who have shown increasing opposition to the United States' attempt to get "unconditional" peace talks started.

The American Jewish Congress asked President Johnson by telegram yesterday to remove Lieut. Gen. Lewis B. Hershey as Selective Service Director if he refused to comply with the draft law "as interpreted by the Department of Justice."
UPPER BROOKVILLE, L.I., Jan. 14 Cyril C. Ryan, former Nassau County Civil Defense Director and former Mayor of Freeport, died here today at his home. He was 67 years old.
With only mixed success the business community sought yesterday to recover a part of the losses suffered during the transit strike.
Mayor Lindsay, part-owner of a sailboat, won't be able to make it to the Coliseum today to open the 56th National Boat Show.

PELHAM MANOR. N.Y., Jan. 14 Mr. and Mrs. John Bertil de Brun have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Bettie de Brun, to John Andrew Cumming, son of Mrs. Arthur G. Harris. The couple plan to be married in June.
The directors of the Standard Oil Company (Ohio) yesterday elected John L. Ross a vice president and advanced Ralph A. Hart from vice president to senior vice president.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 The creation of a special committee to conduct a "thorough, bipartisan investigation" of the nation's antipoverty program was proposed today by a group of House Republicans.

The Coast Guard yesterday called off the search for 20 men missing since early Tuesday when the 10,500-ton Spanish freighter Monte Palomares sank in the Atlantic at a point 840 miles northeast of Bermuda. Only six of her 38-man crew have been saved and one body has been recovered.

Ninety-seven investment banking firms filed yesterday a test case against James J. Saxon, Controller of the Currency, seeking to invalidate his regulations authorizing national banks to underwrite revenue bonds.
A scramble of strong advances in secondary and lowpriced issues and declines in many investment-grade shares left the stock market with a modest gain yesterday.

The American Broadcasting Company discovered yesterday that its campy new series, "Batman," had scored so impressively in the early ratings that it was certain to be classified with the elite of intentional camp.
The city's 102 agencies have submitted 1966-67 budget requests totaling $4,718,093,523 or $765,956,213 above their current allocations.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 (AP) The Senate took up today the first bill of the new session a measure to preserve the wilderness atmosphere of five so-called wild rivers. But action was put off until next week.
A new air traffic rule cutting the lateral distance between flights across the North Atlantic went into effect as scheduled this week despite attempts by pilot organizations to delay it.

TOKYO Saturday, Jan. 15 Japan and the Soviet Union initialed here today a long-awaited civil aviation agreement that is expected to open the way for the first Tokyo-Moscow commercial flights across Siberia by next June.

KARACHI, Pakistan, Jan. 14 The Pakistani Government was attempting today to cope with the "dismay and disappointment in various quarters" over the agreement signed in Tashkent Monday by President Mohammad Ayub Khan and the late Prime Minister Lal Bahadur Shastri of India.
TOKYO, Jan. 14 Takeshi Watanabe, 59-year-old adviser to Japan's Finance Ministry, is generally expected here to be chosen as president of the Asian Development Bank in September.

The State Department will oppose the visit to the United States of any major performing-arts attraction from the Soviet Union without some assurance of a new and satisfactory cultural-exchange agreement.
ATLANTA, Jan. 14 About 1,000 persons marched on the Georgia Capitol today to protest the ouster of Representative-elect Julian Bond, a Negro pacifist, from the State House of Representatives.
SAN DIEGO, Jan. 14 Paul Bondeson, who relinquished a club job last August to rejoin the pro tour, shot a 65 today to lead the $40,000 San Diego open golf tournament by one stroke at 132.
Mayor Lindsay said yesterday that he and his staff were developing "sound and sensible" procedures intended to avert crises in the city's labor relations.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 (AP) President Johnson remained aloof today as an international argument raged about his clothing.

Edith L. Turner of 41 Park Avenue, president and general manager of Hotel Representative, Inc., and of Hotel Counselors, Inc., both at 125 Park Avenue, died yesterday at the Hospital for Special Surgery. She was 66 years old and was the widow of Jean Brazeau.

Mrs. Louise Edwards Crowell, a former singer and pianist and the wife of Paul Crowell, a consultant to the Mayor's Temporary Commission on City Finances and a former City Hall reporter for The New York Times, died yesterday in the Madison Avenue Hospital. She was 64 years old and lived at 161 West 16th Street.
GRINDELWALD, Switzerland, Jan. 14 (AP) The Austrian girl skiers swept the first four places in the downhill race of the Grindelwald series today to score an upset victory over the French.
From the pricing front yesterday came word that the Pan American Sulphur Company would "review" its scheduled increase in the price for sulphur.
National Airlines, Inc., had a net income of $17.8-million in the 12 months to Nov. 30, up from $10.2-million in the period ended Nov. 30, 1964, according to L.B. Maytag Jr., president.

Hardships witnessed or shared during the transit strike prompted several New Yorkers this week to contribute to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. One $10 bill was accompanied by a note saying only: "For a pair of new shoes during the subway strike."

NEW DELHI, Jan. 14 (Reuters) Prime Minister Lal Bahadur Shastri died penniless, a member of his household said here today. Mr. Shastri donated his salary of 3,000 rupees ($630) a month to promote the country's social and economic advancement, it was said.

The marriage of Miss Joan Patricia Taaffe, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William P. Taaffe of Pluckemin, N.J., to William Edwin Engel Jr. son of Mr. and Mrs. Engel of Westfield, N.J., took place here yesterday afternoon.

BRIGHTWATERS, L.I., Jan. 14 Mr. and Mrs. John F. Ryan have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Patricia Marie Ryan, to George F. Armstrong, son of Mr. and Mrs. George B. Armstrong of Baltimore and New York. The wedding is planned for late spring.

Secretary of Labor W. Willard Wirtz asserted last night that Mayor Lindsay had ignored his recommendation that the cost of the transit strike settlement be kept within the guidepost set by the Federal Government.
TUCSON, Ariz., Jan. 14 (UPI) President Johnson's estimate of a $1.8-billion deficit for the fiscal year 1967 is "utterly ridiculous," former Senator Barry Goldwater said yesterday.
Half the parking summonses issued here are ignored, according to John M. Murtagh, Administrative Judge of the Criminal Court.

The Beaux Arts Trio added more Charles Ives to the undeclared Ives Year that seems to be in progress. Last night at the Hunter College Playhouse, they performed the Trio for Piano, Violin and Cello. The work was written in 1911, but was not published until 1955, the year after the composer's death.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 This was the day Representative Herbert Tenzer had picked to open his campaign for a Federal wetlands preserve along the South Shore of Long Island.

ORMOND BEACH, Fla., Jan. 14 (AP) The defending champion, Phyllis Preuss, won her semi-final match today and will meet Sandra Post, the Canadian junior champion, tomorrow for the South Atlantic women's amateur golf title at the Oceanside Country Club.
Susan Tracy Barden, fashion editor for King Features Syndicate, died Thursday at Gracie Square Hospital. She was 62 yaers old.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 The Military leaders of South Vietnam, responding to American advice, are expected to proclaim further political and economic reforms soon in a drive to seize and win the sympathies of the nation's villagers.
GARY, Ind., Jan. 14 (AP) Lieut. Col. Frank Borman returned to his birthplace for a civic welcome and told a news conference that there was no reason why a Negro could not become an astronaut.

A contract dispute between the American Ballet and the City Center of Music and Drama has left at least 15 musicians apparently assured of full salaries for not playing during the ballet's four-week engagement that starts Tuesday at the New York State Theater.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 Representative Wright Patman, Democrat of Texas, asked the Securities and Exchange Commission today to delay its decision on the application of the First National City Bank, New York, to create and manage a type of mutual fund.
MOSCOW Jan. 14 The Soviet Union has increased its commitment to aid North Vietnam's war effort, according to a communique issued today.

The directors of the Square D Company declared yesterday a quarterly dividend of 45 cents a share, payable April 1 to holders of record of March 16. The company had previously paid 40 cents quarterly.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 Air America, which purports to be a private commercial line, is known to have been hired or perhaps even established by the Central Intelligence Agency.

NANTES, France, Jan. 14 Ambassador Charles E. Bohlen told a group of French students today that if there were a cease-fire in South Vietnam followed by free elections, the United States would accept any Vietcong officials who were legally elected to office.
Automobiles whipped along Fifth and Madison Avenues yesterday faster than anyone could remember.
The New York Yankees temporarily halted their search for a right-handed hitter yesterday by acquiring Lou Clinton, a 28year-old outfielder, from the Cleveland Indians in exchange for Doc Edwards.
A.B. (Happy) Chandler, a controversial figure when he held the post of Commissioner of Baseball, resigned yesterday as commissioner of the year-old Continental Football League.

RIDGEWOOD, N.J., Jan. 14 Mr. and Mrs. Thomas P. Gill have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Susan Ellen Gill, to Robert B. Spellmeyer. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. George C. Spellmeyer of Great Neck, L.I.
President Johnson's appointment of Robert C. Weaver as Secretary of the new Department of Housing and Urban Renewal has been long expected.
Printing and publishing companies are ripe for merger, according to W.T. Grimm Co., a Chicago financial consulting

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 The Opera Society of Washington tonight presented Mozart's "The Magic Flute" with Ernst Maezendorfer of Austria as guest conductor. The production will be repeated Sunday and Monday.
BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Jan. 14 Civil rights marches today in downtown Birmingham and to public schools touched off a Federal investigation to determine whether Federal injunctions had been violated.

The Clarion Concert Society will honor the memory of Noah Greenberg with a performance of Haydn's "Trauer Symphony" at its concert in Town Hall on Tuesday, Jan. 18. Mr. Greenberg, founder and director of New York Pro Musica, died last Sunday. The symphony was one

A four-engine DC-4 passenger plane operated by Avianca Colombia National Airways was reported to have crashed in the Caribbean moments after it took off from Crespo Airport near Cartagena, Colombia at 8:50 P.M. yesterday.

MBABANE, Swaziland, Jan. 11 Perched on a hillside here, just 12 miles from the South African border, is a school for boys founded on the idea that it is a good and natural thing for students of different races to work, play and live together.

The master of one of the two tugs involved in the four-craft collision in Kill Van Kull early Wednesday testified at a Coast Guard investigation yesterday that he was unable to help two or three men in the water shortly after the collision. Four men lost their lives in the sinking of the tug Patricia Moran.
WARSAW, Jan. 14 (Reuters) Wladyslaw Gomulka, the Polish Communist leader, today accused Stefan Cardinal Wyszynski, the Roman Catholic Primate, of wanting to win Poland over to the West.

SAIGON, Jan. 14 (UPI) Enemy guerrillas shot down a United States civilian transport plane today, executed the wounded pilot and co-pilot and led off a third crewman with a rope around his neck, the plane's operating company reported.
HAVANA, Jan. 14 (Reuters) A Cuban will be secretary general of a leftist solidarity organization set up by the Tricontinental Congress here, conference sources said today.
HONG KONG, Jan. 14 Scholarly analysts are complaining these days that few events in recent history have done so much to debase the language of diplomacy as has the war in Vietnam.
CINCINNATI, Jan. 14 (AP) Sidney Weil, former owner of the Cincinnati Reds baseball team, was pronounced dead yesterday after a traffic accident on Columbia Parkway. He was 75 years old.

The New York Civil Liberties Union has protested to the New School for Social Research in support of a part-time student to whom the school denied permission to circulate a petition backing the United States military efforts in Vietnam.

THE exhibition of Philip Guston's recent paint ings and drawings at the Jewish Museum (1109 Fifth Avenue at 92d Street) makes a double claim on our attention. There is the work itself 81 items in all, and most of them completed since the artist's retrospective show at the Guggenheim Museum in 1962. And then there is the ideological hankypanky that accompanies the work.

Robert Edward Lee, who retired in 1951 after 30 years as an executive in the claims division of the Fidelity Casualty Company of New York, died yesterday of leukemia at Harkness Pavilion of the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. He was 84 years old.

TO LAY down strategic rules for the handling of part-score deals is very difficult much harder than for higher contracts. In a part score the lead changes hands frequently and there is more opportunity for errors on both sides.
Parks Commissioner Thomas P.F. Hoving sent an aide yesterday to make a survey of park areas that had accommodated cars during the transit strike.

SEOUL, South Korea, Jan. 14 In a move to counter North Korea's increasing diplomatic activities, South Korea has adopted a "flexible" stand in dealing with countries having formal diplomatic ties with the Communist North.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 This is not basically a "high style" city, according to Mrs. Dorcas Hardin, who ought to know, being the owner of one of the capital's most fashionable dress shops on Wisconsin Avenue in Georgetown.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 Wholesale prices took another sizable jump in the week ended last Tuesday, the Labor Department reported today. Although most of the increase came in the farm and food sector, industrial prices crept further upward.
ROME, Jan. 14 (AP) Premier Aldo Moro won a vote of confidence in the Chamber of Deputies tonight on his conduct of foreign policy after Amintore Fanfani's resignation as Foreign Minister.

GENEVA, Jan., 14 University economists and central bank and treasury officials of the world's major financial powers are gathering in Zurich the Swiss monetary center to join in an informal search for ways to keep balance-ofpayments problems under control.

The acting water commissioner is wondering, in effect, if a man with $40 in his pocket and nothing in the bank is better off than a man with $27 in his pocket and a small unknown cash reserve available.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 (AP) Huge colored clouds of chemicals, expected to be easily visible along the East Coast, will be shot aloft by rockets from Wallops Island, Va., next Monday and Tuesday.

ATHENS, Jan. 14 The wreckage of a plane believed in be a United States Air Force C-47 carrying 10 men, including high-ranking United States military officers, was sighted today near the snow-capped peak of a 7,700-foot mountain south of the Corinth Gulf.
The battle for control of the Crucible Steel Company of America entered a new phase yesterday.

The International Business Machine Corporation added another record yesterday, reporting the highest gross and net earnings for any single quarter in the final three months of 1965. This increased the year's results to the highest level ever achieved by the giant business machine producer.
BONN, Jan. 14 The West German Government announced today it would carefully examine ways of helping the nation's steel industry.

NEWARK, Jan, 14 The American Civil Liberties Union of New Jersey announced plans today for a broad legal offensive against attempts to "breach the constitutional wall that separates government and religion."
NEW DELHI, Jan. 14 Mahavir Tyagi, Indian Minister for Rehabilitation, resigned today in protest against the Tashkent Declaration.
CHICAGO, Jan. 14 Fina1 arguments in the nine-month Krebiozen fraud trial centered today on the color of the substance.
BOSTON, Jan. 14 (AP) Herman Rifkin, a motion picture distribution pioneer and a survivor of the 1942 Cocoanut Grove fire, died today at Peter Bent Brigham Hospital. He was 81 years old.
Liberia, with more than 17.5 million gross tons of shipping under her flag, has moved to assure that she does not become a haven for overage merchant tonnage.

The International Business Machine Corporation added another record yesterday, reporting the highest gross and net earnings for any single quarter in the final three months of 1965. This increased the year's results to the highest level ever achieved by the giant business machine producer.
BOSTON, Jan. 14 (AP) Herman Rifkin, a motion picture distribution pioneer and a survivor of the 1942 Cocoanut Grove fire, died today at Peter Bent Brigham Hospital. He was 81 years old.
Liberia, with more than 17.5 million gross tons of shipping under her flag, has moved to assure that she does not become a haven for overage merchant tonnage.
BONN, Jan. 14 The West German Government announced today it would carefully examine ways of helping the nation's steel industry.

NEWARK, Jan, 14 The American Civil Liberties Union of New Jersey announced plans today for a broad legal offensive against attempts to "breach the constitutional wall that separates government and religion."

HOUSTON, Jan. 14 (AP) The two-time champion Buffalo Bills will meet a one-weekold All-Star team tomorrow in the American Football League's All-Star Bowl an old game with a new name that closes the season and opens a new chapter in football.

Representatives from most of the city's public and private welfare agencies concerned with children bombarded a state legislative committee yesterday with demands for planning, coordination of services and imagination. No one asked for money.
LONDON, Jan. 14 The High Court today found a pedestrian responsible for the death of a motor scooter driver and ordered him to pay damages of 2 ($5.60) a week for the next 32 years.

ROCHESTER, Minn., Jan. 14 (AP) Dr. Roger L.J. Kennedy, who had been a Mayo Clinic physician and president of the Minnesota State Medical Association, died of a stroke today at St. Mary's Hospital. He was 68 years old.

The New York Telephone Company said yesterday that its records showed it had handled upward of 2-million calls concerning problems arising from the 12-day transit strike through a special number, 999-1234, that it had set up for that purpose.
The 1965 substitution rule, permitting almost unrestricted used of platoons, is not likely to be changed by the Football Rules Committee convening today at New Orleans, in the opinion of Stu Holcomb.
Government bond prices declined again yesterday, continuing a drop that started Thursday following President Johnson's State of The Union Message.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 Alaska filed suit today to remove itself from coverage by the Voting Rights Act of 1965

The London Stock Exchange opened quietly yesterday, and closed off in dull trading. Thursday's announcement by British Petroleum of a $168million new stock issue was credited with rallying petroleum issues.
MORGANTOWN, W. Va., Jan. 14 (UPI) West Virginia University appointed Jim Carlen, a defensive coach at Georgia Tech, as head football coach today to succeed Gene Corum.

Harold Kohon, with the pianist Allen Weiss as his collaborator instead of the other three members of the Kohon Quartet, played a program of violin sonatas at Town Hall late yesterday afternoon. It was an imaginative bit of program building, including one first performance and nothing in the old chestnut category. Even the Saint-Saens Sonata in D minor (Op. 75), which came last, can hardly be called overfamiliar.

An ecumenical benefit, newest expression of the growing rapprochement between Protestants and Roman Catholics, will be held on Friday at 8 P.M. in the auditorium of the Maritime Union Building, Seventh Avenue and 13th Street.

Four major lumber associations reported an increase of 42.2 per cent in production for the week ended Jan. 8, compared with the level in the 1965 week. Output rose 25.3 per cent from the preceding week.

J. Dudley Devine, a Manhattan lawyer and former president of the New York Young Republican Club, received a three-year suspended sentence in Federal Court yesterday after pleading guilty to three of 19 counts of forgery and false accounting in a bankruptcy case.

Orin Lehman, Democratic candidate for Congress in Manhattan's 17th District, accused Councilman Theodore R. Kupferman, his Republican opponent, yesterday of wanting the United States "to turn tail" in South Vietnam.
FREEPORT, L.I., Jan. 14 The vanguard of about 250 bird watchers who specialize in waterfowl will start a oneweek census of ducks and geese in New York City and Lone Island tomorrow.
The Chemical Bank New York Trust Company, which ranks fourth in size in New York City, but is sixth in deposits in its foreign branches, announced a step yesterday to bolster its overseas operations.

The widow of Ernest Hemingway filed suit yesterday to prevent the distribution and sale of a book that includes an account of the years before the author's death, when he had reportedly tried to commit suicide several times.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Jan. 14 Mike Tilley became the seventh Hofstra basketball player to reach the 1,000-point mark as he scored 30 points tonight to lead the Flying Dutchmen to a 77-75 upset of New York University.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 (UPI) A man described by the police as an escaped mental patient fired a rifle shot into the air today about half a block from the White House.

French and Flemish tapestries hung from the walls of the Imperial Ballroom at the Americana last evening for the sixth annual Quadrille Ball. White plumes and marabou arranged with pink and red carnations served as table centerpieces.

CARTERET, N.J., Jan. 14 Alexander LeBow, president of the LeBow Supermarket and Bow-Dan Realty Company, and vice president of the Carteret Bank and Trust Company, died today in his home at 42 Atlantic Street.
WESTBURY, L.I., Jan. 14 Timely Truth flashed speed at the close tonight to take the feature mile pace at Roosevelt Raceway.

The Transit Authority was prohibited yesterday from punishing any of its union employes for their 12-day transit strike until the Condon-Wadlin Law, under which the strike was declared illegal, has been tested.
Bill Carr, an American Olympic champion in 1932, died yesterday of a heart attack in Tokyo, where he was serving as Far Eastern representative of two United States manufacturers. He was 56 years old.

A salon designed for men with thick wallets and thin hair will open Tuesday at 26 East 64th Street. It is part of a project in "togetherness" conceived by Bernard Bohle, a Vienna-born hairdresser who came to New York nine years ago.

Three jurors were chosen yesterday for the trial of three men charged with the murder last Feb. 21 of Malcolm X, the black nationalist leader. One juror was chosen on Thursday. Of the four so far chosen, two are Negroes.

The appointment of Horace G. Craddock as president of Flagship Line Agency, Inc., exclusive sales agent for the Norwegian cruise ship Viking Princess, has been announced by Batolf Batolfsen, chairman.
NORTH BERGEN, N.J., Jan. 14 Mrs. Wilbur L. Ross has made known the engagement of her daughter, Miss Karen Jane Ross, to Robert L. Tanzola Jr. His parents are Mr. and Mrs. Tanzola of Tenafly.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 (AP) The Agriculture Department announced today that its cropland conversion program would be operated on an experimental basis this year in 67 counties in 21 states.

WASHINGTON--The Bureau of Engraving and Printing is inviting everyone to come on over to see its etchings. Great art it may not be, but the taxpaying tourists who respond to the free invitation seem to know what they like.

The mobile boarding teams that the Coast Guard put into the field during the summer of 1965 hit pay dirt, especially in those areas where official inspections had been absent in local boating circles.

The vicious invective unleashed by Izvestia against two jailed Soviet writers, Andrei D. Sinyavsky and Yuli M. Daniel, gives dismaying evidence of how easily the old Stalinist impulses can still rise to the surface in Moscow. There has been no public trial of these two men who have been accused of writing the books and stories published abroad under the pseudonyms "Abram Tertz" and "Nikolai Arzhak."

James French Baldwin, a well-known big-game angler of Upper Brookville, L.I., is only too happy to tell how his fish, including a whale, got away. But unlike most other fishermen he plans it that way.

ROME, Jan. 15--A debate in which Premier Aldo Moro of Italy and his former Foreign Minister, Amintore Fanfani, patched up surface solidarity brought out clearly, observers noted today, that Mr. Fanfani has some embarrassing friends --the Communists.
The industry that has put this nation on wheels now is making a sizable contribution toward putting many citizens on the waterways.

Compact transistor units with low power consumption have been developed in navigation and communication instruments for greater safety and convenience afloat without undue strain on the boat's electrical system. There are many examples at the show.
American boat buyers will be able to choose from at least 3,802 models of stock recreational boats this year, according to a compilation by Popular Boating.

With all sorts of schemes being advanced to shore up the failing structure of commuter travel and to improve intercity travel by whatever medium, a Chicago lawyer has stepped into the picture with a proposal to stem the decline of intercity travel by railroad.
More than 75 dinghies, prams, canoes, kayaks, life rafts and unusual boats-- including a 6 -foot Ski Craft, the smallest boat in the show--are on view at the Coliseum.

A new network of 15 very high frequency radio stations will be established before the 1966 hurricane season next June to provide mariners with continous FM transmission of weather warnings, forecasts and reports, according to the Department of Commerce.
The airline industry is currently a victim of its own prosperity as far as the Civil Aeronautics Board is concerned, the head of the regulatory agency indicated last week.
SYRACUSE, Jan. 15-A national convention with the purpose of helping poor persons gain control of Federal funds in poverty programs was held here today.
SEOUL, South Korea, Jan. 15--South Korea is studying a plan to send additional troops of about one division to South Vietnam soon, it was reliably reported here today.

IN Brazil it is called favella; in Argentina, banda de miseria; in Peru, barriada. In Colombia it is tugurio. But whatever the name, its characteristics are the same: It is the rudest kind of slum, clustering like a dirty beehive around the edges of any principal city in Latin America.
By an odd coincidence, two of this winter's more important books, by two of the country's more important fact writers, will deal with the closing days of world War II.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 15--A stepped-up Soviet diplomatic offensive in Asia and the Mideast is being forecast by foreignpolicy experts both in and outside the Government.
Warren Giles, president of the National League, was named yesterday to receive the William J. Slocum Memorial Award by the New York Chapter of the Baseball Writers' Association.

THE subject of Wilfrid Blunt's biography, Sir Sidney Carlyle Cockerell (18671862), was one of those cultivated amateur connoisseurs which only England can produce. "Specialists are dull people," he told his children.

Professor Max Siegel, associate dean of students at Brooklyn College, disclosed last week that high school graduates with a history of mental illness are running into increasing difficulty in gaining admission to college.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Jan. 15-- The rainstorm that killed nearly 405 people and left 50,000 temporarily homeless here this week has laid bare Rio's deep and ugly urban crisis.

IN a converted schoolhouse in Arlington, Vt., lived a curious and important figure in American music who will be 90 years old on March 11--Carl Ruggles. FLORENCE, Italy, Jan. 16 Never ask an Italian designer of one of the boutique collections, which were shown this week at the Pitti Palace here, exactly where his clothes should be worn. It is up to the woman who buys them to work out the answer alone.

HAVERFORD, Pa., Jan. 16 Sam Howe won the William F. White Memorial Cup squash racquets championship for the second successive year today by defeating his brother, Ralph, of Oyster Bay, L.I., 15-6, 12-l5, 18-15, 9-15, 18-16.

WASHINGTON The honeymoon is certainly over between President Johnson and the business community, but it looks from here as if the marriage has an even chance to last. It will if the partner in the White House has anything to say about it.
LONDON, Jan. 15 The Conservative party has been torn in recent days by internal conflicts of a kind more familiar among its Labor rivals.

SHAKER HEIGHTS, Ohio, Jan. 16 Mr. and Mrs. Edward T. Butler have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth Ann Butler, to Brian P. McKegney, son of Mr. and Mrs. Osborne McKegney of Riverdale in the Bronx, New York, and Westhampton, L.I.

In 1965, the United Aircraft Corporation reached new milestones in its traditional spheres of flight and made important contributions to rocketry and space technology, William P. Gwinn, president, said in his annual review of the company's operations.
The National Biscuit Company had the best year in its history, with 1965 sales and earnings at records, Lee S. Bickmore, president, said in a preliminary report issued over the weekend.
In a major expansion of its headquarters, the stock brokerage firm of Bache Co. has leased 35,000 square feet of additional space in 40 Wall Street.

IT WAS Ninette de Valois who once wrote about opera ballets as "an isolated limb of Satan," and doubtless those Parisian abonnes, the Jockey Club, who fostered the vogue for opera ballets also regarded them as a leg-show. They really are something of an abomination, a distraction to opera lovers, an annoyance to ballet lovers. At best they can scarcely be made more than tolerable.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 The number of American families on general relief has fallen below 300,000 for the first time since 1957, in direct response to the booming condition of the economy.
BOSTON, Jan. 16 (UPI) Ths Boston Celtics took advantage of the illness of Wilt Chamberlain, the Philadelphia scoring star, today and routed the 76ers, 137-122.
Aided by increased mechanization and automation, the nation's soft coal industry last year achieved another peak in efficiency of operation.
It was ear-nipping cold yesterday, toe-tapping cold last night and it will be roses-inthe-cheeks cold today, but to the coldly reasoning men of the Weather Bureau, it is not a cold wave.
"I DON'T want to become a specialist in liquidating offices," Timothy Jeffries Cooney said between puffs on one of his eight-a-day cigars yesterday.
Trading was brisk in memberships on the New York Stock Exchange in 1965, with 97 seats changing hands. Prices ranged from a high of $250,000 to a low of $190,000.
Crop harvests last year by the nation's farmers were the biggest for any year. The output was 17 per cent more than the 1957-59 average despite drastic curtailment programs by the Government.

It was Artur Rubinstein Day at Carnegie Hall yesterday. On the stage where he made his American debut 60 years ago, the pianist received an award from a group that has a special reason for admiring him.
In the field of medical research and development, 1965 might have been called the year of artificial substitutes for vital human parts.

Enrique Negron, the Bronx grocer who was stabbed in the back when he went to the aid of a policeman being attacked by an angry mob last spring, has lost his store, his savings and most of his friends.
It was a good year down on the farm in 1965 and the farmequipment industry reaped a handsome sales harvest of its own.

Blackout. That was the story of the electric utility industry in 1965. What had otherwise been a perfect, record-shattering year disappeared in the night of Nov. 9 when the Northeastern sector of the United States and lower Canada went dark for a few minutes to more than 12 hours in some areas. An area of 80,000 square miles with some 30 million people was affected.
The word is out in the men's wear industry. The word is "fashion," and it helped break the mythical 20-million-suit barrier last year.

Paul Hersh, violist of the Lenox String Quartet, made his New York debut as pianist in 1964 playing Bach's "Goldberg" variations. Late yesterday afternoon, the remarkable young man appeared in Town Hall for his second New York piano recital.
WASHINGTON The Government's machinery for making economic policy suffered a spectacular breakdown in 1965, but most people here still believe it is the best machinery available.

Like a long-distance runner who finishes a race out front with plenty of stamina to spare, the chemical industry ended 1965 with a remarkable record and ready to increase its future share in the country's economic boom.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 16 A diplomatic and political storm has broken around the Iranian Embassy in Beirut as a result of anti-Egyptian statements attributed to the Ambassador in Arabic newspapers.
TOKYO, Jan. 16 (AP) The Hanoi radio charged today that United States aircraft bombed a North Vietnamese village Friday. The broadcast, monitored here, said:
WASHINGTON The Government is going all-out in 1966 to solve the nation's most perplexing economic problem the chronic deficit in the balance of international payments.

Business and industry realized last year the richest bounty of profits on record. Sharing in the boom in a most direct way were at least 20 million shareowners who received the biggest dividend payout in corporate history.
The aerospace industry flew high in 1965 and it's due to gain a still greater sales altitude in 1966.

The shoe industry had its second best production year in 1965. Output came to about 630million pairs. This was surpassed only in 1959, when 638million pairs were turned out, according to the Boot and Shoe Recorder, a publication of the Chilton Company.
HISTORY is on their side, but taste and tariffs are against them, four British carpet manufacturers agreed last week at a reception in their honor given by the British Consulate General.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 16 A Lebanese Army spokesman brought out two Palestinian prisoners here last night to show that they were in good health. He denied allegations that a third prisoner, whose death was announced last Monday, had been tortured.

France's agreement to meet today with its five Common Market partners in Luxembourg marks the beginning of the end of the crisis in the European Economic Community (E.E.C.). The negotiations will not be easy. Nor is it certain that this two-day meeting of foreign ministers will terminate the six-month French boycott of E.E.C. institutions. But there no longer can be any doubt that the Common Market will survive the current threat to its cohesion.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 16 (AP) Twenty-nine scientists, 16 of them from Harvard University, condemned today the use of chemicals by the United States to destroy crops in Vietnam.
More and more manufacturers and merchandizers are turning their attention to the youth market 24 million free-spending American teen-agers.
When the Bureau of National Affairs, Inc., surveyed 140 concerns last year, more than half of them reported that Negroes accounted for less than 4 per cent of their work forces.

WENGEN, Switzerland, Jan. 16 (AP) Guy Perillat of France won the Lauberhorn special slalom ski race for the second straight year today as Billy Kidd, the United States star, spoiled his chance for victory in a split-second misstep only 20 meters from the finish.
The creation of a new United States Lines container services division, to be headed by Robert B. Murphy, was announced here yesterday by William B. Rand, president of the line.

The machine-tool industry, by the nature of its products, requires a high ratio of skilled shop workers, engineers and technicians. And the ratio is destined to go higher, reports the National Machine Tool Builders Association.
Unlike a rubber ball, which has to return to the ground before bouncing upward again, the rubber industry just keeps climbing.
Mayor Lindsay will create today a Transportation Administration and a Transportation Council to advise it on improving the movement of people and goods within and through the city.

HOUSTON, Jan. 16 (AP) While Air Force Maj. David R. Scott orbits around the world outside the Gemini 8 spacecraft, he will try his hand at some plain "nuts and bolts" mechanics as well as space acrobatics.

The Federal requirement that certain elderly people take loyalty oaths as a condition for obtaining Medicare benefits is repugnant and should be rescinded. The provision affects the two million uninsured by Social Security who will receive aid from the general fund rather than from the Social Security tax fund, and applies only to those receiving hospital care, not the separate voluntary medical insurance that helps pay doctors' bills.
WASHINGTON--War in Vietnam has joined with changing public attitudes to flatten out the curve of Federal spending for science and technology.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 (UPI) Longtime friends of President and Mrs. Johnson have donated $140,000 to be used to plant hundreds of new flowering cherry trees at Haines Point on the Potomac River, it was announced today.
Aeroflot, the Soviet Union's airline, is expected to carry more than 48-million passengers during 1966, according to a Tass report from Moscow.
A wide variety of new products, improved methods of processing and distribution as well as continued expansion and research marked the activities of the food industry last year.
The merchants are probably home from their conventions by now, but the ideas they took with them will give them something to think about and work on for a long time.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 The Johnson Administration is tentatively planning to end its peace drive next week after the Vietnamese new year unless some favorable response is received by then, reliable sources said today.

The life insurance industry took in $18.3-billion in life insurance and annuity premiums last year, about $1.3-billion more than in 1964, but to many industry officials that was not a big-enough slice of Americans' savings.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., Jan. 16 Mr. and Mrs. Philip W. Straw of Upper Montclair have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Amy Worden Straw, to Donald William Loveland, son of Roger P. Loveland of Rochester, N.Y., and the late Mrs. Dorothy Dobbins Loveland. A May wedding is planned.
HOLLYWOOD The producer's face was ashen as he slammed down the telephone. "You wouldn't believe this conversation," he told his visitor. "I mean, things are really getting out of hand."

ALICIA DE LARROCHA may not yet be a household name in this country. But pianists certainly are aware of her existence, and her recital Saturday evening at Hunter College attracted such colleagues of hers as Artur Rubinstein, Claudio Arrau, Ania Dorfmann and scads of the younger generation.
VILA, New Hebrides, Jan. 5 The political future of the New Hebrides is certain to be fraught with more than the ordinary complications that attend the evolution of backward colonial territories.
GSTAAD, Switzerland, Jan. 16 (AP) Mrs. John F. Kennedy and her daughter, Caroline, spent an afternon of undisturbed skiing here today. They appeared happy and to enjoy every moment of it.

MONTE CARLO, Monaco, Jan. 16 (UPI) Tragedy struck one of the smoothest Monte Carlo auto rally runs in years today when two Spanish drivers, one a last-minute replacement, were killed in a crash into a roadside tree in Southern France.

AUSTIN, Tex. When the silver and blue Presidential plane lands at Bergstrom Air Force Base here, it brings Texas closer to the Federal Government, which, in the past, has often been "those people in Washington."

The House Merchant Marine and Fisheries Committee plans early hearings on proposed legislation to make the Maritime Administration an independent agency, Representative Edward A. Garmatz reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON Organized labor, emerging from a year that served it a curious blend of success and failure a year in which it achieved many longsought social goals without winning the bread-and-butter legislation it had expected is dedetermined to make a significant mark in the legislative and political arenas.

RIVERHEAD, L.I. Neither the economic fates nor the zeal of professional planners in 1965 altered the basic nature of Long Island as an elongated suburb studded with industry that trails off into farmland.

James E. Goodman, an executive vice-president of the General Motors Corporation, in charge of its automotive and defense divisions, died of a heart ailment Saturday at St. Mary's Hospital at Rochester, Minn. He was 61 years old and lived in Bloomfield Hills, Mich.

THE cool, methodical chairman of the Federal Reserve Board unfurled a storm-warning flag on June 1 when he suggested that the accelerating pace of the expansion had some similarities to the 1929 period and that an unsustainable boom might be followed by a bust ... Waved that flag vigorously again in early December, ...
Investors clearly showed last year that they were more interested in fast-moving "glamour" stocks than in the safety of investment-grade issues.

Brand names, new money, a bigger population and related off-season products are expect ed to spark the pleasure marine industry to another good year in 1966, just as they did in 1965. Last year sales increased by an estimated 4 per cent.
SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Jan. 16 Rhodesia's bankers appeared today to be preparing for a stiff new round of economic sanctions from Britain.

Commercial bankers had a difficult year in 1965.

RIVER VALE, N.J., Jan. 16 Betsy Gerson took exactly 160 jumps at the Holiday Farms horse show today on four different mounts. As a result, the 18-year-old Cazenovia College freshman from Closter, N.J., won the open and green jumper championship and took reserve honors in the open working hunter division.

ARLINGTON, Va., Jan. 16 Mr. and Mrs. James F. McHale have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jane Ann McHale, to Michael Manning Dickson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard H. Dickson of Indianapolis.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 (UPI) A resarcher said today that the newly developed winter tires containing studs were more effective on ice than regular snow tires but less effective than chains.
More than $1 billion in free samples was received by the American public last year, it was estimated recently by James J. Harris, chairman of the Guest Pac Corporation of Mount Vernon, N.Y.

The story of the home entertainment business is really the story of color television, although black-and-white TV, radio, phonograph and stereophonic sound also showed glowing sales and growth. What's more, they all seem headed for another high mark this year, barring shortages of vital components.
Miss Susan Safford Dill and James David Bernstein, Peace Corps volunteers, were married in a civil ceremony in Taza, Morocco, on Dec. 28.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 16 (AP) St. Joseph's of Philadelphia, a big favorite, needed a field goal at the final buzzer by Steven Donches, a substitute, today to gain a 71-69 basketball victory over Villanova.
The steel industry enters the new year free from the specter of a strike that haunted it a year ago and with the prospects of much better business than it foresaw just three months ago.
The petroleum industry went through the earnings roof last year. Profits set a record.
NEW DELHI, Jan. 16--The Jan Sangh, a right-wing Hindu party, condemned today the Indian-Pakistani agreement at Tashkent and called on the nation to oppose it.
WASHINGTON A shift in emphasis that the new antitrust chief, Donald F. Turner, has brought into the Justice Department promises a year of both controversy and excitement in the antitrust field.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., Jan. 16 There were some strange doings at this Palisades Interstate Park resort today as Class A honors in the 42d Swedish Ski Club jumping tournament was won by pintsized Ralph Semb of Millers Falls, Mass.
Sales of air-conditioning units of all types will top $3 billion this year for the first time, it is predicted by the Carrier Corporation, the world's largest manufacturer in the field.

TOKYO The chairman of the Tokyo Stock Exchange, acknowledging that he was "among the most bullish" of officials, has expressed hope that the reviving market might rise toward a record level late this year.

CHICAGO, Jan. 16 (UPI) A four-goal outburst by Bobby Hull came in a losing cause tonight as the New York Rangers defeated the Chicago Black Hawks, 6-5. The loss enabled Montreal to tie Chicago for first place in the National Hockey League.

The stock market blasted ahead to new peaks in 1965 and kept climbing in the opening weeks of 1966. Its momentum was supplied by record expansion on the domestic front and a buildup for the war in Vietnam the main question mark for the new year on Wall Street.
YORKTOWN HEIGHTS, N.Y., Jan, 16 Robert Simon, vice president and treasurer of Crown Publishers, Inc., of New York, died of a heart attack today at his home on Underhill Road. His age was 57.

A prototype of the camera that astronauts will use to film the century's greatest television spectacular live shots from the moon has been cleared for testing on the first unmanned Apollo flights this year.
PITTSBURGH A rapidtransit system is in the works for Allegheny County.

WHITE PLAINS "Something exciting is happening here that never happened before," said Alexander C. Baskind, the state Commerce Department's regional manager in the three counties sprawling across 861 square miles north of New York.

DETROIT, Jan. 16 (UPI) Norm Ulman's three goals and the shutout goal tending of Roger Crozier gave the Detroit Red Wings a 4-0 victory over the Toronto Maple Leafs tonight in a National Hockey League game.

"Don't look back something may be gaining on you" is one of the maxims that the imperishable pitcher Leroy (Satchel) Paige lives by. It is also a maxim the New York Stock Exchange will have to learn to live with.
The $14-billion women's garment industry is making sweeping changes in techniques as it seeks to lure customers with new colors, styling detail and fabrics.

TRENTON, Jan. 16 Mr. and Mrs. Edwin J. Burns have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Alyce Kathleen Burns of New York, to Frederick Mitchell Espy of Los Angeles. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Wallace S. Espy of Cincinnati.
The port's first official harbor welcome of 1966 for a passenger liner is scheduled for tomorrow when it greets the 21,164-ton Europa of the North German Lloyd.
One of the newest phrases in the lexicon of economists is "the labor force explosion."

THE refrigerator died on a summer Sunday. Ap- parently, all refrigerators die on Sunday. It was a double tragedy. Inside was $25 worth of groceries in danger of their life, and the door probably had the only gasket ever installed by three women.

The attempted revolution in Nigeria is a result of tribal, social, political and religious tensions breaking through a veneer of stability. This most populous nation of Africa has often been held up as a rare example of African democracy. It has, however, been in a state of thinly disguised ferment for years.

CONCEICAO DO ARAGUAIA, Brazil The first great wedge of agricultural colonization is pushing into the Amazon wilderness here west of the Araguaia River.

This year marks the 150th anniversary of the nation's gas industry. It is a definite cause for celebration, particularly as the industry of today has just completed another record year and seems headed for still another.
BEEF stew is a perennial favorite for midwinter budget meals. Although most homemakers have a tried and true recipe, experimenting with flavor combinations can be rewarding.
A Haitian stood accused yesterday of killing a woman who he believed had put a voodoo curse on him.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 16 (AP) The National Collegiate Athletic Association's football rules committee formally rejected today a return to tighter substitution rules.

OTTAWA, Jan. 17--The Canadian Government has protested to the United States Department of State about recent regulations of the Securities and Exchange Commission affecting many Canadian companies.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 17--Industrial production rose nearly 1.5 per cent in December--an unusual rise even for the present boom period--the Federal Reserve Board announced today.

Commissioner of Buildings Charles G. Moerdler received at least five letters marked "confidential" yesterday in response to his appeal on a Sunday television program for letters from citizens having knowledge of payoffs or bribery in his department.
MINEOLA, L.I., Jan. 17-- Palmer D. Farrington, former Hempstead presiding supervisor, was acquitted today of a charge of accepting an unlawful fee of $10,000 in return for political favor.
"Man of La Mancha," the musical at the downtown ANTA Washington Square Theater, is a virtual sellout but falls short of making what is considered a reasonable profit.
LONDON, Jan. 17--Important changes in the system of investment incentives for key sectors of the British economy were announced today in a government white paper.
With their offer of scholarship aid to white students, the nation's leading Negro colleges have given notice that a new chapter in their history has begun.
The Norfolk Western Railway reported yesterday record net income of $90-million for 1965, an increase of $10-million, or 12 per cent, over the $80million earned in 1964.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 (AP) --The Supreme Court refused today to review an order for a third trial in the case of a carpenter who said he contracted lung cancer from smoking cigarettes and sought damages from Liggett Myers Tobacco Co.

ALBANY, Jan. 17--Joseph F. Carlino, the former Speaker of the Assembly, has been advised by an Assembly committee that he is exempt from the new State Ethics Law, which bars former lawmakers from lobbying in Albany until they have been out of office for at least two years.

Before spring begins, residents of the Bronx, Manhattan and Brooklyn, as well as commuters in Westchester and on Long Island, may be able to ride in hydrofoil boats between their areas and points in lower Manhattan.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Jan. 17 (AP)--Walter Cronkite, Columbia Broadcasting System newsman, was named the winner last night of the annual Trans World Airlines award for outstanding reporting of aerospace subjects.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 17-- Vice President Humphrey announced today a $50,000 endowment for the Estes Kefauver Memorial Foundation.
SAIGON, Jan. 17--The South Vietnamese Government, with the logistical support of the United States, has undertaken the largest propaganda campaign ever attempted in this country.
ROME, Jan. 17 (Reuters) United States movies seen in Italy during 1965 were less harmful than European films the Vatican newspaper Osservatore Romano said today.
The United States offensive for peace in Vietnam is "bound to reach fruition," Arthur J. Goldberg, the chief United States representative at the United Nations, said last night.

SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Jan. 17--Prime Minister Ian D. Smith, said in a nationwide broadcast tonight that he was willing to reopen negotiations with Britain. It was his first conciliatory statement since his Government declared independence from Britain Nov. 11.
The Federal Government's new presence in the arts makes it almost a certainty that the mid-1960's will be a great watershed in their history in America.

A soprano and a tenor came to the rescue last night of the Metropolitan Opera's performance of "The Girl of the Golden West," but by the end of the second act it was not quite certain whether they had rescued the Puccini opera or done it in.
Robert M. Benjamin, a lawyer and a former Moreland Act Commissioner, died yesterday at his home, 45 East 82d Street. He was 69 years old.
Francis I. duPont Co., Brokerage firm, has appointHarold A. Rousselot, a general partner since 1955, as a senior partner, it was announced yesterday.

ALBANY, Jan. 17--Governor Rockefeller said today that he would seek a $15.5-million budget increase to combat the state's "No. 1 health problem" --mental illness.
American Jewish Reform rabbis are going to West Germany this summer to help overcome "a virtual vacuum" on information about Judaism and the Jewish people.

A man identified as the bandit who made a fiasco of a million-dollar jewel and gold robbery in 1963 because he could not operate a stick-shift auto was arrested by the Federal Bureau of Investigation yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 (AP) --The White House announced today that Mrs. Lyndon B. Johnson would make a speaking tour Feb. 23-25 to Denver and Tuscaloosa, Ala.
Charles J. Arnold and a group of associates have purchased Beardmore Products, Inc., from the Chase Manhattan Bank for an undisclosed amount of stock and cash.

The Chase Manhattan Bank, the last of the major New York City banks to report its 1965 results, reported yesterday a record total of net operating earnings and a yearend total of assets and deposits that clearly establishes Chase as the largest bank in the city, at least as of Dec. 31.

ATLANTA, Jan. 17--Depositions were taken today in a suit filed by the National Association of Insurance Agents and a Georgia insurance association to force an Atlanta bank to stop selling fire and casualty insurance.
LUXEMBOURG, Jan. 17-- France outlined far-reaching proposals today to reduce the power of the Common Market's Executive Commission.
CHICAGO, Jan. 17--Five new members have been elected to the board of trustees of the University of Chicago. They are:
Allan W. Ames, a retired vice president of the Marine Midland Trust Company of New York (now Marine Midland Grace Trust Company), died on Sunday in his home at 245 East 72d Street. His age was 72.
BONN, Jan. 17--Hoesch, A.G., and Huettenunion, A.G., two West German steel giants at Dortmond on the Ruhr, will merge this year to improve their competitive position in the European steel industry.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 17--Urban expressways can benefit the neighborhoods through which they pass and need not be a curse, a University of Washington professor said today.

Despite numerous job offers, Enrique Negron plans to leave the Bronx and go to sea. The 56-year-old grocer and one-time seaman, who lost his store and most of his savings after he helped a white policeman threatened by an angry mob last spring, stepped into the offices of the National Maritime Union, at 36 Seventh Avenue, yesterday afternoon to check on his union application.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 (UPI)--President Johnson was accused today of discriminating against military families.

Mr. and Mrs. A. Atwater Kent Jr. of Newtown Square, Pa., and Palm Beach, Fla., have announced the engagement of Mr. Kent's daughter, Miss Suzanne Atwater Kent, to Thomas Hitchcock 3d, son of Mrs. Thomas Hitchcock of New York and the late Mr. Hitchcock, the international polo player.
DETROIT, Jan. 17 (AP)-- The United States automobile output picture brightened today with the return of the American Motors Corporation to production after a shutdown of 13 working days.
DETROIT, Jn. 17 (UPI)-- Walter Reuther called today for new bargaining approaches to end "obsolete" strikes like the New York transit walkout.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 17--Sargent Shriver is giving up his job as director of the Peace Corps but will remain as head of what President Johnson promised today would be an expanded antipoverty campaign.

GROTON, Conn., Jan. 17-- The chairman of the Joint Congressional Committee on Atomic Energy cautioned today that the Defense Department might be imperiling the nation's security by its "reluctance" to build a nuclear powered surface fleet.

A songwriter asked yesterday that the New York State Supreme Court remove the board of directors of the American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers (ASCAP) on the grounds that they were elected illegally and that they had discriminated against the "poorest and least influential" members of the organization.

The Detroit Edison Company and subsidiaries reported yesterday total revenues of $363,330,850 for 1965. This compared with $342,855,777 one year earlier. Net income rose to $57,564,258, equal to $2 a share on 28,820,587 shares outstanding.

PURCHASE, N.Y., Jan. 17-- Returning from a tour of South Vietnam, Representative Ogden R. Reid said today that he saw the "beginning of hope there, but nothing more."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 (UPI)--Dr. Glenn T. Seaborg said today man might be able to create life "before the end of this decade."
TWO electrically operated home devices of more than routine interest were introduced last week.

The race for the savings dol lar is getting hotter. The First National City Bank, the second-largest commercial bank in New York, announced yesterday a per cent across-theboard increase in the rates it pays on investment certificates of deposit. The new rates are 4 per cent on 30-to-89 day money, 4 per cent for 90-to179 days, and 4 per cent for 180 days out to two years.

HOUSTON, Jan. 17 (AP)-- Commissioner Joe Foss of the American Football League withheld approval tonight of the trade that would have sent two San Diego linemen, Ernie Ladd and Earl Faison, to Houston.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 (AP) --The Supreme Court granted a hearing today to a youth convicted of criminally libeling public officials during a coal mine dispute in Kentucky.

"The Big Money," a television show on which a contestant could win $50,000 by accomplishing physical feats, is being developed by the National Broadcasting Company. A half hour pilot show will be taped this week at the network's studios in Burbank, Calif.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 (AP) --A corporate tax lawyer who is challenging the constitutionality of New York City's jaywalking regulations was denied a hearing today by the Supreme Court.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 (AP) --President and Mrs. Johnson have never met the parents of their daughter Luci's fiance, Airman Patrick J. Nugent, but they have talked by telephone and have received letters, the White House confirmed today.
Frederick W. Padgett, a retired petroleum chemist and engineer, died Sunday in Fort Lauderdale, Fla. His age was 77.

BONN, Jan. 17--For the first time, a West German Cabinet Minister has stated publicly that his Government is prepared to yield former German lands in the east to reach a frontier settlement with Poland.

Bonwit Teller and Sears, Roebuck Co. are considering opening major branches in a proposed new shopping center in Fairfield County, Conn., between U.S. 1 and the Connecticut Turnpike, on the Greenwich-Stamford line.
