Assignment of the revision bill to legislative committees headed by Senator John H. Hughes, a conservative Republican, and to the Assembly Rules Committee, headed by Speaker Anthony J. Travia, is now being construed by some as an obstacle to divorce-law reform.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17-- The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether three private parties might move into the Government's long-standing Paso Natural Gas Company's acquisition of the Pacific Northwest Pipeline Corporation.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 17-- The Treasury's three-month bill rate soared at today's auction to the highest level ever reached, the agency disclosed tonight.
Capt. Ove V. Hultin, master of States Marine Lines freighter Steel Maker, said yesterday that teamwork made possible the rescue last Monday of four sailors from the Spanish freighter Monte Palomares.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 (AP) --The public schools have been the target of increased pressure and harassment during the last three years, a commission of the National Education Association reported today.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., Jan. 17 --Arthur B. Miller, a retired civil engineer and architect, who did much work for the late John D. Rockefeller Jr., died Saturday in his home at 47 South Fullerton Avenue of arteriosclerosis. He was 91 years old.

Council President Frank D. O'Connor accused the state yesterday of "clamping an unrealistically low ceiling" on state aid for education and "failing in...[its] duty" to seek Federal aid for the communities of the state.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 (AP) --The Supreme Court today directed the National Labor Relations Board to reconsider, in the light of earlier court decisions, a case involving a charge of unfair labor practices by The Detroit News.
Walter Abel, actor, has been elected to succeed Peggy Wood as president of the American National Theater and Academy.

Carlton Everett Tucker, executive officer and former professor at Massachusetts Institute of Technology collapsed and died in his office at the Institute in Cambridge, Mass., yesterday afternoon. He was 69 years old. He had been under treatment for a heart condition.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 17-- Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara announced today that the Defense Department would seek an increase of 113,000 men in the strength of the armed forces.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 17--The Supreme Court today barred the city of Macon, Ga., from withdrawing as a trustee of a park to allow the park, as a "private" facility, to discriminate against Negroes.

The steady demand for money --particularly short-term money--at relatively attractive rates and the expectation in some quarters that those rates will rise further continued yesterday to affect the various segments of the bond market.
William Klein, lawyer for the Shubert theater interests for 60 years, died Sunday in the Hudson View Nursing Home in Yonkers. He was 90 years old and lived at 30 East 72d Street.

MIAMI, Jan. 17 (UPI)--Mrs. Candace Mossler and her nephew Melvin Lane Powers went on trial today for the murder of her Texas millionaire husband, Jacques Mossler, on a June night nearly 18 months ago.

Mayor Lindsay said yesterday he had "no reason to believe that Robert Moses will not go along" with the new administration's plans to create an all-embracing trans portation authority that would include the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27--The executive committee of the United States Conference of Mayors has expressed displeasure with the proposed transfer of the Community Relations Service from the Department of Commerce to the Department of Justice.

The Caterpillar Tractor Company surpassed all previous records in sales and earnings last year with increases of 16 per cent and 23 per cent, respectively, over 1964, according to the report issued late yesterday.

James Stafford, the young pianist from Louisiana who now teaches in Mexico City, chose to perform on a darkened stage at Carnegie Recital Hall Sunday night. Speculation as to the reason could be endless; suffice it to say that it betokened the eccentricity evident in his playing.

The United States Office of Education has granted $411,000 to the city's Board of Education for educational programs at the High Rock Nature Conservation Center on Staten Island during the next three years.
The Federal Government is awaiting word from the Lindsay Administration on what it wants to do with plans for about $450 million in urban renewal projects proposed by the Wagner Administration.

The last (and only) time Bill Crothers ran a mile, he finished fourth in the 1963 Millrose Games. On Jan. 27, when the 59th annual Millrose Games are staged at Madison Square Garden, Crothers will be in the Wanamaker Mile again. He expects to do much better than fourth.
MOSCOW, Jan. 17--Izvestia, the Soviet Government newspaper, apparently set the stage today for a trial of two writers who are under arrest on charges of having published anti-Soviet works abroad.
MIAMI BEACH, Jan. 17-- The car-buying public appears, if showroom conversations are the test, to be only slightly more interested in automobile safety than it was a year ago.
BLOOMINGTON, Ind., Jan. 17 (UPI)--Indiana, paced by its backcourt men, Vernon Payne and Max Walker, broke a fourgame losing streak tonight with a 73-61 Big Ten upset triumph over 12th-ranked Iowa.
NEW CITY, N.Y., Jan. 17-- Nine housewives picketed the Katz manor house on South Mountain Road in Rockland County today in an effort to prevent its destruction for development of High Tor State Park.

The Rev. Gommar DePauw, the embattled leader of the Catholic Traditionalist Movement in the United States, won support yesterday for his claim that he is a priest of the Diocese of Tivoli-Rome in Italy, and no longer subject to the authority of Lawrence Cardinal Shehan of Baltimore.
Mayor Lindsay has named James R. Dumpson, the former Welfare Commissioner, temporary head of the Economic Opportunity Committee, New York's antipoverty policy board.
The Lindsay administration began an intensive study yesterday of ways to prevent strikes against the city.
MONTICELLO, Ark. Jan. 17 (UPI)--James Caloway, an alumnus with an excellent sixyear record at an Indiana high school, was named head football coach today at Arkansas A. and M. College.
NEW HAVEN, Jan. 17 (AP) --Straughton Lynd, the Yale professor who recently returned from a trip to Hanoi, told a meeting tonight that he was considering resigning from the university faculty.
WARWICK, R.I., Jan. 17 (AP)--Conklin Mann, a New York advertising executive before his retirement in 1963, died here yesterday. He was 81 years old.
FREEPORT, L.I., Jan. 17-- A fire late tonight caused considerable damage to the Columbus Avenue Elementary School here, the Fire Department reported.
ENGLEWOOD, N.J., Jan. 17 Miss Mary Ann Bertram and Kurt S. Wiesner plan to marry May 14.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 (AP) --Pentagon figures show that the Army has lost officers at a heavier rate in the Vietnam fighting than in Korea or in World War II.

Apparel needs for United States military operations in Vietnam and some increased buying by wholesalers in expectation of shortages have led to longer deliveries for chambray and poplin apparel, muslin sheets of certain sizes and other textiles.
Steel production climbed for the second time in a row in the week ended Saturday, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

SUMMIT, N.J,., Jan. 17-- C. Dale Whitesell of 74 Valley View Avenue, vice president of the Holmes Agency, real estate dealers and insurers here, died yesterday at his home after a short illness. He was 43 years old.

Matthew J. "Joe" Culligan, who was the target in an editors' rebellion at the Curtis Publishing Company in Oct. 1964, has found a new job far afield from the magazine publishing, advertising, television and radio industries in which he had made his career.

As the crowds at the National Boat Show here pore over the spiffy array of vessels in the Coliseum, too few customers seem to care if the objects of their desire are safe as well as shiny. The United States Coast Guard, the agency in charge of protecting boating people from their own carelessness, does care and it said so yesterday through Capt. David W. Sinclair.

Commissioner Pete Rozelle of the National Football League will conduct a hearing on the dispute between the Chicago Bears and the Los Angeles Rams over the Bears' defensive coach, George Allen, the league announced yesterday.
Events in Brazil and Nigeria were on the minds of commodity traders yesterday.
CARACAS, Venezuela, Jan. 17 (UPI)--Venezuela's tallest building, Caracas's first, skyscraper, will soon be constructed.

An American expatriate was fined $5-million here yesterday for being the alleged go-between in the theft of microorganisms and secret formulas from the American Cyanamid Company. The stolen items were then sold to an Italian drug concern.
The election of John R. Edmonds as executive vice president of Allied Chemical Corporation's Semet-Solvey division was announced yesterday by Harold E. Imes, division president.
LONDON, Jan. 17--The man charged with restoring order in Nigeria is a somewhat eccentric, Britishtrained, tough professional soldier who carries a stuffed baby crocodile as a swagger stick.
The pace continued fast and furious on the American Stock Exchange yesterday as turnover exceeded five million shares for the first time in more than three and a half years.

ATLANTA, Ga., Jan. 17-- The Southern quail shoot er looked long and hard up into the lowering sky. He and his visiting Yankee friend had been doing a lot of looking into rainy skies in the last few days.

YONKERS, Jan. 17--Samuel Colin, treasurer of the Jewish Community Center here, where 11 persons lost their lives last month in a fire, died today in Miami Beach, where he was vacationing with his wife. He was 76 years old.

CHICAGO, Jan. 17 (UPI)-- A hearing on disorderly conduct charges against the world heavyweight champion, Cassius Clay, was continued today when his attorney, Chauncey Eskridge, asked for a jury trial.

ST. JAMES, L.I., Jan. 17-- Mr. and Mrs. Thompson Barker of St. James and New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth Mathilde Barker, to Josiah Pierce, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Curtis Pierce of New York and Huntington. A summer wedding is planned.
ALBANY, Jan. 17--Mayor Lindsay will be in the State Capitol tomorrow to have breakfast with the Legislature and try to sell his legislative program over juice and coffee.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 (UPI)--The Equal Employment Opportunity Commission prodded employers today to stop asking job-seekers about their race, color, religion or national origin.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 17--In the Supreme Court of the United States today, the following proceedings were had:
WASHINGTON, Jan. 17-- The Food and Drug Administration, long a target of public and Congressional criticism, got a new chief today and the promise of an organizational shakeup.

The Johnson Administration's report on foreign aid makes the point that its $3.5-billion program is in fine shape. The only trouble is that its beneficiaries, the developing countries, are worse off than ever.

Agreed to decide whether parties representing consumer interests should be allowed to intervene in a Government antitrust suit to oppose a divestiture agreement between the Justice Department and the defendant (No. 79, Cascade Natural Gas Corp v. El Paso Natural Gas Co.; No. 82, California v. El Paso Natural Gas Co.; No. 596, Southern Calif. Edison Co. v. El Paso Natural Gas).

Bobby Hull of the Chicago Black Hawks, this season's goal-scoring leader, and Gordie Howe of the Detroit Red Wings, the career pacesetter, were named yesterday to The Associated Press' National Hockey League All-Star team for the first half of the 1965-66 season.
A not entirely repentant Cub Scout who broke a storm door window during his den meeting has sent the Neediest Cases fund a $3 contribution as payment.
New Yorkers are to be kept up to date on city affairs by Mayor Lindsay in a series of televised "fireside chats."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17-- North Korea has stepped up its military infiltration of South Korea considerably as a response to South Korea's contribution to the Vietnamese war, the commandant of the Marine Corps said today.
The British pound was slightly lower in moderately active trading on foreign exchange markets here yesterday. The pound closed at $2.8042, down 3 points from Friday.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Jan. 16--John Joseph Broderick, famous as one of New York's toughest detectives in the nineteen-twenties and nineteen-thirties, was found dead in bed this morning at his white farmhouse outside this farm trade center. Today was his seventy-second birthday. Members of his family said he had suffered from heart disease for 10 years.

The 1966 fund-raising campaign of the national women's division of the American Jewish Congress will open with a benefit patroness luncheon at the Regency on Jan. 31, with Mrs. I.W. Kahn, the division's campaign cabinet chairman, presiding.

The appointment by Mayor Lindsay of a fifteenmember panel chaired by Louis M. Loeb, former president of the City Bar Association, to recommend new judges should go a long way toward separating the local judiciary from party politics.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17-- Secretary of Commerce John T. Connor said today the "present thinking" of the Government was that the voluntary balanceof-payments program should be ended by February of next year.
ALMERIA, Spain, Jan. l7 (AP)--A collision during a refueling operation today sent a United States B-52 jet and a KC-135 jet tanker crashing in flames along Spain's Mediterranean coast.

The Lockheed Aircraft Corporation has received an $83,674,205 Navy contract for the manufacture of P-38 aircraft in Burbank, Calif. It also has received a $23,824,805 Navy contract for research and development on submarine-launched missiles in Sunnyvale, Calif.
Two measures now before the New York State Legislatures involving Shechita, or Jewish ritual slaughter, have stirred up considerable controversy.

BREWSTER, N.Y., Jan. 17-- Senator Robert F. Kennedy toured New York City's northern suburbs today to talk to the residents about their problems, which ranged from water pollution to the war in Vietnam.
The attempted bloodless coup in heavyweight boxing has apparently been stalled by the Establishment's legal, financial and personal pressure.

NAIROBI, Kenya, Jan. 17-- Two weeks after being expelled on three hours' notice from Rhodesia, the Right Rev. James A. Pike, Episcopal Bishop of California, assailed the Smith regime at a church synod in neighboring Malawi yesterday.
The alumni of St. John's University heard both sides in the 14-day-old teachers' strike against the university last night at an emotional meeting at St. John's Brooklyn center.

ROME, Jan. 17--A 20-year, $25-million bond issue, floated on the Italian money market by the European Coal and Steel Community together with a consortium of eight Italian banks, was underwritten by the consortium even before it was due to go on public sale tomorrow.
The threatening note given to a teller yesterday took so long to read that it led to the arrest of the robbery suspect.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17--Dr. Morris Chafetz, a Harvard psychiatrist, proposed the other day that since "alcohol is here to stay" we should try to develop a healthy attitude toward it by teaching social drinking in the schools. It would be a good idea, the doctor said, for students to begin "practice drinking" in elementary school and continue through college.
Thousands of students here voluntarily stayed after school yesterday to make up for class time lost during the transit strike. But many other youngsters passed up the opportunity.

Supper dances at the French Consulate, 934 Fifth Avenue, will follow the premiere performances of the Comedie Francaise at the New York City Center Feb. 8 and 17. The company, France's oldest theatrical group, will play Moliere's "L' Avare" on the 8th, and Feydeau's "Un Fil a la Patte" on the 17th.
CAPETOWN, South Africa, Jan. 17 (Reuters)--South Africa will hold a general election March 30, Prime Minister Hendrik F. Verwoerd announced here tonight.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 (UPI)--Senate Democrats and Republicans joined today in support of President Johnson's proposal to leave some of the nation's wildest rivers in their untamed state.
Leon Keyserling, an economic adviser to the Transport Workers Union last night called the settlement terms in New York's transit strike "rational, reasonable and fair."
Nathan Milstein's violin recital at Carnegie Hall Sunday night included something for everybody except those who like modern music.
SAIGON, Jan. 17--The Vietcong kidnapped an American aid official tonight on a road 35 miles northwest of Saigon, a United States mission spokesman said.

SYDNEY, Australia--Australia's new banknotes for decimal currency, which were put on show just after the first of the year, will come into use with the country's conversion to decimal currency on Feb. 14.

WASHINGTON Jan. 17 (UPI)--The House was asked today to delay action on proposed Congressional contempt citations against three persons who refused to testify last spring in Chicago at a hearing on Communist activity in that area.
LONDON, Jan. 17 (Reuters)--Noel Coward will make his first appearance on the London stage in 13 years in March with new plays he has written.
The wholesale commodity price index maintained its Wednesday level of 112.6 on Thursday but fell on Friday to 112.3.

The nine-story store and office building at 380 Fifth Avenue, northwest corner of 35th Street, entirely occupied under lease by Bond Clothes, is under contract of sale to Harry G. Silverstein Sons, realty investors. The seller is the FifthThirty-Fifth Corporation, headed by Rhoda L. Schwimmer.
MEXICO CITY, Jan. 17--The body of Joseph Head 3d, a 26year-old Pennsylvania State University graduate student who was robbed and murdered in the State of Puebla 10 days ago, was cremated here today.
Prices of sporting goods-- catcher's mitts, football shoes, athletic clothing and so on will be going up 3 to 5 per cent at retail.
Traffic flowed smoothly up Madison Avenue and down Fifth in the rush hour last night. The avenues were two-way until last Friday when they were made one-way by Traffic Commissioner Henry A. Barnes.

The Duke of Windsor could have kept the throne of England and married the woman of his choice if he had fought a more determined battle, according to the memoirs of the late Lord Beaverbrook, published this week.
Prices on the London Stock Exchange fell slightly yesterday as the financial community awaited the Government's white paper on investment incentives.
A fire damaged one of three presses at The New York Post last night and water from an automatic sprinkler system damaged the two other presses.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17--Republican Congressional leaders, staging their own televised "State of the Union Message," voiced support tonight for Administration policy in the Vietnam war but urged economies in civilian programs, rather than new taxes, to pay for it.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 17 (UPI)--The National Collegiate Athletic Association Football Rules Committee wound up its 1966 meeting today by outlawing a pyramid defense against place kicks, but made no major changes in college football's playing rules.

ROSLYN, L.I., Jan. 17-- Jule W. Kanegsberg, vice president of the Blanchard Press in Garden City, printers of periodicals, died yesterday at North Shore Hospital in Manhasset. He was 55 years old and lived at 90 Oak Drive.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 17-- The White House said today that no deadline had been set for ending President Johnson's peace offensive.

Stefan Wolpe and Lou Harrison Composers, have been granted Phebe Ketchum Thorne Fellowships of $10,800 each. They will be paid $3,600 a year for three years, the maximum that an artist on fellowship can exclude from his income for tax purposes if he is not working for a degree.

An investigation of HaryouAct's "summer crash program" of 1965 has concluded that, while the program fired the imaginations of thousands of Harlem residents, it was marked by haphazard administration, faulty record-keeping, and inadequate follow-up procedures.

Conferred with William Porter, Deputy U.S. Ambassador to Vietnam; met with Democratic Congressional leaders to discuss scheduling of messages to be sent to Congress in the coming weeks; announced that Assistant Secretary of State Jack Hood Vaughn would succeed Sargent Shriver as director of the Peace Corps; White House said that President Johnson has set "no deadline" on his peace crusade in Vietnam.
There are enough laws on the books already against deception and abuse in advertising and packaging, a leading executive in the food industry said yesterday.

FLORENCE, Italy, Jan. 17 --Emilio Pucci does not have to lie awake nights, but those jersey dresses designed by Ken Scott and shown last weekend during the Italian boutique collections in the Pitti Palace here may someday give him a lot of competition.

BAY SHORE, L.I., Jan. 17-- Edmund Ward Poor, treasurer and a director of the Grumman Aircraft Engineering Corporation at Bethpage, drowned last night in a canal behind his home, 28 Garner Lane. He was 61 years old.

LUSAKA, Zambia, Jan. 17 The Government said today that it had ordered Britain's Deputy High Commissioner out of Zambia because his continued presence was considered harmful to BritishZambian relations.

LONDON, Jan. 17 (Reuters)--Britain's traditionally staid Couture Week took an eccentric turn today when it opened with a show of plastic hats, elastic jewelry to decorate hands and feet, and fun fur coats in long-haired African monkey and American raccoon. Gimmicks were thick enough to set visitors wondering if they had somehow stumbled into the current spring Italian showings--noted for their outrageousness--rather than conventional London.

THE National Collegiate Athletic Associaiton has enough skeletons rattling around in its closet to supply the anatomy classes at every medical school in the country. It really uncovered a lulu at its recent convention when this sterling collection of educators set a deadline for compliance with a rule previously passed but not effectuated.

MOSCOW, Jan. 17--Leonid I. Brezhnev, First Secretary of the Soviet Communist party, flew back from Mongolia today with a mutual assistance treaty providing for unspecified joint military measures in Mongolia, which is on Communist China's northern frontier.
PHOENIX, Ariz., Jan. 17 (AP)--The American Chemical Society opened its winter meeting tonight by awarding $8,500 to researchers throughout the United States.

A WINTER baking spree is one way to get rid of minor frustrations through kneading, and a feeling of satisfaction results from producing a tastetempting treat. The aroma of baking breads coming from the kitchen welcomes family and friends in from their wintertime outdoor activities.
The team ranking, with points figured on a 10-9-8-7-6-5-43-2-1 basis for first through 10th places (first-place votes in parentheses) and won-lost records through games of last Saturday:
LAHORE, Pakistan, Jan. 17 (UPI)--Four officials of two opposition political parties were arrested yesterday on a charge of having violated the Government ban on public gatherings.
The Alleghany Corporation's control since 1954 of the New York Central Railroad has been challenged again.

TRENTON, Jan. 17--Gov. Richard J. Hughes apologized to Senator Robert F. Kennedy today for the "discourteous bandying" of the name of Mrs. John F. Kennedy as a possible New Jersey Democratic candidate for the United States Senate.
The stock market moved into new high ground again yesterday, but profit taking shaded early gains and closing prices generally were below their best levels of the session.
ROCHESTER, Minn., Jan. 17 (UPI)--Mickey Mantle, wearing a 10-gallon Stetson hat, checked in at the Mayo Clinic today for examination of a troublesome right shoulder.
Plans for the first AngloSoviet film co-production, a spectacle embracing live-action drama, music and dance as well as animated sequences, were announced here yesterday by Oliver Unger.

NEW DELHI, Jan. 17--Former Finance Minister Moraji Desai, an aspirant to the Prime Ministership, accused the Congress party's president, Kumaraswami Kamaraj, and most state chief ministers today of attempts to put pressure on the voters and on him.

Louis J. Lefkowitz, New York State Attorney General, yesterday ripped into New York's savings and loan brokers --the men who for a fee solicit savings accounts for savings and loan associations, mostly those in California.

Henry Spinelli, a pianist from Pittsburgh, pulled no punches for his New York recital debut Sunday night at Town Hall. He played two works only, large ones, neither of them cream puffs; the Bach E minor Partita and the Ives "Concord" Sonata. What's more, he gave them without intermission.
HOUSTON, Jan. 17 (AP)-- Directors of the Pan American Sulphur Company will meet Wednesday to review the company announced plans to raise prices of sulphur $5 a ton.

PARIS, Jan. 17--A key witness in the Ben Barka case, which has puzzled Frenchmen over the roles of their competing secret police organizations, died tonight just before he was to have been arrested. According to the French press agency, the witness, Georges Figon, shot himself as the police were knocking on his door.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17-- The Federal Government is considering the dispatch of special investigating teams to areas of tight labor supply to determine the extent of the nation's growing manpower shortage and what can be done to ease it.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 17-- Southern lawyers told the Supreme Court today that their states were being arbitrarily punished by the Voting Rights Act of 1965.
ALBANY, Jan. 17--Alexander Aldrich, who is Governor Rockefeller's 37-year-old cousin and executive assistant, announced today that he would resign Feb. 1 to run for Congress.

A FUNNY thing happened to Hughes Rudd on his way to celebrity. The Central Intelligence Agency offered him a place in its mystic mansions. Spurred by that glancing recognition he won a prize from The Paris Review.
ALBANY, Jan. 17--Governor Rockefeller indicated today that New York City had little chance of getting the nearly $600-million more in state financial aid sought by Mayor Lindsay.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Jan. 17 (Reuters)--The Jakarta Military Command today banned all demonstrations in the area of the capital, saying that recent student demonstrations against rising prices had been exploited by "imperialists and Communists."

MIAMI, Jan. 17--A crowd of 21,667 assembled today under clear blue tropical skies and in 66-degree weather to open Hialeah's 39th season of winter racing. The patrons set an openingday record mutuel handle of $1,932,629.

Sherrill C. Corwin has announced his resignation as a director of the Allied Artists Pictures Corporation to avoid the possibility of a conflict of interest in view of his recent election by the directors of the National Association of Theatre Owners as president-designate, to succeed Marshall Fine in October.

TRENTON, Jan. 17--Gov. Richard J. Hughes apologized to United States Senator Robert F. Kennedy of New York today for the "discourteous bandying" of the name of Mrs. John F. Kennedy as a possible Democratic candidate in New Jersey for the United States Senate.

ATLANTA, Jan. 17 (AP)-- Gov. Carl E. Sanders said today that he would call a special election for Julian Bond's seat in the Georgia House of Representatives unless an alternative was found. The Governor acted after a Federal Court hearing was set for five days past the deadline for calling the election.
The election of three new members of the board of directors of the Glen Alden Corporation was announced yesterday. They are Patrick J. Clifford, Maurice Goodman and Luther H. Hodges.
The Port of Saigon is expected to be able of handle 600,000 tons a month of inbound cargo by the end of this year, a leading American specialist said here yesterday.
The New York Jets got a $400,000 scare yesterday, Happily for them, the American Football League and the party of the first part, Joe Namath, it was only a scare.
Mayor Lindsay was introduced to a new phase of his job as the city's Chief Magistrate yesterday when he issued his first proclamations. Aden Blast Injures Briton
BERLIN, Jan. 17--When the curtain fell in Berlin's Schiller Theater on Saturday, an angry voice rang out from a back row, piercing the silence: "My God, that play was bad."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 (AP) --President Johnson told Congress today he was deeply concerned about political unrest, potential famine and national enmities in much of the lessdeveloped world.

TORONTO, Jan. 17--More than 350 exhibits concerning the tangled finances of the nowinsolvent Atlantic Acceptance Corporation were introduced today at the opening of a Government inquiry into the causes and results of the finance company's collapse.

MONTE CARLO, Monaco, Jan. 17 (AP)--Hazardous driving conditions over twisting mountain roads made slippery by snow and ice cut the field in the 35th annual Monte Carlo Rally to just over 100 cars tonight.

MIAMI, Jan. 17--The Phipps family, three generations strong, attended the opening of Hialeah Park today. It was worthwhile as one of the family horses, Time Tested, won the second half of the Royal Poinciana.

CHICAGO, Jan. 17--George B. Young, president of Field Enterprises, Inc., publisher of The Chicago Sun-Times and The Chicago Daily News, announced today that the parent company would start a new suburban daily on Jan. 31.

HULL, England, Jan. 17-- Reginald Maudling, deputy leader of the Conservative party, said tonight that most Labor party Members of Parliament felt that Britain should end her support of United States policy on Vietnam.

A 19-year-old youth accused of robbing from two to three taxi drivers a week for the last three months was seized early yesterday in a Harlem basement by three detectives and a slightly wounded victim.

MANY times in close basketball games, the last second shot is the most important. With thousands screaming in an arena, an athlete releases the ball as the buzzer sounds and the ball falls through the hoop for what might be the winning point or points.
The General Foods Corporation had record sales and earnings in its fiscal third quarter and nine months, it was reported yesterday by C.W. Cook, president.
CHICAGO, Jan. 17 (AP)-- Dr. Gary' Steiner, a University of Chicago psychology profe ssor and author, died today after plunging five floors from a window in a downtown office building.

The directors of the Franklin National Bank, Mineola, L.I., have promoted James B. Agnew to senior vice president and vice chairman of the metropolitan division. He formerly was a vice president of the metropolitan division.

LAGOS, Nigeria, Jan. 17-- The head of Nigeria's military government declared today that all army units throughout the country had sworn loyalty to the new regime following the weekend coup by a small band of young officers.
Memberships on the New York Stock Exchange were almost as popular yesterday as some of the glamour issues.

Capt. John F. Morin, master of the tug Patricia Moran, which was sent to the bottom of Kill Van Kull last week with the loss of four lives, said here yesterday that he was unable to maneuver clear of the tanker with which his craft collided.
Directors of the Ashland Oil and Refining Company announced yesterday a two-forone split of its stock and an increased quarterly dividend.

The appointment of Paul W. Whelehon to be vice president-sales manager of P. Ballantine Sons, brewer of Newark, N.J., was announced yesterday by John E. Farrell, president. Mr. Whelehon will report to John J. Soughan, vice president-marketing, and will be responsible for all wholesale, branch, retail, special sales and ale development operations of Ballantine.

The city's general relief rolls have continued to rise even though relief has declined across the nation. And while nationally the number of fatherless children on relief reflects a steady increase, the rise in the city has been precipitous.

PEKING--Communist China is charging, in the wake of Moscow's diplomatic activity in countries along the Chinese frontier, that the Soviet Union has taken a new step toward a worsening of relations between the two Governments.
Deputy Mayor Robert Price had a secret meeting with Michael J. Quill while the Transport Workers Union president was a prisoner in Bellevue Hospital during the 12-day transit strike.
SAIGON, Jan. 17--The United States formally announced today that it would honor the Lunar New Year cease-fire proposed by the Vietcong and accepted, with modifications, by the South Vietnamese.
Vincent J. Donehue, the Broadway and television director, died yesterday morning at Lenox Hill Hospital, Park Avenue and 77th Street. He had Hodgkin's disease. His age was 50.
Charles (Ruby) Stein, who is described by the Government as the most notorious loan shark in the New York area, pleaded guilty yesterday in Federal District Court to evading $139,213 in income taxes.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17-- The Senate today gave swift, unanimous approval to Presi dent Johnson's nomination of Robert C. Weaver to be Secretary of the new Cabinet-level Department of Housing and Urban Development.
Charles (Ruby) Stein, who is described by the Government as the most notorious loan shark in the New York area, pleaded guilty yesterday in Federal District Court to evading $139,213 in income taxes.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17-- The Senate today gave swift, unanimous approval to Presi dent Johnson's nomination of Robert C. Weaver to be Secretary of the new Cabinet-level Department of Housing and Urban Development.

CARLISLE, Pa., Jan. 17-- Mr. and Mrs. George H. Bostock have announced the engagement of their daughter, Dr. Barbara Ann Bostock, to Dr. William Bell. His parents are Mr. and Mrs. William R. Bell of Rochester.
The city school system said yesterday that it "anticipated" a grant of $3,537,940 from the Ford Foundation to develop a new high school curriculum.

Parks Commissioner Thomas P.F. Hoving paid a surprise visit yesterday to the locker room of the women's bathhouse at Thomas Jefferson park in East Harlem and found about 75 elderly men playing cards there with coats and hats on.

HOUSTON, Jan. 18 (UPI) The Houston Oilers of the American Football League, who recently handed their head coach, Hugh (Bones) Taylor, a three-year contract, announced tonight they had rescinded the contract and would not rehire Taylor.

ALBANY, Jan. 18 John V. Lindsay came to the state capital today for the first time as Mayor of New York. Like his predecessors, the city's 103d Mayor came in search of money, and like many of them he did not get what he wanted.
ALBANY, Jan. 18 Governor Rockefeller sent a budget marked down slightly below $4billion to the Legislature today.
The appointment of John L. Eyre as president of the Saguenay Shipping, Ltd., was announced yesterday by Aluminium, Ltd., parent company of the Montreal shipping concern.
One more survey, this one taken by the National Industrial Conference Board, has reported still another bullish outlook for business conditions in the next six months.
LONDON, Jan. 18 (Reuters) Eton, the private school that had educated more prime ministers than any other, may abandon its uniform of top hat, deep white collar and black tailcoat.

The right of a probationary fireman to his job despite the fact that as a Jehovah's Witness he cannot salute the flag was defended yesterday by Fire Commissioner Robert O. Lowery and Corporation Counsel J. Lee Rankin.
The financially hard-pressed city administration announced yesterday that it wanted to borrow $253,240,000 a larger sum that any city has ever borrowed at one time.

A powerful voice in organized labor has now been raised in support of the proposition that there must never again be strikes of such paralyzing dimensions as the New York transit tie-up. Walter P. Reuther rightly declares that "society can't tolerate stoppages which endanger the very existence of society."

SACRAMENTO, Calif., Jan. 18 (AP) State education officials unanimously agreed today they had no legal grounds to revoke the teaching credentials of a San Diego teacher, Mrs. Geri Turner Davis, for her controversial play, "A Cat Called Jesus."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 Representative Wright Patman lost another skirmish today in his battle against legislation to ease antitrust restrictions on bank mergers.
LOS ANGELES, Jan. 18 A prominent lawyer was arrested here today on a charge of hiring a man to murder his divorced wife and her lawyer, Murray M. Chotiner.
The Los Angeles Unified School District sold $27.5-million of Series E bonds yesterday at a price that set its annual net interest cost at 3.5455 per cent.
Paperboard production increased 11.8 per cent, to 454,400 tons, in the week ended Jan. 15 from the level in the 1965 week, the National Paperboard Association reported yesterday.
LONDON, Jan. 18 The Chief Justice of Rhodesia, Sir Hugh Beadle, flew here today for talks with Prime Minister Wilson and other British officials.
OTTAWA, Jan. 18 The Government called on the new Parliament today to approve costly programs for education and to bolster the country's agriculture and industry.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 18 American President Lines is going through with its original plan to have its liner President Roosevelt stop at Israeli as well as Arab ports on a forthcoming round-the-world cruise.
AUSTIN, Tex., Jan. 18 Campus liberals have rallied to defend the right of Royce McPhail, Grand Dragon of the Ku Klux Klan in Texas, to speak at the University of Texas.

THE boutiques those terribly personal, little shops that have spawned the adventurous fashions of the nineteen-sixties are on the threshold of big business. Several New York boutiques are initiating wholesale and franchise operations for stores throughout the country that would like to capitalize on their recent and rapid successes.

ON the assumption, perhaps, that there are people in this city who still don't get enough everyday razzle-dazzle, confusion and cacaphony, the Film-Makers' Cinematheque, which hustles an "underground" movies pitch in an old-fashioned basement theater at 125 West 41st Street, is providing an additional excess of it.

The presence of Vice President and Mrs. Humphrey added 3 fillip to the American Ballet Theater's opening last night. They and members of the National Council on the Arts were guests of honor at the New York State Theater.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 (UPI) The House Small Business Committee, which favors tighter regulation of tax-exempt foundations, reported today the story of a foundation in Stuart, Fla., that is accused of using its multimillion-dollar assets mainly for the benefits of the man who controls it.
The accents of erudition including the voices of two Nobel laureates rose in a hall of marble columns here this week.

Countess Raoul de Roussy de Sales, widow of a well known French correspondent and author here during World War II, died Monday in Lenox Hill Hospital of a cerebral hemorrhage. She was 74 years old and lived at 45 East 66th Street.
SAIGON, Jan. 18 Kientuong Province is a desolate place nestled against the Cambodian border 50 miles west of here.
Jordan Christopher, the young guitarist-singer, musical director of Arthur, the discotheque, has been signed for his second film, "The Return of the Seven" by the Mirisch Corporation.

The City Council was thrown into an uproar yesterday by charges that some members of its staff had been picked without adequate attention to their qualifications.

ON "THE ZOO TRAIN" to Capetown, Jan. 18 Like a flock of migrating birds, South African civil servants are traveling the 1,000 miles from Pretoria to Capetown this week as the Government shifts from one of its capitals to the other.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 18 The United States protested today against proposed United Nations aid to the University of Havana on the ground that the institution's problems were caused by the Cuban Government's actions.

In the words of one of its own advertising campaign themes, Doyle Dane Bernbach, Inc., must be doing something right. At least an awful lot of advertisers think it is.
William C. Agee and Mrs. Patricia Fitzgerald Mandel have been appointed to staff posts at the Whitney Museum of American Art.

LONDON, Jan. 18 The rival American and British bidders for the British Diners' Club sat around the peace table today discussing expansion of the British credit-card business through a trans-Atlantic partnership.
The American Stock Exchange almost made it 15 in a row yesterday.
ALBANY, Jan. 18 New York City received an additional $100 million from the state today to help maintain the 15-cent transit fare, but it may be some time before the cash can be used for that purpose.
PARIS, Jan. 18 A major amalgamation of banking and heavy industry was announced today by the vast Compagnie Financere de Suez and the large private industrial enterprise, Pont-a-Mousson.

LINCOLN, Neb., Jan. 18, (AP) Nebraska took the Big Eight Conference basketball lead tonight as the Cornhuskers defeated sixth-ranked Kansas, 83-75. Nebraska has a 4-0 wonlost conference record while Kansas has a 4-1 mark.
Senator Robert F. Kennedy lent the Kennedy touch yesterday to Orin Lehman's campaign for the Congressional seat vacated by Mayor Lindsay in Manhattan's 17th District.
Caution remained as the watchword yesterday in the Government bond market, but a new vitality, however durable, was evident in corporate debt and municipal bond circles.

Stockholders of the Hackensack (N.J.) Trust Company approved yesterday "by an overwhelming margin" the conversion of the bank from a state to a national charter. The move has already been given preliminary approval by the Controller of the Currency, James J. Saxon.
NEW DELHI, Jan. 18 The leader of India's Congress party predicted tonight that Mrs. Indira Gandhi would be elected tomorrow as the country's third Prime Minister.
ALBANY, Jan. 18 The state's programs for the mentally ill are crippled by inadequate staff and the absence of a commissioner, an assembly of citizens told the Governor and legislators here today.
NORTH BELLMORE, L.I., Jan. 18 Miss Harriet Goldberg and Ira Frederic Maltin plan to marry on March 31.
ALBANY, Jan. 18 Following is the text of the annual budget message sent to the Legislature today by Governor Rockefeller:
WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 President Johnson asked Congress today to approve United States participation in the Asian Development Bank.
PHOENIX, Ariz., Jan. 18 A panel of dental scientists suggested today that tooth decay might be reduced if people spent less time chewing easily digestible foods such as starches and sugars.

MONTREAL, Jan. 18 (UPI) Bobby Hull of the Chicago Black Hawks, leading the National Hockey League in scoring with 59 points on 36 goals and 23 assists, has won $500 for leading the league at the midpoint of the season.

PARIS Americans are too impatient in love, war and diplomacy. They expect maximum results in minimum time. This ingrained habit can often lead to divorce or disappointment and, both militarily and diplomatically, the latter is true of our approach to Vietnam.

SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, Jan. 18 The papal nuncio, three jeeps filled with American soldiers and a dozen American newsmen were pinned down by machine-gun fire from the national police on a main boulevard for 10 minutes tonight.
WHAT is the Columbia Broadcasting System up to? Is it trying to demoralize America still further? Doesn't it know there is a war on?

The Columbia Broadcasting System has notified the country's largest advertisers that it contemplates revision of the traditional practice of granting discounts to purchasers of large blocks of time on the air.
LONDON, Jan. 18 A critic of Conservative party policy, Angus Maude, resigned today from his position on the party's front bench in the House of Commons.

STRATFORD, Conn., Jan. 18 Mrs. Thomas D. Stoliker has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Louisa Stillwell Benson, to Michael John Spinelli, son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis J. Spinelli of Pittsford, N.Y.
CHICAGO, Jan. 18 The role of Dr. Andrew C. Ivy in the development of Krebiozen was described today as solely that of an adviser on scientific testing methods.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 Attorney General Nicholas deB. Katzenbach told the Supreme Court today that the Voting Rights Act of 1965 was an appropriate exercise of Congress's power to prevent racial discrimination in voting.

President Johnson was giving a last scrutiny the other day to a list of designers for membership in the new National Council on the Humanities. Beside a professor's name there was a notation that he had attacked Administration policies at a teach-in on Vietnam.
A $15,000-a-year position of housing consultant was set up yesterday by Mrs. Constance Baker Motley, Manhattan Borough President. She appointed Miss Frances Levenson to the post.
The stock market climbed to record highs yesterday for the third successive session, but some profit taking in the afternoon erased part of the early gains.
Soybeans were the protagonist yesterday in a futures trading drama day that surprised many analysts. Prices climbed as much as 8 cents a bushel after a slow start.
A national emergency committee of liberal clergymen has begun an intensive grassroots effort to counteract pressures on President Johnson for the renewal of bombing in North Vietnam.

"Cinerama's Russian Adventure," a film made up of highlights of seven feature films made by the Soviets in Kinopanorama, a process compatible with three-screen Cinerama, is being prepared for a New York showing around Easter.
JERUSALEM, (Israeli) Sector), Jan. 18 The World Zionist Organization, concerned about its declining influence, opened its governing body today to prominent Jews unaffiliated with Zionist groups.

The former head of the Building Department's receivership inspection squad was suspended yesterday under charges that he took kickbacks from his inspectors and met with and accepted a drink and money from a landlord's representative.
A clinical psychologist who was also a successful song writer plunged to his death early yesterday from his seventh-floor apartment at 322 Central Park West.

IT TAKES many sharp-eyed buyers and a lot of travel ing to Germany, Austria, France, Finland, Spain and various parts of the United States to put together the kind of furniture show opening today on Macy's ninth floor.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 Lincoln Gordon, United States Ambassador to Brazil, was named by President Johnson today as Assistant Secretary of State for Inter-American Affairs. He succeeeds Jack Hood Vaughn, who has been appointed director of the Peace Corps.
An $18.6-million Navy contract for production of aluminum powder has been awarded to the Aluminum Corporation of America.
SAIGON, Jan. 18 Leaflets urging Communist guerrillas to go home to their families during the Lunar New Year holiday period fell on Vietnamese citizens and United States soldiers in this city today.

The Scott Paper Company attained record earnings for the eighth straight year and set a sales mark for the 13th consecutive year, according to its 1965 annual report issued yesterday by Thomas B. McCabe, chairman.

BEVERLY HILLS, Calif., Jan. 18 The police here are quietly investigating the strangely twisted backgrounds of the two would-be kidnappers of Leonard k. Friestone amid growing indications that the men may have been involved in other crimes.

BONN, Jan. 18 West Germany's biggest refugee organization reacted with indignation and threats today to a statement by a Bonn Cabinet minister yesterday suggesting that Germany is prepared to yield some of its former eastern province's in a frontier settlement with Poland.

NEW HAVEN, Jan. 18 Kingman Brewster Jr., president of Yale University, described today as "a conscientious effort," though "naive and misguided," the recent "factfinding" trip to North Vietnam by Staughton Lynd, an assistant professor of history.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 The Pentagon's plans to increase the size of the armed forces include a major expansion in the Army's new glamor forces, the "Sky Cavalry," military officials said today.
My Fair Lady" at the Crierion Theater. The Sound of Music" at the Rivoli.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 Personal income rose by $4.4billion in December to an annual rate of $550.5-billion, the Commerce Department reported today.
LOS ANGELES, Jan. 18 (AP) The County Coroner's office reported today that Miss. Nina Clemens Gabrilowitsch, the last direct descendant of Mark Twain, had died Sunday. She was 55 years old.
Enrique Negron, the 56year-old Bronx man whose rescue of a besieged patrolman cost him, he said, his friends and his grocery store, received a job yesterday.

MOSCOW, Jan. 18 The chief designer of the Soviet space program, Sergei P. Korolev, a figure cloaked in anonymity until his death last Thursday at age 59, was given a state funeral in snow-swept Red Square today.
PINE MOUNTAIN, Ga., Jan. 18 The annual board of directors' meeting of the Shootin' and Excusin' Society of North America way held yesterday at the quail-shooting preserve of Callaway Gardens.

TOKYO, Jan. 18 (AP) Communist China, charged today that in the weeks since the United States halted bombing at tacks on North Vietnam, air raids in Laos "have become mor frantic than ever before." It said that American planes were spraying toxic chemicals over upper Laos.

ALBANY, Jan. 18 Republicans presented their plan for mapping new legislative districts today. They pronounced it superior to the Democratic plan offered last month, but voiced readiness to compromise.

BEDFORD, N.Y., Jan, 18 Mr. and Mrs. Robert Leon Grosjean of Hope Hill, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Marilen Lahr Grosjean, to Rodman King Tilt Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Tilt of Sugar Hill Farm.

Rudolf C. van den Elsakker, board chairman of Montanore, Inc., importers and exporters of nonferrous metals, died Monday in Columbus Hospital, apparently of a heart attack. His age was 55, and he lived at 206 East 20th Street. He was also president of the Ferro Trading Corporation, importers and exporters of ferrous metals.
KINGSTON, N.Y., Jan. 18 Dr. Herbert, I. Bloom, rabbi emeritus of Congregation Temple Emanuel here, died today at the Kingston Hospital. His age was 66.
MIAMI, Jan. 18 (AP) Graustark continued his unbeaten string today with an easy five-length victory in the Grenada Purse at Hialeah.

BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 18 The wave of change rising from the Vatican Council has washed to the foothills of the Argentine Andes, carrying strife and sorrow to the doorstep of an elderly Roman Catholic Archbishop.
The United States Steel Corporation, the nation's largest producer of steel, served notice yesterday that it intended to compete more vigorously in the chemicals industry.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 A youth who pleaded guilty to bombing the homes of Negro civil rights workers in McComb, Miss., testified today that the United Klans of America, Inc., had organized and executed much of the racial violence in that city.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Jan. 18 Rio de Janeiro's carnival will be held on schedule despite the recent devastating cloudbursts, it was announced today.
The above advertisement for Suntory, Ltd., a Japanese producer of alcoholic beverages, suggests that all is not tea gardens in the Land of the Rising Sun.
W.R. Grace Co., a big chemical, transportation and manufacturing concern, disclosed yesterday that it had sold certain assets of its polymer chemicals division to the Allied Chemical Corporation.

The Rhodesian deadlock has taken a possibly hopeful turn with the visit to London of the Chief Justice, Sir Hugh Beadle. He was invited by the British Government and went with Prime Minister Ian Smith's consent. Since his position is independent of the colonial government, and since he is a civil servant appointed by Queen Elizabeth, he could provide the needed link for a kind of negotiation between Salisbury and London.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 18 (UPI) Trailing by 20 points at half-time, the Detroit Pistons stormed back tonight to upset the Boston Celtics, 116-115, in a National Basketball Association game.
NEW CITY, N.Y., Jan. 18 Ten women succeeded temporarily today in halting demolition experts seeking to make last-minute plans for razing the historic Archer M. Huntington Manor House.
The 108-foot tug Patricia Moran went down in less than three minutes after being in a collision with the 225-foot tanker Miorania Marlin last Wednesday, three of her crew members said here yesterday.

SAIGON, Jan. 18 United States military officials announced today that an additional 7,000 combat troops were going ashore in South Vietnam, bringing the number of Americans fighting here to nearly 190,000.

THE fascination animals hold for children may be stimu lated along with reading habits by humorous fantasy about nature's creatures, such as a frog choir vocalizing around a pond, or by a scientific book on the kangaroo or the whale.

A citywide program to enroll the 270,000 elderly New Yorkers who have not yet filed for supplementary medical insurance under Medicare was announced yesterday by the Economic Opportunity Committee and the Social Security Administration. The cut-off date for filing is March 31.

Theater-party agents will be the subject of Gertrude Berg's next comedy, "The Playgirls," which is scheduled to arrive here Oct. 5. Miss Berg has been away from the local stage since ill health forced her to cut short a successful run in "Dear Me, the Sky Is Falling" in 1963.

Holding that Customs had suppressed 12 books it held to be obscene "for an unlawfully protracted time." United States District Judge Marvin E. Frankel yesterday ordered the paperbacks released to the claimant.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 Securities industry opposition to the creation and management of a mutual fund by the First National City Bank of New York rests solely on industry fears that banks could run mutual funds "better or cheaper or both," a spokesman for the bank said today.
Mayor Lindsay left a formal dinner party last night and sped to a four-alarm fire in Brooklyn, where, in evening clothes, he shook hands with firemen and nearly slipped on the icy street.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 (UPI) The American Nazi party is going to get back its swastika arm bands and its portrait of Adolf Hitler, the Internal Revenue Service announced today.

"Tall Figure, Number IV," an 8-foot 10 inch bronze sculpture of a woman by Albert Giacometti, who died Jan. 11, was shipped yesterday by the Sidney Janis Gallery to a private collector in the Midwest, who bought it for "upward of $60,000."
Kings Point beat Pratt, 52-50, last night on a last-second basket by Bill Heffernan.

The Western Union Telegraph Company announced yesterday that it had offered the holders of its common stock the right to subscribe to 376,059 shares of a new issue of 4.6 per cent convertible cumulative preferred at $100 each.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 18 Secretary of Agriculture Orville L. Freeman said today that the United States would contribute $130-million toward the 1966-68 operations of the World Food Program.

The Los Angeles Dodgers, who won 13 straight games in a late-season surge that enabled them to capture the National League pennant, were named the team of the year for 1965 yesterday in the annual Associated Press poll.

NEW MARTINSVILLE, W. Va., Jan. 18 (UPI) Ralph Conley, a 54-year-old reporter for The Wheeling Intelligencer, was sentenced to five days in jail and fined $10 yesterday on contempt of court charges because of an article he wrote.
The wholesale commodity price index fell Monday to 112.1 from 112.3 on Friday.
SAIGON, Jan. 18 Premier Nguyen Cao Ky hinted today that "a small group of people" was attempting to overthrow his seven-month-old Government.
ALBANY, Jan. 18 (AP) Mayor Lindsay appears destined to be plagued with transportation problems.
HONG KONG, Jan. 18 Communist China declared today that a new worldwide movement against the influence of the United States and the Soviet Union had begun.
CINCINNATI, Jan. 18 (UPI) The Cincinnati Royals beat the Los Angeles Lakers, 119108, and ran their winning streak to eight games tonight in a National Basketball Association game.

ALBANY, Jan. 18 The Governor's budget stirred little debate after it was introduced today. Many legislators, it seemed, were more interested in John V. Lindsay who was making his first trip to Albany as Mayor.
WHITEHALL, Wis., Jan. 18 (AP) A Pennsylvania teenager, sought in the slaying of his parents, was arrested here tonight when his car skidded off a hilly highway into a snowbank.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 The Brotherhood of Locomotive Firemen and Enginemen opened today its campaign to restore thousands of firemen's jobs on the nation's railroads.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 President Johnson was described today as "grateful" to Senator Everett McKinley Dirksen for his support of Administration policy in Vietnam.
KALAMAZOO, Mich. Jan. 18 (AP) Dr. Marshall M. Knappen, a professor of political science at Western Michigan University, was found dead in his apartment yesterday. He was 65 years old.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 18 Harvard's hockey team routed Dartmouth, 8-3, tonight in Watson Rink.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 Behind the present debate on America's future strategy in Vietnam lie two fundamentally different arguments about modern China.
The Sinclair Oil Corporation announced yesterday the election to its board of Donald M. Kendall. He is president and chief executive officer of Pepsico, Inc.

Lawrence Cardinal Shehan of Baltimore, supported by Vatican officials, yesterday ordered the Rev. Gomar A. De Pauw to report to him and reiterated his directive that the priest leave the Catholic Traditionalist Movement.

TRENTON, Jan. 18 (AP) Gov. Richard J. Hughes was stuck for 10 minutes tonight in a stalled elevator at the Hotel Hildebrecht with about 10 other persons. He said he was forced to jump about five feet to escape.
The British pound was steady in moderate trading on foreign exchange markets here yesterday. The currency's closing quotation of $2.8044 reflected a gain of 2 points over Monday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 Robert C. Weaver was sworn in today as the nation's first Negro Cabinet member and was promptly instructed by President Johnson to help "make our cities places where the good life is possible."
The Nassau Heart Association will benefit from the second Queen of Hearts Ball, to be held on Jan. 29 in the Garden City (L.I.) Hotel.
The Port of New York welcomed yesterday a frequent visitor under a new name the North German Lloyd liner Europa, the former Swedish liner Kungsholm.
PALO ALTO, Calif., Jan. 18 Miss Jean Hunter Wilbur and Gerald Kermit Gleason, student at the Harvard University Law School, plan to marry in the summer.
ST. LOUIS, Jan. 18 (UPI) The St. Louis Hawks rallied from a 21-point deficit in the third period tonight to defeat the New York Knickerbockers, 109-107, in a National Basketball Association game.

BOGOTA, Colombia, Jan. 18 (UPI) Authorities said today that early investigation had indicated that the pilot of an Avianca Airline DC4 that crashed into the Caribbean last week, killing 56 persons, suffered a heart attack.

The Dry Dock Savings Bank announced here yesterday the election of Lawrence Lachman as a trustee. Mr. Lachman, a native New Yorker, is president of Bloomingdale's, a major retail division of Federated Department Stores, Inc.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 (AP) The United States deplored today the expulsion of American newsmen from Indonesia and declared that "the free flow of information is essential."
TORONTO, Jan. 18 A government inquiry into the collapse of the Atlantic Acceptance Corporation in June, 1965, adjourned today until Feb. 7, when further exhibits will be introduced.
LAGOS, Nigeria, Jan. 18 A bloody power struggle has set in among the leaders of Nigeria's two-day-old military Government.
CANBERRA, Australia, Wednesday, Jan. 19 (AP) Prime Minister Sir Robert Menzies announced today that he was retiring from leadership of the Government.
PITTSBURGH, Jan. 18 A year-round academic calendar was blamed today for most of the recent financial difficulties at the University of Pittsburgh.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 Roman Catholic, Protestant and Jewish leaders formed a coalition today against poverty which they assailed as "morally intolerable" in this rich nation.
Paradise Island, a 750-acre tract just off Nassau in the Bahamas, has been sold by Huntington Hartford to the Mary Carter Paint Company of Tampa, Fla.
The Sun Oil Company announced yesterday a sharp advance in earnings for 1965 and a four-for-three stock split.
DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., Jan. 18 Three times in the 24-hour race at Le Mans, France, in 1959, 1962 and 1963, the name "Elde" appeared on the list of drivers for Ferrari.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 Walter P. Reuther, disturbed by the damaging impact of the New York transit strike, spelled out in more detail than before a plan he is espousing to insure that public employes obtain equitable contract gains without resorting to walkouts.

Frank (Tug) McGraw, the first pitcher in the history of the New York Mets to defeat Sandy Koufax, took time out from his duties with the Marines yesterday to become the first Met to sign a contract for 1966.
Secretary of the Treasury Henry H. Fowler was in New York yesterday to open the silver anniversary campaign for United States savings bonds.

A 140-acre estate and dairy farm on Silver Lake in Red Hook, Dutchess County, N.Y., has been purchased by the State Department of Social Welfare. The estate, which is to become a branch of the Highland Training School for Boys, will be used as a rehabilitation center for youths under 13 years of age.

ATLANTA, Jan. 18 (UPI) Gov. Carl E. Sanders today set a special election for Feb. 23 to fill the seat in the State House of Representatives that was denied to Representative-elect Julian Bond because of his views on Vietnam.

The second "Late Late Concert" of the season will be given, on Feb. 5 at 11:30 P.M. at Philharmonic Hall. Allan Miller will conduct the Late Late Concert Players and the Concert Choir of the Master Institute in a program of music by Purcell, Mozart, Bach and Haydn. Tickets are now on sale at the Philharmonic Hall box office and Bloomingdale's. All seats are $2.
The Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company announced here yesterday the election as a director of Lynn A. Townsend, president of the Chrysler Corporation.
Directors of the S.S. Kresge Company proposed a two-forone split of its common stock yesterday and indicated plans to increase dividends starting with the June quarterly payment.

Roger Kellaway, a jazz pianist whose interests range from old-fashioned, two-fisted swing to electronic experimentalism, ran through a large part of his gamut last night at the Donnell Library Center, 20 West 53d Street. The concert, in which Mr. Kellaway was assisted by Eddie Gomez, bass, and Mel Lewis, drums, was the first at which modern jazz has been played at the center.

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 18 (AP) Johnny Morris of Pittsburgh used a left jab to pile up points and gained an upset decision over Rubin (Hurricane) Carter tonight in a 10-round middleweight fight at Civic Arena.

An express bus rolled with case and speed on a test run down Fifth Avenue from 135th Street to Madison Square and back to its departure point by way of Madison Avenue in an hour and 19 minutes yesterday afternoon.

ALBERTO MORAVIA, who is generally acknowledged to be Italy's greatest living writer, is known in this coun try chiefly as the author of psychologically perceptive, anguished, broodingly erotic novels and short stories.
Professional ski racing, which has traveled an erratic road in recent years, is receiving another chance to make the grade.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 A majority of the Senate put its support today behind Administration efforts to achieve a treaty limiting the spread of atomic weapons.

LONDON, Jan. 18 (Reuters) World shipping losses in 1965 were the worst for many years, with the total tonnage lost possibly 50 per cent more than the average in the four previous years, the Institute of London Underwriters was told today.
Charles L. Gordon, a bandmaster and composer, died Monday at Parkway Hospital, Forest Hills, Queens. He was 96 years old and lived at 84-98 Homelawn Street, Jamaica, Queens.

Lionel I. Pincus, a 34-year-old investment banker who majored in creative writing in college, has been named president and chief executive officer of E.M. Warburg Co., Inc., a New York investment banking firm with European connections.
BIRMINGHAM, Jan. 18 (AP) Civil rights lawyers asked a Federal judge today to dismiss orders temporarily restraining demonstrations involving public schoolchildren.

Mrs. Carrie Rothschild Wakeham, an honorary chairman of the New York Federation of Women's Clubs, and long a civic leader, died Monday in her home. She was 96 years old and lived at 210 West 70th Street. She was the widow of Dr. Frederick L. Wakeham, a physician.
CHICAGO, Jan. 18 A Negro parents' group leading a boycott of Jenner Elementary School, the largest in Chicago, would end tomorrow but added that the effort had "showed them that we mean what we say."

WESTBURY, L.I., Jan. 18 Bob Farrington returned to action at Roosevelt Raceway tonight, after being absent five nights because of a suspension. The leading driver in the nation for four of the last five seasons, Farrington pleased his followers in the crowd of 16,108 by guiding two winners home in seven attempts.
THE new German look, fresh from the cabarets of Dusseldorf, was uncorked last night at the Barbizon-Plaza Theater, where the Kom(m)odchen Company opened its second visit here.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 The Weather Bureau hopes to begin cloud-seeding experiments in the drought-stricken Northeast next summer to determine how rainfall might be increased.
SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 18 (UPI) Kathleen Norris, author of more than 80 romantic novels and a militant feminist, died today at the San Francisco home of her son, Dr. Frank Norris. She was 85 years old.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 18 Warren Abner Seavey, Bussey Professor of Law Emeritus at Harvard University, died today of a heart attack in Weston, where he made his home. He wa 85 years old.
Last year for the first time in the short but spectacular life of the electronic data-processing industry all the major companies in the field approached their ultimate goal profit.
The Clarion Concerts program given under the direction of Newell Jenkins at Town Hall last night underwent considerable change between the time it was planned and the time it was given.
EMPORIUM, Pa., Jan. 18 Max F. Balcom, chairman of the board of Sylvania Electric Products, Inc., from 1950 to 1953, died last night in his home. He would have been 78 years old Thursday.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 18 Canada urged today that a proposed world conference on outer space be held in New York to attract top-level Government leaders as well as scientists.
The London Stock Exchange was mixed yesterday as dealers speculated on further economic measures by the British Government during the next few weeks.

The Phillips Petroleum Company has announced that its new subsidiary, the Phillips Petroleum International Investment Company, had released for sale abroad an issue of $25-million of guaranteed sinking fund debentures.
A.B. Hancock Jr., the owner of Moccasin, denied the undefeated filly had been injured.
THE American Ballet Theater sweetly, effortlessly and most splendidly made sweet, effortless and splendid history at the New York State Theater last night.

THE people who could have everything usually don't when it comes to the latest thing for their kitchens, a talk with kitchen planners and a check of dwellers in posh town houses and apartments discloses.
HOUSTON, Jan. 18 (AP) The American Football League announced plans today to add two teams for the 1967 season, making a total of 11.
Whether his directorship of the poverty program enhances or detracts from his reputation in the future, Sargent Shriver's service with the Peace Corps has marked him as an effective idealist.
ELGAR'S "Falstaff" isn't doing badly for a piece that is next to unknown in New York concert halls.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 A major effort to revive the Dirksen amendment on legislative apportionment by a massive grass-roots lobbying campaign will be started here tomorrow. A new group, calling itself the Committee for Government

CHICAGO, Jan. 18 (AP) George Halas, the owner-coach of the Chicago Bears, dropped his breach-of-contract suit today that sought to prevent his aide, George Allen, from becoming head coach of the Los Angeles Rams.
LONDON, Jan. 18 Britain's corporate and private investors must now pay a premium of 18 per cent on the dollars they need to make foreign investments outside the sterling area.
"Silence," by Yuri Bondaryev, will be published by Houghton Mifflin on Feb. 18. This is a novel by a new Soviet writer, translated from Russian by Elisaveta Fen.

The Columbia Broadcasting System will not televise "The Plainsman," a two-hour motion picture produced for the network by Universal Pictures. It was scheduled for Feb. 10 on the "C.B.S. Thursday Night Movies" series.

An undisclosed number of students at the Washington Square complex of New York University have been ordered out of a dormitory as a result of an inquiry by the university and the police into reported use of marijuana.
Mayor Lindsay has proposed Milton Mollen, his running mate for Controller last fall, for a Criminal Court judgeship.
UPTON, L.I., Jan. 18 A nuclear physicist went berserk at the Brookhaven National Laboratory here today and shot three co-workers before committing suicide.

Judge Henderson, a vice president of the International Longshoremen's Association, has been dismissed for "defiance" of the negotiating team that approved the union's four-year contract signed last year.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 The White House dropped today the requirement that telephone callers give their names and sometimes their numbers to the operators at the White House switchboard.

GENEVA, Jan. 18 The Swiss Government said today that the 5 per cent reduction it decreed last year in the number of foreign workers on the country's payrolls would be followed by a new cut of still undetermined size.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 A Defense Department spokesman said today that Soviet military attaches were recently called to the Pentagon and advised that hereafter they must obtain any Government military and military-related publications from the official liaison offices of the military services.

If Mayor Lindsay expected to get a big bundle of aid for New York City on his mission to Albany, he was disappointed, of course. The rejection seems to have been complete, except for the very substantial help committee by Governor Rockefeller prior to Mr. Lindsay's arrival at the Capitol.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 A Government official ruled out "normal evolutionary progress" today in obtaining an acceptable solution to highway transportation and safety problems.
LONDON, Jan. 18 (Reuters) Norman Hartnell, who designs many of Queen Elizabeth II's clothes, bared his models' knees for the first time today when his spring collection was presented.
TRENTON, Jan. 18 Gov. Richard J. Hughes called on the people of New Jersey today to escape the shadows of New York City and Philadelphia ...

MELBOURNE, Australia, Jan. 18 (Reuters) Ron Clarke, of Australia, the holder of six world records, bettered the Australian national records for 5,000 meters and three miles at Landy Field, Geelong, tonight.

The Transit Authority said yesterday that the transit strike and settlement would cost it about $15.5-million in the next six months. This, it said, will raise to $75.5-million its operating deficit for the fiscal year ending June 30.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 Postmaster General Lawrence F. O'Brien announced today an extensive mechanization and effidiency program that postal officials hope will bring about overnight delivery of first-class mail throughout the nation by 1967.
SETAUKET, L.I., Jan. 18 (UPI) A group of Long Island conservationists has a plan to reward the type of organizations they often consider enemies of conservation construction concerns.

MONTE CARLO, Monaco, Jan. 18 (UPI) A total of 85 cars completed the second section of the 35th Monte Carlo automobile rally today and qualified for the provisional classification, which will be announced tomorrow. They are the survivors of the 192 cars that started last Friday from nine cities.

PARIS, Jan. 18 President de Gaulle was faced today with a national scandal that many observers believe could undermine his regime and cloud the political future of some of his Cabinet ministers and closest advisers.

SAIGON, Jan. 18 American officials in Saigon believe that the United States should insist that there be no ceasefire during any peace negotiations with North Vietnam and that a time limit, probably not more than a month, be set on any talks. These suggestions have been passed on to Washington.

Representative Adam Clayton Powell lost a legal battle yesterday to overturn a $575,000 judgment that was imposed on him for the illegal transfer of his home in Puerto Rico to avoid paying a defamation judgment.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 President Johnson ordered today an increase in the 3 per cent interest rate on Government savings bonds, though he did not specify the new rate.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 (AP) A few months were added to the nation's life expectancy protection in 1964, the Public Health Service reported today.
Republicans in the State Legislature have devised a reapportionment plan that could offer the basis for an intelligent compromise by Feb. 15.
ALBANY, Jan. 18 (UPI) Governor Rockefeller plans to have the State Commerce Department open a Far East office.

An indictment charging Philip B. Kohut, former Commissioner of Public Safety of Long Beach, L.I., with having taken bribes to promote the sale of Duncan parking meters was reinstated yesterday by the Appellate Division.
LUXEMBOURG, Jan. 18?The extraordinary ministerial meeting to resolve the crisis of the Common Market ended in deadlock tonight but with an agreement to go on talking.

BRUSSELS, Jan. 18 Doctors in Liege, Antwerp and Flanders provinces began an "administrative strike" against the Government today after it announced last night that consultation fees would be frozen at present levels.

MIAMI, Jan. 18 (UPI) The defense told 12 prospective male jurors today that evidence of a love affair between Mrs. Candace Mossler and her nephew, Melvin Lane Powers, would not be enough to convict them of the murder of Mrs. Mossler's millionaire husband.

The Johnson Administration is making slow but steady progress toward its goal of eliminating the chronic payments deficit that is the difference between what the nation takes in from abroad and what goes out. But its efforts are also causing a retreat from the objective of a freer and healthier world economy.

CARACAS, Venezuela, Jan. 18 (AP) Two top Venezuelan officials are leaving for the United States today to try to counter mounting resentment over an estimated $100-million in back taxes levied against American oil companies.

John E. Duffy, a retired detective who served 28 years in the New York Police Department, 18 as a detective, died Monday in Mercy Hospital, Rockville Centre, L.I., of a stroke, after an illness of six months. Mr. Duffy, who lived with his daughter, Mrs. Claire McCann, at 1539 Peninsula Boulevard, L.I., was 65 years old.

City Hall is trying to get grants from large and small foundations, donations from private benefactors, advice from universities and such volunteer work from civic minded New Yorkers as painting a wall in a hospital.
Does a 16-foot outboard really need a depth sounder? Should a small family cruiser be equipped with a radio direction finder before it leaves the dock?

The Rev. Gommar A. De Pauw, controversial leader of the Catholic Traditionalist Movement, was directed yesterday by a Bishop to defy an order by Lawrence Cardinal Shehan to report to the Cardinal's Baltimore office "to discuss your future."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19, (UPI) The Civil Aeronautics Board refused today to let either Braniff Airways or American Airlines provide temporary nonstop service from San Antonio to New York and Washington.

ALBANY, Jan. 19 A key official of the Rockefeller administration winced the other day when asked why Mayor Lindsay had pressed his request for nearly $600-million more in state aid when there was no chance that he could get it.
Deputy Mayor Robert Price, Mayor Lindsay's chief political adviser, will speak before a Republican National Committee conference on big-city politics Monday night.

TELEVISION seeped into the 46th Street Theater last night. Harry Tugend's play "The Wayward Stork" is a "situation comedy" with a situation that the networks might consider controversial, but essentially it is material to be viewed through hassockborne toes on a 21-inch screen. It flounders around in a 30foot proscenium.
THE Presidency is always changing. Neither Washington nor Lincoln, for example, got full-page ads signed by distinguished citizens to guide them in domestic and foreign affairs.

NEW DELHI, Jan. 19 Mrs. Indira Gandhi became India's third Prime Minister today. Her father, Jawaharlal Nehru, was the country's first, and held the job for 17 years. In the first direct contest ever held for the post, Mrs. Gandhi was elected by legislators of the Congress party gathered in the great teak and green plush central hall of Parliament.

CLEARFIELD, Utah, Jan. 19 Employes of the General Services Administration, Job Corps members and a group of volunteers today slowly continued sorting and stacking such items as medicines, fooddonors had hoped would reach Vietnamese villagers by Christmas.

ROME, Jan. 19 Pope Paul VI said today that the Roman Catholic Church must guide the search for Christian unity avoiding both overenthusiastic blurring of doctrinal positions and an attitude of indifference or skepticism.

The appointment of Capt. Arthur H. Fertig as vice president and general manager for the shipping activities of the Dragor Shipping Corporation was announced yesterday by Ralph R. Weiser, president of the company.

The 40-story office tower that is to rise on the site of the New Weston Hotel at Madison Avenue and 49th Street will consist of a 14-story base and a 26-story tower and will contain 632,725 square feet of rentable office space, the builders said yesterday. Demolition of the 700-room hotel started this week.

THE Touchdown Club of New York has paid tribute to a number of notable football figures over the years at its annual dinner. A really handsome score will be made at the Hotel Astor tonight when the club presents its award to D. Ormond (Tuss) McLaughry, a coach for 35 years and now one of the elder statesmen of a game he has graced with such distinction.
Dick Sisler, who was dismissed as manager of the Cincinnati Reds after they finished fourth last season, was named yesterday as the winner of the Good Guy Award of New York baseball writers.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Jan. 19 Gov. J. Millard Tawes presented a balanced record-breaking budget of $883-million at the opening session of the Maryland Legislature today without calling for a tax increase.
