TORONTO, Jan. 19 The United States Steel and Carnegie Pension Fund, the Connecticut General Life Insurance Company and the Ford Foundation face a combined loss of about $9.5-million from debt and equity investments in the now-insolvent Atlantic Acceptance Corporation.
SINGAPORE, Jan. 19 (AP) The Indonesian Journalists Union demanded today that Chinese Communist correspondents be expelled from Indonesia.
THE producers of "The Roger Miller Show," which was presented last night over the National Broadcasting Company's television network, did not show a whole lot of faith in their star.

Travelers will be able to fly from New York to San Juan, P.R., in a four-engined jetliner for only $45, if a tariff proposal filed this morning by Trans Caribbean Airways is approved by the Civil Aeronautics Board.

Directors of the Douglas Aircraft Company increased the quarterly cash dividend to 25 cents a share from 15 cents and also voted a year-end stock dividend of 3 per cent at their meeting yesterday in Santa Monica, Calif.
Marianne Moore put a $17 burglarproof lock on her door. She had a peephole installed. She kept a bag of pepper on a table in the hall. And she had a tear-gas cylinder to repel attackers.

The United Gas Corporation and subsidiaries reported yesterday a gain of "about 1 per cent" in operating revenues for 1965. Ed Parkes, president, placed revenues at $445-million against $441-million in 1964. He added that increases came from condensate, gasoline, petroleum products, copper, potash, sulphur and instruments. These offset the decline in natural gas revenues.
The New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday that short interest fell to 10,106,791 shares as of Jan. 14, a drop of 1,616,818 shares from the total shown on Dec., 14.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 Four Nobel laureates urged today that government take an active role in curbing population expansion. One of them raised the possibility that uncontrolled population growth might force man to resort to cannibalism, and another feared that the world would be plunged into a new Dark Age.
CHICAGO, Jan. 19 The Krebiozen fraud trial was delayed today by the death of the father of a juror.
For soybeans, yesterday was a day of life-of-contract highs, followed by nervous reaction. The rises and falls followed a spectacular price rise on Tuesday.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala. Jan. 19 (UPI)-The Rev. Martin Luther King Jr. sent his top lieutenant to this city today and promised to come here himself next week to help organize demonstrations protesting alleged voter registration discrimination.
The Great Northern Paper Company, which first employed Robert A. Haak as a sales aide in 1933, announced yesterday his election as president.

PALOMARES, Spain, Jan. 19 United States Air Force men today were reported searching the Spanish countryside for an atomic device that was understood to be missing after the collision of a B-52 nuclear bomber and a jet tanker Monday during a refueling mission.

Francis X. Smith, 42-year-old chief of the rackets bureau of the Queens District Attorney's office, announced his resignation yesterday and declared his candidacy for the Democratic nomination for Queens District Attorney.
NEW CITY, N.Y., Jan. 19 Governor Rockefeller came to the rescue today of a picket line of downcast women as wreckers began to take apart the roof of the former Archer M. Huntington manor house here.
MOSCOW, Jan. 19 (UPI) Izvestia hinted tonight that the Soviet Union was preparing for a new space flight that would break United States endurance records.

The $15.3-billion Chase Manhattan Bank, largest in New York at the end of 1965, has had a field day in getting new branches approved since it converted from a state to a national charter last Sept. 24.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (AP) The Federal Narcotics Commissioner, Henry L. Giordano, said today that enforcement procedures in New York were nullifying a state law aimed at rehabilitating addicts. The law offers certain addicts a choice of having felony charges set aside if they commit themselves to a three-year course of treatment and rehabilitation.
WASHINGTON, Jan.19 The Selective Service System will probably reinstitute tests, class rank or both as factors in granting college student deferments, Lieut. Gen. Lewis B. Hershey indicated today.
WELLSVILLE, N.Y., Jan. 19 Senator Robert F. Kennedy brought his highly developed version of the off-season, offyear campaign to the snowswept Southern Tier of his home state today.
FRANCONIA, Va., Jan. 19 "I like the feeling of abundance," Mrs. Walter Husted said the other day over a rich and puffy chicken pudding made from a recipe that dates from 1824.
The American Telephone and Telegraph Company announced yesterday plans to sell $250million of debentures and the Southern Company disclosed plans to market $131.5-million of fired-income securities.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (AP) The two Democratic leaders of the Senate Mike Mansfield of Montana and Russell B. Long of Louisiana took the Senate floor today to deny that they were engaged in a behind-the-scenes power struggle.

ATLANTA, Jan. 19 (AP) A group of public health officials plans such mass testing for tuberculosis in public schools next year that it hopes a whole generation of school children will grow up without the disease.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 Italy has asked the United States to supply enriched uranium to fuel a nuclear-powered vessel she wants to build for the Italian Navy.

The election of Curtiss E. Frank as president of Dun Bradstreet, Inc., credit-reporting organization, and as chief operating officer for the Dun Bradstreet Group was announced yesterday by J. Wilson Newman, chairman and chief executive officer.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 The president of the United States Chamber of Commerce met with President Johnson today and afterward called for voluntary price and wage restraint by business and labor.
The nation electric power production rose 7.0 per cent in the week ended Jan. 15 from the level in the 1965 week, it was reported yesterday by the Edison Electric Institute.

Cliff Richey of Dallas, the nation's third-ranking tennis player and a member of the United States team touring Australia, has been instructed to withdraw from the Australian championships and return home in time to enroll in high school Monday.

The British pound was steady in moderately active trading on foreign exchange markets here yesterday. Traders reported substantial commercial business. The final level was $2.8045, up a point from Tuesday's close.

BANBURY, England, Jan. 19 (Reuters) An attempt by Fairleigh Dickinson University of Rutherford, N.J., to acquire the Banbury Cross, celebrated in the nursery rhyme beginning "Ride a cockhorse to Banbury Cross," was turned down today by Banbury's Mayor, Mrs. G.M. Wilson.
The New York Yankees signed their third straight convalescent ballplayer yesterday, bringing Elston Howard to terms for a salary of about $60,000.
TRENTON Jan. 19 (AP) A freshman State Assemblyman has begun a tongue-in-cheek drive to make the catfish New Jersey's state fish.
Visions of bellywhopping and snowball fights flickered briefly for children here yesterday, but it was just another tantalizing moment in a so far all-butsnowless winter.
The Department of Defense is reappraising the role of the merchant marine as a fourth arm of defense.

SAIGON, Thursday, Jan. 20 United States officials in Saigon, both military and civilian, are opposed to a unilateral extension of the cease-fire scheduled for the Lunar New Year holiday, which began at midnight.

The selection of a jury for the trial of the three men accused of having killed Malcolm X, the Negro leader, was completed yesterday. The panel comprises nine men and three women. Three of the men, including the foreman, George Carter, a chemist, are Negroes.
HARIPIECES for women in New York have become so popular that even the hairdressers are astonished.
CHICAGO, Jan. 19 An open letter to President Johnson, signed by 900 faculty members in Illinois universities and colleges, today asked him to negotiate with the Vietcong in Vietnam.

MILLBURN, N.J., Jan. 19 The New Jersey Symphony, led by Kenneth Schermerhorn, undertook an ambitious and altogether praiseworthy task at the Millburn High School auditorium tonight when it played the first performance of Roger Sessions's Symphony No. 6. Or at least played as much of it as is completed.

ANDY SACKS of Los An geles captured first prize in the recent First Annual Championship Tournament of the Student Chess Club of Los Angeles. In this six-round Swiss system, sponsored by the Piatigorsky Foundation, there were 18 participants, all under 18 years of age.

To dramatize his stand against adjournments in court actions involving housing violations, the city's Buildings Commissioner, Charles G. Moerdler, sat in on a case in Housing Court yesterday that had been adjourned seven times. And while he was waiting for that case to be called, he got involved in another because of a request for an adjournment.
James MacGregor Burns, the historian and occasional Presidential adviser, warned yesterday that Presidents might someday be captives of consensus politics.

DETROIT, Jan. 19 (UPI) A mild-mannered police clerk told the police today he had killed his wife, had hidden her body behind a bush and then had married a Polish divorcee "to provide a mother for my child."
ALBANY, Jan. 19 Defense lawyer Louis Nizer accused the Manhattan District Attorney's office today of an "artful design" to suppress evidence that could have saved Mark Fein from a murder conviction.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan 19 Lebanon expelled Ambassador All Fitouhi of Iran today as the diplomatic crisis between the two countries deepened.
The familiar pilot light on the gas stove may soon become a thing of the past.

PEAKING, Jan. 19 The general political department of China's People's Liberation Army wound up a 20-day conference with a call for greater Communist party control of the armed forces at a time when they are being put on war footing.

I saw we were licked, so I gave in." That's the way Robert Page, president of the Phelps Dodge Corporation, explained his decision to comply with President Johnson's action in rolling back the price of copper. He was asked yesterday during a luncheon in his honor at Tucson, Ariz., why domestic copper was selling for 36 cents a pound and foreign copper as high as 70 cents.
The president of the United Federation of Teachers warned yesterday that the city's teachers would not show up if the Board of Education started the school year two days earlier than usual next fall.
WILLISTON PARK, L.I., Jan. 19 Dr. Wilfred M. Post, a surgeon, died today at Nassau Hospital. His age was 89.
NEWARK, Jan. 19 (AP) A new, three-year constructionunion contract, described as the highest-paying in the industry, was announced today.
The stock market succumbed to profit taking yesterday and declined after reaching new highs in the three preceding sessions.

ALGIERS, Jan. 19 A spokesman for the National Liberation Front of Vietnam said yesterday that it was studying a "suggestion" by Sanford Gottlieb, an American pacifist leader, to use Algiers as relay point for mail addressed to United States soldiers who are prisoners in Vietnam.

WHITE PLAINS, Jan. 19 Mrs. Louis Francis McIntyre has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Nancy Marie McIntyre, to Jay James Ryan of New Rochelle, son of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond Thomas Ryan of Westfield.
Everybody talks about the importance of protecting the wife against the hazards of an untutored widowhood of poverty and economic naivete.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 Dr. John Randolph Graham, a general medical practitioner in New York from 1900 to 1954, died today in the Mar-Salle Convalescent Home here after a long illness. He was 91 years old, and had lived in the house for two years.
The affiliated Chesapeake Ohio and Baltimore Ohio railroads announced the elections yesterday of three vice presidents and a general counsel to serve the companies jointly.
Two men who admitted that they had attempted to bribe a housing authority policeman were sentenced to three years in prison yesterday.
Greater voluntary compliance to the nation's laws governing unfair competition is the primary objective of the Federal Trade Commission, Paul Rand Dixon, chairman, asserted yesterday.
In the tradition of Abraham Lincoln, who wrote speeches on the backs of envelopes, an art director doodled his way to a new corporate symbol on an agency envelope but on the front of it.

LONDON, Jan. 19 Michael Tippett is one of the originals of 20th-century music. Like Janacek and Var se he pursues a path as far removed from the orthodoxies of the avant-garde as of the academies. But he has never produced anything more extraordinary or individual than his latest work, "The Vision of St. Augustine." It was given its first performance tonight at the Royal Festival Hall with the composer himself conducting.

PARIS, Jan. 19 President de Gaulle dismissed an air force general, Paul Jacquier, today as head of the secret service organization that has been involved in the kidnapping and probable murder of the Moroccan opposition leader Mehdi Ben Barka.
An increase of 3,821,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks in the week ended last Friday was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute.
Mayor Lindsay said yesterday that he would support any effort to abolish the city's generation-old requirements that cabaret entertainers and employes be fingerprinted and licensed.

BOSTON, Jan. 19 (AP) Richard Cardinal Cushing, Roman Catholic Archbishop of Boston, issued a statement today to clarify his role with an interfaith group called the National Emergency Committee of Clergy Concerned About Viet Nam.
LONDON, Jan. 19 (Reuters) London's top couturiers emerged with orange and lemon color schemes today, the second day of the spring fashion showings.

The Transit Authority has been experiencing its own version of a run on the bank. Passengers have been hoarding the 15-cent subway tokens in the mistaken belief that they will get cut-rate rides if the fare is increased.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 "In the middle of the 11 P.M. television news a few days ago," writes a gentleman in Pennsylvania, "it suddenly occurred to me that I must be an extremely, perhaps a dangerously, unorthodox American.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (AP) Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara, who sidetracked $620-million worth of new defense housing construction last month, proposed today to expand the leasing of privately owned housing by the military.
Mrs. John L. Loeb, niece of the late Gov. Herbert H. Lehman, was sworn in as unsalaried Commissioner to the United Nations in a ceremony at City Hall yesterday.
The pros and cons of community antenna television (CATV), whose operators pipe programs by wire directly to homes of subscribers, were debated here yesterday at a luncheon meeting of broadcasters.
Mayor Lindsay announced last night that as a result of the city's financial crisis he had issued an executive order forbidding the hiring of new city employes.
Senator Jacob K. Javits recommended yesterday that the voting age in the state be lowered to 18. He also called for statewide primary elections to choose candidates for state offices.

SANTA MONICA, Calif., Jan. 19 (AP) Charles W. Hinman, a lawyer, pleaded not guilty today to charges that he tried to hire two men to kill his divorced wife and Murray M. Chotiner, a prominent political figure who was her divorce counsel.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 19 (AP) The first shipload of $70-million worth of food, medicine, clothing and tools collected in the United States as gifts in a people-to-people program arrived today at Danang in South Vietnam.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., Jan. 19 Leslie Floyd Egbert, executive vice president of the Columbia-Minerva Corporation, manufacturers of hand-knitting yarns, died yesterday in Mountainside Hospital here after a brief illness. He was 64 years old.

Wendy Brennan, a slip of a girl who looks much younger than her 25 years, gave a cello recital in Carnegie Recital Hall last night, making her local debut. A pupil of Kurt Reher in her native Los Angeles and of Paul Tortelier in Paris, she has given concerts in Europe and on the West Coast.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 A special commission of the National Science Foundation said today that man's tampering with his environment was one of the three main problems threatening the future of mankind.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 The head of a leading public employes union warned today that there was no handy panacea that would prevent strikes by such workers.

TRIPOLI, Libya, Jan. 19 Britain has nearly completed an ostentatious withdrawal of her 1,200-man infantry garrison in western Libya but is discreetly holding on to more strategic installations in eastern Libya.
The holograph manuscript of the book "In His Steps," which helped revolutionize America's attitudes toward its social problems, was sold yesterday at a Parke-Bernet auction for $4,500.
A division of the Metropolitan St. Louis Sewer District in Missouri sold yesterday $20-million of bonds to an underwriting syndicate headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc.
ALBANY, Jan. 19 A legislative committee studying liquor prices will investigate reports that criminal elements are gaining influence in the industry, its chairman said today.

The American Civil Liberties Union attacked yesterday the granting of punitive damages in libel suits where the libel dealt with public issues. It called such damages "inconsistent with First Amendment principles."

The marriage of Miss Emily Elizabeth Vail, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert G. Vail of East Marion, L.I., to Dr. Philip H. Henneman took place yesterday afternoon. The bridegroom is the son of Mrs. Harry E. Henneman of New Rochelle, N.Y., and the late Mr. Henneman.
Three-year old Julie Ann McEvoy, a baptized Roman Catholic, attended one of her first church services yesterday in a Presbyterian church.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 Sargent Shriver conceded today that there was very little his poverty agency could do to help the elderly poor.
TRENTON, Jan. 19 The Essex County delegation, the biggest Democratic bloc of votes in the Legislature, came out firmly today against the state income tax proposed by Gov. Richard J. Hughes.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 20 Robert L. Johnson, former president of Temple University and one-time director of the State Department's International Information Agency, died yesterday at his home in Wynnewood. He was 71 years old.
The homes of six representatives to the United Nations will be open on the afternoon of Feb. 2 for a tour arranged by the New York women's division of the Salvation Army.

Otto Preminger, the director and producer, lost his case yesterday to prevent any cutting or what he considered excessive commercial interruptions during the televised showing of his film "Anatomy of a Murder."
Eastern Airlines became the Metropolitan Opera's 55th corporate patron yesterday by giving the company $25,000.

ATLANTA, Jan. 19 (AP) An Atlanta Negro businessman lost a legislative election for a place on the State Highway Board today and his backers charged that Gov. Carl E. Sanders had used pressure tactics to defeat him.
Good evening, fellow New Yorkers. My purpose tonight is to report to the taxpayers of our city on the problem underlying almost every one of this city's troubles.
SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, Jan. 19 Wild shootings late last night and early today underscored the savagery of the hatred here and cast new shadows over efforts to obtain a workable peace.

A ROSE is a rose is a rose, and what's in a name? However, the self-styled Hungarian National Ballet (big lettering) and Folk Ensemble (little lettering), which opened a two-week season at the New York City Center last night, is confusingly titled. This is not a classic ballet company, as the name would seem to imply, but a folk-dance ensemble. The major ballet company of Hungary is the Budapest Opera Ballet.
Theodore C. Sorensen, former special counsel to President Kennedy, is moving here to join the law firm of Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton Garrison.
The auxiliary of University Hospital will benefit from a luncheon and fashion show to be held on Tuesday in the Colonnade and Grand Ballroom of Delmonico's.

Greek gold and the diamonds and platinum of the age of Alexander may prove to be as much a revelation to scholars as to the public, which will see it in an exhibition opening today at the Brooklyn Museum.

LONDON, Jan. 19 Britain's railway workers decided today to go on strike next month over a pay dispute with the Government. The decision to strike at midnight Feb. 14 was announced by the executive of the National Union of Railwaymen.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 The Supreme Court took the following actions today:

The Metropolitan Opera has set $200 as the top ticket price for its gala benefit performance on April 16, the final appearance of the company at Broadway and 39th Street. The Met moves to new quarters at Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts next fall.

BIRMINGHAM, England, Jan. 19 (UPI) Jack Bodell, Britain's busiest heavyweight last year, made his 1966 debut a successful one tonight by Scoring a unanimous decision over Jose Juvillier of France in a 10round bout at the Midland Sporting Club.

The United States has done virtually everything with its rivers from damming and deepening them to rerouting them, controlling their floods, and harnessing them for hydroelectricity not to mention polluting them.

OTTAWA, Jan. 19 Increasing hazards and hardships encountered by the Vietcong in South Vietnam could lead to peace in 1966, in the opinion of experts on Vietnam in the Canadian Department of External Affairs.
A tax representative of internationally known opera stars, two prominent fight promoters and three Internal Revenue Service employes were among nine men arrested yesterday on bribery charges.
A California drug concern has developed a new birth control pill that may be cheaper and easier to take and may have fewer side effects than oral contraceptives now in use.

SAIGON, Jan. 19 South Vietnam's Government has arrested a number of junior military officers and a former general in a move to avert a plot against it, informed sources said today. The number of arrests was put at 10 to 50.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 The Republican leaders of Congress labored under heavy handicaps in giving their response to the President's speech on the State of the Union. Senator Dirksen noted one in particular that burdens the political opposition when he observed: "The President has a mandate under the Constitution to give to the Congress information ... together with his recommendations. We have no such mandate."

J. Lewis Fox, a 56-year-old Democratic State Assemblyman from Far Rockaway, Queens, was indicted here yesterday on charges of perjury as an outgrowth of the investigation into the sale of beef mixed with horsemeat.
BUCK HILL FALLS, Pa., Jan. 19 More than 500 Methodist leaders began today the delicate task of redefining the church's mission in theological teams that would be applicable to the modern world.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), Jan. 19 Hebrew University plans to build a Harry S. Truman Center for the Advancement of Peace to honor the man whose decision to recognize Israel in 1948 was crucial to the existence of the young nation.

NEW DELHI, Jan. 19 When Indira Nehru was a little girl her grandfather's house in Allahabad could be a lonely place. Her father, Jawaharlal, and all her other adult relations were often hustled off to jail for their role in the Indian independence movement.

CHICAGO, Jan. 19 (UPI) George Halas, owner-coach of the Chicago Bears, charged today that the deal that sent George Allen to become head coach of the Los Angeles Rams "started with subterfuge and ended with chicanery.

ALL top-ranking experts are eager to earn the right to play in the International Team Trials and in the world championship. In the past, eligibility for the Trials has been based on performances in major events during the previous 12 months. The American Contract Bridge League has recently modified its regulations, permitting a pair with a particularly good record in one year to carry forward some credit toward Trials qualification in the following year.

ALBANY, Jan. 19 About 10,000 illiterate New Yorkers who have been promised free elementary education will be turned away at the classroom door or forced to drop out of their present classes because more than $1-million in Federal aid is not forthcoming.
DENVER, Jan. 19 Mr. and Mrs. Sam H. Uchill have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Deborah Diane Uchill, to Clifford Bruce Miller, son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Miller of Oak Park, Mich.
The Waterfront Commission of New York Harbor announced yesterday that it has opened an investigatian into charges of discrimination against Negro longshoremen in the port.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (UPI) Senator Everett McKinley Dirksen of Illinois said today that he would force a Senate fight this session in an effort to overturn the Supreme Court's latest school prayer decisions.
ALBANY, Jan. 19 The Chief Judge of New York State, Charles Desmond, said tonight that Governor Rockefeller's crime program was too meager and too slow.
Along with the usual assortment of docile craft, the fleet at this year's National Boat Show bristles with domesticated versions of some of the country's wildest racers.

HOUSTON, Jan. 19 (AP) Commissioner Joe Foss of the American Football League nullified a controversial five-player deal between the Houston Oilers and the San Diego Chargers today on the ground that K.S. (Bud) Adams, the Houston owner, had been guilty of tampering in seeking the services of Ernie Ladd and Earl Faison, San Diego's All-League defensive linemen.

WASHINGTON, Jan.19 (AP) Senator John J. Williams told the Senate today that a convicted labor leader whose sentence was commuted by President Johnson donated $2,000 to the Democratic National Committee last year.
UNITED, NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 19 The politicians and soldiers at home are giving black Africa's delegations here a hard time.
Congestive heart failure brought on the collapse of Michael J. Quill, president of the Transport Workers Union, while he was in Civil Jail on Jan. 4.

Mayor Lindsay intervened yesterday in a controversy between residents of Greenwich Village and Traffic Commissioner Henry A. Barnes over the conversion of Fifth and Madison Avenues to one-way streets.

CAROL JANEWAY is a nature-lover whose hobbies are tending the large garden behind her Milligan Place home and growing herbs and plants on her apartment's balcony. But Mrs. Janeway is also a designer and ceramist who uses her imaginative and whimsical perception of nature in decorating ceramic ware.
A young package handler at the United Parcel Service has been arrested on charges of taking nearly $17,000 in gold from shipments to jewelers here in the last 11 days.

BOGOTA, N.J., Jan. 19 Prof. Ernest Lyman Scott, a physiologist who after his retirement from Columbia University's College of Physicians and Surgeons started a second career and became a horticulturist died at his home here today at the age of 88.
Yesterday might well have been that mythical day that George C. Whipple Jr., vice president of Benton Bowles, Inc., humorously wrote about last year in "The Day the Press Releases Stopped."
The American Stock Exchange yesterday had its worst day in more than three weeks as the market made a broad retreat on heavy trading.

GERMAN shepherd breeders are placing too much emphasis on the flying trot and not enough on temperament, Laurance A. Horswell, a show judge and dachshund fancier, warned at the Dog Fanciers Luncheon Club meeting in Luchow's restaurant yesterday.
Men's sportswear took on a new look yesterday at a meeting of merchandising and operating executives of J.M. Fields discount stores.
NEWARK, Jan. 19 The crime rate for major offenses in Newark in 1965 dropped 8 per cent below the rate for the year before, it was announced today.
MIAMI, Jan. 19 (AP) Indian Sunlite and Native Street, the favorites with the crowd of 17,026, won divisions of the Jasmine Stakes for 3-year-old fillies at Hialeah Park today.

Group riding in taxicabs proved to be one of the few bright spots during the twelve dismal days of the transit strike. But the Police Department called a halt to the practice as soon as the strike ended, citing a "tremendous number" of complaints supporting its traditional view that the practice is "not in the public interest." No evidence was presented, however, that group riding proved dangerous either to passengers or to drivers.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 New orders received by producers of durable goods continued to advance somewhat in December and at year's end their backlong of unfilled orders was $8-billion higher than it was at the end of 1964.
STRASBOURG, France, Jan. 19 "Business as usual," joked a senior staff official of the Common Market commission today.

ATLANTA, Jan. 19 The Government is asking hundreds of retired military officers to serve as Federal voting examiners in the event that Federal registration of Southern Negroes is expanded this spring.

Ruth Yorck, a novelist and playwright, died yesterday at the Martin Beck Theater, 302 West 45th Street, just before the start of the matinee of "Marat/De Sade." She was 62 years old and lived at 21 Cornelia Street.

Del E. Webb, 65-year-old Phoenix, Ariz., real estate developer and promoter, who through the Del E. Webb Corporation also operates several Las Vegas, Nev., hotels and motels, has parted company with L. C. "Jake" Jacobson, one of his closest partners.
LAGOS, Nigeria, Jan. 19 Maj. Gen. Johnson T.U. AguiyiIronsi has emerged in control of Nigeria after a bitter power struggle in which at least 24 officers have been killed.
LONDON, Jan. 19 (AP) World shipping and the men who insure it suffered a disastrous year in 1965, a British authority reported today.
LONDON, Jan. 19 The United States Information Service announced today that the bulk of its collection of books, now housed in the United States Embassy, would be given to the University of London.
DOBBS FERRY, N.Y., Jan. 19 Dr. and Mrs. Osamu Mabuchi have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mimi Mabuchi, to Shigeyoshi Ikeda, son of Mr. and Mrs. Koshiro Ikeda of Miyazaki, Japan.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (AP) A top legal spokesman for the military services said today that members of the armed forces facing criminal charges often "are now accorded more legal safeguards than members of the civilian community in similar circumstances."

Dr. Harold King, chairman of the economics department at Seton Hall University in South Orange, N.J., and a writer, died of a heart ailment Monday in Lone Island College Hospital in Brooklyn. He was 52 years old.

The necessary first step toward coordinating mass transit within the five boroughs has now been taken by Mayor Lindsay. New York's ordeal in the recent strike has demonstrated with force how dependent the city is on the efficient functioning of its transportation system. It has made equally plain the interdependence of all the units in that system and the impossibility of continuing to treat them as self-contained entities without a common mission.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (UPI) Senator James O. Eastland, Democrat of Mississippi, said today that the Mississippi Freedom Democratic Party had extended a speaking invitation to Herbert Aptheker, who recently returned from an unauthorized visit to North Vietnam.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 The Supreme Court declined today to apply retroactively its 1965 ruling that state judges and prosecutors cannot comment on a defendant's failure to take the witness stand.
The American Stock Exchange reported yesterday the changes carried below in the share holdings of officers, directors and controlling stockholders of listed companies.

Mrs. Indira Gandhi is going to be a very interesting and unusual Prime Minister of India. This is not simply because she is a woman and the daughter of Jawaharlal Nehru. She is very much of a person in her own right, with positive ideas that will not necessarily coincide with those of her father or of her predecessor, Lal Bahadur Shastri, for whom she was Minister of Information.

WALLINGFORD, Conn., Jan. 19 The Rev. Dr. George Clair St. John, who in a 40-year regime as headmaster of the Choate School made it one of the country's most distinguished preparatory schools for bays, died today at his home in Hobe Sound, Fla. He was 88 years old.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 19 The governing council of the United Nations Development Program approved today 82 pre-investment development projects, at a cost of $254.5-million.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (UPI) Representative Frank T. Bow, Republican of Ohio, has criticized the Federal Job Corps program for investing in 30,000 brass-buttoned blazers for its enrollees while, he said, soldiers in Vietnam are going without soap and writing paper.
Members of the New York Times chapel of Local 6 of the International Typographical Union made their annual contribution yesterday to the newspaper's Neediest Cases Fund.
Trans World Airlines, Inc., broke all records last year in revenues and earnings.

A simultaneous starting date. Aug. 29, was approved for the Mallory, Adams and Sears Cup sailing events at the annual meeting of the North American Yacht Racing Union in the New York Yacht Club yesterday. The prizes represent the North American championships for men, women and juniors in that order.
A $5-a-ton price increase for sulphur spread yesterday.

Manhattan College, which did not enter the field events, came on strongly in the track competition last night to retain the team title in the Metropolitan Amateur Athletic Union Junior indoor championships at the 102nd Engineers Armory.
St. John's stopped the nation's third-ranking basketball team, St. Joseph's of Philadelphia, 82-72, at Alumni Hall in Queens last night.

EACH of the four prize winners of the Dimitri Mitro poulos International Music Competition was assured of a berth next season; but their appearance last night with the New York Philharmonic, in Philharmonic Hall, was to decide where the berth would be.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 President Johnson urged Congress today to pass the Administration's tax bill by March 15.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 The Administration is under considerable pressure from abroad to prolong the pause in the bombing of North Vietnam well beyond the holiday ceasefire now going into effect.

A deckhand on the tanker Morania Marlin said yesterday that it was a coal barge and not his ship that caused the sinking a week ago of the 108foot tug Patricia Moran. The tug sank in Kill Van Kull, between Staten Island and Bayonne, N.J., after a collision. Four of the tug's 10-man crew were lost.

ROME, Jan. 19 There is a double-faced navy and kelly green wool suit in the tiny couture house of Ognibene-Zendman that could be the most startling spring outfit in New York, if some woman will only get it there. An American named Peter Zendman and an Italian named Sergio Ognibene showed it in their spring-summer collection (all the couture houses here are showing new fashions this week).
PINE MOUNTAIN, Ga., Jan. 19 The northern bobwhite quail, which ranges from New York to Florida, isn't very big only a few ounces of flesh and brown mottled feathers.

Shirley Temple, the former child star, will make one of her infrequent public appearances here tomorrow night. As Mrs. Charles A. Black, a pretty, 37year-old San Francisco housewife, she will represent the San Francisco International Film Festival at the annual dinner dance of New York's film importers at the Americana Hotel.

Councilman Theodore R. Kupferman declared yesterday that he thought Orin Lehman, his Democratic opponent for Representative from Manhattan's 17th Congressional District, was "deliberately misconstruing" Mr. Kupferman's position on South Vietnam.
The Hanna Mining Company, an iron-ore producer, announced the election yesterday in Cleveland of Gilbert W. Humphrey as chairman.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 President Johnson asked Congress today for nearly $12.8billion in additional funds, primarily to pay for the war in Vietnam.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 Eight Democrats in the House of Representatives, anticipating that the Administration's efforts to obtain negotiations in Vietnam may succeed, have organized a conference to work out recommendations as to what form a peace settlement might take.

The Morgan Guaranty Trust Company, New York's largest purely "wholesale" bank, specializing in banking for corporations and wealthy individuals, announced an increase, effective next Monday in the rate it charges on loans to stock brokers.
LONDON, Jan. 19 An imminent food crisis has become the gravest problem facing the managers of Indonesia's badly eroded economy, according to reports reaching London.
KEY WEST, Fla., Jan. 19 (AP) Nine Tampa fishermen who spent two days in Cuba after one of their boats had struck a reef and sunk returned today to the United States.

PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 19 Prof. W. Frederick Stohlman, associate professor emeritus of art and archeology, who retired in 1954 after 34 years' service, died today in Princeton Hospital of complications following a stroke last July. He was 79 years old.
Two architectural historians were named yesterday as the first curators of Central and Prospect Parks.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., Jan. 19 E. Eldridge Thomas, retired personnel manager and assistant treasurer of J.P. Morgan Co., investment bankers, died last night at his home, 80 Miller Road. He was 87 years old.
A group of students from St. John's University sat attentively yesterday in the basement lounge of a private school in Jamaica, Queens, and heard a lecture on animistic psychology.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 The House Banking Committee, after six months of bitter wrangling, approved legislation today that will open the door wider to future bank mergers.
SCARSDALE, N.Y., Jan. 19 Miss Susan Elizabeth Kolker and Donald Finkel will be married here next month.
NEWARK, Jan. 19 (AP) After 63 years in this country, Ralph Barbarulo of Newark put aside his fears today and applied for citizenship.

MIAMI, Jan. 19 (AP) Mrs. Candace Mossler arranged today to transfer her four adopted children from Houston to Miami schools while the process of selecting a jury for her murder trial went on in Circuit Court.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Jan. 19 Mixing pain-killing drugs with pesticides offers a means of making these toxic chemicals harmless to man and beast, a panel of chemists said today at the winter meeting of the American Chemical Society.

DELRAY BEACH, Fla., Jan. 19 Mr. and Mrs. John Knight Whittemore of Gulfstream have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth Harwood Whittemore, to Stephen Cutter. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Cutter of Palm Beach.

DELRAY BEACH, Fla., Jan. 19 Mr. and Mrs. John Knight Whittemore of Gulfstream have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth Harwood Whittemore, to Stephen Cutter. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Cutter of Palm Beach.

David Blum last night introduced an unexpected novelty at his second concert of the season with the Esterhazy Orchestra at Town Hall. As usual there were unfamiliar music of the classic period, a fine soloist and a large turnout. But Mr. Blum appeared sprouting a Henry VIII beard, and it was a pleasant jolt.
Top people in the performing arts will soon be teaching courses now being formulated by three New York colleges.
Two women representing rival historical societies clashed yesterday over the fate of the Kingsland Mansion in Flushing, Queens, an 18th century Colonial farmhouse recently designated a city landmark.

SAN DIEGO, Calif., Jan. 19 A Government committee proposal to permit the construction of United States-flag merchant ships in foreign shipyards would cost the nation's shipyard and supply industry $5-billion in contracts over the next decade, a shipbuilding spokesman estimated last night.
TORONTO, Jan. 19 (AP) The Toronto Maple Leafs poured four third-period goals past a substitute netminder, Don Simmons, and whipped the New York Rangers, 6-2, in a National Hockey League game tonight.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 The United States apparently moved last year into first place among the leading industrial nations in its rate of economic growth after being near the bottom for years. Although final figures on the gross national product or the total output of goods and services are not yet in for most countries, it appears that the United States topped them all in its rate of increase.

CANBERRA, Australia, Jan. 20 (AP) Prime Minister Sir Robert Menzies resigned today. Federal Treasurer Harold E. Holt, a close associate, was elected to succeed him as Prime Minister and parliamentary leader of the Liberal party.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 20 --Dr. Nathan M. Pusey, president of Harvard University, told the Board of Overseers today that he could see no end to the effort of raising capital funds. Asserting in his annual report that Harvard had raised considerable sums in the last 10 years, Dr. Pusey commented:
LONDON, Jan. 20 (UPI)-- Vera Pearce, actress and aunt of Harold E. Holt, new Prime Minister of Australia, died on Tuesday at St. Thomas Hospital, it was learned today.

LONDON--British exporters now have fewer forms to fill out, a small tax rebate and improved insurance and financing facilities, but the outlook nevertheless is for some tapering off of export growth in the new year.

SAIGON, Friday, Jan. 21 (AP)--A wild burst of smallarms shooting broke out at a busy Saigon intersection shortly after noon today, apparently touched off when the explosion of firecrackers led some South Korean troops to believe they were under fire. No one was reported injured in the 15 minutes of gunfire.

A group of Reform Democratic legislators has declared itself in favor of holding fast for the party's proposal for reapportioning the state on nonpartisan lines. This is a laudable goal if the Reformers only remember that even the most scientifically constructed plan to reapportion so diverse a state as New York can never be perfect the first time around.

The American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals kicked off the celebration of its 100th anniversary year with a dinner dance and gaming party at the Sheraton-East last night in what was a decidedly Victorian setting.
LONDON, Jan. 20--Foreign Secretary Michael Stewart told British business leaders today they were not meeting the challenge of Latin-American markets.
LONDON--With the exception of a quaint pub or two and several Georgian, Edwardian or Victorian relics, High Street, Britain, is little different visibly today from Main Street, U.S.A.

A world bridge record is broken each January in Boston, in the process contradicating a popular assumption. The record is for the biggest individual championship ever played, and the assumption is that bridge players do not like individual events in which they switch partners throughout.
Banks here and across the nation continued yesterday to make changes among their operating and supervisory personnel.
A campaign to win the Democratic nomination for Governor for Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. is being quietly but actively organized throughout the state.

ROME--More than any other area in the south, the island of Sandinia illustrates some of the social and economic obstacles to Italy's long-range southern development program, and the measures being taken to overcome them.

Three arbitrators, in a unanimous decision, have ruled against Mrs. Nina Savo, widow of Jimmy Savo, comedian and writer, who contended that the $440,000 musical, "Little World, Hello!," was a distortion of her late husband's autobiography, which had that title. Consequently, rehearsals, which were postponed from Jan. 10, will begin next Monday for a Broadway opening on April 16.

LONDON--The new year started in Britain with a flood of price increases, disappointment with progress in righting the balance-of-payments deficit and indicationn that further recessionary measures may be produced this spring.

Copper futures followed the news yesterday and dropped sharply. The announcement that the Government had sharply restricted exports brought an immediate reaction with opening prices well below the previous day's close.
PARIS, Jan. 20--France plans to build rockets far bigger than the missiles now being developed for her fledgling nuclear strike force.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20-- John W. Gardner, Secretary of the Department of Health, Education and Welfare, disclosed for public inspection today an extensive reorganization of the Government's largest, and reputedly most unmanageable, civilian agency.
Senator Robert F. Kennedy called yesterday for "a full program of law reform and constitutional amendments to make it easier to vote in New York State."
ROYAL OAK, Mich., Jan. 20 (AP)--Two University of Michigan students were denied appeals to reinstate their college draft deferments today.
BRUSSELS--France's boycott of the European Economic Community has retarded one of the community's most ambitious and portentous undertakings, the drafting of a five-year economic "plan."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 20-- Following is the text of Presi dent Johnson's message to Congress today on four-year terms for Representatives and abolition of the Electoral College:

MADISON, N.J., Jan. 20-- Mr. and Mrs. John F. Leonard have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Catherine Grace Leonard, to Frank White Bennett 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Bennett Jr. of Durham, N.C. A March wedding is planned.
Uisge beatha. That's Gaelic, for "water of life," and is the expression for a popular old drink--whisky. In 15th century Scottish records, it is also referred to as "usquebaugh."
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Jan. 20 (AP)--Former Gov. Michael V. DiSalle said tonight that he would not seek the Democratic nomination for Governor this year, "nor will I be available for a draft."
ATHENS--Burdened by vast unsold stocks of tobacco, Greece has become the object of Communist efforts to arrange major barter deals.
A record total of 371,221 Volkswagen passenger cars, vans and station wagons were sold in the United States last year, according to Volkswagen of America.

THREE housewives sat in the second-floor library of a town house on East 79th Street yesterday morning, sipping coffee and talking about what it is like to be out of a job. Out of a paying job, that is.
Madison Fund, Inc., a closedend investment company, plans an offering of convertible preferred stock.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20-- The Securities and Exchange Commission asked 550 member firms of the New York Stock Exchange today to supply it with full information about the stock trading of their members --except for specialists, floor traders and odd-lot dealers--for two separate two-week periods.
BRUSSELS--The European Economic Community "celebrated" its eighth birthday this month, but as the quotation marks imply, it was not a very festive occasion.
Six persons who conspired to steal microorganisms and secret formulas used in the production of antibiotics were sentenced to prison yesterday. A seventh person received a suspended sentence.
PARIS--"For France, the new year can and ought to be the year of serenity, of confidence and of ardor."

ROME--During the boom years of the late fifties and early sixties, Italians were in a spending mood, and they were able to indulge their whims. But in doing so, as one economist pointed out, they helped to push imports up and upset the trade balance.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20-- Electronic eavesdropping by the Federal Bureau of Investigation at Las Vegas casinos has created serious problems for the Justice Department in its prosecution of Las Vegas gamblers.
Piedmont Airlines announced yesterday the purchase of six Boeing 737 short-to-mediumrange jetliners with an option for six more.

BOSTON, Jan. 20 (AP)-- Although Casey Stengel was ineligible, his name appeared on 11 of the 302 ballots cast by the baseball writers in the Hall of Fame vote that elected Ted Williams in a landslide today.

Mrs. Nina Girsdansky Seldin, a for lyric soprano specializing in folk songs under the professional name of Nina Gordani, died yesterday of cancer in her home at 333 Central Park West. She was 64 years old.
NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Jan. 20--Miss Roslyn Davidson and Michael Jay Nissman plan to marry May 28.

A Navy study group has recommended Department of Defense support for a program of nuclear-powered merchant vessels, but the recommendation has been quietly buried, according to reliable sources in Washington.

LONDON, Jan. 20--Queen Elizabeth tonight commuted the death sentence of a black African prisoner in Rhodesia, thus setting up a legal and moral test in the conflict between Britain and the Rhodesian rebel regime.
AN elegant antiques show had an elegant preview last night and, while footmen in medieval livery had a onenight stand, the opening to the public today should, on its merits, be a sell-out.
The money market, behaved in paradoxical fashion in the week ended Wednesday.

Anthony E. Tancreto, the man who tries to predict snow here, showed his weather instruments yesterday to the man who gets stuck with the snow when it comes, Sanitation Commissioner Joseph F. Periconi.

MOSCOW--On one of the closing days of l965 Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin and his closest associates in the Soviet Government met around a conference table in a Kremlin office to approve a list of plants that were to be converted to a new system of planning and operation early this year.
Eighteen children received minor injuries yesterday when a school bus and a taxi collided at 223d Street and Schieffelin Avenue in the Wakefield section of the Bronx.
A lawyer and a professional gambler received prison sentences yesterday in Federal Court for income tax evasion.
Harvey Rosenberg, a Washington lawyer, was indicted here yesterday by a Federal grand jury on a charge of perjury.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara told Congress today of plans for "massive application of firepower" in Vietnam to support American fighting men and reduce casualties.
Speculation over a nationwide rail strike next month depressed industrial shares on the London Stock Exchange yesterday. However, gold and copper issues showed some wide gains.
Vice President Humphrey is to campaign for Orin Lehman, Democratic candidate for the seat formerly held by Mayor Lindsay in Manhattan's 17th (Silk Stocking) District.
LONDON, Jan. 20--Lord Macdonald of Gwaenysgor, a pit-boy in coal mines who became Governor of Newfoundland, died in a hospital at St. Asaph, Scotland, today. He was 77 years old.
The academic and scholarly community has been put on notice that it need expect no support from the new National Foundation on the Humanities if the object is pedantry.

The Ivor B. Clark Company, Inc., mortgage specialists of 666 Fifth Avenue, have opened an office in Chicago at 7 South Dearborn Street, under the direction of Frank J. McCabe Jr. Mr. McCabe has been elected a vice president of the company.
BANGKOK, Thailand, Jan. 20 (UPI)--A crippled American F-105 jet fighter fell into a Village in northeastern Thailand today, killing 16 civilians. The pilot had parachuted to safety.

LAUSANNE, Switzerland, Jan. 20 (UPI)--Banff Canada, emerged as the most likely candidate to hold the winter Olympic Games of 1972, according to an International Olympic Committee source. An attempt by Banff to attain the 1968 games failed by only a few votes. The deadline for 1972 bids was today.
SAN SALVADOR, Jan. 20-- At night when the traffic clears away from downtown streets here, boys with buckets of paint and brushes take over.

BOSTON, Jan. 20 (UPI)-- The last-place Boston Bruins staged a third-period comeback tonight on goals by John McKenzie and Ron Stewart for a 4-3 victory over Chicago that kept the Black Hawks from taking the National Hockey League lead.

Dr. Bernard E. Donovan, the Superintendent of Schools, declared yesterday that the city should continue its specialized schools--the Bronx High School of Science, the High School of Music and Art, Stuyvesant High School and Brooklyn Technical High School.

GHOSTS, ghosts, ghosts flitted around the State Theater of Lincoln Center last night, the ghosts of all our dance yesterdays, as the American Ballet Theater swept us, with rewarding confidence, into its past and, excepting the brightest, youngest generation, our own.

The Pennsylvania Railroad, the nation's largest surface carrier, reported yesterday a system consolidated net income of $70,113,000, equal to $5.06 a share. This compares with the 1964 net income of $60,097,000, or $4.37 a share, restated to reflect a change in the basis of consolidation.
The wholesale commodity price index fell to 111.9 on Wednesday from 112.0 on Tuesday in its fourth consecutive day of decline.
NEW DELHI, Jan. 20-- President Johnson has invited Mrs. Indira Gandhi, India's new Prime Minister, to visit Washington at "an early date" to discuss "the many momentous problems we both face."

The Transcontinental Gas Pipe Line Corporation has filed plans with the Federal Power Commission a $230-million, three-year construction program that would include a 33mile underwater crossing of the lower New York Bay from the Jersey shore to Long Island.

MOSCOW, Jan. 20--A leading Soviet physicist, Dr. Pyotr L. Kapitsa, urged today that the country periodically weed out unproductive research workers to help close the science gap with the United States.
COPENHAGEN, Denmark-- "The important thing to realize about Denmark," remarked Ivar Norgard, "is that we are no longer an agricultural country. We have become an industrial nation."
The Real Estate Board of New York named Leon Casper winner of its annual "most-ingenious-dear" contest last night at the board's anniversary dinner at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
Failure of the Johnson peace offensive thus far to bring about formal negotiations with Hanoi inescapably raises the question: What course should the United States now follow?
WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 (AP) --Norway paid tribute today to the United States Coast Guard, which rescued 24 crew members of a Norwegian tanker after a collision off the New Jersey coast in 1964.
LONDON, Jan. 20--Foreign Secretary Michael Stewart told British business leaders today they were not meeting the challenge of Latin-American markets.
ALBANY, Jan. 20--The state's top court ruled today that distillers may set the price consumers pay for liquor.

NO more intriguing possibility has been put to simmer on a back burner in the Hot Stove League than the one that suggests that Mickey Mantle might wind up as the Yankee first baseman next season. It makes for utterly fascinating conjecture and is not quite so wild an idea as it originally may have seemed when the news trickled over the wires from the Mayo Clinic, where Mantle has been undergoing inspection.
MADRID--Like a painting by El Greco, the Spanish economic scene last year was a study in lights and shadows.

NEW DELHI, Jan. 20--Mrs. Indira Gandhi, who was chosen yesterday as India's first woman Prime Minister, owes her election to three men. They are her late father, Jawaharlal Nehru; her chief rival, Morarji Desai, and her main backer, Kumaraswami Kamaraj.

BONN--For a decade and a half West Germans have been congratulating themselves on the "economic miracle" that enabled them to rise from the ashes of defeat and achieve a prosperity surpassing that of any other European country.

The steel industries of Europe face a difficult year. Last year, declining demand was offset to some degree by export demand, as the United States market--threatened by a possible strike--raced to build up extra inventories.
PARIS, Jan. 20--French officials accused West Germany today of obstructing a settlement of the European Common Market crisis. "The Germans are the problem," an official said.
Labor shortages, which have been chronic in Western Europe in the last five years, showed no signs of easing in 1965.

SYDNEY, Australia, Jan. 20 --Harold Edward Holt has served a long apprenticeship to the man he is succeeding as Prime Minister, but he is not cast in the mold of Sir Robert Menzies, who retired today.

The metropolitan area chairman of an engineers' group has accused Mayor Lindsay of choosing two lawyer-politicians instead of technically-qualified men to head two city departments concerned with technology.

INDEPENDENCE, Mo., Jan. 20--President Johnson, emphasizing that the United States was determined to block Communist aggression in South Vietnam, appealed anew to North Vietnam today to go to the negotiating table.

Guatemala is a beautiful and colorful country, cursed throughout its history by misrule or tyranny. The story since 1944 has been one of attempted democracy and reforms, a Communist upsurge, a C.I.A.-engineered revolt, military rule, graft, corruption and--since 1963--military rule again, but without the graft and corruption.

The hardships, humiliations and waste inherent in poverty in New York City were detailed yesterday for more than 12 hours as the city and Federal antipoverty programs were criticized by scores of men and women.
Shick Electric, Inc. has selected Dancer-FitzgeraldSample, Inc., as the new agency for its $5-million account.
PARIS, Jan. 20--Hilaire Hiler, painter, authority on color techniques, and a colorful figure of the nineteen-twenties in Paris, died yesterday at the American Hospital. He was 69 years old.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 20--The United Mine Workers of America is planning to begin labor negotiations soon with the nation's major soft coal producers.

The Kennecott Copper Corporation reported yesterday a sharp increase in its earnings for 1965, setting them at $9.22 a share, compared with $5.98 in 1964. Preliminary figures for the fourth quarter of last year showed net income of $2.22 a share, against $2.11 in the 1964 period.

ROME, Jan. 20 (Reuters)-- The Italian Center-Left coalition of Premier Aldo Moro was defeated in the Chamber of Deputies tonight when a Government bill to establish state kindergartens was rejected by 250 votes to 221.
CHICAGO, Jan. 20--The Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. said today that he had put a deposit on a West Side slum apartment and would move in soon.

Three floors in the American Management Association Building at 135 West 50th Street, between the Avenue of the Americas and Seventh Avenue, have been leased by the New York Telephone Company. The aggregate rental in the long-term lease is about $5-million.
The Marine Midland Corporation, a bank-holding company operating in New York State, announced in Buffalo yesterday the election of Seymour H. Knox 3d as a director.
STOCKHOLM--Sweden's high economic temperature has cooled off lately and shows signs of dropping further.
PARIS--President Johnson is placed in a particularly complex position as he seeks a way between escalation and retreat in Vietnam. Four essential problems, indeed, do not directly pertain to the war.
GENEVA--The Swiss housewife and the family breadwinner are becoming casualties in their Government's war against expansionist forces in the economy.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20(AP) --The Government established today a "virtual embargo" on the export of domestic copper ores and other unrefined copper, and set strict quotas for the shipment abroad of other categories of the metal.
BOSTON, Jan. 20--Richard Cardinal Cushing disavowed today any connection with the interfaith National Emergency Committee of Clergy Concerned About Vietnam.
DUSSELDORF, Germany --Every weekday at lunchtime the big black Mercedes limousines pull up in front of the discreetly sober facade of Dusseldorf's Industrial Club.

DALLAS, Jan. 20--Mr. and Mrs. Robert Enoch Illes have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Stephanie Illes, to David Edward Ladewig, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Garner Ladewig of Ridgefield, Conn. The wedding is planned for June 25.
PARIS, Jan. 20--France issued an international warrant tonight for the arrest of Morocco's Interior Minister, Gen. Mohammed Oufkir, in connection with the kidnapping of Mehdi Ben Barka.
A broken water main that knocked out the heating system in a Manhattan State Hospital building, on Wards Island has forced the evacuation of 950 mental patients.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 20--The United States came out today for the calling of a world conference in 1967 on the exploration and peaceful uses of space.

ISTANBUL--Turkey is entering the new year with greater hope for a substantial upsurge in economic expansion and gains than at any time since a military revolt in 1960 shook the country and undermined the confidence of the business community.

LONDON, Friday, Jan. 21 (Reuters)--An auto mechanic who accidentally swallowed gasoline while siphoning a tank became probably the world's first gasoline addict, the British Medical Journal said here today.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Jan. 20 (AP)--Nancy Johnson of Providence, R.I., upset Sandra Post, Canadian junior champion, in the first round of the Doherty golf tournament today, but all other favorites advanced at the Coral Ridge Country Club, a 6,250-yard, par-76 course.
KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, Jan. 20--President Sukarno admitted today that elements within Indonesia were trying to depose him.
TOKYO, Jan. 20 (Reuters)-- A Japanese-Soviet civil aviation pact to be signed in Moscow tomorrow will eventually bring European capitals within 12 hours of Tokyo.
LOS ANGELES, Jan. 20 (AP)--Martha Raye returned today from a three and a half month entertainment tour of South Vietnam with a message to antiwar demonstrators from American soldiers.

LISBON--After five years of fighting in Africa, Portugal began to feel the cost of war. Inflation set in slowly but firmly last year, and economists questioned whether Portugal could achieve adequate development aims and continue to pay for the defense of her African possessions.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 (AP)--Vice President Hum phrey said today that the Ad ministration has no plans to place restrictions on spending by Americans traveling abroad this year.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 20-- Senator Jacob K. Javits introduced today a bill to give the President power to deal with labor disputes such as the New York transit strike.
A proposed two-for-one stock split, an indicated increased dividend and record sales and earnings for 1965 were announced yesterday by the Carborundum Company.

BOSTON, Jan. 20 (UPI)-- American League teams will play fewer night games in 1966 than in 1965 and will experiment with a variety of afternoon and twilight games, Joe Cronin, the league president, said today.

HELSINKI, Finland--A visitor to Finland is aware of the forest as soon as he reaches Helsinki's airport. On the drive into the city, thick stands of pine and spruce stretch back from the road and crowd against the edge of the city itself.

Mayor Lindsay announced the appointment yesterday of Alfonso Narvaez, a 35-year-old Democrat and former newspaper reporter, as head of the new office of Inspector General in the Department of Buildings.
BELFAST, Northern Ireland --Long the most neglected part of the United Kingdom, Northern Island has become an outstanding example of regional development on a social basis as well as an economic one.
Arturo Benedetti Michelangeli will give a piano recital at Carnegie Hall tonight at 8:30.
THE White House announced last night the appointment of Henri Haller, a native of Altdorf, Switzerland, as chef of the executive kitchen.

LAKE FOREST, Ill., Jan. 20 --An April wedding is planned by Miss Janis Lee Wellin and John K. Notz Jr. of Chicago. Their engagement has been announced by Miss Wellin's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Elmez Wellin, Mr. Notz is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Notz of Winetka and Delray Beach, Fla.
D. Ormond (Tuss) Mc Laughry, one of America's best-known college football coaches, was the honored guest of the Touchdown Club of New York at its annual dinner last night at the Hotel Astor.

In remarks taped for broadcast later this month, Cassius Clay said that he carried Floyd Patterson through their heavyweight title fight last Nov. 22 because "every fighter should take it easy on a man if he is seriously hurt."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 (AP) --The domestic Peace Corps said today that two girl volunteers were being returned to the Red Cliffs, Wis., Indian reservation where opposition to their presence had developed.
BOSTON, Jan. 20 (AP)--Ted Williams, baseball's only .400 hitter in the last 25 years and one of the most feared sluggers ever, was elected today to the Hall of Fame.

Quotations, supplied by the National Association of Securities Dealers, are representative inter-dealer prices as of approximately noon. Inter-dealer markets change throughout the day. Prices do not include retail markup, markdown or commissions.

Ebenezer Hill, a retired engineer and real-estate operator and a member of a prominent Norwalk, Conn., family, died Wednesday at St. Barnabas Hospital at the age of 90. In recent years he had made his home at the Seville Hotel.

SYDNEY, Australis, Jan. 20 (UPI)--Cliff Richey, an American tennis star, departed for Texas today within hours of receiving an ultimatum from the United States Davis Cup Committee that he was likely to be drafted into the Armed Forces if he did not enroll at a Dallas high school by Jan. 24.
VIENNA--A slowdown in the growth rate spread through Austria's econmny last year. The rate of increase of the gross national product fell to 3.5 per cent, about half the 1964 increase.

The Sailboat Training Facility, a New York nonprofit organization devoted primarily to advanced instruction in yacht racing for the young since 1959, was reorganized yesterday with a different name and different objectives by the same officers and directors.
MOSCOW--Housetops here are still decorated with signs that exhort a passerby to "drink tomato Juice," "eat cornflakes" and "put your money in a sav ings bank."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 (AP) --Relatives of "big shots" in Government received emergency security clearances in at least two cases, according to testimony by Otto C. Otepka that was issued today by the Senate Internal Security Subcommittee.

LAS VEGAS, Nov., Jan. 20 (UPI)--Ralph Alsup Sr., a southern Nevada labor union official, was killed last night by an assassin who waited in ambush outside his home and fired a shotgun blast from close range.
PARIS--A meeting in Luxembourg. Murmurs in London. Reforms in Prague and Budapest and Warsaw. Reshuffling in Paris. From the Washington end, bridgebuilding.

ONE of "wonder boys" of West Germany's postwar economic revival, he has built nation's biggest radio company from scratch since war. . . . Now hopes to kill two birds with one stone by arranging for production of tape-recorder parts in Poland, relieving labor shortage at home and assuring foothold in untapped markets of Eastern Europe....Owned small radio shop near Nuremberg in 1945.

J.H. Tyler McConnell resigned yesterday as secretary director and member of the finance committee of the Hercules Powder Company to become president and chief executive officer of the Delaware Trust Company, Wilmington, effective Feb. 1.

HEROES' TWILIGHT: A Study of the Literature of the Great War. By Bernard Bergonzi, 235 pages. Coward-McCann, $5. IT IS always a pleasure to read intelligent English criticism, even when, as in the case of Bernard Bergonzi's "Heroes' Twilight," the pleasure consists of having the obvious well and soundly stated.
PARIS--On the streets of Sofia, gypsy women dressed in gypsy frocks peddle chewing gum and a thingamajig for threading needles.

Miss Paula Naprstek was married last evening to Dr. Frank White in a Methodist ceremony performed by the Rev. Burton Davison in the bride's apartment at 90 Morningside Drive. Miss. Naprstek is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Karel Naprstek of Rabat, Morocco.
PITTSBURGH, Jan. 20--Miss Mary Alexandra Lowenthal and L. John Felstiner Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Felstiner of Mount Vernon, N. Y., plan to marry here Feb. 19 and to live in Woodside, Calif.
BALTIMORE, Jan. 20 (AP) --Scoring, 6 points in the final 15 seconds, the Baltimore Bullets defeated the Los Angeles Lakers, 123-121, tonight in a National Basketball Association game.

SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, Jan. 20--Leon Bosh Garcia, 28-year-old son of former President Juan Bosch, was in somewhat better condition at the hospital today. He was shot during a barroom argument early today and sufferred intestinal, arm and leg wounds.
A tall, young Bryn Mawr graduate who has been designated by Mayor Lindsay to be the official photographer at City Hall, will draw her $9,100-a-year salary from antipoverty funds.

PARIS--At the end of this year the seven-nation European Free Trade Association will become in fact a free trade association. The tariffs that the seven countries charge on their trade with one another will all--with some special exceptions--be gone.
