JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector) --Banks like to advertise the security they provide, and Israeli banks are no different. One such institution, however, recently coupled this guarantee with a thought that was on many Israeli minds:

SYDNEY, Australia, Jan. 20 --The Governor General, Lord Casey, designated Federal Treasurer Harold E. Holt today to form a government as successor to Sir Robert Menzies, who is retiring as Prime Minister.
A decrease in worldwide exports of Bordeaux wines has prompted the French Government to draft a program aimed at improving the quality of Bordeaux wine sold outside France.
ROME, Jan. 20--There has never been so much catchup, marron glace, egg yolk, saffron or aubergine in Italy as at the haute couture collections for spring and summer now being shown here.
RABAT, Morocco, Jan. 20 The only reports that press censors in Morocco have allowed local newspapers to print about the Ben Barka case are those that implicate French officials.
NICOSIA, Cyprus--"Invest in Cyprus?" an economist declared: "I wouldn't hesitate. I think this country has a great future.
HELSINKI, Finland--Like some larger nations and a great many people, Finland found herself strapped for ready cash last year.

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., Jan. 20--Mr. and Mrs. Grant D. Whipple of Locust Valley and Cape Neddick, Me., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Joan Morgan Whipple, to Peter Peirce Rice. He as the son or Mrs. Stiles Morrow Decker Jr. of Ardsley, N.Y., and Kittery Point, Me., and of John Rice.

MIAMI, Jan. 20 (UPI)-- Alondra II, a recent arrival from South America, scored a clever victory at Hialeah Park today When the Uruguayan-bred mare won the $6,000 Seven Seas purse by a length and onequarter.
Sylvia Caduff, a 28-year-old brown-eyed slip of a girl from Switzerland, is going steady-- for the moment--with Brahms.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20-- President Johnson sent to Congress today his proposals for extending from two years to four the terms of members of the House of Representatives and for abolishing the Electoral College.

Gino Prato, the "little shoemaker" who was probably the most appealing of the big winners of the era of television quiz programs in the nineteenfifties, died Tuesday in Baptist Hospital in Miami. He was 64 years old and had been living in retirement in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., for the last nine months.

A number of European nations, as well as Japan, tested new approaches last year to enlarge their foothold in Communist markets. Their programs reflected the steady--but still slow--increase in the volume of East-West trade.

NEWPORT, R.I., Jan. 20-- The Town Council of nearby Middletown will decide within a week whether or not it will grant a zoning exemption to permit George T. Wein, jazz promoter, to build a permanent home for the Newport jazz and folk festivals on 104 acres of residential land in that town.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 20--The Committee for Economic Development recommended today major changes in the way Congress handles appropriations and the Federal budget.
A newspaper executive, a labor leader and an industry mediator agreed in a panel discussion last night that the future of the city's newspapers could and should be good.
RIGA, U.S.S.R., Jan. 20 (AP) --Valery Skvortsov of the Soviet Union won the high jump in an international track meet today with a leap of 7 feet 1 inch.

LONG BEACH, Calif., Jan. 20 --Mrs. Nell Mitchell Jordan, widow of William George Jordan, author and philosopher, and sister of the late Earle Mitchell, actor, died early today at Magnolia Hospital, Long Beach, where she had been ill for a year. She was 81 years old.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., Jan. 20 (UPI)--Contempt of court citations against Dr. King and four other civil rights leaders should stand, the Alabama Supreme Court ruled today.
The United States Pavilion at the World's Fair, often praised for its clean, simple lines, is not going to be demolished after all.

Robert Moses and the two vice chairmen of the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority issued a strongly worded memorandum yesterday opposing legislation to merge the authority with the city's subways, buses and other transportation facilities.
Senator Robert F. Kennedy warned here yesterday that disasters similar to the race riots in the Watts section of Los Angeles could explode in other cities.

Following is a sampling of international trade fairs for 1966. The list, based on a compilation by the United States Department of Commerce, does not cover all of the hundreds of exhibits scheduled. Most of the big general international trade fairs are included, but otherwise the purpose of the list is to show the variety of trade exhibits as well as the many countries in which they are held.

DETROIT, Jan. 20 (AP)-- The Detroit Red Wings moved into first place in the National Hockey League tonight by defeating the Montreal Canadiens, 5-2. The loss dropped the Canadiens into a tie for second with the Chicago Black Hawks, who lost to the Boston Bruins.

RIVERSIDE, Calif., Jan. 20 (UPI)--Dave Pearson of Spartanburg, S.C., won the pole position for the Riverside 500mile stock-car race today when he set a one-lap record for the raceway--107.078 miles an hour --in qualifying trials.
Former Mayor Robert F. Wagner will receive the annual award of Americans for Democratic Action at its 18th annual National Roosevelt Day Dinner next Thursday night at the Astor Hotel.
THE HAGUE, The Netherlands--The Dutch coalition Government is stepping up its efforts to smooth the nation's industrial transition.
Consumption of newsprint in the United States set a record of 8,459,948 tons in 1965, a rise of 5.2 per cent above the previous mark set in 1964.
The Housing Authority said yesterday that a manager of one of its low-income projects on the West Side had agreed to sell his interest in eight deteriorated buildings in the area.

The New York City Opera Guild will get on the telephone Monday morning to try to raise $65,000. It hopes to sell out the opening night performance of Ginastera's "Don Rodrigo" in the City Opera's new home, the New York State Theater in Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts.

LONDON, Jan. 20--The British Aircraft Corporation said today its hopes for selling seven VC 10's to Middle East Airlines had been dashed by the British Government's new policy on investment allowances.

Madison Avenue became more and more an international highway in 1965. Agency traffic, while not bumper to bumper, continued to flow abroad at an increasing rate, despite the caution light that President Johnson flashed over the balance of payments.
PHOENIX, Ariz., Jan. 20--A synthetic fiber said to have the highest resistance to heat and corrosion of any man-made fiber was announced today at the winter meeting of the American Chemical Society.
The Transit Authority has notified its subway change booth clerks that they need not accept $5 bills because a large number of counterfeit specimens are believed to be in circulation here.

MIAMI, Jan. 20 (AP)--Mrs. Candace Mossler said today that one man had threatened to doom her to the electric chair and another had promised to clear her if she was convicted of having murdered her wealthy husband.
Mayor Lindsay, who raced out to a fire Tuesday night, turned his attention yesterday to smoke.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 20-- Labor gave a cool reception today to a business leader's call for voluntary wage and price restraint.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20-- Rail freight ton-mileage and intercity truck tonnage for the week ended Jan. 15 showed substantial increases over the volume handled during the corresponding week of 1965, it was announced today.

Melvin Hall, a 29-year-old Negro of 107-25 171st Place, Jamaica, Queens, was in critical condition with gunshot wounds early this morning in Queens General Hospital. The police said he was shot by a patrolman whom he had assaulted with a knife.
PITTSBURGH, Jan. 20 (UPI) --Bill Austin was named head coach of the Pittsburgh Steelers of the National Football League today. He was given a threeyear contract.
Mayor Lindsay strengthened his "job freeze" order yesterday by declaring that it stood "supreme" over city contracts with organized employe groups and Civil Service regulations.
WATERFORD, Ireland, Jan. 20 (Reuters)--An Irish Government corvette fired a blank shot recently during a battle between rival fishermen off Ireland, a special court was told here today.

MADRID--In the past, tourism, coupled with remittances from the 600,000 Spanish emigrants in Western Europe and with foreign investments, plugged Spain's balance-of-payments gap. But last-year, despite the arrival of 14 million tourists, these pressures were no longer sufficient. Experts speak privately of a new 1966 balance-of-payments deficit of $300-million.
Chas. Pfizer Co., Inc., had a banner year in 1965, with records set in sales, earnings and dividend payments, John E. McKeen, chairman, reported yesterday.
INDEPENDENCE, Mo., Jan. 20--President Johnson proposed today a cooperative international attack on disease, hunger and illiteracy "to help improve the life of man."

Four large New York City banks announced yesterday that they were increasing to 5 per cent from 5 per cent the interest rate on loans to brokers, a move begun Wednesday by the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company of New York.

Stage presentations have been scheduled at various churches. "Three at the Triangle," which opened last night at the Church of the Holy Trinity, will be performed through Sunday night. The bill consists of "The Meek" and "The Artist," both by Jerome Kass, and "Big Man," by Lawrence Weinberg.
LUXEMBOURG--It's a good thing cab drivers and many other people here don't read economic statistics.

The bond market, for the most part, resisted any tendency to decline yesterday despite the announcement Tuesday of a $250-million American Telephone and Telegraph Company debenture offering in March and higher interest rates on broker loans.
The Federal Reserve Board moved decisively yesterday to choke off the sale of short-term unsecured promissory notes by commercial banks in order to get lendable funds.

Edward Cold was elected chairman of the Committee for Democratic Voters, the sevenyear-old parent organization of the Reform Democratic movement, in a hotly contested election at the Belmont Plaza Hotel last night.
The men's apparel industry is ready to meet the call for trousers, shirts, uniforms and other clothing items required by the armed forces in Vietnam, industry spokesmen declared yesterday.

Timothy J. Cooney, the man Mayor Lindsay appointed to "disassemble" the city Civil Defense office, was embarrassed to learn from the City Record yesterday that his salary as director of Civil Defense had been increased from $17,500 to $20,000 a year.

OSLO, Norway--If anything describes Norway's economy in 1965, it is "business as usual." And "as usual" means a new record in the national gross product, which increased by about 6 per cent. Expansion in nearly every field of production, and prospects for 1966 are generally optimistic. This growth is remarkable also because the law giving everybody a four-week vacation went into effect.
To the surprise of few observers in retailing, the nation's leading chain stores and mail-order houses set a sales record last year.

TRENTON, Jan. 20--Efforts to assure a bipartisan constitutional convention next March apparently broke down today as independent and insurgent candidates for convention delegate seats were filed in five of New Jersey's 21 counties.
ARCADIA, Calif. (UPI)-- Nashua Plume and Going Abroad--running as an entry-- finished one, two today in the $12,000 League of California Cities Purse at Santa Anita.
The New York Stock Exchange has reported the changes carried below in the share holdings of officers, directors and controlling stockholders of listed companies.
JERUSALEM, (Israeli Sector), Jan. 20--Israel's leaders gathered tonight to honor former President Harry Truman and the peace center that will be built in his name at Hebrew University.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20--The world's first operational weather satellite system, making weather pictures available to stations throughout the world on a regular basis, is expected to go into operation next month.
The Commonwealth Edison Company has decided to add a third nuclear generating unit to its Dresden station about 50 miles southwest of Chicago, near Morris, Ill.

The Lindsay administration, breaking a long-standing tradition that City Hall does not take a hand in the internal operations of the Police Department, has asked the department not to fill six first-grade detective vacancies.

An affluent American public, showing an interest in gracious wining and dining, bought more imported cordials and liqueurs last year.

Governor Rockefeller and Carl Spad, the Republican State Chairman, have rejected a proposal for "nonpartisan" designations for one-third of the delegates to the 1967 State Constitutional Convention. Litho City, a proposed gargantuan union project of housing and cultural facilities, is not going to be built on Manhattan's West Side near Lincoln Center. The sponsors hope for another site, but plans are indefinite.

Julian Bond, the Atlanta Negro whose views on the war in Vietnam led to his being barred from his seat in the Georgia House of Representatives, is applying for status as a conscientious objector under the Selective Service law.
The world's current fastest humans indoors are Darel Newman and Sam Perry. They have never run against each other. Next weekend, they will meet twice in three nights.

Music of high quality in a program of judicious brevity plus expert performances made Gerald Ranck's harpsichord recital in Carnegie Recital Hall last night a particular pleasure.

John Lewis, the jazz pianistcomposer-arranger, has been named a trustee of his alma mater, the Manhattan School of Music.

A selective list of restaurants in New York and vicinity is given every Friday on this page. The restaurants are rated on the basis of four stars to none. The criterion is the food and service in relation to the cost of dining in any particular establishment.

PINE MOUNTAIN, Ga., Jan. 20--There are a number of pleasures to be had from a day of quail shooting. There is the simple pleasure of just being out on a bright day in good company, of making good shots or missing them. But a large part of the reward is watching a good dog at work.
Changes in the Boeing 727 jetliner to improve the chances of passenger survival in accidents have been suggested by the Civil Aeronautics Board.

ALBANY, Jan. 20--The Lindsay Administration asked the Legislature today for authority to build "vest-pocket" parks in the city and to grant nearly half of the money from a proposed $200-million park bond issue for the purpose.
FRINTON-ON-SEA, England, Friday, Jan. 21 (Reuters)--An attempt to pull the pirate radio ship Caroline off a sandbank here failed early today after the tow rope snapped.

DUBLIN--After many months of hard bargaining, Prime Minister Sean F. Lemass achieved the biggest political and economic victory of his career last month in obtaining a free-trade agreement with Britain.

Roland Petit, French choreographer and dancer, and his wife, Zizi Jeanmaire, will head the cast of an hour-long ballet show to be televised in color by the National Broadcasting Company on Friday, March 11, at 7:30 P.M. ...

MONTE CARLO, Monaco, Jan. 20 (UPI)--Paul Toivonen and Erik Mikander of Finland, driving a French Citroen DS21, were declared official winners of the Monte Carlo auto rally tonight when the first five finishers were disqualified for violating rules.

TEHERAN, Iran, Jan. 20-- The Government announced today the arrest of 55 members of an underground group called the Islamic Nations party. The Government said it was plotting "armed uprising, psychological warfare, terror, bloodshed and chaos" across the country.

An average of more than 19,500 passengers were aboard Atlantic Passenger Steamship Conference liners every day during 1965, Dr. H.N. Dutilh, chairman of the conference and managing director of HollandAmerica Lines, reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 (AP) --The United States lost 351 warplanes and helicopters in the Vietnam war last year and "we anticipate that 1966 losses will be somewhat higher," Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara said today.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia-- Considering that they so regularly proclaim brotherhood, it may seem to be an anomaly that the Communist countries of Central and Southeastern Europe have traded so little among themselves in the last two decades.

PEBBLE BEACH, Calif., Jan. 20--Although he began with a 6 at what he declared was the "easiest hole on the course," Al Geiberger shot a 68 today to lead the $100,000 Bing Crosby pro-amateur golf tournament.

Edsel Ford, a 36-year-old Arkansas writer who believes he was named for the late automobile manufacturer but is not sure, last night won the $3,500 top prize of the Poetry Society of America. He received the award at the Society's annual dinner at the Hotel Astor.
PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 20-- Favorites won their matches as the annual New Jersey women's squash tournament got under way at the Pretty Brook Tennis Club today.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y.-- Imperceptibly since last summer--and with a headlong rush in recent months--needier nations have been flooding the offices of Paul G. Hoffman with appeals for pre-investment surveys of their natural resources.
About 1,000 newspaper executives were given a couple of rousing pep talks yesterday on the state of their industry.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 20--Attorney General Nicholas deB. Katzenbach ordered Federal voting examiners into Birmingham, Ala., and surrounding Jefferson County tonight.
BRUSSELS--Wear and tear had bent the rail on which the garage door slid open and shut, and the door was stuck shut. Fortunately for the suburban householder, his car was outside the garage.
New York University has acquired the 29-story apartment hotel at 1 Fifth Avenue, "to preserve the character of the neighborhood."
The British pound was firm in moderate trading on foreign exchange markets here yesterday, closing at $2.8061, up 6 points from Wednesday.
Production of private and commercial vehicles in France in 1965 was down to 1,375,000 units, compared with 1,390,000 in 1964, the French Motor Industry Federation estimates.

CHICAGO, Jan. 20 (AP)-- Directors of the International Harvester Company approved today a plan for reorganizing the big farm-implement and truck company's capital structure under a new Delaware charter.

The continued search for more crude oil when supplies are already excessive, and strong competition for marketing outlets highlighted activity last year in the petroleum industry in the non-Communist nations abroad.
PROVIDENCE, R.I., Jan. 20 --Gov. John H. Chafee has about made up his mind to seek a third term, rather than to campaign for the seat of Democratic Senator Claiborne Pell.
INDEPENDENCE, Mo., Jan. 20--President Johnson presented Medicare Card No. 1 today to "the real daddy of Medicare" --former President Harry S. Truman.
CANBERRA, Australia, Friday, Jan. 21 (UPI)--Sir Shane Paltrdige, the Senate leader, who resigned Wednesday as Defense Minister, died today of cancer in Perth Hospital.

GRAND JUNCTION, Colo., Jan. 20--The engagement of Miss Mary Katharine Harris, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. J. Morgan Harris, to William E. Kriegsman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edwin Kriegsman of New York and Scarsdale, N.Y., has been announced by the future bride's parents. A June wedding is planned.
BEIRUT--The Arab Common Market was born Jan. 1, 1965, and a year later the prognosis for its survival through another year is not hopeful.

BADGASTEIN, Austria, Jan. 20 (UPI)--Nancy Greene of Rossland, B.C., put an end today to French-Austrian womens' ski supremacy when she won the special slalom of the Silver Jug races with a two-run aggregate time of 87.88 seconds.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 (AP) --Senator Eugene J. McCarthy called today for an investigation of the activities of the Central Intelligence Agency.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20-- Lord Chalfont, Britain's chief disarmament negotiator, indicated cautious optimism today over the possibility of an international treaty with the Soviet Union to prevent the spread of nuclear weapons.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 (AP)--The Commerce Department estimated today that retail sales amounted to $5.10billion in the week ended Jan. 15, an increase of 8 per cent over the corresponding week of 1965.
MONTREAL, Jan.20 (Canadian Press)--Charles B. Neapole, a vice president of the Royal Bank of Canada, will be the new president of the Montreal and Canadian Stock Exchanges, it was announced today.

BEIRUT--For Lebanon, a country not larger than Connecticut and with a population of not more than two million, 1965 may be remembered as the year in which contradictions within the economy emerged to the surface to affect the dayto-day life of the Lebanese.

Donald Gramm sang his first Geronte in Puccini's "Manon Lescaut" with the Metropolitan Opera last night, and Mario Sereni his season's first Lescaut. Both did fine, outgoing jobs and sang powerfully, especially Mr. Gramm, every one of whose tones was easy to hear and rang richly.
BONN, Jan. 20--West Germany's Interior Ministry said today that it had caught five Soviet citizens spying on West German territory.
"I KNIT on the train to Stamford all the time and no one ever looks up at me," said Donald Blick, who is 6foot-3 and weighs 240 pounds.

Landes Lewitin, an American painter who combed brilliant colors onto his canvases and developed his own alphabet of symbols, died yesterday in the French Hospital at 324 West 30th Street. He was 73 years old and lived at 117 Waverly Place in Greenwich Village.
Despite a sharp price rise in Syntex, most issues on the American Stock Exchange yesterday weakened for the third consecutive day as the trading pace also slackened.

A recognition, somewhat belated, of Dick Thomas as horseman of the year was observed yesterday by officials of Roosevelt Raceway at a ceremony at the Hotel Lexington. The ceremony was conducted in connection with the Chinese New Year, which started at noon (New York time).

TO such worthies as "The Saint" and "Secret Agent" there is another name to be added, "The Baron." The latest in the British productions to reach the American screen carries forward the Londen tradition of turning out smooth sleuths who function with more style than the Hollywood-based bread.

"Society at large" well ultimately have to pay the costs of pollution controls just as it now pays for such other social goals as factory safety, abolition of child labor and minimum wages, according to the January issue of the Morgan Guaranty Survey.

CHICAGO, Jan. 20--Harry Moroni, a restaurateur whose Corona Cafe was a gathering place for several generations of Chicago newspapermen, theatrical figures and politicians, died today in Presbyterian-St. Luke's Hospital. He was 80 years old.
SAIGON, Jan. 20--Generals and statesmen agree that bombs and bullets may never win the war in South Vietnam, but they feel that perhaps an idea for taking a sort of census of grievances will.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20--The new chairman of the Interstate Commerce Commission, J.W. Bush, said today he expects the commission to make its final decisions in seven major railroad cases by the end of this year. The seven include the merger of the Pennsylvania Railroad and the New York Central and the application of the New Haven Railroad to discontinue all passenger service.

JERSEY CITY, Jan. 20--An indignant artist, whose painting of two frolicking nude women was banned from an exhibition scheduled to open here Saturday, took her other three paintings from the show today.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia--In other Communist countries they speak of "economic reform," but when President Tito talks about what is going on in Yugoslavia he calls it an "economic revolution," and rightly so.

BERLIN--East German workers received more takehome pay last year and could buy more and better goods for their money. Production, farm output and exports rose. Yet at the end of 1965 the Communist country found itself in a crisis as bad as any in its 20-year history.
Eventually the Treasury will run out of silver--but that day is several years off, according to the annual review of Handy Harman, fabricator of precious metals.
Russell V. Downing, president and managing director of Radio City Music Hall, is retiring effective Feb. 1 and will be succeeded by James F. Gould, executive vice president.
CIRENCESTER, England, Jan. 20 (AP)--Viola Lady Apsley, Conservative Member of Parliament for Bristol from 1943 to 1945, died last night at her Gloucestershire home. She was about 65 years old.
ATHENS--Yannis Hadjis, a farmer from Thessaly, in central Greece, is not happy with the way things are going in Greece these days.
LONDON, Jan. 2--George Devine, a leading figure in contemporary theater, died in London today. He was 55 years old.
"WE don't recommend generators for any cruiser under 33 feet," Lloyd Koppel of Owens Yachts was saying yesterday at the National Boat Show.
Ron Swoboda, home-run king of the New York Mets at the age of 21, signed his 1966 contract yesterday at a 60 per cent raise in pay.

In his first fireside TV talk to the people of New York, Mayor Lindsay at last began to come to grips with the bleak reality of this city's fiscal emergency. While during his election campaign he took the crisis too lightly, his tendency now seems to be to go to the opposite extreme and call for austerity measures so severe as to be self-defeating.
BAKERSFIELD, Calif., Jan. 20 (AP)--An excited motorist telephoned the Kern County sheriff's office that there was a mass rally of the Ku Klux Klan along the Kern River.
The International Business Machines Corporation announced yesterday the delivery schedule for its new super computers, the System-360 model 90 series.
SAIGON, Friday, Jan. 21, Vietcong guerrillas mounted a series of scattered and apparently minor attacks during the first 24 hours of their holiday cease-fire, allied military sources said today.

BEIRUT, Lebanon--The most significant change in the political economy of the Middle East last year was a swing toward conservatism. The "revolutionary Arabs" moved away from doctrinaire socialism and conceded that free enterprise could be useful.

RICHMOND, Va., Jan. 20 (AP)--A Federal court held today that activities of the North Carolina Dental Society "have the character of state action" and that the society's all-white membership policy was unconstitutional.

James P. McFarland, executive vice president of General Mills, Inc., has been elected a director of the Toro Manufacturing Corporation. Also announced was the resignation of Leslie N. Perrin as chairman.
BOSTON, Jan, 21 (AP) The Boston Red Sox, seeking steady customers for 1966, appealed today to a group of Boston business executives to purchase season tickets.
WARSAW, Jan. 21 The political leadership of Poland announced today an extensive program of large-scale public ceremonies to mark what it terms the 1,000th anniversary of the Polish state.

Ed Giacomin was recalled by the New York Rangers yesterday to replace their injured goalie, Cesare Maniago. Giacomin is scheduled to join the Blues in Boston this afternoon for the game with the Bruins.
MADRID, Jan. 21 (AP) Spain projected her dispute with Britain over possession of Gibraltar into the North Atlantic Treaty Organization today.
The Fifth Avenue Coach Lines tried to protect its corporate prestige yesterday with a legal suit aimed at keeping its name listed on the New York Stock Exchange.
MIAMI, Jan. 21 The Soviet Union will help Cuba to search for petroleum in keys that surround the island, the Havana radio said today.
The Astor Hotel, one of Times Square's last links with its elegant past, is going to be torn down to make room for a 40-story office building.

Copper and cocoa, two commodities now in the international spotlight took off in opposite directions yesterday. Copper rebounded after its recent price drop while cocoa futures moved down sharply in heavy profit taking.

LONG BEACH, L.I., Jan. 21 Mr. and Mrs. Joseph F. Carlino have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Donna M. Carlino, to Edward Alfred McCoyd, son of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred McCoyd of Glen Cove.
The appointments of Michael M. Devcich as president of the Pacific Mills Worsted stein as president of the Raeford Worsted Company were announced yesterday.
MIAMI, Jan. 21 (AP) Severe pains from an old back injury sidelined Percy Foreman, defense attorney, today after he completed an interrogation of 12 prospective jurors for the Mossler murder trial.
ALGIERS, Jan. 19 Ramadan, the month-long Moslem religious period of daytime fasting and nightly feasting, draws to a close this weekend with the climactic Night of Doubt.

TOKYO, Jan. 21 Premier Eisaku Sato has asked the United States to continue the pause in the bombing of North Vietnam while Japan pursues intensive diplomatic efforts in support of Washington's peace offensive.
State legislators from around the United States plan to establish a center to help them improve their methods of operation.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 Col. Emmett Gilliam Scott, of the Army's Supply and Maintenance Command, the unit that procures supplies for Vietnam, told a meeting of top steamship officials today that they had "gone far beyond that was expected of you" to meet the current demand for emergency shipments to Saigon.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 (UPI) Three Democratic Senators sought today to blunt the campaign by Everett McKinley Dirksen of Illinois, the Senate Republican leader, to nullify the Supreme Court's one-man, one-vote ruling on apportioning state legislatures.

The International Chamber Orchestra series at the Grace Rainey Rogers Auditorium of the Metropolitan Museum of Art is giving New Yorkers a chance to hear several new ensembles this year. The latest to appear is the Krakow Choir and Orchestra from Poland, which made its American debut in the hall last night. Consisting of about two dozen instrumentalists and 20 singers, the group was conducted by Andrzej Markowski.
TOKYO, Jan. 21 (AP) Leslie M. O'Connor of Phoenix, Ariz., one-time secretary of baseball and former president of the Pacific Coast League, died here yesterday at the age of 77.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 21 (AP) The Philadelphia 76ers dissipated a 16-point lead, but rallied behind the scoring of Chet Walker and Wilt Chamberlain to defeat the New York Knicks, 109-98, tonight in a National Basketball Association game.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 Secretary of State Dean Rusk said today that the Administration's peace probe had met an overwhelmingly favorable response abroad "except from those who could in fact sit down and make peace."

MONTE CARLO, Monaco, Jan. 21 (UPI) The organizing body of the Monte Carlo auto rally officially rejected today an appeal by British Mimi-Cooper and Ford drivers who were disqualified from the first four places in the rally.

Robert J. McGuire resigned yesterday as an assistant Uni ted States Attorney for the Southern District of New York to become legal adviser to Muhamed Abscir, commander of the national police force in Somalia, Africa.
COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Saturday,Jan. 22 (Reuters) A powerful explosion damaged the Yugoslav Embassy here early today, the police reported.

A BARE stage, a pink floorcloth, eight young dancers clad in bold primary colors, a jazzy score, a bouncing dance and Jerome Robbins's "Interplay" is back in town, revived last night for the first time in some years by the American Ballet Theater at the State Theater, Lincoln Center.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 (AP) Spread over 52 pages of fine print in today's Congressional Record are the names of 8,600 persons who held summer jobs last year with the Post Office Department.
CHICAGO, Jan. 21 (AP) Lahti, Finland, has been added to the list of cities bidding for the 1972 Winter Olympics, Avery Brundage, president of the International Olympic Committee, Said today.

THE TIN MEN. By Michael Frayn, 216 pages. Atlantic-Little, Brown. $4.95. ADILATORY dabbler in Michael Frayn's new satire, "The Tin Men," is trying to produce salacious novels for the printed-voyeurism trade by computerized automation.

PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 21 The 17th annual auction of the Smith College Club will be held here next Saturday under the chairmanship of Mrs. Raymond W. Mitchell. It will start at 10 A.M. in a new location, the Italian American Sportsmen's Club on Terhune Road.

LISBON, Jan. 21 The jazz combo of the United States Sixth Fleet was so well received this week at the University of Coimbra that student activists gave up plans to protest United States Vietnam policies.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 An assistant director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation was granted a patent this week for a "bug-proof" conference room.
The New York Jets basketball team will appear at the Hicksville High School tonight in a benefit game against the school's faculty.

The correspondence columns of the current issue of Harper's contain two letters that will be familiar to anyone who has ever looked through The Times Book Review or any other literary periodical. The writers are assailing a reviewer (in this case Roderick Cook), saying bluntly that he didn't know what he was talking about and probably hadn't even read the book (Peter Matthiessen's "At Play in the Fields of the Lord").
THE modern gallery that made a debut at Gimbels yesterday opens one more avenue to shoppers for good design in home furnishings.

BALBOA, Canal Zone, Jan. 21 With Mexico's Presidet Gustavo Diaz Ordaz looking on as guest of the Panama Canal, the heaviest single cargo ever lifted across the isthmus was put through the locks today. Also in the control house as the Norwegian oreship Essi Gina moved northbound with 52,843 tons of iron ore from Peru, bound for Rotterdam, was Panama's President Marco A. Robles.
City Council President Frank D. O'Connor swore in his personal staff yesterday in a simple informal ceremony in the Council Chamber.

PEBBLE BEACH, Calif., Jan. 21 Although he has yet to win a major tournament, Don Massengale, a 28-year-old Texan, assumed the 36-hole lead today in the $100,000 Bing Crosby pro-amateur golf tournament.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 21 (AP) Staughton Lynd, the Yale faculty member who made an unauthorized trip to North Vietnam, says much of the public reaction to what he did is favorable.
The United States challenged North Vietnam yesterday to match American sincerity in the quest for a negotiated peace.
A court battle over the purchase of 26 per cent of the stock in the Fibreboard Paper Products Corporation of San Francisco has been averted.
The concert to have been given tonight by the Henry Street Settlement Music School Orchestra has been postponed to Feb. 19.
MIAMI, Jan. 21 Jewels worth half a million dollars were stolen today from the ocean-front apartment of a wealthy New York woman while she was at the Hialeah Race Track.

WEST ORANGE, N.J., Jan. 21 John J. Clunan a former chief division auditor in charge of the field accounting divisions of the Western Union Telegraph Company, died yesterday in the Northfield Manor Nursing Home here at 777 Northfield Avenue. His age was 93.

THE textbooks often lay down standards for re biddable suits, and Q J x x x is usually the suggested minimum. This gives a misleading impression of expert practice. In standard methods a player who rebids his original suit at the first opportunity will have a six-card suit at least nine times out of ten.
The City Human Rights Commission, exercising a new power for the first time, has posted a warning notice on an apartment that allegedly had been refused to a would-be tenant for racial reasons.
William S. Connell was named yesterday as a vice president of C.V. Starr Co., a member of the American International group of insurance companies.

SINGAPORE, Jan. 21 (UPI) Indonesian students battled and threw rocks yesterday in a wild free-for-all at the presidential palace in Jakarta after an appel by President Sukarno for loyalty and unity, according to the official press agency Antara.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 The assumption spread in Congress today that the United States military manpower commitment to Vietnam would grow to 400,000 men this year. This compares with the peak 407,000 of the Korean War.
MADRID, Jan. 21 (Reuters) A funeral service was held today in Seville for Juan Francisco de Cardenas, former Ambassador to the United States, who died here on Wednesday night at the age of 84.

TRENTON, Jan, 21 The top Democratic and Republican state party leaders exchanged charges of bad faith today over alleged attempts to politically rig the upcoming Constitutional convention on legislative reapportionment.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 21 Don C. Silverthorne, on trial on charges of defrauding the defunct San Francisco National Bank, is building his defense on the theory that the Government is to blame for the bank's closing.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 21 The chief delegates to the United Nations of 15 African countries staged a civil rights demonstration here today. It took the form of a luncheon to honor Julian Bond, the young American Negro who has been barred from the Georgia State Legislature because of his stand against United States policy in Vietnam.
URBANA, Ill, (Science Service) Models of spacecraft are being used to study temperature problems of these craft at great savings over present
The British pound declined in moderate trading on foreign exchange markets here yesterday. The currency closed at $2.8043, down 7 points from Thursday's final level.

SLOATSBURG, N.Y., Jan. 21 Rockland County Judge Herbert E. Henion and Mrs. Henion have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Dawn Merle Henion, to Lieut. Woodruff Leeming Tuttle, U.S.A. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Franklin Benjamin Tuttle of Brooklyn and Kinderhook.
A dispute over using five British musicians has caused the cancellation of a recording session scheduled for tomorrow.
LAUNCESTON, Australia, Jan. 21 (Reuters) A century by Colin Cowdrey of the Marylebone Cricket Club marked the final day of the three-day match against Tasmania, which ended in a draw today.
PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 21 The two top-seeded players will meet tomorrow in the final round of the New Jersey women's squash racquets tournament at the Pretty Brook Country Club.
Jackie Gleason will not return to television next season. The announcement yesterday was made jointly by the comedian and the Columbia Broadcasting System.

MORE and more department stores have taken in recent years to photographing domestic fashions in foreign settings. The magic aura surrounding travel that has swelled American tourism of late has also rubbed off on the less-than-romantic fashion merchant.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 (AP) Maj. Gen. Clifford Lee Corbin, U.S.A., retired, died of pneumonia yesterday at Walter Reed General Hospital. He was 82 years old.

ARTURO BENEDETTI MICHALENGELI has the Manner, the authentic Manner. He makes concert going a real event. Everything about him seems surrounded by mystery his aloof manner, his unusual brand of piano playing, his look of sheer detachment while playing, as though he were outside of himself but observing himself very carefully. When...
ATHENS, Jan. 21 The Soviet Union charged today that United States agents kidnapped a Soviet tourist in Greece last month.
Following are excerpts from the transcript of Secretary of State Dean Rusk's news conference in Washington yesterday, as recorded by The New York Times:

Four professors at prominent universities have decided not to participate in a lecture series at St. John's University as a result of the university's dismissal of 31 teachers, according to Dr. Israel Kugler, president of the United Federation of College Teachers.
The Yorkville Dinner Dances are traditionally done up in white, pink and silver, and last night's annual event in the Grand Ballroom of the Plaza was no exception.
Peter Weiss's "The Investigation," one Of the major theatrical events in Europe last year, is headed for Broadway.

The stock market was pretty much of a scrambled affair yesterday and trading was heavy. At the close of activity on the New York Stock Exchange, more issues showed declines than gains and the leading market averages were slightly on the upside.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 Lizbeth B. Hughes, a teacher who spent most of her life in Burma for the American Baptist Foreign Mission Society, died yesterday in the Fairfax (Va.) Nursing Home. She was 97 years old.

BONN, Jan. 21 A Munich court sentenced two former SS officers today to terms of five years at hard labor and three years and eight months in prison respectively for their roles in the murder of more than 600 Jews in the Soviet Union in wartime.

SAIGON, Saturday, Jan. 22 An American officer was killed and two American servicemen were slightly wounded before dawn today when a Vietcong bomb exploded outside a United States armed forces billet here.
A former member of the Black Muslims said yesterday that he saw the three men accused of murdering Malcolm X standing over his body with guns in their hands.

Mayor Lindsay is treading dangerous ground with his statement that the city's fiscal policy must be "supreme" over the requirements of its contracts with civil service unions. While governmental legal tradition unquestionably provides strong support for the Mayor's position, it must be weighed against the potential impact on his efforts to bring some stability into municipal labor relations in the wake of the transit strike.

Chinatown opened a threeday celebration yesterday of the lunar year 4664, the Year of the Morse, with centuries-old rituals of parading dragons and lions and the din of thousands of firecrackers to frighten away any evil spirits lurking in the vicinity.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 21, The Soviet Union has again charged that too many top-level jobs in the international organization are held by Americans and Britons.
LONDON, Jan. 21 Issues central to Britain's export drive have been raised here by the withdrawal of the British Aircraft Corporation from competition to sell long-range

Joseph Cohn, secretary-treasurer of the Tubular Textile Machinery Corporation, textile processing, and the Compax Corporation, a subsidiary, died on Wednesday in his home at 101 Central Park West. He was 67 years old.

The Cunard Line fleet broke all passenger-carrying records of the Atlantic Passenger Steamship Conference last year by transporting 163,761 travelers, or 25 per cent of all tourists carried by the 22 member lines of the association, the British carrier reported yesterday.
HOLLYWOOD, Jan. 21 Elizabeth Taylor and Richard Burton, the world's highestpaid movie stars, have been putting on a stirring free performance here for the last two weeks, much against their wishes.

The Pastors resolution urging rapid conclusion of a nuclear nonproliferation treaty emphasizes again that time is running out on the effort to halt the spread of nuclear weapons. Within the next few years the increasing economic feasibility of nuclear power will bring more than a dozen additional countries within reach of an atomic weapons capability.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 Secretary of State Dean Rusk said today that the Tashkent accord between India and Pakistan opened the door to the resumption of United States economic aid to the two countries.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 The nation's railroads went to court today to block a possible strike next week while awaiting a decision that could clarify a muddled rail labor picture.
PARIS, Jan. 21 Chrysler is the only United States company among this year's 12 favored foreign stocks on the Paris stock exchange, according to an annual poll published here.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 The index of wholesale primary market prices averaged unchanged at 104.5 of its 1957-59 base during the week ended Jan. 18, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today. Farm products and processed foods rose in price while industrial commodities held steady.
The State Supreme Court opened the way yesterday for taxpayer suits to force the Transit Authority to punish under the Condon-Wadlin Law workers who struck the city
WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 (UPI) A Republican member of the House described today the Middle East trip of President Johnson's brother-in-law as "just a little Texas-style nepotism."
If some salesmen who have been on their feet at the Coliseum for the last week had been in a prizefight instead of a boat show, the referee would have stopped it by now.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 21 The "stockpiling" of merchant marine shipping space that is essential for military purposes, with the cost paid for by the Department of Defense, has been called for by J. Paul St. Sure, board chairman of Pacific Maritime Association.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 (UPI) James R. Hoffa, president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, said today that strikes by his members were at a low and would be fewer if local officials did not try to negotiate on their own in labor disputes.
LONDON, Jan. 21 (AP) K.T. Keller, former president and chairman of the Chrysler Corporation, died today in the Dorchester Hotel. He was 80 years old.

LANSING, Mich., Jan. 21 (AP) Lou Gard, a Western Michigan University student who bowls for fun, rolled a 300 game today against the nation's top professionals, in the third day of the National All-Star tournament.

Mickey Mantle will have a bone chip removed from his right shoulder on Tuesday at the Mayo Clinic in Rochester, Minn., the New York Yankees learned yesterday. If the operation is successful. Mantle should be ready to begin spring training on March 1 with the rest of the club, the Yankees were told.

In the chapel of St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church last evening, Miss Faith Orcutt, daughter of Mrs. Le Roy B. Pitkin of Manhasset and Westhampton Beach, L.Y., and William A. Orcutt of Durham, N.C., was married to Robert Mowry Chase. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. William Earle Chase of Pelham, N.Y. and Lauderdale-by-the-Sea, Fla.
MIAMI, Jan. 21. Take a horse out of Australia and ship him to the United States, don't race him for more than 10 months, put a strange jockey on him and what happens? He wins.

The 15 largest mutual savings banks in New York City. which showed a net loss of $32.9-million in deposits during the first week of January, have roared back with an $88-million gain during the second week.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 21 Seven experts have come up with recommendations to both industrial and underdeveloped countries to modify their attitudes on use by the less-developed group of secondhand machinery.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., Jan. 21 Mr. and Mrs. Lewis M. Leisinger have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Lynne Margaret Leisinger, to Ens. John Emerson Chubb Jr., U.S.N He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Chubb of Grosse Pointe, Mich. A late summer wedding is planned.

Deputy Mayor Robert Price threatened after last November's election to oppose the renewal of the license for the National Broadcasting Company's television station in New York. Last night he said that, after meeting with N.B.C. lawyers, he had changed his mind.

Kipchoge Keino, perhaps the most exciting runner in the world, will make his American and indoor debut tonight with a possible iron-man stunt, He will run the mile in the Los Angeles Invitation meet and may run the two-mile as well.

ALMERIA, Spain, Jan. 21 (AP) Spanish doctors checking policemen and others working around the wreckage of an American bomber were quoted tonight as having said they found traces of "contamination" among some of them.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 (AP) The Civil Aeronautics Board approved today reduced fares for two airlines American and Allegheny. They are designed to encourage young people to travel by air.

Acting on the second tip by Mayor Lindsay in two days, an air pollution inspector issued a summons to Consolidated Edison yesterday for emitting "dense smoke" from its East River power plant at 14th Street.

SYRACUSE, Jan. 21 (AP) A Federal mediator said today that negotiators had reached a tentative agreement that would end a strike that has idled the Aluminum Company of America's cable division in Rome, N.Y. since Nov. 14.

AMMAN, Jordan, Jan. 20 The Jordanian Government is seeking modern military aircraft in a general refurbishing of its armed forces and wants, if possible, to obtain United States R-104 supersonic fighters.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 (AP) A $2.1 million contract with the United Aircraft Corp. for two gas-turbine passenger trains to demonstrate highspeed runs between Boston and New York was announced today by Senator Claborne Pell. Democrat of Rhode Island.

The Museum of Modern Art has announced plans for its first international program of animated films, Monday through Feb. 6. The program will include movies from the United States, Canada, Denmark, France, Britain, Japan, Poland, Rumania and Yugoslavia.
LONDON, Jan. 21 (Reuters) George Harrison, the Beetles' 22-year-old lead guitarist, married Patti Boyd, 21, a blond actress and model today.
CHICAGO, Jan. 21 The Government charged today that Krebiozen promoters fit the historic mold for "medical quackery" by "always claiming credit for any good that other treatment did."

ALLAHABAD, India, Jan. 21 All night they came, and through the pale dawn: naked holy men covered only with white ashes; priests in saffron robes and garlands of marigolds; turbaned Sikhs with tangled beards; clerks from Be nares in spectacles and frayed jackets; farmers wrapped in wool blankets.
The United States Court of Appeals yesterday upheld for the first time a case of punitive damages assessed against a motorist who had caused an automobile accident.
BOSTON, Jan. 21 "Larry O'Brien is known to more people on a two-block stretch of Pennsylvania Avenue than he is in the entire Commonwealth of Massachusetts."

The purpose of the second concert in the "Jazz at Hunter" series, held last night in the Hunter College Assembly Hall, was to examine the jazz composer. To this end, works by Duke Ellington, Dizzy Gillespie, Benny Golson, Thelonious Monk, Jelly Roll Morton, Gerry Mulligan and Charlie Parker were played by as assemblage of more than two dozen musicians.

WEST HARTFORD, Conn., Jan. 21 Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Stanley R. Rich of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Julie Alice Rich, to Joseph Abbott Ingelfinger, son of Dr. and Mrs. Franz Joseph Ingelfinger of Cambridge and Ipswich, Mass, The wedding will be in July.

The ruling by the New York State Court of Appeals on Thursday that the National Distillers and Chemical Corporation could fix the retail price of its liquor under the state's Fair Trade Law was applauded yesterday by the majority of independent package store owners.
LONDON, Jan. 21 London critics were well nigh unanimous in praise of Donald Howarth's "A Lily in Little India," which opened last night at the St. Martin's Theatre.

City Council President Frank D. O'Connor, in his first public criticism of Mayor Lindsay, said yesterday he was "dismayed" at what he called "the attempt by the Mayor's office to interfere in the professional operations of the Police Department."

The Appellate Division reserved decision yesterday on a move to block the Port of New York Authority, from acquiring 16 acres of property on the lower West Side for its proposed $525-million World Trade Center.
PARIS, Jan. 21 Relations between France and Morocco appeared to be in the balance today.

BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 21 The Most Rev. Alfonso Maria, Buteler, bowing to pressure generated by progressive priests in his Andean archdiocese, promised today to implement reforms decreed by the Vatican Council.

Councilman Theodore R. Kupferman urged yesterday the construction of floating theaters where concerts and plays could be given in the summer and recreation piers where "teen-agers and senior citizens could relax and play."
ANNISTON, Ala., Jan. 21 (AP) A Federal court jury acquitted Kenneth L. Adams today of charges of receiving stolen Army explosives.
William A. Stewart, vice president of the Chauncey Real Estate Co., Ltd., died Wednesday at the Nassau Hospital in Mineola, L.I. He was 68 years old and lived in Bellerose, L.I.
The sack of Staten Island continues as if it were preordained Nobody seems to be able to turn back the invaders.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 (AP) President Johnson announced today the appointment of a national advisory council to the United States Public Health Service on administering new Federal scholarship grants to students of medicine, dentistry and related fields.
A 41-Year-old Bronx man with a record of 18 arrests in the last 21 years was found shot dead early yesterday morning in a quiet waterfront community of Throgs Neck.
A formal declaration of war for control of the Crucible Steel Company of America was signed yesterday by Morris J. Rubin, Chicago industrialist.
Can a husband obtain a divorce from his wife on the ground that she committed adultery by being artificially inseminated without his knowledge or consent?
Since 1961, when Ralph Cohen formed the apparel concern that bears his name, the company has sewn more than eight million yards of Indian madras cloth into a variety of women's sportswear.
HONOLULU, Jan. 21, (UPI) Sandbag dikes were thrown up today to keep flooding rainwaters out of the lobbies of Waikiki Beach hotels as heavy rains and a cold front hit Hawaii.

Last night at 7:45, Dr. Joseph C. Hinsey went to a dissection, not a terribly unusual thing for the director of a medical center to do. But last night it was different, because Dr. Hinsey himself was to be dissected.
The question of who owns old movies and has the right to show them to the public has turned into a modern cliffhanger, with the copyright law as the villain.

ROCKVILLE CENTRE, L.I., Jan. 21 Mr. and Mrs. George Edelstein have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Judith Edelstein, to Robert Diskint, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Diskint of Fresh Meadows, Queens.
Plans for the largest utility merger in years were made public yesterday in Chicago following a meeting of Commonwealth Edison Company directors.

Wright A. Nodine, senior vicepresident and management-account supervisor of Lennen Newell, Inc., advertising agency at 380 Madison Avenue, died Wednesday at his office. He was 45 years old and lived in Manhasset. L.I.

Gundaris Pone is a facile composer of strong intellect whose best work is academic and whose least efforts are eclectic. Five of his chamber pieces were played last night at Carnegie Recital Hall and none exhibited the unity of style that marks compositional personality.

Mayor Lindsay's new Transportation Council set up two subcommittees yesterday to make prompt recommendations in disputes over where to locate a new East River subway tube and the Richmond Parkway on Staten Island.

SAO PAULO, Jan. 21 "I hear we are all going to stop," shouted a taxi driver today to a fellow cabbie as they both idled their motors at a red light.
The Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company announced yesterday at a board meeting in Jacksonville, Fla., the election of J. Gordon Christian Jr. as president of its Southern division.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 (AP) Peru called today for an extraordinary meeting of the Council of the Organization of American States to denounce intervention in the American republics. The Council will meet Monday to hear the Peruvian complaint.

MOSCOW, Jan. 21 A 27year-old American tourist committed suicide on his way to a Soviet labor camp to which he had been sentenced to 18 months for an illegal border crossing, Russian authorities told the United States Embassy tonight.
The American Stock Exchange gave it a good by yesterday, but couldn't quite make it as stocks continued to weak an on lower volume.
Customer borrowings from New York Stock Exchange member firms surged close to a historic high during December, the exchange reported yesterday. The total rose $311million, to $5,543,000,000.

WANTAGH, L.I., Jan. 21 David Rosenblum, 42 years old, was driving his car past a pond at Sunrise Highway and Wantagh Parkway today when he saw four youngsters, who, had been ice skating, fall through the ice. He ran to a nearby construction site, grabbed some boards and started toward the pond.
Investors returned to the London Stock Exchange yesterday, sending all sections up. There was institutional buying in various groups, but most prominently among the tobacco and steel issues.
Two gunmen robbed a payroll delivery car in Queens yesterday of $8,757 and escaped with the auto as well after a booby-trapped money satchel failed to work properly.
