GREENWICH, Conn., Jan. 22 --Miss Claire Irene Muldowney, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Cleary Muldowney of Hyannis, Mass., was married today to Carl Ernest Nauen, son of Ern est C. Nauen of Greenwich and the late Mrs. Nauen.

COLTS NECK, N.J., Jan. 22 --Mr. and Mrs. Robert G. Potts have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Nancy Potts, to Second Lieut. Westcott Hoge Smith. U.S.A.F. He is the son of Brig. Gen. Pinkham Smith, commander of air forces in South Korea, and Mrs. Smith.
ROME, Jan. 22--Farmer Premier Amintore Fanfani declared himself today to be "available" to help form a government to end the current crisis.
A modern architectural approach to home design has appeared in the 270-year-old residential community of Harrison, in Westchester County.
THE Ohara Center of Japanese Flower Ar rangement, the first of its kind devoted solely to ikebana in the United States, will open Friday in New York City.

SYDNEY, Australia, Jan. 22 (AP)--Arthur Ashe, the favorite and Clark Graebner scored decisive straight-set victories today and gave the United States a sweep of opening matches in the Australian national tennis championships.
In the American Supramar booth at the National Boat Show, a continuous color film has been calling attention to what the exhibitor contends is "the greatest boon to boating since Noah's Ark."

OWEGO, N.Y., Jan. 22--The guest of honor was nearly an hour late, what with the snowstorm and stopping at the parochial school, but the bare, low-ceilinged hall of the Goodrich Settlement Grange was still crowded with heavybooted farmers and their wives.
BOSTON, Jan. 22 (AP)--Dom DiMaggio, former Boston Red Sox outfielder, will rejoin the club for spring training at Winter Haven, Fla., General Manager Dick O'Connell said today.
ASHKHABAD, U.S.S.R.-- A joke making the rounds of this modern Soviet city tells of some old Turkmenian nomads watching a movie full of dreadful scenes of shipwreck and tempest.
What is the lowest rent possible in new construction in the New York City Metropolitan area? What guidelines should a prospective tenant keep in mind when apartment hunting?
The nation's two largest hotel chains, the Hilton Hotels Corporation and the Sheraton Corporation of America, are making inroads in a field long dominated by motels--the franchise business.
MONTREAL--In a few days, residents of this city, and visitors, too; will begin their an nual exodus to two of the best-known winter events in North America.

WOODCLIFF LAKE, N.J., Jan. 22--Mr. and Mrs. Thomas R. Morgan have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Catherine Marie Morgan, to Henry Joseph Hecker, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Francis Hecker of River Edge. A wedding on April 16 is planned.
SYRACUSE, Jan. 22 (AP)-- Syracuse and Army will resume football relations with a twogame series in 1970 and 1972, the schools announced today. The teams have not met in the last six years.
ATHENS, Jan. 22--A ban by the Greek state-owned radio this week on the songs of a Communist composer has upset the country's leftist politicians and intellectuals.
A champagne reception has been arranged for the opening of an exhibition of paintings by Mary Cassatt on the evening of Feb. 1 at the Knodler Art Galleries.
Bryan C. Duffy of New York has announced the engagement of his daughter. Miss Julia Eileen Duffy, to Edward J. Miller, son of Mrs. Paul Miller of Long Island City, Queens, any the late Mr. Miller.

BOWIE, Md., Jan. 22--Bowie race track officials took emergency precautions today as two cases of dreaded swamp fever were reported among the stabled horses. with 48 horses, was quarantined and the owners were barred from running or exercising the animals at the track.
CAMP PARKS, Calif., Jan. 19--Job Corps costs at Camp Parks have risen above original estimates, but nobody knows, or is prepared to say, how much.

PARIS, Jan. 22--Three years ago, almost to the day, President Charles de Gaulle began to reshape the European Common Market. His veto of Britain's bid for membership cracked the vital spirit of unity. Last July he stopped the machinery altogether by walking out.
A little construction can go a long way toward transforming a neighborhood, even in crowded Manhattan. The evidence continues to mount in brick and concrete in a small section of the East Side.
What may be the city's smallest residential cooperative is planned in Greenwich Village.
MILWAUKEE, Jan. 22--The Federal Government has made Milwaukee a sort of guinea pig in a study of a growing labor shortage.

HUNTER, N.Y.--As skiing continues to gain in popularity as a family sport, ski school directors here in the northern Catskills are focusing considerable attention on future skiers--toddlers who have not even reached kindergarten age.

San Francisco can frown upon those in the "steel ball era" who knock down landmarks to build anew. The city points with pride to its bright example of teamwork when good men got together to develop rather than destroy a charming old city block.
HANOVER, N.H., Jan. 22-- Manhattan College broke four meet and two Leverone field house records today as the Jaspers defeated the Dartmouth trick team, 73-31.
CAMP PARKS, Calif., Jan. 19--Job Corps costs at Camp Parks have risen above original estimates, but nobody knows, or is prepared to say, how much.
Blue Cross premiums will not be reduced July 1 when Medicare relieves the insurance plan of its most expensive item the bill for patients 65 and over.
KARACHI, Pakistan Afghanistan's effort toward a quick transition into a 20thcentury nation is being hampered by a lack of trained manpower.
BANGKOK, Thailand Despite its perch at the edge of the Vietnam conflict, the estimated 29.3 million people of this kingdom recorded a year of economic progress.
Montgomery Ward Co., the mail-order chain organization, announced over the weekend in Chicago the election of James Lutz and Ashley D. DeShazor as vice presidents.

SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, Jan. 23 The United States has given the Dominican Republic $90-million in economic aid since the outbreak of the revolution last April. All the assistance was in direct grants.

THE top man at the National Boat Show since 1949 bought a boat there this year that was both fitting and characteristically diplomatic. Specifically, Joseph Emery Choate bought a Banana Boat, an 8 -foot ark made of vinyl and rubber that cost $55 and can be folded into a small...
TOKYO The movie amusement center at Yurakucho, in downtown Tokyo, had a boom last spring, similar to the country's biggest holidays at the New Year, with "Goldfinger," one of the James Bond series.

NEW YORK, despite its multiple diversions, is not an easy city for youngsters, Boys, in particular, tend to assert their independence early, partly in an effort to break away from parental strictures and partly in rebellion against the highly scheduled lives middle-class childred lead.

NEWPORT, R.I., Jan. 23 The Chapel-by-the-Sea was the setting this afternoon for the marriage of Miss Irene Denny Partridge, daughter of Capt. Benjamin Waring Partridge, U.S.N., and Mrs. Partridge, to Eugene Flournoy Stevens. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Stevens of Exeter, N.H.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 23 A cross was burned in the War Memorial Plaza here tonight and, shortly after, another object was burned on the lawn of the Roman Catholic Cathedral of Mary Our Queen, the police reported.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 A Presidential commission on automation has unanimously agreed to a report that finds technological change presents no basic threat to employment that cannot be overcome by vigorous fiscal policies to spur economic growth.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N. Y., Jan. 23 Knut Stromstad, a former athletic instructor in Switzerland who is now a sales trainee for Alcoa Aluminum in Boston, won the Ramapo Mountain Ski-jumping championship by a handy margin today.
Dr. Edward Aaron Goodwin, a retired obstetrician and gynecologist, died on Saturday in his home at Miami Beach. He was 82 years old and had lived in New York until he retired 10 years ago.
WOODSTOCK, England, Jan. 23 (UPI) An audience of 400 attended a concert in Blenheim Palace today commemorating the first anniversary of the death of Sir Winston Churchill.
The Park Association of New York City assailed yesterday the proposed route of Richmond Parkway through Staten Island's green belt.
MIAMI, Jan. 23 (AP) Eduardo Zuleta of Ecuador, a protege of Pancho Segura, won three matches today to take the singles and share the doubles titles in the City of Miami tennis championships.

ALGIERS, Jan. 23 The official party weekly has warned non-French oil companies they will have to accept recent Government-dictated terms or give up their conces sions and get out of Algeria. The warning came in a long article in this week's edition of Revolution Africaine.
TOKYO The Japanese automobile industry, which has developed into the second largest foreign exchange earner, looks for further expansion of trade both in foreign and domestic markets in 1966.
YONKERS, Jan. 23 Frank D. O'Connor, president of the New York City Council, charged the Rockefeller administration tonight with slowness in combating the narcotics problem in New York.
NORTHAMPTON, Mass., Jan. 23 Dr. Marjorie Roach, assistant physician at Smith College since 1960, died at the Smith infirmary today. She was 62 years old.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 Administration forces are frankly gloomy as they prepare to reopen their Senate battle tomorrow to wipe out state laws banning the union shop.
HONG KONG The Red Dragon has put its best face forward here. It is benign and smiling and if it has any teeth, they are well concealed.

BURLINGAME, Calif., Jan. 23 Miss Virginia J. Burns, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. H. Jay Burns, was married here today to Richard E. Cheney of New York, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Royal F. Cheney of Pana, Ill. The ceremony was performed at the home of the bride's parents by Superior Court Judge J. Albert Branson.
Archie R. Boe, a 44-year-old career man at the Allstate Insurance Companies, has been advanced to the presidency of the concern, a subsidiary of Sears, Roebuck Co., it was announced over the weekend.
MIDDLE ISLAND, L.I, Jan. 23 Jane Litchford rode Fanfare, a 4-yeas-old chestnut gelding, to the limit working hunter championship after a hackoff today at the Middle Island Riding Club horse show.
Leon Sosnoff of 215 West 90th Street, a partner in Jonick. Robbins, Greene Sosnoff, accountants, died of a heart attack Saturday in his office at 521 Fifth Avenue. His age was 51.
CAMDEN, Ala., Jan. 23 (UPI) A white farmer shot and killed a Negro man today, touching off a singing, chanting demonstration by Negroes at the scene.
PARIS, Jan. 23 The imme- diate meaning of the European Common Market crisis for the United States is in the Kennedy round.
ATLANTA, Jan. 23 In a forest near Panama City, Fla., bankers and other investors in the South's timber industry recently watched in surprise as a tractor-like machine roared toward a tall pine.
SYDNEY, Australia, Jan. 23 (AP) Arthur Ashe needed four sets to defeat an unheralded Australian and Clark Graebner won a controversial five-set match today in the Australian tennis championships.

NORTH SALEM, N.Y., Jan. 23 Karen Kelso's Royal Flush captured the open jumper championship at the first Salem View Farms winter horse show today, Piloted by Jack Rockwell, Royal Flush won one class and took a third place for 7 points.

SAARBRUCKEN, Germany, Jan. 23 (AP) An arms smuggling ring that supplied Kurdish insurgents in Iraq with Czechoslovakian weapons via West German and Turkish go-betweens has been uncovered after the arrest of a Saarland businessman, authorities reported today.
NEW DELHI, Monday, Jan. 24 Mrs. Indira Gandhi, the Prime Minister-designate, submitted her Cabinet to President Sarvepalli Radhakrishnan early today.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Jan. 23 William S. Spencer of Salt Lake City won the national biathlon championship today under near-blizzard conditions. Spencer's time of 1 hour 45 minutes 20 seconds for the 20kilometer four-target course was the best in a field of 22 starters, including six Canadians.
John H. Wurts of Binghamton, N.Y., president of the Marine Midland Trust Company of Southern New York, died yesterday morning at the Sheraton East Hotel. He was 55 years old.

The Motion Picture Relief Fund has received a $100,000 donation from Bob Hope to the Fund's $40-million endowment and building campaign. The comedian asked that the gift be considered a memorial to Charlie Cooley, Mr. Hope's school mate, who worked with him in vaudeville, films and television.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 23 (AP) Mayor Samuel W. Yorty replied today to a California advisory committee's report accusing him and Los Angeles's Police Chief William H. Parker, of "gross negligence" in this city before the Negro riots in the Watts section last August.

MIDDLETON, Wis., Jan. 23 (AP) John Balfanz, the 1964 national champion, racked up his second straight victory today in a qualifying meet for the United States ski jumping team, which will take part in the world championships in Norway.

Mrs. Nelson A. Rockefeller, wife of the Governor, will be the guest of honor at a luncheon at the St. Regis Roof on Feb. 1, to be given by the women's division of the United Jewish Appeal of Greater New York. The event will open the group's 1966 fundraising campaign.

SEOUL, South Korea Government officials here believe South Korea's most advantageous economic course lies in developing job-producing factories, with a sound basic structure of heavy industries and services.

The Italian political crisis a a typical shakedown and readjustment of a situation that had become too unstable. Once Foreign Minister Fanfani resigned last month and bared the internal divisions in the Christian Democratic party, a clarification became necessary.
The General Electric Credit Corporation announced over the weekend the introduction of a new plan through which it would aid construction equipment dealers to enter the equipment-rental business.
ROCKTON, Ill., Jan. 23 (AP) Five persons were killed to day in a collision of two light planes near the Wagon Wheel Airport in northern Illinois, the police in nearby Beloit, Wis., said.
LAGOS, Nigeria, Jan. 23 Nigeria quietly mourned her Prime Minister today.
The resignation of Martin Landey as president of Lady Van Heusen, Inc., a division of the Phillips-Van Heusen Corporation, was announced over the weekend.
Senator Robert F. Kennedy said yesterday that he had been working for more than a year on a Bronx park project that Mayor Lindsay publicized on Saturday as a city development.

TOKYO, Jan. 23 About 50,000 Japanese seamen are scheduled to stop work at midnight tomorrow, halting the operation of 1,240 ocean-going and coastal ships for 15 days in the "fourth wave" of a strike for higher pay.

LONDON, Jan. 23 (AP) Col. Francisco Caamano Deno, who led the rebel movement in the four-month Dominican civil war last year, warned today of more trouble in his homeland if regular army officers there refuse to accept transfers abroad.

PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, Jan. 23 (AP) A Haitian commercial airliner crashed near the southwest coast of Haiti yesterday, killing 30 persons, including two United Nations officials and the wife of a third. There were five survivors.

THE most successful New York tournament player in 1965 was Charles Coon, according to figures released by the American Contract Bridge League last week. He amassed 702 master points, and demonstrated his versatility by winning them with a wide variety of partners.
With hundreds of boat horns filling the Coliseum with the traditional din, the National Boat Show last night ended one of its most successful cruises.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 The "one voice" with which President Johnson has wanted to speak to Latin America will no longer be the controversial voice of Thomas C. Mann.
Dick Clapp, who programs computers at Stevens Institute of Technology, ran through eight miles of slush to win the Road Runners Club of New York handicap run yesterday in the Bronx.
LOS ANGELES, Jan. 23 Politicians on several office levels are being accused of using the drive against poverty here as a maneuver to advance their own causes.

PARTLETT, N.H., Jan. 23 The Ski Masters competition, in which style rather than speed is the factor, ended in a blinding snowstorm today, with George Hodgkins Jr. and Lucy Boynton taking the division titles.
SEOUL, South Korea South Korea, beginning to capitalize on its ample reservoir of the cheapest labor in East Asia, has raised the value of its exports more than fivefold since 1960.
MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 23 (AP) Circuit Judge Pat Cannon, an iceman who became a Congressman, died at his home today. He was 61 years old.

TOKYO Will the increased outlays of public funds planned by the Japanese Government for 1966 spur recovery from one of the country's worst economic recessions in years? will the present moderate inflationary trend be heightened by flotation of Government bonds and projected rises in commodity and service prices?

TAPPAN, N.Y., Jan. 23 American Legion Post 1271 has formally adopted Company C of the First Battalion, Second Infantry, First Division, now serving in the village of Phuocvinh, 40 miles north of Saigon.
A spokesman for the city's trade unions said yesterday that organized labor would oppose new legislation to limit strikes by public employes.
NEW DELHI, Jan. 23 The Indian Government announced tonight that it had arrested Daniel H. Walcott, a convicted American gunrunner who had escaped capture by the Indian police.
Three rabbis representing the Orthodox, Conservative and Reform branches of Judaism voiced cautious agreement yesterday that religious unity of the three branches could be achieved.
A number of large industrial property purchases were recently completed in New Jersey.

Mr. and Mrs. David M. Solinger of 33 East 70th Street have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Lynn Solinger, to Robert A.M. Stern. His parents are Mr. and Mrs. Sidney S. Stern of Brooklyn.

BRUSSELS, Jan. 23 Charles F. Schank, since August, 1964, the senior representative here for the United States Atomic Energy Commission, died early today, apparently of a heart attack. He was 65 years old.
SYDNEY, Australia Undaunted by the failure of the straight banana, agricultural scientists now are whipping a square pineapple into shape.
Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. declared in a sermon here yesterday that "slavery could not have lasted so long had not the church sanctioned it."

The season's first full winter storm left one to two inches of slush in the city yesterday and blankets of snow in the suburbs, upstate New York and neighboring states. Snow depths ranged from two to three inches in eastern Long Island to 27 inches near Buffalo.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 23 (AP) The first female managing editor of The Harvard Crimson, the 93-year-old university undergraduate daily newspaper, was named today by the executive board.
TOKYO Behind the facade of an over-rising standard of living, the Japanese economy is undergoing a profound reorganization spurred by a year-long recession in business activity.
Isadore B. Geller of 180 West End Avenue, who retired 15 years ago as a real-estate investor, operator and builder here, died Saturday in Miami Beach, where he spent winters. His age was 74.
The police entered an East Side penthouse early yesterday and broke up a party of 30 young persons. They said they found marijuana and pep pills in the apartment.
WALDWICK, N.J., Jan. 23 Steve Turner scored the biggest upset of the Eastern clay-court indoor tennis championship tonight with a 6-1, 6-3 victory over Tom Roesch, the sixthseeded player.
Nassau County Executive Eugene H. Nickerson said yesterday that many persons had urged him to seek the Democratic nomination for Governor this year but that he had not yet decided to do so.
American Export Isbrandtsen Lines announced plans yesterday to take the lead in a multimillion-dollar race to establish a regular container service across the Atlantic.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., Jan. 23 Matthew L. Wilson, assistant treasurer and assistant secretary of the Bell Telephone Laboratories in Murray Hill, died of a stroke tonight while plowing snow in front of his home at 26 Morris Avenue. His age was 64.

BRUNSWICK, Me., Jan. 23 The composer Carl Ruggles, who is considered one of the two pioneering originals of contemporary American music (the other is Charles Ives), was honored by Bowdoin College this weekend.
ACCORDING to the Chinese lunar calendar, the Year of the Horse began Friday, and that may suggest a Chinese menu to an adventurous cook.
NEW DELHI India's population increased last year, and this fact influences every facet of the country's economic planning.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Jan. 23 (AP) Thomas Merton indicated today that he would no longer write about world affairs.
TURIN, N.Y., Jan. 23 (AP) Warren Witherill of Lake Placid, N.Y., and Terry Phelps of Lyons Falls, N.Y., ties today in the 12th annual Oneida Silversmiths Slalom Trophy Race at Snow Ridge.
JAKARTA, Indonesia The quickest solution the Indonesian Government has found to the problem of making money is, literally, to make it.
HONG KONG Last year Cambodia severed relations with one world power and came close to a break with another.
ALBANY, Jan. 23 (AP) The State Motor Vehicle Commissioner sought today to head off moves to extend the deadline for registering automobiles beyond Feb. 1.
LEVITTOWN, L,I., Jan. 23 Two holdup men escaped with $45,000 in cash and checks last night after kidnapping the manager of a Shoprite supermarket and forcing him to open the office safe.
CHICAGO, Jan.23 (AP) Some persons who work with high-powered radar equipment show evidence of accelerated aging in their eye lenses, two New York medical investigators reported today.

Representative Paul G. Rogers, a supporter of a strong merchant marine, warned yesterday that the United States was running a poor second to the Soviet Union in shipbuilding and other maritime activities.

SIR JOHN GIELGUD'S readings from the works of Shakespeare were brought to television yesterday afternoon in the first part of an adaptation of "Ages of Man," his 1959 success in the theater. It was a viewing occasion to be treasured, as the audience at home could see in close-up Sir John's gifts for casting a spell of theater.

SINGAPORE Few Asian countries have matched Singapore's economic strides. But the industrializing island nation sees dark days ahead and the threat of a Communist takeover unless its goods find a crack in Western markets.

HONG KONG, Discontent over the state of Burma's economy and the Government's economic policy was shown last August when the public was invited to air its grievences in a "People's Forum" in the press.
Congress will begin this week to analyze carefully the Administration's request for another supplemental appropriation of $12.7-billion to help finance the Vietnamese war.
FREEPORT, Grand Bahamas, Jan. 23 (AP) Paul Kelly of Scarborough, N.Y., shot a 73 today for a total of 287 to win the Bahama open golf championship and pocket $750.

Three major contributors to the development of jet engines will share the Goddard Award of the American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics, to be presented tomorrow night at the Statler Hilton Hotel here.

Seymour N. Siegel does not plan to withdraw his retirement as director of the city's radio station, WNYC, unless the future relationship between City Hall and the Municipal Broadcasting System is carefully shelled out.

SAIGON, Jan. 23 Although the South Vietnamese Government has given its highest priority this year to a new plan for "rural pacification," some old Vietnam hands express doubt that this is the year when pacification will achieve much.

TAIPEI, Taiwan The biggest incentive for foreign investment on Taiwan is the establishment of the Export Processing Zone in Kaohsiung, where the application of tax and duty incentives has brought investors from the United States, Europe, Japan and Hong Kong. At year's end, more than 20 investment cases had been approved by zone adminstrators. The first factory will begin operations in March.

"Some Democrats in Albany are about to commit political prostitution with the Republicans" by carving out legislative districts safe for each other, R. Peter Straus, president of radio station WMCA, charged yesterday.
Representatives of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association will meet with Deputy Mayor Robert Price and then with Mayor Lindsay this morning to discuss police complaints against Mr. Price.

PEBBLE BEACH, Calif., Jan. 23 Don Massengale likes to look at the Pacific Ocean here, but when he's playing golf along its shores he prefers to stay out of it. "I haven't been in it yet, either to swim or from the fairway," said the 28-yearold Texan from Jacksboro after gaining his first major triumph, the Bing Crosby tournament.

Councilman Theodore R. Kupferman, the Republican candidate for Mayor Lindsay's vacated seat in the 17th Congressional District, said yesterday that he was opposed to President Johnson's proposal that the term for members of the House of Representatives be lengthened to four years.

LONDON, Jan. 23 Charles Cooper, a West Midlands steelmaker, sent a telegram yesterday to Prime Minister Wilson and the Conservative opposition leader, Edward Heath, demanding a public inquiry into natural gas shortages this winter.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 Secretary of State Dean Rusk expressed hope tonight that friendly European powers would offer fighting troops for South Vietnam.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Jan. 23 Miss Beth Ann Seidmon, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Edward Edgar Seidmon of Plainfield and Milford, N.J., was married today to Arthur Lewis Nelkin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Nelkin of New York.
HONG KONG Defense considerations are expected to figure significantly in Communist China's economic priorities in 1966 as Peking begins its third five-year plan.
ROME, Jan. 23 President Gluseppe Saragat appeared tonight to be facing a choice between calling new elections in Italy and asking Premier Aldo Moro to form a new center-left coalition Cabinet.
LONDON, Jan. 23. Scientists at the Pasteur Institute in Paris have won an unusual victory with wide implications for scientific work in France.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 23 (UPI) Two world indoor records were broken, another was tied and Kipchoge Keino of Kenya put on an iron-man double last night in the Los Angeles invitation track meet running the mile and two mile races 90 minutes apart in his first appearance on the boards.

PEBBLE BEACH, Calif., Jan. 23 At the edge of the Pacific today, Don Massengale of Texas won the Bing Crosby golf tournament with a 72-hole score of 283. The 28-year-old professional kept clear of ocean hazards and closed with a 70 at the Pebble Beach links to score by one stroke.
SAIGON, Jan. 23 You can take an American out of his own backyard, but you can't take the backyard out of him.

ROCHESTER, Jan. 23 (AP) Sandy Koufax, the 30-year-old left-handed pitching star of the champion Los Angeles Dodgers, was named the winner today of the S. Rae Hickok Professional Athlete of the Year Award for 1965.

The marriage of Miss Janet Schecter, daughter of Mrs. Samuel B. Schecter of New Rochelle, N.Y., and the late Dr. Schecter, to Michael Suisman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward A. Suisman of West Hartford, Conn., took place here yesterday afternoon. Rabbi Jacob K. Shankman performed the ceremony at the Plaza.
BELT manufacturers, reeling under fashion's as sault on the waistline in recent years, have found a hipline to hang onto.
BIRMINGHAM, Jan. 23 (AP) The police arrested Hosea Williams, a staff officer with the Southern Christian Leadership Conference, on traffic charges early today.
RIVERSIDE, Calif., Jan. 23 (UPI) Dan Gurney, driving a 1966 Ford, won the $77,000 Riverside 500-mile stock car road race today for the Fourth consecutive time.
SYDNEY, Australia Australians celebrated Christmas and rang in the new year with festivities a shade less enthusiastic than in the past.
Does Estelle Winwood, who has been acting for 78 years and who will be 83 years old today, have any advice for young actors?

Roman Catholic, Protestant and Eastern Orthodox churchgoers prayed together yesterday for the reunion of a divided Christendom in a service described by its sponsors as the first fully ecumenical rite ever conducted here.
ROME, Jan. 23 Pope Paul VI said today that "perhaps the hour" of Christian unity "is near" but prayer and "divine aid, almost a miracle of the Lord" are needed for its realization.

J.S. Bach's three cantatas for the Feast of St. John the Baptist were given by the Festival Orchestra and Chorus and assisting soloists at Philharmonic Hall yesterday afternoon. Thomas Dunn conducted.

NINETY-FIVE years ago today the city of Paris was still defying the Prussian armies that invested it since the previous September. Although the second empire of Napoleon III had been disastrously defeated by the superior might and efficiency of Prussia, Paris itself, with furious gal lantry, was still at war.
TRIPOLI, Libya, Jan. 21 The Communist countries have mounted a determined and increasingly successful commercial drive in Libya. The Western powers have become concerned.
A specialist in the use of radioactivity as a tool for dating ancient rocks and sediments believes he has found evidence that the ice ages were caused by changes in the orbit and tilt of the earth.
The Doyle Dane Bernbach bandwagon just keeps rolling along, and advertisers just keep jumping on. And if it keeps rolling at the same pace, it might have to roll right up to an employment agency.
The International Civil Aviation Organization plans to undertake a new study of the technical aviation problems of the European-Mediterranean region.
BOSTON, Jan. 23 The Atlantic Monthly will effect a change of command tomorrow when Edward Weeks relinquishes the helm as editor-in-chief to Robert Manning, a successor of his own choosing.
RABAT, Morocco, Jan. 23 King Hassan publicly expressed confidence today in the Moroccan officials who have been implicated in the Ben Barka case.

The Republic Steel Corporation, the nation's third largest producer of steel, reported over the Weekend record sales and shipments for 1965 and an increase in its earnings for the third consecutive year.
NIVERVILLE, N.Y., Jan. 23. (AP) Two children drowned in Kinderhook Lake yesterday when the power sled driven by their father plunged into a hole in the ice.

KITZBUHEL, Austria, Jan. 23 (AP) Billy Kidd of Stowe, Vt., fell in the slalom event of the Hahnenkamm men's ski races today, suffering injuries that will knock him out of the remainder of the European tour.
Four national swimming champions were among a fivemember squad named by the Amateur Athletic Union yesterday to compete in an international meet at Bremen, Germany, next Saturday and Sunday.
RYE. N.Y., Jan. 23 Unseeded Charlton MacVeagh of New York won the 24th annual Apawamis Club Invitation squash racquets tournament today at the Apawamis courts.

TALAN, South Korea "Let's transform our 5,000year-old farming in these five years!" says the slogan on a public signboard in this model farm district. Alongside is a chart showing the progress of some of the 82 projects carried out during the first year of Taian Myun's (Taian Townships) development Program.
The election of Warren J. Freeman as president of the General Bronze Corporation was announcd here over the weekend.
ABLE industrialist, spokesman for Keldanred, Ja pan's Federation of Economic Organizations ... president of Shinetsu Chemical Company, post in which he succeeded father seven years ago
WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 President Johnson's proposal for a law to ban racial discrimination in the sale or rental of housing has met with less than enthusiastic response from civil rights groups.
The weekend snowstorm forced the postponement yesterday of a National Basketball Association game as will as several local sailing events.
WARSAW, Jan. 23 Stefan Cardinal Wyszynski, the Roman Catholic Primate of Poland, fervently renewed today his church's appeal for reconciliation of all peoples.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 (UPI) The Government announced today the creation of four regional centers to help school teachers and administrators solve desegregation problems.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., Jan. 23 Mrs. Mildred Leake Shetterly, wife of C. Russell Shetterly of the New York bond-law firm of Mitchell, Pershing, Shetterly Mitchell, died of a heart ailment today in her home at 14 Stonehouse Road. She was 66 years old.
HONG KONG The Asian search for economic well-being was seriously retarded in 1965 by war and political turmoil. It was the most discouraging year of the last decade.

IT is no wonder that Gerard Souzay is one of the world's foremost song recitalists. Last night, in the Rogers Auditorium of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, the French baritone displayed the versatility and virtuosity that every singer of art songs should have, but which few ever acquire.
The New York Mets have suggested that the "world's largest ice skating rink" be built for winter use at Shea Stadium.
Events today: Puccini's "La Boheme," Metropolitan Opera, 8 P.M.; New York Philharmonic, Hall, 7:30; American Symphony Orchestra, Carnegie Hall, 8:40 Raymond Lewenthal, pianist, Town Hall, 8.

MINEOLA, L.I, Jan. 23 Members of the Nassau County Board of Supervisors have been asked to go to jail if their county-owned limousines need gas, but if they don't want to go to jail they can go to the Mosquito Control Center or certain other county installations. This hap

The Bunraku Puppet Theater of Japan will appear from March 15 through March 27 at the City Center. Paul Szilard will present the three-centuryold organization on its first commercial tour outside of Japan.

On an open slope above a slow bend in the Allegheny River, just west of Salamanca, N.Y., Seneca Indians are living like Scarsdale executives in new ranch-type houses built for them by a guilt-ridden Federal Government. They are not entirely pleased.
LAGOS, Nigeria, Jan. 23 (AP) The Nigerian Ministry of Information announced today that Dennis Neeld, a correspondent for The Associated Press, had been expelled from the country.

COLOMBO, Ceylon Ceylon, whose decade-long venture into Socialism led to an alliance with the Communists last year, has switched her allegiance and become the core of a new "club" that's trying to set things right.
A 19-year-old youth was arraigned on assault and robbery charges yesterday as a suspect in a holdup that resulted Saturday in the shooting of a policeman in East Harlem.
PITTSBURGH, Jan. 23 The steel market seemed to be moving steadily toward a tight supply situation, mill analysts said today.

WASHINGTON, Jan, 23 The Federal National Mortgage Association announced today a small reduction in the interest it pays on its shortterm discount notes, after six consecutive increases that began in early September.

In a recent case before the New York State Workmen's Compensation Board, a worker was granted an award for injuries he had sustained in a fall on his employer's icy driveway. He had been on his way to work.
AKOSOMBO, Ghana, Jan. 23 President Kwame Nkrumah extolled the United States yesterday in cermonies opening the $403-million Volta River hydroelectric project here.

SEOUL, South Korea South Korean insurance companies, after a long period of struggling through war, inflation and economic uncertainty, hope that an era of growth now lies ahead in a new atmosphere of political and economic stability.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., Jan. 23 (AP) An Erie, Pa., airman took a point lead, lost it, then fought back today and won the first annual Colt Sahara United States open indoor archery championship and a $1,000 first prize.

In the performance of Verdi's "Aida" given by the Metropolitan Opera on Saturday night, Sherrill Milnes sang the part of Amonasro with the company for the first time, and Martina Arroyo (Aida), Irene Dalis (Amneris) and John Macurdy (Ramfis) appeared in their parts for the first time this season. Mr. Macurdy replaced Nicola Ghiuselev, who was indisposed, Franco Corelli was Radames, and Raymond Michalski was the King.
Miss Nicki Sue Fox, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Fox of Kew Gardens Hills, Queens, was married yesterday to David Thomas Adler, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas C. Adler of Cincinnati.

The board of directors of the United Housing Foundation has elected Jacob S. Potofsky, president, and Harold Ostroff, executive vice president. The foundation is the sponsor of a number of large housing cooperatives here.
DETROIT, Jan. 23 (UPI) The first-place Detroit Red Wings, paced by the goal-tending of Roger Crozier, defeated the New York Rangers, 5-1, tonight in a National Hockey League Game.

MANILA "We are in crisis!" Those words by the newly elected President, Ferdimand E. Marcos, thundered from loudspeakers and echoed through Luneta Park as Vice President Humphrey of the United States and 33 other foreign dignitaries listened to the President's inaugural adress.
MANILA The handwriting on the wall is bold and clear to Benigno S. Aquino Jr., 33-year-old Governor of Tarlac Province, 80 miles north of here.
LONDON, Jan. 22 The Royal Mint announced today it was accepting further orders for the Churchill commemorative crown.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y. Pope Paul VI touched a sensitive nerve in the United Nations when he told the General Assembly last October: "You must strive to multiply bread for the tables of mankind."
Tony Vincent of New York has been ranked No.1 for 1966 in the men's 35-years-and-over division of the Eastern Lawn Tennis Association.
HONG KONG, Jan. 23 Communist China was reported today to have sent jet fighters into North Vietnam.

SEOUL, South Korea Only a year ago or so, South Koreans were frightened when American officials implied that United States assistance might end within a relatively few years. They could hardly imagine themselves standing on their own feet so soon.
Abraham Zvi Halevy, Hebrew poet and teacher, died Saturday night of a heart attack at his home at 316 West 107th Street. His age was 58.

SINGAPORE, Jan. 23 (UPI) Diplomatic sources in Jakarta reported today the Chinese Embassy there had spirited out 150 sacks of documents believed to contain "embarrassing material" linking Chinese Communists in Indonesia with the unsuccessful coup Sept. 30.

MATSUSHIRO The almost incessant tremors that have rocked this town since August have left the people wakeful, ready for a sudden jolting disaster in the night. Numbing cold comes with the extinguishing of all fires. There is financial and psychological strain in the constant preparedness for danger.

George J. Crane, the first principal of Bayside High School in Queens, died yesterday in St. John's Queens Hospital, Elmhurst. He was 72 years old and lived at 63 Greenway North, Forest Hills, Queens.
ANKARA, Turkey, Jan. 23 Ihsan Sabri Caglayangil, the Foreign Minister, said today that Turkey would be prepared in principle to accept what he called an "Austrian solution" for Cyprus.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Jan. 23 (AP) Mrs. Nancy Roth Syms of Hollywood, Fla., sank a 50-foot putt on the 35th hole today and won the Helen Lee Doherty women's amateur golf tournament with a 2-and1 decision over Barbara McIntire.

Kay Bache, treasurer of the Patent Scaffolding Company, a division of the Harsco Corporation in Long Island City, Queens, died Saturday in Whitestone hospital, Queens. He was 58 years old and lived at 144-88 Sanford Avenue in Flushing, Queens.

Miss Linda Block, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Israel Block of Forest Hills, Queens, was married yesterday to Lawrence Rose, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Rose of New York. The ceremony was performed at the Whitestone Hebrew Center by Rabbi Joseph Wise.
KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia Despite the shadow war with Indonesia and the separation of Singapore, Malaysia has closed another year of solid economic progress.

GUATEMALA, Jan. 23 The Tropical Radio Telegraph Company, a wholly owned subsidiary of the United Fruit Company, will be taken over by the Guatemalan Government at midnight tomorrow, the day the company's contract expires.

Benjamin Bresnik, a partner in the Garden State Propane Gas Company, Parsippany, N.J., died yesterday in his home at 1829 Caton Avenue, Brooklyn. He was 63 years old. He also had a home in Woodridge, N.Y.
ANOTHER episode in fashion's continuing court ship of the art world is being enacted at Bonwit Teller.

The perennial bill to legalize moonlighting by New York City policemen has been introduced in the State Legislature, but the police lobby isn't pressing as hard as it used to for the right to hold outside jobs.

A total of 1,037 oceangoing vessels arrived in the Port of New York last month, compared with 1,013 for November, 1965, and 993 for December, 1964, according to the Maritime Association of the Port of New York which keeps a tally on Ship movements.

GARMISCH-PARTENKIRCHEN, Germany, Jan. 23 (UPI) Erwin Thaler and Adolf Koxeder of Austria were named European two-man bobsled champions today when warm weather forced the cancellation of the final day of competition.

Artur Rubinstein played the two Brahms Piano Concertos Saturday night at Carnegie Hall and you had to be there to believe it. It was the last of three concerto programs celebrating the 60th anniversary of the pianist's United States debut and on Jan. 28 he will be 80 years old.

Canada, like the United States, has just heard a state-of-the-union message in the form of a Speech from the Throne, in which Prime Minister Pearson came up with a costly and aggressive new social and economic program.

The intense search for oil and natural gas in Australia has resulted in another "significant" discovery of natural gas off the Victoria coast, according to the Australian News and Information Bureau here.
More than half a billion dollars of municipal bonds are scheduled for sale this week, the biggest weekly volume in history.
MANILA Philippine officials and business leaders believe the decision to establish the headquarters of the billiondollar Asian Development Bank in Manila poses a great challenge and opportunity.
SAIGON There are two wars in South Vietnam.
A "new emphasis" in foreign aid that would place the highest priority on education and training in underdeveloped nations was urged last night by Supreme Court Justice Abe Fortas.

SAIGON, Monday, Jan. 21 An uneasy cease-fire ended last night as South Vietnamese, American and other allied troops began resuming offensive operations against the Vietcong after the Lunar New Year festival.

A steady flow of neon gin will soon replace that dried-up waterfall in Times Square. Huge, 42 -foot-tall bottles of Haig Haig scotch whisky will stand at the 44th and 45th Street corners of the block-long display.
NEW DELHI Drought, war and the suspension of new foreign aid were the three horsemen in the Indian sky last year.
TOKYO, Monday, Jan. 24 A strong earthquake shook the Matsushiro area, 110 miles northwest of here, last night, bringing down roof tiles and causing other minor damage.

For the Brooklyn Philharmonic concert at the Brooklyn Academy of Music Saturday night, there were more black ties and ball gowns than one sees at the Met in a week. A sign that Brooklyn is serious about music? Hard to tell.

PORT MORESBY, New Guinea In cool, green Gimi Valley, 7,000 feet up in the Eastern New Guinea Highlands, a grizzled Australian dressed in faded khaki shorts, digger hat and tattered shirt parked his laden truck by the side of a bumpy, rutted road.
HONG KONG "Hong Kong is a remarkable manufacturing machine fueled by the industry of its people," an admiring visitor Commented the other day.
PARIS, Jan. 23 The French Government recalled its Ambassador to Morocco, Robert Gillet, tonight as the "Ben Barka scandal" cast a new chill on FrenchMoroccan relations.
SYDNEY, Australia, Monday, Jan. 24 (Reuters) Clark Graebner apologized to an umpire today for losing his temper during the Australian tennis championships yesterday.

HONG KONG Macao, a Portuguese enclave of six square miles and 250,000 people on the coast of China, imported about $50-million worth of gold last year, according to official figures. What became of the gold is not shown in any official statistics, but the trade would appear to be a profitable undertaking, as a syndicate of businessmen was prepared to pay $1 an ounce to Macao authorities for the privilege of handling it.
TAIPEI, Taiwan For Taiwan, 1965 was a year marked by strong industrial growth, solid agricultural advances and political calm.

Thomas Brockman, a pianist who made his debut here in 1950, returned to Town Hall late yesterday afternoon. He played Falla's Fantasia Betica, Haydn's Sonata in C, No. 50, Louise Talma's Passacaglia and Fugue and Schumann's Fantasy in C.

DEVENTER, The Netherlands, Jan. 23 (UPI) Ard Schenk, a 21-year-old Dutch Air Force man, won the European speed-skating championship today with a score of 180,040 points in the four events of the two-day meet.

KARACHI, Pakistan, Jan. 23 (Reuters) The sister of Pakistan's founder today condemned the Tashkent Declaration between Pakistan and India as a betrayal of everything achieved by the blood of Pakistan's soldiers.
VICTOR KORCHNOL one of the brightest Soviet chess stars, achieved an imposing record in the 1965 Asztales Memorial Tournament at Gyula, Hungary, scoring 14 to lead the 16-man field.
Last night's concert of George Gershwin music at Philharmonic Hall was, as such affairs go, refreshing.

VERA, Spain, Jan. 23 (AP) A burst of offshore activity stirred speculation today that searchers might have found in the Mediterranean an unarmed nuclear weapon that has been missing since last Monday when a United States B-52 bomber crashed nearby.

Directory of the Bates Manufacturing Company, Inc., and Martinall Industries, Inc., have approved in principle a plan for the combination of their business and operations, according to a joint statement issued over the weekend.
NEW DELHI A year of war, riots and political feuds has seirously disrupted Kashmir's economy.
Cardinal Spellman blessed and dedicated yesterday the new Pope Paul VI clergy residence on the grounds of the Frances Schervier Home, 2975 Independence Avenue, Riverdale, the Bronx.
Dr. Alice von Bauer Crow, former associate professor of education at Brooklyn College, died Saturday in her home, 633 East 19th Street, Brooklyn. She was 71 years old.
The Xerox Corporation registered a 47 per cent increase in earnings last year on a sales gain of nearly 40 per cent.

The Bankers Trust Company, New York, announced over the weekend the election as directors of Philip D. Reed, retired chairman of the General Electric Company, and Andrew W. Tarkington, president of the Continental Oil Company.

WOODMERE, L.I., Jan. 23 Miss Lorraine Gall Mennen, was married here this afternoon to George James Gutsche Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Gutsche of Waukesha, Wis. Judge Julius Chinman of the Nassau County District Court performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Joseph B. Mennen.

The city school system is planning a high school that will have three terms in each school year to make fuller use of buildings and to enable students to make more rapid progress. Dr. Bernard E. Donovan, Superintendent of Schools, revealed yesterday that school officials had been working on the plan with the State Education Department for several months.

A bill modifying the standards for bank mergers has been approved by the House Banking and Currency Committee after a heated and highly technical debate. It is of course a compromise, and like most compromises, especially those conceived in haste, it is a grab bag that offers something to everyone with an interest in the proposed legislation.
CHICAGO, Jan. 23 Chicago's Police Superintendent, Orlando W. Wilson, said today that there were serious flaws in American criminal justice that only the public could correct.
A dispute over the operation of Newark's antipoverty program appears to be on its way to settlement a settlement in which political representatives will have more decision-making power.
KARACHI The soaring optimism that surged through Pakistan's economy last year has been replaced by a grim determination to "make do."

HONG KONG There's a kwok in almost everyone's future here. The Kwok family large, gregarious and monolithic is better known to local residents as the Wing Ons, but whatever the name, it seems to mean success.
ENGLEWOOD, N.J., Jan. 23 Myron Pantzer, president and board chairman of the Ormont Drug and Chemical Company here, died of a heart attack in his home today. He was 48 years old.
The British tanker Chelwood Beacon ran aground early yesterday at the entrance to New York's Lower Bay and her captain reported the ship was in danger of breaking up in 15-to 25-foot waves.
MOSCOW, Jan. 23 Soviet sociologists are expressing growing concern about the billions of man-hours a year they say are wasted by the nation's citizens in shopping, errands and household chores.
"The Doctors," which starts its fourth year as one of daytime television's major medical programs in March, is losing its registered nurse.
BOSTON, Jan. 23 Miss Irene Survillo, daughter of the Right Rev. and Mrs. Eugene Survillo, was married this afternoon to Vilnis Snikeris, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jekabs Snikeris.
NORWALK, Conn., Jan. 23 Richard W. Sweeney Jr., managing editor of The Norwalk Hour since 1956, died yesterday at Norwalk Hospital at the age of 68.
SUKIRAN, Okinawa The long-range plan for the Ryukyus, designed to insure for these islands one of the highest economic growth rates in Asia, is being revised upward.
Sailors who find a haven at the Seamen's Church Institute, 25 South Street, may also view one of the most varied art collections ever displayed there.
PERTH, Australia This friendly, easygoing city of balmy, Mediterranean-like sunshine has quickened its pace in the last few years as a center of vast mineral, agricultural and industrial development.

Ronald Theodore Lyman Jr. of Boston and Henniker, N.H., and Mrs. Seymour L. Cromwell of 1 Gracie Terrace and Bridgehampton, L.I., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth Parker Lyman to Jack Edward Henderson Jr. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Henderson of Foxchapel, Pittsburgh.

Senator Robert F. Kennedy plans to confer this week with a leader of the United Federation of College Teachers, which is striking at St. John's University, and has said he would also like to talk with the university administration.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 President Johnson has set a formidable task for himself the unraveling of the tangled relationships among Federal, state and local governments and within the Federal structure itself.

It was a rather Churchillian figure that walked on to the stage of Town Hall carrying a guitar last night, and the nearcapacity audience welcomed Andres Segovia with an outpouring of enthusiasm, respect and affection that would have moved the late British statesman. It is no hyperbole, after all, to say that Segovia enjoys a comparable eminence in the world of music. He is held in a universally high regard that sometimes approaches reverence.

THERE was an almost capacity audience on Satur day night at the Kaufmann Hall of the 92d Street Young Men's and Young Women's Hebrew Association, where Bertram Ross and his dance company made the second of their appearances here this season.
AUCKLAND, New Zealand New Zealand is in for a severe economic crisis this year or she isn't. It depends on which prophets you believe.
LONDON, Jan. 23 Interparty support for British policy on Rhodesia was preserved today at a meeting of political leaders with Sir Hugh Beadle, Chief Justice of Rhodesia, at 10 Downing Street.
Miss Stephanie Heyman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Heyman of 1100 Park Avenue, was married yesterday evening to Jon Michael Reckler, son of Dr. and Mrs. Sidney M. Reckler of Denver.

NEW CITY, N.Y. Two highways and the scenic threemile Tappan Zee Bridge south of Nyack have changed the economic and social structure of Rockland County, the smallest in area in the state outside of those that make up New York City.
SYDNEY, Australia, Monday, Jan. 24 (Reuters) The Royal Australian Air Force today investigated reported flying-saucer sightings in North Queensland.
NEW DELHI, Jan. 24 Mrs. Indira Gandhi was sworn in today as India's Prime Minister. She succeeds Lal Bahadur Shastri, who died Jan. 11.

CAIRO, Jan. 24 The United States Ambassador, Lucius D. Battle, met briefly today with Hassan Zayyat, Under Secretary of the Foreign Ministry, at the Ambassador's request. Later Mr. Zayyat called in the North Vietnamese Ambassador, Nguyen Xuan, the Middle East News Agency reported.
Long-term Government bond prices, which declined slightly last week for the first time in three weeks, fell more sharply yesterday. A few dropped as much as 8/32.
PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 24 (AP) Linus R. Gilbert died Sunday in Princeton Hospital. He was 76 years old and lived on River Road, Princeton.

ORLANDO, Fla., Jan. 24 Since the late nineteen thirties, whenever sportsmen have talked of the most basic and important item of equipment common to all the knife one name has been accepted as the standard all others must meet. The name is Walter D. Randall Jr., the maker of the world-famous blades carrying the legend, "Randall Made."
Ken Boyer, the seven-time All-Star third baseman and the National League's most valuable player two years ago, signed his 1966 contract yesterday with the New York Mets.

Mrs. Lillian Schwartz Schwerer, wife of Paul Schwerer, died Sunday in Ann Arbor, Mich., of a heart attack. She was 56 years old and lived at 663 Rugby Road, Brooklyn. She was stricken while visiting her daughter, Mrs. Glenda Zahner.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (AP) Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara said today there was no evidence that a squadron of Chinese Communist MIG's had moved into North Vietnam.
JACKSON, Miss., Jan. 24 (UPI) The State Supreme court overturned today the grand larceny conviction of a Negro on the ground that no Negroes were on the grand jury or trial jury.

ROME, Jan. 24 West Germany, Belgium and the Netherlands gave clear indications today that they were unready to yield to French demands for curbing the supranational economic integration powers of the European Common Market.
LONDON, Jan. 24 The Government will shortly publish its plans for a state industrial finance agency modeled after Italy's sprawling Institute for Industrial Reconstruction.
Buildings Commissioner Charles G. Moerdler agreed yesterday to restore and expand the city's cyclical slum inspection program he curtailed last week.

BANGKOK, Thailand, Jan. 24 Thanat Khoman, Thailand's Foreign Minister, today sharply criticized the report of Senator Mike Mansfield's study mission, which toured Southeast Asia in November and December.

WHITE PLAINS, Jan. 24 In a ruling that could affect school systems throughout New York, a State Supreme Court justice has widened a public school district's obligation to provide transportation to a resident who attends a Roman Catholic school outside the district.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 "Hi, vital young voters of America. Buckle your chin straps, pull up a crunchy bowl of roasty-peppies and settle back for another exciting installment of 'Live End Kids.'

Stirrings have begun among West Side Democrats for what may be the Reform movement's big effort this year the third attempt to unseat Representative Leonard Farbstein in the 19th Congressional District.

The French have an unhappy knack for getting involved in sensational scandals. The Ben Barka case may yet take its place with the great and historic French scandals of the past John Law, Panama, Dreyfus, Stavisky. No two were alike; all of them involved Government officials, the army, the police and corruption.

Rosalie McChesney, a former senior assistant librarian in the New York Public Library at Fifth Avenue and 42d Street, died last Friday at Lenox Hill Hospital. She was 73 years old, and lived at 11 Riverside Drive.

TOKYO, Tuesday, Jan. 25 Premier Eisaku Sato urged today that an international conference be held on Vietnam. He also said he would send a special ambassador to various countries in a peace making effort.

EAST HARWICH, Mass., Jan. 24 Mr. and Mrs. J. Allen Hopper have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Patricia Hopper, to Ronald Barry Strasberg, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Strasberg of Westbury, L.I. A spring wedding is planned.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 The Supreme Court took the following actions today:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 Robert G. Baker, former secretary of the Senate Democratic majority, pleaded not guilty today to charges of tax evasion, theft, fraud and conspiracy. His trial was set for Oct. 17.

Frank Wille, the 34-year-old New York State Superintendent of Banks, announced yesterday his support of an 11-point program to aid commercial banks in New York plus a single proposal that has been sought by the state's savings banks and savings and loan associations.

W.W. Norton Company, book publishing concern, will pay a bonus to its authors because the concern had the largest sales in its history last year. The writers will receive 5 per cent extra on semiannual statements, which are mailed in February.
Vice President Humphrey charged yesterday that the Communists had tried to undermine United States credibility in the peace offensive for Vietnam.
TEL AVIV, Jan. 24 Arab marauders struck across the Israeli border last night, ending a peaceful interlude of nearly three months.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 President Johnson sent to Congress today his $112.8-billion budget for the fiscal year 1967 a budget that will add moderate further stimulus to an already booming economy.
Robert E. Reardon, former editor of The Villager, Greenwich Village publication, died yesterday in Bellevue Hospital of internal bleeding. He was 43 years old.

The Burroughs Corporation, manufacturers of computers and other business machines, has leased the ground floor and part of the basement in the 27-story office building recently completed by Samuel Rudin at 110 Wall Street, northeast corner of Front Street. The total area consists of 12,000 square feet.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 Attorney General Nicholas deB. Katzenbach said today that the transfer of the Community Relations Service to the Justice Department would give the department an affirmative means of achieving racial justice and an entree into Northern racial problems.

EXCEPT for a slight change in title, "The Shop on Main Street" (formerly High Street) which set up for eminently merited business at the 34th Street East yesterday, is the same stunning Czechoslovak picture that knocked us out of our chairs when it was unassumingly presented at the New York Film Festival last fall.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 24 Nicholas S. Ludington of Gladwyne, a founder of the former Ludington Airlines and a special assistant to the late James V. Forrestal, Secretary of Defense, died Saturday at his winter home in Key West, Fla. He was 61 years old.

LONDON, Jan. 24 (Reuters) Four of Shakespeare's bestknown plays and a "surprise" non-Shakespearean play will make up this year's program for the Royal Shakespeare Company's season at Stratford-onAvon, it was announced today by Peter Hall, director of the troupe.
HONG KONG, Jan. 24 (AP) Chinese border-crossers reported today that Communist China had declared its five coastal provinces military zones and put the area under partial military control.

Robert Glasser, the chairman of the New York State Harness Racing Commission, said yesterday that his board would insist on health certificates for all horses entering this state to compete at raceways. The order came in the wake of disclosures of the outbreak of swamp fever at a barn at the Bowie thoroughbred racing track in Maryland.

Mrs. Helen Bailey Graves Ballantine, widow of Arthur A. Ballantine, Under Secretary of the Treasury in the Hoover and Roosevelt Administrations, died yesterday in St. Luke's Hospital. She was 84 years old and lived at 435 East 52d Street.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (UPI) Two proposals designed to subject the Central Intelligence Agency to closer Congressional scrutiny were offered today in the Senate.

PARIS, Jan. 24 A Gaullist Deputy and close friend of Interior Minister Roger Frey was accused today by the weekly magazine L'Express of having been personally involved in the abduction here of Mehdi Ben Barka, an exiled Moroccan Opposition leader.
LONDON, Jan. 24 Prime Minister Wilson is expected to announce a reformulation of Britain's policy toward Rhodesia when Parliament reconvenes tomorrow after the Christmas recess.
The burgeoning State University of New York, whch dates only from 1948, is preparing for a major role in the educational aspects of international affairs.
LEXINGTON, Ky., Jan. 24 (AP) Louisiana State was hot tonight, but Kentucky was hotter and the second-ranked Wildcats downed the Tigers, 111-85, in a Southeastern Conference basketball game.
Prices turned firm yesterday on the London Stock Exchange in moderately active trading. Copper and steel issues supplied most of the strength.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 A foreign-aid estimate of $3,386 billion for the new fiscal year was submitted to Congress today in the President's Budget Message. He asked that a continuing program of economic and military aid be authorized in advance for each of the next five years.
The Baldwin-Montrose Chemical Company, Inc., has won an important round in the battle over a conflict-of-interest charge brought by the Paramount Pictures Corporation.
MODERN-DAY pirates open a new season this week. The treasure they seek: A share of the intensely competitive and highly lucrative American women's apparel market.
One of Malcolm X's halfdozen armed guards testified yesterday that he had ducked for cover as Malcolm was being slain by shotgun and pistol fire in the Audubon Ballroom last Feb. 21.

RECENT administrative reorganization by the Amer ican Contract Bridge League may increase the number of Regional Championships available to New York players, and therefore their chances of winning the red points needed for Life Master status.

Mrs. Beatrice Cohen Ullman, a member of the board of directors of the Westchester Federation of Jewish Charities, was killed Sunday night in a head-on automobile collision near Savannah, Ga. She was 63 years old and lived at 139 East 63d Street.

Dr. Homi Jehangir Bhabha, who was killed yesterday in a plane crash on Mont Blanc, was India's foremost atomic scientist and the dominant figure in that Country's plans to harness the atom. He was 56 years old.
The Israel Bond Organization reported last night that a record $91,392,800 in Israel bonds was sold last year.
NEWPORT, R.I., Jan. 24 John Barry Ryan, a grandson of the financier Thomas Fortune Ryan, died today at his home, Moorland Farm. He was 65 years old.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Jan. 24 President Humberto Castelo Branco set up a security investigation today of foreign financial influence in mass communications in Brazil.

PARIS, Jan. 24 The most unlikely place in the world to hear Herb Alpert's Tijuana Brass is in the salon of a French haute couture house, which is usually a hushed, all-gray room that bristles with gladioli.

SAIGON, Jan. 24 The apparent determination of Asian countries allied with the United States not to be officially associated with the American effort in Vietnam is one of the striking characteristics of the war.
The New York committee of the Frontier Nursing Service will hold a tea Feb. 7 at the Cosmopolitan Club, 129 East 65th Street.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 Shortly before he became chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee in 1959, Senator James William Fulbright made a speech setting forth his ideas on the proper role of the Senate in the formulation of foreign policy.

Bruno Sammartino of Abruzzi, Italy, retained his wrestling championship and gold belt last night by defeating Baron Michele Scicluma of Malta before 12,345 at Madison Square Garden. The Maltese Baron was disqualified for deliberately throwing Sammartino on Danny Bartfield, the referee.

The Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company continued its record-breaking performance in 1965, registering net income of more than $116million and worldwide sales of $1,000,200,000, highest in its 63year history.

Special to The New York Times UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 24 The Secretary General, U. Thant, said in a message of condolences today that Dr. Homi J. Bhabba, the Indian atomic physicist killed in an air crash today, had given brilliant inspiration to the United Nations.

MIAMI, Jan. 24 (AP) Circuit Judge George Schuiz, losing his patience after more than five days of questioning of prospective jurors for the Mossler murder trial, threatened today to take over the examinations himself.

DETROIT, Jan. 24 Secretary of Commerce John T. Connor said today that responsible leadership in the automobile industry would bring less public pressure on the Government to solve various highway problems.

THIS novel is probably the best of James T. Farrell's farewells to the fecund, fiery midlands of America. His cinderblock style does all that he asks of it. The everlooming portal to New York is complete.
SAIGON, Tuesday, Jan. 25 A United States Air Force C-123 transport plane carrying 47 American servicemen crashed and burned in the Central Highlands of South Vietnam today, killing all aboard.

FORT WORTH, Tex., Jan. 24 A $1,250,000 theater, the latest addition to Fort Worth's projected "square mile of culture," opened here tonight. The city's civic and social leaders imported show business personalities to help them celebrate the event.

Thomas Caldecot Chubb, the author, and Mrs. Chubb of Greenwich, Conn., and Springwood Plantation in Thomasville, Ga., have announced the marriage on Saturday of their daughter, Miss Rosamond Caldecot Chubb, to Hillyer McDowell Young, son of Mr. and Mrs. John M. Young of 10 Gracie Square and Bedford, N.Y.

Clinical laboratories in this city are going "from terrible to bad" in performance, the Health Department reported yesterday. In an effort to speed improvement, the department will give on-the-spot consultations and week-long training courses to laboratory technicians beginning next fall.
PATERSON, N.J., Jan. 24 (AP) Magistrate Charles J. Alfano ruled today that the master of the house has the right to turn off his television set.

MOSCOW, Jan. 24 An autopsy disclosed today that Newcomb Mott, the 27-year-old American said to have committed suicide last week while in Soviet custody, had "multiple lacerations" on his body in addition to a deep cut across the throat that was the apparent cause of death.
Three commodity groups have announced elections of presidents.

JACKSON, Miss., Jan. 24 (AP) Mississippi's State Sovereignty Commission seems doomed 10 years after it was formed to fight for segregation.
TRENTON, Jan. 24 The Republican minority leaders in the Senate and Assembly announced their opposition today to the graduated state income tax proposed by Gov. Richard J. Hughes.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (UPI) The Supreme Court refused today to examine a complaint that about 4,000 defendants arrested last year in the Watts riots in Los Angeles are not getting necessary legal help.

TRENTON, Jan. 24 The State Supreme Court upheld today the right of Black Muslims to refuse to pledge allegiance to the American Flag.
