BIG things are happening with little furniture. The Lilliputian look in furnishings long favored by fashionable interior decorator's and antiques collectors has reached mass proportions.

Puccini's "La Boheme" has been a particular delight at the Metropolitan Opera this season. Last night it seemed brighter than ever, and the difference was Richard Tucker, making his first appearance of the season as Rodolfo.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 The United States Patent Office is preparing to modernize the distribution system for its vast stores of technological data.

SAIGON, Tuesday, Jan. 25 The Vietcong staged a mortar attack on the big United States and South Vietnamese air base at Danang early today, killing two Americans and two Vietnamese Government soldiers.
BANBURY, England, Jan. 24 (Reuters) Banbury Cross, mentioned in the nursery rhyme, will stay where it is, the town council decided tonight.

CHAMONIX, France, Jan. 24 An Air India Boeing 707 jetliner crashed into a ridge today near the three-mile-high summit of Mont Blanc. killing all 117 persons aboard. With 45 feet more of altitude the plane would have cleared the ridge.

The Fifth Avenue Coach Lines got some respite yesterday in State Supreme Court as Justice Harry B. Frank reserved decision on the company's move to prevent delisting of its shares by the New York Stock Exchange. Trading has been halted in the issue since Jan. 17, but actual delisting can take place only with the approval of the Securities and Exchange Commission.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 The foreseeable costs of the war in Vietnam were listed as $10.3billion, nearly one-fifth of the total defense outlay of $58.3billion, in the budget President Johnson submitted to Congress today for the fiscal year 1967, beginning July 1.
BONN, Jan. 24 (AP) A spokesman for Chancellor Ludwig Erhard said today that West Germany would refrain from sending military aid of any kind to Vietnam.

PUERTO PLATA, Dominican Republic, Jan. 24 A United States-built concrete highway runs 100 miles from Santo Domingo northwestward to Santiago de los Caballeros, past cane fields and towering mountains whose foothills are enlivened by graceful trees with orange-red flowers.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (UPI) The Justice Department asked for contempt of court action today against school authorities in Concordia Parish of Louisiana for their alleged failure to integrate schools under a Federal Court order.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (AP) Peru accused the Soviet Union today of violating the principle of nonintervention by pledging to support subversive movements against Peru and other Latin-American nations.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (AP) A Federal judge issued a temporary restraining order today halting any threat of a strike by the Brotherhood of Railroad Trainmen pending a hearing next Monday.
PASADENA, Calif., Jan. 24 Lawrence Swift, a partner in Foster Adams, 120 Broadway, New York, members of the New York and American Stock Exchanges, died here yesterday in his home at the age of 82.
BOSTON, Jan. 24 (AP) The 9,500-ton freighter South African Victory sent an S.O.S. today reporting her cargo had shifted and she was in danger in stormy seas 20 miles northeast of Provincetown.

The major work in the American Symphony Orchestra program at Carnegie Hall last night was Tchaikovsky's "Pathetique" Symphony, but the most interesting music was to be found in Webern's Six Pieces for Orchestra. Conductor Leopold Stokowski had sandwiched these between an Overture in G minor by Telemann and the Dance of Seven Veils from Strauss's "Salome."

BUCHAREST, Rumania, Jan. 24 The Communist Government brought to a climax today a countrywide celebration of the 107th anniversary of the union of Moldavia and Walachia, two principalities that form the basis of modern Rumania.
ALBANY, Jan. 24 The Democratic proposal to authorize a state lottery was assured of approval by the Legislature today.
SELMA, Ala., Jan. 24 (UPI) William Baker, Selma Public Safety Director, said tonight he would run for Sheriff of Dallas County against the incumbent, James G. Clark Jr., a stanch segregationist.

THE quest for an authentic, palatable Viennese dinner for the 800 guests expected to attend the 11th annual Viennese Opera Ball on Feb. 4 bogged down for a few hours yesterday as committee members ate, drank and debated their way through food samples from which they hoped to select the perfect Austrian menu.
COLOGNE, Germany, Jan. 24 The stars and stripes with matching accessories will fly for the first time at the International Furniture Fair opening here tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether the strike-bound Florida East Coast Railway might deviate from its collective bargaining contract in the course of its battle with the unions.
The budget request for the operation of the Maritime Administration in the 1967 fiscal year that was submitted to Congress by President Johnson yesterday is the lowest in seven years.
CHICAGO, Jan. 24 The Chicago Board of Trade raised today initial and maintenance margin requirements on its five major grain commodities.
CHICAGO, Jan. 24 Final arguments in the marathon Krebiozen trial ended today with a Government charge that the defendants had perpetrated "one of the biggest swindles in history."
A new policy has been adopted by the Stratford (Ont.) Shakespearean Festival. It will do two productions at the Manitoba Theater Centre in Winnipeg before its regular season begins.
CENTRAL ISLIP, L.I., Jan. 24 Two Suffolk County patrolmen fought a gun battle with a New York City policeman here last night as they attempted to arrest him for allegedly beating his wife.
Miss Amy Gail Granowitz and Howard Rosenbloom plan to marry here May 8.
Miss Eileen Marie Devine plans to be married April 16 to John Gregory Huarte, winner of the Heisman Memorial Trophy as the outstanding college football player in 1964.
LAKEWOOD, N.J., Jan. 24 The head of the Rabbinical Council of America appealed to religious leaders of the major faiths today to support the Administration's quest for peace in Vietnam.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Jan. 24 Gov. William W. Scranton proposed to the State Legislature today increased outlays for education and mental health, but he promised this would not require new taxation as he proposed a record $1.4-billion budget.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 24. New York State stands both to profit and lose under the new budget that President Johnson submitted to Congress today.
ROCHESTER, Minn., Jan. 24 (UPI) Mickey Mantle entered St. Mary's Hospital tonight for surgery on his injured right shoulder.
ALBANY, Jan. 24 Prodded by Governor Rockefeller, Motor Vehicle Commissioner William S. Hults today gave New York motorists 15 more days to obtain their 1966 passenger car license plates.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 Strong opposition to a resumption of the bombing of North Vietnam was registered by leading Senators today as President Johnson continued to weigh in silence his next moves in the Southeast Asian war.
MUNCIE, Ind., Jan. 24 (UPI) Oscar Robertson led the way with 29 points tonight as the Cincinnati Royals trounced the San Francisco Warriors, 135-112, in a National Basketball Association game.
BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Jan. 24 Federal voting examiners sent by Attorney General Nicholas deB. Katzenbach registered more than 1,100 persons, most of them Negroes, on their first day in Birmingham today.
Prince Philip of Britain will make an 11-day tour of the United States, beginning in Miami on March 8, an aide to the Prince announced here yesterday.
New Yorkers with ideas for city laws can send them to a new "Citizens Suggestion Box on Legislation," City Council President Frank D. O'Connor announced yesterday.

Mayor Lindsay said yesterday that his campaign pledge to cut $300-million to $400-million from the city's operating costs could not be construed in terms of dollar savings alone. He said a substantial part of the savings would be "in terms of increased productivity without any reduction in essential city services."
What can I do about Harlem?" This was the headline of a small ad that a rather small savings and loan association ran in this paper for two days early this month.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 The Senate plunged half-heartedly today into what Senator Everett McKinley Dirksen described as "the second battle of 14(b)."
NEW HAVEN, Jan. 24 (AP) John Rothchild, managing editor of the Yale Daily News, today challenged Linda McVeigh, the first female managing editor of The Harvard Crimson, to a game of jacks.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24. For the first time in its history, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration has been allocated a budget appropriation that represents a decrease from that of the previous year.

Both banks of the Hudson along the eighteen-mile stretch between the George Washington Bridge and the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge are undergoing great changes. Projects costing $1.5-billion are under way or in preparation; within a decade they will radically transform both sides of the majestic river. They point up the urgency of coordinated planning to protect a magnificent natural resource.

TOKYO, Tuesday, Jan. 25 Crews affiliated with the AllJapan Seamen's Union began a 15-day work stoppage at midnight, affecting approximately 1,240 ships. The strike followed the failure of Government efforts to find a settlement to the long wage dispute. About 50,000 crewmen responded to the strike call.
The Columbia University Graduate School of Journalism has raised $2.95-million of its $3.8-million Half-Century Fund campaign, Elliott V. Bell, chairman of the fund committee, announced yesterday.

Fifty-two men scrambled down rope ladders from the stricken tanker Chelwood Beacon early yesterday and late Sunday and leaped to rescue craft below. They were plucked to safety by men on two small vessels that heaved in the storm-churned Atlantic.
Genesco, Inc., an apparel and footwear manufacturer and retailer, announced here yesterday the election of H. W. Brawley as vice president for national and international relations.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 The Treasury bill rate fell back sharply at today's auction following last week's steep increase, the Treasury disclosed tonight.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 In the Supreme Court of the United States today, the following proceedings were had:
WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 Increased taxes on airline passenger tickets, higher fees for parcel post and a large new tax on heavy trucks were proposed by President Johnson today in his Budget Message.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (AP) A hearing examiner has ruled that school boards in six Louisiana Parishes (Counties) are not eligible for any Federal financial assistance because they have not complied with the antidiscrimination provisions of the Civil Rights Act of 1964.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 Mr. and Mrs. Gerald C. Gross have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Laura Helen Gross, to Francis John Wilcox, son of Mr. and Mrs. Stuart Wilcox of East Coker, Somerset, England.
CAMDEN, Ala., Jan. 24 Ninety-five Negro demonstrators marched to the Wilcox County Courthouse today to protest the slaying of a Negro carpenter.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today that it was lifting the ban on trading of two stocks, Noramco and Bristol Dynamics.
The Shasta Joint Junior College District, situated in northcentral California 160 miles from Sacramento, sold $4-million of bonds yesterday to a syndicate led by the Bank of America.
Deputy Mayor Robert Price met yesterday with officials of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association in an effort to resolve complaints that he had made undue demands on the police force.
MILAN, Italy, Jan. 24 (UPI) An Italian Marchese who was allegedly shot by his wife, an American socialite, died today.

MINNEAPOLIS, Jan. 24 (UPI) Tony Oliva of the Minnesota Twins, the American League's leading hitter the last two years, was sued for $81,000 today by a woman who allegedly was injured when he flung a bat into the stands.
ALBANY, Jan. 24 An electric voting system will be installed in the Assembly, Speaker Anthony J. Travia said today.

Henry C. Roberts, who for many years operated a bookstore at 380 Canal Street, near the corner of West Broadway, died yesterday at the Veterans Administration Hospital in Brooklyn. He was 76 years old and lived at 2996 Bedford Avenue, Brooklyn.
MALVERNE, L.I., Jan 24 The State Education Commissioner, James E. Allen Jr., postponed today the effective date of his order to integrate the elementary schools here.
HONIARA, Solomon Islands, Jan. 12 In any listing of backward territories, the British Solomon Islands Protectorate would have to be given a prominent place.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 In two recent court orders, American judges have implicitly contributed to weakening the most fundamental bases of the judicial system. These are respect for and compliance with its decrees, and the impeachment process prescribed for Federal judges in the Constitution.
The stock market advanced yesterday in brisk trading.
Boys and girls who are seventh graders in private schools will dance with one another Friday at Delmonico's at the Goddard Gaieties. The theme of the evening will be carnival time.
Governor Rockefeller said yesterday that New York and Connecticut were preparing to take over commuter service on the New Haven Railroad.
A manned round trip to Mars can be reduced by more than a year's time if the spacecraft goes or returns by way of Venus, two space agency scientists reported yesterday.

Announcement has been made here of the engagement of Miss Nicole Jeanne Marie Bernadette Challamel, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph-Francois Challamel of Paris, to Robert Treat Buck Jr., son of Mrs. Buck of Fall River, Mass., and the late Mr. Buck. A July 2 wedding in Paris is planned.

Dr. Lyndon O. Brown, an advertising executive and marketing research expert and former president of Knox College, died Sunday in Lawrence Hospital Bronxville, N.Y., after a long illness. He was 63 years old and lived in Bronxville.
PORTLAND, Me., Jan. 24 Carl Ruggles's "Sun-Treader" has finally come home.
Parks Commissioner Thomas P.F. Hoving said yesterday he was "pretty damned upset" about Columbia University's plans for a gymnasium in Morningside Park.

CAPETOWN, Jan. 24 When Helen Suzman, the only member of the South African Parliament who stands for multiracial government, enters the lobby these days, there is usually a colleague there who says: "Hello, Helen, Won't be seeing you here much longer."
The British pound closed unchanged from its Friday rate of $2.8043 in moderate trading on foreign-exchange markets here yesterday.

The American Broadcasting Company will add two more British productions to its weekly television program schedule beginning in the spring. "The Baron," a British show about a secret agent, made its debut on A.B.C. last week.

The Florida East Coast Railway restored passenger service on its lines on Aug. 2 last year under orders from the Florida Public Service Commission. In its report at Sept. 30 to the Interstate Commerce Commission the railroad said that its passenger revenues for the two months, Aug. 2 to Sept. 30, amounted to $3,000.

The Storer Broadcasting Company announced yesterday that it was offering to holders of its common stock and class B common stock, rights to subscribe to $34.41-million of 4 per cent 20-year convertible debentures.
E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., the nation's largest chemical producer, turned in the highest operating earnings in its 163-year history in 1965. The profit from operations amounted to $407.
GENEVA, Jan. 24 The World Health Organization's executive board has approved at its current session a 10-year program for the eradication of smallpox throughout the world.
The Bank of Commerce, New York, announced yesterday the election of William G. Sly as a vice president. He was formerly an assistant vice president of the Franklin National bank.

ATLANTA, Jan. 24 (UPI) Lawyers for Julian Bond were told today to prove that race had figured in the expulsion of Mr. Bond, a Negro, from the Georgia House of Representatives or remove that issue from their Federal case.

Mr. and Mrs. Franz Schager of 1088 Park Avenue and Oyster Bay, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Waring Schager, to George Peter Giard Jr. His parents are Mr. and Mrs. Giard of Dallas.
Billy Kidd, the Olympic skier, said yesterday the ankle injury suffered Sunday in Austria was "not very serious" and he hoped to return to competition in about two weeks.
ROCHESTER, Jan. 24 Dr. Henry C. Yutzy, vice president of the Eastman Kodak Company, died today of a heart attack at the age of 55.
LONDON, Jan. 24 Enterprising Britons can now make money melting down their jumbosized pennies for the copper content.
Members of the United States National Student Association plan to join picket lines Friday of teachers who are on strike at St. John's University.

SYDNEY, Australia, Jan. 24 (AP) Two American teams advanced to the men's doubles quarter-finals of the Australian tennis championships today but the pick-up team of Arthur Ashe and George MacCall was defeated.
A steadiness marked by caution prevailed in the grain markets yesterday.
Bob Barker, ranked No. 8 in the East, heads the draw for the Metropolitan indoor claycourt tournament opening Friday night at the new Midtown Tennis Club, Eighth Avenue and 27th Street.
BLADON, England, Jan. 24 (Reuters) Three wreaths lay on the white marble gravestone of Sir Winston Churchill in the village churchyard here today, the first anniversary of his death.
The National Steel Corporation rode the wave of heavy steel demand last year into the billion-dollar club, reporting sales above that level for the first time in its history.
BIRMINGHAM, Ala, Jan. 24 (UPI) A drunken driving charge against Hosea Williams, a top aide to the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., was dismissed tonight in Traffic Court.
Steel production in the United States continued to climb last week, rising 1.4 per cent to the highest weekly level since last August, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

If there is a piano piece wilder, more foolish and more fun to listen to than the "Hexameron" that Liszt and five other composers wrote, this reviewer has not heard it. Raymond Lewenthal played it at Town Hall last night in the last of his three programs this season devoted to Liszt's piano music, and it made quite a show.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 24. Laughlin E. Waters, a middle-ofthe-road Republican, withdrew today from the California governorship race and threw his support to George Christopher, former Mayor of San Francisco.

The Newspaper Guild of New York filed unfair labor practice charges yesterday with the National Labor Relations Board against The New York Herald Tribune, The New York Journal-American and The New York World-Telegram and The Sun.
MOSCOW, Jan. 24 (AP) President Johnson's budget "has all the earmarks of a war budget," Tass said tonight.
Traffic Commissioner Henry A. Barnes proposed yesterday that the city build a $6.5-million garage in Queens to help alleviate traffic congestion in Manhattan.

RUTGERS UNIVERSITY, the recipient of a $3-million grant for football scholarships, will be able to improve its entire scholarship program as a result of the generosity of the late Thomas Turner Barr, Rutgers class of 1913.
Floyd McKissick, newly elected director of the Congress of Racial Equality, criticized churchmen last night for not taking a bigger role in the civil rights movement.
NEWARK, Jan. 24 Mrs. Vera Brantley McMillon, project manager for the $3-million job training program for welfare recipients in this area, has been dismissed from her position, it was disclosed today.
The ever-upward path of new car sales in the United States has taken a turn downward.
The American Stock Exchange did a complete turnabout yesterday after four consecutive setbacks. It advanced along a broad front on active trading.
Emergency sanitation crews and a bright sun helped the city clean up quickly yesterday after its first major snowfall of the winter.

KARACHI, Pakistan, Jan. 24 Governmental uncertainty over whether the moon could be seen anywhere in Pakistan Saturday night upset the celebration of Eid-ul-Fitr, normally the year's most joyous holiday in this most-populous Moslem nation.

MIDHURST, England, Jan. 24 (Reuters) Kenneth Macfarlane Walker, a surgeon in London and author of the best-selling "The Physiology of Sex," died at his home here during the weekend. He was 83 years old.

FARGO, N.D., Jan. 24 (AP) Maj. Frank L. Anders, believed to be the oldest holder of the Medal of Honor, died here last night at the age of 90. Major Anders was awarded the nation's highest military honor for gallantry during the Phillippine Insurrection in 1899.

THE emerging nations of Africa have emerged so fast that one batch of athletes at the 1964 Olympics in Tokyo carried the flag of Northern Rhodesia in the opening-day parade and marched out during the closing ceremonies bearing the banner of newly created Zambia. The Olympic impact of performers from Africa has been slight to date, but the reservoir of raw talent is so enormous that the flow will reach flood tide in the future.
OTTAWA, Jan. 24 A parliamentary challenge by Conservatives to the Government of Prime Minister Lester B. Pearson that had been scheduled for today has been postponed until tomorrow night.

BOWIE, Md., Jan. 24 Results of blood tests taken of 19 of 38 quarantined horses at the Bowie race track have turned up two suspected cases of swamp fever, a track spokesman said tonight. A report on the other 19 horses had not been received.
TEL AVIV, Jan. 24 Foreign Minister Abba Eban called today for Tashkent-type negotiations between Israel and the Arab powers either directly or with the help of a major power.

A powerful group of chemical manufacturers said yesterday it would help the Government to determine whether the system of setting duties on certain chemical imports should be subject to negotiations at the long-stalled Kennedy round of tariff negotiations.

Serious dissatisfaction with the relationship between the chancellor of the City University and the presidents of the municipal colleges has been voiced by Dr. Buell G. Gallagher, president of City College.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 The Supreme Court agreed today to a speedy hearing on whether New York may enforce an English literacy test to deny the vote to citizens who are literate only in Spanish.
The city plans to let a lease on Friday that will permit the development of a 63-acre marina, shopping area and recreation center in Mill Basin, Brooklyn.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 24 Miss Ellen Paul, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James W. Paul of Glen Head, L.I., and Delray Beach, Fla., was married today to Thomas Lejeune Johnson. He is the son of Mrs. Thomas B. Crumpler of New Orleans and Dr. Pearce Sherwood Johnson of Birmingham, Ala.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., Jan. 24 The union that bargains for New York City's public school teachers today offered to buy a 40-room castle overlooking Huntington Harbor for a rural retreat "for the average teacher."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (AP) Prof. Staughton Lynd of Yale said tonight that he was in telephone contact with the Communist-led National Liberation Front of South Vietnam only three days ago and that President Johnson could do the same if he wished.

Mayor Lindsay and his aides are learning the hard way how easy it is to get into publicity trouble. One trivial tempest has arisen over use of policemen and police cars at City Hall. Someone, apparently misusing the name of Deputy Mayor Robert Price, sent a policeman out for sandwiches and coffee. Mr. Price acknowledges using a police car on three occasions to transport him to various places.

A FITTING ending to a winter menu would be a raspberry-topped cheese pie that is not too heavy and yet satisfies a craving for a "real dessert." A few fresh berries decorating the top makes the pie colorful enough for a celebration.
International Flavors and Fragrances, Inc., announced here yesterday the election of Leroy Frantz Jr. as vice president for operations.
MANILA, Jan. 24 President Ferdinand Marcos said today that the Philippines had a "vital stake in the survival of South Vietnam" and promised continued assistance to the best of our ability."

Schacht Steel Construction, Inc., announced yesterday that Judah Gribetz, Commissioner of Buildings in the Wagner Administration, has joined the company as president. Mr. Gribetz succeeds Lawrence Schacht, head of the company since 1933, who has been elected chairman of the board and chief executive officer. The latter post is a new one in the company.
A group of 25 unemployed Negroes locked arms and formed a human chain across a major Harlem intersection yesterday in a protest demonstration for more jobs.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (AP) The Selective Service System said today that it had instructed local draft boards that young men under orders for induction no longer should be permitted to enlist in the National Guard or Reserves.

Sent his budget to Congress; met with Gen. Maxwell D. Taylor, a White House consultant and former U.S. Ambassador to Saigon; met with Agriculture Secretary Freeman; met with Postmaster General O'Brien; announced several nominations.

PARIS, Jan. 24 "I needed a giraffe," said Pierre Cardin after he hired his newest mannequin. The giraffe is a 5-foot-7 brunette from Turin, Italy, whose name is Ornella Benedetto. Cardin has always been partial to smallboned short girls like his Japanese model Hiroko, so Ornella's height created a stir.

Only two young musicians could have accomplished it, and two young musicians did. Paul Zukofsky, with the partnership of Gilbert Kalish at the piano, played all four of Charles Ives's Violin Sonatas last night in Carnegie Recital Hall. When it was all over, the two boys and the audience had had a thorough workout. But it was a stimulating and exciting evening.
The basic prices of chromium chemicals, used in a variety of products but most familiar as trim on automobiles, are going up in most categories. This is the first general advance since 1956.
About 57,000 persons who said they were put out of work by the recent 12-day transit strike have filed for unemployment insurance benefits, the State Department of Labor said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 Government spending on President Johnson's program to create the Great Society will rise by more than $3-billion next year, with almost every single element of the program included.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (UPI) The Justice Department filed a suit today to desegregate the municipal swimming pools of Laurel, Miss.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (AP) Representative Charles E. Bennett protested today, the scheduled burial of Robert G. Thompson, a convicted Communist leader, in Arlington National Cemetery.
TRENTON, Jan. 24 The State Supreme Court ruled today that the state could not ask the death penalty in the retrial of a convicted murderer originally sentenced to life imprisonment.

Mr. and Mrs. William Roger Salomon of New York and East Quogue, L. I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Susan Foster Salomon, to Charles Anthony Seiniger. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles W. Seiniger of New York and Westhampton, L.I.

The eight investigators of the Security Bureau, Inc., organized 20 years ago to suppress theft and pilferage in the port, recovered $575,000 in stolen cargoes last year, Jones F. Devlin, president of the group, said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 Mrs. Emalea Warner Steel, daughter of Mrs. Irving Warner of Wilmington, Del., and the late Mr. Warner, was married today at Christ Episcopal Church in Georgetown to Stephen Anthony Trentman of Dana Point, Calif.

The Pennsylvania Turnpike Commission sold yesterday $77.5-million of revenue bonds to finance improvements to the tunnels along the route through the Allegheny Mountains in south-central Pennsylvania.
THE women who seem to represent the conservative in fashion took a closer look yesterday at the girls in the sleeveless vinyl dresses with skirts four inches above the knee and plastic visors.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 (AP) Representative James J. Howard, Democrat of New Jersey, called today for adoption of a national highway safety program. He urged the creation of a national traffic safety center in the Commerce Department.
The spot rate on the British pound remained steady yesterday at its Monday quotation of $2.8043 in continued slow trading on foreign exchange markets here.
A cashmere coat was stolen last night from Lieut. Gov. Malcolm Wilson's official car, which was parked in front of Governor Rockefeller's office at 22 West 55th Street.
VILLANOVA, Pa., Jan. 25 (AP) Bill Melchionni scored 23 points tonight and led Villanova to an easy 94-66 victory over St. Peter's of Jersey City.
The Transit Authority said yesterday that conversion of Fifth and Madison Avenues to one-way traffic had made bus travel on these thoroughfares slower and had led to a 20 per cent decrease in riders.

The Realty Foundation of New York has named S. Dudley Nostrand as "The Real Estate Man of the Year," and he will be the foundation's guest of honor at its annual dinner on April 18 at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

YONKERS, Jan. 25 Thomas Alfred Ruppert, a 17-year-old high school pupil and Youth Corps worker here, was accused tonight of having started the fire in the Yonkers Jewish Community Center on Dec. 20 that killed nine children and three adults.

TRIPOLI, Libya, Jan. 21 Libya, often taken for granted as an acquiescent partner in the rough and tumble politics of the Arab world, is moving these days with quiet independence and new self-assurance.

Sunday evening's performance of Giordano's "Andrea Chenier," sponsored by the Metropolitan Opera Guild, will benefit the production fund of the Metropolitan Opera Association. Fausto Cleva will conduct the opera in its first performance here in three years. Heading the cast will be Renata Tebaldi, Franco Corelli and Tito Gobbi.

PARIS Although the aims and methods of France and its allies today seem incompatible, General de Gaulle will ultimately decide not to withdraw France from either NATO or the Common Market. This is the judgment of Dirk Stikker, the Dutch statesman who until last year was Secretary General of NATO. The judgment appears in Stikker's memoirs, to be published Monday by Harper Row.
UNION, N.J., Jan. 25 George A. Bond of 1170 Burnett Avenue, former head of the contract department of the Navy in Mountainside, died yesterday at his home. His age was 69.
LONDON, Jan. 25 (UPI) Jack Hawkins has undergone an operation for throat cancer and is "making remarkable progress," his wife said today.

ATLANTA, Jan. 25 Representatives of eight civil rights and human relations organizations attacked today the United States Office of Education's school desegregation program as "too weakly drawn and too timidly enforced."
PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Jan. 25 Miss Kathleen Ann Raby and John Gregory Bartels Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Bartels of St. Louis, plan to marry in June.

ROME, Jan. 25 The leader of Italy's Communist party called today for cooperation with left-wing Roman Catholics as an alternative to the CenterLeft Coalition that has ruled Italy for two years but is now in crisis.
Reynolds Co., members of the New York Stock Exchange, announced here yesterday the admission of A. James Bach as a general partner.
TEN days after its official publication, Truman Capote's account of a multiple murder in Kansas in 1959 seems on its way to making more money faster than any book in the history of publishing.

VENISON in the freezer is like money in the bank whether from a family hunter or a hunter friend. For best eating the frozen venison, in fact all frozen game, should be used in four months and can be thawed and cooked according to any recipe for frozen game.

AIMLESS ruffing by the declarer, reducing his trump length in the process, is a frequent type of misplay. It is true that there are some hands in which the best policy is to take all the ruffs that are available and leave the trump suit untouched until the end-game, but they are not very common and today's deal was not one of them.

The Houston Music Theater, which will cost about $3-million, will open its doors on May 17 with a bill not yet selected. Another Texas city, Fort Worth, dedicated its new 500-seat William Edrington Scott Theater, representing an expenditure of $1.25-million, on Monday night.

KAANAPALI, Hawaii, Jan. 25 (AP) A scientific adviser to President Johnson says the United States is the only nation in the scientific revolution and that Soviet Russia, Great Britain and West Germany had not yet entered it.

PARIS, Jan. 25 The French television network began an unrehearsed interview program last night in response to criticism that the Government dominates coverage of public issues to the virtual exclusion of dissent.
More than 1,000 women showed up at Hunter College last night for the 25th anniversary meeting of the Girl Scout Council of Greater New York.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 The Johnson Administration has decided to hold its controversial guideposts for wage-price increases which it uses as a major weapon to fight inflation at 3.2 per cent in 1966.

SYDNEY, Australia, Jan. 25 (UPI) Clark Graebner and Arthur Ashe reached the quarterfinals of the Australian national championship today, but two other Americans, Marty Riessen and Herb Fitz Gibbon were eliminated.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 President Johnson announced today that he had chosen Mrs. Constance Baker Motley, Manhattan Borough President, to fill a vacancy on the Federal District Court in New York City.

The British by-election tomorrow at Hull on the Yorkshire coast has become of national importance. In the 1964 general election, Labor's majority was only 1,181, with nearly 48,000 people voting. Theoretically, a swing of 600 votes away from Labor would bring victory to the Conservative candidate and reduce Prime Minister Wilson's majority in the House of Commons to one. Such a result could force Mr. Wilson into a general election before he wanted it.
Mrs. Selma Pfeiffer Edelman, wife of Selig Edelman, a retired New York lawyer, died Monday night at Mount Sinai Hospital. She was 80 years old and lived at 115 Central Park West.
LONDON, Jan. 25 The Common Market will continue with or without France, and the time is fast approaching for Britain to renew her application to join, in the view of diplomats concerned.
The New York Stock Exchange removed the cover from its crystal ball yesterday for a glimpse of what automation portends for the Big Board community.

Continuing Congressional distrust of the Central Intelligence Agency has been most recently reflected in the resolutions submitted by Senators McCarthy and Young. The former proposes a Senate investigation of the C.I.A.'s impact on United States foreign relations, while the latter advocates a SenateHouse "watchdog" committee on the C.I.A. analogous to the Joint Committee on Atomic Energy.

GABRIELS, N.Y., Jan. 25 Almerindo Portfolio, Treasurer of the City of New York during the administration of the late Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia, died here Sunday night after a long illness. He was 88 years old.
Soybean futures prices reached new seasonal highs yesterday in five out of six contracts, following news of a record December crush of the beans into oil and meal.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 Mrs. John V. Lindsay went to Washington today to attend a luncheon given by Mrs. Lyndon B. Johnson at the White House for 17 women of achievement.
The American Stock Exchange just managed to show a gain at the close yesterday as late profit taking reduced the number of advances.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 24 (AP) The Civil Rights Act of 1964 applies retroactively to cases involving the conviction of persons for violations of state statutes that violate the Federal legislation, a Federal Appeals Court has ruled.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Jan. 25 George L. van Moppes of 1448 Concord Place, formerly a member of L.N. van Moppes Co., Newark jewelers and diamond merchants for many years, died yesterday at his home of a heart attack. His age was 68 and he had retired in 1962.
More than $100-million of taxexempt bonds and $50-million of corporate bonds were placed on the market yesterday, and most of the new issues got off to slow starts.

THE general air of happiness in Carnegie Hall re sulted from a performance well sung, well rehearsed, well conducted. Boito's "Mefistofele" was the opera, and it had been absent from the local scene some 40 years. Too long; much too long. After all the second-rate early Italian operas so persistently revived during the last decade, it was a thrill to encounter a work of strength, imagination, personal melody and bigness of scope.
LONDON, Jan. 25 The Government announced today plans for its Industrial Reorganization to assist British industry become more competitive.
Until he was named head of the Bureau of Labor Statistics last fall, Arthur M. Ross was a professor of industrial relations at the University of California.

It was with the New York Philharmonic that Rudolf Serkin made his first public appearance in this country, on Feb. 20, 1926. Last night in Philharmonic Hall, the orchestra celebrated the 30th anniversary of that important event by presenting the great pianist as soloist in one of its gala Pension Fund Benefit Concerts.

A building loan of $3.9-million has been arranged by Ackman Brothers, mortgage brokers, on the 19-story office building being constructed at 110 Church Street. The loan was arranged with the Bowery Savings Bank for the building's owners, Dewey Carver and his son, Michael.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 (AP) A Senate subcommittee called today for an expenditure of $20billion over the next six years to control water pollution. The total would include $6-billion in Federal money.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 The British Government has decided to retain strong military forces indefinitely east of Aden and particularly in Southeast Asia, according to highly placed informants here.

CHAIMONIX, France, Jan. 25 (UPI) Officials have abandoned until spring their efforts to recover the bodies of 117 persons killed when a Boeing 707 jetliner of Air India crashed into Mont Blanc yesterday.

Almost every day, the economic impact of the upward spiral in interest rates that has followed the Dec. 6 increase in the Federal Reserve discount rate is assuming more meaning for the man in the street.
MIAMI, Jan. 25 (AP) Paul Falkenstein paid $100,000 tonight for a colt at the Hialeah sale of Florida-bred 2-year-olds in training. The price was a record for the sales.
Michael J. Quill, the blustery president of the Transport Workers Union, made his first public appearance yesterday after three weeks in the hospital.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 President Johnson gave members of Congress the impression tonight that he was moving toward a decision to renew the bombing of North Vietnam and to increase American troop strength in South Vietnam.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 Opponents of the Administration's union shop proposal may seek to amend the Senate's morning prayer tomorrow in a new effort to block consideration of the controversial measure.

"THIS place is still in transition," Mrs. Gower Champion says of the 10th and 11th floor 14-room duplex in the East 70's that she, her husband, their two little boys and a fat, easygoing Shetland sheep dog have occupied for a year and a half.

The Continental Can Company showed a 21 per cent increase in earnings last year and a sales gain of 6.3 per cent both the highest in the company's 60-year history, Thomas C. Fogarty, chairman, reported yesterday.
ROME, Jan. 25 (AP) Scattering tourists in all directions, an Italian rammed his auto up the steps of St. Peter's Basilica today and crashed against the entrance.

The setting up of two new executive vice presidencies was announced here yesterday by the Georgia-Pacific Corporation, a leading maker of paper and plywood products. Harry J. Kane and Julian N. Cheatham were named to the positions.

STOCKHOLM, Jan. 25 "It's been a dream. We have fallen in love with Sweden and the Swedes." Jacquelin Watson said today. She is one of 53 Negro teen-agers from Chicago's South Side who left Stockholm today after 15 days as guests in private homes.

TOKYO, Jan. 25 (Comtelburo) Japan is planning to apply to the World Bank for a $100-million loan to finance part of the cost of building a highway connecting Tokyo with Nagoya in central Japan, the Ministry of Finance said today.
New York State Assemblyman S. William Green was elected yesterday to the board of the Grand Union Company, the large supermarket chain based in Paterson, N.J.
"If we can show more consistency and get the defensemen and forwards to do more checking in front of the net, we'll look better in the winning column."
Institutional buying, augmented by a shortage of stock, raised prices yesterday on the London Stock Exchange.

Controller Mario A. Procaccino yesterday sought to reassure the nation's financial community of the city's financial solvency, as New York prepared to receive bids on the largest loan the city has ever floated $253-million.
Otto Graham exercised the privilege of changing his mind yesterday when he accepted a rich, long-term contract as the head coach and the general manager of the Washington Redskins.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 President Johnson proposed to Congress today a new regional planning program to help break "poverty's grip on rural America" by pooling the resources of rural counties and towns.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 25 An International conference on the peaceful uses of outer space was approved today by a 28-nation group.
Mayor Lindsay asserted yesterday that he was giving "the highest possible priority" to efforts by a tripartite panel to develop new collective-bargaining procedures to avert strikes by city employes.

The Youngstown Sheet and Tube Company, a major steel producer, said yesterday that the continuing cost-price squeeze, aggravated by higher labor costs, was a chief reason that the company's 1965 earnings fell 4.2 per cent as sales rose 6.2 per cent to a record.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 25 Nigeria's new military Government today proclaimed here its interim character and promised the country a new Constitution.
MILWAUKEE, Jan. 25 (AP) A Wisconsin judge ruled today that baseball must stand trial in a state court on charges of violating antitrust and monopoly statutes.
HARTFORD, Jan. 25 Charles Sudarsky, one of the oldest practicing lawyers in this city, died Friday night at a convalescent home at the age of 80.
The United States District Court here granted yesterday a preliminary injunction against the First Hartford Exchange Fund, Inc., of 44 Wall Street.

STONY BROOK, L.I., Jan. 25 Dr. Alfred H. Boutwell, minister of the First Baptist Church, Ithaca, N.Y., from 1929 until his retirement in 1949, was killed in an automobile accident near here yesterday. He was 82 years old and lived on West Meadow Lane.

MONTREAL, Jan. 25 (AP) Bobby Hull's countdown has moved into the serious stage, with the Chicago Black Hawks' star racing the National Hockey League schedule in his bid to break the record of 50 goals.
WASHINGTON (UPI) Piloty error caused the nonfatal crash of a Northeast Airlines DC-6B at New York's La Guardia Airport on June 5, 1964, the Civil Aeronautics Board reported today.
Bankers in New York City, who are struggling to cope with record-breaking loan demand, are finding their problems compounded by an unexpected source: the nation's major life insurance companies.
WASHINGTON, Jan, 25 Soybean stocks totaled 619 million bushels on Jan. 1 and were 18 per cent higher than a year earlier, the Agriculture Department reported today.

As one of the nation's top trial lawyers, Edward Bennett Williams has never been averse to introducing the ele ment of surprise. It would seem that he still favors that tactic in his comparatively new role as president of the Washington Redskins. Into the vacant coaching post for his capital Braves he has moved a real sleeper, Otto Graham. This is a maneuver that's worthy of that perpetual winner, Perry Mason.
Miss Andrea Maureen Penson and William H. Blumberg were married yesterday evening at the Regency by Rabbi Edward T. Sandrow.

Several of New York's most prominent politicians are in full cry at the moment trying to force the Pennsylvania and New York Central Railroads, if and when merged, to take over the New Haven's uneconomic passenger service.
The W.T. Grant Company, which operates 1,100 general merchandise stores in 46 states, announced yesterday the election of De Witt Peterkin Jr. as a director.
DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., Jan. 25 There was a report from Modena, Italy, late last week that the Ferrari factory had "withdrawn" its entries from the Daytona 24hour Continental, to be run on Feb. 5 and 6.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara said today that the missile forces planned by the Pentagon would be more than enough to wreak "an unacceptable degree of destruction on both the Soviet Union and Communist China simultaneously."
MIAMI, Jan. 25 (AP) Roman Brother, the 1965 horse of the year, made his 1966 debut today and scored an impressive victory in the eighth race at Hialeah.
Carl Winter, former Michigan state chairman of the Communist party, was named yesterday as editor-in-chief of The Worker, the twice-a-week Communist newspaper here.
ALBANY, Jan. 25 The Lindsay administration pleaded today for new state funds for the City University of New York, but warned it would resist any state attempt to control the university's affairs.
The appointment of Daniel P. Reid as staff vice president and general sales manager for Trans World Airlines was announced yesterday.
Harold Roberts Hansen, vice president of Lyras-Adams, Ltd., a real estate and construction company at 111 East 38th Street, died Monday in his home, 155 East 38th Street. He was 63 years old.

MADRID, Jan, 25 (UPI) The crash of a United States Air Force B-52 bomber with atomic weapons aboard eight days ago has resulted in the indefinite suspension of all American nuclear bomber flights over Spain, highly reliable sources said today.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 25 The United States Government has considered taking the Vietnam war to the Security Council for debate four times since July, a reliable source disclosed tonight.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 Qualified sources here said that a small number of Soviet type MIG-21 jet fighter planes have been seen in North Vietnam, presumably at air fields near Hanoi.
NEW LONDON, Conn., Jan. 125 Felix Thomas, a retired patent attorney and mechanical engineer, died yesterday in Lawrence Memorial Hospital here at the age of 77. He lived on Meadowwood Road, Essex.

Six men, including a suspended Federal meat inspector, were named in four indictments yesterday by a Federal grand jury looking into the transportation of 360,000 pounds of uninspected horsemeat from Wisconsin to New York and Boston.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 (AP) The Senate Foreign Relations Committee was reportedly divided today over the desirability of inquiring into the secret operations of the Central Intelligence Agency.

DELAWARE, Ohio, Jan. 25 Dr. and Mrs. Allan Clark Ingraham of Delaware and Eastham, Mass., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Betsey Clark Ingraham, to Frank Scorgie Rhame. He is the son of Mrs. Thelma Scorgie Rhame of Laguna Beach, Calif., and William Thomas Rhame of San Antonio, Tex.

A bill sponsored by Senator Dodd of Connecticut to stop the mail-order trade in guns will soon be up for a vote in a Senate subcommittee. It is a considerable testament to the power of the gun lobby that more than two years after the assassination of President Kennedy Congress has still taken no action to prevent the sale of firearms by mail to unknown purchasers who may be criminals, mental defectives or insane.

PARIS, Jan. 25 Left-wing opposition leaders headed by Francois Mitterrand, unsuccessful candidate in last month's run-off presidential election against General de Gaulle, denounced the Government's handling of the Ben Barka scandal at a mass meeting here today.
CAPETOWN, South Africa, Jan. 25 The opposition United party demanded today that Prime Minister Hendrik F. Verwoerd take "risks" in supporting the white-minority regime in Rhodesia.
TED and Betty are seen everywhere. They winter in Palm Beach and summer in Southampton. They are invited to parties in all the best homes.

A two-hour television production of Arthur Miller's "Death of a Salesman' will be presented in color on Sunday, April 3, at 9 P.M. by the Columbia Broadcasting System. Lee J. Cobb and Mildred Dunnock, who costarred in the play when it opened on Broadway in 1949, will portray the same roles on TV.
Sales set a record in 1965 and earnings were the second highest in company history, the Lukens Steel Company reported yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 The differences between President Johnson and the Chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, J.W. Fulbright, tell quite a lot about the President's concept of his job.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 (AP) President Johnson, a one-time heart patient, proclaimed February as American Heart Month today and said "heart disease can be conquered."
Casey Stengel returned to New York yesterday for the first time since he retired as manager of the Mets, and he could not have created a bigger splash if he had waded ashore at the Battery.

The International Business Machines Corporation proposed yesterday a three-for-two stock split for its 275,650 shareholders. This would be I.B.M.'s tenth stock split since 1926 and the third three-for-two split in the last 8 years.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 (AP) The Long Island Rail Road will be used to test the feasibility of a gas-turbine power unit for commuter trains under a $924,406 grant approved by the Department of Housing and Urban Development.

Within a few hours yesterday, the New York Yankees announced the retirement from baseball of Tony Kubek, a cautiously optimistic report on Mickey Mantle's shoulder operation, and the return of Bobby Richardson.
THERE was a great and general sigh of relief in many city agencies yesterday. Constance Baker Motley, a singleminded woman,...

Mayor Lindsay and Senator Jacob K. Javits yesterday endorsed the recommendation of Senator Robert F. Kennedy that the merging Pennsylvania and New York Central Railroads be compelled to absorb the New Haven Railroad's reportedly unprofitable commuter service.
SYDNEY, Jan. 25 Australia's new Prime Minister, Harold E. Holt, has retained all the ministers he inherited from Sir Robert Menzies, who retired last week.

"Thunderball," the fourth James Bond secret agent film, is about to set another record. By the end of next week, the film, which cost approximately $6.5-million to produce, will have earned about $15-million in the United States and Canada and thus will be in the black after just seven weeks of domestic release.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 It is doubtful that the world can survive half rich and half poor, Sir Charles Snow, the British scientist and author who is better known as C.P. Snow, told the House Committee on Science and Astronautics today.

There's just no way to tell what the New York Knickerbockers will do. Last night in Madison Square Garden, they shot at a horrible 5-for-28 clip in a miserable first quarter against the Detroit Pistons.
Ask any city planner and he'll tell you about those days when it all seems pointless and he has to let off some steam. At such grim times, darts may be the answer.
The stock market moved to slightly higher ground yesterday in fairly active trading.
LONDON. Jan. 25 The London Stock Exchange disciplined eight individual members and five member firms today for facilitating tax-evasion transactions in Government bonds.
ATLANTA, Jan. 25 Georgia and North Carolina have already begun moving toward President Johnson's goal of district development programs for underdeveloped areas, state ofcials said today.

MOSCOW, Jan. 25 The Soviet Communist party announced today that Leonid I. Brezhnev, its First Secretary, had been appointed chairman of a commission to draft a new collective-farm charter. The aim would be to turn agriculture into a more viable sector of the nation's economy.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 (AP) The Pentagon disclosed today that it was holding up the burial of Robert G. Thompson, convicted Communist party leader, in Arlington National Cemetery pending a legal opinion on his eligibility.

ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 25 (AP) Native Diver took the lead a few strides out of the gate and set the pace for the remainder of the way today and won the $28,500 San Pasquale Handicap at Santa Anita Park.
Two Federal agencies have rejected a request by New York State for $1-million for the $4.5million, nuclear-powered desalting project planned for Riverhead, L.I.
Back in 1919, a teen-ager walked into a camera shop in Troy, N.Y., carefully counted out $1 in change he had saved by running errands and mowing lawns and plunked it down to buy a box camera.
LONDON, Jan. 25 New British sanctions against Rhodesia, expected today, have been held off at least temporarily.
HULL, England, Jan. 25 "The Hull voter who really wants to hear the candidates' arguments before voting in Thursday's by-election has only to pick up his telephone and dial 211331.
Councilman J. Raymond Jones of Harlem, New York County Democratic leader, ruled himself out last night as a possible successor to Constance Baker Motley as Manhattan Borough President.

Mrs. Carols Outcalt of New York and Mexico City has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Beatriz Carol Outcalt, to Mark Avery Lothrop, son of Mr. and Mrs. Warren Craig Lothrop of Wilmette, Ill.

Three new screen assignments have been announced. They involve Tippi Hedren, the heroine of Alfred Hitchcock's. "The Birds" and "Marnie"; Lee Marvin, who won acclaim for "Cat Ballou" and "Ship of Fools; and Robert Ellis Miller, television director.

CINCINNATI, Jan. 25 (UPI) The Cincinnati Royals rallied behind the shooting of Oscar Robertson tonight to beat the Boston Celtics, 113-101, and move into first place in the Eastern Division of the National Basketball Association.
NEW DELHI, Jan. 25 India and Pakistan were reported to have begun withdrawing their troops along the cease-fire line today.

GOLDSBORO, Md., Jan. 25 Clifford Hughes, operator of a dog farm here, was charged today with nine counts of cruelty to animals after a raid by agents of the Humane Society of the United States and state troopers.
Dr. Herman L. Reis, who heads the state's largest savings association, the West Side Federal Savings and Loan Association, has finally decided to retire.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 Civil rights attorneys urged the Supreme Court today to declare poll taxes unconstitutional as discriminatory burdens on the right to vote.

PORTSMOUTH, Va., Jan. 25 Mrs. Alfred V. McGinnis has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Katherine Tucker McGinnis, to Robert Stephen Block of New York, son of Mrs. Jesse C. Block and the late Mr. Block.
Police Commissioner Vincent L. Broderick ordered yesterday the first major shake-up in the Police Department since he took office last June.

The 12th annual Hungarian Charity Ball will be given on Feb. 5 in the Grand Ballroom of the Pierre by the Hungarian Catholic League of America. Proceeds will aid refugees, students and needy Hungarians.

RABAT, Morocco, Jan. 25 The Government press accused France today of having created the diplomatic crisis over the Ben Barka affair but said the door was still open to efforts to reach an amicable settlement.

STUART, Fla., Jan. 25 It is perfectly reasonable that Northerners should enjoy the exhilarating briskness of winter storms. But when the fringe effects disturb the waters, and temperatures down here for fishermen, obviously a food thing is being carried too far.
ROY, N.M., Jan. 25 (AP) A 2,000-mile-an-hour SR-71 superspy plane crashed today about 30 miles east of here, and sheriff's officers said one person was killed and another injured.

After creating one of the most talked-about beer salesmen in recent memory the 2,500 year old brewmaster Young Rubicam, Inc., is parting company with the brewery whose beer he sold (or maybe didn't sell enough of) P. Ballantine Sons.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 Deputy Mayor Robert Price of New York has given big-city Republican leaders some startling behind-the-scenes reports on last fall's mayoral contest. The controversial Mr. Price thus started a new controversy: Was he kidding?
Earnings of the United States Steel Corporation climbed 16.3 per cent last year as sales rose 8.1 per cent to a record. Roger M. Blough, chairman, reported yesterday.
Three major oil companies reported yesterday the highest profits ever attained in a single year.
FRANKFORT, Ky., Jan. 25 The Kentucky General Assembly completed passage today of a civil rights bill broader in scope than the Federal act of 1964.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 (AP) A world's record so far as is known for the continuous generation of electricity by a nuclear reactor was claimed today by the Atomic Energy Commission.

M. Lincoln Schuster and Leon Shimkin are discussing a deal that would transfer entire control of Simon and Schuster, Inc., to Mr. Shirnkin. Mr. Schuster, president of the book publishing concern, now owns half its stock and Mr. Shimkin the other half.

The Texas Power and Light Company sold yesterday $20million of 30-year mortgage bonds that were reoffered publicly priced to yield 4.89 per cent the highest yield for a triple-A corporate bond issue in more than five years.

CARLINVILLE, Ill., Jan. 25 Mrs. Liston Morse has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Patricia Ann Morse, to Herbert James Lyall 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert James Lyall of Plandome, L.I.

CHICAGO, Jan. 25 A move by Montgomery Ward Co., to enter commercial banking for the first time was under way today in the form of an offer to shareholders of the Pioneer Trust and saving bank to buy their stock.

The Commercial Solvents Corporation and Reichhold Chemicals, Inc., announced yesterday they had, "by mutual agreement." terminated negotiation to merge into a broadly diversified worldwide chemical company.
ALBANY, Jan. 25 Julian Bond, the Negro pacifist who was denied a seat in the Georgia Legislature because of his views on Vietnam, was introduced today to the New York Legislature.

The Salvage of the stranded 31,801-ton British tanker Chelwood Beacon is to begin this morning off Sandy Hook, N.J. The 665-foot steamship ran aground Sunday two miles east of Sandy Hook Lighthouse during a storm.
President Johnson may have to appoint a committee soon to decide by whom, how and particularly where a 2,000-yearold Egyptian temple will be put together again.
GENEVA, Jan. 25 The Soviet Union's chief disarmament negotiator carefully avoided today making a halt in the war in Vietnam a condition for progress toward arms controls.

The man of tomorrow said yesterday that he would run only a mile at the Millrose Games, perhaps in less than 4 minutes, and then, hopefully, spend the rest of his time chasing a little orange Japanese cap.
The Union Carbide Corporation set earnings records last year, while its sales exceeded the $2-billion-mark for the first time, Birny Mason Jr., president, reported yesterday.

TOKYO, Jan. 25 Japanese Government leaders took steps today to abandon the current five-year national economic plan and work out a new program attuned to the country's rapidly changing economic conditions.
ALBANY, Jan. 25 Governor Rockefeller is shuffling his press relations staff for his third-term gubernatorial campaign and is temporarily hiring former Mayor Robert F. Wagner's press secretary.
SAIGON, Jan. 25 Investigators were seeking the cause of the crash early today of a United States Air Force transport plane near Ankhe, north of Saigon, in which all 46 Americans aboard were killed.
Benjamin Abrams, chairman and chief executive officer of the Emerson Radio and Phonograph Corporation, and Max Abrams, president, said yesterday they would retire Feb. 16.
Nine members have been added to the National Institute of Arts and Letters. The elections, in three of the institute's divisions, were announced yesterday by George F. Kennan, president.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 Big-city Republican leaders looked to the urban vote today as the key to victory in future national elections.
ALBANY, Jan. 25 The administration of Mayor Lindsay is asking the Legislature to remove the upper income limits on persons living in public lowrent housing projects.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 (UPI) Supreme Court Justice Tom C. Clark has signed an order barring the merger of the Dean Foods Company with the Bowman Dairy Company, Chicago milk distributors, until the Supreme Court takes a look at the transaction.

MONTREAL, Jan. 25 One of Quebec's leading Cabinet members, Welfare Minister Ren Levesque, has warned that French Canada will take over control of the economic life of Montreal in the foreseeable future.
MIAMI, Jan. 25 A cheating scandal involving the theft and duplication of examination papers was under investigation here today at the University of Miami.
JERUSALEM, Israeli Sector, Jan. 25 (AP) Prof. Saul Adler, head of the parasitology department of the Hebrew University, died of cancer today. He was 71 years old.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 Senator Wayne Morse opened his annual offensive today against the Administration's foreign aid program.

HARTFORD, Jan. 25 The Connecticut Supreme Court ruled today that the Synanon Foundation could no longer use a 20-room mansion in the exclusive Greens Farms residential section of Westport as a rehabilitation center for narcotics addicts.
No physical phenomenon, not even the lowly bubble, seems to escape the attention of scientists and engineers working on the airplanes, rockets and spacecraft of the future.
The election of Anna Maria Rappaport as vice president and associate actuary of the Standard Security Life Insurance Company of New York was announced yesterday.
The United States clay court tennis championships have been awarded to the Town Club of Milwaukee for 1966 after being held in Chicago for more than 30 years.
The American Trial Lawyers Association has begun a campaign against what it calls "the greatest unsolved murder mystery of our times" automobile accidents.
OTTAWA, Jan. 25 The minority Liberal Government of Prime Minister Lester B. Pearson withstood tonight the first serious threat to its leadership in the new Canadian Parliament.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Jan. 25 Arthur A. Miller, who retired in 1946 as a vice president of the Chase National Bank (now the Chase Manhattan Bank), died today in his home at 155 East Sydney Avenue. He was 84 years old.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 One of the smallest items in the budget presented to Congress by President Johnson yesterday may turn out to have immense significance for America's troubled cities.
HOLLYWOOD, Jan. 25 "I'm like something that fell out of a Kafka novel," says Lenny Bruce. "The difference is that Kafka characters never get their day in court. I'll get my day."

In unveiling his new budget, President Johnson emphasized his belief in flexible fiscal policy, which involves moving tax rates up or down to restrain or stimulate demand. But his actual tax proposals appear to depend more on ingenuity than on flexibility.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 The Treasury auctioned $1billion in one-year bills today at an average discount rate of 4,699 per cent, the same rate as the average yesterday on six-month bills.

The American Sugar Company has announced the elections of Robert T. Quittmeyer and Guy D. Manuel as vice presidents. Mr. Quittmeyer was assistant general counsel. Mr. Manuel continues as president of the Spreckels Sugar Company, a division.

MIAMI, Jan. 25 (UPI) Two women who said they could vote the death penalty if evidence warranted it were tentatively accepted as jurors today in the murder trial of Candace Mossler and her alleged lover, Melvin Lane Powers.
CHICAGO, Jan. 25 The Krebiozen fraud case went to the jury late today, nine months after the trial began.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 Stephen S. Chandler, the Federal judge who became the center of controversy last month when other judges attempted to remove his authority, notified the Supreme Court tonight that he was willing to retire.

BRATTLEBORO, Vt., Jan. 25 (AP) Leif Bringslimark, a former Norwegian champion now representing the Telemark Ski Club of New York, won the postponed second-round jump today in the Nordic combined trials for berths on the United States Federation Internationale de Ski team.
The 40th anniversary dinner dance of the Physicians Wives League of Greater New York will take place at the WaldorfAstoria on Feb. 12.

LONDON, Jan. 25 (AP) Eduardo Corletti, an Argentine fighting out of Rome, outpointed George Chuvalo of Toronto, the fourth-ranked challenger for Cassius Clay's heavyweight title, in an upset over 10 rounds tonight.
Expert pianism, first-rate musicianship and mature interpretative ability were distinguishing features of the New York debut recital given at Town Hall last night by Duncan McNab.
The Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., and its subsidiaries reported yesterday new highs in operating revenues and net income for 1965.
HONG KONG, Jan. 25 Peking leaders, in their public statements, are emphasizing the likelihood of an eventual war between Communist China and the United States.
SANTIAGO, Chile, Jan. 25 (AP) Chile announced tonight that agreement had been reached with the United States on a plan to settle differences over copper prices.

CANADA came to Brooklyn last night when Les Grands Ballets Canadiennes made their New York debut at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. This is one of Canada's oldest dance institutions, and is based in Montreal.

Many owners of compact cars may have to pay more for automobile insurance this year because it has been found that smaller cars do not have fewer accidents or cost less to repair than the larger ones.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 The Senate Commerce Committee questioned Roger W. Wilkins for two hours today and then unanimously approved his nomination as director of the Community Relations Service.

Political interference in approval of sponsors and "loose supervision of costs" has resulted in "excessive profits and fees" for developers of statesupported middle-income housing projects, the State Investigation Commission was told yesterday.

BERKELEY, Calif., Jan. 25 (UPI) A total of $1,000, solicited on the Berkeley campus of the University of California, has been turned over to Vietcong representatives to provide "medical supplies for the victims of U.S. aggression in Vietnam," it was announced yesterday.

Mrs. Janet De Lyra asked a Supreme Court Justice yesterday to punish her husband, John, for failure to pay back alimony she said amounted to $1,400. Justice Frederick Backer reserved decision on the contempt motion.

If man refuses to follow wise conservation practices in controlling his economic affairs, the ultimate victim may be not natural beauty or birds and fish but man himself. This is the sober warning of Interior Secretary Stewart L. Udall in his recent report on the various species of fish, birds and animals that are close to extinction.

A staff study for the city's fiscal inquiry has favored a merger of various transportation facilities, but finds that the subway and bus deficit has grown so high that even a merged operation would need additional revenues.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Jan. 25 (AP) Heavy snow slowed travel and closed schools today in Arkansas. A storm that moved in from the Gulf of Mexico also spread snow and cold rain across a wide stretch of the South.
BONN, Jan. 25 Does Germany's Constitution protect its citizens from the kind of midnight raids and arrests that terrified the country during the Hitler era?
Defense lawyers spent another day yesterday trying to shake the testimony of a bodyguard of Malcolm X.
Two recently announced developments and a third now being tested point to the day when the hemophiliac may be able to carry a vial containing the vital clotting factor his blood lacks.

In the face of the city's drastic economy program, seven new salary increases, totaling $14,500 a year, came to light yesterday through publication in the City Record. The increases were authorized by Mayor Wagner in the final weeks of his administration.

BOWIE, Md., Jan. 25 (UPI) A Maryland State Racing Commissioner, J. Newton Brewer Jr., said today that one horse suspected of having swamp fever died last night and two more animals were believed harboring the disease.
Tidewater Oil Company said yesterday that it had started merger talks with Getty Oil Company, which controls 72 per cent of the 13,348,000 shares of Tidewater outstanding.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 25 (AP) The United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit ruled yesterday that a foreign vessel was considered to be arriving in an American port for the first time even though it might have last sailed from another American port rather than a foreign one.
Mayor Lindsay reappointed Seymour N. Siegel as director of the city's radio communications last night with assurances that WNYC, the municipal broadcasting facility, will not be sold.

Birgit Nilsson and Franco Corelli took the leading roles in last night's "Tosca" at the Metropolitan Opera for the first time this season and gave Puccini's tragic melodrama a run for its money. What voices these two have. For size and vocal power, each stands like a monument to itself.
Bradshaw Crandell, artist, died yesterday of cancer at his home in Madison, Conn. He was 69 years old.
United Artists is in the final stages of negotiations to acquire film rights to the Broadway musical, "Fiddler on the Roof."

LONDON, Jan. 25 A British Monopolies Commission report, undertaken under the new antitrust statute that for the first time subjects business mergers to Government scrutiny, has found the recent merger of two major industrial concerns "not against the public interest."
TUSKEGEE, Ala., Jan. 25 (AP) Tuskegee's biracial City Council tonight adopted an ordinance prohibiting racial discrimination in places of public accommodation within the city.
ST. LOUIS, Jan. 25 (AP) The St. Louis Hawks scored 78 points in the second half tonight and trounced the San Francisco Warriors, 142-107, in a National Basketball Association game.
PASS CHRISTIAN, Miss., Jan. 25 Benjamin Yoe Morrison, a national leader in horticulture and plant breeding, died of a heart attack today in Gulfport Memorial Hospital. He was 74 years old.
Events today: Beethoven's "Fidelio," Metropolitan Opera. 8 P.M.; New York Philharmonic, Philharmonic Hall, 8:30; Mendelssohn's "Elijah," Oratorio Society of New York, Carnegie Hall, 8:30.

DURBAN, South Africa, Jan. 26 Harold Strachan, a for mer political prisoner, was found guilty today of having lied when he wrote of brutality in South African jails. A series of articles on his experiences appeared in The Rand Daily Mail.

Mrs. Rita Seligson Pavenick, wife of Stanford Pavenick, president of the Aljen Manufacturing Corporation, makers of toilet articles, died yesterday, in the New York Infirmary. She was 45 years old and lived at 341 Scotland Road, South Orange, N.J.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 A strong plea for more support for the social and behavioral sciences was made today by a well-known physical scientist.

Alfred J. Scotti, chief assistant district attorney for Manhattan, said yesterday that his office was "conducting a very thorough and intense investigation" of La Vie, a restaurant at Second Avenue and 47th Street.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 A strong suggestion that the Chinese Communist party is having some difficulty in controlling the army has been broadcast by Peking. The statement hints that not all military men share the party's confidence in the nation's ability to cope with a war against the United States.
AUCKLAND, New Zealand, Jan. 26 (AP) American girls won five of six events and broke three New Zealand records today in an international swimming meet.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 26 (AP) Five Louisiana parish (county) school systems, which have lost more than $2-million in Federal aid for refusing to desegregate their classrooms, said today they were doing all right and did not intend to give in.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., Jan.26 Talbot Babcock of Scarsdale and Jamestown, R.I., has announced the engagement of his daughter, Miss Janet Elizabeth Babcock, to Edwin Charles Hahn 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Hahn Jr. of Scarsdale.
Both Coca-Cola and Pepsi Cola will be produced this year in Eastern European countries for the first time under plans now being worked out.

NEWARK, Jan. 26 Attorneys for 60 municipalities, 6 counties, 4 railroad brotherhoods and the state appeared at a hearing of the Board of Public Utility Commissioners today to protest the ending of New Jersey suburban passenger service proposed by the ErieLackawanna Railroad.
LONDON, Jan. 26 The Moscow Zoo has given a new nod to the nyet-again-da-again romance of Chi-Chi and An-An, the London Zoo said today.
BONN, Jan. 26 Atomic physicists and other Government-employed scientists in West Germany have begun a mass demand for higher wages and increased professional recognition.

A Brooklyn builder netted a windfall of $1,826,000 from a housing project whose legal representatives included a City Planning Commissioner and a State Senator, according to testimony before the State Investigation Commission yesterday.
PARIS, Jan. 26 A daring raid has been mounted on the trademarks of many of the world's leading corporations.

"EVERYTHING was first class," said D. Roy Hol loway of Woodbury, Conn., a professional handler, yesterday about the series of dog shows that ended in Nassau, the Bahamas, last week. "They really rolled out the red carpet and went all out for the exhibitors.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 President Johnson's recommendations for tax increases to help finance the Vietnam war have stirred so little controversy that only seven witnesses have asked to be heard by the House Ways and Means Committee.

The John Birch Society will produce a 15-minute weekly radio program titled "The Birch Report." It has asked members, especially those with businesses, to purchase air time in their areas and sponsor the programs on a commercial basis.

SEOUL, South Korea, Jan. 26 Gen. Dwight E. Beach, the top United States commander in Korea, said at a news conference today that the United States was speeding up delivery of weapons to South Korean forces in compensation for the dispatch of one Korean division to South Vietnam last October.
A "George Washington Baroque Marathon" of four concerts will be given on Feb. 20 and 21 at Philharmonic Hall.
ANKHE, South Vietnam, Jan. 26 Four soldiers of the United States First Cavalry Division (Airmobile) have been charged with illegally possessing narcotics, and 20 are under investigation.
Luther Adler, who replaced Zero Mostel twice in "Fiddler on the Roof" here, will play the role of Tevye on the road, but only for 25 weeks.
JUST as hemlines are going up, up, up, so are heels going down, down, down. Paris has confirmed a trend already manifest here.

PARIS, Jan. 26 The French Foreign Minister Maurice Couve de Murville, told a Cabinet meeting today how tension between France and Morocco had risen over a two-month period because of the Ben Barka kidnapping.
MELBOURNE, Australia, Jan. 26 (AP) John Coyle, the young Melbourne ace, beat Ron Clarke over two miles at Geelong tonight in the third fastest time ever recorded for the distance.
Brener Lewis, Inc., real estate brokerage concern specializing in hotel and motel transactions for the last 21 years, is being dissolved, effective next Tuesday.
Priests who become "militant in the inner working of labor unions" have been criticized by the Most Rev. Egidio Cagnozzi, the Vatican's Apostolic Delgate to Washington.

ALBANY, Jan. 26 The Democrats are planning to push again for passage of the bill vetoed by Governor Rockefeller last year that would permit primary fights for the governorship and other statewide offices.
