President Johnson's message on the nation's cities is an eloquent statement of the problem; his program is a modest but auspicious beginning.

ALBANY, Jan. 26 The State University of New York ranks academically "a good distance behind City University, the University of California and all members of the Big Ten Conference," its president told a legislative committee today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (AP)--Vice Adm. Hyman G. Rickover said today that the proposed second nuclear-powered aircraft carrier would require refueling only once during its 25-year life span.
A heavy storm pounded up the Eastern Seaboard yesterday and began dumping snow on New York City and its suburbs.

The London Stock Exchange opened firm yesterday and continued to edge up throughout the day, although demand slackened toward the close. Shortages of stock for sale made up for the lack of volume in most sectors, and the advance was general.
The American Stock Exchange struggled through a short breakdown in its quotation ticker system yesterday, but managed to show gains by the close of trading despite some late profit taking.

The two elements of novelty in the Boston Symphony Orchestra's concert in Philharmonic Hall last night were the Presence of Jean Martinon as guest conductor and the local premiere of Marius Constant's 24 Preludes for Orchestra. Preceding the new work came Mendelssohn's "Italian" Symphony: after it, Richard Strauss's "Ein Heldenleben," both of them old friends.

Daily doses of fluoridated vitamins can help to reduce tooth decay in children at least as well as fluoridated water, three Indiana University scientists will report next week in The Journal of Dentistry for Children.

Jean Ratelle Scored at 18:02 of the third period to give the New York Rangers a 4-3 victory over the front-running Detroit Red Wings last night in a National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden.

STUART, Fla., Jan. 26 If a ladyfish were 5-feet long it would rival the salmon, sailfish or any of the top gamesters for honors in the sportiness sweepstakes. One might almost call it a poor man's bonefish.
SEOUL, South Korea, Jan. 26 Three North Korean infiltrators were sentenced to death in Seoul district court today in two separate trials on charges of attempted espionage.
TRENTON, Jan. 26 Two men broke into a radio studio here tonight and assaulted a commentator who has criticized right-wing groups.

Mrs. Mary Hickey Luter, wife of John Luter, a member of the faculty of the Columbia University Graduate School of Journalism, died yesterday of a cerebral hemorrhage at St. Vincent's Hospital. She was 44 years old and lived at 25 Fifth Avenue.
MOSCOW, Jan. 26 The Soviet Union announced today plans for a mammoth publishing project, a 200-volume library of what it considers the masterpieces of world literature.
The Landmarks Preservative Commission announced yesterday that 33 buildings in Brooklyn would be proposed for landmark designation at its next public hearing on Feb. 8 at City Hall.
New York's waterfront watchmen have rejected a new four-year working agreement negotiated earlier this month with employers of the New York Shipping Association.
A bodyguard for Malcolm X testified yesterday that he did not fire at the three men accused of murdering the Negro leader for fear of hitting women and children.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 The Federal Maritime Commission appeared today to have won an initial victory in its efforts to gain access to steamship conference business records both here and abroad.
THE Southwest is entitled to withdraw from the Union after last night's installment of "This Proud fund" over the American Broadcasting Company network.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (AP) The United States accused the Soviet Union today of waging a "campaign" to escape blame for the events leading to the death last week of Newcomb Mott.

TUYHOA, South Vietnam, Jan. 26 The young American paratrooper had, on impulse, written on the green-and-tan camouflage cover of his steel helmet the words "Tui Wha, Jan. 23, 1966, 2 killed, 8 wounded."

The Women's City Club of New York, a nonpartisan civic organization, recommended yesterday a municipal income tax, off-track betting and an increase in the real estate tax as part of a program to put the city on a sounder economic footing.
HANOVER, N.H., Jan. 26 Northeastern tallied two quick goals after Dartmouth had tied the score, 4-4, late in the third period to defeat the Indians, 6-4, tonight.

Prime office space in the booming midtown East Side area has risen between 45 and 65 cents a square foot a year in the last five years, Julien J. Studley, Inc., office leasing organization, reported yesterday.
LAGOS, Nigeria, Jan. 26 The Federal military Government extended its grip over the four regions of Nigeria today in sweeping decrees denouncing "political gangsters" of the old regime.

A strong expansion of economic resources in the United States during the next five years means that there will be little in the way of inflation, according to a report published yesterday by the Interpublic Group of Companies, Inc.

LONDON, Jan. 26 Andrei Gulyashki, said to be the Communist world's Ian Fleming, came to London yesterday to try to get the feel of James Bond's habitat.
Mobile museums that will trundle art and natural history exhibits and even movies through the streets of New York may be in the city's future. Parks Commissioner Thomas P.F. Hoving said yesterday.
An exhibition of Latin-American art from the 19th and 20th centuries opens today at the Yale University Art Gallery in New Haven.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (AP) Senator Hugh Scott, Republican of Pennsylvania, said today the date set for Robert G. Baker's trial was "a palpable scheme" to avoid having the former Senate aide's activities exposed before the November elections.
PARIS, Jan. 26 During the Arab League meeting in Casablanca in September, diplomats were surprised to see the 12 chiefs of state crowd into a special bus to go to the mosque for prayers.
NEW DELHI, Jan. 26 Mrs. Indira Gandhi, the new Prime Minister, said tonight that her Government's "first duty" was to feed India's 485-million people.
The National Basketball Association decided yesterday to add a Chicago team in time for next season, bringing its membership to 10 teams for the first time since 1953.
MIAMI, Jan. 26 (API) Gallant Romeo, the third choice with the crowd of 17,746, whipped Time Tested in a blistering seven-furlong duel at Hialeah today in the $33,350 Royal Palm Handicap.

The first American astronauts to land on the moon will unpack a 150-pound package of scientific instruments and begin a series of seven geophysical experiments, the space agency announced yesterday.
LOS ANGELES, Jan. 26 (AP) A coroner's jury exonerated the police today in the shooting death of two men who allegedly attempted to kidnap Leonard K. Firestone, the rubber magnate.

ATLANTA, Jan. 26 (UPI) The Atlanta Falcons went for youth in picking their head coach today. He is 38-year-old Norb Hecker, the defensive backfield coach of the Green Bay Packers, who signed a four-year contract for a total of about $100,000 with the new National Football League team.

WASHINTON, Jan. 26 The foreign trade surplus of the United States fell by more than $1.5-billion in 1965 to a total of $5.2-billion, Commerce Department figures showed today.

LONDON, Jan. 26 The declining fortunes of the transAtlantic passenger steamship industry was the subject of intense discussion behind closed doors here today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 The Treasury offered today holders of $13-billion of its securities maturing in February, April, May and August the chance to get 5 per cent for their money.

SAIGON, Thursday, Jan. 27 (AP) A Vietcong platoon of 14 men defected to the Vietnamese Government a week ago on the eve of the lunar New Year cease-fire, the Vietnamese press reported today. The defection was at Phuocbinh in Phuonglong province on the Cambodian border about 75 miles northwest of Saigon.

The Contemporary Chamber Ensemble in Residence at Rutgers University, led by Arthur Weisberg, gave the first performance of Beatrice Witkin's "Combinations for Thirteen" and the first New York performance of Meyer Kupferman's "Infinities Twelve" last night at Hunter College Playhouse.

MIAMI, Jan. 26 (AP) Defense attorneys moved today for dismissal of the murder indictment against Mrs. Candace Mossler and her nephew, Melvin Lane Powers, charging that it had been based on perjured testimony.

Howard B. Wakeman, senior vice president of the Long Island Lighting Company, was elected yesterday as a director of the utility.

THE Vanderbilt Cup, awarded to the winners of the National Knockout Team Championship, will be fought for in March for the 39th time, during the Spring Nationals in Louisville, Ky. The trophy is the oldest in contract bridge.

MONTREAL, Jan. 26 (UPI) The Chicago Black Hawks, getting two goals from Phil Esposito and outstanding goaltending from Glenn Hall, defeated the Montreal Canadiens, 4-2, tonight and moved to within 2 points of the first-place team, Detroit, in the National Hockey League.

THOMAS EMERY of New York, the moving spirit behind the armed forces chess tournaments sponsored by the American Chess Foundation, resumed an old rivalry with Pierre Morra during a recent visit to Monte Carlo.
BOSTON, Jan. 26 The Massachusetts Teachers Association imposed professional sanctions today against the public school system of Nantucket.
Photo Magic, Inc's much touted 12-picture-a-minute developing machine got off to a rather fuzzy start yesterday.
Bond prices yesterday continued on the downward path they have followed so monotonously in recent months.

The Coast Guard reopened yesterday South and Sandy Hook Channels, which lead to the Perth Amboy-Arthur Kill area of the port. The channel had been closed since Sunday as a result of the grounding of the 665-foot British tanker Chelwood Beacon.

LONDON, Jan. 26 Edward Heath, leader of the opposition Conservative party, differed today with Foreign Minister Joseph M.A.H. Luns of the Netherlands on the timing of a fresh approach by Britain to enter the Common Market.
Staff physicians at Mount Sinai Hospital will be required to take courses in the humanities. The program will affect 1,000 attending physicians and 300 residents and internes.
The nation's electric power production rose 8.9 per cent in the week ended Jan. 22 from the level in the 1965 week, it was rported yesterday by the Edison Electric Institute.

The New York Heart Association, the forerunner of the sytematic national drive by public and voluntary agencies againt heart illnesses, celebrated its 50th anniversary last night at a dinner at the Biltmore Hotel.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 Conversion of the Government's student loan program from Federal to private financing as proposed by President Johnson in his budget message this week will make about 90 per cent of the nation's college and university students eligible for this type of assistance, an official of the Office of Education said today.
The Monsanto Company had its best year in history with sales and earnings at a new record, the preliminary statement disclosed yesterday.
TRENTON, Jan. 26 Charges that groups of Young Republicans sang anti-Semitic and racist songs at a state convention in New Jersey and at a national convention in Miami were made public today.

AFTER more than 60 years, New Yorkers finally had a chance to hear the enormous Piano Concerto by Ferruccio Busoni. It was played last night in Carnegie Hall, under the auspices of Daniell Revenaugh, who conducted the American Symphony Orchestra and Masterwork Chorus. Mr. Revenaugh was the moving spirit in its revival.
The Fiduciary Trust Company of New York announced the election yesterday of P. Philip Lacovara as a vice president and as trust officer.

MOSCOW, Jan. 26 (UPI) The Soviet Communist party newspaper Pravda reported today that the principal North Vietnamese port, Haiphong, had been partly evacuated and mobilized in anticipation of United States air strikes.
Home opening dates of the 10 National League baseball clubs this season will be spread over five dates, ranging from April 11 to April 19.
Smiling broadly, Mayor Lindsay strode into an East Harlem public school at 6:30 last night, to the cheers of a crowd that had waited for him since 8 A.M. with hope and some resentment.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (UPI) A controversy over the proposed burial of Robert G. Thompson in Arlington National Cemetery spread from Capital Hill to Moscow today. Mr. Thompson, convicted of Communist conspiracy, won a Distinguished Service Medal in World War II.

PUTNEY, Vt., Jan. 26 (AP) Mike Gallagher of Killington, Vt., captured the opening 15kilometer (9.3-miles) crosscountry race and John Bower of Auburn, Me., took the Nordic combined lead today in trials for the United States ski team.

PARIS, Jan. 26 All the highwaisted dresses that keep coming out in the French haute couture collections now in their third day look great on flat-chested, small-boned girls who are no taller than the average American 10-year-old.

Proximity, considered harness racing's greatest trotting mare at the time of her retirement in 1951, was destroyed humanely at the Castleton Farm in Lexington, Ky., Wednesday after she had suffered a broken hip in an accident.
OTTAWA, Jan. 26 (AP) Canada will give up next month the reconnaissance role it has performed for the United Nations Force in Egypt since April, 1957, the Defense Department said today.

The report of the St. Regis Paper Company issued yesterday disclosed record sales and earnings for 1965. Net profit rose to $35,866,000, or $2.81 a share, on 12,747,785 common shares from $26,903,000, or $2.14 a share on 12,554,002 shares earned in 1964.
Heads of city departments have been directed by the Lindsay administration to obtain clearance from designated aides to the Mayor before appearing before state and city legislative bodies.

Longshoremen walked off the job at two Hudson River piers yesterday, one group for 15 minutes and the other for the whole day.

ATLANTA, Jan. 26 Seventyfive faculty and staff members from predominantly Negro educational institutions announced today their support of Representative-elect Julian Bond in his efforts to be seated in the Georgia House of Representstives.
LONDON, Jan. 26 Britain is now spending just over 1 per cent of her gross national product on overseas defense costs the troops and bases scattered from the Rhine to Borneo.

The exciting spectacle of indoor track returns to Madison Square Garden tonight with the 59th annual Millrose Games. The blue-ribbon field includes world record-holders and national champions from the United States, Canada, West Germany, Czechoslovakia, Belgium and Kenya.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (AP) William Robert Grubb, a special assistant to the Controller of the Currency, died last night at the Washington Hospital Center. He had suffered a heart attack several days earlier. He was 50 years old.
PITTSBURGH, Jan. 26 Dr. Stanton Chapman Crawford, acting chancellor of the University of Pittsburgh, died in his home today after a heart attack. He was 68 years old.

The city lost more than $237,000 on the operation of Shea Stadium last year, and its deficit this year will be at least double that amount unless Mayor Lindsay finds ways of increasing revenue from the stadium.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (AP) The Food and Drug Administration announced today that half a million disposable hypodermic needles were being recalled because nonsterile needles had been found among samples.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 Secretary of Labor W. Willard Wirtz said today that the unemployment rate might fall to 3.5 per cent by the end of June. He said that this should not create "serious" manpower shortages.
The 1967 Federal maritime budget proposals are coming under increasingly heavy fire from all segments of the maritime industry and from Congressional quarters.

DULUTH, Ga., Jan. 26 Carl A. Maxwell, a mechanical engineer and special assistant on the staff of E.F. Wentworth Jr., president of the Foster Wheeler Corporation, died of a heart attack yesterday at the Dutch Mill Motel here. His age was 77. He lived at 2 Tudor City Place, New York.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 Administration efforts to force a vote on a labor bill were blocked again today when opponents plunged the Senate into debate over putting the fall text of the Senate's opening prayer of yesterday in The Congressional Record.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Jan. 26 Army defeated Rutgers, 62-61, today in a game in which the cadets' all-America basketball candidate, Mike Silliman, wrenched a knee. Silliman left the contest after four minutes of play and did not return.
Executives of two of the country's major distillers expressed reluctance or doubt yesterday about making available to a legislative committee the data upon which they based ...
