ATHENS, Jan. 26 An expert in the preservation of antiquities appealed today for international cooperation in protecting Athen's 2,400-year-old Acropolis from decay.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 Senator Edward V. Long, Democrat of Missouri, has nominated former President Harry S. Truman for the Nobel Peace Prize.
TOKYO, Jan. 26 Japan's new diplomacy in Southeast Asia is expected to be spearheaded by a Tokyo-sponsored program of economic aid to Indonesia through an international consortium.
The Lindsay administration is planning to set up 35 local Mayor's offices at an annual cost of about $1.25-million to bring government closer to the residents of the five boroughs.
Earnings of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation rose 1.4 per cent last year on a 15.1 per cent increase in sales, the company reported yesterday.

The Salvation Army opened yesterday its Greater New York Annual Fund Appeal, seeking a record $4.4-million to cover an anticipated deficit in its $13.7million budget for 140 institutions and services. Salvation Army institutions, through fees and grants, produce $9.3-million of the total.
Mayor Lindsay strongly defended Deputy Mayor Robert Price yesterday against recent criticism.
Miss Linda Jane Zimmerman and Eric Lipsett Albin plan to marry in the spring.

A brotherhood award to Charles W. Engelhard Jr., one of the world's powerful industrialists and a Johnson Administration appointee to promote better race relations, was protested yesterday by the American Committee on Africa.
Senator Jacob K. Javits called last night for an end of all trade by the non-Communist world with North Vietnam, which he said amounted to $35.6-million in 1964 and was even higher last year.

SAIGON, Jan. 26 The air war in South Vietnam continued at a brutal pace today. American and Vietnamese fighterbombers lashed at suspected Vietcong troop concentrations and bases throughout the country with tons of high explosives and napalm.

BERKELEY, Calif., Jan. 26 Dr. Israel Lyon Chaikoff, professor of physiology at the University of California, wellknown for his research, died at Alta Bates Hospital here yesterday after a severe asthmatic attack. He was 63 years old.
PENSACOLA, Fla., Jan, 26 (UPI) The Navy skipper whose submarine on one assignment sank more Japanese shipping than any other in World War II, apparently took his own life yesterday in a motel room.
The State of Delaware sold yesterday $15-million of bonds to an underwriting syndicate managed by the Fist Boston Corporation.
The Advertising Research Foundation elected a new chairman yesterday. He immediately asked for more money not for himself, but for the work of the nonprofit organization.

An Ohio industrialist called last night for a relaxation of trade barriers between the United States and the Soviet Union as a means of bringing "great security and stability to both of our economies."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 The Spanish Government has quietly asked that the United States avoid refueling its nucleararmed bombers over Spanish territory and that it conduct such operations over the sea in the foreseeable future.
Net income of the Standard Oil Company of California rose 13 per cent to $391-million in 1965 from $345,288,000 in 1964, the company reported yesterday.

The Vietnam decision President Johnson now faces is not only whether to resume the bombing offensive but, even more important, whether to suspend the peace offensive. Administration spokesmen claim that the peace effort would continue even after the air attacks resume, but this is mere semantics. It would be motion without meaning, for if the daily bombing North Vietnam begins again, there can be little possibility of further diplomatic exchanges with Hanoi.
LONDON, Jan. 26 A lastminute poll tonight gave the Labor party a substantial edge in tomorrow's crucial by-election in the city of Hull.
The seventh annual Diamond Ball for the benefit of the Institute of International Education last night was a truly international gathering.
The American Stock Exchange has reported the changes carried below in the shareholdings of officers, directors and controlling stockholders of listed concerns.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 The Secretary and the Chief of Staff of the Air Force supported today Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara's plans to cut back the Strategic Air Command's fleet of nuclear bombers.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (AP) The American Public Power Association, after a study of last November's power failure in the Northeast, today recommended more authority for the Federal Power Commission. The association represents some 1,400 locally owned public power systems in the United States.
GLENS FALLS, N.Y., Jan. 26 (AP) A fire said to have been set by a 4-year-old boy killed his baby sister today and injured his parents and grandmother. Three children escaped.
Despite all the esoteric work they do, computers have little outward glamour but every so often the glamour shines through among the mathematically inclined employes who use them.
ALBANY, Jan. 26 Governor Rockefeller ordered rewards today for state employes in New York City who got to their jobs during the recent transit strike.

TUXEDO PARK, N.Y., Jan. 26 Charles Petrosky, a professional from New York, won by default today from Bud Palmer, also of New York, in the only match scheduled in the United States open court tennis championship.
The Northrop Corporation announced yesterday that it was considering the acquisition of the Hallicrafters Company, a Chicago electronics concern.

Alexander Ince, the former publisher of Theater Arts and a theatrical personality, died last night in St. Clare's Hospital after suffering a cerebral hemorrhage on Monday. Mr. Ince, who always made a great secret of his age, was believed to have been in his late 70's. He lived at 200 West 54th Street.
Xerox Corporation announced in Rochester yesterday a modification of its organizational structure and appointment of several senior officers.

Sir Arthur Conan Doyle, who spent much of the fortune he earned from his Sherlock Holmes stores on resarch into spiritualism, is becoming a motion picture and television producer approximately 35 years after his death.

Parimutuel betting on horse racing has been legal in New York since 1939, and during that time $17.5billion has been gambled and the state has taken S1.5-billion in taxes. Last year the tax-take was about $140-million.

STRATTON MOUNTAIN, Vt., Jan. 26 Professional ski racing, with an emphasis on showmanship, was introduced at this popular southern Vermont retreat today. And, by the time the opening session of the two-day ...

HOLLYWOOD, Jan. 26 (UPI) Fletcher Wiley, a former radio personality, died today from burns sustained from a fire in his apartment. He fell asleep on a couch while smoking, the police said. Mr. Wiley was 69 years old.
McKesson Robbins, Inc., the nation's largest distributor of drugs and pharmaceuticals, opened its fight yesterday in Federal Court to preserve its corporate entity.
The spot rate on the British pound closed off a point at $2.8042 in continued light trading on foreign exchange markets here yesterday.

Tony Kubek's retirement leaves the New York Yankee shortstop job wide open, and it may prove to be a golden opportunity for Bobby Murcer, a 19-year-old infielder who was one of the most highly regarded young prospects the Yankees had last season.

GENEVA, Jan. 26 William C. Foster, United States disarmament negotiator, welcomed today a Soviet indication of a desire to avoid having the search for agreements on arms controls disrupted by the war in Vietnam.
NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 26 (AP) A Federal appeals court dismissed today a $1-million libel suit against the Curtis Publishing Company by the chief of the Mississippi Highway Patrol.
A delegation of persons opposing the $500-million project for a World Trade Center here called on Mayor Lindsay late yesterday to tell him of their objections.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Jan. 26 Berton Braley, a freelance poet and journalist who wrote verses by the thousands, short stories by the hundreds and books by the score, died here Sunday. He was 83 years old.
Dr. Frank Nicolai of Stewart Manor, L.I., an orthodontist, died on Monday at Mary Immaculate Hospital, Jamaica, Queens. He was 71 years old.
ALBANY, Jan. 26 Democratic and Republican legislative leaders opened the way today for a possible compromise on reapportionment.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 Like most of us, the Air Force loses things. Last week in Spain it lost an H-bomb. Two planes collided in the Spanish sky, and when the wreckage was searched, one of our H-bombs was missing.

BOWIE, Md., Jan. 26 (UPI) The Maryland Racing Commission was speeding a program today to help isolate an outbreak of suspected swamp fever at Bowie race track. The track was closed today by a severe snowstorm.
CHICAGO, Jan. 26 The Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. took occupancy of a four-room flat in a West Side Negro slum called North Lawndale today.

LONDON, Jan. 26 Somerset Maugham, who died on Dec. 16, left the equivalent of $140,000 and the income from the copyrights of his works to Alan Searle, his secretary and companion for the last 34 years of his life.
CHICAGO, Jan. 26 A Federal jury sworn last April 30 spent its first full day in deliberations today.
NEW PROVIDENCE, N.J., Jan. 28 (AP) Robert H. Badgley, former Mayor of this borough, died today at his home at 30 Glenside Road. He was 53 years old.

Robert Ferdinand Wagner, private citizen, returned to New York yesterday. Deeply tanned from his 26-day Mexican vacation, he submitted cheerfully to newsmen's questioning at Kennedy International Airport but steadfastly refused to be drawn into any criticism of his successor.

COLUMBIA, S.C., Jan. 26 (AP) Legislators from small counties, seeking to retain as much political power as possible, have filibustered for more than 100 hours to block a plan to reapportion the South Carolina Senate.
MIAMI, Jan. 28 University of Miami officials hope to complete their investigation into an examination cheating scandal by the end of this week, a spokesman said today.

SYDNEY, Australia, Jan. 26 (UPI) The last two United States doubles teams were knocked out of the Australian national championships today, with the big upset suffered by Marty Riessen of Evanston, Ill., Clark Graebner of Beachwood, Ohio.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 There is not much doubt here that President Johnson will soon order a resumption in the bombing of North Vietnam, but debate is continuing in a divided Congress and within an Administration that is by no means unanimous on the issue.
LONDON, Jan. 26 Arthur Miller's play "Incident at Vichy" opened at the Phoenix Theater tonight. Most of the newspaper critics were disappointed.
The Great Northern Railway and its merger partner, the Northern Pacific Railroad, each reported sharply higher earnings for 1965 yesterday.
THE smile was disarming and the look in those blue eyes as honest and forthright as always. Tony Kubek seemed to be bursting with health.
ITHACA, N.Y., Jan. 26 (UPI) Cornell invaded another Ivy League campus today and signed Jack Musick as its new head football coach.

Fritz Jahoda brought an interesting piano program to Carnegie Recital Hall last night that listed familiar names in off-beat repertory. There was Haydn's Sonata in C (No.50), Schubert's Funf Klavierstucke, Beethoven's Six Bagatelles, three Debussy Etudes, Luigi Dallapicoola's Sonatina Canonica (1942) and Chopin's Rondo in C (Op.73.).
AUSTIN, Tex., Jan. 26 Purchase of half the stock in the Capital Cable Company, Austin's community antenna television system, was announced today by the Texas ...

Prices for futures in two commodities reacted sharply to the supply situation yesterday, but for opposite reasons. In the case of soybeans, a Government report showing bigger stocks on hand than expected sent ...
HONG KONG, Jan. 26 (AP) Time, Inc., and the National, Broadcasting Company are part of an international group that was awarded the franchise for Hong Kong's first wireless television station today.
Directors of Philip Morris, Inc., maker of Marlboro, Parliament, Philip Morris and other cigarettes, voted yesterday a three-for-one split of the common stock.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (UPI) Senator Robert F. Kennedy, Democrat of New York, today proposed spending $22.5million a year in Federal funds to treat the nation's drug addicts as patients instead of criminals.
WESTBURY, L.I., Jan. 26 Duke Darnley, a 5-year-old trotter, was removed from his barn at Roosevelt Raceway today as a precautionary measure against an outbreak of swamp fever.
ATHENS, Jan. 26 The Greek Government tonight ordered the mobilization of Athens's trolley-bus crews, whose three-week strike has disrupted the main transit system.
TRENTON, Jan. 26 The Democrats and the Republicans reached a compromise today that will assure a bipartisan Constitutional Convetion in March on legislative reapportionment.
The United States has dropped to 12th place among the shipbuilding nations of the world, Lloyd's Register of Shipping reported yesterday.

DETROIT, Jan. 28 (UPI) Tom Gola and Emmett Bryant combined for closing period spurts tonight to lead the New York Knickerbockers to a 115103 victory over the San Francisco Warriors in a National Basketball Association game.

YONKERS, N.Y., Jan. 26 Police officials here were surprised today to discover that the arson suspect they had been seeking throughout the eastern states since yesterday was already in the custody of the Westchester County Family Court at White Plains.

The Westinghouse Electric Corporation has joined the elite group of some 30 American companies whose earnings total $100 million or more a year. Its net income for 1965 reached $106,903,000, D.C. Burnham, president, reported yesterday.

Morris Gold, the first prosecution witness in the trial of former Assemblyman Hyman E. Mintz, testified yesterday that Mr. Mintz had advised him to give evasive and unrevealing answers to a grand jury.

FORT NELSON, B.C. Travelers on the dusty Alaska Highway long ignored Fort Nelson as just a spot in the muskeg. But this frontier town at the 300-mile post has flourished in recent years on major discoveries of natural gas.
The spot rate on the British pound rose 6 points above the Wednesday level to close at $2.8084 in moderate trading on foreign-exchange markets here yesterday.

John D. Harper, president of the Aluminum Company of America and chief target of the Johnson Administration in the recent "aluminum war," urged businessmen to accept Government interference in their affairs but to learn to deal with it.

The United States Treasury's offering of 5 per cent notes was greeted enthusiastically by potential investors yesterday, and New York City's $253.24million bond offering was reported late last night 82 per cent sold.

Robert Cannon, a state circuit judge in Wisconsin, was named full-time administrator by the major league player representatives yesterday. He received a five-year contract and a $50,000 annual salary.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 27 (UPI) Gene Mauch had his contract as manager of the Philadelphia Phillies extended for a year through 1967 today and looked into 1966 with the conviction that the Phils were one of the two National League teams that fared best in offseason deals.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 (AP) The Defense Department sent the Selective Service System a draft call today for 32,900 men in March, Selective Service. said.

MANHASSET, L.I., Jan. 27 -James Ruderman, a structural engineer who designed many of the major office buildings in New York City, died of a heart attack today while going to work on the Long Island Rail Road. He was 67 years old and lived at 28 Norgate Road here.

Mr. and Mrs. Walker Gentry Buckner of 120 East End Avenue and Fishers Island, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Gentry Buckner, to Douglass Nelson Loud. He is the son of Nelson Montgomery Loud of New York and Locust Valley, L.I., and the late Mrs. Cathryn Douglass Loud.
Carl M. Loeb, Rhoades Co., investment bankers and members of the New York Stock Exchange, announced yesterday the admission of Robert R. Rose as a general partner.
HOLLYWOOD, Fla., Jan. 27 (UPI) The defending chamions, Mrs. Nancy Roth Syms and Maureen Crum, scored a first-round viotary today in a Hollywood international women's four-ball golf tournament.
PARAMARIBO, Surinam The discovery of oil by workmen digging a well in a schoolyard just west of here in October dominated another year of steady progress in this Third Province of the Netherlands.
CHAPEL HILL, N.C., Jan 27 (A) Harry B. Murkland, a former associate editor of Newsweek magazine, died of burns received yesterday in a fire in his room at a nursing home here. His age was 64.
The city was warned yesterday by a top financial consultant to stop borrowing and get back to paying its bills with current funds.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 The Government disclosed today its basic ideas for improving the world monetary system, focusing on the creation of a new international money.
BOGOTA, Colombia "The studied ineptitude in our Government lacked only the appearance of the Marx Brothers to make the situation credible," said one angry businessman in describing Colombia in 1965.

CHICAGO Jan. 27 (AP) The National Basketball Association officially awarded a franchise to the Chicago Bulls today for $1.6-million. The 10th league member was assigned to the Western Division, shifting the Baltimore Bullets from the Western to the Eastern Division.

A bill to require the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority to coordinate highway planning with the City Planning Commission will be filed in Albany by two Manhattan legislators. State Senator Whitney North Seymour Jr. announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 The Defense Department refused today to permit the burial in Arlington National Cemetery of Robert G. Thompson, a decorated World War II veteran who was later convicted as a top Communist conspirator.

MAPLEWOOD, N.J., Jan. 27 Erwin Bruce Hallett, senior member of the law firm of Hallett and Wirth, 61 Broadway, New York, died yesterday at a nursing home in Madison, N.J. He was 79 years old and a resident here for many years.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 About 2.2 million people moved above the poverty line last year, President Johnson said today in his Economic Report.
Indoor tennis, long in the doldrums here, reaches an apogee tonight with two tournaments, the Eastern indoor clay championships and the metropolitan indoor event, running at the same time.

DAVOS, Switzerland, Jan. 27 (Reuters) Rudi Liebrecht of the Netherlands won the international speed-skating competition today, although he finished no higher than third in any of the two-day competition four events.
A spot check of American companies whose names appeared on a list of raided trademarks shows most have taken legal action to protect themselves, some with quick success.
BONGSON, South Vietnam, Jan. 27 Even in the Airmobile Division, somebody always has to go by truck.
ENGLEWOOD CLIFFS, N.J., Jan. 27 Jack D. Conn, an executive with Bregman, Vocco and Conn, music publishers, died here today in his home after a brief illness. He was 39 years old.
ELATH, Israel, Jan. 20 "Sir did you know there were beatniks in your garden!"

The by-election in Hull, England, kept a number of buyers on the sidelines yesterday at the London Stock Exchange, waiting to see if there would be a shift in the balance of power in Parliament. The upshot was a moderate decline is prices practically across the board.

Eugene Lane Wells, certified public accountant and partner in the firm of Main Lafrentz Co., died Wednesday night at the Harkness Pavilion, Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. He was 59 years old and lived at 345 West 58th Street.
ABOUT a month ago a Soviet literary critic con demned Ilya Grigoryevich Ehrenburg's defense of the Soviet literature produced during the nineteen twenties.

LA PAZ, Bolivia Record prices for tin, which accounts for 70 per cent of this nation's foreign-exchange earnings, and good prices for other metals helped Bolivia weather a year of economic reorganization.
OTTAWA Along wellington Street, the Bank of Canada finds itself in tight quarters, squeezed into a squat mausoleum sort of building, designed in the style of 1937 Washington.

EAST ISLIP, L.I., Jan. 27 The engagement of Miss Jean Livingston Hollins to David Lawless has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Robert Livingston Hollins, parents of the bride-tobe. Mr. Lawless is the son of Mrs. Herbert Lawless of Sandusky, Ohio, and the late Mr. Lawless.

Henri Soule, owner of Le Pavilion and La Cote Basque and the most dynamic force in the history of French cuisine in America, died yesterday afternoon of an apparent heart attack at La Cote Basque. He was 62 years old.
SAIGON, Jan. 37 The infantryman's war in South Vietnam is were hard work.
WASHINGTON Cuba had her best sugar crop since 1961 but the economic benefit was limited by the low price around 2 cents a pound.
TORONTO The president of the Toronto Men's Press Club presented the picture of a blacked-out city and said, "Everybody has a bad day once in a while. But you, Ross wow!"
RIO DE JANEIRO This is to be the year of the "strong" cruzeiro.
KINGSTON, Jamaica With high ceremonial protocol involving ministers of state, Jamaica and the Windward Islands have proclaimed a truce in the Great Banana War of 1965.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 Critics in the House made their annual assault on the Committee on Un-American Activities today, but as usual were able to muster only a handful of votes against the panel's request for operating funds.
The Jones Laughlin Steel Corporation reported yesterday that earnings plummeted 25.5 per cent last year as sales rose 4.8 per cent.

SAIGON. Jan. 27 (AP) A survey sponsored by the United States diplomatic mission was reported today to show that the Vietcong were relying almost entirely on conscription of men. Volunteers were said to be extremely difficult to find.
MEXICO CITY The Government's drive to industrialize Mexico may soon oblige the farmer to pay more money for tractors.

Some draft boards, with the blessing of Selective Service Director Lewis B. Hershey, have apparently been accelerating induction as a means of punishment for young men who burn their draft cards or otherwise illegally express their objection to fighting the war in Vietnam. This means of retaliation is a misuse of the draft and a denial of the fundamental principle that the armed forces are not in any sense a penal institution.
ERIE, Pa., Jan. 27 (UPI) Two businessmen and a pilot from eastern Pennsylvania were killed today when their private plane developed engine trouble and crashed near here during a heavy snow squall.

Fanny Rose Shore, born in Winchester, Tenn., and widelyknown as Dinah Shore, the star of 575 coast-to-coast television shows, opened a limited engagement this week at the Plaza Hotel's handsome Persian Room. It is Miss Shores' first nightclub appearance in New York in a decade.

DENVER, Jan. 27 (AP) The judicial council of the United States Court of Appeals for the 10th Circuit today scheduled a hearing on Feb. 10 to give Federal Judge Stephen S. Chandler an opportunity to say why he should not be deprived of his judicial powers The hearing will be in Oklahoma City.

TRENTON, Jan. 27. The National and State Republican chairmen and Young Republican leaders ordered today a purge of New Jersey Young Republicans who had joined in crude anti-Semitic and racist "sing-alongs" at their state and national conventions.

BAYONNE, N.J., Jan. 27 Mrs. Mae Rogers Kelly, a retired New York City public elementary school teacher, and widow of Charles E. Kelly, died today in Bayonne Hospital. She was 72 years old and lived here at 20 West 45th Street.
MIAMI, Jan. 27 (AP) Braulio Baeza, a 25-year-old Panamanian rider, today became the first jockey ever to ride five winners at Hialeah in one afternoon.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 President Johnson announced today the appointment of 26 members to the National Council on the Humanities.
LONDON, Jan. 27 Dame Edith Pitt, Conservative Member of Parliament and a former junior minister, died today. She was 59 years old.
President Johnson will come here on Feb. 23 to receive the Freedom House Freedom Award, the White House announced yesterday.

Indoor track, a sport that week in and week out generates excitement by the barrel, returned to Madison Square Garden last night. There were 16,000 spectators, some of whom had paid $25 to scalpers for their seats. They overpaid. Someone forgot to bring the excitement.

The Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) and its affiliates, the world's leading petroleum enterprise, estimated consolidated earnings for 1965 at $1.035-billion, down 1.5 per cent from the $1.051-billion profit of the year before. It was the first annual decline for Jersey Standard in eight years.

NEWARK, Jan. 27 William White, chairman of the board of the Erie-Lackawanna Railroad, said today that the problem of its deficit-ridden suburban passenger service in New Jersey would not be solved merely by raising fares.
DARIS, Jan. 27 There were moments today when the mood was Mexican at the new spring-summer collection of Christian Dior.

Horsemen at Roosevelt Raceway are eagerly awaiting the announcement today by the New York State Harness Racing Commission of results of an investigation into the condition of Duke Darnley, the 5year-old trotter that was hastily removed from the grounds of the Westbury, L.I., track on Wednesday.
BERKELEY, Calif., Jan. 27 (UPI) Peggy Fleming, one of America's top figure skaters, glided to a big lead today in her quest for a third straight national title.
Orders for machine tools set more of a record last year than the builders had expected.
ARCADIA, Calif. Jan. 27 (UPI) Undefeated Saber Mountain raised his stock as a Derby colt today when he captured the $32,250 San Vicente Stakes at Santa Anita by a length and a half.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 May a professional bank robber deduct his attorney's fees as a business expense?

Oil operations by private companies in South America are becoming more difficult. The governments of almost every nation are insisting on more revenue from the private companies and are generally assuming greater control over prices and operations.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 Consumer prices last month made their sharpest December rise in 15 years.
BOWIE, Md., Jan. 27 (AP) Trainers of thoroughbreds now based at Bowie race course have had their stall allotments at Lincoln Downs canceled, presumably because of the swamp fever scare at Bowie.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 New enforcement powers that would enable the Government to crack down more swiftly on banks and savings and loan associations that are following unsafe financial practices endorsed today by President Johnson in his Economic Report.
PORT-OF-SPAIN, Trinidad The first automobile-assembly plant in the West Indies opened here this month as another step toward the industrialization of Trinidad and Tobago.
The Florida Development Commission sold yesterday $21.05-million of bonds to refund a bond issue sold in 1960 to finance causeways and bridges in south St. Petersburg.

Jose Ferrer will be the guest star in "Oedipus Rex" from Feb. 24 to March 5 at the University of Utah's 1,000-seat Pioneer Memorial Theater. The university is spending $18,000 on the production, of which $2,500 will go to Mr. Ferrer.

The American and Foreign Power Company, Inc., and its subsidiaries announced yesterday that preliminary unaudited figures for 1965 showed that net income had reached a record of $13.7-million, equal to $1.85 a share. This compared with $13.1-million, or $1.78 a share, in 1964.
A task force of men interested in widening the horizons of American foreign traders will move out of New York in April on the luxury liner Brasil, bound for east coast ports of South America.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 President Johnson's Economic Report illustrates the cruelest paradox of war: increased prosperity for many, increased sacrifice for many more.

Governor Rockefeller, who called himself a "frustrated architect," last night received some degree of recompense for that regret: The American Institute of Architects gave him its highest honor for a man who is not an architect.

ROBERT LEE, personnel director for Shell Oil Company, has lost 12 pounds since last fall. Frank Carter, Shell's director of employe activities, has also "shed a few." Over at Mutual of New York, Frank Galucci dropped between 20 and 25 pounds.
LONDON, Jan. 27 The Labor Government won a landslide victory in the crucial by-election in Hull tonight.

SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic--A civil war is, apart from its horrors, a luxury that a developing nation can ill afford. The Dominican Republic, which showed a deep production slump instead of growth last year, was saved from complete economic and social collapse following the fighting only by huge amounts of United States aid.

CARACAS, Venezuela Latin America's wealthiest country enjoyed a record economic year in 1965. The enviable gains in industry and business, however, failed to mask concern over disturbing effects of growing nationalism and the lag in social progress.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 Andrew Green Lynch, the first ambassador of the United States to the Somali Republic, died Tuesday at his home in Barneveld, N.Y., at the age of 63.

CHICAGO, Jan. 27 The Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. made a peace pact today with the Chicago Police Department under which he will take personal responsibility for keeping the department informed of his group's activities, even those that might result in arrests.
The huge American cotton surplus of more than 15 million bales presents a problem that the textile industry must help solve, Orville L. Freeman, Secretary of Agriculture, said here last night.

About 75 customers and 20 employes fled a one-alarm fire at the Stage Delicatessen last night. A crowd of several hundred persons watched firemen fight the blaze from 7:17 P.M. to 8:05 P.M., when it was declared under control.
ATHENS, Jan. 27 Three Greek composers, in a protest against censorship, withheld all their music from the public today.
NEW DELHI, Jan. 27 The new Indian Government decided today to raise the rice ration in Kerala state in as effort to stave off a general strike and possible violence there tomorrow.

Dr. and Mrs. Gerhard Nuyken of Berlin and Seoul, South Korea, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Sabine Eva Nuyken, to Pfc. Timothy Clark Bryant, U.S.A., son of Mr. and Mrs. Alan Willard Bryant of New Canaan. Conn.

IT may be assumed on the evidence that it is not for any lack of quality or power of articulating what it has to say that Joseph Losey's "King and Country" is so late in being released in New York following its production in England and its one showing here at the Lincoln Center Film Festival in 1964.
Roy Goodman, the city's director of finance, said last night that Mayor Lindsay's administration would have to impose new taxes, including an income tax, to meet its financial needs.
WILMINGTON, Del., Jan. 27 Frederic A. Wardenburg, a member of the board of directors of E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co. since 1939, died today at his home. He was 84 years old.
SUDBURY, Ont. On a raw night last autumn, the local hockey arena was packed with 2,300 members of the Quarter Century Club of the International Nickel Company of Canada. Ltd.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 27 The gap between what, the United States is doing in. Vietnam and what most of the United Nations thinks should be done is growing wider every day.

Why does a company that distills liquor, and also makes food products, use the courts to enforce fixed retail prices on its vodka and bottled cocktails while neglecting to fix retail prices on its steak sauce?
TORONTO Oliver Goldsmith said it first in, "The Deserted Village":
Baseball's wandering Braves, who have sold one million dollars' worth of season tickets in Atlanta, were ordered by a Wisconsin judge yesterday to prepare to open the season in Milwaukee.

In the Metropolitan Opera's thoroughly splendid presentation of Beethoven's "Fidelio" last night Ezio Flagello, making his first appearance of the season in the role of Don Fernando, the Minister of State, made shiningly clear why a company always brings out one of its big guns for this role, one of the briefest in all opera.
HAMILTON, Ont. Canadian steel production, which increased 8.7 per cent last year to about 9.85 million ingot tons, is expected to rise 9 per cent more this year to 10.7 million tons.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Jan. 27 All Brazilian ports were declared national security zones today. The declaration makes strikes or slowdowns by dock workers a military crime.
NEW HAVEN, Jan. 27 The Connection Supreme Court has agreed to review the negligent homicide conviction of Michael V. Smith, a figure in the 1964 Darien teen-age drinking scandal.

CHICAGO, Jan. 27 About 200 representatives from all the states, the District of Cohunbia, Puerto Rico, the Virgin Islands and Canada gathered here today to explore the potentfalities and problems of public patronage of the arts.
The number of business failures in Canada rose to 2,533 in 1965. This was the fourth consecutive year in which bankruptcies have risen.
BOGOTA, Colombia "Don't ask us where we fly; just tell us where you want to go." This proud slogan of the bush pilots here has become the slogan of Colombia's national line, Avianca.

MOSCOW, Jan. 27 The United States Embassy rejected today the Moscow radio allegations that it had been indifferent to the fate of Newcomb Mott, the 27-year-old American tourist Who was said to have committed suicide last week while in Soviet custody.

Two inches of snow fell in New York yesterday morning, according to the United States Weather Bureau. But the effect on the drought-stricken city's upstate watershed was "practically null," a spokesman for the city Department of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity said.

Douglas Dillon, former Secretary of the Treasury, has been named a director of the Chase Manhattan Bank. Chase, which has $15.3-billion in assets, is the second-largest commercial bank in the country after the Bank of America.
Real Estate Commissioner Frank L. Lazarus has submitted his resignation to Mayor Lindsay.
Passengers on North American airlines that serve Latin America's west coast, who have long been accustomed to hearing flight information in English and Spanish, are now listening to Japanese.
The stock market turned to the downside yesterday after the opening transactions had been cleared, and at the close advances and declines were about evenly matched.
The New York State Assembly plans to have electronic voting machinery ready for next year's legislative session. This is an admirable move and the only wonder is why it was so long in coming.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 Mrs. Willard J. Hall of Washington and Rehoboth Beach, Del., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Mary Theresa Hall, to Benjamin Postell Fishburne 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Fishburne Jr. of Washington.

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 27 (UPI) Busch Stadium, which has echoed to Cheers for such baseball immortals as Rogers Hornsby, Dizzy Dean and Stan Musial, was donated today to the Boys' Club by the St. Louis Cardinals.

GENEVA, Jan. 27 Pope Paul VI called for the "blessing of Almighty God" on the Disarmament Conference, which resumed here today after a four-month recess amid growing international tension over Vietnam.
MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay The badly shaken economy of Uruguay managed to struggle to its feet as 1965 drew to a close, only to face another year of hard decisions.
MEXICO CITY As 1965 ended, Mexican businessmen were feeling proud of themselves. They had had a good year and took a large part of the credit for the general advance of the country as a whole.
The Bank of America, San Francisco, the nation's largest bank, has applied for and has received "trading privileges" on the Pacific Coast Stock Exchange.

MEXICO CITY This country's paper and pulp industry appears to be entering a decisive phase in which it can either remain static or become in a relatively short time one of the most advanced in Latin America.

GREAT NECK, L.I., Jan. 27 Mr. and Mrs. Samuel A. Zimbalist have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Michelle S. Zimbalist, to Renato Rosaldo Jr., son of Dr. and Mrs. Rosaldo of Tucson, Ariz. They plan a June wedding.

ENGLEWOOD, N.J., Jan. 27 The Yale Alumni Association of Bergen County and vicinity will give its annual Yale Whiffenpoof Dance Feb. 5 at the Edgewood Country Club in River Vale. Henry P. Becton of Englewood and Alfred L Test Jr. of Ho-ho-kus are co-chairmen of the event and vice presidents of the association.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Jan. 27 (AP) Gary Player shot a six-under-par 65 today, breaking the Parkview course record in the first round of the $3,500 Transvaal open golf tournament.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 Fifteen Democratic Senators sent a letter to President Johnson today urging him to continue the pause in the bombing of North Vietnam.
A former executive on the Ford account in the Detroit office of the J. Walter Thompson Company, Inc., will soon be named director of advertising and sales promotion for the Ford Motor Company.
The famed Athabasca tar sands of Canada are at long last about to yield their oil content to an energy-hungry world.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y. National elections are scheduled for March 6 to return the country from a military to a constitutional regime. Meanwhile, it was business as usual for Guatemala.

Henri Soule was the Michelangelo, the Mozart and the Leonardo of the French restaurant in America. He was a man of towering standards with cool disdain for the commonplace and the sham and a keen appreciation for those who dined in his company on vintage champagne (almost al

John Francis Dailey Jr., who was chief assistant United States Attorney here 30 years ago and is now a practicing lawyer, was indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury in Brooklyn on stock fraud charges.

PARIS The Soviet Union's Asian diplomatic offensive has so far concentrated on hemming in China. Kosygin in Tashkent, Shelepin in Hanoi and Brezhnev in Ulan Bator, Outer Mongolia's capital, have had success in terms of Soviet national policy.

PANAMA CITY A firm Government policy against demonstrations by either the far right or the far left, plentiful credit for sound enterprise, and the clearing up of $10-million of national debt helped to make 1965 a year of fairly brisk business for Panama.

TOKYO, Jan. 27 Talks between representatives of the All-Japan Seamen's Union and two shipowner organizations were suspended without agreement this afternoon, dashing hopes for an early end of Japan's biggest and costliest maritime stoppage.
OTTAWA In the year ahead the use of Canada's tremendous water resources may become the critical issue in United States-Canada relations.
VANCOUVER, B.C. "We're going to try to forget sorrow. We're going to concentrate on happy things."
William Warfield lifted Mendelssohn's oratorio "Elijah" to his broad shoulders last night and carried off a stirring performance.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y. Just a week before Christmas an unusually portentous dedication took place in Fort-deFrance, on the island of Martinique. It marked the opening of the newly constructed Bakoua Hotel, an establishment symbolizing a resurgent drive to add new luster to the "pearl of the Artilles."
CHICAGO, Jan. 27 A Federal Distriot Court jury deliberated for the third day today without reaching verdict in the Krebiozen fraud and conspiracy case.
Directors of United Air Lines, Inc., voted yesterday a two-for-one common stock split.

A quiet but bitter debate on the function of the city parks broke into the open yesterday with the request by the Citizens Housing and Planning Council that the new curator of Prospect Park be discharged.
Ellison L. Hazard, president of Continental Can Company, was elected to the board of the Kennecott Copper Corporation, yesterday.
LIMA, PERU What would have been another year of solid progress here was marred somewhat by diverse problems:

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica AsPresident Francisco J. Bolmarich Orlich's term of office ends, Costa Rica's elections Feb. 6 may bring a change in economic policy if the opposition coalition prevails over the Government's own candidate.
LANSING, Mich., Jan. 27 The presidents of the four major automobile companies met tonight with Michigan legislators for a discussion of the highway safety problem.
ASUNCION, Paraguay The completion of a road from this landlocked country to the Brazilian port of Paranagua on the Atlantic coast dominated the economic news here in 1965.
CIUDAD GUAYANA, Venezuela A vast "new" city is rising here on the empty, grassy plains of southern Venezuela. So new is Ciudad Guayana that it appears on few maps printed within the last year.

GAYENNE, French Guiana This sleepy South American corner of France was thrust into the space age last year as work began on a $75-million missile and rocket research center in the jungle about 30 miles west of this capital.
OTTAWA The Canadian labor movement, with 1.6 million members, is showing steadily Increasing energy and vigorand a militancy new to Canada ...
Governor Rockefeller has quietly commuted the death sentences of two holdup men convicted of the 1962 murder of two New York City detectives.

New York borrowed $253,240,000 yesterday equivalent to $32.54 for every man, woman and child in the city and found it had to pay more interest on the loan than at any other time since May, 1932, when the city was in the toils of an earlier financial crisis.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 Senior British Cabinet ministers told American officials today that Britain intends to continue her "world" defense role.

The Chemical Bank New York Trust Company and the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company announced yesterday that they were increasing their rates on unsecured personal loans from 4 per cent discounted in advance to 5 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 (AP) The Senate confirmed I today without debate President Johnson's nomination of Roger W. Wilkins to be Director of the Community Relations Service, set up under the 1964 Civil Rights Act to mediate racial disputes.

The Kammermusiker of Zurich helped celebrate Mozart's 210th birthday, to the day, when the group made its American debut last night in the ConcertParty series being held this season in the Bowman Room of the Biltmore Hotel.

GEORGETOWN, British Guiana British Guiana's year-old coalition Government has succeeded in laying a foundation for speedy economic development in this British territory, which attains independence May 26.

TOKYO, Jan. 27 Premier Eisaku Sato, with his eyes fixed warily on a general election, faces difficult tasks in carrying out his pledges to end Japan's economic recession, help bring peace to Asia and modernize his conservative party.

FRANKFORT, Ky., Jan. 27 The Kentucky Legislature adopted overwhelmingly today a tough new law to curb the surface or strip mining of coal. The industry's virtually uncontrolled growth here had prompted an angry citizens' uprising.
MILWAUKEE, Jan. 27 (UPI) The annual Milwaukee Journal track meet held for the last two years as the United States Track and Field Federation indoor, championships has been canceled for this year.
Youth beat a path to the airlines yesterday when a new half-fare plan went into effect for persons 12 through 21 years old.
INUVIK, Northwest Territhe Arctic Circle, atop a thick building its first Arctic city.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 (UPI) For millions of schoolchildren, this may be the last school year in which they can buy milk during recess at reduced prices.
MEXICO CITY This country's industrial growth for 1965 will probably prove, when all the statistics have been compiled, to be greater than the 13 per cent increase in 1964, government authorities say.
WINNIPEG, Manitoba When it came time for the Winnipeg Sales and Marketing Executives Club to name a Salesman of the Year for 1965, the award went easily to a politician. Gurney Evans.

A selective list of restaurants in New York and vicinity is given every Friday on this page. The restaurants are rated on the basis of four stars to none. The criterion is the food and service in relation to the cost of dining in any particular establishment.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 Secretary of Labor W. Willard Wirtz said today that restricting the inflow of foreign farm labor was only the first step in a Johnson Administration program to improve the lot of the migrant worker.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 Civil rights groups have mounted a campaign for the enactment of strong, comprehensive legislation on law enforcement at this session of Congress.
QUITO, Ecuador Sound fiscal policies and continued investment in industry absorbed most of the rude shocks dealt to this nation's economy early in 1965.

BOGOTA, Colombia The talk at the dinner table got around to taxes, and the host, an importer, told his guests: "We had a bad year. I cleared $40,000 (U. S.) and my lawyer was furious that I paid $35 in taxes. He said that if I insisted on paying taxes I didn't need him."

MONTREAL As the United States and Canadian automobile industries waited last October for President Johnson to sign the expansion-minded auto trade agreement, General Motors of Canada, Ltd., was observing an earlier expansion of its own.
W.R. Grace Co., a widely diversified manufacturing, chemical and shipping concern, announced here yesterday the election of William J. Haude and George F. Mason Jr. as vice presidents.
SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 27 (UPI) Frank Beard, who became a golf star after a nearness, shot a five-under-par 66 today to take the first-round lead in the $50,000 Lucky International golf tournament.

TEGUCIGALPA, Honduras This capital city of 200,000 population looks sleepy and isolated. But there is a group of men in it who are wide awake to outside reality, and 1965 was the year when they tried to make everyone else aware of it too.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 (AP) A Federal judge extended today a temporary restraining order forbidding the Brotherhood of Railroad Trainmen from striking over a Federal arbitration ruling that eliminated 6,000 jobs.

STUART, Fla., Jan. 27 An angler wishing to take a break from the rigors and trials of a snowy northern winter doesn't necessarily need lots of money for a Florida vacation. He can hope for some cooperation from the weather, but he also can get along with a modest amount of cash.

SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, Jan. 27 The Dominican Popular Movement, which describes itself as a Marxist-Leninist party, attacked former President Juan Bosch, one of the leading popular figures here in a clandestine publication distributed today.
TORONTO Self-critical jokes are a staple of Canadian satiric revues. There is the one about Prime Minister Lester B. Pearson's telephoning President Johnson and being asked to spell his name.

The United States National Student Association announced yesterday that it would stage marches today at the Jamaica and Brooklyn campuses of St. John's University to protest the dismissal of 31 teachers.

"IF Kingston were to change its name to Matalon, many residents of Jamaica's capital would regard it as only fitting," an island industrialist remarked last year. He was referring to the multifarious effects that the Matalon enterprises have had and are having on the economy, growth and geography of the port City.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 A change in the basic approach to regulation of rates for freight transportation was proposed today by President Johnson in his Economic Report to Congress.
TRENTON, Jan. 27 Robert L. Goldman, the radio moderator who said he was attacked late last night while he was on the air, returned to work today. He vowed "to continue to damn right-wing extremists.
LONDON, Jan. 27 Ronald Owen Lloyd Armstrong-Jones, father of the Earl of Snowdon, died today at his home at Plas Dinas, Caernarvonshire, Wales. His age was 66.

BOGOTA, Colombia, Jan. 27 A parliamentary commission has demanded a thorough investigation of Operation Simpatico, a research program designed to test the effectiveness of military and civic action in rural areas.

Joseph C. Wilson, president of the Xerox Corporation, told the New York Society of Security Analysts last night that the company was going to hold a big party in Rio de Janeiro within the next 10 years.
Grey Advertising, Inc., has paid the price for two recent account acquisitions, and for the money, it was apparently a bargain.

The formation of a Committee on Alcoholism to study and plan services for the metropolitan area was announced yesterday by the Community Council of Greater New York, a health and welfare organization.

HAMILTION Bermuda On the basis of available indications the economy of this resort island appears to have leveled off last year despite a 25 per cent increase in the number of visitors staying in hotels.
TWO devices designed to take the "rock 'n' roll" out of boating appeared in adjoining fourth-floor booths at the recent National Boat Show.
PARIS, Jan. 27 The United States has asked Monaco to quash the raid being made there on trade names.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 President Johnson told Congress today that the nation could continue to have rapid growth in the economy and lower unemployment this year without a serious rise in prices.

You are aware how closely we follow the efforts of the United Nations to promote peace. Now that the 18-nation committee on disarmament is to resume its work at Geneva, we wish to address to you as urgent appeal, inspired by the desire to see the work of this committee culminate in positive and concrete results, and thus mark a new advance towards the achievement of disarmament, which is so unanimously awaited and desired.
RIO DE JANEIRO After increasing exports to a 14-year high of $1.6-billion last year, Brazil is taking steps to get an even larger share of world trade this year.
RIO DE JANEIRO The Latin-American nations are making painfully slow but significant headway in the epic development struggle of the Alliance for Progress.

William Epton, the 33-yearold Communist who was convicted of criminal anarchy and spreading the Harlem riots of 1964, was sentenced yesterday to a year in jail. In imposing sentence, Supreme Court Justice Arthur Markewich said Epton envisioned himself "as a hero, a leader, a Lenin, a Trotsky, a Castro."

THE reasons that may motivate a player to dou ble are thoroughly documented in bridge literature. Apart from routine penalty and take-out doubles, the latter category including negative and responsive doubles, there are optional doubles, cooperative doubles, negative slam doubles, inhibitory doubles including the exotic striped-tail ape double and a variety of lead-directing doubles.

At the recent fifteenth Pugwash meeting, held in Addis Ababa, an unusually large number of distinguished Africans joined with physical and social scientists from the more industrialized Communist and non-Communist nations to discuss problems of common interest.
Twelve persons were injured yesterday when three upper floors of a 103-year-old loft building collapsed at Broadway and Grand Street in lower Manhattan.

The American Telephone and Telegraph Company and the Western Union Telegraph Company have again begun a discussion of the possible sale of A. T. T.'s teletypewriter exchange service TWX to Western Union.
An evaluation of television shows published yesterday in Parents' magazine said that "The F.B.I" was "unsuitable for children because of preoccupation with crime."
STELCAM, Sask. His wife's blue Thunderbird is seven years old, and their furniture still comes from Moose Jaw Hardware. Booker Cornea makes $16,000 a year, but he's in no hurry to flash it around.
Luis Dominguez of New York, one of the most talented of the rising young court tennis players, defeated A. Haddon Tomes Jr., of Tuxedo Park. N.Y., yesterday in the United States open championship.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 The aluminum research submarine Aluminaut, which is capable of diving deeper than any other submarine in the world, is being prepared for shipment to Spain to assist in the search for a missing hydrogen bomb, the Defense Department said today.

WESTBURY, L.I., Jan. 27 The syndication of Orbiter, a New Zealand pacer, was announced today by Del Insko. In co-operation with a group that includes Mickey Miller of the Rochelle Stable and Danny Miller of the Sambe Stables, Insko has bought the 6-year-old gelding from W.S. Bargie for $125,000.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 President Johnson disappeared from public view today as he continued to wrestle with what associates termed an "excruciating" decision whether to order resumption of the bombing of North Vietnam.

SAN SALVADOR Spurred by a continuing industrial expansion, Salvador enters 1966 with confidence in her over-all economic future, despite some uncertainly about her two major export crops, coffee and cotton.
TORONTO When the police paraded George and Viola MacMillan down King Street last fall to be booked, the new reform spirit in Canadian securities regulation was publicly played.
KINGSTON, Jamaica A Jamaican buttering his bread has an apt illustration of one of his island's chief economic problems: the butter comes from abroad, yet Jamaica has the cattle to produce its own.
William P. Gwinn, President of the United Aircraft Corporation, was elected yesterday to the board of the Shell Oil Company, enlarging the member of directors for the oil producer to 14.

PALERMO, Sicily, Jan. 27 (AP) An Italian judge today cleared Calogero (Charles) Orlando, a United States citizen, of accusations that he participated in a movement linking the Sicilian Mafia and the American Cosa Nostra.
HALIFAX, N.S. In Canada's laggard Atlantic provinces, friendship is evident toward what people call "the Boston States."
WILLEMSTAD, Curacao A small ray of light pierced the deepening clouds of unemployment late last year as work began on a Hilton luxury resort here and on a similar Sheraton hotel on nearby Aruba.
BUENOS AIRES the Argentine economy, which abounds in paradoxes, has produced a beauty in its tumbling securities market.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 The Johnson Administration's decision to hold the guideposts for noninflationary labor agreement at 3.2 per cent for 1966 set off opposite reactions today within labor and management.

ABERCROMBIE FITCH held a preview of its Bermuda Week promotion yesterday with a combination of sun and sports fashions, calypso singers, rum swizzles and a Bermuda bobby who had sensibly worn his winter uniform.
Dividend payments declared payable by Canadian companies in 1965 ran at a record rate for the seventh consecutive year.

Manhattan Borough President Constance Baker Motley, whom President Johnson has just named to fill a vacancy on the Federal District Court, is a capable lawyer who has specialized in civil rights, was an alert and uncompromising back-bench State Senator and served the city well as a Borough President and member of the Board of Estimate. She has a questioning, logical mind, a firm grasp of the law and and abiding sense of social justice.

SANTIAGO, Chile Latin America's first Christian Democratic Government spent its initial year in office here planning sweeping economic and social reforms amid growing opposition from right-wing and left-wine interests.

Secret meetings, surveillances and the use of concealed tape recorders formed the core of testimony yesterday at a Buildings Department hearing for a high-ranking inspector suspended on charges of taking kickbacks.
WARSAW, Jan. 27 Warsaw in January is gray but not grim. Night falls early, but lights are bright and people stay out late.
Mayor Lindsay and City Council President Frank D. O'Connor collided yesterday or plans to bring government "closer to the people."
On Valentine's Day, Feb. 14, supporters of the Gallery of Modern Art will go to the movies, where they will also drink and dance.
MEXICO CITY The five modest countries of Central America that have formed a modest common market did more than modestly well in 1963.

The American Stock Exchange ended mixed yesterday as late selling again nullified earlier gains. This was the third consecutive session in in which the market weakened in the last hour or so of trading on selling pressure.
Mayor Lindsay announced the appointment of two Reform Democrats yesterday to the Rent and Rehabilitation Administration.
The Federal Reserve, anticipating the Treasury's $13-billion refunding, which is now in progress, moved to keep the money market on an even keel in the week ended Wednesday night.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 (UPI) The big four of the United States auto industry agreed reluctantly today to go along with President Johnson's proposal to restore excise tax cuts on cars to help finance the Vietnam War.
It seemed yesterday that no matter which railroad report one looked at one could find a variety of records being broken.
BUENOS AIRES The economic record to be written by Argentina this year will depend on how seriously she tries to put her inflation-racked house in order.
SAO PAULO, Brazil The undeveloped potential for beef cattle production in Brazil is receiving strong incentives now after a long period of discouraging Government controls.

EDMONTON, Alberta As Canada's northernmost big city, where January weather is 30 below zero, Edmonton has grown as a supply depot for the fur trade, Klondike gold fields, Peace River farmlands, the United States Army, Alberta oil and gas, Northwest Territories minerals and the Athabasca tar sands.
CAMPOS, Brazil "We are, not ungrateful to sugarcane. It made this community. But now we have to diversify," said the planter.

SYDNEY, Australia, Jan. 27 (AP) Arthur Ashe of Richmond, the men's favorite, and two American women, Nancy Richey and Mrs. Carole Graebner, scored straight-set victories today to gain semi-finals in the Australian national tennis championships.
Mayor Lindsay, donning a yamilke, offered his condolences yesterday to the widow and three daughters of a Lower East Side clothing shop owner who was slain in a holdup Monday.
BOSTON, Jan. 27 (UPI) Pit Martin scored four goals tonight to lead the Boston Bruins to a 5-3 triumph over the Chicago Black Hawks.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., Jan. 27 Miss Margaret Elizabeth Singleton and Walter D. Clark Jr., son of Walter D. Clark of Essex, Conn., and the late Mrs. Jane Schley Clark, plan to marry in June in Washington.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 Intercity truck tonnage and estimated rail freight ton-mileage in the week ending Jan. 22 were both considerably above the level of the corresponding week of 1965.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 The State and Commerce Departments are closely following reports of trademark raiding through registrations in Monaco, and are studying the situation to determine whether any action by the United States Government would be helpful.

New York State was judged responsible yesterday for the death by negligence of a 6year-old mentally retarded boy who became a "walking skeleton" after his admission to the Willowbrook State School on Staten Island.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 (AP) Senators seeking to block an effort to make union shop contracts permissible in all states urged today that this bill be dropped in favor of legislation limiting the right to strike.

CHARLESTON, S.C., Jan. 27 Maj. James A. Nelson, U.S.A.F., and Mrs. Nelson have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Judith A. Nelson, to Howard G. Meyers Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Meyers of Woodside, Queens, New York, and East Patchoeue L.I.
LUXEMBOURG, Jan. 27 Five of the six members in the European Common Market composed some of their differences yesterday and today but remained divided on the key issue, voting.
A tentative agreement has been reached on the formation of a major new bank holding company in upstate New York.
MEXICO CITY Mexican farmers have been so successful that the government has had to take steps to limit production in certain products.

The 39-man crew of the cargo ship Seatrain New Jersey faced the bleak prospect last night of riding out gale-force Atlantic winds and 20-foot seas with railroad cars and truck trailers rolling loose on her decks.
STRATTON MOUNTAIN, Vt., Jan. 27 Some of the greatest professional ski racers in the world have been nursing a well-guarded secret. They have trouble doing a topflight snowplow.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y. In three years, the private peace corps called Accion demonstrated in Venezuela that an urban slum could become a selfreliant community.

COLLEGE PARK, Md., Jan. 27 DeMath High of Hyattsville, Md., beat Boys High of Brooklyn, 82-67, and Rice of Manhattan rallied to defeat St. John's of Washington, 66-49, tonight to set up a meeting of unbeaten teams in Saturday's final at the University of Maryland's Cole Fieldhouse.

The Olin Mathieson Chemical Corporation reported yesterday a 21 per cent increase in earnings last year, a new high. It also set a new sales peak for the fifth year in a row, Gordon Grand, president, said.
FORT WAYNE, Ind., Jan. 27 (AP) Boston withstood repeated Detroit challenges tonight to capture a 131-112 National Basketball Association victory from the Pistons.
Two tenement fires in the Bronx and one in Brooklyn claimed the lives of eight children yesterday. The youngsters ranged in age from 2 months to 6 years.
Former Mayor Robert F. Wagner caught up on some mail yesterday, paid some bills, dropped in at his law office, and made his first public appearance since leaving City Hall.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 James M. Gavin, retired lieutenant general and former Ambassador to France, was called to the Pentagon last week to discuss with Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara and other officials his criticism of United States policies in Vietnam.

YONKERS, Jan. 27 A 17year-old youth suspected of setting the fire that killed 12 per sons in the Jewish Community Center here last Dec. 20 will probably be charged with firstdegree murder if he is found to be sane.
The wholesale commodity price index fell to 112.3 on Wednesday from 112.4 on Tuesday.

BUENOS AIRES The insatiable thirst for foreign capital in underdeveloped lands often leaves a bitter aftertaste with investors and recipients. This situation is repeatedly manifested by the inability of investors to withdraw profits or capital, in many cases after years of pioneer work under hard conditions.
MIAMI, Jan. 27 (AP) Mrs. Candace Mossler was stricken by a migraine headache today and she was helped from the courtroom where she is on trial for the murder of her wealthy husband. Jacques Mossler.
PRINCE GEORGE, B.C. 'It's crazy here," brags Ed, the waiter.
LONDON, Jan. 27 The ailing trans-Atlantic passenger steamship industry ended a two-day conference here today with a statement that threw little light on what it intended to do about its problems.

SEOUL, Korea, Jan. 27 Bruce Downes, editorial chairman of three publications of the Ziff-Davis Publishing Company in New York, died today in a hospital in Pusan, Korea, after suffering a stroke Tuesday. Mr. Downes, who was 66 years old, arrived in Korea Jan. 3 on a lecture tour sponsored by the United States Information Agency.

THE startling sight of seemingly bare feet pattering along city sidewalks may become a familiar one this spring if some shoe designers have their way. The newest shoe to hit the streets in both Paris and New York is made of seethrough vinyl.

MEXICO CITY The nations of the Central American Common Market have displayed notable success in the field of common financing. The Integration Bank in Tegucigalpa had a striking increase in its capitalization in 1965. It received a $35-million loan from the United States shortly after it may decided to establish within the bank a Fund for Economic lategratian with $7-million contributed by the five countries.

Former State Senator MacNeil Mitchell testified yesterday that while he was head of the Joint Legislative Committee on Housing, he helped organize state-financed housing projects from which his law firm derived at least $427,633 in fees.

WALLINGFORD, Conn., Jan. 27 Mr. and Mrs. Earl G. Leinbach have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Linda Corinne Leinbach, to Peter Benton Ramaley. He is the son of Mrs. George Ephraim Ramaley of Coatesville, Pa., and the late Mr. Ramaley.

MILLERTON, N.Y., Jan. 27 Mr. and Mrs. Gerald Hewes Carson have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Nancy Gay Carson, to Benjamin Calhoun Payne, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas L. Payee of Wilmington, Del.

Leonard Bernstein, back again with the New York Philharmonic after a few weeks' absence, continued his exploration of "Symphonic Forms in the 20th Century" in the orchestra's concert in Philharmonic Hall last night.

Dr. Charles Townes, provost of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, said last night that manned exploration of the moon would probably be cheaper in the long run than study by unmanned vehicles.
ST. GERVAIS, France, Jan. 27 (UPI) Marielle Goitschel, France's Olympic gold medal Alpine skier, won the St. Gervais special slalom today for the second successive year.
OTTAWA Prime Minister Lester B. Pearson started his second minority Government this month With far more sureness in economic policy than two and one-half years ago.

NICOSIA, Cyprus, Jan. 27 About 500 young Turkish Cypriote fighters in an enclave on the northern coast are to be sent to Turkey under arrangements made by the United Nations, reliable sources reported today.

DURBAN, South Africa, Jan. 27 Harold Strachan received a two-and-a-half-year prison sentence today from the magistrate who found him guilty yesterday of having lied about brutality in South African jails. The allegations appeared in articles written for The Rand Daily Mail.
For commodity futures, yesterday was a day of indecisive, downward drifting. Prices for most, major commodities closed lower on relatively little news.

BEWILDERING Ballet Theater, how one loves and hates you! Forgive the prosaic apostrophe but here, at the New York State Theater of Lincoln Center last night, was the American Ballet Theater, the previous night's debacle forgotten, pitching in the mayor leagues. This company is the all-Indiarubber enfant terrible of our dance world, and even when you scold it, you can't help liking it.

IN his role as the Clown Prince of Baseball, Al Schacht has been quick with the quip and fast with the sight gags. But he also has his serious moments, particularly when he comes across an opinion that is entirely contrary to his own, one that has been solidified by more than half a century of close association with the sport.

The ground lease is a device that enables a builder to rent instead of purchase land on which he plans to build.

President Johnson's Economic Report for 1966 exudes confidence. After five years of balanced, noninflationary expansion, the President expects more of the same this year. He acknowledges that the nation is now in a new economic environment, with demand for resources pressing on supply; but he is convinced that his Administration will be as successful in meeting "the challenges of prosperity" as it has been in reaching the present happy state.

MONTREAL As the countdown begins for the opening day of the Expo 67 world exhibition, the farthest thing from anyone's mind is that this extravaganza, the first of its kind in Canada, will turn a profit.

GOTEBORG, Sweden, Jan. 28 (UPI) Raimo Nisula, a promising heavyweight from Finland, knocked out Al Jacobs of Belgium in the first round of a scheduled six-round bout tonight.

Police Commissioner Vincent L. Broderick said yesterday that having outsiders review police behavior would be "an impetus to some policemen to not taking action where they should take action."
New York City's $253.24-million of bonds placed on the market Thursday were reported all sold by noon yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 28(AP) The United States, imposing new economic sanctions against the rebel Government of Rhodesia, asked American importers today to stop buying Rho desian chromite.

JERSEY CITY, Jan. 28 (AP) Superior Court Judge Robert A. Matthews dismissed a contempt of court citation today against the Broadway National Bank of Bayonne and its board chairman, Harvey Dembe, in an issue connected with Anthony DeAngelis.

MEGEVE, France (UPI) Jacob Tischhauster 24-yearold Swiss post office worker sped down the Jallet slope today in 1 minute 54.72 seconds to lead the field at the halfway mark of the Emile Allais Cup giant slalom ski race.

The Saturday Evening Post announced yesterday that beginning with the issue of March 12 the newsstand price per single copy will be increased from 25 to 35 cents. Subscription prices remain unchanged.

Premature babies may grow to be left tackles on a high school football squad, but they have common academic problems through their early years, a medical doctor and a clinical psychologist have determined.
The number of publications dealing with antiques has increased as the market widens.

An emergency inspection program of loft buildings will be started by the Buildings Department early next week in the area where 12 persons were injured Thursday when three floors of a building collapsed.
BOGALUSA, La., Jan. 28 (AP)--A Negro leader warned Ku Klux Klansmen today that if another cross was burned in Negro neighborhoods "we shall strike a match on you, baby."
About 275 students joined the picket lines of striking teachers at St. John's University yesterday.
NEW HAVEN, Jan. 28 Miss Charlotte Elizabeth Seymour, daughter of Prof. and Mrs. Charles Seymour Jr., was married today to Thomas E. Lovejoy 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Lovejoy Jr. of New York.
COLOGNE, Germany, Jan. 28 "If we didn't have kitsch, a German exhibitor said today at the Cologne International Trade Fair, "we would have to invent it."

MOSCOW, Jan. 28 (AP) The body of Newcomb Mott left for Massachusetts tonight, leaving behind a growing SovietUnited States dispute over the circumstances of his death Jan. 20 on a Soviet prison train.
One of the most expensive and complicated shallow holes in Manhattan has been virtually completed.

The Lindsay administration filled a $14,000-a-year post yesterday that Mayor Lindsay had branded last fall as "evidence of the way in which a Democratic administration layers "unwarranted expenditures' on the taxpayers."

Charles G. Moerdler, Commissioner of Buildings, dismissed a buildings official last night on charges of having taken $30 in bribes three hours before the official was to become eligible for retirement.

LONDON, Jan. 28 (Reuters) The International Athletes Club of Britain condemned Mexico City as a site for the 1968 Olympic Games today and attacked the International Olympic Committee for "autocratically and irrevocably" deciding that the games be held there.
ALGIERS, Jan. 28 Forty Moroccan students invaded the Moroccan embassy in downtown Algiers today and held the ambassador, Thami Quezzani, captive for almost two hours.

MOUNT KISCO, N.Y., Jan. 28 Mrs. Elizabeth Breck Eckerson, a granddaughter of Edward B. Wesley, a New York investment banker who provided funds and business guidance in 1851 to help start The New York Times, died yesterday in Northern Westchester Hospital. She was 87 years old and was the widow of Dr. Albert B. Eckerson, a Mount Vernon physician.
A review of 223 special and citizens committees that still are on the city's books was ordered yesterday by Mayor Lindsay with a view to saving money.

GENEVA, Jan. 28 The In ternational Committee of the Red Cross is refusing to accept donations from United States groups for the war victims in North Vietnam and for victims among the Vietcong guerrillas of South Vietnam unless the donors agree to remain unidentified.

Mrs. Rae Berk Harris, widow of Dr. Leon Harris, a physician and dentist, died at Elkins Park, Pa., on Thursday. She was one of the original founders of the Women's American ORT (Organization for Rehabilitation through Training).

Dr. Elias Lincoln Stem, formerly a surgeon here, died of a heart ailment in San Diego, Calif., on Wednesday at the age of 67. He had been known for his research work on nerve block for intractable pain.
Bishop Aloysius Louis Scheerer of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Multan in West Pakistan, an American Dominican missionary, died of a heart ailment Wednesday in Multan. He was 56 years old.
Robert M. Fowler, president of the Canadian Pulp and Paper Association, criticized yesterday the rapid expansion of kraft pulp facilities now under way in Canada.
License Commissioner Joel J. Tyler swore in three deputies yesterday and took the occasion to defend Mayor Lindsay's administration.

The National League voted yesterday to defy a Wisconsin court and committed itself to Atlanta in preference to Milwaukee in baseball's escalating dispute over where the Braves will open the 1966 season.
LAGOS, Nigeria, Jan. 28 Nigeria's supreme commander made public sweeping reforms tonight aimed at eliminating corruption and tribalism and curbing the powers of the old political parties.
Steel issues weakened yesterday on the London Stock Exchange but the market as a whole ended mostly firm.
