BONN, Jan. 28 A twin-engine Lufthansa German Airlines plane, with 42 passengers and a crew of four, crashed tonight while attempting to land at Bremen Airport. No survivors were reported.
John Harllee, chairman of the Federal Maritime Commission, will meet with the Committee of European Shipowners in London on Monday, the regulatory agency announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 Mrs. Lucy Cobb Jones, a diplomatic special editor for the magazine U.S. News World Report, died at the George Washington Hospital here Wednesday after a long illness. She was 53 years old.

ALWIN NIKOLAIS is the great showman of contemporary dance; the Flo Ziegfeld of the upper intellectual crust. He is also a modern dance pioneer of enormous importance. Last night the fine dance subscription series at Hunter College Playhouse continued with Mr. Nikolais's lighthearted, sweetly trivial "Galaxy."
The prognosticators proved to be exceptionally wrong in the Yorkshire by-election of Hull.
Ed Sullivan's statements that Jackie Mason made "obscene gestures" on one of his Sunday night television shows were legally dismissed yesterday.
A leading physicist described yesterday a hypothetical "gravitational bomb" that would be roughly a million times more powerful than any nuclear weapon in existence.
ADELAIDE, Australia, Jan. 28 (Reuters) Graham McKenzie, a medium pace bowler, shattered England's batting today on the first day of the fourth cricket test match.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 Following is the text of the letter of President Ho Chi Minh of North Vietnam to some heads of state and others "interested in the Vietnam situation." The text was broadcast in English by the Hanoi radio today and monitored here.
Directors of the Socony Mobil Oil Company, Inc., raised the quarterly dividend to 80 cents a share from 70 cents and also proposed a two-for-one stock split.
Two more horses at Bowie race track in Maryland were discovered yesterday to harbor swamp fever, the disease that has killed one horse at the track and infected others.
PARIS, Jan. 28 Pierre Cardin is a big leap ahead of anyone else when it comes to creating young-looking clothes that, oddly enough, often look great on quite grown-up women.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), Jan. 28 Israel's longsimmering dispute over the influence of Orthodox Jewish leaders erupted today when a Reform rabbi charged that his congregation had recently been refused permission to worship in two Tel Aviv public halls.
The State Liquor Authority ordered yesterday a 30-day suspension of the liquor license of La Vie Restaurant of 869 Second Avenue, at 47th Street, on the basis of three charges last year.

Mr. and Mrs. Frank C. Wachsmith of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Louise Wachsmith, to George Rodney R. Hatter. His parents are Mr. and Mrs. Ralph Hatter of Linn, Kan.
JACKSON, Mich., Jan. 28 The Consumers Power Company announced today plans to build a $100-million nuclear power plant on a 600-acre site in Lake Michigan 35 miles west of Kalamazoo, Mich.
SAIGON, Jan. 28 Four American fighter-bombers were reported lost in South Vietnam today, and a five-day lull in the ground war ended as significant fighting erupted.
The election of James E. O'Brien, a San Francisco attorney, as a director and a vice president of Standard Oil Company of New Jersey was announced yesterday. It will take effect March 1.
Another installment of the American dream of being a boss went on display yesterday at the New York Coliseum.
LOS ANGELES, Jan. 28 Pale and perspiring, Hedy Lamarr, the 51-year-old movie star, protested today that she was "mystified" by her arrest last night on a charge of shop lifting.

His contemporaries long ago recognized that the acting profession was the loser when Michael J. Quill chose unionism as his career. He was a man who loved to have the last word and to make his entrances and exits with a dramatic flourish.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 (UPI) Postmaster General Lawrence F. O'Brien asked Congress today to increase parcel post rates and to simplify regulations to put the service on a break-even basis.
The American Stock Exchange failed again yesterday to overcome a recent hazard late selling and as a result the market closed mixed in heavy trading.
BUCHAREST, Jan. 28 In the ever livelier world of Bucharest intellectuals, the topic this month is a movie called "Sunday at 6 o'Clock."
Two children died yesterday in a fire in a Bronx tenement, bringing to 10 the total number of fire fatalities in the city in the last two days.

Lehman Brothers, on behalf of the Kewanee Oil Company of Bryn Mawr, Pa., has offered to buy any or all of the outstanding shares of the capital stock of Kendall Refining Company, Bradford, Pa., at $52.50 a share. The offer will expire at 5 P.M. Monday unless extended.
Guests arriving for the Blue Ridge Ball last night closed the Plaza's heavy glass doors on the winter and found a bit of spring inside.
A key witness in the state's case against former Assemblyman Hyman E. Mintz and Carl Kaplan, former Fallsburgh, N.Y., Police Chief, yesterday recanted earlier testimony he had given.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 (AP) A bill calling for the annual allotment of $500-million to eliminate or to abate pollution in the nation's streams, lakes and rivers was introduced today by Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts.
Owen Marsh, designer of women's clothing and a former musical prodigy, died yesterday in his home at 182 West 58th Street of a heart ailment. He was 69 years old.
MIAMI, Jan. 28 (UPI) The selection of a 12-man jury that will try Mrs. Candace Mossler and her nephew for the murder of Mrs. Mossler's millionaire husband was completed today.

BONGSON, South Vietnam, Jan. 28 The outcome of the battle between troops of the United States' First Cavalry Division and more than 500 enemy troops on a sandy landing zone north of Quinhon was still in doubt tonight after eight hours of fighting.

The evidence emerging from the State Investigation Commission hearings on alleged abuses of the Mitchell-Lama Housing Law makes it clear that there is something rotten with the law quite apart from any question of individual ethics. Designed to provide state financing for middle-income projects, the legislation has proved to be a bonanza for lawyers and builders and others with the right political connections.

MONTREAL, Jan. 28 (AP) Bobby Hull, a left wing of the Chicago Black Hawks who is within 11 goals of breaking the National Hockey League record for one season, has taken a solid lead in the balloting for the circuit's most-valuable-player award.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Jan. 28 (AP) Gary Player of South Africa, the United States Open golf champion, helped to rescue one of five children trapped today in a deep monsoon drain at the Parkview golf course. The New Zealander, Bob Charles, a former British Open winner, and other golfers and officials helped to rescue the other four.
MADRID, Jan. 28 It was reliably reported today that contact had been made by sonar and steel cable with a missing United States nuclear weapon.
Kipchoge Keino wants to run in Boston tonight. Boston wants Kipchoge Keino to run in Boston tonight. But his home office has exercised its veto, so instead of running, Keino is flying home to Kenya.
The spot rate on the British pound closed yesterday at $2.8040, down 8 points from Thursday, in moderate trading on foreign-exchange markets here.
EL PASO, Tex., Jan. 28 (AP) The commanding general of Fort Bliss reduced today the sentence of an Army lieutenant who participated in an antiVietnam war demonstration to one year.
Three National Guard armories, several hotels including the Astor and five Y.M.C.A. residences were opened last night to accommodate slum residents without heat over the weekend.

Mrs. Bernard Peyton of Princeton, N.J., and Eugene du Pont 3d of Yemassee, S.C., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Leslie Dudley du Pont, to Cuthbert Latta Myrin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Lars B. Myrin of Ivy, Va.
ROME, Jan. 28 (AP) Mrs. John F. Kennedy arrived for a weekend in Rome today and managed to mingle with throngs of tourists in the city's streets without being recognized.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 The Johnson Administration is said to be planning its course in Vietnam on the assumption that Communist China is nowhere near intervention in the war.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., Jan. 28 The engagement of Miss Susan Lavinia Callis to Daniel Stauffer Raabe Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Raabe of Yonkers, has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. George Crawford Callis, parents of the bride-to-be.
For almost two decades "Kiss Me, Kate," the Cole PorterSam and Bella Spewack musical, has been rolling along from one round-the-world success to another without touching Japan.
Last night's bitter cold hindered firemen as they battled two severe blazes, one in the Bronx and the other on the West Side.

PARIS, Jan. 28 France and the Soviet Union denied today that they had encountered technical obstacles in their joint venture into color television. The countries asid that they would have their system ready for European exhibition by the beginning of April.
Governor Rockefeller confirmed yesterday that he wanted Lieut. Gov. Malcolm Wilson and State Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz to run with him for re-election next November.

Profits for Best Co. in the fiscal year ending Jan. 31 should run about 10 per cent above last year's $971,742, or $1.65 a share, Wilbur J. Allen, president, said yesterday at a special stockholders' meeting.

BONN, Jan. 28 The FockeWulf plant near Bremen, which manufactured one of Germany's most redoubtable fighter planes during World War II, will be used to produce West Germany's first civil jet aircraft. Britain and the Netherlands will share in development costs.
CHICAGO, Jan. 28 (UPI) Loyola rallied tonight to defeat the University of Calif. fornia, Los Angeles, 102-96, its 12th consecutive basketball victory.
LUXEMBOURG, Jan. 28 The prospects for a resolution of the crisis in the European Economic Community improved perceptibly tonight.
BOWIE, Md., Jan. 28 (UPI) Racing resumed at Bowie today after two days of inactivity because of snow and the 7,939 fans on hand saw Prince Afoot win the featured $7,500 Odenton Purse at 55-1.
CAIRO, Jan. 28 The United States is quietly moving toward providing the United Arab Republic with assistance in a major birth control campaign to check the increase in Egypt's population.

SYDNEY, Australia, Jan. 28 (AP) Nancy Richey of Dallas and Mrs. Carole Graebner of Beachwood, Ohio, gained the final of the women's doubles in the Australian national tennis tournament today as the United States continued its revival on the courts.
Mayor Lindsay's new limousine, originally offered to him without cost by the Ford Motor Company, will be leased by the city for "something under $1,000 a year."
Spurred by inflation and scarcity, fine antiques are soaring to phenomenal prices, and New York dealers see no ceiling in the future.

LONDON, Jan. 27 Every concertgoer knows the overture to Rossini's "La Gazza Ladra," but how many have ever seen the opera itself? It had not been heard here since 1883, when it was given in much curtailed form, and even in Italy the original version has not been performed since 1858.
The Landmarks Preservation Commission has designated seven more buildings in Manhattan as landmarks, bringing the total in the borough to 32.
One of the most rewarding screen bills in town is the Museum of Modern Art's program of animated films from 10 countries. This is the museum's first such program.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 28 Leon Cherksey, chairman of the board of Amchem Products, Inc., in Ambler since 1956, died yesterday in Einstein Medical Center here. He was 68 years old and lived in Wyncote.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Jan. 28 The Government is seeking to implicate three of the most important liberal organizations in South Africa in the underground activities of Abram Fischer, the former lawyer who is accused of having been the leader of the banned Communist party.
The student newspaper at the Bernard M. Baruch School of Business and Public Administration published Thursday a two-page list of the editors' opinions on the competence of 51 faculty members.
ATLANTA, Jan. 28 Three Federal judges dismissed today a contention that Representative-elect Julian Bond was denied his seat in the Georgia Legislature because he is a Negro.
James T. Dooley has been promoted to senior financial vice president of John Wanamaker Philadelphia, Inc., Richard C. Bond, president, announced yesterday.
RIDGEFIELD, Conn., Jan. 28 Tomorrow Israel Grossfeld will close his haberdashery shop on this town's quaint Main Street indefinitely and begin an anguished search for his son.
Soybeans and grain futures were firm yesterday on the Board of Trade in Chicago. Cold weather in the Midwest helped strengthen their cash prices.

The Dave Horowitz Quartet took a running leap toward the jazz avant-garde last night at the Renata Theater, 53 East 11th Street. But, despite some fine flurries of discordant sound, the group never quite got away from its traditional roots.

Solomon N. Petchers, real-estate investor, manager, developer and broker and a philanthropist who, his associates say, had given away about $1-million, died Thursday at the Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 65 years old and lived at 200 Central Park South, with all office at 33 Riverside Drive.

A TIMELY and enlightening retrospective of films made by Peter Weiss in Sweden in the 1950's, before he wrote "Marat/Sade," is obligingly being presented by the Film-Makers' Cinematheque in the basement theater at 125 West 41st Street. Showings will be given tonight and tomorrow night at 8 and 10.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 28 (UPI) Frank Beard, the firstround leader by a single stroke, moved three ahead of the field today in the second round in the $57,000 Lucky International golf tournament by firing a 67 for a 36-hole nine-under-par total of 133.
The Federal Reserve Bank of New York is concerned about check-collection problems that stem from the use of the MICR (magnetic ink character recognition) transit-routing system.
ANN ARBOR, Mich., Jan 28 (AP) A circuit jury convicted 29 persons today of trespassing in a sit-in last Oct. 15 at offices of the Ann Arbor draft board.
TORONTO, Jan. 28 The baby-blue Continental convertible pulls up beneath the trees at the stud farm and the woman gets out, smiling and smoothing her floral silk dress. She has come to see the horses.
BRONXVILLE, N.Y., Jan. 28 Mrs. Katherine Young Carson widow of John L. Carson, was married today to Albert L. Williams, president of the International Business Machines Corporation.
NEW DELHI, Jan. 28 Widespread violence broke out today in the southern state of Kerala during a general strike protesting a cut in the rice ration.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 Members of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee openly challenged today the legality of the nation's deepening military involvement in the ... Vietnam war and demanded a detailed explanation of Administration policy.
CHICAGO, Jan. 28 (AP) The jury in the trial of four promoters of the drug Krebiozen deliberated today without reaching a verdict. The seven women and five men on the panel received the case Tuesday.

The Senate of the United States is now engaged in a demeaning exercise. Senator Everett Dirksen, the minority leader, is directing a filibuster against the motion of Senator Mike Mansfield, the majority leader, to call up for debate a bill to repeal Section 14(b) of the Taft-Hartley Act.
The stock market moved down yesterday, with the investmentgrade issues bearing the brunt of the decline. Trading again was brisk.

The difficulties of ecumenical cooperation even when the will is there will be dramatized here next week when the National Lutheran Council holds its 48th and final meeting at the Park Sheraton Hotel.
Sales of antiques in 1965 reached $650-million, an increase of 62 per cent over 1959.

The 11,683-ton Seatrain New Jersey was under way for New York yesterday, escorted by two Coast Guard cutters after spending a night adrift in stormy Atlantic waters some 250 miles east of Cape Hatteras.

W.R. Grace Co. is planning to enter the canned and snack-food business. A tentative agreement for the acquisition of Nalley's, Inc., Tacoma, Wash., a processor of a diversified line of food products, was announced yesterday by W.R. Grace.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 The Securities and Exchange Commission adopted an amendment to its proxy rules that will tighten the required reporting of transactions of corporate officers and directors and other insiders with the company itself or subsidiaries.

J.C. Bradford Co., Inc., as agent of the Seaboard Western Investing Corporation, announced yesterday the company had extended through Feb. 11 its offer to purchase, at $45 a share, the first 450,000 shares of common stock of the Northwestern Insurance Company, tendered under the terms of the offer.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28--The index of wholesale primary market prices advanced one-tenth of 1 per cent to 104.6 of its 1957-59 base during the week ended Jan. 25, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today. Farm products and processed foods rose in price while industrial commodities averaged unchanged.
Michael J. Quill, president of the Transport Workers Union, died yesterday evening of a heart attack 28 days after he had led his union into a transit strike that paralyzed the city for 12 days.
Sandy Koufax continued to reap the rewards of his season's work yesterday. He received the Van Heusen Award for grand performance in baseball, outpolling Willie Mays, Tony Oliva and Smokey Burgess.
ROME, Jan. 28 Italy's Communist party, the largest in the Western world, faced open disagreement among its top leaders today and the possibility of a split.

DETROIT, Jan. 28 Robert B. Evans, 59-year-old millionaire Detroit industrialist, disclosed today that he had acquired more than 200,000 shares of American Motors Corporation stock in the last few weeks.
MIAMI, Jan. 28 (AP) The University of Miami has voided the results of a final examination that was stolen from a professor's office by one student and sold to others.
Lawrence Cardinal Shehan, the Archbishop of Baltimore, yesterday barred the Rev. Gommar A. DePauw, leader of the Catholic Traditionalist Movement, "from any and all exercise of the sacred ministry."

ALEXANDRIA, Va., Jan. 28 Miss Lucinda Lewis Smith, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Howard Worth Smith Jr., was married today to Dr. William Seale Jr. He is the son of Mrs. Seale of Beaumont, Tex., and the late Mr. Seale.

Le Pavillon and La Cote Basque, two of New York's most distinguished restaurants, were closed yesterday because of the death of their owner, Henri Soule. La Cote Basque, under the supervision of Raymond Desgigot, maitre d'hotel, will reopen at noon Monday, and Le Pavillon, under the supervision of Martin Decre, maitre d'hotel, will reopen the following day at noon.
The American Heart Association yesterday named Representative John E. Fogarty, a Rhode Island Democrat, as the recipient of its 1966 Heart-of-the-Year Award.
LONDON, Jan 28 (AP) Betty Stockfield, a well-known British actress, died Wednesday at the home of a sister in Surrey. She was 61 years old.
Prince Charles spent a little more than an hour in New York yesterday, while his Qantas Boeing 707 jet was being refueled at Kennedy International Airport on its way to Australia.
Miss Anne Chi-fang Wang will be married to James Reeve Pusey, the son of Nathan Marsh Pusey, president of Harvard University, and Mrs. Pusey of Cambridge, Mass., and Seal Harbor, Me.

PECANS are indigenous to North American and the name is said to have come from the Indian word for nut. This year the bumper pecan crop suggests using the nuts in all kinds of unusual ways such as in penuchi, a creamy fudge. It is easy to make if a candy thermometer is used to check the temperatures that are critical in its preparation.
BERKELEY, Calif., Jan. 28 (UPI) Scott Allen moved ahead of the defending champion, Gary Visconti, today in his bid to recapture the men's national figure skating title.
ROCHESTER, Minn., Jan. 28 (UPI) Mickey Mantle is recovering so well from his shoulder operation that he has abandoned all thoughts of retiring.
MIAMI, Jan. 28 (UPI) Hialeah split its first turf course stakes race of the season, tomorrow's Palm Beach Handicap, into two divisions today, when 28 grass runners were entered.

RIVERHEAD, L.I. Jan. 28 (UPI) A Suffolk County grand jury today found insufficient evidence of wrongdoing to return an indictment after a five-month inquiry into Islip Town building and land buying practices.
The election of Emil Levin of the Flushing law firm of Levin Levin as a trustee of the Queens County Savings Bank was announced by the bank yesterday.
The Air Force has awarded a $14.1-million contract to the Allison division of the General Motors Corporation for T56 en gines and equipment.

Ruth Laredo, an American pianist who has appeared here in recitals and in chamber-music concerts in the last few years, was presented last night in the Metropolitan Museum's Young Artists Series in the Rogers Auditorium.
ROME, Jan. 28 J. Paul Getty, described as the richest man in the world, said today that he planned to settle in Italy to escape the rigors of the English climate and London smog.
GENEVA, Jan. 28 The Soviet Union is expected to stall negotiations on a treaty to ban the spread of nuclear weapons by insisting on priority for its own draft.
Golf organizations were advised yesterday to have lakes on their property to assure adequate and seasonable water supply.

MRS. LYNDON B. JOHNSON spent most of Thursday and yesterday shopping for clothes here without ever leav ing the Presidential Suite at the Carlyle Hotel. Several designers scurried in with clothes and scurried out again with sealed lips about orders. Geoffrey Beene sent three dresses over on Thursday and it was reported from other sources that Mrs. Johnson chose one a turquoise silk and wool flounced dress.
Deputy Mayor Robert Price said last night that he did not believe President Johnson had "accomplished very much by trying to degrade the recent transit strike settlement."
The General Baking Company announced yesterday the election of John M. Kingsley Jr. as vice presidenttreasurer and M. Frank Cummings as vice president-controller.
TUXEDO PARK, N.Y., Jan. 28 Jack Johnson began the defense of his United States open court tennis championship today with an 8-0, 8-4 victory over Luis Dominguez of New York at the Tuxedo Club.

TOKYO, Saturday, Jan. 29 A 42-year-old son-in-law of Emperor Hirohito and a Ginza bar hostess-owner were found dead last night in the woman's apartment here. The deaths, apparently from suffocation, caused dismay in the Imperial family and a sensation in Japanese news media.
KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, Saturday, Jan. 29 (UPI) Prime Minister Abdul Rahman has been informed of the United States' intention to resume bombing North Vietnam, the newspaper Straits Echo said today.

Governor Rockefeller has, regrettably, rejected a promising plan to insure that one-third of the delegates to the 1967 State Constitutional Convention be selected on a nonpartisan basis. The scheme's lack of appeal in the Executive Chamber doubtless stems from the fact that its sponsor is Howard J. Samuels, an upstate Democrat who himself would like to be Governor.

An education was guaranteed yesterday for the orphan son of a Marine Corps sergeant killed last year in Vietnam in his "only day in action" in 14 years of service.

EAST NORWICH, L.I., Jan. 28 Mr. and Mrs. Harold E. Kester have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Marjorie Diane Kester, to Peter Sheridan Smith. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Smith of Durham, N.H.
A year ago this week, Abram Louis Fischer, a prominent South African lawyer who had been charged with being the leader of the banned Communist party in his country, went into hiding.

GREEN BANK, W. Va., Jan. 25 A clash of cultures on the frontiers of science and nature is ending here with the departure of about 30 top scientists from the National Radio Astronomy Observatory. From now on they will commute 110 miles to work.
Mayor Lindsay announced yesterday that he was prepared to battle the City Council in the streets over his controversial plan to set up local Mayor's offices throughout the city.

This is an extremely valuable and important book because it dares to look at the realities of modern capitalism and report them accurately. HONG KONG, Saturday, Jan. 29 President Ho Chi Minh of North Vietnam has denounced United States offers of unconditional peace talks as "an effort to fool public opinion."
MADRID, Saturday, Jan. 29 (AP) Spain today prohibited all United States planes carrying nuclear weapons from fly- ing over her territory.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 What sort of art should the United States send to the big international exhibitions? On what principles should the selections be made? To whom should the decisions be entrusted? Most important, perhaps, to whom should the selections be addressed?
DETROIT, Jan. 28 (UPI) A strike at the world's largest auto stamping factory may put country out of work if it is not settled by next weekend, a Chrysler Corporation spokesman said today.

THE American Bridge Association was founded in the thirties by Negro players who were barred from regular club and tournament play. This discrimination is a thing of the past, except in parts of the South, and today the Association has cordial relations with the American Contract Bridge League.

BELLEFONTAINE, Ohio, Jan. 28 (AP) The last car of a New York Central passenger train derailed tonight and spun into the path of a New York Central freight train coming in the opposite direction, causing the engine and 40 cars from the freight to derail.

HOLLYWOOD, Fla., Jan. 28 (UPI) A pair of teen-agers, Debbie Austin and Candy Phillips, scored the biggest of three upsets today in the quarterfinals of the women's international four-ball golf tournament. They eliminated the defenders, Mrs. Nancy Roth Syms and Maureen Crum, 4 and 3.

Joseph E. O'Grady put in his last full working day as chairman of the Transit Authority yesterday convinced that transit crises would recur here and that mass transportation in this city could never be self-sustaining.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 (AP) President Johnson and members of his Cabinet joined in prayers for peace today at memorial services for the late Indian Prime Minister, Lal Bahadur Shastri.
RICHMOND, Jan. 28 Grover Cleveland Bergdoll, the most publicized draft dodger of World War I died of pneumonia yesterday in the Westbrook Psychiatric Hospital here. He was 72 years old.

Within three weeks after President Kennedy was assassinated in Dallas a law had been passed by Congress, and signed, providing his widow with suitable office space for a year and also a staff, whose salaries were not to exceed $50,000. Since 1958 widows of Presidents and former Presidents have also had available to them an annual pension of $10,000 and other perquisites.

SAIGON, Jan. 28 (UPI) Lieut. Gen. Nguyen Van Thieu denied today that he ever said United States and South Vietnamese air force planes have been bombing the Communist supply route, the Ho Chi Minh Trail, in Laos.
BONN, Jan. 28 Ford of Germany, having successfully thrown its weight around in West Germany's rough-andtumble auto market last year, is taking steps to build up its productive muscle.

A FIERCE frontier spirit burns in many working New Yorkers. They long to pull up cooperative apartment stakes and live out yonder, close to the soil, where the wild crabgrass grows and the indomitable Volkswagen roams.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 The possibilities of studying the ocean, its storms, currents, shoals and even its marine life from orbiting spacecraft are being actively explored by the Navy and the National Aeronautics and Space Administration.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 A former Klansman wounded while on a Klan mission testified today that the United Klans of America, Inc., had dispatched 1,000 armed members to Plymouth, N.C., last August to put down a Negro demonstration.

YONKERS, Jan. 28 Miss Judy Carmody Lyons, daughter of Mrs. Philip Anthony Lyons of Yonkers and Pine Plains, and the late Mr. Lyons, was married today to Roger Charles Wolf, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Wolf of Cincinnati.
The Lindsay administration will establish in time for the spring semester a program to have college students earn credit by working as internes in the city government.
Dr. Frank Stanton, president of the Columbia Broadcasting System, lashed out yesterday at critics, in and out of Government, of his network's coverage of the Vietnam war.
A dinner and later a theater party to the musical "Sweet Charity" at the Palace Theater will be held on Feb. 2 to benefit the alumnae educational fund of the Ethel Walker School in Simsbury, Conn.

The attempt by Ernest Hemingway's widow to block publication of a book about the author was described in court here yesterday as an action to "suppress or distort the truth" about his mental breakdown before his "suicide."

BOSTON, Jan. 28 (UPI) The Detroit Pistons, paced by Joe Strawder's 29 points, held off a last-minute Boston comeback bid tonight to outlast the Celtics, 108-105, in a National Basketball Association game.
BOSTON, Jan. 28 A massive explosion and fire in downtown Boston tonight wrecked two hotels, killed at least nine persons and injured more than 50 others.
Double-parked cars, including diplomatic vehicles, will be towed away from the theater district during performances under a policy established yesterday by Mayor Lindsay.
The number of major crimes in the city during the transit strike was 15.7 per cent higher than during the same period in 1965, the Police Department reported yesterday.

Ernie Terrell's application for a New York State boxer's license was denied yesterday by the State Athletic Commission because of the Chicago heavyweight's association with Bernie Glickman, allegedly a friend of underworld figures.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 Selective Service headquarters announced today that tests and class standing would be restored as criteria for the deferment of college students.

WESTBURY, L.I., Jan. 28 Dr. Sidney Nusbaum of Herkimer, supervising veterinarian of the State Department of Agriculture, examined the 5-yearold trotter Duke Darnley today at a private farm 70 miles from here. The findings of the examination will be withheld pending the submission of the doctor's reports to the director of the Bureau of Animal Husbandry at Albany.
Prices are going up on electric motors.
SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Jan. 28 (Reuters)--The Rhodesian pound will be valued in terms of gold and not sterling, as it had been in the past, the Ministry of Information announced here.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 28 John A. Glascott, supervisor of intramural sports at the University of Pennsylvania and a former game official of the National Football League, died yesterday of a heart attack while driving on the Roosevelt Boulevard extension of the Schuylkill expressway.

The controversy that began when Deputy Mayor Robert Price's office asked the Police Department to hold open six detectives' posts apparently has been settled, along with police complaints that Mr. Price used police cars for personal purposes.
ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 28 (AP) Isle of Greece was selected today as the probable favorite in a cast of 14 4-yearolds entered in the $134,500 Charles H. Strub Stakes at Santa Anita tomorrow.
NEW DELHI, Jan. 28 A "commercial missile" that could transport 170 passengers from Bombay to New York in 39 minutes was envisioned here today by an American aircraft company executive.

LONDON, Jan. 28 Charles Philip Arthur George, Prince of Wales, Duke of Cornwall, Duke of Rothesay. Earl of Carrick, Earl of Chester, Baron of Renfrew, Lord of the Isles and Prince and Great Steward of Scotland, flew off today for distant Australia and a new experience in princely education.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 28 Secretary General Thant is preparing new feelers on possible mediation of the Cyprus crisis, according to dip lomatic sources.
The election of Dr. Trajano Pupo Netto of Sao Paulo, Brazil, as a director of Anderson, Clayton Co. of Houston, was announced yesterday by S.M. McAshan Jr., president.
SAIGON, Jan. 28 A United States spokesman announced today that there were about 197,000 American servicemen in South Vietnam.

Net income of Texaco, Inc., rose 10 per cent to a record of $636,698,153 last year, from $577,361,048 in 1964, J. Howard Rambin Jr., chairman, reported yesterday. The earnings are equal to $4.71 a share, compared with $4.27 a share a year earlier.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 (UPI) A Senate supporter of the Administration's bill to nullify state "right-to-work" laws called today for an intensive effort by the Democratic leadership to break a filibuster against the measure.

The centennial of Yeshiva Chofetz Chaim, 346 West 89th Street, will be observed tomorrow with a dinner at the New Yorker Hotel. The guest of honor will be Rabbi Hagaon Harav Mendel Zaks, dean of the Yeshiva. Proceeds will go to the school's scholarship fund.

REPRESENTATIVES of the 35 International airlines that operate in the Western Hemisphere will begin a series of meetings in Panama City tomorrow to determine new fares for flights linking North, South and Central America.
Air Canada received the first of 18 twin-jet DC-9 airliners that it has ordered from the Douglas Aircraft Company, the manufacturer said here last week.
BINGHAMTON, Jan. 29-- The State University of New York at Binghamton has taken a Negro state college in Mississippi under its wing in a program of exchanging professors, students and library books.
Broadway participated last night in one of its favorite rituals: the ceremonial comeback of a star in eclipse for many years.
A PHOTOGRAPHER'S work can be evaluated only by his total output, not by individual pictures alone, the late Dorothea Lange told this writer in an interview about 13 years ago.

ALBANY, Jan. 29--State controller Arthur Levitt said today the surplus revenue of the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority would not be enough to bail out New York City's deficitridden Transit Authority.

The head of the Zionist Organization of America yesterday denounced the broadening of the executive of the World Zionist Organization to include religious figures in the governing structure.
The concert given Saturday night at Town Hall by the Dessoff Choirs was a remarkable effort and, in many ways, a remarkable achievement.

SAIGON, Monday, Jan. 31 (AP)--A large Vietcong force Wiped out both a Government militia unit and a relief force in a fierce weekend battle 55 miles south of the big United States air base at Danang, military authorities reported today.
Wind, snow and icy cold struck most of the nation yesterday.
PANAMA, Jan. 30--A fierce political struggle is approaching here with the Panama Canal at stake.
The tightening labor market has caused recruiters to raise their bids for new salemen by more than 4 per cent in 1965, a study by the National Industrial Conference Board indicates.

TOKYO, Jan. 30--Striking Japanese seamen agreed to return to work at 8 A.M. tomorrow, ending the most costly shipping tie-up in the history of this maritime nation. The walkout had idled hundreds of vessels for as much as five weeks of the last 65 days.
LUSAKA, Zambia--For Zambia's copper mines, upon which the country's economy entirely rests, the period since independence in October, 1964, has been marked by increased production and higher profits.

The combined deposits of the nation's 300 largest commercial banks on Dec. 31 amounted to a record total of $208,192,428,631, according to a survey conducted by The American Banker, a trade publication.
Arthur J. Goldberg declared last night that despite the "intransigent" position taken by President Ho Chi Minh of North Vietnam, the United States would continue to press for peace in Vietnam.

Scheduled airlines in this country expect to place 282 new turbine-powered aircraft in service this year, the Air Transport Association of America, reported yesterday. The new planes are valued at $1.4-billion.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 30--The United States lost $72--million of gold in December, bringing the outflow for all of 1965 to $1,664,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

A growing abuse of the term "creativity" in occupational therapy, entertainment and business is vulgarizing original thought in modern society, according to Dr. Michael Wyschogrod, an assistant professor of philosophy at City College.

With 200,000 American troops in Vietnam and growing concern that many more may have to join them there, pressure is increasing in Washington for a formal, full dress Congressional debate on United States policy in this area.

TUXEDO PARK, N.Y., Jan. 30--G.H. (Pete) Bostwick Jr. of Locust Valley, L.I, added the United States open court tennis championship to his national amateur title today.
The State Mediation Board plans to meet today with union and management representatives in an effort to end the strike by 500 hearse and funeral limousine drivers, that started Saturday.
Eastern Air Lines has announced the appointment of John B. Andersen as vice president in charge of advertising and sales promotion.
CHICAGO, Jan. 30--Jury deliberations in the Krebiozen fraud trial were recessed this afternoon when a juror collapsed.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31--Increasingly preoccupied with the war in Vietnam and virtually paralyzed by snow and a Senate filibuster, Congress faces an uncertain week.
Sam Howe ran off six consecutive points yesterday in the final game to defeat his younger brother Ralph and win the Harry Cowles invitation squash racquets tournament at the Harvard Club.
BRIGHTON, England, Jan. 30 (Reuters)--Hartley Power, the actor for whom Edgar Wallace wrote his thriller "The Squeaker," died yesterday in a nursing home at the age of 71.

HOUSTON, Jan. 30--Voters approved a $136.8-million combined Houston-Harris County bond issue yesterday. The money, part of which will be borrowed in March and September, will be used for capital improvements.

ANKHE, South Vietnam, Jan. 30--Assaulting from two directions, three battalions of the United States First Cavalry Division (Airmobile) battered enemy units today in the coastal lowlands north of Quinhon.
ABIDJAN, Ivory Coast-- The "better mousetrap" formula has been working for this West African nation with huge success.

PARIS, Jan. 30--The game has begun. As of this weekend there are four official proposals for reform of the international monetary system. After two years of study and shadow-boxing, there is basis now for negotiating.
HONG KONG. Jan. 30--Liu Shao-chi, head of state of Communist China, today pledged in a letter to Ho Chi Minh the firm support of Peking for the "just stand" of North Vietnam.
CZESTOCHOWA, Poland, Jan. 30--Stefan Cardinal Wyszynski defiantly declared today that the Roman Catholic Church of Poland could not be vanquished by any temporal power.
A party in Brooklyn ended in a fight at 5:30 A.M. yesterday in which a 16-year-old youth was shot dead and three other young men were wounded.
Lehn Fink Products Corporation announced over the weekend that it had received several offers for the purchase of the company.

THE Columbia Broadcasting System canceled its "Sports Spectacular" yesterday afternoon for a 90-minute Congressional debate in miniature on the Vietnamese war. The pre-emption reflected a welcome concern by C.B.S. to cover the deeper issues and problems of the conflict in Southeast Asia more thoroughly.
BOSTON, Jan. 30 (UPI)-- A pair of early tallies by Henri Richard and Giles Tremblay proved enough tonight to give the Montreal Canadians a 3-1 National Hockey League victory over the Boston Bruins.

NAIROBI, Kenya--For more than half a century, since Britain imported thousands of Indian coolies into Kenya to build the railroad from Mombasa to the Great Lake, Indians have dominated Kenya's commerce.

Jack Paar, who retired from his weekly television show last year, will be the host of a special one-hour variety program titled "A Funny Thing Happened on the Way to the White House." Planned as a satire on politics, the show will be televised by the National Broadcasting Company at 8:30 P.M. on May 19.
Erich Leinsdorf conducted the Boston Symphony Orchestra at Carnegie Hall Saturday night in the second of the four Brahms programs the Bostonians are giving in the "Festival of Visiting Orchestras."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30-- The most talked about item on the agenda of the Republican state chairmen's meeting yesterday was a report on the Michigan state committee's use of a computer to process and program its fund solicitations.

ST. PAUL, Jan. 30 (AP)-- Rich Wurster, a long-legged newspaperman from Ballston Spa, N.Y., streaked to victories in two windup races today to capture the senior men's division of the national outdoor speed-skating Championships the second year in a row.
ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia--For much of Africa, the winds of change that have buffeted the continent turned into whirlwinds last year.

ROME, Jan. 30--Pope Paul VI renewed today his hope that "arms will be reduced to simple means of security." He also prayed that "man will not be a victim of himself, of his progress and the formidable instruments by which he expresses his ingenuity and multiplies his power."

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Jan. 30--Rutgers University received $3,885,671 in gifts, grants, contracts and scholarships during November and December, Dr. Mason W. Gross, the president of the state university, announced today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30-- Five prominent members of Congress gave widely varying opinions about Vietnam in a panel discussion today that was viewed as a likely preview of a searching Congressional debate.
The Health Insurance Plan of Greater New York is renewing its bid for legislation that would let it own or lease its own hospitals.

CINCINNATI, Jan. 30 (AP) --Mrs. Eileen Kennedy Grote, the wife of David J. Grote, publicity director for the National Baseball League, was found dead today in the kitchen of her home. She was 35 years old. The cause of death was not determined.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30-- Under Secretary of State George W. Ball, defining the purposes of American policies in Vietnam, said today that the United States could not repudiate its commitment to fight there "without tearing and weakening the entire structure on which the world's security depends."
LISBON--The guerrilla wars in Portuguese Africa, dragged on in 1965, but economic development moved forward.
LANSING, Mich., Jan. 30 (UPI)--Dick Weber, last year's winner, staved off a strong comeback by Nelson Burton Jr. today to win the annual All-Star bowling tournament for the fourth time in five years.

OAKLAND, Calif., Jan. 30 (AP)--George Flint and Tom Keating, both linemen, have been acquired by the Oakland Raiders from the Buffalo Bills in the completion of an October American Football League trade that sent a flanker, Bo Roberson, to the Bills.

Emile Francis, the general manager and of the New York Rangers, must have chosen the correct words when he addressed his men before their game last night with the Toronto Maple Leafs at Madison Square Garden.

LAGOS, Nigeria--It was business as usual on Saturday morning, Jan. 15. The banks were open and the downtown department stores and native markets were jammed with last-minute weekend shoppers. As usual, the traffic was bumper to bumper.

A MAJOR gap in the New York tournament sched ule arises from the fact that there is no provision for competition among the 200 clubs in the metropolitan area. This contrasts unfavorably with the situation in London, England, where interclub contests are popular at various levels of expertise.

Jose Iturbi was 70 years old on Nov. 28, but the pianistic fluency that has seen him through countless performances over the past half-century has not deserted him, Neither have his fans. LAWRENCEVILLE, N.J., Jan. 30 (AP)--Rider College, trailing by 14 points at halftime, upset Long Island University, 77-68, today in a Tri-State League basketball game.

THE American Ballet Theater put its worst foot forward on Saturday and promptly tripped over it. The disparity between the best of Ballet Theater and the worst is so remarkable that at times one feels there must be two companies, or rather one real company and an impostor. If so, Saturday at the State Theater of Lincoln Center, was the impostor's afternoon.
KANSAS CITY, Mo., Jan. 30 (AP)--Reaves Peters, former executive director of the Big Eight Conference and a leader in national sports organizations, died at his home tonight. He was 72 years old.

NEWARK, Jan. 30 (AP)-- Six Jersey City men who were discharged from their jobs at the insistence of their union have received a total of $26,686 in back pay and interest, the National Labor Relations Board said today.
Robert Brustein, drama critic of The New Republic magazine, is expected to be named dean of the Yale University School of Drama this week.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa--The people of the three British territories in southern Africa--Basutoland, Bechuanaland and Swaziland--are beginning to face economic realities as they prepare for the last lap toward self-determination.
A State Supreme Court justice has ruled that the estate of Lee Shubert is entitled to receive about $28-million from the estate of his brother, J.J. Shubert.
HUDSON, N.Y., Jan. 30-- Olana, the "Center of the World" three miles south of here, faces a 60-mile panorama of the Hudson River and the Catskills and its own destruction.

The Lindsay administration has received 3,000 applications for government jobs since Election Day.

TUNS--During 1965 Tunisia's unfavorable balance of trade took a 50 per cent turn for the worse, to judge by the figures for the first eight months. However, new oil discoveries and tourist trade offer the Tunisians new hope for making money in 1966.
Albert B. Maginnes, a lawyer who had been active in sports, died yesterday at the Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 68 years old and lived at 912 North Street in White Plains.

CAIRO, Jan. 30--A chill has come over the usually cordial relations between the United Arab Republic and Communist China, which is already suffering from other recent setbacks in Africa.
KHARTOUM, Sudan--On the bridge over the White Nile, a lookout scans the surface of the majestic river for signs that a deceptively innocent-looking flower is floating downstream.

BOSTON, Jan. 30 (UPI)-- The Boston Celtics nosed out the surging New York Knickerbockers, 118-115, today and recaptured first place in the National Basketball Association's Eastern Division.
New York garment makers specializing in women's and children's apparel have managed to put two good years back to back. This in itself is a creditable performance.

Police Commissioner Vincent L. Broderick urged yesterday that fines for illegal parking in midtown Manhattan be raised to $50. Traffic Commissioner Henry A. Barnes immediately supported the idea.

A campaign to make the city's parks safer and more usable at night was announced yesterday by Park Commissioner Thomas P. Hoving.

Five panels of judges have named 29 books as outstanding candidates for the annual National Book Awards. The winners will be announced on March 15 at Philharmonic Hall.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y.-- Whether in industry or in agriculture, the outlook in Guinea in 1965 was brighter than at any time since the former French territory achieved statehood in December, 1958. The country is rich in resources in both fields.

The State Supreme Court upheld yesterday the right of Investigation Commissioner Arnold G. Fraiman to discharge 14 staff lawyers he had inherited from the Wagner administration.

A gang shot up a Brooklyn street Friday night, leaving behind seven guns of various kinds, bullets imbedded in buildings, and a mystery that had police still puzzled yesterday after questioning more than 100 persons in the neighborhood.
GREENVILLE, Miss., Jan. 31 (AP)--A small band of Negroes moved into the deactivated Greenville Air Force Base today saying, "We are here because we are hungry and cold and we have no jobs or land."
The New York Yankees signed a pair of reinforcements from the National League yesterday --Bob Friend and Ruben Amaro --and both were welcomed by Manager Johnny Keane as regulars.

PARIS, Jan. 31--Ranking officials of the major Western financial powers met here today to start their examination of new proposals for international monetary reform, particularly the proposals of the United States and a group of Common Market countries.

A massive health program that will provide low-income areas with thousands of physicians who will practice preventive medicine as well as treat illnesses was announced yesterday by Hospitals Commissioner Alonzo Yerby.
MOSCOW, Jan. 31--The Soviet Union fired a new unmanned space rocket toward the moon today apparently in another attempt at the soft landing that has failed in four previous attempts.
ALBANY, Jan. 31--Assembly Speaker Anthony J. Travia said today that enactment of a state lottery might lead to tax cuts next year.

MANCHESTER, England, Jan. 31 (UPI)--The British and Empire bantamweight champion, Alan Rudkin, survived a cut left eye and mouth tonight to gain a 10-round decision over Edmundo Esparza, of Mexico at the Belle Vue Arena.

The two insurgent directors of the Paramount Pictures Corporation--Herbert J. Siegel and Ernest H. Martin--are making a renewed effort to obtain a current list of Paramount stockholders. This is apparently in an attempt to gain additional seats on the board of Paramount.
HOLLYWOOD, Jan. 31 (AP) --A young Yugoslavian actor shot and killed the estranged wife of Mickey Rooney, then killed himself, the police said today.
Conservationists will begin a new round today in their fight to halt unruly development on Staten Island.

Favorable earnings reports continued to flow out of the oil industry yesterday. The Phillips Petroleum Company, the Union Oil Company of California, the Atlantic Refining Company and the Sunray DX Oil Company all re ported higher revenues and profits for 1965.
MIAMI, Jan. 31 (UPI)-- Ogden Phipps's Poker responded to the urging of Braulio Baeza in the stretch and pulled away to a three-length victory in the featured sprint at Hialeah race track today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31--The Supreme Court agreed today to review the jury-tampering conviction of James R. Hoffa, president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters.

HOLLYWOOD, Jan. 31 (AP) Elizabeth Patterson, a character actress familiar to moviegoers for her portrayals of sweetfaced gentlewomen and mothers, died today in Good Samaritan Hospital in Los Angeles at the age of 90.

Livingston L. Wingate is still "completely occupied with the fiscal reconstruction" of Haryou-Act's books, despite the fact that today was to be the day for an ordered accounting of the troubled antipoverty agency's financial problems.

CASEY STENGEL was still in a state of mild shock yesterday. The night before he had learned that the Hall of Fame committee had voted to waive the five-year waiting period and thereby had cleared the way for his quick acceptance among the ranks of the immortals.
NEW HAVEN, Jan. 31--Dirk Brouwer, Munson Professor of Natural Philosophy and Astronomy at Yale University and director of the Yale Observatory, died today in Yale-New Haven Hospital.

TRENTON, Jan. 31 (AP)-- New Jersey will open all its state oyster seed beds in Delaware Bay for the coming planting season, the first time it has done so since a mysterious disease struck almost a decade ago.

A proressor emeritus of romance languages of the City College lost his suit yesterday to establish the right to deduct the expense of a European trip on his income tax return. He had contended that this was a legitimate business expense designed to improve his skill as a linguist.

Well-justified public indignation has finally triumphed over the power and the greed of the stripmining interests in Kentucky. In their quest for prof-- its, coal mine operators have long ravaged the land, using power shovels in open terrain and bulldozers in mountainous country to tear away the topsoil. They cared not whether they left the earth piled up...
Although it is not on the agenda for today's board meeting, directors of REA Express, Inc., are expected to discuss the naming of a successor for William B. Johnson as president.

From Miami to Montreal millions are still contending with the aftereffects of the great storm that may go into history as the blizzard of '66. The bitter cold, the abundant snow and the piercing wind combined to give us all a humbling lesson on the enormous energy at nature's disposal and the impact it can have upon men's petty plans.

A combat veteran of the war in Vietnam, who does not read music, is the composer of the fastest selling ballad that RCA Victor has had--with the exception of some of Elvis Presley's--in the last seven years.

WHITE PLAINS, Jan. 31-- The father of a 17-year-old boy accused of setting a fire in Yonkers in which 12 persons were killed, filed a legal request today that the youth be released from Grasslands Hospital, where he has been under psychiatric observation for nearly a week.

SWARTHMORE, Pa., Feb. 1 Dr. Warren F. Faragher, a pioneer in petroleum chemistry, died here yesterday at the age of 81. He was vice president of the Research Institute of Temple University at his death.

THE average player uses the Blackwood convention far more frequently than the expert, who is aware of its limitations, Blackwood should not be used, for example, when holding two quick losers in an unbid suit. If this is the problem, judicious cuebidding may be the answer, as in the deal shown in the diagram. It was played last Wednesday in the weekly duplicate game at the Mayfair Club.
HONG KONG, Feb. 1 North Vietnam declared today that the United Nations Security Council had no right to deal with the Vietnam question.

John Gielgud will star in a 90-minute adaptation of "Ivanov," the Chekhov drama, to be televised in color next season in prime evening time by the Columbia Broadcasting System. The play was taped in London last week soon after it had closed a successful stage run.
CHICAGO, Feb. 1 (UPI) Jesse Owens, the United States hero of the 1936 Olympic Games in Berlin, was fined $3,000 today for having evaded payment of $68,166 in Federal income taxes.

The increase in new construction and renovation projects in every part of the city has continued the sharp climb of real estate's assessed value. According to a tentative estimate of assessments made public yesterday for the fiscal year 196667, the total now stands at $32,280,645,336, the highest of any city.
GREENVILLE, Miss., Feb. 1 Air Force troops weathered a flurry of kicks, bites and curses today while ejecting 110 civil rights workers and impoverished Negroes from a deactivated Air Force base.
The America, Can Company regained its top rank among the nation's can companies last year in sales and earnings. In 1964 the Continental Can Company had moved ahead of American.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 North Vietnam's Defense Minister, Gen. Vo Nguyen Giap, has issued an analysis of American war aims that predicts inevitable failure for the United States regardless of the size of its commitment.
The Lindsay administration is wrestling with the problems involved in making good on one of Mr. Lindsay's most unusual campaign promises to man City Hall "24 hours a day" with a senior official.
Mrs. Joseph Lyles Bowling of Brooklyn has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Barbara Elizabeth Bowling, to Robert Perry Crawford Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Crawford of Glens Falls, N.Y.
Automobile production in January totaled 816,115 units, 1 per cent below the record 826,836 cars turned out in January, 1965.

The United States Savings and Loan League, the largest trade association in the $130billion savings and loan industry, predicted yesterday that January was a "break-even" month in the receipt of new savings.

CHARLESTON, W. Va., Feb. 1 John D. Rockefeller 4th, 28year-old nephew of Governor Rockefeller of New York, charted a political career of his own today as a Democratic candidate for the West Virginia Legislature.
PARIS, Feb. 1 New egalitarian laws went into practice today, revolutionizing the legal concepts of the French home and the legal relationship between man and wife.
Mrs. Leonore Smart Smith of Katonah, N.Y., and Henry Taylor Gibson of Pound Ridge, N.Y., were married in Cuidad Juarez, Mexico, on Thursday.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 What this country's capital needed was a couple of 70-degree days to extricate it from 21.5 inches of snow (not counting drifts).
MIAMI, Feb. 1 Three skippers were tied for first place today after the third race in the Bacardi Cup for Star Class sloops was sailed on Biscayne Bay.

ROME, Feb. 1 (AP) A new scandal rocked Italy today as 12 Government officials, including a former Christian Democratic member of Parliament, were charged with having embezzled more than $1.6-million in state funds.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 The impasse between the Justice Department and Federal District Judge Stephen S. Chandler over his disputed authority to try cases was broken at least temporarily today.

SAIGON, Feb. 1 American planes bombed North Vietnamese port facilities and communications lines for the second day today, following the end of Washington's pause to allow a response to its peace offensive.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 Ten Democratic Senators decided tentatively today to try to force the Administration into a thorough discussion of Vietnam policy.
TOKYO, Feb. 1 Japan's governing political party was badly shaken today by a scandal linking the private secretary of a senior legislator to a gangster organization.
HOLLYWOOD, Feb. 1 (AP) Hedda Hopper, the Hollywood gossip columnist, died in Cedars of Lebanon Hospital today of double pneumonia with heart complications. She was 75 years old.

Dean Witter Co., investment banking concern and member of the New York Stock Exchange, announced here yesterday the admission of Joseph E. Bitterly, Reading B. Fahnestock and Earl Bruce Towlen as general partners.

President Johnson's message to Congress embraces two long overdue reforms in the handling of American foreign-aid legislation. He has agreed to separate economic from military assistance and to ask the Congress for five year authorizations in both categories, instead of leaving the programs largely on a year-to-year basis.
FRED ALLEN sang this ditty by Arthur Schwartz and Howard Dietz in a 1929 revue called "The Little Show," and it is still the love song of the sedulous gadget collector.

ROME, Feb. 1 The Vatican radio, speaking of the Vietnam crisis and Pope Paul VI's recent suggestion for neutral United Nations mediation, said today that anyone refusing an initiative by the United Nations was taking on ...
ALBANY, Feb. 1 Senator Jacob K. Javits called today for an immediate increase of 25 cents to $1.50 in New York State's minimum hourly wage.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (UPI) A Mississippi Ku Klux Klan leader invoked the Fifth Amendment today when asked whether his group had ordered the "extermination" of one of three civil rights workers slain in the state.

BERN, Switzerland, Feb. 1 (UPI) The Soviet Union has asked Switzerland for permission to open the first Communist-backed bank in this world financial center, the Swiss Federal Banks Commission reported today.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 The power of the President to do what he likes on questions of war or peace has seldom been dramatized more sharply than in Mr. Johnson's conduct of the Vietnam war.

The Intramerican Life Corporation, a new holding company, described as the nation's first multiracial insurance company, accepted a check for close to $3-million yesterday from the Franklin National Bank.

GEORGETOWN, British Guiana, Feb. 1 (AP) Boxing fans almost rioted last night when Referee Bill Brown raised by mistake the arm of the Jamaican middleweight champion, Roy Lee, in victory after a 10-round bout.
A $30-million issue of highway construction and improvement bonds was sold yesterday by the Louisiana Capital Construction and Improvement Commission in Baton Rouge.
ELIZABETH, N.J., Feb. 1 The Elizabethtown Consolidated Gas Company reported earnings today of $444,791, or 47 cents a share, for the first quarter of the fiscal year ending Dec. 31.
Dr. H. Guyford Stever, president of the Carnegie Institute of Technology was elected yesterday as a director of the Koppers Company, a producer of tar products and chemicals.

Frustration over the jamming of midtown streets with illegally parked automobiles undoubtedly explains Police Commissioner Broderick's desire to raise the fine to $50. It also explains the swift endorsement of the idea by Traffic Commissioner Barnes. Their irritation is abundantly justified; their corrective is not.
FOR the Chinese, its the Year of the Horse. For Ken Venturi and Arnold Palmer, it's the Year of the Comeback.
BOWIE, Md., Feb. 1 (UPI) Officials at the Bowie race track said today that all horses released from their stalls during yesterday's fire had been rounded up.
ARCADIA, Calif., Feb. 1 (AP) Hirsch Jacobs's Be Suspicious wore down the leaders near the 16th pole today to win the $20,000 added Pasadena Stakes for 3-year-old fillies at Santa Anita.

HOLLYWOOD, Feb. 1 Buster Keaton, the poker-faced comic whose studies in exquisite frustration amused two generations of movie audiences, died of lung cancer today at his home in suburban Woodland Hills. His age was 70.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 President Johnson told Congress today that the appalling conditions of the underdeveloped half of the world "challenge our own security and threaten the future of the world." He then requested the smallest appropriation for improving them in the 18-year history of foreign aid programs.
WASHINGTON, Feb.1 (UPI) Swiss-born Henry Haller, who asserts he can cook in any language, reported for duty today as President Johnson's White House chef.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb. 1 Jordan held the key tonight to whether the Security Council could debate a draft United States resolution seeking peace in Vietnam.
It was a bad day for shipping yesterday for passenger liners, tankers and tugs, both at sea and in port.
The Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith approved yesterday a budget increase of $739,000 over last year's figure.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 Following are excerpts from President Johnson's message to Congress today on foreign aid:
Hess, Goldsmith Co., a division of Burlington Industries, Inc., announced here yesterday the appointment of William F. Colton as president and chief executive officer.
An ocelot, a jaguar and a monkey will join a fashion safari on March 3 at the Pierre's Grand Ballroom.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Feb. 1 President Charles Helou of Lebanon is carrying out a sweeping purge of ambassadors, ministers and judges.

The Boston Celtics kept their slight grip on the Eastern Division lead intact by beating the Detroit Pistons, 100-81, in the first game of a National Basketball Association doubleheader at Madison Square Garden last night. Then the New York Knickerbockers, who have long established rights to last place in the East, rallied in the closing minutes for a 112-109 victory over the Baltimore Bullets.

WASHINGTON, Feb.1 Senator J.W. Fulbright, chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee, said tonight that if Hanoi and Peking did not wish to go to the United Nations Security Council on the question of Vietnam, he saw nothing wrong with reconvening the Geneva Conference of 1954.

TOKYO Four leading Japanese manufacturers of specialty steels are expected to merge soon. The move is in line with recommendations to the Government designed to meet the effects of the current business recession.

William S. Paley, chairman of the board of the Columbia Broadcasting System, announced yesterday that he was giving the city a vest-pocket park off Fifth Avenue where footsore shoppers and strollers could sit under over-arching locust trees and watch a waterfall.
Dr. Martin Lazar, director of the Bronx State Hospital since June, 1963, shortly after its opening, died there yesterday, apparently of a heart attack. He was 56 years old.

TORONTO, Feb. 1 (Canadian Press) George, and Viola MacMillan were remanded Tuesday for a fourth time for preliminary hearing on fraud charges in connection with trading in shares of Windfall Oils and Mines, Ltd., in July, 1964.
Two Roman Catholic priests at St. Vincent's hospital receive an electric shock whenever they reach for a highball.
The Port Authority overcame yesterday what it believes will be the last serious legal threat to its construction of the mammoth World Trade Center in downtown Manhattan.
Thousands jammed St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday to murmur prayers amid the chants and Gregorian music of a solemn requiem mass for Michael J. Quill, president of the Transport Workers Union.

The Equity Corporation, a closed-end, non-diversified investment company whose affairs have been under a wide-ranging investigation by the Securities and Exchange Commission, dropped its chairman last night and set out on a new course under new command.

WOODBRIDGE, Conn., Feb. 1 Miss Katherine Esther McAlenney's engagement to Theodore Dean Lazo of New York has been announced by her parents, Dr. and Mrs. Paul Francis McAlenney. Her fiance is the son of Mr. and Mrs. J. Oscar Lazo of Bombay, India.

Mrs. Francis J.M. Robb of Flushing, Queens, has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Mary Jo Robb, to John David Murphy, son of Mrs. John G. Murphy of Jamaica Estates, Queens, and the late Dr. Murphy.

FIRST things first, and the Rumanian Folk Ballet, which opened a week's engagement at the New York City Center last night, possesses two dozen or so of the prettiest girls currently in New York. Second things second, and as folk ensembles go, these Rumanians go with the best of them.
DETROIT, Feb. 1 (AP) A high wire walker fell 45 feet to the floor of Detroit's State Fair Coliseum today before 8,000 matinee patrons.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 1 Gov. Edmund G. Brown of California announced his intention to seek a third term today with the observation that his Republican rivals were less "tough" than those he had defeated in his last two campaigns.
ATHENS, Feb. 1--Ten persons were hunt today in downtown clashes between anti-Government students and the police.
HONG KONG, Feb. 1 Jenmin Jih Pao, the chief Chinese Communist newspaper, said today that American military strategy had switched from "U.S.-Soviet confrontation to U.S.-China confrontation."
MONTREAL, Feb. 1 (UPI) Bobby Hull of the Chicago Black Hawks increased his lead in the National Hockey League scoring race last week.

A state witness testified yesterday that he had been told that promoters seeking a license to operate the Finger Lakes racetrack donated $125,000 to the state Democratic party for the 1958 election campaign.
ANN ARBOR, Mich., Feb. 1 (UPI) Illinois shook off its first-half foul trouble and defeated Michigan in basketball, 99-93, tonight. It was the first Big Ten loss of the session for the Wolverines.

A seminar on "The Art of Animation," open to the public, will be held at 8:30 tonight at the Museum of Modern Art Film Library auditorium, 11 West 53d Street. John Hubley, head of Storyboard, Inc., and producer of many animated subjects, including "Of Stars and Men," will be moderator.
Bloomingdale's, a major retailing division of Federated Department Stores, Inc., announced here yesterday the appointment of Vincent P. Brennan as a senior vice president.
A 2-alarm fire in a 12story brick commercial building at 456 Park Avenue South disrupted traffic for an hour during the morning rush hour yesterday.

SENECA FALLS, N.Y., Feb. 1 (AP) John Rosenkrans, chairman of the founding committee and former acting chairman of the board of trustees, has been elected Eisenhower College's first president. He is 41 years old.
NEW DELHI, Feb. 1 E.M.S. Namboodiripad, the leader of India's pro-Peking Communist party, was arrested today.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 Samuel Byron Williams, who helped develop the first electric digital computer, died yesterday at Suburban Hospital in Chevy Chase, Md. He was 84 years old.

The New York Board of Trade has named Lathrop Douglass, a fellow of the American Institute of Architects, as chairman of its Architectural Advisory Council. He succeeds Max O. Urbahn, president of the New York chapter of the American Institute of Architects.
BOSTON, Feb. 1 Former Gov. Endicott Peabody today formally entered the race for the Democratic nomination for Senator.

William H. Booth was sworn in as the new chairman of the city's Commission on Human Rights yesterday and promptly declared that he regarded the building-trades unions as "particularly guilty" of job discrimination.
Botany Industries, Inc., announced yesterday a one-price policy for its men's suits, sport jackets and slacks, effective with the fall 1966 line.

A musical version of Truman Capote's short novel, "Breakfast at Tiffany's," is due in October at the Majestic. Nunnally Johnson and Sidney Michaels have written the adaptation. Mrs. Martha Brautigam Fraser, widow of William Fraser, treasurer and director of J.P. Stevens Co., Inc., textiles, died Monday in her home, 520 East 86th Street. Her age was 86.

PASADENA, Calif., Feb. 1 (AP) A second successful test of three radar-controlled rocket engines designed to help lower a United States Surveyor spacecraft gently onto the moon was announced today by the Jet Propulsion Laboratory.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 1 Leonard A. Heinrich, one of the very few persons in this country who could make reproductions of medieval armor, and armorer of the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York from 1924 to 1964, died yesterday. He came into his house on Brunswick Pike here after shoveling snow and suffered a heart attack. He was dead on arrival at Princeton Hospital. He was 65 years old.

Directors of the United Artists Corporation voted yesterday a special cash dividend of 50 cents a share on the common and class B common stock outstanding on March 11. In addition, the board proposed a two-for-one stock split in the form of a stock distribution of one share for each share held.

BERLIN, Feb. 1 Three Germans were sent to prison today for having unlawfully used United States Army uniforms and license plates in an escape operation in which an East German man and two women were brought to the West last Dec. 19.

A concert to benefit the Library Fund of the New York College of Music was presented last night at the Hunter College Playhouse, under the sponsorship of Edouard Morot-Sir, the cultural counselor to the French Embassy.

ALBANY, FEB. 1 Assembly Speaker Anthony J. Travia, setting the stage for a possible showdown over reapportionment, will introduce his socalled "professors' plan" for new Senate and Assembly districts in the Legislature tomorrow.

The 80th birthday of Mies vander Rohe will be observed by the Museum of Modern Art with an exhibition opening today and running through March 20.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 A Connecticut shopkeeper asked the Federal Bureau of Investigation today to help him find his son, a brilliant sophomore at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology who has been missing for 63 days.

LONDON, Feb. 1 Queen Elizabeth II left today for a five-week tour of British dependencies and Commonwealth countries in the Caribbean after her plane had been delayed here by a bomb scare.
OAKLAND, Calif., Feb. 1 (AP) Joseph R. Knowland, publisher of The Oakland Tribune, died today at his home in suburban Piedmont. He was 92 years old and had been in failing health in recent months.

For the third year in a row, the response to The New York Times Neediest Cases appeal has set a new record. Contributions of $14,401.25 received since the last report brought the total given the 54th annual fund to $722,476.95.

SAIGON, Feb. 1 The United States and South Vietnamese high commands have launched a major offensive in the rice deltas of central Vietnam in an ambitious effort to trap and destroy four enemy regiments.
MIAMI, Feb. 1 (AP) A farm workers' bus collided with a train engine at a crossing in the fields south of Miami tonight, killing at least 18 and injuring 14.

BRUSSELS, Feb. 1 The Government of Premier Pierre Harmel, harried by disputes over the mine issue and the health insurance system, sought to stabilize a highly volatile political situation today.

The New York Yankees had almost no trouble keeping a stiff upper lip yesterday. With appropriate fanfare, they signed the strongman of their pitching, staff, Mel Stottlemyre, one of the few players on the team to escape the Yankee plague of 1965.

BUDAPEST, Feb. 1 The Government disclosed today that its radical changes of prices for foodstuffs and textiles had been somewhat modified, apparently as a gesture to the grumbling citizenry.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (AP) Farm product prices increased 1.5 per cent during the month ended Jan. 15, the Agriculture Department reported today.

DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., Feb. 1 Jochen Rindt (first name pronounced Yoken) is, at 24 years of age and after only three years of competition, one of the world's finest auto race drivers.

The acting executive secretary of the interfaith National Emergency Committee of Clergy Concerned About Vietnam called upon ministers and rabbis throughout the country yesterday to designate a Sabbath service "in the near future" for a collection to aid refugee work in Vietnam.

FORT WORTH, Feb. 1 Dr. Richard Fargo Brown became director today of the still-unbuilt Kimbell Art Foundation Museum.
The Italian Line announced last night that the board of directors in Genoa had accepted the resignations of Giuseppe Ali, director general, and Mario Donini, deputy director general.

Whether the sun shines or not today the traditional Groundhog Day this week will mark the midpoint of winter. Before the week's end we will have traveled half way from the winter solstice to the vernal equinox. There is that much truth in the old legend; if we put faith in the omniscience of the hiberating marmot, at worst there should be only six more weeks of winter.
