IF Jolly Jack Adams, the long-time frontoffice genius of the Detroit Red Wings, had no other claim to fame, his position of eminence in hockey circles still would be secure. He's the guy who discovered Gordie Howe, the best and most enduring of all superstars.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 Controller of the Currency James J. Saxon has formally notified the Kenosha National Bank of Kenosha, Wis. that he will approve its application to establish a branch bank. Wisconsin state law flatly prohibits creation of any new bank branches.

Resumption of the upward trend in cigarette sales was reflected yesterday in the record sales and earnings for 1965 reported by the American Tobacco Company, maker of Pall Mall, Lucky Strike, Tareyton and other cigarettes.

KARACHI, Pakistan, Feb. 1 President Mohammad Ayub Khan tonight asserted in a nationwide broadcast that the declaration of peaceful intentions he and the late Prime Minister Lal Bahadur Shastri of India signed last month in Tashkent, in Soviet Central Asia, was in the best interests of Pakistan.
Profit taking took command of the stock market yesterday and prices tumbled.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 The House Ways and Means Committee completed hearings on the Administration's tax-increase bill today with favorable action likely within a week or 10 days.

FLINT, Mich., Feb. 1 (AP) Members of the C.S. Mott family announced today organization of a philanthropic foundation and donated $99,000 to the Planned Parenthood Federation of America, New York, as their first public gift.
Yale Express System, Inc., which has been operating under Chapter X of the Bankruptcy Act since last May, resumed terminal operations yesterday in Queens.
Mayor Lindsay lost his fight yesterday to win the crucially needed support of the Democratic majority in the City Council for his Little City Halls program.

WESTBURY, L.I, Feb. 1 The Long Island Philharmonic Society and the New York City Ballet will present a series of free concerts, starting Feb. 15, to stimulate interest in the performing arts among schoolchildren on Long Island, it was announced today.
Earnings of the National Lead Company climbed to $5.10 a share last year from $4.80 in 1964, the company reported yesterday.

SAMUEL LIPMAN, a pianist who seemed to disap pear from New York concert halls following a promising beginning here 10 years ago, returned to Carnegie Hall last night as soloist with the National Orchestral Association.
The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation announced yesterday that it would become the chief tenant in the new 40-story office building to be erected at 437 Madison Avenue.
ALBANY, Feb. 1 The Roman Catholic Church has sent a letter to all state legislators calling on them not to take any immediate "affirmative action" on the bill to reform the state's divorce law.
Manhattan Fund, Inc., the new mutual fund headed by Gerald Tsai Jr., appeared ready yesterday to shatter all sales records for the initial offering of an investment company's shares.

IRENE KAMP's play "The Great Indoors," which opened last night at the Eugene O'Neill, pretends to be serious. Unsuccessfully, It is only one more product of the school that looks on serious problems as a source of tricky plots.

MIAMI, Feb. 1 (AP) A defense attorney said today that Jacques Mossler had been a ruthless financier and a sexual deviate who could have been slain by any of thousands of persons, including many who had threatened his life.

STUART, Fla., Feb. 1 Many of the visiting anglers here seek a most wily opponent, the largemouth bass. They don't have to go far, for only a few miles of travel to the west lie the bass-holding series of canals and ditches draining Lake Okeechobee, which is also fine bass water.

"An understanding of the biology of aging is within reach of this generation," an authority in this field of scientific research said in a speech prepared for delivery at the New York Academy of Sciences last night.

Alnor Aluminum, S.A., a joint venture of the Harvey Aluminum Company of Torrance; Calif., and Norsk Hydro of Norway, announced yesterday the award of a construction contract and financing arrangements for an aluminum reduction plant in Norway.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Feb. 1 (AP) Manhattan lost a 17-point lead, but rallied in the final nine minutes tonight for an 85-78 Metropolitan Conference basketball victory over Rutgers.

Exhibitors at the annual Start-Your-Own-Business Exposition at the New York Coliseum expressed themselves as highly pleased with attendance and business written as the fiveday event closed last night.
The Chira String Orchestra was heard last night at Town Hall in a program that was long on quantity and uneven in quality.
MIAMI, Feb. 1 Graustark, the great, a descriptive term that is hardly inappropriate in view of his performance record, will be on display again tomorrow at Hialeah Park in the $29,950 Bahamas.

TORONTO, Feb. 1 Eric W. Kierans, former president of the Montreal Stock Exchange, charged tonight that the United States, Government's voluntary restrictions on investment abroad would have "a disastrous impact" on the Canadian economy.
The 65 intervenors in the planned investigation of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company's rate structure have been joined by three others.
Mayor Lindsay made it clear yesterday that the controversial Flatlands Industrial Park in Canarsie, Brooklyn, would go ahead according to plan.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (UPI) The House Veterans Committee cleared the way today for quick approval of a new G.I. bill of rights for 3.5 million men and women who have served in the armed forces since 1955.
BRUSSELS, Feb. 1 (UPI) State troopers fired on demon strators who were bombarding them with bricks and cobblestones tonight in the Belgian mining town of Winterslag.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 A leading steel industry executive suggested today that the steel-import problem might be handled by a temporary and voluntary program of import restraint.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 Surplus food will be made available in a day or so to the poor at Greenville and elsewhere in Mississippi, the Office of Economic Opportunity said today.

Mr. and Mrs. Martin R. Herrick of 25 Sutton Place South have announced the engagement of Mrs. Herrick's daughter, Miss Sidney Kathryn Bohanna, to John Richard Westley, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard O. Westley of Winnetka, Ill.
A modification of the corporate operating structure of the Boeing Company was announced yesterday.
LEOPOLDVILE, the Congo, Feb. 1 The Congolese Government announced today a break in trade links with Rhodesia in a move that many believed would cripple the Congo's own shaky economy.

Julie Andrews, Carol Channing and James Fox have been signed to star in "Thoroughly Modern Millie," a comedy set in the nineteen-twenties. Ross Hunter plans to start production May 2 for Universal Pictures. Richard Morris's script has been on Mr. Hunter's schedule since 1964. The color film will include hit tunes of the period.

The engagement of Miss Barbara Jane Clark to John Vincent Cronin has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Percy L. Clark of Valleyfield, Quebec. Mr. Cronin is the son of Mr. and Mrs. William P. Cronin of Essex Fells, N.J.
THIRTY minutes after William Henry Booth was sworn in gas chairman of the city's Commission on Human Rights yesterday he was at his desk at the commission's office on 80 Lafayette Street.
COLUMBIA, S.C., Feb. 1 (UPI) The South Carolina Senate ended its 13-day filibuster on reapportionment tonight by giving in to the filibustering small-county forces.

The State Investigation Commission heard testimony yesterday that a Brooklyn insurance salesman received $75,000 and insurance contracts after arranging a meeting between the applicant for a housing project and Milton Mollen at Mr. Mollen's home.
COLUMBIA, S.C., Feb. 1 (UPI) The South Carolina Senate ended its 13-day filibuster on reapportionment tonight by giving in to the filibustering small-county forces.

The State Investigation Commission heard testimony yesterday that a Brooklyn insurance salesman received $75,000 and insurance contracts after arranging a meeting between the applicant for a housing project and Milton Mollen at Mr. Mollen's home.

Despite its strong criticism of the Federal Reserve Board's action in raising interest rates in December, the Johnson Administration is apparently reconciled to additional tightening moves by the money managers if inflationary pressures arise.
Mayor Lindsay yesterday named 13 city officials to a new temporary Antipoverty Operations Board, which will act as the top city agency for review and approval of local antipoverty projects.
MORRILTON, Ark., Feb. 1 Conway County is an Ozard foothills fief of 15,000 persons that for 15 years has been under the political control of a shy, poetic sheriff named Marlin Hawkins.

GOODING, Idaho, Feb. 1 Mrs. Patricia Lawford, sister of President Kennedy and Senators Robert F. Kennedy of New York and Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts, was granted a divorce today from Peter Lawford, the actor, in a 12-minute court action that ended their 11-year marriage.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (AP) Twelve leading Italian-Americans gathered at the Justice Department today to protest proposals to publish the memoirs of Joseph M. Valachi, convicted murderer and onetime Mafia figure.
Herbert L. May, whom the United Nations World called "the spark plug of international drug control," died yesterday in his home at 166 East 63d Street. He was 88 years old.
LONDON, Feb. 1 Lieut.Gen. Arthur Ernest Percival, who surrendered Singapore to the Japanese in February, 1942, died today at the age of 78.
Vice President Humphrey called last night for the election of Orin Lehman to the 17th Congressional District seat formerly held by Mayor Lindsay.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 Senator Everett McKinley Dirksen threatened today to tie up virtually all legislation until the Administration abandons efforts to get a labor bill to the Senate floor.

The engagement of Miss Barbara Susan Golden, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Carl Golden of Forest Hills, Queens, to Stanley M. Hochhauser, son of Mr. and Mrs. Morris Hochhauser of Brooklyn, has been announced by the prospective bride's parents.

McLEAN, Va., Feb. 1 Mr. and Mrs. Cabell Maddux Jr. have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Katharine Pollard Maddux, to Alfred Ballentine Houghton, son of Mrs. William C. Barbee and the late Alfred M. Houghton.
The Ohio Bell Telephone Company sold $60-million of debentures yesterday in an offering that carried a yield of 4,942 per cent the highest for a triple-A corporate issue in nearly six years.

A far-sighted program to protect and enhance the magnificent natural resources of the Hudson River Valley has now been proposed by the commission Governor Rockefeller appointed a year ago. By accepting its statesmanlike provisions, the Governor has improved his position on two of the most important and controversial issues involved.

BONN, Feb. 1 Concerned by signs that West Germany's "economic miracle" might be starting to fray around the edges, Chancellor Ludwig Erhard's Christian Democratic party has proposed legislation to preserve the value of the Deutsche mark and maintain full employment.

Mrs. M. Dreher Armstrong of 112 East 61st Street and Mr. and Mrs. Norman Scott were hosts at a cocktail party yesterday evening at Mrs. Armstrong's home honoring Miss Liane Augustin, the Viennese singer.
NEW HAVEN, Feb. 1 (AP) Robert Brustein, the drama critic, was named today dean of the Yale University School of Drama.
SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 1 (AP) The California Supreme Court reversed yesterday a lower court that had ordered the comedian Lenny Bruce to a rehabilitation center as a narcotics user.
Walter O'Malley said yesterday that the political and legal atmosphere of Milwaukee made the city a poor risk for a National League franchise at this time.
William Harrigan, who appeared in more than 40 stage plays in a career that spanned six decades, died here yesterday after having undergone surgery at St. Luke's Hospital. He was 71 years old.

"You tools the wrong line! You took the wrong line!" said a voice, evidently the conductor's, as the Brighton Beach local hurtled along the BMT's Fourth Avenue Line tracks shortly after 6 o'clock last night.
A dispute over the engineroom manning of a new $12million automated freighter is holding up the ship's scheduled departure from New Orleans.
Rod Gilbert, the star right wing of the New York Rangers, underwent a successful spinal fusion operation yesterday at St. Clare's Hospital.
Miss Lois Elena Moran and Ronald Jochum Ziegler plan to marry on June 4 at St. Patrick's Cathedral.

SINGAPORE, Feb. 1 Hundreds of Chinese and Malays clashed today in a two-hour riot that left 15 persons injured, one critically. It was the worst outbreak of communal violence since July, 1964, when scores were killed.
William B. Johnson, 47, has been elected president and chief executive officer of Illinois Central Industries, the parent company of the Illinois Central Railroad, it was announced yesterday.
Representatives of the city multi million dollar construction industry and building owners yesterday got Buildings Commissioner Charles G. Moerdler's promise to cut down on red tape and corruption.
The spot rate on the British pound closed at $2.8040, up three points over the previous day's quotation, in moderate trading on foreign exchange markets here yesterday.
The night people will be replaced by day people when the site of the Stork Club on East 53d Street is turned into one of the city's first model vestpocket parks.

Panagra (Pan American Grace Airways) has entered the New York-Florida route case with a "bombshell" offer to cut rates as much as 20 per cent below those of carriers now authorized to serve Miami from coastal cities in the Northeast.

Hope that the stalled Kennedy round of tariff-cutting negotiations can be started toward final agreement by early spring was expressed yesterday by William M. Roth, deputy United States representative for trade negotiations.

CHICAGO, Feb. 2--Murray Stein, chief enforcement officer for the Federal Water Pollution Control Administration, said to day that a major precedent-set ting breakthrough had been achieved with the setting of a Dec., 1968, deadline for clean ing up the southern end of Lake Michigan.
LONDON, Feb. 2 (AP)--A senior American diplomat in quired today into the extent of Britain's trade with North Viet nam and, by British accounts, found it is fractional.

Lydia Strong, an editor and writer who contributed articles to The New York Times Maga zine, died on Monday of brain cancer at the Clearview Nursing Home, Whitestone, Queens. She was 59 years old and lived at 350 West 24th Street.

PARIS, Feb. 2 (Reuters)-- A tip that the police thought would lead to a suspect in the kidnapping of Mehdi Ben Barka, Moroccan opposition leader, brought death to a French detective superintendent on a Paris sidewalk at dawn today.
LONDON, Feb. 2--Sir Rich and Grant Woodman Burbidge, former chairman of Harrods, died last night at his home at Ashampstead in Berkshire, west of London. He was 68 years old.

THE dances of Yuriko, who appeared with her com pany at the 92d Street Young Men's and Young Women's Hebrew Association last night, seem to come in billow ing circles. Her choreography has a bland simplicity, so that the simplicity delights even while the blandness lulls with a not disagreeable sameness.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2--At- least nine and perhaps 11 North Vietnamese regiments of 1,800 men each have been identified in South Vietnam, according to official estimates here.
Two persons were killed yesterday in a fire that de stroyed a four-story Harlem tenement house.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb. 2--The search for a treaty to prevent the further spread of nuclear weapons is looked upon by all parties as the major issue to be tackled by the Geneva disarmament nego- tiators.
Operations of the American Cyanamid Company in 1965 re sulted in record sales and earn- ings for trie fifth year in a row, W. G. Malcolm, chairman and chief executive officer, re- ported yesterday.
Teams of firemen and build ing inspectors fanned out into "Hell's 100 Acres" yesterday morning to find building viola tions that could lead to tragedy.
Meeting, New York Chamber of Commerce, 65 Liberty Street, noon. Speaker: Governor William W. Scranton of Pennsylvania.
BOWIE, Md., Feb. 2 (AP)-- Bowie race track, hit by snow, fire and disease, plans to reopen Friday if the weather cooper ates.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., Feb. 2-- Frank D. Van Valkenburg of Oyster Bay, who retired in 1956 as assistant secretary of Carter- Wallace, Inc., New York drug manufacturers, died today in Glen Cove Community Hospital. He was 75 years old.

GREENWICH, Conn., Feb. 2 --Frederick Albert Hayes, a management consultant on re tirement of Bigelow-Sanford, Inc., died today at Greenwich Hospital. He was 76 years old and lived at 15 Linwood Ave nue, Riverside.
Mayor Lindsay told a group of about 75 Puerto Ricans at City Hall yesterday that "no particular ethnic group owns any job" in his administration.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 (UPI) --Trans World Airlines told the Civil Aeronautics Board today that it planned to provide direct service between Miami and Eu rope if it obtained a route be- tween Northeastern cities and Florida.

By a vote of 9 to 2, with 4 abstentions, the United Nations Security Council yesterday decided to debate the draft United States res olution seeking a negotiated settlement of the war in Vietnam. Jordan, which had balked at voting Tuesday, cast the ninth and deci sive vote for the inclusion of the resolution on the Council's agenda.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2-- Without fanfare, Mrs. Lyndon B. Johnson has added exten sively to the American art in the White House.

Miss Margaret Barbee, execu tive director of the Sheltering Arms Children's Service for 23 years until her retirement in February, 1964, died on Tues- day at Roosevelt Hospital. She was 67 years old and lived at 235 East 22d Street.
MINEOLA, L.I., Feb. 2--The resignation of Nassau County's Commissioner of Public Works and the appointment of his suc cessor was announced today by County Executive Eugene H. Nickerson.

GLEN COVE, L.I., Feb. 2-- Franklin Drake Mooney, who never worked on deck or below, but developed and directed the fortunes of a shipping empire from Pier 32 on the Hudson River, died yesterday at the Glengariff Nursing Home. He was 92 years old.
Brooklyn policemen raided a Williamsburg apartment yester day and closed what they charged was a policy bank han dling $1.5-million in bets a day.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Feb. 2 (AP )--Howell A. Jones, vice president and treasurer of Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute in Troy, died here today, ap parently of a heart attack, while on a business trip. He was 64 years old.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2--The Treasury issued new standards today for valuing imports of sneakers that will have the ef- fect of reducing the duty. The imports involved are worth $17- million a year.

LONDON, Feb. 1--Part of a Continental Oil Company drill ing rig was reported today to have sunk in the North Sea about 45 miles from where the British Petroleum Company rig Sea Gem collapsed in December with a loss of 13 lives. No one was aboard.
PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 2 --Almet Jenks, writer and sportsman, died here today at the age of 74.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2--The State Department decided today to revoke the passports of Staughton Lynd, Herbert Ap- theker and Thomas E. Hayden on the ground that they had violated travel regulations in visiting Hanoi and Peking.

In what was described as a result of its merger with Bat ten, Barton, Durstine Osborn, Inc., last October, Clyne Maxon, Inc., is "resigning" the Mohasco Industries account, effective June 1. Mohasco makes carpets and rugs.
HONG KONG, Feb. 2--Com munist China supported North Vietnam today in its assertion that the United Nations Secu rity Council has no right to dis cuss Vietnam.

Pan American World Air way's Inc., achieved records in revenues and earnings in 1965, a preliminary report by Juan T. Trippe, chairman, disclosed yesterday. Fourth-quarter re sults also reached high ground. Net income last year climbed 27.3 per cent to $47,275,000, equal to $3.28 a share, on 14- million average shares out standing. This compares with $37,140,000, or $2.69 a share, on 13,830,000 shares in 1964.
When it comes to taxation, everyone has a common attitude --tax the fellow next door, not me.

PITTSBURGH, Feb. 2--Evi dence of public concern about the course of the war and the resumption of American bomb- ing in Vietnam all but vanished in the Middle Atlantic states this week under a record snow fall.

LONDON, Feb. 2 (UPI)--The British aviation industry of the future will be smaller, self-sup porting, closely aligned with the rest of Europe and at least partly state-owned, Aviation Minister Fred W. Mulley pre dicted tonight.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2-- The Securities and Exchange Commission suspended trading today in the stock of United Security Life Insurance Com pany, Inc., of Birmingham, Ala.

The conference of bishops of the Polish National Catholic Church of America has denounced as "irresponsible" a letter sent by Roman Catholic bishops of Poland to their Ger man counterparts last Novem ber as a step toward rapproche ment between the Polish and German peoples.
Police Commissioner Vincent L. Broderick said yesterday that he sought "no guidance what soever" from the Lindsay ad ministration in running his de partment.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2--Sen ator Mike Mansfield of Montana said today that "the time is fast approaching" when he would seek to shut off a fili buster that has virtually para lyzed the Senate for nine days.

BOSTON, Feb. 2--Kenneth P. O'Donnell, former appoint ments secretary to President Kennedy, formally announced has candidacy for Governor of Massachusetts here today. WASHINGTON, Feb. 2--The director of Project Head Start, one of the antipoverty cam paign's most popular programs, claimed significant gains today for participating children.

When United States bomb ers fly on missions over North Vietnam, they are accompa nied by an unusual looking plane with a huge radar saucer on its top. The radar plane is designed to give an early warning of approaching enemy fighters.

BONN, Feb. 2--West Ger many will incur an inter national payments deficit of be- tween $350-million and $500- million this year, according to a study published today by the Dresdner Bank, one of the nations leading commercial banks. This will follow a deficit of some $1.5-billion in 1965, the bank said.
ENCINO, Calif., Feb. 2--Miss Judith Lynne Brown and Neil Hamilton Kleinman plan to marry here on July 16.

JACK AND SONYA DOR- MAN of Stony Point, N.Y., own a litter of Akitas for which they claim a first in dogdom. Until the litter of eight came along nine weeks ago, none of the big Japanese dogs had been whelped in New York State.
The Metropolitan Opera gala, benefit on April 16, the company's last performance at the old house at Broadway and 39th Street, is sold out. No more orders can be ac- cepted.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2--The Organization of American States emphatically condemned today a move by a newly formed African-Asian-Latin. American group to extend "wars of na tional liberation" to the Ameri- cas.
The election of J.A. O'Con- nor Jr. as chairman of the Murphy Oil Corporation was announced yesterday by C.H. Murphy Jr., president and chief executive officer.

FORT MONMOUTH, N.J., Feb. 2--A Signal Corps ser geant re-enlisted for a six-year term yesterday and the Army paid him $9,558. It was believed to be the largest bonus paid under a bonus system that went into effect on Jan. 1.

PALISADE, N.J., Feb. 2-- Louis Silver, a lawyer who spe cialized in casualty law, died today in Englewood Hospital after a short illness. He was 53 years old and lived at 204 McElroy Avenue here. His of fice was in Jersey City.
Four utility systems--three electric and one gas--announced spending plans yesterday of nearly $500-million for expan- sion.
KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, Feb. 2 (AP)--The Malaysian Government announced today that it was imposing controls beginning tomorrow over news related to national security.

PATERSON, N.J., Feb. 2-- Mr. and Mrs. Herman Yucht have made known the engage ment of their daughter, Miss Maxine Yucht, to Jonathan Ar thur Schein, son of Dr. and Mrs. Albert J. Schein of New York and Ossining, N.Y.

The appointment of Alex ander J. Allen, executive di rector of the Urban League of Greater New York, as director of the Eastern Re gional Office of the National Urban League was announced yesterday. He succeeds Nel son C. Jackson.
LONDON, Feb. 2--A 500- pound unexploded German bomb was gingerly lifted with out incident today from the Thames River, where it fell 25 years ago during the Nazi blitz.
The Brick Presbyterian Church will hold its annual dinner dance on Wednesday at the Plaza's Grand Ballroom.

MIAMI, Feb. 2 (AP)--A broadcast executive testified to day that he had seen a man "with a similarity" to Melvin Lane Powers leave the Gover nor's Lodge Apartments the night Jacques Mossler was murdered there.
Mr. and Mrs. Leo Bernstein of 2 Fifth Avenue have an nounced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ellen Vee Bernstein, to Dr. Roger P. Plot- kin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert S. Plotkin of Milwaukee.
The American Stock Ex change bounced back yester- day to recover most of the losses registered Tuesday when the market had its worst set back in seven months.
Oveta Culp Hobby, chair- man of the board and editor of The Houston Post Com pany, was elected yesterday as a director of the General Foods Corporation.

A variety of disability benefits are available to the typical worker, who generally has little knowledge of the battle over who should provide or regulate that protection. But because he is caught in the crossfire of that battle, he should be concerned with the possible effects its outcome would have on him.
BONGSON, South Vietnam, Feb. 2--American infantrymen piled up steep hills in 95-degree heat today, pursuing the enemy force that they fought last week.

Prof. Peter A. Bee, former dean of students and former chairman of the mathematics department of the New York Community College, Brooklyn, died on Monday in St. Vincent's Hospital on Staten Island, after a long illness. His age was 60.
GREENVILLE, Miss, Feb. 2 (UPI)--Civil-rights leaders said today they had begun a new drive to persuade Negro share croppers to leave cotton planta tions and more into a tent city near here.

THERE are some pretty good scares in the final scene of "Wait Until Dark." which oepned last night at the Ethel Barrymore and which I saw at its last preview. Much of that final scene takes place in total blackness. The heroine is blind, and to give herself a chance against the villain who menaces her, she puts out all the lights.
Dr. Douglas Quick, an early user of radium in the treatment of cancer, and one of the first doctors to specialize in cancer treatment, died last Sunday in Utica, N.Y. He was 74 years old.
JACKSON, Miss., Feb. 2-- Gov. Paul B. Johnson ap peared before the Mississippi Legislature today and called for an end to 58 years of state prohibition and a system of legal sales of liquor.

Tom Courtenay, the young British actor now appearing in "King and Country" and "Doc tor Zhivago," and David Jans- sen, star of the television se ries, "The Fugitive," will have major roles in two forthcoming movies.
CHICAGO, Feb. 2 (UPI)-- Bobby Hull scored his 43d and 44th goals tonight to help the Chicago Black Hawks over- come a two-goal deficit and beat the New York Rangers 4-3.
A charge that a group of "neo-Nazi" youths have been terrorizing other students at the Bronx High School of Sci ence was made last night at a career-guidance conference in the school.

A sharp attack on the auto mobile and its manufacturers on the issue of safety was made yesterday by lawyers, physi cians, engineers and politicians as the American Trial Lawyers Association opened a campaign against what it termed "mur der by motor."

Despite considerable appre hension about the future of the United States commitment in Vietnam and distrust of Presi dent Johnson's ability, the pre- vailing opinion in New York, Connecticut and New Jersey seems to be support of the President's position to resume bombing of North Vietnam.

Directors of the Allied Stores Corporation announced plans yesterday to increase the quar terly dividend by 10 per cent and to split the common stock on the basis of 2 shares for each share outstanding.
NEW HAVEN, Feb. 2--Phil Dyer and Dave Allen scored two goals each to lead Boston Col lege to an 8-0 hockey victory over Yale tonight.

Two Waldbaum Supermarkets were held up within 20 minutes yesterday morning in Brooklyn by a trio of gunmen, believed by the police to have been re sponsible for a number of other supermarket robberies during the last several weeks.

Vic Obeck resigned yesterday as director of athletics at New York University. Obeck, who had held the post since 1957, will be replaced Sept. 1 by Ben Carnevale, who has been head basketball coach at the United States Naval Academy for the last 20 seasons. Navy officials said they would wait until the end of the basketball season be fore naming Carnevale's suc cessor.
Prices on the London Stock Exchange closed generally high er yesterday after earlier weak- ness caused by the Bank of England's directives tightening and prolonging the credit squeeze.

ALBANY, Feb. 2--The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People began court action today against the State Education Commis sioner, charging him with "arbi trary and capricious" delay in the public schools of Mal- verne, L.I.
PHOENIX, Ariz., Feb. 2 (AP)--A three-man Federal judge panel today ordered re apportionment of the Arizona Legislature and changes in two Congressional districts.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 (AP)--New orders received by manufacturers rose in De- cember to record levels, up 3 per cent from the preceding month after seasonal adjust- ments.
PARIS, Feb. 2--The French Government, in a formal state ment of unusual sharpness, con demned the military and diplo matic aspects of United States policies on Vietnam today.

GREENVILLE, Miss., Feb. 2 --After working hours in Ra leigh, N.C., State Treasurer Ed win Gill plops himself into an easy chair in the Sir Walter Hotel, where he lives, and "feels the pulse" of the public as it strides from the hotel entrances to the elevators.
An increase of 3,606,000 bar rels in the nation's gasoline stocks for the week ended last Friday was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum In stitute.

Sifting through last year's activity, the New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday that the value of institutional holdings of shares listed in creased $12-billion, to $109-bil- lion, at year's end.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., Feb, 2 --Negotiators for the Bee Line, Inc., and Local 252 of the Transport Workers Union failed to reach a contract settlement today as a strike inconven ienced 38,000 bus riders for the second day.

Orin Lehman, Democratic can didate for Congress in Manhat tan's 17th District, urged the Federal Government yesterday to give more financial aid to the city both for education and to fight water pollution.

Wolfgang von Karajan is less known here than his younger brother Herbert, the conductor, Nevertheless, last night the elder brother made a special kind of mark on the local music scene when the Wolfgang von Karajan Organ Ensemble made its New York debut at Town Hall.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2--A new kind of bird flew into our war vocabulary the other day when Senator Mike Mansfield called Senator George Aiken "an owl." Mr. Aiken had just given the Senate a few thoughts on the Asian war and, in calling him "an owl," Mr. Mansfield said he meant to suggest that Aiken was "a wise man."
The election of R.H. Mul- ford as a director of the Marathon Oil Company was announced yesterday follow- ing a board meeting in Hous- ton.
TOKYO, Feeb. 2 (AP)--The Vietcong joined Hanoi and Pe king today in declaring that any decisions on Vietnam made by the United Nations Security Council would be "null and void."
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2-- Many Senators reported today that their mail was heavily against escalation of the war in Vietnam.
Four high-speed container- ships, designed to meet the challenge of a new ocean ship- ping era, will be ordered by Moore-McCormack Lines.

DETROIT, Feb, 2 (AP)-- The Chrysler Corporation and the United Auto Workers reached agreement tonight on all issues involved in a six-day strike at the company's subur ban Sterling Township stamp- ing plant, the union said.

MISCHA ELMAN, that violin recital last night in Carnegie Hall. He has been giving one there virtually every season since 1908, when he made his American debut. It was only a few weeks ago that Mr. Elman passed his 75th birthday.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 2-- Deep-seated regret that bomb ing of North Vietnam was re newed has gripped the Pacific and bordering states. But the mood of a substantial majority, as suggested by inquiries in a cross-section of opinion leaders, is one of resignation to the be lief that perhaps there was no practicable alternative.

SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Feb. 2--Desmond Lardner-Burke, Rhodesia's Justice Minister, dis closed today that opponents of the regime of Ian D. Smith had formed a "shadow cabinet." He said the opponents hoped to take over the country if re- quested to do so by the Royal Governor, Sir Humphrey Gibbs, or Prime Minister Wilson of Britain.
ALBANY, Feb. 2--Clashing theories on how the state should deal with narcotics addicts ap- peared likely today to touch off a bitter fight in the Legislature.

THE PRESIDENT Attended swearing of John Dusenberry as a member of Council of Economic Advi sers; sent Congress $524-mil- lion International Health and Education program message; met with Indian Ambassador, B.K. Nehru.
The entire blockfront on the west side of First Avenue be- tween 83d and 84th Streets has been sold to Joseph and Andrew Giffuni, builders, who plan to erect a 22-story luxury apart- ment house.

Earl Brown, a former Har lem Councilman, testified yes terday that while he was a member of the City Housing and Redevelopment Board, Coun cilman J. Raymond Jones said to him that there was "enough money in housing that anyone could get rich--in or out of office."
The Midwest and East began to emerge yesterday from the blanket of ice and snow left by one of the century's worst storms.
YONKERS, Feb. 2--Patrick R. O'Callaghan, vice president of the American Irish Histori cal Society, died Monday in St. John's Hospital. He was 47 years old and lived at 833 Tuckahoe Road.

Miss Audrey A. Martucci, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jo seph Ralph Martucci of Yon kers, was married yesterday morning to Lieut. John Fred- erick Bubel Jr., U.S.A.F., son of Mr. and Mrs. Bubel of the Bronx.

A small but charmingly designed park is to be cre ated on Fifty-third Street between Fifth and Madison Avenues for the enjoyment of the people of New York. Complete with locust trees, chairs and water fall, it will be given by William S. Paley, chairman of the Columbia Broadcasting System, in memory of his father. The hope is that it will become a model for other individuals, corporations, institutions and local agencies to follow.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2-- Louis Levine has stepped down as Director of the United States Employment Service to take a manpower post in the Labor De partment. He has been named Assistant Manpower Adminis trator.

ROME, Feb. 2--Italy's Com munist party announced today a reorganization of its top lead ership that appeared, to most observers, to reinforce the con trol of the party's Secretary General, Luigi Longo, at the ex pense of feuding rivals.

THE big domes in the Amateur Athletic Union can draw blanks and act stupid on occasion, just as can their counter- parts in the National Collegiate Athletic Association. A record for egregious blunders was set this year when the National A.A.U. indoor championships, which Dan Ferris had spent decades in building into a major attrac tion, were summarily exiled to--of all places --Albuquerque, N.M.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Feb. 2-- The presidential aspirations of Brazil's War Minister, Gen. Artur Costa e Silva, were en dorsed today by the leader of the Government's political party.

The Delaware Hudson Com pany announced yesterday it had voted to seek inclusion of the railroad in the Norfolk Western Railway System on the basis of an exchange of 2.4 shares of D. H. for one com- mon share of N. W.
LONDON, Feb. 2--London bookies, an enterprising lot who turn frequently from horses and greyhounds to politics and econ- omics, are taking bets now an the next governor of the Bank of England.
LONDON, Feb. 2 (AP)-- Soviet Union astronomers pro posed today the establishment of an international research program to find out if life existed in space.

BRATISLAVA, Czechoslova kia. Feb. 2 (UPI)--Mrs. Lud- milla Belousova Protopopov and her husband, Oleg, of the Soviet Union retained their pairs title in the European figure-skating championships tonight with a breath-taking acrobatic pro- gram.

Walter O'Malley, the presi dent of the Los Angeles Dodg- ers, supported his contention yesterday that immediate ex pansion of major league basebll was impossible. O'Malley also said that the Dodger farm clubs had dwindled from 28 to four and "we don't have enough jplayers to stock our own clubs."
The Federal Communications Commission indicated concern yesterday over the decline in the stock price of the American Telephone and Telegraph Com- pany.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2-- President Johnson renewed to day his appeal to business and labor for self-restraint to avoid inflation.
MOSCOW, Feb. 2--Yevgeny Yevtushenko, controversial So viet poet, made a triumphant return to the Moscow stage to day with a recital about his experiences during two months in the Army.
A NIGHT at the movies no longer means a day in the dress shops. All it takes is the marquee.

The Tennessee Gas Transmis sion Company and subsidiaries achieved 12 per cent gains in both net income and operating revenues for 1965. Revenues topped $1-billion for the first time rising to $1,037,916,339 from $930,195,024 in 1964. All figures reflect the acquisition of the Packaging Corporation of America.
Few of the youngsters looked up from their play dough when Mrs. John V. Lindsay walked into the nursery at Grosvenor Neigh borhood House yesterday for a 40-minute tour of the pre school facilities.
For the first time in its 83 year history, the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) has moved outside its corporate confines in nominating direc- tors.

BEFORE the start of the 19th and final round of the 1965 Zagreb, Yugoslavia, international tournament, Boris Ivkov of Yugoslavia and Wolfgang Uhlmann of East Germany were tied for the lead with 12 points each. Uhlmann, who was paired with Bent Larsen of Denmark, faced a more diffi cult assignment than Ivkov, who was paired with his countryman Mata Damjano- vich.
The spot rate on the British pound eased a point from its level on Tuesday to close yes- terday at $2.8039 on moderate trading on foreign-exchange markets here.
Jim Hickman, who has played in more New York Met games than any man, signed a contract yesterday to extend his labors another season.
Having already killed a whisky ad considered deroga tory to the race, American In dians took aim yesterday at a soft drink and found that it had already capitulated to the Chinese.

A survey of 54 investment companies showed yesterday that purchases ran ahead of sales by $731-million to $626- million in the final quarter of 1965. Popular stock averages moved into new high ground during this period.

FRENCH LICK, Ind., Feb. 2 --Ben M. Herbster, president of the United Church of Christ, said today that his denomina tion was again recruiting civil rights workers to combat racial injustice in the South.

NEW touches of the jungle have emerged on the home furnishings front in recent months with the ap pearance of what looks like, but isn't, giraffe, tiger, leop ard, cheetah, zebra, civet cat or ocelot. The objects in volved are rugs, footstools, benches, pillows, waste- baskets and magazine racks.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Feb. 2 (UPI)--The Chamber of De- puties last night approved a wage readjustment bill con taining three riders vital to the government's planned intention to form mixed companies with United States copper mining interests in Chile.

After a year and a half of incredibly involved litiga tion, the Democrats and Republicans now seem on the verge of solving the reapportionment of the State Legislature amicably. A conference of the leaders of both sides has brought them closer than ever before to a mutually satisfactory compromise.

NEWARK, Feb, 2--Two groups of prominent Negro res idents, organized in separate nonprofit corporations, proposed today the construction of an apartment development formid- dle-income and elderly occupants in downtown Newark.
Long Island University marked its 40th anniversary yesterday with the announce ment that it would seek $100- million for new construction and endowment before it turns 50 years old in 1976.

LONDON, Feb. 2--With re straint still the dominant theme of British economic policy, the Treasury announced today the fifth straight monthly increase in the nation's gold and con- vertible currency reserves.

WELLINGTON, New Zealand, Thursday, Feb. 3 (AP)--All six members of an American Navy plane crew were killed in a crash in the Antarctic today, Operation Deepfreeze headquar ters announced in Christchurch.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2-- President Johnson asked Con gress today for a global attack on ignorance and disease and called on all nations--"friend and foe alike"--to join in the battle.

The Consolidated Edison Com pany said yesterday that if it did not build a hydroelectric power project at Storm King Mountain it would have to build more coal-burning plants in New York City. This, it noted, would mean continued fouling of the air here.

SAIGON, Feb. 2--American casualties for January in the Vietnamese war passed 1,200. The losses occurred in a rela tively quiet month in which there was little contact with organized Vietcong guerrilla units or with infiltrated North Vietnamese troops.
A program offering careers as policemen to young men primarily from minority groups will be conducted jointly by the Police Depart ment and the Board of Edu cation.
OTIS AIR FORCE BASE, Mass., Feb. 2 (AP)--An Air Force plane carrying a midget submarine to hunt for a miss ing nuclear bomb left tonight for Spain.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 2 --It was just a family affair, really, but the gathering of the Whitney clan and a swarm of friends here yesterday proved that American zillionaires never run out of ways to raise the crop they know best: money.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2--The official barometric groundhog in Pennsylvania could have had a better reason than the sight of his shadow for returning to his burrow today. The United States Senate is engaged in a filibuster to prevent the passage of perhaps the most untimely legislative proposal in recent history.
The Coast Guard cutter An- droscoggin reached the dam- aged Liberian ship, Arion, last night 690 miles east of Ber muda and prepared to escort her to Bermuda.
NEW DELHI, Feb. 2--Kerala students protesting a cut in rice rations raided a railroad station at Varkala this morning.
Miss Brenda Eileen LaGrange of 530 East 72d Street and Lawrence I. Weisman of 945 Fifth Avenue plan to marry on March 12 in the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church.
A drove of dinosaurs is making its way south from New York and will arrive in Florida this week for a five- day stand in Miami beginning next Wednesday.

Despite the mountainous obstacles still to be over come, the vote to place the Vietnam war on the agenda of the United Nations Security Council provides an opening for international action to move the conflict from the battlefield to the conference table. The for mal debate that has been authorized is far less im portant than the informal consultations now opening to prepare for that discussion.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2--The House voted overwhelmingly to- day for contempt-of-Congress citations against the Imperial Wizard of the United Klans of America, Robert M. Shelton Jr., and six of his Grand Dragons and other state leaders.
Car sales in the United States slowed in January, according to reports received from Detroit yesterday.

The Vulcan Materials Com pany has announced the elec- tion of Dr. John J. McKetta and Jack W. Lambert as directors. Dr. McKetta is dean of the College of Engineering at the University of Texas. Mr. Lam bert is president of the Lambert Bros. division of Vulcan Mate- rials.

Earnings of oil companies set a record pace last year, alhough profits of the Continental Oil Company were 4 per cent below its 1964 record net income be- cause of "an unexpected increas in Libyan income taxes."
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb. 2--Secretary General Thant invited a searching in quiry into United Nations spending policies by a 14-man committee that began work to day.

OMAHA, Nebr., Feb. 2 (AP) --An all-woman jury late today found former Mayor James Dworak not guilty on a charge of agreeing to accept a bribe. In doing so, it accepted the 40-year-old former official's ex planation that in agreeing to take a $25,000 campaign fund contribution from a Chicago in vestor, John Coleman, he was seeking evidence of a bribe offer.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2--Sec retary of Defense Robert S. Mc- Namara said today that every senior officer at the Pentagon had rejected the "enclave" strategy for the war in Vietnam.

PALM SPRINGS, Calif., Feb. 2 (UPI)--Jack McGowan, a touring pro who weighs only 140 pounds, took the first-round lead today in the $100,000 Bob Hope Desert Golf Classic with a record-tieing six-under-par 66 at the Eldorado Country Club.
A spot check by The New York Times indicates wide spread support in the nation for President Johnson's decision to resume the bombing of North Vietnam.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Feb. 2--Abram Fischer, the prominent lawyer who went underground allegedly to take command of the banned Com munist party, was indicted here today on a charge of sabotage. The charge carriers a maximum penalty of death.
Giro Tomasetti, a former vice president of the International Alliance of Theatrical Stage Employes, was indicted yester day by a Federal grand jury on charges of embezzling $6,000 in union funds.

TOKYO, Feb. 2--Japan's Diet (Parliament) returned to normal operation today after Premier Eisaku Sato formally apologized to the legislative body for the involvement of a member of the ruling Liberal- Democratic party in a scandal over the sale of pistols.
Columbia University men will no longer have to keep their room doors open when they en tertain women visitors in the dormitories.

CANBERRA, Australia, Feb. 2--Britain's Defense Secretary, Denis Healey, said today that if Britain withdrew from her air-and-naval base at Singa pore he hoped Australia would provide alternate base facilities. He added that if there were no- where else for Britain to go should the Singapore base be given up, "then we shall have to go home."
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 (AP) --Dr. Robert C. Weaver, Sec retary of Housing and Urban Development, swore in two key aides today.
The three national television networks took action yesterday to escalate their coverage of the war in Vietnam and related worldwide developments.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb. 2--Waleed Moham med Sadi of the Hashemite Kingdom of Jordan unexpect edly found himself the center of world attraction yesterday and today as the pivot of a great-power dispute in the Se curity Council over the Unit ed States request for a de- bate on Vietnam.
A businessman was held in $5,000 bail yesterday in Federal Court on charges of giving a $2,500 bribe to an Internal Revenue Service agent in an at tempt to cut his tax liability by $48,800.
After one month of 16-hour days for its new director, the Youth Board is again contend- ing for the city title of chief teen-age trouble-shooter, a title it earned and lost over a decade ago.

The Apostolic Delegate to the Roman Catholic Church in the United States has informed the Rev. Gommar De Pauw that in the view of the Holy See he is still a priest of the archdiocese of Baltimore and therefore subject to the author ity of Lawrence Cardinal She- han.
Earnings of the Phelps Dodge Corporation, the large domestic copper producer, climbed by 20 per cent last year, the company reported yesterday.

PARIS, Feb. 2--The opening round of negotiations to reform the international monetary sys- tem was adjourned this after noon after three days of cross- examining on four proposed ap proaches on how to go about it.
California sold yesterday $100- million of bonds to an under- writing syndicate headed by the Bank of America and the First National City Bank.
John F. Burke was an usher at the Fox Theater in Brooklyn when it opened on Aug. 31, 1928.

ESTHERVILLE, Iowa, Feb. 2 (AP)--A parachutist rode a balloon today higher than any other man has ever done before, technicians said, but his attempt at a world free- fall record was foiled by frozen equipment.
WESTBURY, L.I., Feb. 2-- The groom wore light tan corduroy pants and a bulky sweater.
EICTION lacks poise these days. It is in a moody, broody era. Its humor is hysterical. Its tragedies are psycho pathic. No great salt cleansing winds blow.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2--Sen- ate Republicans ran into unex pected candidate problems today on the eve of a dinner that is expected to raise almost $500,- 000 for the 1966 campaigns.
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 2 (UPI)--Girard College trustees asked the United States Dis trict Court here Tuesday to dismiss a suit against the school's all-white admission policy.
MOSCOW, Feb. 2--The 1963- 64 decline in the Soviet Union's rate of industrial growth was reversed last year, according to official statistics published to day.
BOSTON, Feb. 2--President Johnson has stirred firm but grudging response in New Eng land to his decision to resume bombing of North Vietnam.

Mr. and Mrs. Martin A. Roe der of 145 East 74th Street have made known the engage ment of their daughter, Miss Katherine Anna Roeder, to James Michael Rosenberg, son of Mr. and Mrs. Allan H. Ros enberg of Roslyn, L.I.
The stock market overcame early weakness yesterday with a strong rally in afternoon trading.
DETROIT, Feb. 2--Public fig ures in Michigan and Ohio feel a vague, nagging apprehension over the American commitment in Vietnam but generally be lieve that it should be honored, nonetheless.

William D. Marks Associ ates, a real estate concern spe- cializing in leasing new and distressed commercial and resi- dential buildings, has been or ganized by William D. Marks, who is also president of Arthur M. Marks Associates, an ad- vertising and public relations firm specializing in real estate. The new real estate company will have offices at 37 West 57th Street.
The nation's electric power production rose 11.9 per cent in the week ended Jan. 29 from the level in the 1965 week, it was reported yesterday by the Edison Electric Institute.
SANTA MONICA, Calif., Feb. 2 (UPI)--Sid Luft, movie pro ducer, former husband of Judy Garland, has filed a $6-million libel suit against Jack L. War ner, head of Warner Brothers Pictures.
EDWARDS AIR FORCE BASE, Calif., Feb. 2 (AP)-- United Auto Workers union members have voted to call off a strike against North Ameri can Aviation's Rocketdyne Di- vision.

ROME, Feb. 2--Federico Alessandrini, deputy director of the Vatican daily news paper L'Osservatore Romano, said in an article today that the American peace offensive "did not lack in sincerity" and that Pope Paul VI recog nized this even as he sug- gested that the Vietnam crisis be arbitrated by neu tral countries in the United Nations.

MIAMI, Feb. 2--Graustark encountered what was expected to be his first real test today and he passed with honors. The unbeaten 3-year-old colt owned by the Darby Dan Farm, com peting in the $29,950 Bahamas Stakes, took the seven-furlong race by four lengths over Ogden Phipps's Impressive, with Mrs. Ann Zeek's Fleet Admiral third, 4 lengths farther back.

SIGNS all over one of the basketball world's favorite eating spots say, "Carnevale is back at Leone's." As of noon yesterday these adver tisements for an Italian car nival celebration took on a second meaning--a welcome home for the Navy basketball coach who is returning to his ...
DETROIT, Feb. 2--The direc tors of the American Motors Corporation, re-elected today at the company's annual stock holders' meeting, again ruled to omit a quarterly dividend for the current period.
KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, Feb. 2--President Sukarno was reported today to have agreed to reshuffle his 96-man Cabinet.

SYDNEY, Australia, Feb. 2--Three youths burned their national service certificates, (the Australian equivalent of draft cards) in a protest to night against the conscrip tion of 20-year-olds for army service.
JEAN SAUBERT is about to try a major comeback. Jean is the brunette with the big smile who made Amer ica's ski fans happy in 1964 by winning two Olympic Al pine medals at Innsbruck, Austria.
A small-time criminal yester day faced 87 active or retired detectives, some of whom were believed to have tortured him four years ago, but he refused to identify any of them, reliable sources said.
Harold E. Searle of South Orange, N.J., a retired sales executive of the International Nickel Company, died in Pitts burgh on Tuesday while visiting relatives. He was 65 years old.
Haryou-Act reported yester day that its program reached over 10,000 youths in central Harlem last year.
The bond market, like Cae- sar's Gaul, was divided yester- day into three parts.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 (AP) --The House Veterans Affairs Committee put off action again today on a bill to provide edu cational and other benefits for veterans of the armed services.

The Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company, which has moved cautiously in its subur- ban expansion plans in recent years, won approval from the New York State Banking Board yesterday for its first branch in Westchester County.

ANKARA, Turkey, Feb. 2-- Fist fights broke out in the Turkish Parliament today when a member of the small right- wing Nation party was pulled from the rostrum and dragged along by members of the ruling Justice party.

Rinks from the Eastern sea board and Canada will begin competition today in the 11th annual Cuthbertson Bonspiel at the Saint Andrews Golf Club at Hastings-On-Hudson, N.Y. The curling tournament will run through Sunday.

TORONTO, Feb. 2 (UPI)-- James Oliver Buswell, Ameri can violinist, received the unan imous acclaim of Toronto's three daily newspapers for his performance with the Toronto Symphony Orchestra last night.

The Kewanee Oil Company increased its cash offer yester- day for the capital stock of the Kendall Refining Company in an effort to block the proposed merger of Kendall into the Witco Chemical Company.
ALBANY, Feb. 2--Democrat ic and Republican legislative leaders said today that they were moving closer together on a reapportionment compro mise.

Fred Lazarus Jr., 81-year- old chairman and a founder of Federated Department Stores, Inc., turned over the reins of the country's largest department-store chain yes terday to his son, Ralph Lazarus, president.
KARACHI, Pakistan, Feb. 2 (Reuters)--Twenty-three per sons were killed today when a vulture flew into the blades of a helicopter and the craft crashed in flames.

"Luv" is spreading over the world. The latest foreign ver sion of Murray Schisgal's three- character comedy will be pre sented in mid-March in Bel grade, Yugoslavia, in a small avant-garde theater called Atelier 212.

"Darling" and "Juliet of the Spirits," two films explicitly frank in their depictions of the seamier sides of contemporary society, were honored here last night by the National Catholic Office for Motion Pictures for their "artistic vision" and "ex pression of authentic human values."
HOUSTON, Feb. 2--Presi- dent Johnson's decision to re sume bombing of North Viet nam has the overwhelming ap proval of residents of Texas and Oklahoma. But the war it self has much less support.
Plans to establish a Harold R. Medina Chair in Procedural Jurisbrudence were announced yesterday by the Columbia Uni versity School of Law.
BERLIN, Feb. 2--A United States Army court-martial sen tenced a soldier today to three months in prison for having as sisted in an East Berliner's attempt to cross into the West.
A new labor agreement cover ing 25,000 workers in 2,400 of fice and loft buildings here will provide wage increases totaling $11 a week during a three-year contract.

Traffic Commissioner Henry A. Barnes said yesterday that he expected work on the city's new $100-million electronic traf fic control system to begin this summer. He said he hoped to have it working in Queens by fall.
MOSCOW, Feb. 2 (AP)-- Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin ac cused the United States today of intentionally threatening world peace with the renewed bombing of North Vietnam.
HARTFORD, Feb. 2 (UPI)-- A Brooklyn, N.Y., book store clerk was free today to travel throughout the country in a drive to finance his appeal on a Selective Service Law convic tion.

BREMEN, Germany, Feb. 2 (UPI)--A pair of American- made pliers clutched in the hand of a dead co-pilot raised spec ulation today that a fight in the cockpit may have led to the crash of a Lufthansa air liner last Friday.
EVANSTON, Ill., Feb. 2-- The National Merit Scholarship Corporation announced today that 251 Negro high school sen iors had won four-year college scholarships.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2.-- The Atomic Energy Commission announced today a program to develop a nuclear-powered de vice to treat "heart block," a common cardiac disease.
MOSCOW, Feb. 2--Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin called to night for a ban on the use of nuclear weapons against coun tries without such weapons on their territory.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2-- The Maritime Administration was asked today to break out an additional 25 dry cargo ships from Government reserve fleets to carry military cargoes for the Navy's Military Sea Trans portation Service.
KARACHI, Pakistan, Feb. 2 --At least 30 per cent of Pakistan's current wheat crop has been ruined so far by the most severe drought of this cen tury.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Feb. 2 (AP)--Navy passed the .500 mark today for the first time this season with its fourth straight basketball victory, a 96-79 triumph over Hofstra.

CRANBURY, N.J., Feb. 2 --Robert Lee Hoke, who was in charge of public relations for Laurence S. Rockefeller's resort hotel operations, died this morn ing of a heart attack as he boarded a train at Princeton Junction to go to his New York office. He was 44 years old and lived at 6 King George's Road here.

CHICAGO, Feb. 2--Accept ance without enthusiasm is the general atttude toward the Vietnam War in the upper east ern Middle West despite Presi dent Johnson's quest for a United Nations peacemaking role.
KANSAS CITY, Mo., Feb. 2-- The nation's midsection has ac cepted President Johnson's re sumption of bombing in North Vietnam as logical, expected and proper.
For the second time in the conspiracy trial of former As semblyman Hyman E. Mintz a prosecution witness admitted yesterday that he had commit ted perjury while testifying be- fore a grand jury.

Joseph G. Goldring, founder of Goldring Motors, Inc., died of a heart attack Tuesday in his office at the company head quarters, 9601 Kings Highway, Brooklyn. He was 71 years old and lived at 30 Vernon Avenue, Atlantic Beach, L.I.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb. 2--The United States' search for peace in Vietnam through the United Nations made its first significant ad vance today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2--The Justice Department said today, it would review an outline of Joseph M. Valachi's memoirs for material offensive to Italian- Americans before it approved the publication of the convicted murderer's life story.
Copper futures, which time and again have set new life-of- contract highs is recent weeks, did it once again yesterday.

The Lockheed-Georgia Company of Marietta, Ga., announced yesterday awards of two major subcontracts for the Air Force C-5A cargo jet.

William L. Edwards Jr., vice president and controller of the Universal Match Corporation, was elected yesterday as a director of the concern.

The election of J. Victor Herd as chairman of the Salvation Army's New York advisory board was announced yesterday. He succeeds Walker G. Buckner, who has completed three terms of office, the maximum under the board's constitution.

DON CARPENTER'S first novel roars through dim Western streets like an articulate Hell's Angel looking for a fight. Jaw clenched, it swaggers into the living room with all the bad news about life down at the poolroom. By the time Jack Levitt, the book's outcast hero, reaches his final failure, giggles have replaced pity.

PARIS, Feb. 6 Chancellor Ludwig Erhard of West Germany, who arrives here tomorrow for two days of talks with President de Gaulle, is likely to find the French in no mood to discuss more than routine matters.

HONOLULU, Feb. 6 President Johnson's sudden decision to meet here with top United States and South Vietnamese officials struck this island with the force of a kona storm the local version of a hurricane and with a lot less warning.
TORONTO, Feb. 6 (Canadian Press) Steve Vehslage of New York won the Canadian amateur open squash title today by defeating Colin Adair of Montreal, 15-8, 15-10, 15-8.

HONG KONG, Feb. 6--Both North Vietnam and Communist China said today that the gathering in Honolulu of United States and South Vietnamese leaders was proof that the United States was facing increasing difficulties in Vietnam.

Mrs. Barbara Bailey Brown, wife of Wentworth Brown, vice president of the overseas division of the International Paper Company, New York, died yesterday in the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center after a brief illness. She was 56 years old and lived at 5355 Henry Hudson Parkway in Riverdale, the Bronx.
LONDON, Feb. 6 The Jodrell Bank radio observatory said tonight that its tracking station received photographic transmissions from Luna 9 for one hour and 21 minutes earlier this evening.

The series known as "International Zone" is the quietly effective program of United Nations Television. While so much televised news from the United Nations necessarily is concerned with conflict and discord, this half-hour stresses progress in achieving the better life. Yesterday afternoon the television unit began another season on Channel 4 with a report on emancipation of women in Tunisia.
MIAMI, Feb. 6 (AP) Seven children and three men died early this morning in a fire that swept a crowded, dilapidated tenement near downtown Miami.

Carlos Montoya, wizard of the guitar and absolute master of flamenco musical styles, gave a recital at Town Hall on Saturday night that, as usual, drew so many devotees the overflow had to be seated on the stage.

JERUSALEM, (Israeli Sector) Feb. 6 Israel's High Court reversed itself today and ruled that an Arab terrorist condemned to death by a military court would not be entitled to a foreign lawyer when he was retried.
CANTON, N.Y., Feb. 6 (AP) The St. Lawrence ski team, aided by a victory today in the jumping competition, won the 33d annual St. Lawrence winter carnival ski meet.
Hermann Prey sang two Schumann cycles, "Liederkreis" and "Dichterliebe," Saturday night at Hunter College in what might be called a classical style. The German baritone's

Traffic in midtown and downtown Manhattan creeps at an average of 8 miles an hour but travel between homes and Manhattan points by rail and subway "is even slower," according to James S. Schoff, chairman of the Regional Plan Association.
CORTINA D'AMPEZZO, Italy, Feb. 6 (UPI) Guy Perillat of France won the Ilio Colli Cup giant slalom today to match his first place in yesterday's special slalom.
BRUSSELS, Feb. 6 A doctors' strike scheduled for midnight tonight was called off this evening in response to the personal intervention of King Baudouin.

STOWE, Vt., Feb. 6 Linda Bocock, a 22-year-old Canadian who had the good fortune to marry a ski instructor, won the women's division of the Stowe Cup downhill today. This victory, linked with her secondplace finish in the slalom yesterday, gave the hazel-eyed former Olympian the combined honors for the weekend.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 The Administration will soon send to Congress a bill designed to make it easier for workers and businesses adversely affected by rising imports to receive what is known as "adjustment assistance."

FLINT, Mich., Feb. 6 (AP) Bill Lanigan, an 18-year-old speed skater from New York, finished first in an Olympicstyle competition today and was named to participate in the world men's championships in Gotteborg, Sweden, Feb. 19 and 20.
A week long refresher session for the Federal Government's labor mediators will open today in the America Hotel in Houston.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 The Senate is expected to show organized labor this week what Administration sources have said all along: The votes are just not there to bring a union shop bill to the floor.

Mayor Lindsay's Law Enforcement Task Force called yesterday for a "thorough reevaluation" of the Police Department and sweeping changes, including the creation of a civilian-controlled board to review police actions.

DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., Feb. 6 Ken Miles of Hollywood and Lloyd Ruby of Wichita Falls, Tex., were the winning drivers today as Mark II, seven-liter Ford coupes swept the top three places in the Daytona Continental, the first 24-hour sports-car race in the United States.
The blood-lust of the crestfallen Ranger fan was sated last night as the New Yorkers outpointed the Montreal Canadiens.
DURBAN, South Africa, Feb. 6 (AP) Gary Player of South Africa made up a two-stroke deficit on the final round today and won the Natal open golf tournament with a par 72 and a 72-hole score of 286.

BEDFORD, N.Y., Feb. 6 Led by Pamela Strohm of Huntington, L.I., a quintet of riders from Cedar Lodge Farm in North Stamford, Conn., carried off the lion's share of honors at the Sunnyfield Farm Horse Show here today.

Dominick Argento's "The Masque of Angels," a one-act opera written for the Center Opera Company of Minneapolis in 1964, was given its first performance here yesterday at St. George's Church. The performers were students and teachers from Syracuse University, repeating a campus production.
PARIS, Feb. 6 (AP) The favored Elma won the $50,000 Prix de France trotting race today, beating Apex Hanover by a tenth of a second at Vincennes race track.
Ed Winrow of the New York Athletic Club won the Henry E. Isola Memorial run yesterday in record time. The race is sponsored by Road Runners Club of New York.

One of the more distinctive sounds of the jazz world of the nineteen-forties and fifties the quavering ululations of Sarah Vaughan with their occasional excursions onto vocalized roller-coaster rides returned to Carnegie Hall Saturday night after an absence of several years.

Frank Wille, the New York State Superintendent of Banks, has thrown the weight of his department behind a substantial expansion of branching privileges for mutual savings banks, and savings-and-loan associations in New York.
LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Feb. 6 John Bower, a husky athlete from Auburn, Me., won the jumping section of the United States Nordic combined skiing event today and finished first in the over-all competition.
PITTSBURGH, Feb. 6 Steel men were cheered by rising demand last week but were fearful that the strong market might lead to heavy imports.

Itzhak Perlman, young Israeli violinist, was soloist with the National Symphony conducted by Howard Mitchell at Philharmonic Hall yesterday afternoon. This was the fourth of five concerts on the National's "Family Day" series at the hall this season. As in the others, Mr. Mitchell introduced each work with a few spoken remarks in lieu of printed program notes.

Many older persons who soon will be eligible for the Federal Medicare program, which goes into effect July 1, are in a quandary as to what they should do with existing health insurance policies, or whether they should buy supplemental insurance.
The National Saving's and Trust Company and the Bank of Commerce, both of Washington, D.C., have agreed in principle on merger terms, it was announced over the weekend.
PETERBOROUGH, Ont., Feb. 6 (Canadian Press) Don Knight of Dundas, Ont., retained his Canadian men's figure skating championship today.

MOSCOW, Feb. 6 Valery Tarsis, an outspokenly antiSoviet writer living in Moscow, said today that he had been given permission to leave the Soviet Union to deliver a series of lectures at a British university.
More small groups and fewer large ones this is likely to become the guiding principle in our policy for sending cultural presentations abroad.

Music by four 20th-century Norwegian composers was played by the Philadelphia String Quartet at Carnegie Recital Hall yesterday afternoon. The program was given under the patronage of the Norwegian consul general, August Fleischer, and the northern mood was enhanced by the lack of heat in the hall's back rows.

LEWISBURG, Pa., Feb. 6 Cyrus H. Karraker of Lewisburg, who retired two years ago as a professor of history at Bucknell University, died of a heart attack yesterday in Evangelical Community Hospital. He was 69 years old.
WESTBY, Wis., Feb. 6 John Balfanz, the 25-year-old ski salesman with the built-in jumping jack, finished one of the most consistent performances by an American today.
ATLANTIC CITY, Feb. 6 Vic Seixas, a former Wimbledon and United States tennis titleholder, won his first men's squash-racquets championship today at Chalfonte-Haddon Hall Racquet Club.
A United States spacecraft scheduled to orbit the moon this spring on a photographic expedition may include the Soviet Union's Luna 9 on its "shooting" list.

Grosvenor Neighborhood House will receive the proceeds of the sixth annual dance of the Blue Hill Troupe, to be held on Friday at the Sheraton-East. The troupe will sing selections from Gilbert and Sullivan operettas.

RYE, N.Y., Feb. 6 Dr. Graham Knox of the Field Club of Greenwich, Conn., and Mrs. Thornton Gerrish of the home club won the Apawamis Club invitation mixed doubles platform tennis tournament for the second successive year today.
ROME, Feb. 6 Pope Paul VI indicated today that he was giving "attention" and "prayer" to the Vatican's diplomatic bid for arbitration of the Vietnam crisis.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 Following are the votes of delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on the major roll-calls in Congress during the week ended yesterday.

LITCHFIELD, Conn. It is the tiniest place anyone almost missed, two miles from Litchfield on Route 25, surrounded by the White Memorial wildlife preserve. Yet people come from as far as New York (100 miles) to the doll's house of a bakery known as the Dutch Epicure Shop.
RALEIGH, N.C., Feb. 6 An unexpectedly close margin in a special election yesterday in the First Congressional District has heartened Republican leaders in North Carolina.

Real estate foreclosures and surrenders of deeds in Manhattan totaled 130 in 1965, according to a study by the Real Estate Board of New York. In 1964 there were 151 "distress conveyances," another term for foreclosure used by the board.

LAST night's documentary entitled "The Voice of the Dragon" was a study of the methods employed by Peking in indoctrinating the mass of Chinese people in Communist philosophy. The program raised serious questions of procedure in utilizing propaganda film.

It is all but a quarter of a century since the American Ballet Theater introduced Eugene Loring's "Billy the Kid" into its repertory. On Saturday afternoon at the State Theater of Lincoln Center this Whitmanesque, Wild West dream returned to New York in all its glory.
The gentlemanly campaign for Mayor Lindsay's former seat in the 17th Congressional District took on an edge of acerbity yesterday on its next to last day.

DAYTONA, BEACH, Fla., Feb. 6 (AP) The Ford Mark II cars, which made such an impressive showing in the 24hour Daytona Continental, are second generation prototypes and among the most powerful of this type built.

CHICAGO, Feb. 6 (UPI) Eric Nesterenko drove in a rebound with less than two minutes to play tonight to give the Chicago Black Hawks a 3-2 victory over the Toronto Maple Leafs and a first place tie in the National Hockey League with the Montreal Canadiens and the Detroit Red Wings.

Forty thousand of Rhode Island's senior high school students from public, private and parochial schools will see free performances of "Twelfth Night" at the 2,000-seat Albee Theater in Providence. Twenty matinees, starting tomorrow and winding up April 29, will be given.
Two big issues of industrial company bonds will head the slate of securities offerings this week.

The Propeller Club of the United States has named Wilfred J. McNeil, president of Grace Line, Inc., as general chairman of the annual American Merchant Marine Conference. The three-day conference will start Oct. 3 in Washington in conjunction with the 1966 convention of the club.
LONDON, Feb. 6 How does an art museum defend itself against fake paintings being brought in and hung in its exhibition rooms?
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 6 Tom Farrell is taking the high road and Bill Crothers the low road toward indoor track's race of the year.

The second of two programs of music by Olivier Messiaen took place at Calvary Episcopal Church last night with performances of "Les Corps Glorieux," which is for organ, and "Visions de I'Amen," for two pianos. The first concert, given last week, offered "Le Livre d'Orgue" and "Les Trois Petites Liturgies de la Presence Divine."

MOUNT HOPE, N.Y., Feb. 6 The Ardsley Curling Club rink, skipped by Richard C. Wells, won the Ardsley Medal today by defeating the Montreal Caledonian rink, skipped by Gerald Boyd, 11-4, in the 12-end final of the annual Cuthbertson bonspiel.

The Gettysburg College Choir, an ensemble of some 60 voices from the Pennsylvania Lutheran school, gave an unaccompanied concert in Town Hall late yesterday afternoon under the direction of Parker Wagnild. The program consisted of sacred music, ranging from works by Gallus and Gibbons to arrangements of Negro spirituals and including a motet for double chorus by Bach.
THE longer Louis Auchincloss contemplates the mysteries of human character the more mysterious he finds them.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (UPI) United States economic activity in the next decade will flow toward the Far West and Southwest, the National Planning Association predicted today.

An outsider arriving in West Germany might wonder who had won the September election. Less than five months after registering its fifth straight victory, the Christian Democratic Union of Chancellor Ludwig Erhard is mired in political troubles.
MOSCOW, Feb. 6 The Russian lunar observatory has closed down, the Soviet Union announced today. Tass, the official press agency, said the Luna 9 research program had been completed.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 Is the United States Government engaged in false and misleading advertising? Those who think it is include officials of two of the Government's own agencies and some bankers. The bankers, to put the matter more accurately, merely argue that if their own bank advertising is misleading, as the Government has been telling them, then so is the Government's. No more so and no less so.
RICHMOND, Feb. 8 (AP) Chuck McKinley, ranked No. 4 in the United States, defeated Frank Froehling, 6-1, 6-2, today to win the Richmond indoor invitation tennis tournament.
ALBANY, Feb. 6 Mayor Lindsay will make his second money-hunting trip to the state capital Thursday.

TORONTO, Feb, 6 Canada's decision to sell $100-million of her gold reserves to the United States is being interpreted by some economists here as evidence of a desire for continued financial cooperation with the United States.
The president of the New Jersey College of Medicine and Dentistry, Dr. James E. McCormack, has been appointed director of the New York Academy of Medicine.
LONDON Feb. 6 A British moon expert said today that information obtained from Luna 9 photographs could save the United States space program a year in research probes of the moon's surface.
Eight Jewish teen-agers watched in wonder yesterday as a Roman Catholic priest donned the traditional vestments of his calling.
CORTINA D'AMPEZZO, Italy, Feb. 6 (AP) Marred by the death of a German driver in a crash, the world four-man bobsledding championship was called off today without a winner.
TRIVANDRUM, India, Feb. 6 Would the people of a hungry North Dakota town eat sweet and sour pork shipped in from San Francisco?

GREENWICH, Conn., Feb. 6 Mrs. Chauncey K. Hubbard of Greenwich and Hyannis Port, Mass., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Georgiana Drake Hubbard, to David A. McCabe, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles B. McCabe of Greenwich.
WARSAW, Feb. 6 A blistering personal attack on Stefan Cardinal Wyszynski was published today in a mass-circulation newspaper close to the ruling Communist party.

Mrs. Constance Maslin Boal, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Victor C. Maslin of Kent, England, was married yesterday to Robert Carl Sussman at 215 East 68th Street, the home of the bridegroom's parents, Mr. and Mrs. George A. Sussman, who also have a home in Stamford, Conn. The bride is the widow of Samuel Boal.

Airplane travel is one of the safest means of transport, but the recent disasters suffered by Indian and Japanese airliners serve as cruel reminders that fatal accidents can occur. Under these circumstances, it is lest than prudent to load into a single plane as much of the Government's top leadership as President Johnson took with him in his eleven-hour flight to Hawaii.

HONOLULU, Feb. 6 The leaders of South Vietnam are expected to ask President Johnson to blockade Haiphong harbor, intensify the bombing of North Vietnam and greatly increase the number of American troops in South Vietnam.

DETROIT, Feb. 6 James R. Hoffa, the resilient president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, sat solemnly last night while one after another of his union associates stood to praise him as a humanitarian, a fine family man, and a great labor leader.

SAIGON, Monday, Feb. 7 (AP) United States planes began raiding North Vietnam just a year ago. Despite the estimated total of 30,000 tons of bombs dropped, enemy troops and supplies keep pouring down from the North.
PITTSBURGH, Feb. 6 (UPI) Duquesne rallied from a 10point half-time deficit today to upset fourth-ranked Providence, 78-76, and snap a 10-game Friar winning streak.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 President Johnson plans to ask Congress to invest more than $400-million in the first largescale Federal assault on the problem of highway safety.

A massive technological breakthrough that will revolutionize urban living through new methods of mass transit was envisioned last week at the first International Urban Transportation Conference in Pittsburgh. But the immediate realities for transit in New York as in most other metropolitan centers are more prosaic and a good deal more bleak.

A recently formed company headed by a Houston insurance executive announced over the weekend an offer to purchase up to 55 per cent of the stock of the Phoenix Insurance Company, Hartford, at $75 a share.

HONOLULU, Feb. 6 It is clear from the complex situation in Vietnam that what President Johnson and the leaders of South Vietnam decide at the conference in Honolulu this week will largely have to conform to the realities of the war.
