American Airlines, Inc., reported over the weekend for 1965 net earnings of $39,658,000, including profits of $375,000 from the disposal of property and equipment.
Fifteen Harlem merchants hired a private detective last night to patrol their block, despite the fact that the 32d Precinct station house in on the same street.
As far as the city is concerned, most of the snow this year has fallen in the wrong places.
Robert Goelet, financier and real-estate developer who was a leader in social circles here and in Newport, R.I., for many years, died yesterday in his home, 4 East 66th Street. He was 86 Years old.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 More than 100 law professors expressed opposition today to Congressional contempt proceedings against three uncooperative witnesses in an antiCommunist investigation and seven Ku Klux Klan leaders.

Not surprisingly, racial discrimination by building trades unions is the first target of a Federal court action initiated under the fair employment sections of the Civil Rights Act. Despite intense pressure from the national A.F.L.-C.I.O. and their own parent unions, many construction locals in every part of the country cling to their traditional Jim Crow practices.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y. Feb. 6 The largest crowd of the season for a ski-jumping, event, 28,321, was on hand today to see Roger Dion, the Canaan, N.H., college sophomore, record the highest scoring performance by an American here since 1954.
The election of Allen S. Rupley as chairman of the board of directors of W.R. Grace Co. was announced over the weekend by J. Peter Grace, president and chief executive officer.

PALM SPRINGS, Calif., Feb, 6 (AP) Doug Sanders won the $100,000 Bob Hope Desert Golf Classic today by defeating Arnold Palmer on the first hole of a sudden-death playoff. Sanders made a 15-foot putt for a birdie 2 on the extra hole.

A New York rabbi called on Attorney General Nicholas deB. Katzenbach last night to investigate whether "any central organization" was responsible for an outbreak of fires and vandalism in synagogues in various parts of the country.

HELMETTA, N.J. Feb. 6 (AP) A young couple and two of their three children died early today when fire swept their wooden, ranch-style home shortly before the family was to have celebrated the father's 26th birthday. GLEN HEAD, L.I., Feb. 6 Archibald L. Gillies of Glen Head announced tonight that he was withdrawing from the competition for the Republican nomination for United States Representative from the Third Congressional District in Nassau County.

GREENVILLE, Miss., Feb. 6 Aunt Neff's Cafe was crowded one afternoon last week in nearby Sunflower, but the bright posters that advertised a cheap brand of beer and a still cheaper soft drink were failing to drum up any business.
The Diners' Club announced over the weekend that it would reduce its commission rate to restaurants from 7 per cent net to 5 per cent of gross, elective April 1.

HONOLULU, Feb. 6 (UPI) Following is the text of remarks by President Johnson welcoming South Vietnam's Premier, Air Vice Marshal Nguyen Cao Ky, and the chief of state, Lieut. Gen. Nguyen Van Thieu, here:
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Feb. 6 Ten persons were trampled and crushed to death on a narrow staircase early today in a stampede from an African dance hall here that had been raided by the police.

BOSTON, Feb. 6 (AP) John Havlicek scored 14 points and turned in a tremendous defensive performance in the final period in leading the Boston Celtics to a 100-99 decision today over the Philadelphia 76ers in a National Basketball Association game.
The Celanese Corporation had the highest sales and earnings in its 47-year history in 1965. Results for the fourth quarter also set a record.

Deposits in the nation's 506 mutual savings banks increased $220-million during January, with well over half, or $130-million, being accounted for by net gains at savings banks in New York State. This is in sharp contrast to the situation in December, when savings-banks deposits increased by $590-million nationally but declined $1.1-million in New York.

The Costa Ricans ran true to form and defeated the Presidential candidate of the party in power. A man with no political experience, Prof. Jose Joaquin Trejos Fernandez, was elected over one of the best-known public figures in Costa Rica, Daniel Oduber Quiros.
ZACHARY, La., Feb. 7 (UPI) A Negro's house was bombed last night, the fourth such mysterious explosion involving Negroes since last summer in the Baton Rouge area. Zachary is north of Baton Rouge.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J. Feb. 7 A proposed 10-year, $288.8-million educational exansion program was made public today by Rutgers, the state university of New Jersey.
LONDON, Feb. 7 Britain tightened economic sanctions against rebel Rhodesia tonight by formally making it a crime for anyone to export tobacco from the country.
An unidentified group of investors has offered to buy 500,000 common shares of the Studebaker Corporation at $30 each, it was announced last evening.
LONDON, Feb. 7 The Government clamped down further today on the use of installment credit. The move is part of the effort to restore Britain's balance of payments equilibrium by the end of the year.

CHICAGO, Feb. 7 Augustine J. Bowe, presiding judge of the Municipal Division of the Circuit Court, collapsed and died of a heart attack last night while taking a walk near his home. He was 73 years old.
HONOLULU, Tuesday, Feb. 8 A large increase in bombing of North Vietnam would not assure victory in South Vietnam, a high United States official said last night.

BACK in the old days many sports writers were reluctant to call a spade a spade and went in for synonyms, some of them quite far-fetched. For a reason that strains comprehension they referred to outfielders as "pickets." But that word has a new significance now that the benign and fatherly figure of Jimmy Hoffa has suddenly cast a somber shadow over the realm of sports.
NEWARK, Feb. 7, (AP) Elmira College of New York won a legal battle today for possession of a $1.75-million art collection assertedly donated by Mrs. Geraldine Rockefeller Dodge.

BUDAPEST, Feb. 3 Because of a need to impose stiff price increases on basic consumer goods and services, the Communist Government of Premier Janos Kadar appears to have lost much of the public sympathy that it earned over the last six years.

The mew 545-foot Colombian motorship Ciudad de Bucaramanga made her debut here yesterday. The $6-million vessel is the fourth of six automated cargo ships to be added to the fleet of Flota Mercante Grancolombiana, S.A.
HONG KONG Feb. 7 The Chinese Communist party is openly complaining about senior army officers who are resisting further ideological indoctrination.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Feb. 7 Milovan Djilas, the former Communist who changed his political views, today began the ninth year of a 13-year sentence in a cold cell in the Sremska Mitrovica Prison.
Ten wives of Staten Island ferry officers who have been out of work since they struck last spring picketed the terminal at South Ferry last night and prevented cars from boarding two boats.
BIRMINGHAM Ala., Feb. 7 (AP) The Southeastern Conference penalized the University of Alabama, the 1965 national football champion, today for violating a league scholarship rule.
The first installment of a $138-million Alpine oil-pipeline financing the largest corporate underwriting in recent European history got under way yesterday in London.
American Export Isbrandtsen Lines took another step yesterday in its efforts to become the nation's foremost operator of nuclear-powered merchant shipping.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 7-Senator J.W. Fulbright expressed fear today that the war in Vietnam might lead to a conflict with Communist China.
JERSEY CITY, Feb. 7 Carmelo Iglesias, a 26-year-old Puerto Rico-born college student, was named to the Jersey City Civil Rights Commission today.

SHARPEVILLE, South Africa, Feb. 5 This black township, the scene of an event six years ago that gave South Africans one of their most sobering experiences since the Boer War, is shown off by white officials these days as a model community.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 7 "Differences on policy matters" were given today as the reason for the resignation of Charles A. Wellman as president and chief executive officer of the First Charter Financial Corporation, effective immediately.
"What's good for the [Police] Department is good for the policeman and, more importantly, for the public."
New York's City Hall, hailed as "architecturally the finest treasure of our city," was designated yesterday as a landmark.

"THE minute a dress is too high priced, it gets too serious. People are finally waking up to the idea that clothes are not that important it's bad taste to be expensively dressed." Rudi Gernreich, the California sportswear designer, made the remarks yesterday at
Senator Robert F. Kennedy is using a four-man screening board to select men from New York State as candidates for appointment to the three main service academies.
SAIGON, Feb. 7 South Vietnamese clustered on Saigon's fashionable Tu Do and crowded into the central market place tonight to see their first television show.
PARIS, Feb. 7 President de Gaulle pleased Chancellor Ludwig Erhard of West Germany today by expressing the expectation that Germany will be whole again.
Prices on the London Stock Exchange were mixed at the close as the market turned cautious after the steady uptrend of last week.

ALBANY, Feb. 7 Mayor Lindsay is preparing to put a bill before the Legislature that would remove the heads of the Transit Authority and the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority and give the Mayor virtually full control over the naming of their successors.
ATHENS, Feb. 7 The Government tonight ordered civil mobilization for 8,500 state school teacher, who struck Saturday demanding higher pay.
The man of achievement, with drive and leadership in personality, probably has more than the average amount of uric acid in his blood, a new study suggests.
ALBANY, Feb. 7 A union official testified today that distillers exercised virtually exclusive control over liquor distribution in New York State.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 New Jersey construction contractor leaders met with the staff of President Johnson's Council of Economic Advisers today as the Government's effort to curb inflationary forces in the industry intensified.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 (AP) The House Ways and Means Committee agreed informally today on a way to soften the blow, of proposed increased withholding for some taxpayers with "higher than average deductions.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 With a backlog of 500 complaints awaiting adjudication, the Department of Health, Education and Welfare is organizing a broad attack on racial discrimination in schools, hospitals and other Federally supported facilities under its jurisdiction.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb. 7--All the Latin-American members of the United Nations except Mexico filed a formal protest with Secretary General Thant today against the action of a conference in Havana in advocating the use of armed force by liberation movements.
KARACHI, Pakistan, Feb. 7 (Reuters) Pakistan and India have agreed in principle to allow flights over each other's territory again, it was announced here today.
MADRID, Feb. 7 Spain's top professional soldier, Capt. Gen. Agustin Munoz Grandes, has been shifted to the Reserve. The move adds to speculation on the nation's political future.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 The forces for and against fluoridation of community water supplies fought today from their respective encampments on either side of the Potomac River.

UTICA, N.Y., Feb. 7 Senator Robert F. Kennedy said here today that he favored liberalization of New York State's "archaic" divorce laws. He did not say how he wanted the laws to be changed, but he said that he was concerned over the fact that the only ground for divorce in the state was adultery.

BUSONI'S gigantic Piano Concerto, composed in 1904 and not heard in New York until only a few weeks ago, received still another performance last night. George Szell and the Cleveland Orchestra were the sponsors in Carnegie Hall, with the Italian pianist, Pietro Scarpini.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 An Interstate Commerce Commission lawyer said today that trustees of the financially-distressed New Haven Railroad had failed to show that its passenger service was "an undue burden" on its interstate operations.

Mitchell M. Benson, a longtime radio executive who produced and directed "Duffy's Tavern" before moving on to television, died in Bedford Hills, N.Y., Sunday. He was 60 years old and lived at 4 Peter Cooper Road.

The One William Street Fund, which became the world's largest "no-load" mutual fund in July, 1964, by eliminating its sales charge, reported yesterday that 1965 sales were its highest and share redemptions its lowest since 1962.

ISLIP, L.I., Feb. 7 Mr. and Mrs. Gerard Hallock have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Helena Parsons Hallock, to John A. Pless of New York, son of Mrs. Pless Sichel of Paris and the late Anthony Pless.

RALEIGH, N.C., Feb. 7 A committee of University of North Carolina trustees voted tonight to bar scheduled campus speeches by a Communist and an opponent of the House Un-American Activities Com mittee.
The engagement of Miss Ruth Harris to John Alan Singer, son of Prof. and Mrs. James Singer of Brooklyn, has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Irving Harris.

TRIVANDRUM, India, Feb. 7 Under a mango tree, surrounded by a forest of red flags, a leader of Kerala's rightwing Communists began his fifth day of fasting today to protest a cut in the state's rice ration.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 7 (AP) Wilt Chamberlain scored 65 points tonight, the most in one game in the National Basketball Association this season, and led the Philadelphia 76ers to a 132-125 victory over the Los Angeles Lakers.
Gordon Edwards, president of the National Dairy Products Corporation, was elected yesterday to the board of the Irving Trust Company, New York.

Northrup Knox of Buffalo won the first four sets from Ronald Hughes of England in their challenge match for the world open court tennis championship yesterday, and seemed almost certain to retain the title he is defending for the first time since he won it from Jack Johnson, the Chicago professional, in 1959. The scores were 6-0, 6-3, 6-5, 6-0.
The directors of the FMC Corporation yesterday proposed a two-for-one stock split, an after-split, quarterly dividend increase of 25 per cent, and announced record sales and earnings for 1965.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 (UPI) Two Government hearing examiners recommended today that Federal aid to two school districts in Mississippi and one in Louisiana be cut off because of racial discrimination.
LINCOLN, R.I., Feb. 7 (AP) Two horses making their first start of 1966 produced a $1,789.20 daily double today at Lincoln Downs.
Sir Isaiah Berlin of Oxford University, who is regarded as one of the world's foremost scholars, will join the faculty of the City University of New York next fall, serving for at least a year.

AUSTIN, Tex., Feb. 7 Two Senatorial candidates the Republican incumbent, Senator John G. Tower, and a liberal newspaper editor running as an independent, Ronnie Dugger filed for the office here today.
LOS ANGELES, Feb. 7 The Justice Department is investigating the reported production by leftists here of radio tapes aimed at undermining the United States military effort in Vietnam.

Tax Antoine, dean of television weathermen in New York, issued a new forecast yesterday. On March 14 he will switch from WNBC-TV (Channel 4), where he has dealt in meteorology for 17 years, to WABC-TV (Channel 7).

DETROIT, Feb. 7 (AP) Walter P. Reuther, president of the United Auto Workers Union, cut off the tip of his ring finger and also cut two other fingers of his left hand while using a power saw at his home in suburban Rochester last week.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 A new G.I. Bill of Rights for veterans sailed through the House today after years of active blocking from three Administrations. The vote was 381 to 0.
EAST ORANGE; N.J., Feb. 7 Upsala lost a tough basketball game tonight to City College, 78-72.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 The Treasury bill rate rose slightly at today's auction, the Treasury disclosed tonight.
BOSTON, Feb. 7 (UPI) Boston longshoremen have voted to end their traditional shapeup hiring methods and allow automation of the docks in return for a guarantee of 40 weeks of work a year.
A competition to find the most talented pianist in the public high schools here is under way, sponsored by radio station WQXR, in cooperation with the Board of Education.

AMITYVILLE, L.I., Feb. 7 Harry J. Blank, board chairman and treasurer of Zophar Mills, Inc., 112 26th Street, Brooklyn, died Saturday in Brunswick General Hospital here after a short illness. He was 68 years old and lived here at 130 Riverside Avenue.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 (UPI) Two Mississippi law officers and a former officer were charged by the Justice Department today with violating the civil rights of prisoners.

Dr. Bernard E. Donovan, Superintendent of Schools, criticized the United Federation of Teachers yesterday for urging its members not to admit to their classrooms studentteachers from St. John's University. The university is being picketed by the local chapter of a related union, the United Federation of College Teachers.
Steel production dipped seven-tenths of 1 per cent last week, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.
Long-term Government bond prices, which last week registered their sharpest declines since the Federal Reserve discount rate went up in early December, continued to
TORONTO, Feb. 7 (Canadian Press) The Royal Commission on the Atlantic Acceptance Corporation held a brief sitting today to accept 83 documents as evidence.

Those in Britain, the United States and the Soviet Union who have concluded, from the Luna 9 photographs, that the moon is covered with lava-like material were sharply criticized yesterday by those who think it is dust.
SOUTH PORTLAND, Mc., Feb. 7 (AP) Eighteen Pakistani crewmen walked off an oil tanker last Sunday on the grounds that they were being forced to extend their contracts on an unseaworthy vessel.

The city's Department of Marine and Aviation has deferred for the second time the closing date for bids for the proposed $12-million marina, shopping center and recreation area in the Mill Basin area of Brooklyn.
The spot rate on the British pound continued to show an easing tendency yesterday, closing at $2,8033, down 3 points from Friday's level, in moderate trading on foreign exchange markets here.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 The United States has been supplying Hawk anti-aircraft missiles to Iran as part of its military aid program for the Middle Eastern ally, State Department officials disclosed today.

MONROVIA, Liberia, Feb. 7 (Reuters) About 10,000 Firestone rubber workers in Liberia returned to work today after a five-day strike said by officials to have cost the company several hundred thousand dollars.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 (AP) President Johnson sent a message tonight to the opening session of the 14th annual Women's Forum on National Security, applauding their theme "United We Stand."

SCARSDALE, N.Y., Feb. 7 Mr. and Mrs. William Harrison Soth have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Cynthia Ann Soth to Cary Cornelis de Vroedt, son of Mr. and Mrs. Cornelis de Vroedt of Astoria, Queens, and Lake Peekskill. A June wedding is planned.
LEXINGTON, Ky., Feb. 7 (AP) Kentucky gained an 85-75 Southeastern Conference basketball victory tonight over Florida.

GENEVA, Jan. 7 Dr. Robert S. Aries, a Bulgarian-born chemist, was committed by a local court today to stand trial on criminal charges of swindling and industrial espionage based on complaints filed by United States companies.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 Three leading economists argued today that Europeans and Americans have a false view of the United States balance of payments a view leading to American capital-movement controls that are harming both sides.

Walter Lovinger, founder, president and chairman of Eastern District Burglar Alarm Corporation, 3440 Atlantic Avenue, Brooklyn, died Sunday of a heart attack in his home at 165 East 72d Street. He was 58 years old.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 (UPI) The Senate, marking time until a preliminary test tomorrow, droned into a 12th day of talk today on President Johnson's bill to nullify state "right to work" laws.

DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., Feb. 7 While four factorysupported Fords and an Italian Ferrari with factory blessing took the top places and most of the $52,000 prize money in the Daytona 24-hour Continental, one of the most valuable trophies went to a General Motors Chevrolet division Sting Ray backed by a local dealer.
CHARLESTON, W. Va., Feb. 7 (AP) Johnny Lesher, a sharpshooter from Claymont, Del., led West Virginia to a 94-90 upset over Dulke's basketball team tonight.

PLANDOME, L.I., Feb. 7 The engagement of Miss Susan Klaussmann, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Eric K. Klaussmann Jr., to John Jeffrey Derecki, son of Mrs. Carl H. Schneeweiss of Sparta, N.J., has been announced by the future bride's parents.
PALM BEACH, Fla.--The bikinis haven't been in evidence much here lately, partly because of the cold snap but also because the capital of conspicuous consumption is basically conservative.

Three pharmaceutical producers and one hospital supply manufacturer turned in record sales and earnings in 1965, with substantial gains shown by each of them. They include the Bristol-Myers Company; Parke, Davis Co.; William H. Rorer, Inc., and the American Hospital Supply Corporation.

SAN DIEGO, Calif., Feb. 7 (AP) Faulty winds ruined Serena's chance of a speed record and cost the San Francisco scratch schooner the lead today near the end of the 1,430-mile San Diego Acapulco yacht race.
BALTIMORE, Feb. 7 (AP) Longshoremen returned to work in the Port of Baltimore tonight, ending an 11-day wildcat strike that cost the port $5 million in business.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 A bitter dispute involving outright name-calling among the members of the Federal Trade Commission became public today in connection with one of the Commission's RobinsonPatman act cases against apparel manufacturers.
TRENTON, Feb. 7 Gov. Richard J. Hughes's state income tax bill was introduced today in the Assembly. He plans for a vote on it March 14 and a week later in the Senate.
ALBANY, Feb. 7 The Senate voted today to establish a state lottery, with the proceeds to be spent exclusively for education. The Assembly is expected to follow suit tomorrow.
Ron Hunt signed his 1966 contract with the New York Mets yesterday for $25,000, the same salary he received last year when he was injured twice and missed 105 games.
The wholesale commodity price index rose to 112.7 on Friday from 112.6 on Thursday.
Quality stocks dominated trading on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday as prices generally moved ahead in brisk trading.

ST. LOUIS, Feb. 7 (AP) The A.F.L-C.I.O. Building and Construction Trades Council was enjoined today from trying to stop the contractor for the Gateway Arch Visitors Center from doing business with a plumbing company employing Negroes.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb. 7 Alexander Calder has presented one of his stabiles as a gift to the United States delegation.
The American Machine and Foundry Company announced here yesterday the election of Ray L. Coffey as a vice president and general counsel.
BUFFALO, Feb. 7 (AP) Floyd Gray of New York City won the featured senior men's three-mile event yesterday in the New York State outdoor speed skating championships at Delaware Park.
NEW DELHI, Feb. 7 (AP) A Fokker Friendship propjet airliner with 3 persons aboard is missing and feared down today in a Himalayan pass in Kashmir.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 Members of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee subjected United States policy in Latin America to intensive and often critical questioning in a day-long confirmation hearing for Ambassador Lincoln Gordon today.

OKLAHOMA CITY, Feb. 7 (AP) The judicial council of the United States Court of Appeals for the 10th Circuit in Denver has issued a modified version of its order stripping United States District Judge Stephen S. Chandler of Oklahoma City of all his powers and authority.
Two composers, Harold Branch and Harold Seletsky, presented a program of their works in Carnegie Recital Hall last night.
BOSTON, Feb. 7 (AP) Harvard, backed by the brilliant goal-tending of Bill Fitzsimmons, upset Northeastern, 5-1, tonight in the annual Beanpot hockey tournament at the Boston Garden.

Representatives of Baltimore and San Francisco-Oakland groups seeking franchises in the National Hockey League's projected six-team second division expressed optimism yesterday after having their applications screened by the circuit's board of governors at the Hotel St. Regis.
ALBANY, Feb. 7 Governor Rockefeller announced today the appointment of Jackie Robinson, the former baseball star, as a Special Assistant to the Governor for Community Affairs.
The House of Representatives votes tomorrow on a resolution to cite three Chicago residents for contempt of Congress for their refusal to testify before the Committee on Un-American Activities.
Prince Philip, the Duke of Edinburgh, will be guest of honor at a dinner March 19 at the Americana. The event will be a benefit for Variety Clubs International.
YONKERS, Feb. 7 A 66year-old Columbia University physicist and his 62-year-old wife, who was crippled in an automobile crash last summer, were found dead this morning in their Yonkers apartment.
Dr. and Mrs, Bernard Rogoff of Forest Hills, Queens, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ilana Rogoff, to Edward S. Reich, son of Mr. and Mrs. Herman Reich of Brooklyn.

HONOLULU There's so much prosperity in Hawaii that it's becoming a problem. Every year it is more difficult for the islands to protect their much-promoted, very valuable image of a "Pacific Polynesian Paradise." How do you hide superhighways and high-rise hotel-apartment and business buildings from the tourist who comes here ex

ROSEMONT, Pa., Feb. 7 Mr. and Mrs. Thomas M. Rauch have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Paton Spring Rauch, to Andrew Jackson White, son of Dr. and Mrs. William H. White of St. Louis.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 The Securities and Exchange Commission made known today its intent to stand by its guns and insist on more complete information from securities firms on their earnings.

A Federal grand jury indicted A. James Comenzo, a former floor broker on the New York Produce Exchange, and several other defendants yesterday on charges of fraud and violations of the Commodity Exchange Act.
The common problems of the thoroughbred and standardbred racing interests have led to an era of good feeling between the groups.
Helped by a number of special situation issues, the American Stock Exchange turned in another good performance yesterday on fairly heavy volume.

ALBANY, Feb. 7 Efforts to reach a bipartisan compromise on reapportionment of the Legislature stalled today, and Republican and Democratic leaders began pushing their conflicting plans for new Senate and Assembly districts.
NEW HAVEN, Feb. 7--Fifty-eight teachers at the Wilbur Cross High School here have donated 108 of their sick leave days to a young teacher who is recuperating from a heart ailment and surgery.

The low-key atmosphere of the Paris meeting between Chancellor Erhard and President de Gaulle, at which a predicted clash was successfully avoided, owes much to the compromise in Luxembourg last week that eased the crisis in Europe's Common Market.
ROME, Feb. 7 (AP) The Vatican's daily newspaper today praised American movies produced in 1965, declaring that Hollywood is gradually returning to past standards of "supremacy and prestige."

After 15 years of beaming broadcasts through the Iron Curtain, Radio Free Europe has a regular audience of 22 million adults in Soviet-bloc countries, according to the annual report of its parent body, Free Europe, Inc. This figure represents an addition of 2 million listeners since 1964.

The election of Edward J. Daly, president of World Airways, as first vice president of the National Air Carrier Association, was announced yesterday by Roy E. Foulke, president of the trade group representing certificated supplemental air carriers.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., (AP) Three world records were set yesterday in the 28th annual Southland Regatta on Lake Maggiori.
PARIS, Feb. 7 The Government-owned radio and television network was hit today by a strike of most of its news staff. The issue is wages, but there are political effects.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., Feb. 7 Representatives of 250 drivers and mechanics reached a tentative agreement with the Bee Line tonight to end a week-long bus strike that has halted service on four routes in Nassau County.

MIAMI, Feb. 7 (AP) Two ex-convicts testifed today that Melvin Lane Powers had offered them $10,000 to commit murder and one said he had received his proposition in the presence of Mrs. Candace Mossler.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 The Government increased today from 5 to 5 per cent the maximum interest rate on home mortgages insured by the Federal Housing ...
LONDON, Feb. 7 (AP) Queen Elizabeth II has succeeded, after a months-long search, in filling a palace job that carries a lot of prestige. The pay and hours are not very good, though.
Senator John J. William of Delaware, an admirably strict man where political ethics are concerned, did his best the other day to point his party on the right road on campaign financing.

"Strong disapproval" has been expressed by the Dramatists Guild at the practice of reviewing a preview of a production rather than the premiere, it was announced yesterday by Sidney Kingsley, the guild's president.
PALOMARES, Spain, Feb. 7 (Reuters) United States Navy search teams were believed tonight to have found a missing nuclear weapon 1,000 feet down, two miles offshore.

BAY SHORE, L.I., Feb. 7 Four elderly women died in a fire that swept through a rest home here this morning as 15 other boarders, ranging in age from 62 to 100, scrambled for their lives in their nightclothes.
ANKARA, Turkey, Feb. 7 (Reuters) Foreign Minister Ihsan Sabri Caglayangil said tonight that there was a possibility of war between Turkey and Greece and that Turkey had taken all precautions.
Alan E. Schwartz, a lawyer and former chairman of Arlan's Department Stores, Inc., has been elected chairman and
An old New England concern, the International Silver Company, overcame its "Yankee" reluctance yesterday and went before the New York Society of Security Analysts for the first time in its history.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 (AP) Mike Reilly, chief of the Secret Service during the Administration of President Franklin D. Roosevelt, said tonight that he planned to run for the office of United States Senator from Montana.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., Feb. 7 (UPI) A three-judge Federal court today declared Alabama's law excluding women from jury service unconstitutional as of June 1, 1967.

Prices increased sharply in two widely different types of commodities yesterday. Soybeans and wheat on the Chicago Board of Trade soared on news of continued large shipments abroad, and copper futures again moved up the daily 2 cents a pound limit on the Commodity Exchange here, to set new highs because of strikes in Chile and Zambia.

SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Feb. 7 Twenty-four Rhodesians were brought to trial in the High Court here today, accused of having undergone training in the Soviet Union, Communist China and North Korea as saboteurs for Rhodesia's banned nationalist parties.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 7 More than 100 students at Bryn Mawr, Swarthmore and Haverford Colleges, along with several professors, reached the midway point today in an eightday fast in protest against United States policy in Vietnam.

Three of the nation's largest chain-store organizations Sears, Roebuck Co., the J.C. Penney Company and GambleSkogmo, Inc. each announced yesterday record sales for their fiscal year ending in January.
The American Jewish Congress asked the Legislature yesterday to reject a bill requiring school boards to provide "special "remedial services" in private and parochial schools.

Property owners may obtain information about the tentative assessed value of New York City real estate for the fiscal year July 1, 1966, to June 30, 1967, from the Tax Collector's office in each borough.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Feb. 7 Mr. and Mrs. Robert Sargent McCoy have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Patricia Day McCoy, to Douglas Hewitt Shafner. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Douglas F. Shafner of Marblehead, Mass.
THE Far Eastern tour of Mary Martin in "Hello, Dolly!" was presented in newsreel form last night over the National Broadcasting Company's network.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., Feb. 7 State Assembly Speaker Jesse M. Unruh, the Democrat's, mystery man, threw California politicians into fresh turmoil today by refusing to rule out the possibility of his running for any one of several offices this year, including governor.

The directors of the HaryouAct program voted last night to keep Livingston L. Wingate as the nonactive executive director at least until he completes a "reconstruction" of the agency's financial books.
NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 7 Joseph C. Broussard, founder and operator for 46 years of Broussard's Restaurant, died at his home over the restaurant Saturday night. He was 76 years old.
A 25-year-old member of a prominent family was charged with homicide yesterday after the police found the body of a 19-year-old girl in the trunk of his rented car.
GENEVA, Feb. 7 The United States returned unread today a note from East Germany to the 17-nation disarmament conference, which is discussing the question of halting the spread of nuclear weapons.

A psychological test with questions about sexual behavior and religion that was given at a public school here last month was designed for adults, its publisher said yesterday. He evidenced displeasure at its use on 14-year-old pupils.
The storm-battered Liberian freighter Arion was reported by the Coast Guard yesterday to be 260 miles east of Bermuda.
Sullivan, Stauffer, Colwell Bayles, Inc., got its other foot on the Ballantine bar rail yesterday.
DICK HOLUB, Fairleigh Dickinson's basketball coach, had praises yesterday for the ability of present-day college basketball players to hit the basket consistently.
KARACHI, Pakistan, Feb. 7 (AP) Five women died in a landslide near Quetta, 700 miles north of here, after a severe earthquake jolted several cities in West Pakistan today.
The Utica Mutual Insurance Company announced yesterday the election as a director of George L. Nohe, financial vice president of Beech-Nut Life Savers, Inc.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 Antipoverty workers in New York said today they were organizing a national demonstration in Washington for peace in Vietnam.
SAIGON, Feb. 7 After waiting for two days for the rain to stop and the fog to lift, American troops swept today into the Anlao Valley in central South Vietnam.

LONDON, Feb. 7 The belief is growing here that British membership in the Common Market will soon be a real possibility. Intensive speculation on this seems to be based on significant changes of attitude on the Continent and in Britain.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 A Klavern of the United Klans of America Inc., was accused today of conducting a campaign of terror and violence on behalf of a white labor union that struck a Birmingham, Ala., plant where mostly Negroes were employed.

KENNETH REXROTH, the poet, painter, essayist, philosopher, lecturer, translator, and former popcorn machine operator, burlesque house candy butcher, and cow puncher, has written a chronicle of his early years that exerts considerable charm despite its arrogance.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 (AP) An appeal to the Gov ernment to bar chemical coloring or flavoring from peanut butter was voiced today by Dr. Wilhelm C. Hueper, retired chief of the Environmental Cancer Division, National Cancer Institute.
BRUSSELS, Feb. 7 The political situation remained tense and uncertain tonight even though the nation's doctors called off the strike they had scheduled for this morning.
A Manhattan woman complained in court yesterday that her landlord sends up too much heat.
A new theory of how cancer might be caused by such diverse agents as viruses, chemical poisons and atomic radiations was proposed at a scientific meeting here yesterday.

The New York Knickerbockers go after their fourth consecutive victory tonight when they meet the Philadelphia 76ers in the second game of a National Basketball Association double-header at Madison Square Garden. Not since December, 1962, have the Knicks won four straight.
The appointment of Noel Rubinton as general counsel and secretary was announced here yesterday by Bloomingdale's, a major retailing division of Federated Department Stores, Inc.

TORONTO, Feb. 7 Executives of major Canadian subsidiaries of United States corporations said today that their operations probably would be little affected by Washington's balance-of-payments guidelines.
Directors of National Airlines, Inc., approved yesterday a $161-million jet fleet expansion program, the airline announced yesterday.
HUNGRY gulls swoop off the piers as dump trucks loaded with dirt rumble down Emmons Avenue, past the empty fishing boats, the shuttered restaurants and the deserted sidewalks.
The Electric Bond and Share Company reported corporate net income yesterday of $7,659,000, equal to $1.57 a share, for 1965. This was a 13 per cent increase above the $1.39 a share earned in 1964.

MIAMI, Feb. 7 Eric Guerinand Georgie Poole, familiar figures to the fans at Aqueduct, were together today in the winner's circle at Hialeah. They attained that distinctive area after Guerin had ridden Prester John of the Calumet Farm to victory in the fourth race. The 18,600 fans didn't expect that eventuation, as indicated by the horse's straight price of $22.20.

BOGOTA, Colombia., Feb. 7 The captain of an American vessel seized last week by the Colombian Navy for allegedly having fished in Colombian territorial waters has denied any violation, it was reported here today.

A spokesman for the American Association of University Professors said yesterday that it would look into a complaint by the Rev. Gommar A. De Pauw that he had been illegally suspended from his teaching duties at Mount St. Mary's College and Seminary, Emmitsburg, Md.

The Right Rev. James P. DeWolfe, Episcopal Bishop of Long Island for 23 years and a central figure in the ouster of the Rev. Dr. John Howard Melish from a Brooklyn church in 1949, died Sunday night at St. John's Episcopal Hospital in Brooklyn. He was 70 years old.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 The Federal Reserve Board, by an unusual 4-3 division, approved today the merger of the Security National Bank of Pacific Grove, Calif., into the United California Bank of Los Angeles.
Steven Kapchak, the bootblack at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel since it opened in the fall of 1931, was told last Saturday at 7:30 P.M. that his services were no longer wanted.

DARIEN, Conn., Feb. 7 Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Foster Draper haven announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Anna Blackwood Draper, to Lieut. (jg.) George Taft Shaw, U.S.N., son of Mr. and Mrs. John C. Shaw 3d of Rowayton.
ST. JOHN, Virgin Islands, Feb. 7 There aren't a great many men who can boast that they have a pet barracuda, or the skill to spot bonefish where others see nothing. But Ridge Folk can.
LOS ANGELES, Feb. 7 (AP) A man who says going broke can help you get rich is giving $1-million to Claremont Men's College.
A delegation of about 25, mostly Negroes, scuffled with the police yesterday in an attempt to get into City Hall to see Mayor Lindsay about jobs, housing and other issues.

All that glitters from Friday to Sunday is not gold in the middle of the week, as Portia might have said. Consequently, movies of Shakespeare, ballet and opera are making money for theater owners who once viewed such cultural efforts with profound distaste.
JACKSON, Miss., Feb. 7 (UPI) Wirt A. Yerger Jr., who guided Mississippi Republicans to new political heights over the past decade, resigned today as state party chairman.

HONOLULU, Feb. 7 Premier Nguyen Cao Ky of South Vietnam had his first session around a table with Americans before he ever reached Honolulu: He lost $8 in a poker game aboard his airplane on the way here.

HONOLULU, Feb. 7 President Johnson and the leaders of the Saigon Government agreed today that social and economic reform in South Vietnam was a key element in winning the war against Communist aggression and infiltration.
ARCADIA, Calif., Feb. 7 (UPI) Alex Maese, a popular Western rider, was named today the 1966 winner of the George Woolf Memorial Jockey Award.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 The Securities and Exchange Commission began proceedings today aimed at the revocation of the broker-dealer registration of Investors Overseas Services, the organization that controls the Fund of Funds, the fastgrowing mutual fund that is sold to foreign investors.
The Congress of Racial Equality disavowed yesterday an "intolerable" racist attack made by one of its local officials at a meeting of the Board of Education in Mount Vernon, N.Y.

Verdi's "Un Ballo in Maschera" was revived at the Metropolitan. Opera last night after a three-year absence. If both Ita Maximowna's handsome sets and costumes and Guenther Rennert's traditional staging were carry-overs from before, the performance had such musical freshness that it might as well have been a brand-new production. It is a splendid addition to a season more than halfway through.

Archibald MacLeish has been elected a Fellow of the Acad emy of American Poets for 1966. Mrs. Hugh Bullock, president of the academy, yesterday announced the election by its board of chancellors, all poets or critics.
Just who is president or in control of Avien, Inc., remained a mystery yesterday.
NEW HAVEN, Feb. 7 After 171 years, Boswell is being definitively Boswelled.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Feb. 7 Jose Joaquin Trejos Fernandez, a political novice, was the President-elect of Costa Rica today after a narrow victory over Daniel Oduber Quiros, the candidate of the ruling National Liberation party.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 (AP) Whether Staughton Lynd violated any rules by going to London depends on whether he received notifcation before he left that his passport had been canceled, the State Department said today.
A new real estate concern, with offices at 400 Madison Avenue, has been organized by Joel I. Banker under the name of Joel I. Banker Realty, Inc.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb, 7 Arthur J. Goldberg, chief representative of the Uniited States, spent an hour today with Secretary General Thant, discussing the outlook for a negotiated settlement of the war in Vietnam.

SESTRIERE, Italy, Feb. 7 (UPI) Jokio Kasaya, a 23year-old Japanese economics student, gained the first Gold Medal of the World University Games today by winning the special ski jumping event. The contest was marred by the fall of a Soviet jumper and a dispute over the maximum number of entries from each nation, which caused three Soviet athletes to be dropped from the standing.
MOSCOW, Feb. 7 On the moon the scene all around is of a wasteland more desolate and forbidding than anything earth has to offer.
An olive branch was extended yesterday in track and field's fight for control. At least, it looked like an olive branch, though it might have been only an out for a man who didn't want to say no.

A Broadway musical is to emerge from Dr. Eric Berne's book, "Games People Play: The Psychology of Human Relationships." The 192-page book that has been on the best-seller list for 28 weeks was published in 1964 by Grove Press.

THE Bermuda Regional Championship that ended Saturday was by far the biggest tournament ever held on that isolated Atlantic outpost of Britain. Some 600 players took part, and some New Yorkers were winners. The Open Pair championship was captured by Paul Trent and Carol Krupp, and the Men's Pair Championship by Dr. Robert Tator, playing with Chester Davis Jr. of Arlington, Mass.

EL PASO, Tex., Feb. 7 Federal charges were filed today against five El Paso men in connection with what United States Customs officials called an arms conspiracy involving persons in the United States, Mexico, Panama and other Latin-American countries.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 Most oF the critical response to the television treatment of "Batman" seems to have missed the point. The critics have been debating whether it is so bad that it's good or so bad that it's terrible, but the important fact is that it's un-American.
The "enclave strategy" for Vietnam has evoked a variety of opinions from supporters and opponents of the Johnson Administration's policies.
A portable clothes dryer that accommodates two pounds of laundry and dries nylons in 10 minutes was among the products introduced yesterday at the opening of Macy's housewares show in the basement.
Staten Island's Borough President and three City Councilmen have recommended to Mayor Lindsay that the proposed route of the Richmond Parkway be retained.
Congestion in the courts, where cases sometimes have to wait four or five years before they come to trial, is a familiar if depressing story.

TOKYO, Tuesday, Feb. 8 A United States Defense Department mission has arrived here to explore the possibilities of bartering missiles and other weapons for Japanese vehicles, materiel and supplies for American military forces in South Vietnam, official Japanese sources reported today.
Members of the Transport Workers Union have overwhelmingly ratified new labor contracts with the Transit Authority and its subsidiary, the Manhattan and Bronx Surface Transit Operating Authority.
An extremely close contest is expected today in the special election in the 17th Congressional District for Mayor Lindsay's former seat.
Staten Island's Borough President and three City Councilmen have recommended to Mayor Lindsay that the proposed route of the Richmond Parkway be retained.
Congestion in the courts, where cases sometimes have to wait four or five years before they come to trial, is a familiar if depressing story.

TOKYO, Tuesday, Feb. 8 A United States Defense Department mission has arrived here to explore the possibilities of bartering missiles and other weapons for Japanese vehicles, materiel and supplies for American military forces in South Vietnam, official Japanese sources reported today.
Members of the Transport Workers Union have overwhelmingly ratified new labor contracts with the Transit Authority and its subsidiary, the Manhattan and Bronx Surface Transit Operating Authority.
An extremely close contest is expected today in the special election in the 17th Congressional District for Mayor Lindsay's former seat.
The directors of the General Motors Corporation raised the cash dividend on the common stock yesterday, but dashed Wall Street's hopes for a stock split.

Benedict Livingston has been appointed executive vice president and director of David Scribner Associates, 279 East 44th Street, real estate investment analysts and realty consultants. Mr. Livingston has rejoined the company after two years with the Real Estate Research Corporation.
WHITING, Ind., Feb. 8 (UPI) A fog stripped the paint from scores of homes here today. Those that didn't peel turned a rusty orange.
The United States Lines has gained a lap on its competitors in the multimillion dollar race to provide containership service across the lucrative North Atlantic trade route.

BOSTON, Feb. 8--The nationwide hunt for a 19-year-old honor student at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology that began on Dec. 1 ended today when his body was found frozen in the ice of the Charles River less than two miles from the college.

Fifty years ago, come December, the Philadelphia Orchestra gave the first American performance of Mahler's "Das Lied von der Erde." Generally acknowledged as the composer's masterpiece, it had had its premiere posthumously only five years before that.

PORT OF SPAIN, Trinidad, Feb. 8 (AP)--An overheated floodlamp exploded like a pistol shot 50 feet from Queen Elizabeth II in Trinidad's Parliament today. Glass showered down on some of the dignitaries, but it missed the Queen, who sat calmly on her throne.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y.--A Jewish leader resigned from the national board of the Congress of Racial Equality today, accusing the organization of reacting with "flabby" moral fiber to an anti-semitic remark made by one of its officers in Mount Vernon.

The "fund unit," a suggested new monetary medium for use in world commerce, was formally recommended yesterday for consideration by the governing board of the United Nations Conference on Trade and Development.
The Alleghany Corporation, the big holding company controlled by Allan P. Kirby, reported yesterday net assets of $15.45 a share as of Dec. 31, 1965. This compared with $13.57 a share a year earlier.
Faced with a serious shortage of teachers, the city school system yesterday invited qualified persons to apply for part-time positions.
ATLANTA, Feb. 8 (AP)-- Julian Bond, the young Atlanta Negro who was denied his seat in the Georgia House of Representatives, has become the only candidate for his district post in a special election.
LANSING, Mich., Feb. 8-- Charges of conspiracy and embezzlement were made today against the dismissed executive director of a public agency that operates four hospitals in Detroit suburbs.
Bobby Cassidy of Levittown, L.I., stopped Danny Garcia of the Dominican Republic in one minute 57 seconds of the third round of a scheduled 10-rounder last night at Sunnyside Garden, Queens.

ANLAO VALLEY, South Vietnam, Feb. 8--The men of the United States First Cavalry Division (Airmobile) marched through this valley today in search of the Vietcong and their North Vietnamese allies, but all they found were deserted villages and frightened old men and women and children.

HOWARD SCHENKEN and Peter Leventritt of New York, one of the world's great bridge partnerships, were winners of the Riviera Masters Tournament played in Las Vegas, Nev., last week. They shared a first prize of $7,500 teamed with Lew Mathe and Robert Ammann of Los Angeles.
Governor Rockefeller has offered Mayor Lindsay his advice and complete support on the Mayor's legislative plan for enabling him to unify policymaking in city transportation.

Almost a month after the city transit strike cut a wide swath through the city's garment industry, Seventh Avenue has largely recovered its losses, although the memory of the 12 days of heavy employe absenteeism remains painful.
Dr. Griffith took a leading role on the side of athletics in the perennial controversy regarding athletics versus academic studies.
SACRAMENTO, Calif. Feb. 8--Gov. Edmund G. Brown promised a joint session of the Legislature today that in 24 hours he would present it with his "eighth fully and carefully balanced budget."
LISBON, Feb. 8--Portuguese Government quarters expressed strong displeasure today over a newspaper attack here against the United States Ambassador to Portugal, Adm. George Whelan Anderson.

Mr. and Mrs. Jules K. Lindenberg of 215 East 68th Street have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Dale Alison Lindenberg, to Dr. William James Fisher. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Fisher of Detroit.
DAVIS, Calif., Feb. 8--An analysis of agricultural pesticide residue in the tissues of marine animals produced concern today among scientists who have been studying the oceans as a major food source.
ATLANTA, Feb. 8 (UPI)--A Georgia judge ruled today that the Braves must play baseball in Atlanta this season regardless of how a judge in Milwaukee might rule in a forthcomiing antitrust suit.
IT is about 4 o'clock on an average afternoon in New York. At the Algonquin, Tarzan's first movie mate chats with a friend and sips tea.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 8-- Ronald E. Ramsey, a bearded, young, self-styled "international freedom fighter," identified himself today as the producer of taped broadcasts used on the Hanoi radio that have urged American soldiers in Vietnam to "lay down your arms."

SAIGON, Feb. 8 (Reuters) --Guerrillas attacked an isolated Government outpost in Tayninh Province near the Cambodian border today, then ambushed a force of 200 South Vietnamese sent in to help the outpost.

Following in his father's footsteps, Edward B. Hinman became president of the International Paper Company at a board meeting yesterday. His father, John H. Hinman, who retired as honorary chairman last May, had been president from 1943 to 1954 and board chairman from 1954 to 1961. He joined the company in 1913.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 (AP) --Several members of the House raised strong objections today to President Johnson's proposal for four-year terms for Representatives.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8-- Lieut. Gen. James M. Gavin told the Senate Foreign Relations Committee today that, in his opinion, a large-scale increase of American troops in Vietnam would involve the risk of war with Communist China.
MADISON, Wis., Feb. 7-- Kappa Delta sorority has been suspended as of September, 1967, from the University of Wisconsin because its national president has failed to sign a nondiscirmination pledge.
ALBANY, Feb. 8--Governor Rockefeller said tonight that he will ask the Legislature to enact benefits for veterans of the war in Vietnam.

MONTREAL, Feb. 8 (AP)-- Bobby Hull of the Chicago Black Hawks increased his point total to 73, according to the weekly National Hockey League statistics released yesterday, and is closing in on the season record of 96 points held by Dickie Moore.

Dr. Harold Jacobziner, assistant commissioner of the New York City Department of Health, died at Mount Sinai last night following a long illness. He was 64 years old and had served in the department since 1930.

HOUSTON, Feb. 8 (AP)-- William Lockhart Clayton, a cofounder of what is believed to be the world's largest cotton company and a former Under Secretary of State, died of a heart attack in Methodist Hospital here this afternoon. The tall, stooped, white-haired; 86year-old Mississippian died at 4 P.M. after he was stricken in his Houston home.
LUSAKA, Feb. 8--The Government ordered nationwide price control today. The move is thought to be the first indication here of an impending total break in Zambia's trade relations with Rhodesia.
A life mask of President Lincoln, the only bronze from a mold that was made 60 days before his assassination, will be on view today at the American Museum of Natural History.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 8--Consumer installment credit rose $647-million in December and a record $8-billion for 1965 as a whole, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

WILMINGTON, Del., Feb. 8-- Shareholders of Madison Fund, Inc., in a special meeting here, voted today charter revisions to increase the common-stock authorization from 12.5 million shares to 15 million shares.
The wholesale commodity price index rose to 113.0 on Monday from 112.7 on Friday.
PARIS--International opinion is quite as bewildered as American opinion concerning United States policy in Vietnam. This is as true for adversaries of the United States as for friends.

OTTAWA, Feb. 8--The Canadian Government intends to pursue at policy friendly toward foreign capital while also looking to Canada's national interest, Finance Minister Mitchell Sharp indicated in an interview last night.
Widespread gains on the Tokyo stock market yesterday carried the market's Dow-Jones index over the 1,500-yen mark for the first time in two-andone-half years.

HONOLULU, Feb. 8--The leaders of South Vietnam said today that they would not negotiate with or recognize the Vietcong and showed they had little enthusiasm for a peace negotiations with North Vietnam.
WEST ORANGE, N.J., Feb. 8--Miss Nancy Carole Siminoff and John B. Lowy plan to marry on Aug. 11.

MIAMI, Feb. 8 (AP)--Roman Brother, the handicap champion of 1965, was injured during the Seminole Handicap last Saturday and was reported unable to start in the $100,000 added Widener Handicap on Feb. 19.
NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Feb. 8--Frederick Breitenfeld, patent lawyer, a partner in Breitenfeld Levine, 551 Fifth Avenue, New York, died today in his home, 72 Stony Run. His age was 67.
CLAVIERE, Italy, Feb. 8 (AP)--The Soviet Union picked up two gold medals and France one today in the World University winter games. It was a bad day for the small American team.
MIAMI, Feb. 8 (AP)--A Texas convict said today that Melvin Lane Powers had told him he had stabbed Jacques Mossler to death.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 (UPI)--A high United States official said today that he believes that North Vietnam "can make its own decisions" despite Chinese Communist influence.
Mayor Lindsay asked the Port of New York Authority yesterday to delay building the $525-million World Trade Center in downtown Manhattan.

EL PASO, Tex., Feb. 8 (AP) --A Federal agent said today that undercover agents had made a $30,000 down payment for weapons from five El Paso men who were arrested yesterday and charged with conspiring to smuggle weapons to Latin America.
New camera models and film sales produced record-breaking sales and earnings for the Polaroid Corporation last year.
Barge traffic on the nation's 12 major waterways was up 6.4 per cent last year over 1964, according to the Army Corps of Engineers.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 8--A deactivated Air Force base in Greenville, Miss., from which Air Force troops ejected impoverished Negroes last week, has been turned over to the Mississippi authorities.

BALTIMORE, Feb. 8 (AP) --Almost all members of a rebellious longshoremen's local here were back at work on the waterfront today after ending an 11-day wildcat strike that cost the Port of Baltimore an estimated $5-million.

KENILWORTH, Ill., Feb. 8 --Mr. and Mrs. Theodore Craig Diller have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Rebecca Crossetts Diller, to James Robert Howe, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Mitchell Howe of Summit, N.J.
THE focus fell on two of the American Ballet Thea ter's male dancers as the company last night opened the fourth and last week of its current season at the New York Theater, Lincoln Center.

CHICAGO, Feb. 8--More than 100 scholars and experts on Communist China gathered today at the University of Chicago for a series of meetings on that nation's economics, manpower, population and social structure.

SAIGON, Feb. 4--Although military authorities insist that it is "next to impossible" for an American soldier to survive in South Vietnam while absent without leave, two members of the First Calvary Division (Airmobile) have been proving the contrary for several weeks.
Norton W. Simon, who in recent years has emerged as the dominant power in a number of the nation's leading corporations, now has moved into the S.S. White Company, a dental supply concern.

Councilman Theodore R. Kupferman held Manhattan's 17th (Silk Stocking) District for the Republicans yesterday by defeating Orin Lehman, a Democrat, in the special election for Mayor Lindsay's old House seat. He won by 995 votes.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 8--The Senate refused today to shut off a filibuster against an Administration bill to nullify state laws banning the union shop.
Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Smith, Inc., will start on March 1 its own automatic quotation system for over-thecounter stocks, thus breaking new ground in the brokerage industry.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 8-- President Johnson plans to ask Congress to harness the nation's agricultural capacity to its foreign policy objectives in a five-year program of overseas loans and grants.

ARMONK VILLAGE, N.Y., Feb. 8--Dana Kelley, a vice president of the Bankers Trust Company, New York, died last night at White Plains Hospital after a long illness. He was 63 years old and lived at 15 Whippoorwill Road.

BEDFORD, Mass., Feb. 8 (UPI)--The Soviet Union turned off its transmitters at "key moments" so American radio-telescopes could not di rectly pick up Luna 9 photographs of the moon, the Air Force Cambridge Research Laboratory said today.
Television has come full circle. Milton Berle, its first major star in 1948, will return next fall on a one-hour weekly variety show over the American Broadcasting Company network.
ROME, Feb. 8 (AP)--Pope Paul VI has abolished an agency that for four centuries has put books considered objectionable on the Roman Catholic Index, the Vatican reported today.
The Continental Insurance Companies reported yesterday an adjusted operating income in 1965 of $47.1-million, or $3.92 a share. In 1964, it was $34.3-million, or $2.73 a share.

WATERLOO, N.J., Feb. 8 (AP)--A second Battle of Waterloo appears in the offing, with New Jersey's Conservation Commissioner and his sister lined up on opposite sides over a reservoir that would inundate a $2-million restored Colonial village.

MIAMI, Feb. 8--A Wheatley Stable 3-year-old about whom so many glowing references have been made that he has even been extravagantly described as "better than Buckpasser" flashed to a six-length victory, today, in a seven-furlong maiden race.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 8-- Eight years ago, as a lieutenant general, James Maurice Gavin sharply criticized his Government's militarystrategic policies before a Congressional panel.

HONOLULU, Feb. 8 (AP)--Following are the Declaration of Honolulu and a joint communique today by President Johnson and the South Vietnamese chief of state, Lieut. Gen. Nguyen Van Thieu, and Premier Nguyen Cao Ky:
Colorado Springs sold $16million of bonds yesterday to help finance its water supply development program, a $64million program started in July, 1963.

The Board of Health removed the director of one of the city's largest commercial clinical laboratories yesterday, and revoked the laboratory's permit to perform hormone tests unless a new director was named within 60 days.
The annual Russian Mi-Careme Dinner Dance, to be held at the Pierre on Feb. 18, will benefit war invalids and needy members of the Association of Former Imperial Russian Cavalry and Horse Artillery.
LOS ANGELES, Feb. 8--Following is the text of President Johnson's statement on the Honolulu conference with South Vietnamese leaders shortly after his arrival here tonight:

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 8-- President Johnson returned to the mainland tonight from a three-day conference with South Vietnamese leaders in Honolulu and declared that the United States and South Vietnam would prevail in the battle against aggression and for social reform in Vietnam.

We in the Police Department have carefully reviewed the report to you dated Dec. 31, 1965 of the Law Enforcement Task Force, copies of which you made available to me on Jan. 21, 1966. I enclose, herewith, a memorandum incorporating my specific comments thereon.

Enrique Negron, the Bronx grocer whose defense of a besieged patrolman is reported to have earned him the enmity of some of his neighbors, received a check yesterday for $1,053 from the police force of Des Moines, Iowa.

Alan Blank's "Composition for 11 Players" and Roman Haubenstock-Ramati's "Credentials" were the premieres at the concert of the Contemporary Chamber Ensemble in residence at Rutgers last night at Carnegie Recital Hall, and both are, in effect, works in progress.
MOSCOW, Feb. 8--A welltrodden footpath connects the Aeroport subway station with the community of tall new apartment buildings sprung up in the last few years a couple of miles from downtown Moscow.

LONDON, Feb. 8 (AP)--A prominent English poet today called Robert Lowell, the 48year-old American defeated for the post of professor of poetry at Oxford, "the most brilliant and original and serious poet of his generation."

WOMEN are a paradox to James Laver. "When a woman becomes emancipated, you would think she would go in for an orgy of femininity," he said yesterday. "Instead she flattens her figure and cuts off her hair. She did it after World War I and again after World War II."
The 10,815-ton Liberian freighter Arion limped into St. George's, Bermuda, yesterday under escort of the Coast Guard cutter Cook Inlet.
Page Communications Engineers, Inc., has received a $20-million Army contract for continued work on a wide band communications system.

THE customers put on the show at D/R International Monday afternoon. They designed the dresses, made them and then modeled them for other customers who had come to buy fabrics, home furnishings or Marimekko dresses in the shop at 53 East 57th Street. The D/R staff acted as judges and awarded prizes for the best designs.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 8--The state of Alabama hired an undercover agent for the Ku Klux Klan to investigate racial strife in that state in 1963.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 (UPI) --President and Mrs. Johnson have invited the parents of Arman Patrick J. Nugent, Luci Johnson's fiance, to stay at the White House after a party this weekend.

CHICAGO, Feb. 8 (AP)-- The March 29 bout for the undisputed world heavyweight boxing title between Cassius Clay and Ernie Terrell received official approval today from the Illinois State Athletic Commission.

Earnings of the Divo-Wayne Corporation in the first fiscal quarter ended Jan. 31, rose to about 75 cents a share from 54 cents a share in the similar three months a year earlier. Newton Glekel, president of the world's largest mobile-home producer, told shareholders at the annual meeting here yesterday.

HONOLULU, Feb. 8--The United States and South Vietnamese Governments issued today a Declaration of Honolulu that appeared to place new emphasis on winning the war through a combination of military action and expanded civic reform programs.

A team of psychologists at St. Luke's Hospital said yesterday that it would surrender copies of a disputed psychological test given to 350 ninth-grade pupils here last month if school authorities so demanded.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., Feb. 8 --Mr. and Mrs. Patrick H. Sullivan have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ann Elizabeth Sullivan, to J. Patrick Kilfoil, son of Mr. and Mrs. John F. Kilfoil of Cincinnati. An April wedding is planned.
BOSTON, Feb. 8--Nathan K. Garhart, the inventor of a process for creating materials widely used in dentistry, died here today. He was 94 years old.
The Procter and Gamble Company, the large soap and toiletries producer, announced yesterday in Cincinnati the election of Edward G. Harness as a vice president and group executive.
The State Tax Commissioner, Joseph H. Murphy, disclosed yesterday that his department had set up roadblocks between New Jersey and Staten Island to enforce the state sales tax.

THE mixologists of Manhattan, the barmen, state that New Yorkers are not for the most part adventurous in their drinking habits. They are slow to change their established habits of Scotch on the rocks, martinis extra dry and, particularly before noon, bloody Marys.
CINCINNATI, Feb. 8 (UPI) --Oscar Robertson led a fourthquarter surge to carry the Cincinnati Royals to a 128-113 victory over the Baltimore Bullets tonight in a National Basketball Association game.
A dinner in the Plaza's Grand Ballroom next Wednesday will open the 1966 fund-raising drive of the United Jewish Appeal's Young Leadership division.
PARIS, Feb. 8--Industrial production in France is rising faster than in any other major Western country, including the United States.
LANSING, Kan., Feb. 8 (AP) --Inmates of the Kansas Penitentiary are embarking this week on a test program for a new influenza pill.

Encouraged by rapidly growing markets, between 50 and 80 United States companies in the heaating, refrigeration and airconditioning fields will make a group debut at this year's spring fair in Hanover, West Germany, which opens April 30.

The engagement of Miss Sally Lynn Grant, daughter of Mrs. Ralph Freyberg of Rye, N.Y., and Arnold M. Grant of New York, to W. Shellman Morse, son of Mr. and Mrs. A. Charles Morse of Winnetka, Ill., has been announced by the prospective bride's parents.
One of Malcolm X's bodyguards admitted yesterday that he had lied before the grand jury in one part of his testimony and had been "mistaken" in another.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb. 8--President Ho Chi Minh sent letters to the leaders of several countries last month, but in his message to India and Canada, it became known today, he mentioned their special responsibility for peace in what formerly was French Indochina.
LONDON, Feb. 8--Mr. Tarsis arrived here tonight by air from Moscow after a stopover in Warsaw.

A castle, a tree and a family cemetery are among 78 properties proposed for landmark designation by the city's Landmarks Preservation Commission. The agency held a public hearing on the proposed designations yesterday at City Hall. It has previously made 50 such designations.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 8-- Cuba is pressing her bitter quarrel with Communist China in the wake of Premier Fidel Castro's denunciation of Peking on Sunday.
The hearings of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee provide the best forum for the needed searching examination of Vietnam policy.

With a cowboy hat and several pairs of skates included in her equipment, Peggy Fleming, the principal United States contender in the women's world figure skating championship, left for Switzerland yesterday.
John J. (Jack) Donohue will bring a young Holy Cross basketball team to face Manhattan tonight in his debut as a college coach at Madison Square Garden.
PORTLAND, Ore., Feb. 8-- State Treasurer Robert W. Straub announced today that he would seek the Democratic nomination for kovernor of Oregon in the primary election on May 24.
While stockholders of the unprofitable Phoenix Insurance Company are being wooed by an investor group, their management has beaten a hasty path to the merger door of a giant insurer.

The New York Yankees converted Phil Linz's restaurant into a hiring hall for baseball players yesterday. In one swoop, they dispensed $128,000 of company funds and signed six of their troops: Jim Bouton, Joe Pepitone, Al Downing, Hector Lopez, Bill Stafford and Jack Cullen.

Directors of the Carpenter Steel Company proposed yesterday a two-for-one stock split, effective April 15, and increased the quarterly dividend on the new shares after the split. The board voted the regular quarterly dividend of 45 cents on the present stock.
LONDON, Feb. 8--Prime Minister Wilson, in an attack on the left wing of his own Labor party, suggested today that some people who talked of peace in Vietnam really want victory for the Communists.
The Portuguese Tourist and Information Bureau, relocating from the New Weston Hotel, which is to be demolished, will join a small community of similar foreign tourist offices on Fifth Avenue.

The consumer side of Westinghouse Electric Corporation's 1965 operations "ran in the black, with practically all units in the group showing profits," Donald C. Burnham, president, told an overflow luncheon meeting of the New York Society of Security Analysts yesterday.
The Good Guy kissed the girl, and the kids giggled. The Bad Guy plugged the Good Guy, and the kids shrieked. The girl outfoxed the Bad Guy, and the kids cheered.
