The Texas Electric Service Company, a subsidiary of the Texas Utilities Company, sold yesterday $15-million of first mortgage bonds to a syndicate managed by Kidder, Peabody Co., Inc., and Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Smith, Inc.
Severe manpower shortages are cropping up in some key areas of the economy as rising military needs in Vietnam give new impetus to the five-year boom.

THE Comedie Francaise opened its three-week visit to New York last night with the first of four plays, Moliere's "L'Avare," and gave it a performance to make you wish that the troupe could be interned on these shores indefinitely.
Mayor Lindsay deftly handled a political hot potatoe yesterday at City Hall while he was accepting a lifetime pass to New York Yankee baseball games.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 (AP) --Advocates of fluoridation ex pressed divergent views today as to whether they should adopt a get-tough policy or continue a quiet but intensified education program to persuade more communities to fluoridate their public water supplies.

IT had been a well-kept secret but that merely heightened the anticipation. In the chill rain at the opening ceremonies of the 1952 Olympic Games in Helsinki, some 70,000 Finns awaited the arrival of the final runner with the Olympic flame. It had been lit originally in the Temple of Zeus at Olympia in Greece and carried by thousands of relay runners across Europe and up to the Arctic Circle.
TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Feb. 8 (UPI)--Florida received today its one-fourth share of a $1,860,000 treasure trove of Spanish galleon gold and silver salvaged from the bottom of the Atlantic.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8-- Lynda Bird Johnson got a big send-off to the University of Texas tonight at a good-by party given by Mr. and Mrs. C. Wyatt Dickerson at Whisky a Go-Go. Washington's most popular discotheque.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 8 --Dr. Robert F. Goheen, the president of Princeton University, said today that the National Collegiate Athletic Association's recent ruling of a minimum academic average for holders of athletic scholarships was "inappropriate and unacceptable" to schools in the Ivy League.
A report of a North Vietnam peace overture tended to depress some prices in commodity futures markets yesterday.

Elizabeth Rich, a pianist who appeared as a soloist with the New York Philharmonic in 1949, when she was 16 years old, played her debut recital last night at Town Hall. It was apparent in Miss Rich's cleanly articulated finger work that much work had gone into her preparation in the formative years. But the total impression of her playing was that of a motor talent unwarmed by mature musicianship.
Reports of peace-effort developments seeking to end the war in Vietnam caused a sharp break in the stock market in the early afternoon yesterday.
Sir Isaiah Berlin, the noted philosopher and Oxford University scholar, said yesterday that he was looking forward to joining the graduate faculty of the City University of New York next fall.
The body of an unidentified young woman, dressed in white and with stage makeup thick on her face, was found in a vacant lot in Flushing, Queens yesterday morning.
--Sophomore Warren Armstrong scored 25 points tonight to spark Wichita State to a 9284 basketball upset over thirdranked Loyola of Chicago.

GENEVA, Feb. 8--Semyon K. Tsarapkin, the Soviet delegate, read to the Disarmament Conference here today a note from East Germany join it in "renouncing nuclear weapons." Neither East nor West Germany participates in the arms talks.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 (UPI) --Assistant Treasury Secretary Robert A. Wallace said today the nation's coin supply was the best in a decade.
The bond market was buffeted yesterday by a report that Ho Chi Minh had asked the Indian Government to initiate peace moves in Vietnam.
Paperboard production increased 8.5 per cent, to 435,800 tons, in the week ended Feb. 5 from the level in the 1965 week, it was reported yesterday by the National Paperboard Association.
The Securities and Exchange Commission was told yesterday that the Swiss interests which bought a big block of common stock of Elgin National Watch Company in December owns 150,200 shares.

VIENTIANE, Laos, Wednesday, Feb. 9--A spokesman for the Laotian Defense Ministry said today that North Vietnamese tanks had been seen for the first time on the Ho Chi Minh trail through Laos, en route to South Vietnam.

DARIEN, Conn., Feb. 8--Mr. and Mrs. Robert Austin Hall have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Yoma Anne Hall, to William Hall Ingraham, son of Mr. and Mrs. Talcott Leroy Ingraham of Wallingford.

SANTO DOMINGO, Feb. 8-- Troops of the regular Dominican Army attacked yesterday the home of Maj. Miguel Angel Calderon Cepeda, former chief bodyguard of former President Juan Bosch, and took the major and four other persons prisoner.

In a last-minute change, the Festival Orchestra Society has scheduled a concert in Philharmonic Hall for Friday at 8 P.M. The orchestra had booked the hall for a benefit concert on that date, with Montserrat Caballe the soprano, as soloist. Miss Caballe became ill, however, and the event was postponed to April 17.
An underwriting sundicate headed by four banks was awarded yesterday $10-million of revenue bonds sold by the Georgia Rural Roads Authority.
Miss Elisabeth-Ann Boyd and Nelson Aldrich Roddman plan to marry in September.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8-- James E. McCarthy, who resigned as head of a major New York City antipoverty program amid charges of mismanagement, has spent the last four months examining the management of poverty projects in other cities.
A dozen loaded coal cars sank to the bottom of the East River yesterday morning after a carfloat listed first one way and then another.

Ben L. Arons, executive vice president of the Fisher Radio Corporation of Long Island City, Queens, died of a heart attack Monday while vacationing in Miami. He was 50 years old and lived at 14 Coutant Drive, New Rochelle, N.Y.

SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Feb. 8--The Rhodesian Government has assumed sweeping new powers of censorship, prohibiting newspapers and magazines even from suggesting whether they or the censor are responsible for the material they print.

STONY BROOK, L.I., Feb. 8 --Mr. and Mrs. Marvin W. Goldberg of Stony Brook and Jackson, N.H., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Nancy Anne Goldberg, to David Wilmot Cloos, son of Mrs. Wilmot David Cloos of Richmond Hill, Queens, and Lake Ariel, Pa., and the late Mr. Cloos.
Sylvania Electric Products, Inc., announced two major expansion moves yesterday.

PALERMO, Sicily, Feb. 8-- Joseph (Joe Bananas) Bonanno, the New York Mafia leader "kidnapped" on the eve of a scheduled appearance before a grand jury, is currently in Tunis as the North African representative of the Sicilian Mafia, according to informed sources here.

THIS seems to be a week for seldom-heard music. Monday night brought the Busoni Piano Concerto and last night, also in Carnegie Hall with the Cleveland Orchestra, Hadyn's "The Seasons." This may not be the rarity that the Busoni is, but it is a great piece of music that is not found in every five-and-dime, and any performance is more than welcome.

PITTSBURGH, Feb. 8--The United Steelworkers of America and 10 major steel producers will begin a series of joint labor contract studies this week that will pose ticklish political problems for the union's new leadership.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 8--An interesting sidelight came to light here today in talk among delegates to an advertising convention.
Stocks rallied in the afternoon and recovered a substantial part of their early losses in heavy trading; volume, 10.56-million shares.

Vittorio de Sica and Cesare Zavattini, the Italian directorwriter team responsible for such films as "Shoe Shine," "The Bicycle Thief" and "Two Women," and Arthur Cohen, Swiss producer, have been signed by Joseph E. Levine's Embassy Pictures to make three Englishlanguage films in the next two years.

A benefit concert for the United Singers of New York will be given Feb. 26 at 8 P.M. at Hunter College Assembly Hall. The concert will be a memoral to Karl F. Bauer, president of the singers when he died on Nov. 6.
Because of the recent cold wave in Florida, housewives in the North will probably have to pay increased prices for citrus products been reduced only last December.

Voters in the Seventeenth Congressional District continued an old custom yesterday by electing a liberal Republican to represent them in the House. Theodore R. Kupferman succeeds to the seat held for four terms by Mayor John V. Lindsay. We congratulate him on his victory. Though we preferred his Democratic opponent, Orin Lehman, we believe Mr. Kupferman will make an able Congressman.
Geoffrey B. Hutchings and Ralph E. Watt have been named to the new posts of senior vice presidents of the Bowater Paper Company. Both men were vice presidents.

Tax experts are searching for ways to relieve the growing financial burdens confronting state and local governments. The latest proposal, made by the bipartisan Advisory Commission on Intergovernmental Relations, urges the Federal Government to provide a special tax credit that would give the states an incentive to raise money by taxing incomes.

PITTSBURGH, Feb. 8 (UPI) --The Donora Wire Works in Donora, Pa., one of the most economically depressed areas in the nation, will be phased out of existence during the next year, the United States Steel Corporation announced today.
Stockholders of LTV Aerospace Corporation, a subsidiary of Ling-Temco-Vought, Inc., at a special meeting in Dallas yesterday, approved a 21 -for-1 stock split of all common stock.

Apparently believing that a National Hockey League franchise for $2-million constitutes a remarkable bargain, six club owners or part-owners from the field of professional football, the current gold mine of the sports world, were among those making bids for big-league hockey teams here yesterday.

Dr. Louis Wender, a psychiatrist and pioneer in group therapy, died yesterday of a heart attack in Montefiore Hospital. He was 76 years old and lived at 25 East 83d Street. His office was at 59 East 79th Street.

The Philadelphia and Reading Corporation, a widely diversified concern that owns 72 per cent of the stock of the Lone Star Steel Company of Dallas, now wants to increase its ownership to 100 per cent.
BRUSSELS, Feb. 8--Premier Pierre Harmel, seeking to hold his coalition Government together, appealed to Parliament today for time and "goodwill."

A man who recently refused in a face-to-face confrontation to identify a group of policemen he said he tortured him, did in fact name two lieutenants and three detectives as his attackers at a closed hearing nine months ago.
The America-Israel Cultural Foundation; the 25-year-old organization led by Isaac Stern, the violinist, opened its new home yesterday at 4 East 54th Street.

Baeza came through with another of his multiple-victory days, riding four winners. His most spectacular achievement occurred in the featured event, a seven-furlong test for older fillies and mares, which attracted three former champions.
The spot rate on the British pound was steady yesterday in slow trading on foreign exchange markets here. It closed unchanged from the previous day at $2.8033.

SAIGON, Feb. 8--United States planes showered the last of some 20 million propaganda leaflets over the population centers of North Vietnam today in the largest leaflet drop north of the demilitarized zone.

The Honolulu conference has followed the classic pattern of summit meetings that are hastily called without thorough preparation in advance: it has left confusion in its wake, with more questions raised than answered.

GREAT NECK, L.I., Feb. 8 --The annexation of predominantly Negro areas and high taxproducing properties from an adjoining school district has been proposed by the Great Neck Superintendent of Schools.

HARTSDALE, N.Y., Feb. 8Miss Pamela Nottage and her sister, Miss Cynthia Nottage, plan to be married to Army lieutenants in the summer. Mr. and Mrs. Paul Hackett Nottage have announced their daughters' engagements to William Otto Mueller Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Mueller of Magnolia, Mass., and Richard Craig Sheldon, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Knowlton Sheldon of Greenwich, Conn.

Two Arizona investors informed the Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday that they would join Morris J. Rubin, Chicago industrialist, in his proxy battle for the control of the Crucible Steel Company of America.

CHELSEA, N.Y., Feb. 8--On a desolate river bank 60 miles north of Times Square, 90 construction workers and a team of engineers are bringing New Yorkers closer to the day when, for the first time, they will drink large draughts from the Hudson River.
"I DON'T fall in love with very many things--I'm a merchandiser, not a possessor," William Doyle, a young antiques dealer, remarked.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 (AP) --The Securities and Exchange Commission revoked the brokerdealer registration today of Arnold Securities Corporation of New York City, for what it said were violations of the antifraud provision of the Federal Securities Act.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 8-- After 36 years "in the trenches and under fire," Rosser Reeves has quit the advertising business to lead a "quiet, unhurried and contemplative life."
An angry 107 families went on a rent strike in Brooklyn yesterday to protest the condition of seven buildings.

The New York Knickerbockers used speed, skillful ballhandling, excellent shooting and other elements of a repertory they have rarely exhibited to beat the Philadelphia 76ers, 136-123, last night and extend a winning streak to four games for the first time since December of 1962.

More than 146 Welfare Department workers in Harlem refused to go into the field yesterday because their union said the work outside was too dangerous.
George Lincoln Rockwell, leader of the American Nazi party, was arrested on the street here last night on a 1960 warrant charging him with disorderly conduct.

A bipartisan bill to make public the names of slum owners--including corporation stockholders--was introduced in the Legislature by six Manhattan members yesterday. The owners would also be made personally liable for repairs and for tenants' claims.

SAIGON, Thursday, Feb. 10 (UPI)--Three elite United States Special Forces teams were totally annihilated by enemy troops within an hour after they landed in Anlao Valley, in advance of a large Allied force earlier this week, it was disclosed today.
Mail from accountants and tax lawyers, among others, indicates that there should be further elaboration on cash dividends from stocks, as they relate to income taxes.
ANYONE who thinks that music was the sole pas sion in the home of Artur Rubinstein, the concert pianist, might well consult the artist's son, Paul. He is an ardent cuisinier.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 9--Dr. James Creese, president of Drexel Institute here from 1945 to his retirement in 1963, died of a heart attack last night in Colorado Springs. He was 69 years old and lived at 11 Alexander Street, Princeton, N.J.

"ANY historian who walks through this minefield of charges and countercharges," President Kennedy wryly said after the Cuban missile crisis in October, 1962, was over, "should proceed with some care."
WASHINGTON, Feb. 9--The House Ways and Means Committee reached informal agreement today on provisions of a tax bill that conforms in all basic respects to the Administration's recommendations.
BRUSSELS, Feb. 9--West Germany's trade balance improved sharply in the last quarter of 1965, with buying fueled by the United States business boom an important factor.
Arthur M. Schlesinger Jr., former special assistant to Presidents Kennedy and Johnson and who has also served as a movie critic, is about to become further involved in show business.

"ANY historian who walks through this minefield of charges and countercharges," President Kennedy wryly said after the Cuban missile crisis in October, 1962, was over, "should proceed with some care."
WASHINGTON, Feb. 9--The House Ways and Means Committee reached informal agreement today on provisions of a tax bill that conforms in all basic respects to the Administration's recommendations.
BRUSSELS, Feb. 9--West Germany's trade balance improved sharply in the last quarter of 1965, with buying fueled by the United States business boom an important factor.

MIAMI, Feb. 9--Destro was the right part of the Ogden Phipps entry today in the $35,350 Mimosa Stakes. Bracketed with My Boss Lady, Destro finished seven lengths ahead of her stablemate in the seven-furlong event. The favored Native Street was third, a head behind My Boss Lady.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9--The margin of fifteen by which the Senate fell short of the twothirds required to bring the repeal of Section 14(b) to the voting stage would seem impossible for the President and trades union leaders to overcome on the next and last try, scheduled for tomorrow.

The National Educational Television network has postponed a program probing nonprescription drugs because of a charge by a pharmaceutical company that statements about one of its products were untrue.

McCann-Erickson, Inc., has taken on the biggest coffee salesman it could find an elephant. It's said to be one of the oldest and largest pachyderms in captivity and fortunately for the cast of the television commercials, one of the slowest.
The F. W. Woolworth Company registered records in sales and earnings in 1965.

The United States Freight Company, the nation's largest freight-forwarding organization, became yesterday the largest single stockholder of Moore McCormack Company, Inc., one of the largest ship lines of the United States merchant marine.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 Congress gave its final approval to a new G.I. Bill of Rights and sent it along to the White House.
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 10 Harold E. Stassen, unsuccessful in three bids for the Republican Presidential nomination, today announced his candidacy for the party's nomination for Governor of Pennsylvania.
BOSTON, Feb. 10 The corporate community of Boston was warned today against the peril of ignoring its cultural tradition as "the Athens of America" as a factor in attracting new industry to the area.
PALM BEACH, Fla. The gravest mistake a newcomer can make is to take the name of this place literally. There's nothing beachy about it.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 Striking out for the third time, the Johnson Administration gave up the fight today to nullify state laws banning the union shop.
The annual report bug appears to have bitten Wall Street brokerage houses at long last. It means that investors will learn more about the concerns that buy and sell their securities.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 President Johnson urged Congress today to authorize a fiveyear Food for Freedom program with $3.3-billion a year to finance "a world-wide war on hunger."
HOUSTON, Feb. 10 (AP) Tornadoes stabbed destructively into eastern Texas and central Mississippi today out of a system of raging rainstorms that battered and drenched the lower Mississippi Valley.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10--Following are excerpts from a statement made by George F. Kennan, former diplomat and head of the Policy Planning Staff of the State Department, at a hearing of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee today:

The Manhattan Shirt Company, one of the nation's Big Three shirt manufacturers, announced yesterday a major executive realignment that brought two great-grandsons of the founder to the senior management position.

The Canadian Women's Club of New York will hold its annual Maple Leaf dinner dance next Friday evening in the Baroque Suite of the Plaza. R.Guy C. Smith, Canada's new Consul General here, and Mrs. Smith, will be the guests of honor.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 Governor Rockefeller placed a package of New York State problems on President Johnson's overcrowded desk today and quietly withdrew.

DETROIT, Feb. 10 (AP) The Detroit Red Wings scored two goals in each period tonight as they defeated the New York Rangers, 6-2, and moved back into a first-place tie with the idle Chicago Black Hawks.
A six-story, air-conditioned apartment house at 3535 Rochambeau Avenue in the Bronx has been sold by the Country Hill Corporation to Norwalk Properties for cash over mortgages of $1,016,000.
Archbishop Iakovos, Greek Orthodox Patriarch of North and South America, was prevented by Turkish officials from conducting a service in Istanbul last Sunday, according to church headquarters here.

David Nadien, 40-year-old Brooklyn-born violinist, will be the concertmaster of the New York Philharmonic starting in September. He comes to one of the world's most important symphonic posts relatively unknown to the public and with virtually no regular experience with an established major symphony orchestra.

PARIS It is a cold war cliche to blame the C.I.A. when things go wrong. Because their very nature condemns them to obscurity and anonymity, intelligence services attract rumors and are incapable of effectively denying them. Thus, C.I.A. "spooks" are often imagined lurking behind disasters ranging from earthquakes to unsuccessful coups d'etat.

Charlie Winner, a mild-mannered man seldom associated with a loser, was named yesterday as the head coach of the St. Louis Cardinals of the National Football League. He succeeds Wally Lemm, who was deposed last January with one year remaining on a two-year contract.

LITTLE DIX BAY, Virgin Gorda, British Virgin Is lands, Feb. 10 At the risk of sounding over-enthusiastic, this visitor would say that if an angler worked at it hard for a while, he'd stand an excellent chance of coming to grips with a record-class bonefish in this area.
The Rev. Gommar A. De Pauw, founder of the controversial Catholic Traditionalist Movement, said yesterday that Communists had "infiltrated" the Roman Catholic Church.
The expansive mood of United States business continued yesterday as companies in a variety of industries announced major growth programs.

Just One Break, Inc., will benefit from a champagne preview of an exhibition of paintings by the Italian artist Bernadino Toppi at the Burgos Galleries, 127 East 57th street, on Tuesday evening. The exhibition will be open to the public Wednesday through March 14.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 Nationwide retail sales, seasonally adjusted, fell 1 per cent in January from the December level to $24,855,000,000, the Commerce Department reported today.
A LOVELY production of a great play opened last night Racine's "Phedre" at the Off-Broadway Greenwich Mews Theater. It is the best performance in English of a classic French tragedy that I have seen.

A bill will be introduced in the City Council next Tuesday that would ease the plight of homeowners who now have to search through the City Record to learn about public hearings on zoning changes that affect their neighborhoods.
E. Victor Seixas of Philadelphia, the defending champion, will meet Sid Hetherington of Montreal today in the first round of the United States veterans squash racquets singles championship.

MONTEGO BAY, Jamaica, Feb. 10 Billy Rose, the showman who made a fortune out of extravaganza, beautiful girls and the stock market, died at 2:15 A.M. today of lobar pneumonia at the Eldmire Nursing Home in Montego Bay. He was 66 years old.
The name of the mystery man who on Monday offered to buy 500,000 common shares of the Studebaker Corporation at $30 a share was disclosed late last night by the Studebaker board.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 (UPI) Representative Olin E. Teague Democrat of Texas, introduced legislation and a constitutional amendment today to outlaw actions by what he called "beatnik types and pseudo-intellectuals" protesting the war in Vietnam.

A selective list of restaurants in New York and vicinity is given every Friday on this page. The resturants are rated on the basis of four stars to none. The criterion is the food and service in relation to the cost of dining in any particular establishment.
ATLANTA, Feb. 10 (AP) Henry Aaron, the Braves' highest paid player, today signed his 1966 contract.
SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Feb. 10--Prime Minister Ian D. Smith warned tonight that Rhodesia would not fall lightly to Britain or any other country contemplating a military adventure.
Several drug and toiletry product manufacturers reported yesterday that sales and earnings were the highest in history.

Litton Industries, Inc., the West Coast business equipment, industrial products and electronics producer, has elected as directors Harry J. Gray and William E. McKenna, both senior vice presidents. The announcement was made yesterday by Charles B. Thornton, chairman.
The Chrysler Corporation reported yesterday record sales and earnings for 1965 as well as for the fourth-quarter.

WESTPORT, Conn., Feb. 10 Mr. and Mrs. Arthur T. Sarnoff have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth Ann Sarnoff, to Bennett Godfrey Galef Jr., son of Mrs. Benjamin Miller of New York and the late Mr. Galef. A May wedding is planned.
The Welfare Department and a union of social workers reached a "temporary compromise" late yesterday in a dispute over unsafe working conditions in Central Harlem.
LONDON, Feb. 10 Maj. Gen. J.F.C. Fuller, a noted military historian and theorist, died today. He was 87 years old.
Christopher Lynch, 18-yearold convicted slayer of a youth in a subway train, was sentenced yesterday to life imprisonment at hard labor.

Leonard Bernstein held three young symphonies up for inspection last night in his ninth New York Philharmonic concert surveying symphonies in this century. None was startling for newness but each had a definite personality.
TEL AVIV, Feb. 10 (AP) Israel's new southern port, Ashdod has been closed because of a labor dispute.

The Federal Reserve System apparently started to move toward a somewhat more restrictive credit policy during the week ended last Wednesday, figures issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York indicated.

City Council President Frank D. O'Connor and Councilman David Ross, the majority leader, pre-filed yesterday a joint resolution to establish a commitee to investigate the city's water shortage. The inquiry, if approved, will go into present plans for meeting the shortage and seek to determine what additional steps may be necessary.
CHICAGO, Feb. 10 Dr. A. M. Halpern of the Harvard University Center for International Affairs said today that Communist China could not afford a defeat for Communism in Vietnam.
Will A. Dillon, who wrote the lyrics for "I Want a Girl Just Like the Girl That Married Dear Old Dad," died yesterday in Ithaca, N. Y. He was 89 years old.

ALBANY, Feb. 10 Mayor Lindsay, City Council President Frank D. O'Connor and City Controller Mario A. Procaccino made common cause today in appealing for what they called "desperately needed" financial assistance for New York.
The Meadow Brook National Bank announced yesterday in West Hempstead, L. I., the election of John H. Vogel as executive vice president.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 10--C. Rodney O'Connor and Tom Vendetti won the opening match of the United States open court tennis doubles championship today by defeating Robert S. Wilford and A. G. Thomson, 6-3, 6-1, 6-5, at the Racquet Club.
The spot rate of the British pound closed ahead two points over Wednesday at $2.8035 in moderate trading on foreign exchange markets here yesterday.

TRENTON, Feb. 10 Organized labor and Hudson County Democrats showed signs tonight of backing a state income tax. Their support is the key to Governor Richard J. Hughes's efforts to have the tax pass the Legislature next month.

A drama by Truman Capote and a folk music show starring Bob Dylan have been added to the list of hour-long programs to be televised next season by the American Broadcasting Company's "ABC '66" series.
HONG KONG, Feb. 10 Communist China implied today that North Vietnam could never win its struggle against the United States unless Hanoi ended its coopera tion with the Soviet Union.
MOBILE, Ala., Feb. 10 (UPI) Tyrone Collins, subject of a bail bond controversy between Alabama and Pennsylvania, was convicted today of assault with a knife and fined $100.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 10 The Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith said today that Ronald Ramsey, radio progagandist against the United States involvement in Vietnam, had an extensive record as a right-wing radical.
CHICAGO, Feb. 10 (AP) The Consolidated Foods Corporation said today it was deferring plans to dispose of its supermarket outlets through a public offering, to allow time for further study.
JAIPUR, India, Feb. 10 (AP) Prime Minister Indira Gandhi said today that India hoped for a peaceful solution to the war in Vietnam but that she could do little to bring it about.

The election of Arthur. J. Goldberg, the chief United States representative at the United Nations, as honorary chairman of the Eleanor Roosevelt Memorial Foundation was announced yesterday. Thomas K. Finletter, former Secretary of the Air Force, was elected chairman, succeeding the late Adlai E. Stevenson.

HAVERFORD, Pa., Feb. 10 Dr. and Mrs. Lloyd W. Stevens have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss MaryEllen Stevens, to Dr. John Adrian Onderdonk Jr., son of Mrs. Frank Raynor Cole of East Orange, N.J., and the late Mr. Onderdonk of Montclair, N.J.

DARIEN, Conn., Feb. 10 Rinks representing the Ardsley (N.Y.) Curling Club, Philadelphia Curling Club of Wayne, Pa., and the host Nutmeg Curling Club won opening matches of the Nutmeg Stone bonspiel tonight. The event, which drew 20 rinks, runs through Sunday. The summaries:

ATLANTA, Ga., Feb. 10 A panel of three Federal judges voted 2 to 1 today to uphold the Georgia House of Representatives in its refusal to seat Julian Bond, an outspoken critic of the nation's policies in Vietnam.

$425-Million to $620-Million Expected to Be Raised The New Jersey Turnpike Authority's plan to widen about 35 miles of the northern part of the turnpike will involve a public offering of revenue bonds totaling between $425-million and $620-million.
KINGS POINT, L. I., Feb. 10 Alfred S. Levitt, a home developer and apartment builder, died yesterday at his home here, apparently of a heart attack. He was 54 years old.
GENEVA, Feb. 10 The Soviet Union said today that it was ready to have the 17nation disarmament conference concentrate on the search for a treaty to halt the spread of nuclear weapons.
Four state legislators from Manhattan filed seven bills in Albany yesterday that would set up programs for stopping the city's air from being used as a "garbage dump."
ST. PAUL, Feb. 10 (AP) Great Northern Railway trains continued to roll over the line's 8,261-mile system today when a Federal Court order blocked the immediate threat of switchmen's strike.
The wholesale commodity price index rose to 113.1 on Wednesday from 113 on Tuesday.
ALBANY, Feb. 10 Mayor Lindsay unwrapped his transportation consolidation plan before legislative leaders today and immediately received general expressions of support for it.

CHICAGO, Feb. 20 (UPI) Three crew members of a fastrolling freight train were killed today when the train plowed into the rear of another freight on a high embankment between two trestles on Chicago's suburban west side.

George Lincoln Rockwell, the self-styled Fuhrer of American Nazis, appeared in Criminal Court yesterday to face a sixyear-old charge of disorderly conduct. He was ordered by Judge Hyman Skolniker to return for a hearing on March 10.

The Bankers Trust Company and the Metropolitan New York Retail Merchants Association have started a program of reporting monthly sales of department stores in the New York area to replace a similar service discontinued by the Federal Reserve Bank last month.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 Russell B. Long of Louisiana, assistant majority leader of the Senate, charged in a major speech today that a group of Americn drug manufacturers had been engaging "in one of the worst conspiracies ever foisted upon the American people."

OYSTER BAY, L. I, Feb. 10 The engagement of Miss Diane Resa Rubin, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Benjamin Rubin of Oyster Bay and Westhampton Beach, to John Arthur Haas, son of Mr. and Mrs. Erwin Haas of Roslyn Heights, has been announced by the prospective bride's parents. An April wedding is planned.
MOSCOW, Feb. 10 Two Soviet writers refused today to plead guilty to criminal charges of slandering Soviet Communism in literary manuscripts smuggled to the West for publication.
Mayor Lindsay announced yesterday the appointment of Mitchell Irving Ginsberg, associate dean of the Columbia University School of Social Work, as Commissioner of Welfare.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development announced today the first "soft" loan to a less developed country made jointly by an industrial nation and one of the bank's subsidiaries.

LITCHFIELD, Conn., Feb. 10 Samuel Richard Fuller Jr., retired textile executive and in World War II chief of materials of the Office of Production Management later known as the War Production Board died here today of the infirmities of age. Mr. Fuller, who lived on South Street, was 86 years old.
Luna 9 has made a radiation measurement that at first glance, seems to indicate the surface of the moon is very low in radioactivity.
Prices on the London Stock Exchange advanced moderately yesterday on hopes that the national rail dispute would be settled before the Sunday night strike deadline.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 (AP) The six Michigan Republican House colleagues of Representative Robert P. Griffin endorsed today his candidacy for the Senate seat held by Senator Pat McNamara, a Democrat.
The confiscation of a painting by a Nazi party agency during World War II was not a lawful government act, State Supreme Court Justice Arthur G. Klein ruled yesterday.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 10 Three victories by Jeff Checkes in foil led New York University's fencing team to a 15-12 victory over Princeton tonight. The victory was the ninth in 10 matches for N.Y.U. Princeton is 5-4.
Prices on the American Stock Exchange surged ahead yesterday for the second consecutive day in hectic trading.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 An unusual hush fell over the prelunch drinkers at the Metropolitan Club here today as members and guests, including Government officials, bankers, lawyers and journalists, grouped, glasses in hand, around a television set.

MADRID, Feb. 10 The Spanish Supreme Court has sharply reduced the prison sentences of 12 Communists, including 3 underground leaders, in a decision viewed as of major legal and political significance.
The antitrust suit brought by McKesson Robbins, Inc. against Foremost Dairies, Inc. which acquired an additional 750,000 shares of McKesson stock through a tender offer is beine withdrawn.
Mayor Lindsay planned to meet this morning with leaders of the Transport Workers Union and members of the Transit Authority in an effort to avert another transit crisis for the city.

An "ever-widening arc" of investigations so described by Buildings Commissioner Charles G. Moerdler led to the indictment of five more Buildings Department employes and four landlord agents yesterday.
The United Jewish Appeal of Greater New York reported last night that it had raised $27,022,851 last year to aid Jews the world over, particularly in Israel.
A special committee of judges and legislators began examining a proposal yesterday that would take the problem of what to do about most traffic tickets out of the hands of Criminal Court.

The body of a red-haired woman found Tuesday in a vacant lot not far from the site of the World's Fair was identified yesterday as that of Sharon Lewis Kleinberg, a 22-yearold dancer and hatcheck girl who used tha stage name Sharon Lewis, according to the police.

IT happens almost every February and it's happening again. Snow conditions are deteriorating in the Hanover, N. H., hills and on the eve of the Dartmouth Winter Carnival ski officials are again on a 24-hour alert. The ski phases of the carnival start...
Emile Griffith, the welterweight champion of the world, will fight Dick Tiger for the middleweight title in Madison Square Garden on Monday night, April 25.

If any part of the vast operations of the General Telephone and Electronics Company did not turn in a record-breaking performance in 1965, it was not apparent from the final statement of operating results released yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 (UPI) The White House announced today that Vice President Humphrey would visit Thailand, Laos, Pakistan, India, Australia and New Zealand after his departure from Saigon on Sunday.
PROVIDENCE, R.I., Feb. 10 (UPI) Rick Barry sparked a fourth-period San Francisco surge tonight that gave the Warriors a 128-117 victory over the Boston Celtics.
BINGHAMPTON, N.Y., Feb. 10 (AP) Three directors, each with more than 35 years of service, have resigned from the board of the Endicott Johnson Corporation, shoe manufacturers.

These half a dozen group interviews conducted for the B.B.C. Third Programme between 1961 and 1964 by The Observer's literary critic, will both fascinate and exasperate the American reader. Patently, their aim was to find out how writers and intellectuals were reacting to current social pressures in two different parts of the world where two opposite political view's dominate.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 Intercity truck tonnage and estimated freight volume generated by carloadings in the week ended Feb. 5 were both ahead of the volume in the corresponding week of 1965.

MIAMI, Feb. 10 Choker made an excellent preparatory showing today for the big race ahead on the Hialeah stakes program. Competing in a 1 1/8mile allowance race against six rivals, the Hobeau Farm's colorbearer romped to a four-length victory over Sheet Anchor, with Mister Bruce next.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 10 (AP) Premier Fidel Castro of Cuba wrote Secretary General Thant tonight that the peoples of 18 Latin-American countries had the right to sweep away their governments by violent revolution and some day would do so.

JOLIET, Ill., Feb. 10 (AP) Robert Friede, who is being held in New York on a homicide charge in the death of a 19-year-old girl, also faces narcotics charges at Joliet, the Illinois State Narcotics Control Division disclosed yesterday.
LONDON, Feb. 10 Britain faces a national strike Monday that will shut down all the railroads and London's subways.

STANFORD, Conn., Jan. 10 Two youths, arrested in a raid on their apartment in Darien last November, were sentenced to four months in Fairfieid County Jail today for possession of marijuana for their own use.

ALBANY, Feb. 10 The names of 400 candidates who passed, the December examination for admission to the New York State bar were announced today by the State Board of Law Examiners. A total of 652 applicants took the test.

ROME, Feb. 10 Restoration work on the 13th-century Church of Saint Anastasia in Verona has brought to light several frescoes by the noted 15th-century artist Liberale di Verona, the Ansa news agency reported today.

PARIS, Feb. 10 Neutralization of all of Vietnam, formation of a transition government in South Vietnam that would hold elections and creation of a powerful international supervisory body were suggested here today as possible "elements for a settlement" in Vietnam.

SEVERAL years ago Tamas Vasary made his New York debut in the Liszt E flat Piano Concerto under George Szell. At that time this writer remarked that the pianist was 29, looked like 17, and could play the piano. Last night Mr. Vasary gave a solo concert in Carnegie Hall. He is now 32, and he still looks 17, and his playing is as smooth, as elegant, as flowing as ever.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 (AP) The United States is losing $1-million a day through delays in unloading ships in Saigon, a longshoremen's union leader told Congress today.

Mrs. Anna Dorsen Shepard, who was supervisor of city planning and housing education under the administration of Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia, died yesterday after a long illness. The widow of Benjamin Shepard, a lawyer, she was 76 years old and lived at 57 West 75th Street.

The stock market faltered yesterday after surging to new high ground on Wednesday. Losses exceeded advances by a small margin and leading market averages finished on the downside, reflecting declines in a handful of Key issues.
The B.V.D. Company, which offered on Wednesday to acquire 50,000 shares of Timely Clothes, Inc., said yesterday that it already owned about 57,000 shares of the 152,000 shares outstanding.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 Arthur J. Goldberg, the United States delegate to the United Nations, suggested today that the United States, having taken the Vietnam issue to the United Nations, would not necessarily press for action by the Security Council.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Feb. 10 (UPI) Rain and cold forced the cancellation today of the first round of the $60,000 Phoenix Open Golf tournament after an early starter, Tommy Aaron had posted a three under par 68.

The squash racquets courts at the University Club on 54th Street and Fifth Avenue will be humming with more than usual activity today. The national singles championship will begin there at 9 o'clock this morning.
VILLAG GATE, 160 Bleecker Street, Clara Ward, vocalist; Dick Gregory, comedian.

SUMMIT, N.J., Feb. 10 Mr. and Mrs. Raymond B. Weatherby have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ann Weatherby, to Carl Truman Smith, son of Dr. and Mrs. Carl B. Smith of Canandaigua, N. Y. A wedding in August is planned.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 The steep growth in the nation's money supply that began in the middle of last year appears to have eased, at least temporarily.
The International Chamber of Commerce warned yesterday that recent Curbs on the international movement of capital were likely to become permanent substitutes for sound monetary management.

Prof. and Mrs, Alfred Iacuzzi of Brooklyn have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Eleanor Frances Iacuzzi, to Duke Giorgio Mutarelli di Saragnano, son of the Duchess Ofelia Mutarelli di Saragnano of Rome and the late Duke Alfredo Mutarelli di Saragnano.
The Boy Scouts, who eagerly follow their "Be Prepared" motto, discovered yesterday that they were holding a Silver Anniversary Dawn Patrol breakfast exactly one year ahead of time.
Joseph L. Pascal, a retired Assistant Corporation Counsel or New York City, died yesterday in the Hudson View Nursing Home, Yonkers, where he had lived in recent years. He was 90 years old.
The fateful drama of the collision of two airliners last Dec. 4 over Westchester was portrayed in transcripts and testimony made public yesterday at the opening of Civil Aeronautics Board hearings.

Elisabeth Schwarzkopf has canceled her remaining performances at the Metropolitan Opera because of illness. The soprano sang there Jan. 29 as Donna Elvira in Mozart's "Don Giovanni," but complained immediately after the matinee of being unwell. She returned to her home in Switzerland that night.
MODEST launching ramps that get built help boat ing more than multi-milliondollar marinas that don't get built, one of the sport's busiest spokesmen said at a recent meeting of government officials.

GENEVA, Feb. 10 A long step along the road to church unity was taken today when the World Council of Churches announced that it was collaborating with the Vatican in the interests of aiding the victims of famine in India and in parts of Africa.
George Jessel will deliver a eulogy today at the service for Sophie Tucker, who died Wednesday at the age of 79, at 1 P.M. in the Riverside Chapel, Amsterdam Avenue and 76th Street.
A Jesuit priest who is chairman of Fordham University's philosophy department at the Lincoln Square division yesterday advocated immediate passage of a reform divorce law in New York State.
LONDON, Feb. 10 Valery Tarsis, the anti-Soviet writer whom Moscow allowed to fly to the West, laid his case before the world today. At the end his cheeks were flushed and his voiced was choked.

Members of Congress's Joint Economic Committee have proposed strengthening ties between the nation's main economic arms the fiscal powers of the Administration and the monetary powers of the Federal Reserve Board. They suggest that coordination of

Sugar and cocoa, which dropped quite sharply on Wednesday, attracted buying strength yesterday. Soybeans, which surged to new lifetime highs earlier this week and made a few more new highs yesterday, fell back sharply.

A policy conflict between John A. Schneider, newly appointed head of the Columbia Broadcasting Syste's broadcasting activities, and Fred W. Friendly, president of C.B.S. News, broke out yesterday on the issue of live television coverage of the hearings of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee.
At least five stars will appear in the revival of "The Women," to be presented from March 22 through April 3 at the Paper Mill Playhouse in Millburn, N. J.
Profits of three metal companies surged last year, reflect ing strong demand and in creased prices.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Feb. 10 The United States unveiled today a $325-million Alliance for Progress aid package to Brazil this year, the biggest to any Latin-American nation.
The bribery-conspiracy trial of former Assemblyman Hyman E. Mintz and a former chief of police of South Fallsburg, N. Y., Carl Kaplan, was recessed yesterday until Monday.
The Contemporary Music Society offered an attractively balanced program last night at the Guggenheim Museum, the third in its series of five this season.
The following reports were provided yesterday by operators of the ski areas. Messages were filed at times indicated in parentheses.
SAIGON, Friday, Feb. 11 Vice President Humphrey tramped through tropical heat and red dust today to inspect three South Vietnamese selfhelp projects. He said he found them "very encouraging."

GLENDALE, Ohio, Feb. 10 Mr. and Mrs. Lawson Ewing Whitesides have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth Lawson Whitesides, to David Garth Holdsworth. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond Holdsworth of Boston and Ringe, N. H. A May 7 wedding here is planned.

LONDON, Feb. 10 Britain is inclined to overlook the worth of the ordinary worker. The Rhodesian Government is in a better position than the British Government to assess the needs and aspirations of the African people of Rhodesia.

NEW YORK hairdressers and merchants who have had plenty to smile about in the recent boom of wigs and hairpieces may soon be tearing their locks over a Government embargo on the importation of such products from five European countries.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 A slightly modified version of the Administration's tax bill was approved today by the House Ways and Means Committee.

A NUMBER of foreign diplomats' wives found a home away home on Seventh Avenue yesterday. They took notes as avidly as store buyers at the second showing of Hannah Troy's summer collection, then partook of a Seventh Avenue lap lunch
Increased public insistence that automobile manufacturers produce a safer car has brought an announcement by General Motors that it will add two major safety devices on all of next year's models.
A large shoe manufacturer and a leading shoe retailer each announced changes yesterday in their top management.
NEWARK, Feb. 10 About 1,500 public school teachers went on strike here today, in defiance of a Superior Court injunction issued yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 The challenge to the Johnson Administration's economic policy for this year on the ground that it risks serious inflation mounted today. Of four lead ing economists who testified before the Joint Economic Committee of Congress, only one thought that it would be a mistake to clamp on the fiscal and monetary brakes now. He was Robert M. Solow of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 Mr. and Mrs. Aaron Levy have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Esther Tekla Levy, to Daniel Michael Eichenbaum, son of Dr. and Mrs. Irving W. Eichenbaum of New Britain, Conn. A July 3 wedding is planned.
A new scientific quarterly, only one-eighth of an inch thick but containing 869 pages, was shown here yesterday by Dr. Howard R. Craig, director of the New York Academy of Medicine.

Two Americans once deeply involved in top-level planning on the diplomatic and military fronts have now given the nation strikingly parallel analyses of the dangers of escalating the war in Vietnam in quest of "victory."
A thumbprint was found in a homemade smoke bomb that was ignited moments before Malcolm X was murdered, a detective disclosed yesterday in State Supreme Court.

A PLAYER who finds himself in an unduly elevated contract because his partner has overbid can comfort himself with the reflection that his skill in dummy-play has received a delicate compliment. Some players in such circumstances devote the playing period to preparing a short speech to be delivered to partner during the postmortem, but a better policy is to try to justify his confidence.
BOGOTA, Colombia, Feb. 10 The Colombian Government has acknowledged participation in a United States social research program here that has been the target of strong criticism for the last week.
RALEIGH, N. C., Feb. 10 (UPI) Second-ranked Duke, with Mike Lewis scoring 20 points, outfought North Carolina State, 78-74, tonight to break back into the victory column.
SAIGON, Feb. 10 Vice President Humphrey arrived in Saigon today and began preparing for three days of visits to ruralpacification projects and American troop installations.

Marian Anderson, Langston Hughes, Duke Ellington and his orchestra and the dePaur Chorus will lead the United States representation to the First World Festival of Negro Arts in Dakar, Senegal, in April.
FORT PAYNE, Ala., Feb. 10 Ryan deGraffenried, a leading candidate for the Democratic nomination for Governor of Alabama, was killed in an airplane crash near here last night.
LONDON, Feb. 10 (AP) An unsigned pamphlet purporting to come from a group of youthful Soviet intellectuals calls on the West for help for Russian Culture.
Bill Starr, a standout tight end at Hofstra University, was signed as a free agent by the New York Jets yesterday.

Lykes Bros. Steamship Company was studying yesterday the terms of an offer by the Marine Engineers Beneficial Association to man and sail two new automated cargo ships that have been held up by a dispute over the size of the ship's engineer officer complement.

New York City's case for more state aid was carried to Albany again yesterday. The need was never more desperate, and seldom if ever before was the appeal argued more earnestly or with less partisanship. The Republican Mayor who had been down to Washington the day before seeking Federal aid was joined in the plea to the Legislature by his Democratic colleagues, the President of the City Council and the Controller.

SAIGON, Feb. 10 A United States plane, the eighth to be lost over North Vietnam since bombing was resumed there 11 days ago, was hit yesterday by two surface-to air missiles, a United States military spokesman said today.
IN the menus below, dishes marked with an asterisk are followed by a recipe.
David J. Miller, a 23-yearold pacifist, was found guilty yesterday in Federal Court of having burned his draft card last October at a protest rally against the Vietnam war and military conscription.
A Brooklyn mother, whose 8year-old daughter had been suspended from school, was arrested yesterday on charges of assaulting the school's principal and his secretary.

SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, Feb. 10--A police sergeant was shot, a youth was killed and 10 civilians were wounded by a grenade today as bands of roving demonstrators continued to clash with police.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 (AP) Photographs and radioed data on temperatures and melting rates were obtained last night as a rocket-propelled vehicle plunged back into the earth's atmosphere at 18,000 miles an hour, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration reported today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 An undercover agent for the Columbus, Ohio, Police Department testified today that he had discovered plots of violence by Klansmen, including a written threat to kill President Johnson.

The captains of commerce and their guests finished their luncheon platters yesterday as white-jacketed waiters brushed crumbs from the long table. Then they turned to the vexing question that concerned them: Is God dead?

WINSTON-SALEM, N. C., Feb. 10 The North Carolina School of the Arts, the South's first state-supported institution for professional training in music, drama and dance, will receive a grant of $1.5-million from the Ford Foundation.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 There is a kind of Gresham's Law of journalism in which the bad news drives out the good, the negative overwhelms the positive, and the warmakers drown out the peacemakers.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 (AP) Senator Abraham A. Ribicoff, chairman of a Senate subcommittee on traffic safety, hailed today the announcement made yesterday that many 1967 model cars will have collapsible steering columns and dual braking systems.
ATLANTA, Feb. 10 A group of civil rights workers has joined in the formation of a South-wide organization to protest the nation's involvement in Vietnam, a spokesman said today.
SAIGON, Feb. 10 Several aspects of the Honolulu conference this week seem to have received little notice.

LONDON, Feb. 10 John Cranko's new ballet, "Brandenburg Nos. 2 4," given its first performance at Covent Garden tonight, is a bravura display piece that takes 16 of the Royal Ballet's finest young dancers and sets them dancing as hard as they can for 30 minutes.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 President Johnson submitted to Congress today his controversial plan to transfer the Community Relations Service, a racial conciliation agency, to the Department of Justice.
CHICAGO, Feb. 10 City Hall announced today a "massive crackdown" by city and county authorities on slum landlords. The goal is to rid Chicago of slums and blighted areas by 1967.
Norman E. Miller, controller since 1956 of Atlas Chemical Industries, Inc., was elected yesterday to the additional post of vice president.
LONDON, Feb. 10 It will cost Britain's taxpayers 4.3million ($12-million) to help Zambia meet the emergencies arising from Rhodesia's seizure of independence, the Treasury disclosed today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 George F. Kennan told the Senate Foreign Relations Committee today that the Administration should decide what could be securely held in South Vietnam and then "dig in and wait" for a political solution to emerge.

WASHINGTON CROSSING, N. J., Feb. 10 Mr. and Mrs. John E. Postley of Washington Crossing and New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Patricia Postley to Donald K. Steinman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Steinman of Garden City, L. I. They plan a July wedding.
The Bronx District Attorney's office disclosed yesterday that it was investigating the financial records of an antipoverty unit set up in that borough last summer.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 The past and present commanders of the Army Special Forces emphatically denied today assertions by a veteran of the elite unit that its members were taught torture methods.

An interfaith mission to the Soviet Union, composed of leaders of the Protestant, Roman Catholic and Jewish faiths, said yesterday that an "atmosphere of fear and insecurity" prevailed among Soviet Jews.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Feb. 10 Three protesting North Korean officials were marched aboard a Europe-bound plane today, and with their departure the "trade mission" of North Korea in Uruguay ceased to exist.

The Ford Motor Company emphasized yesterday that it intended to keep up with advances by its competitors, including the General Motors Corporation, in safety equipment planned for 1967 automobiles. Lee A. Iacocca, vice president of Ford's car and truck group, told a news con ference here that the company "surely will meet any General Services Administration safety requirements."

PARIS, Feb. 10 The Defense Ministers of Britain, West Germany, Italy and Turkey will meet with Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara next Thursday and Friday in a new attempt to solve the divisive issue of sharing nuclear decision-making in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, it was announced here today.

CLAVIERE Italy, Feb. 10 (AP) The Soviet Union and Bulgaria won gold medals in relay ski events at the World University Winter Games today, while Japanese girls made a surprisingly strong showing in figure skating.

HONG KONG, Feb. 10 North Vietnam derided the Honolulu conference today as a "tedious farce" and denounced with particular venom the United States-South Vietnamese agreement on a program for intensifying rural construction efforts in South Vietnam.
Government bond prices continued their decline yesterday, depressed partly by an influential banker's prediction of higher interest rates and partly by talk of a Federal Reserve discount rate rise.
BOWIE, Md. Feb. 10 (UPI) Irish Frost, a Maryland-bred filly owned by H.O.H. Frelinghuysen, pulled away in the stretch at Bowie today to score a three-length victory in the $6,600 Tokoina Park Purse.

LONDON, Feb. 10 The prestigious Royal Shakespeare Company will stage parts of Christopher Marlowe's "Edward II" as a 12-minute sequence in a film adaption of John Lee Carres spy novel "Call for the Dead."
ARCADIA, Calif., Feb. 10 (UPI) Bird of Normandy's victory in the second race today for a $106.20 payoff completed a $1,701 daily double at Santa Anita, the second largest in the track's history.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 President Johnson made a strong defense of individual freedom today as he awarded the National Medal of Science to 11 distinguished scientists.

A new track meet comes to Madison Square Garden tonight for the first time in 32 years. It will provide the only New York appearance of the winter for some of America's (and the world's) brightest young talent.
BRUSSELS, Feb. 10 Belgium was plunged into a new political crisis today when the Socialists pulled out of the coalition Government.

Wives of Staten Island ferry crewmen began a sit-in yesterday outside the office of Deputy Mayor Timothy W. Costello. More than a dozen of the group picketed the South Ferry Terminal in Manhattan and for an hour prevented cars from getting on boats bound for Staten Island.
WESTBURY, L.I., Feb. 10 Even the losers applauded Del Insko after the fourth race at Roosevelt Raceway tonight.
DETROIT, Feb. 10 (AP) All editions of the Detroit News were published on schedule today.
MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 10 (AP) Melvin Lane Powers was quoted by a witness today as saying that Jacques Mossler was keeping Mrs. Mossler "nervous and upset, and I ought to kill him."

ROBESONIA, Pa., Feb. 10 Mrs. Frederic B. Thomson of Big Spring Farm has announced the engagement of her daugh ter, Miss Christal Ann Craig, to James Michael Noble, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jack D. Noble of Lafayette, Calif.
DETROIT, Feb. 10 (AP) The Detroit Lions of the National Football League named Sammy Baugh and Lou Rymkus to their coaching staff today.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 10 Clement Bratone, president of Contractors Supply Company, 3055 Vernon Avenue, Long Island City, Queens, New York, died here today while preparing to play a round of golf. He was 58 years old and lived at 147 Nyac Avenue, Pelham, N. Y.

State Senator Murray Schwartz, a Queens Democrat, said yesterday that he had proposed to American Airlines that it extend its youth fare plan to include elderly persons, and that the line had promised to consider the proposal.
MIAMI, Feb. 10 (AP) The heavyweight champion, Cassius Clay, said tonight that his draft board had told him that he might be acceptable for military service.
The Board of Estimate rebuffed Robert Moses yesterday on an issue that could foreshadow new delays for the proposed $110-million Lower Manhattan Expressway.

Mayor Lindsay declared yesterday that former Police Commissioners Francis W.H. Adams and Michael J. Murphy were "trying to scare the community at large" by accusing him of attempting to gain control of the Police Department.

For some years the New York Cotton Exchange has been about the most inactive trading center here, and with good reason. The Government's cotton program made it more profitable for farmers to place their cotton in Government loans, and hence the Commodity Credit Corporation has long been the major cotton merchandiser.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Feb. 11--Herbert Brayton Clark, the 1936 president of the Northern Baptist Convention, now the American Baptist Convention, and a retired banker, industrialist and philanthropist, died last night at his home here. He was 84 years old.
SAIGON, Feb. 11--Secretary of Agriculture Orville L. Freeman suggested today that the best way to the South Vietnamese farmer's heart is through his crops.

General Aguiyi-Ironsi's military government in Nigeria obviously has galvanized widespread popular support since taking control of the January revolution. It has declared war on corruption, cracked down hard on the tribalism and narrow regionalism that plagued the republic and abolished dozens of unnecessary jobs, bureaus and ministries at both federal and regional levels.
LONDON, Feb. 11 (AP)-- Mary Agnes (Molly) Hamilton, treasured friend of dozens of American war correspondents, died here yesterday. She was 80 years old.

FOR women who dress at the Paris couture, the ultimate in fashion coordination is to punctuate a Givenchy or Balenciaga costume with a Givenchy or Balenciaga scarf. Now the woman who wears American ready-to-wear will be able to play the same game.

BALTIMORE, Saturday, Feb. 12 (AP)--Labor and management bargaining units of the Westinghouse Corporation and members of a salaried employes' union reached an agreement early today and canceled a strike that had been set for Monday.
SAIGON, Saturday, Feb. 12 (UPI)--A teen-aged Vietcong terrorist was killed today by mishandling a bomb intended for the Saigon director of CARE, the international charity agency.

MIAMI, Feb. 11 (UPI)--The Panamanian tanker Padre Island ran aground in the Bahamas today and radioed that 24 of the 32 men aboard had safely reached another ship, the big American passenger liner Brasil, the Coast Guard said.

Nearly 1,000 friends and admirers of Sophie Tucker crowded the Riverside Chapel, Amsterdam Avenue and 76th Street, yesterday for a memorial service to the veteran entertainer who died of lung cancer Wednesday night at the age of 79.
Heavy fog rolling in from the Atlantic tied up air traffic last night and early today in many major airports from New York to Washington.
TRENTON, Feb. 11--Episcopalians who took part in an allegedly racist and anti-Semitic songfest by Young Republican face possible excommunication, a church organization warned today.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Feb. 11--Recent developments in Albania, concerning both the domestic and foreign policies of that isolated Communist country, have aroused puzzled interest here.
DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., Feb. 11--The London Symphony Orchestra will give 17 concerts here between July 28 and Aug. 21 as part of the first Florida International Music Festival.

The two-day strike by the Newark Teachers Association, in defiance of New Jersey's Constitution and a court order, was another cynical demonstration of the contempt for orderly process induced by evidence that irresponsibility pays dividends in civil service labor disputes.

SPRING VALLEY, N.Y., Feb. 11--Student leaders at Rockland Community College voted early today to rescind an invitation to George Lincoln Rockwell, the American Nazi party leader, to speak at the college Feb. 25.

There will be another pro football team in New York next season. This one, without a name as yet, will belong to the Continental Football League and it will play its home games at Downing Stadium on Randalls Island on Thursday nights.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 11-- Prime Minister Indira Gandhi has appealed to President Johnson for an immediate resumption of American economic aid to India, Administration sources disclosed tonight.
CHICAGO, Feb. 11 (AP)--A total of 49,000 traffic deaths in the United States last year, a record, was reported today by the National Safety Council. The previous record was 47,700 in 1964.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11-- President Johnson said today that there were no plans at this time to call up reserves to support the American troop build-up in Vietnam, but he indicated that he was not ruling out such a possibility in the future.

GRENOBLE, France, Feb. 11 (UPI)--Marielle Goitschel and Guy Perillat won their second slalom titles today in the French skiing championships over the new Chambrousse course, which will be used for the 1968 Olympics.
Arlene Honey King, one of over a hundred welfare workers who refused, through fear, to visit clients' homes in Harlem this week, voted yesterday to return to work.
A trailer started canvassing remote neighborhoods in the Bronx yesterday, offering job training and, possibly, even jobs to school dropouts.

LONDON, Feb. 11--British trust busters are investigating rival American and British bids for the Amalgamated Dental Company that ranks as the biggest supplier of dental equipment outside the United States.
Lykes Bros. Steamship Company yesterday rejected an offer by the Marine Engineers Beneficial Association to man the strikebound new automated freighter Elizabeth Lykes on Vietnam operations alone.

Mayor Lindsay and Police Commissioner Vincent L. Broderick discussed the creation of an independent board to review police behavior yesterday, but failed to budge each other from their conflicting stands.

NEWARK, Feb. 11--Mayor Hugh J. Addonizio and negotiators for the Newark Teachers Association agreed tonight, after a two-day strike, to submit the contract dispute to an impartial factfinder and to accept his recommendations.
VIENTIANE, Laos, Feb. 11-- A top Defense Ministry official, Col. Thongpunh Knoksy, expressed concern today over enemy movements in the northernmost and southernmost portions of Laos.

Weeb Ewbank, the coach of two champion National Football League teams who became a loser when he switched leagues, signed a new three-year contract yesterday as coach and general manager of the American Football League's New York Jets.

Louis Weinstein, a senior vice president of the Bank of North America, died yesterday apparently of a heart attack near the main office of the bank at 116 Fifth Avenue. He was 76 years old and lived at 930 Fifth Avenue.

IT is taken for granted that tournament success can only come after a long apprenticeship in duplicate play, but all such generalizations have exceptions. A week ago Don Reid, of Kirkwood, Mo., playing in his first tournament of any kind, headed a field including many ranking experts to win a major regional championhip.

The Lindsay administration was reported last night to be considering an offer of support for the Port of New York Authority's proposed World Trade Center in exchange for construction by the authority of a luxury terminal for ocean liners.

ROCHESTER, Feb. 11 (AP) Dr. Walter R. Bloor, a former president of the American Society of Biological Chemists, died today at his home in Colorado Springs, where he had moved about a year ago. He was 89 years old.
THE transformation of a tough-minded pictorial idea into an engaging but esthetically less compelling fantasy is always difficult to judge. Inevitably, one feels a drop in the esthetic temperature.

Mrs. Jeannette Kittredge Watson, widow of Thomas J. Watson Sr., former head of the International Business Machines Corporation, died Thursday night in her home, 920 Fifth Avenue. She was 82 years old.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11-- The National Institute of Mental Health released today preliminary findings on a new drug that shows promise for narcotics addicts who have withdrawn from heroin and want to stay away from it.
BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 11 (AP)--A Spanish immigrant locked in a bleak asylum for insane criminals for 31 years went free today because a new prison director could not find his file.

Representatives of thirtytwo civic, religious, civil rights hand antipoverty groups expressed yesterday "urgent concern with the ill-feeling, impatience with red tape and general unrest of the man in the street."

The marriage of Miss Christine Young Jones of 424 East 57th Street, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert T. Jones of Elmira, N.Y., to Arthur Rosenstein of 41 Park Avenue, son of Mrs. Sol Berman of New York and the late Ben Rosenstein, took place here yesterday.
Democratic leaders announced yesterday that potential candidates for Governor would be given an opportunity to explain their views at a public forum in Brooklyn on April 26.
Billy Rose left most of his estate to a cultural foundation bearing his own name, according to his will filed for probate yesterday.

The United States Plywood Corporation, the world's largest plywood distributor, announced yesterday it had agreed to acquire the assets of the West Coast Plywood Corporation for 109,000 shares of U.S. Plywood common stock. The deal involves about $5.6-million.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 11--Organized labor, still grumbling over its failure to achieve its main legislative goal this year, began today to turn its attention to its other favorite bills.

CHICAGO, Feb. 11 (UPI)-- A United Automobile Workers local invoked arbitration today in the "neglect of job" suspension of its president for leaving his factory post and rushing the severed arm of a fellow worker to a hospital.
ATLANTA, Feb. 11 (UPI)-- Roger M. Blough, chairman of the United States Steel Corporation, said today he foresaw "no necessity" for steel priority controls because of the war in Vietnam.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 11-- President Johnson approved today the renewal of most United States airline routes to Europe without major change.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Feb. 11 (AP)--Dick Murray scored six straight points that halted a St. Peter's spurt and lifted Army to a 64-58 basketball victory today.
Young filmmakers in this country, who like to win prizes but need money more than they need gold-plated statuettes, can take heart at the news from Montreal.

Andy Stynchula, the defensive lineman who came to the New York Giants two seasons ago in a trade for Sam Huff, has parted ways with the club following a salary disagreement. The 26-year-old Penn State alumnus played without a new contract last season and the Giants' option to his services will cease on May 1.
SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Feb. 11--Rhodesia today blocked Africans of neighboring countries from coming to Rhodesian towns to look for jobs.
HANOVER, N.H., Feb. 11-- There were strange goings-on as the 56th annual Dartmouth Winter Carnival started today.
A series of advanced courses for gifted high school students, organized and taught by Columbia and Barnard undergraduates, will begin this morning on the Columbia campus.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 11-- The Export-Import Bank is exploring with private banks the possible sale of up to $700-million worth of participations in the bank's loans next week.
ROCHESTER, N.Y., Feb. 11 (UPI)--Senator Robert F. Kennedy charged today that the draft law discriminated against young people in lower economic groups.

Dr. Frank Stanton, president of the Columbia Broadcasting System, and Fred W. Friendly, president of C.B.S. News, conferred yesterday on the executive realignment of the company. No comment on the meeting was available and it was indicated there would be no further developments over the weekend.

ANY production of Corneille's "Le Cid" by the Comedie Francaise must take on the character of a ceremonial observance, and it received an opulent one last night in a new production at the New York City Center.
A psychiatric examination was ordered yesterday for a data-processing programer who is accused of challenging another man to a duel over a woman.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11(AP) --A second nationwide warning against the use of two types of imported disposable hypodermic needles from Japan was issued today by Dr. James L. Goddard of the Public Health Service.
Three United States scientists received cablegrams from Moscow yesterday informing them that they had been elected members of the Soviet Academy of Sciences.

BETHESDA, Md., Feb. 11-- Mr. and Mrs. Arthur C. Stern have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth Ann Stern, to Mark Ely Greenwold, son of Mr. and Mrs. Cecil I. Greenwold of Beverly Hills, Calif.
Mayor Lindsay and Transit Authority officials appeared yesterday to be looking toward a legislative solution of the latest transit wage complication.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 11 (AP)--About 100 students and a few faculty members of three suburban Quaker-founded colleges are ending an eight-day fast in protest against the Vietnam conflict, but at least a dozen participants say they will go on for another week.

JAIPUR, India, Feb. 11-- The annual conference of Indias Ruling Congress party staged an open revolt today against the Government's food policy in one of the wildest episodes ever seen at a party meeting.
FORT WORTH, Feb. 11 (AP) --Two Olympians, John Thomas and Jim Grelle, broke Texas records at the Will Rogers Indoor Games tonight, but a California school teacher stole the show.

"1933: Characters in Crisis," by Herbert Feis, will be published by Little, Brown on March 22. Dr. Feis was a member of Herbert Hoover's economic advisory staff specializing in foreign relations. WINSTON-SALEM, N.C., Feb. 11--Although the North Carolina School of the Arts is only in its first year, it represents an important cultural step forward by the South.

DARIEN, Conn., Feb. 11-- The New York Caledonian Curling Club rink, skipped by Ernest Slaybaugh, and the Hamilton (Ont.) Thistle C.C., skipped by Dean Taylor, led the way into the semi-final round today of the annual Nutmeg Stone bonspiel at the Nutmeg Curling Club.

SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, Feb. 11--President Hector Garcia-Godoy swore in Brig. Gen. Enrique Perez y Perez as Minister of the Armed Forces today and the general's predecessor, Commodore Francisco Javier Rivera Caminero, left to take up his duties as a naval attache in Washington.
BONN, Feb. 11--A highranking official of the Brazilian Government has arrived in this country seeking a "friendly settlement" of $15million from Mannesmann (A.G.), the West German industrial giant.

The Sons of the Revolution in the State of New York will again observe George Washington's birthday, at a banquet in the Grand Ballroom of the Plaza on Feb. 22.
ROME, Feb. 11--Premierdesignate Aldo Moro agreed tonight to make a new attempt to end Italy's political crisis and form a new center-left coalition Government.

MEXICO CITY, Feb. 11 (UPI)--Vincente Saldivar will defend his world featherweight championship against Floyd Robertson of Ghana tomorrow night in the first world title bout staged here in 10 years.

TULIA, Tex., Feb. 11 (UPI) --S.F. Flores, a rancher in West Texas, who went from breaking horses for $30 a month to donating more than $2-million to Wayland Baptist College, died yesterday. He was 98 years old.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11--A Government scientist reports he has identified the organism he believes causes one of the most annoying and least studied minor ailments of man--canker sores.

The Norton Company, the world's largest manufacturer of abrasive products, reported yesterday record net earnings for 1965 of $18,406,000, or $3.30 a share. This compares with $18,213,000, or $3.25 a share, the year before.

Mrs. Ozella Davis, 30-yearold Brooklyn mother appeared in court yesterday on charges of assaulting a school principal and his secretary, and filed an assault charge against the principal.

Jerome Lowenthal will play Rachmaninoff's Piano Concerto No. 3 with the New York Philharmonic at 8:30 P.M. Wednesday in Philharmonic Hall and on Monday, Feb. 21, in Constitution Hall, Washington, at 3:30. Aaron Copland's Third Symphony and Mendelssohn's "Fingal's Cave" Overture will also be heard on both programs. Leonard Bernstein will conduct.

The annual dinner of the Catholic Youth Organization of New York will be held on Tuesday in the Imperial Ballroom of the Americana. The award honors a citizen who has provided inspiration and leadership for youth.
MIAMI, Feb. 11 (AP)--A "frightening" but not serious illness sidelined Mrs. Candace Mossler today. Circuit Judge George Schulz recessed her murder trial until Monday.
