University Microfilms, Inc., an educational subsidiary of the Xerox Corporation, is extending its operations in book publishing by arranging with a new organization, the Legacy Library, to reprint children's classics.
HAVANA, Feb. 11 (AP)-- There has been another delay in the scheduled repatriation of nearly 600 Americans and their Cuban relatives to the United States.
SEATTLE, Feb. 11 (AP)-- Robert J. Schoettler, fisheries adviser to the United States agricultural mission in Saigon since 1958, died Wednesday of cancer. He was 63 years old.
ACAPULCO, Mexico, Feb. 11 (UPI)--Sumner A. Long's Ondine was declared the over-all handicap winner of the San Diego-to-Acapulco yacht race yesterday.
The second of 12 railroad coal cars that were lost overboard from a Pennsylvania Railroad carfloat in the East River on Tuesday was raised yesterday.

One of the most active and strongest rail issues in the last week has been Atchison, Topeka Santa Fe. Both its preferred and common stock have traded in unusually large blocks. Yesterday the railroad's common stock rose 3 , to 40 , a new record high; the preferred jumped , to 11.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 (AP)--Mail reaching Senator J.W. Fulbright, chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, is reported running about 30-to-1 against escalation of the war in Vietnam.

WEST HARTFORD, Conn., Feb. 11--Dick Gregory stood on the stage of the William H. Hall High School here today, surveyed an attentive assembly of about 2,000 suburban youngsters and said: "If this audience got any whiter, I'd have to put on sunglasses to look at it."
GURA VAII, Rumania-- After three decades of talk about harnessing the Danube for electric power production, the nations of Southeast Europe are at last beginning to do something about it.
The bond market dropped sharply yesterday, suffering its most severe decline since Dec. 6, when it fell because the Federal Reserve discount rate had been raised.

LISBON, Feb. 11--Portuguese and Zambian authorities are discussing the establishment of an oil airlift from Beira, Mozambique, to Lusaka, Zambia, Foreign Minister Alberto Franco Nogueira confirmed today.
Four American scientists have suggested the ultimate extension of the Indian rope trick.
The wholesale commodity price index rose to 113.4 on Thursday from 113.1 on Wednesday.

Marston E. Drake, president from 1933 until its closing last year of James F. Drake, Inc., dealers in rare books, died Tuesday at the Tri-County Hospital in Kittery, Me. He was 74 years old and had lived here, in Bayside, Queens, and in Plandome, L.I., where he had been a mayor.
The American Stock Exchange managed to finish stronger yesterday on heavy volume despite some late profit taking.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Feb. 11--Lowndes County, Ala., scene of the slaying of two civil rights workers last year, was ordered by a Federal court today to carry out one of the most comprehensive programs of desegregation yet devised for a Deep South school system.

WESTBURY, L.I., Feb. 11-- The infield was a soggy marsh, the parking lots were slippery and melting snow and ice continued going down the drain at Roosevelt Raceway tonight like a horseplayer's bankroll.

JERUSALEM, (Israeli Sector), Feb. 11--Israel's pride, the new port of Ashdod, has closed down in a labor dispute two and a half months after its opening. Only the shouts of dockers playing soccer on the quays break the silence.

More than 30 years ago the late Bishop William T. Manning of the Episcopal Diocese of New York ventured into Harlem, broke the locks on a church that had refused to open its doors to Negroes and then conducted the regular Sunday service.

Columbia University, with Dave Newmark clogging the alley on defense and Stan Felsinger guiding the offense from his guard post, routed Dartmouth College, 85-60, last night in an Ivy League basketball game in University Gymnasium.
MONTCLAIR, N.J., Feb. 11 --Miss Phyllis Louise Michele and James McHenry Nielsen, students at New York Medical College, are planning to be married in June.

A recent note in this newspaper described a new version of "Hamlet," prepared by Rouben Mamoulian. In it the stage and screen director has substituted modern equivalents for some 2,000 Elizabethan words, rewritten lines, eliminated others altogether, provided fresh punctuation and otherwise satisfied his Thespian instincts. There is no malice in this.

Pilar Lorengar, a Spanish soprano who was to make her Metropolitan Opera debut in "Don Giovanni" next Monday, appeared in the opera for the first time instead last night. She came in for Elisabeth Schwarzkopf, who returned to Europe this week after becoming ill and canceling her season's engagements at the Met.

The Civil War centennials are over: No battlefields, no banners. Only the Lincoln symbol remains. His proclamation against slavery meant more around the world than the primary aim of holding the Union together. For emancipation was a message that won hearts and minds--and still does wherever personal freedom is wanting.

A State Supreme Court jury found two manufacturers responsible yesterday for a fire in a garment factory here eight years ago that took 24 lives. But the jury did not know that the companies were defunct and that the 41 survivors and heirs of the victims would therefore probably not be able to collect any damages.

HAUPPAUGE, L.I., Feb. 11 --The police told today how a band of car thieves solicited orders for late-model Cadillacs and then stole cars from garages and side streets, matching them in color and body style with their customers' specifications.

ATLANTA, Feb. 11 (AP)-- Thousands are expected to attend a student rally here tomorrow in support of the United States' commitment in Vietnam while civil rights groups and peace groups plan antiwar demonstrations elsewhere in the country.

The current Moscow trial of Soviet writers Andrei Sinyavsky and Yuli Daniel is really a trial of Soviet justice. Both its conduct and its outcome will provide a measure of how far the much-asserted "new Soviet legality" has progressed beyond Stalinist lynch law.

Montserrat Caball 's illness caused her Philharmonic Hall concert with the Festival Orchestra of New York to be postponed from last night to April 17, but Thomas Dunn, the orchestra's music director, decided not to let the reservation of the hall to go to waste. He brought several of his first-desk men together to play chamber music.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 (UPI) --Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara authorized a stepped up drive today to recruit male and female nurses for the expanding armed forces.

Bruno C. Vitt, a leader in fire insurance who had been president and chairman of The American Insurance Company, now part of the Fireman's Fund American Insurance Companies group, died Wednesday in Pinehurst, N.C., where he resided. He was 71 years old.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Feb. 11--Gasoline from South Africa has been delivered to the Rhodesian Army and police, qualified sources in Johannesburg said today.

AN elegant yet simple dinner for two can be prepared with a minimum expenditure of time and effort, which could be the impetus behind a decision to dine at home next Monday, whether the Valentine to be feted is a spouse or a current beau.

The Western Union Telegraph Company reported gross revenues yesterday of $305,614,734 for 1965. This compared with $299,410,249 a year earlier. Net income increased to $17,833,353, equal to $2.30 a share, from $17,161,406, or $2.29 a share, in 1964.

The New York Stock Exchange released an insider report late yesterday disclosing the sale by six officers of the Anken Chemical and Film Corporation of a total of 27,074 class A shares. There were 1,068,132 shares outstanding as of Sept. 30.

TOKYO, Feb. 11--Japanese rightists paraded in Tokyo today as small groups throughout the country renewed their demand for national observance of the day on which Japan's legendary first Emperor was said to have ascended the throne 2,626 years ago.

The Grand Ballroom of the Americana will be transformed into a great banqueting hall, typical of England, for the March 19 dinner at which Prince Philip, Duke of Edinburgh, will be the guest of the Variety Club International. A program of entertainment by Broadway stars is being arranged by Jule Styne, the song writer.

GREENWICH, Conn., Feb. 11 --Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Robert Ryan McBride of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Virginia Ann McBride, to James Rorke McCarthy, son of Mrs. Charles J. McCarthy of Sayville, L.I., and the late Mr. McCarthy.

THE Musem of Graphic Art, a museum with no building and only the tiniest germ of a collection, is holding a large exhibition in pleasant quarters, in the form of 322 loans hung in the galleries of the Finch College Museum of Art, 62-64 East 78th Street.
PHOENIX, Ariz., Feb. 11 (UPI)--Gardner Dickinson shot a five-under-par 66 today to take the lead in the first round of the $60,000 Phoenix open golf tournament.
PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 11 --Joe Heiser, a sophomore, scored 21 points to lead Princeton to a 79-67 victory over Brown tonight.
BOSTON, Feb. 11 (AP)-- Walt Bellamy turned in a strong effort at both ends of the court to power the New York Knicks to a 122-107 victory over the Detroit Pistons tonight.
Steve Vehslage led the favorites through two rounds of the United States squash racquets singles championship yesterday as he began the defense of his title.

Artur Balsam, well known in New York as an accompanist and chamber music performer, made one of his rare solo appearances last night at Town Hall. He played the Mozart Piano Concerto in F (K. 459) with the Municipal Concerts Orchestra, conducted by Julius Grossman.

BRUSSELS, Feb. 11--Pierre Harmel, the outgoing Premier, implied today that he opposed the calling of new parliamentary elections. Meanwhile, King Baudouin began intensive efforts to find a new government.
John Purroy Mitchel lost his fireboat but regained his head this week.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 11 (UPI)--Willie Mays became the highest-paid player in baseball history today when he signed a two-year contract with the San Francisco Giants for a salary estimated at $130,000 a year.

MIDDLEBURY, Vt., Feb. 11 --Two sophomores, Blaine Doherty and Pete Kirkpatrick, made two goals and one assist each to lead the Middlebury College hockey team to a 7-2 victory over Hamilton College tonight.
WASHINGTON, Feb.11 (AP) --Mrs. Lyndon B. Johnson said today that she and the President were "looking forward very much" to meeting the parents of their daughter Luci's fiance for the first time.
Changes in the senior management of the Union Electric Company of St. Louis were announced yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 11-- Russell Conwell Ball Sr., chairman of the board of the Philadelphia Gear Corporation at King of Prussia, died Wednesday in the Lankenau Hospital. He was 77 years old and lived in Wynnewood.
Raymond International, Inc., has elected Charles F. Woods a vice president in charge of the company's Chapman Derrick Division.

WEST NEWTON, Mass. Feb. 11--Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Edward C. Gratto of West Newton and New Seabury of the engagement of their daughter. Miss Maureen Ellen Gratto, to Franklin Bell Velie. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Lester Velie of Great Neck, L.I.
LONDON, Feb. 11--A suggestion was made here today that a principal accuser at the Moscow trial of two Soviet writers once plagiarized a passage from a Sinyavsky work that he now condemns.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 (AP)--The Armed Forces Institute of Pathology said today that it had the missing part of Benito Mussolini's brain.
The problem of a shortage of freight cars for corn and a large increase in cotton futures trading spiced yesterday's trading in commodities.
ATLANTA, Feb. 11(AP)--Inmates at the United States penitentiary in Atlanta are volunteering for service in Vietnam, even though a law providing for such duty expired at the end of World War II.

HOUSTON, Feb. 11-- City park workers have discovered that 10 big pine trees have been killed by a poisoner. The city's forester, R.C. Barnes, said that the trees-- some 80 years old--had holes bored into them by a brace and bit and the holes had been filled with poison.

GENEVA, Feb. 11--The Rev. Dr. Eugene Carson Blake, Stated Clerk of the General Assembly of the United Presbyterian Church in the U.S.A., was elected Secretary General of the World Council of Churches today. The electors were the group of 100 churchmen who comprise the Central Committee of the World Council.
LONDON, Saturday, Feb. 12--Prime Minister Wilson announced about 1 A.M. today that the threatened national railroad strike, set to begin at midnight tomorrow, had been called off.

More than a century after Lincoln's death, the Negro's share in American life is a mingled portion of rich accomplishment and tragic inequality, of faith redeemed and hope snuffed out, of brilliant opportunity and dark fear.

PANAMA, Feb. 11--Eleven days of hard work here by 26 members of the International Air Transport Association's Traffic Conference No. 1 resulted today in agreement on international airline fares in much of the Western Hemisphere.

SAIGON, Feb. 11--Vice President Humphrey barnstormed around Saigon today, inspecting civic-action projects, shaking hundreds of South Vietnamese hands and hog calling at an agricultural experiment station.
Joshua Egelson, a retired lawyer, died Thursday in the Veterans Administration Hospital, Manhattan. He was 77 years old and lived at 225 East 70th Street.
Railroad issues advanced sharply in the stock market yesterday, but other major groups presented a generally scrambled pattern in moderately active dealings.
Prices on the London Stock Exchange held generally firm yesterday in spite of the threat of a national rail strike next week.

The United States Track and Field Federation held its first invitation indoor track meet last night at Madison Square Garden, and strange things happened. The strangest was Gerry Lindgren's defeat by Tom Laris in the two-mile.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 (AP)--Meki Toalepai, a smiling Polynesian from Samoa, and his Caucasian bride-to-be obtained a marriage license here today after being denied one in Maryland.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 11 (AP)--Staughton Lynd, assistant professor of history at Yale, has been granted a year's leave of absence to do research for a book.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 11-- A 19-year-old Klansman told a Congressional committee today how he had helped to carry a load of dynamite from Georgia to Ohio to start a civil war.

Four major lumber associations reported an increase of 9.7 per cent in production for the week ended Feb. 5, compared with the level in the corresponding 1965 week. Output rose 2.3 per cent from the preceding week.

PARIS, Feb. 11--Edith Piaf, the most popular music-hall singer of the postwar generation, died in October, 1963, but she is still very much alive in France for the public that worshiped her. Her hoarse voice can be heard almost hourly over the radio and nightly on the juke boxes and in the discotheques.

Dr. Roy L. Reierson, senior vice president of the Bankers Trust Company, has kicked off a sharp debate with his prediction that if present economic trends continue, there will be a broad upward adjustment in interest rates, including a further rise in the Federal Reserve discount rate.

CAIRO, Feb. 11--The North Vietnamese Embassy is reported to have given warnings here that Hanoi intends to try United States military prisoners as "criminals against humanity" under North Vietnamese law.
Dr. Alfonso A. Lombardi, executive dean of New York Medical College, died Thursday in St. Barnabas Hospital in the Bronx. He was 49 years old and lived at 435 East 79th Street.
Mr. and Mrs. Enmanuel Groussin of Cali, Colombia, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Genevieve Groussin, to John E. Houx. His parents are Mr. and Mrs. G. Marshall Houx of Rye, N.Y.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11-- President Johnson announced today the nomination of his special counsel, Lee C. White, for the chairmanship of the Federal Power Commission, one of the most sensitive posts in the agencies regulating private business.
Nineteen debutantes made their curtsies and danced the opening waltz last evening in the Grand Ballroom at the Plaza before 1,000 guests at the 14th annual Piarist Ball.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 (AP) --Buying by Communist-bloc nations from the Western World, bolstered by heavy wheat purchases, climbed $1billion, to $6.7-billion, in 1964.
The spot rate on the British pound closed down 8 points from Thursday's quotation at $2.8027 in quiet trading on foreign exchange markets here yesterday.
A harbor squad patrolman drowned yesterday in the East River near the spot where he rescued a man from the water four and a half years ago.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 (AP)--The number of visitors to the United States from overseas has more than doubled in the last four years and exceeded one million for the first time last year, the United States Travel Service reported today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11-- The haste, commotion and public rhetoric of the Honolulu conference this week and the United Nations debate last week obscured but did not alter the Johnson Administration's basic designs and problems in Vietnam.
BEVERLY HILLS, Calif., Feb. 11--Jane Ford Tefft, one of the nation's few women stockbrokers and a prominent amateur flier, died of cancer at her home here today. She was 45 years old.

LINCOLN, Neb., Feb. 11-- Gov. Frank B. Morrison announced his candidacy for the United States Senate today, thus insuring one of the most hotly contested races in the turbulent history of Nebraska politics.

A thumbprint found on a smokemaking device that was set afire moments before the murder of Malcolm X was identified yesterday as having been made by Thomas Hagan, one of the three men charged with the killing.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 --Two physicists have invented a method of making that new tool of science, the laser, more flexible and useful.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11-- The index of wholesale primary market prices advanced onetenth of 1 per cent to 104.8 of its 1957-59 base during the week ended Feb. 8, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today.
The Connecticut General Life Insurance Company announced yesterday the resignations, to take effect March 15, of two top executives and related board and management changes.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 11--A romper lobby from Mississippi petitioned Congress today for a redress of grievances.
LINCOLN, Neb., Feb.11 (AP) --The Nebraska Supreme Court held unconstitutional today two Omaha Sunday closing ordinances.
MONTE CARLO, Feb. 11--A Czechoslovak TV film on antiSemitism won the grand prize of the sixth international television festival of Monte Carlo today.

MINNEAPOLIS, Feb. 11-- Robert Kurka's "The Good Soldier Schweik" is an American opera that has had more than 500 performances in Europe but hardly any in this country since it was completed nine years ago.
CHICAGO, Feb. 11--A scholarly conference on Communist China at the University of Chicago ended today as some of the 38 participants headed for similar meetings in five other cities.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Feb. 11 (UPI)--The chairman of Cassius Clay's draft board, J. Allen Sherman, said today the world heavyweight champion could be inducted into the army before his March 29 title fight with Ernie Terrell.
Concern over midair collisions and near-misses has prompted the Air Line Pilots Association to request an immediate and drastic change in air traffic rules by the Federal Aviation Agency.
BONN, Feb. 11--According to official doctrine, Ger mans on both sides of the Iron Curtain think by day and dream by night of the day when the nation will again be united.

SESTRIERE, Italy, Feb. 11-- Therese Obrecht of Switzerland won the women's downhill ski race today, edging out Jean Saubert of Lakeview, Ore., by a little more than a second, in the day's feature event at the World University Winter Games.

MOSCOW, Feb. 11--Two Russian writers stood up in a court here today and argued the necessity for artistic freedom in answering a prosecutor's accusation that they had tried to undermine Soviet Communism by smuggling manuscripts to the West for publication.

Fairleigh Dickinson Univer sity won two of the six races and scored in the other four to capture team honors yesterday in the annual collegiate track conference indoor relay carnival at FitzGerald Memorial Gymnasium, Queens College, Flushing, Queens.
SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 12--Extremism remains an issue in California's political campaign.
SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 12, (AP) The California heavyweight champion, Thand Spencer, will fight Billy Daniels of Brooklyn on Feb. 21 in a 10round bout at Kezar Pavilion.
It is one of those unexplained curiosities of the advertising business that neither Doyle Dane Bernbach Inc. nor Grey Advertising Inc. uses a comma in its corporate name.
BANGKOK, Thailand, Feb. 12 (UPI) Cambodian soldiers raided a small Thai border village last night, killing two persons and wounding three others, reports today said.
GREENPORT, L.I., Feb. 12 A 19-year-old Youth Corps volunteer was charged today with slaying a 77-year-old widow.
VAIL, Colo., Feb. 12 (UPI) Jamie Paul of Seattle flashed along a two-mile downhill course in 2 minutes 1.69 seconds today to win the first event in the Vail Trophy ski races.

President Johnson, in a special message to Congress, has proposed immediate measures to strengthen the nation's capacity for international educational cooperation and to increase the volume and effectiveness of the exchanges with students and teachers of other lands.

SAN ANTONIO, Tex,, Feb. 14 (UPI) Physicians at Lackland Air Force base diagnosed another case of spinal meningitis today, the latest in the worst outbreak of the disease since 15 persons died at Fort Ord, Calif., a year ago.
LONDON, Feb. 12 (AP) Dr. Roberto Arias, former Panamanian diplomat, left an English hospital today after an 18-month stay.

CHICAGO, Feb, 12 (UPI) Bobby Hull broke a three-game scoring drought with his 45th goal tonight to help Chicago gain a 2-2 tie with the Montreal Canadiens. He then sat out the final period in a hospital with an injured knee.

MADRID The Span ish winter, like all things Spanish, is a study in variety and diversity. And because Spain at this time of year is not quite as filled with tourists as during the warmer months just over 14 million of them came here in 1965 the winter affords an unusual opportunity to see and do many things without being crowded, mobbed or elbowed out of the way.

Earlier in the week the Boston Bruins had the gall to drop the New York Rangers into the cellar of the National Hockey League, a position the Bruins had occupied almost consistently for the last five seasons.
ROTTERDAM "The groundwater level is very high here," commented a construction engineer on the Rotterdam subway project in a masterful understatement.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 President Johnson will propose soon an attack on water pollution through a plan to clean up entire river basins.

WASHINGTON. GEN. WILLIAM TECUMSEH SHERMAN, the leader of the Civil War march through Georgia, once undertook to have a correspondent hanged for espionage. Angrily, he wrote that he would rather be governed by Jefferson Davis than "abused by a set of dirty newspaper scribblers who have the impudence of Satan."

CHICAGO, Feb, 12 With Chicago's big exposition center almost solidly booked with conventions and trade shows for the next several years, civic leaders are considering construction of a second facility, to handle the everincreasing business.

Mr. and Mrs. Charles K. Stoeppler of Buenos Aires and Hilton Head Island, S.C., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Susan Stoeppler, to Christopher Dyer Saudek, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Saudek of Bronxville, N.Y., and Boothbay Harbor, Me.

FARMINGTON, Conn., Feb. 12 St. James Episcopal Church was the setting this afternoon for the marriage of Miss Katherine Pope Cheney, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Wells Cheney Jr., to Thomas Matthew Chappell. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. George Matthew Chappell of Drakes Island, Wells, Me.

MAPLEWOOD, N.J., Feb. 12 Miss Thalia Barbara Smith, daughter of Sylvester Comstock Smith Jr. of West Orange and the late Mrs. Smith, was married this afternoon to Elbert Ervin Husted, 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Husted of Newark and Mantaloking.

Four years of bitter controversy over the proposed Adele Rosenwald Levy playground and community center in Riverside Park at 102d Street promise to be a mere warmup for what the project faces this week.

To the lay reading public Arnold Toynbee is the outstanding historian of the 20th century. The 10 massive volumes of his "A Study of History" and their two-volume abridgement by D.C. Somervell have enjoyed an enormous circulation.

Ch. Blanbeeridge G'Quosa, better known as "Cosy", brought the main honors of the annual Rhodesian Ridgeback Club of the United States specialty to her owner, Mrs. Blanche Brophy of Wallkill, N.Y., yesterday at the Statler Hilton Hotel.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 12 Six straight free throws in the last minute of play tonight gave Princeton a 68-64 victory over Yale. The victory improved Princeton"s Ivy League wonlost record to 8-1 and kept the Tigers in a tie for the lead.

PARIS A world increasingly governed by soldiers might well contemplate the lesson of General Cemal Gursel, the Turkish President now dying in a Washington hospital. Gursel, a respected professional officer, was installed by military comp d'etat in 1960. Yet he made it his primary task to restore normal, civilian, democratic government.
CRANFORD, N.J., Feb. 12 Several top players in the East and elsewhere have accepted invitations to play in the first Cranford indoor doubles tournament starting next Friday at the Tennis Center here.

Playing for the Fabulous Magicians in the opening exhibition game was Ray Felix, the former 6-foot-11-inch Laker and Knick center. Felix, 35 years old, is director of a youth center in the Bronx and plays for the touring team on weekends.
DETROIT, Feb. 12 (UPI) A former mental patient climbed to the pulpit of a crowded Synagogue today, told the congregation that its members "make me ashamed to say that I am a Jew," and shot the rabbi.
A bill providing for the establishment of a loan-guaranty fund to assist in fi nancing new and existing industry in Virginia was introduced last week in the Virginia General Assembly.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Feb. 12 James J.Kermath, a dog breeder and retired firstgrade detective of the New York City Police Department, died of a heart attack yesterday in his home at 155 Crary Avenue. His age was 64.
HOLYOKE, Mass., Feb. 12 (AP) Ed Hurley, an American League umpire for 19 years, said today he intended to fight the league's mandatory program of retiring umpires at the age of 55.

James E. McCarthy, former administrative director of Mobilization for Youth, has produced evidence that he says clears him of charges that he spent more than $23,000 of the antipoverty agency's funds for "wining and dining" between 1962 and 1964.
TORONTO, Feb. 12 (AP) Paul Henderson's goal with one second to play earned the Detroit Red Wings a 3-3 National Hockey League deadlock with the Toronto Maple Leafs tonight.

COMMACK, L.I., Feb. 12 (AP) The New Haven Blades failed to appear for their scheduled Eastern Hockey League game against Long Island tonight in defiance of a suspension of their coach by the league president, Tom Lockhart.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 (AP) World production of oils and fats in 1966 will be a record of 36.8 million short tons, the Agriculture Department predicts.

WHEN Paul Tillich died a few months ago he was universally acknowledged as one of the outstanding theologians and religious thinkers of our time. Yet in the last few years of his life he had been subjected to increasingly severe criticism especially from younger theologians.
The annual report of the Calgon Corporation has become a best seller because everybody is interested in the Pittsburgh company's business water.

John T. Marvin of Xenia, Ohio, and Maj. B. Godsol of Dixon, Calif., who will judge the terrier and working groups at Westminster, respectively, will give their impressions of the dogs they judge at Wednesday's Dog Fanciers Luncheon Club meeting. The event will be at Luchow's Restaurant.

Stocks made a moderate gain on average for the week in heavy trading; rails, electronics, mining and specialsituation stocks showed the biggest gains; volume, 46,736,890 shares.

BILLINGS, Mont., Feb. 10 Within the next few days the audit will be finished that will decide just how many millions of dollars a bank will ask from an insurance company that guaranteed the integrity of the bank's, officers, one of whom, a vice president, died under mysterious circumstances.

HOT SPRINGS, Ark., Feb. 12 (AP) Oak Hill Farm's King of Kentucky overtook C.O. Viar's Bay Phantom in the closing strides today and won the $10,000 Inaugural Handicap in a drizzling rain at Oaklawn Park.

ASHEVILLE, N.C., Feb. 12 The Right Rev. IN the metropolitan area, this is the week of the dog. Philotherians from coast to coast, Hawaii, Puerto Rico and Canada have descended on New York and will be striving to take home the rosette that signifies best in show, along with the pieces of silverware that go with the ribbon.

BOWIE, Md., Feb. 12--Sailor Cap, a 3-year-old owned by Anthony Bonuomo, went to the front at the start of the $23,450 Francis Scott Key Stakes at Bowie today and steadily increased his lead to win by three lengths.

NEENDAKARA, India, Feb. 8 Three-year-old Mary Augustine and her 6-year-old brother, George, are among the most serious malnutrition cases in the health center here. Their wasted limbs, bloated bellies and running sores show that they ars suffering, among other things, from an acute protein deficiency.
The Japanese economy will expand at a faster pace in the 1966 fiscal year than during the current budgetary period, a Japanese banker predicted here last week.

An international art exhibition and auction in Washington on March 20 will benefit equally the gift coupon program of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization and the Library of Brandeis University, Waltham, Mass.

The New York City Police Department's Civilian Complaint Review Board consists of three deputy police commissioners, none of whom has ever been a police officer. Two are lawyers and one is a former newspaperman. Their job is to deal with complaints from the public against the police.

FOLLOWING last year's "Miscellany One" this new anthology provides short stories, instruction (keeping tropical fish, making shadow puppets), poetry and art work for "all ages," although it is certainly not intended for children under 10. SEATTLE, Feb. 12 . Gov. Daniel J. Evans of Washington, a structural engineer by profession, has a new project on the drawing board for 1966 a solid bloc of Republican-run states substantial enough to give the region substantial power in national party affairs. If it is achieved, he could become a significant figure in future national Republican calculations.

SET in the suburbs of an Australian town, Patrick White's new novel is concerned with the lives of two of its residents, the twin brothers Waldo and Arthur Brown. As far as the great world goes the Browns are unimportant figures. Lower middle class, they are not well-educated; not even Waldo, the clever one, who works in the public library.

BLOOMINGTON, Ind., Feb. 12 (UPI) Indiana University's swimming team avenged an earlier defeat and knocked Michigan from the ranks of the unbeaten today with a 66-57 victory.

HONG KONG, Feb. 12 In his lonely eminence in Peking, Mao Tse-tung had cause cause to brood this week about the heresies and ingratitude of former comrades who have decamped from the Chinese Communist fold. Premier Fidel Castro of Cuba is the most recent excommunicant.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 A gradual build-up of American forces in Vietnam to 400,000 men by the end of this year would not by itself require extra defense funds for a tax increase, informed officials said today.

COCOA BEACH, Fla., Feb. 12 (AP) Former Representative Fred Ernst Busbey, an Illinois Republican who during three nonconsecutive terms in the House was a militant foe of Communism, died at a heart attack last night at the Brevard Hospital in Melbourne. He was 71 years old and had retired here from Chicago nine years ago.

The New York Knickerbockers, firmly entrenched in the National Basketball Association's Eastern Division cellar, routed the Los Angeles Lakers, firmly entrenched in the Western Division lead, 140-127, last night at Madison Square Garden.

At a naval base outside Santo Domingo last Friday, Francisco Rivera Caminero, a blunt-spoken, 37-year-old naval officer, relinquished command of the Dominican armed forces and stepped aboard a frigate. Ahead lay a diplomatic post in Washington and virtual exile. Another chapter in the turbulent Dominican drama had ended, another unpredictable phase was beginning.

LAST June 19, early risers in this Mediterranean capital, on their way to work downtown, found two big Soviet-made T-54 tanks stationed in front of the Moorish-style Central Post Office. The tank crews sprawled sleepily next to their guns in the warm sunshine. They would say nothing.

Should scientific ethics or cold war gamesmanship determine the actions of an observatory that intercepts Soviet pictures of the moon? That was the issue raised by scientists last week after the Jodrell Bank Observatory in England made public the Luna 9 pictures before Moscow did. The British pictures were somewhat distorted because they did not know the proper setting for printing out the pictures from the radio signals.

We come to mid-February with a variety of signs that reflect the season. In the zodiac, Aquarius is about to give way to Pisces, water boy to fish, Uranus to Neptune. In the almanac, winter is in its last month, come snow, sleet or whatever the weather may bring. And on the calendar stands Saint Valentine's Day, festival of hearts and flowers, occasion of love tokens and romance.

GORDON PARKS, the photographer, has never suffered the psychic traumas that are commonly alleged to affect most Negroes. He has always known and accepted who and what he is: "I knew I was black," he affirms in his autobiograghy, "A Choice of Weapons," "and that I would always be black." What he has refused to accept is the popular definition of what being black is and the limitations that the definition automatically imposes.

Miss Frances K. Durkan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Durkan of Brooklyn, was married here at noon yesterday to Brendan Harley Dooley. His parents are Mr. and Mrs. T. Brendan Dooley of Malden-onHudson, N.Y.

A new dimension Style Skiing has been added to Alpine competition this season. Free skiing was the feature of an amateur program held on Mount Attitash in Bartlett, N.H., and the National Professional Ski League races at Stratton (Vt.) Mountain last month.

IN the introduction to this account of the first 21 years of his life, Kenneth Rexroth states that his objectives are communion with those he loves, an attempt to understand himself, and to relate "an interesting story of minor historical importance" of backyard Indiana and Chicago in the early 1900's.

Anthony DeAngelis is walloping pots in the kitchen at the Lewisburg, Pa., penitentiary for his part in the $150-millionsalad-oil swindle, but there was an indication last week that some of his old buddies still cast a long shadow over the commodities markets he once dominated.
A corporate headquarters and research park has been added to the growing community of office-research-manufacturing centers at Stamford, Conn.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 Senator Abraham A. Ribicoff urged President Johnson today to arrange a preliminary conference on Vietnam, to be held in Geneva on a specific date, and "let all who are involved in Vietnam" including the Vietcong attend, with no subject barred from the agenda.
The national economy is so strong, in the view of members of the National Tool, Die and Precision Machining Association, that the industry could increase its sales this year by some $250-million.

WE can now at last consider the publishing season officially open: the first John Creasey novel of the year has appeared, and the second will come out next week. Mr. Creasey has recently compiled a complete checklist of his books since 1938: 372 titles, under 13 names, including 12...

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 The Government is now armed with a stronger and more comprehensive law for banning racial discrimination in the sale and rental of housing than that proposed by President Johnson, a private research agency reported today.

AIR-MAIL DAY, which falls on May 27, will be observed during SIPEX, the Sixth Inter national Philatelic Exhibition to be held in Washington from May 21 to May 30. On May 27, the Post Office Department will issue an 11-cent international air-mail postal card, Postmaster General Lawrence F. O'Brien announced last week. The design, although not yet released, will be on the theme, "Discover America."
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Feb. 12 Martin McGrady, a little-known runner from a little-knowrn college, wiped out one of the best world indoor records tonight.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Feb. 12 Louis Englander, a certified public accountant and senior partner with Apfel Englander at 347 Madison Avenue, New York, died yesterday in his home, 40 Carleon Avenue. His age was 73.
NEW HAVEN, Feb. 12 Important paintings, sculpture, drawings and prints acquired during the last year by the Yale University Art Gallery will be put on exhibit starting Wednesday.
Two Roman Catholic parishes in the Bronx that had been straining their architectural seams because of growing congregations are engaged in major expansion programs.

DEAL, N.J., Feb. 12 Mrs. Miriam Ronga Rockafeller of Loch Arbour and Eugene Alan Bush of Rumson were married this afternoon at St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church. The Rev. Joseph Miele performed, the ceremony.

WILTON, Conn., Feb. 12 A May wedding is planned by Miss Susan Dorsey Mountain and David Caulkins Gray. Mr. and Mrs. Robert P. Mountain have announced their daughter's engagement to the son of Dr. and Mrs. Julius C. Gray of Larchmont, N.Y., and Chatham, Mass.

BUFFALO, Feb. 12 (AP) Dennis Ralston of Bakersfield, Calif., the nation's top-ranking player, and Gene Scott of New York won first-round matches today in the annual Buffalo Tennis Club indoor tournament.

SHORT HILLS, N.J., Feb. 12 In St. Rose of Lima Roman Catholic Church today, Miss Nancy Theresa Corge was married to Richard Gerard Callahan by the Rev. Albert Wickens. The parents of the couple are Mr. and Mrs. Charles Edward Corge of Short Hills and Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Callahan of Washington.

MOSCOW, Feb. 12 (UPI) Five Russians were sentenced to death today for taking part in the mass murder of thousands of Russians during the World War II Nazi occupation. A sixth defendant was sentenced to 15 years in prison.
In consideration of the many new investors entering the stock market, the Securities and Exchange Commission early in December acted to make company financial reports simpler and more understandable.
Corporate Thoreaus are working in the wilderness in a quest for solutions to the water pollution problem.
The over-the-counter market turned in a good performance last week as most stocks moved forward on heavy volume.
DES MOINES, Iowa, Feb. 11 The Iowa Supreme Court acted this week to insure 7year-old Mark Painter a "conventional, middle-class, Middle West background."

NEW CANAAN, Conn., Feb. 12 Mr. and Mrs. George A. Murphy of New Canaan and New York have announced the engagement, of their daughter, Miss Jean Russell Murphy, to W. Mason Smith 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. W. Mason Smith of New York and Mattapoisett, Mass. The wedding is planned for September.

ARCADIA, Calif,, Feb. 12 Hill Rise came from far off a blistering pace and won the $56,500 San Antonio Handicap today, stamping himself as a strong threat in the $145,000 Santa Anita Handicap on Feb. 26.
MIAMI, Feb. 12 (AP) A waystop in Miami, home of thousands of their compatriots and relatives, was momentarily too much today for Cubans flying from their homeland toward exile in Costa Rica.

This year's Paris spring collections came through with a warm rosy glow as the designers turned to dresses in nude-looking sheers or with body-baring cutouts. They also insisted that fuller coats with just suggestions of high waistlines were back while the tent dresses underneath were waistless. But there were skinny belts on the short suit jackets for a total look of freshness and freedom, if not fireworks.
RIVERHEAD, L.I., Feb. 12 The Suffolk County Board of Supervisors has decided to apply for Federal and state aid for a billion-dollar sewer system.

In his proposed international Health and education acts of 1966, President Johnson has called for a global attack on ignorance and disease. In this battle, he said, "we call on rich nations and poor nations to join with us to help each other and to help themselves."

MOSCOW, Feb. 12 The literary trial of two Russian authors accused of undermining Soviet communism in clandestine writings ended tonight with the state prosecutor's demanding penalties of hard labor and exile.
HONG KONG, Feb. 13 The visitors from New York were delighted and impressed when a Hong Kong friend visited their hotel mom bearing a bottle topped with gold foil.
"Messieurs, dames, faites vos jeux" and "rien ne va plus" are being heard again, for the first time in more than 30 years, aboard a cruise ship sailing from the Port of New York.

PLANS for the 1966 Young America Gardens Contest have been announced by the Flower and Garden Foundation, a non-profit organization which has sponsored the national gardening competition for children since 1960. The contest will be conducted on a regional basis (East, Mid-America and West) and is divided into two age groups, teen and pre-teen. Prizes include trips, bicycles and cash awards.

For nearly a decade, the Wolfenden Report has been a controversial issue in Britain. It was in 1957 that a Government-sponsored committee headed by Sir John Wolfenden, a leading British academician, completed a three-year study of British morals and recommended, among other things, the removal from criminal law of all penalties for homosexual conduct by consenting adults in private.

PARIS, Feb. 12 The arrest of an important member of the official French intelligence agency this week in connection with the kidnapping and presumed murder of Mehdi Ben Barka has failed to bring authorities any closer to solving the mystery.
GARFIELD, N.J., Feb. 12--A whirlpool deep in Bergen County caused so much trouble that a builder had to send down a deep-sea diver to break it up.

AUSTIN, Tex., Feb. 12 Ronnie Dugger, a leading Texas liberal, entered the race for the United States Senate this week, a move that most political observers interpreted as an assist to the re-election campaign of Senator John G. Tower, an ultraconservative.
LONDON, Feb. 13 (AP) Demonstrators protesting the Vietnam war tried to get into the House of Commons today and stage a "debate" in the empty chamber.

DIRK STIKKER, former Secreretary General of NATO, once made the interesting discovery that Charles de Gaulle had prefaced his book. "The Edge of the Sword" with a misquotation from "Hamlet." The misquotation reads: "Rightly to be great/Is to sustain a great quarrel."

PARIS Europe's railroads are not letting themselves be bypassed by other means of transportation during the present travel boom on the Continent. By offering increasingly faster trains, convenient schedules, modern equipment and installations and new features, the railroads are meeting the competition of the airplane and the automobile.
F. Eugene Dixon Jr. of Philadelphia was re-elected president of the National Steeplechase and Hunt Association at a meeting in the Jockey Club offices, 300 Park Avenue.

DARIEN, Conn., Feb. 12 St. Luke's Episcopal Church was the setting today for the marriage of Miss Anne Louise Fisher, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Shelton Fisher to Jonathan Charles Colby, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert W. Colby of Upper Bronxville, N.Y.
With the recent conversion of 16 Sutton Place from a rental building to a cooperative, only two of the 15 apartment houses on the fashionable thoroughfare are on a rental basis.

CAIRO, Feb.12--The United States turned over to Cairo today the second half of a $12-million contribution to a $36-million international project for saving the Temple of Abu Simbel from submersion under Nile River waters backed up by the High Dam at Aswan.

A $200,000 addition to the New Canaan Savings Bank in New Canaan, Conn., was designed to soften the cold, institutional appearance of the original building, which was built in 1929 and was typical of the original building.

After two-and-one-half years of careful inquiry and tense bureaucratic negotiations, the Agriculture and Interior Departments have joined in recommending the creation of a new national park in the North Cascade Mountains in the state of Washington. But the agreement is fragile and incomplete, and some of the compromises at the heart of the report are damaging.

The affluent teen-age boy who steals hub caps, who crashes and breaks up house parties and drinks too much is very likely to have learned delinquency at his father's knee, a psychiatric social worker declared last week.

"LAST year I spoke at Cambridge," Larry Rivers said in the harsh, scratchy voice that makes him sound like a dropout from the Hell's Angels (though the tone was Boy Scout gee-whiz). "I mean, I'm grown up enough not to be awed by things, but that's quite a distance from the Bronx, where I started out."
MADONNA di CAMPIGLIO, Italy, Feb. 12 (AP) Ludwig Leitner of Germany won the men's special slalom of the Three-Three ski competition today. His total time for the two heats was 93.35 seconds.

The stunning broadcast performance of Verdi's "Aida" yesterday afternoon at the Metropolitan Opera House was one of rare completeness. The epic opera's many facets were each so highly polished that they flashed soft and brilliant hues with equal intensity. The principals integrated their acting and singing into a dramatic whole; this was not a series of solo spots. It is difficult to know where to throw the firt orchid.
BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., Feb. 12 Matt Bimonte, a 14year-old ski jumper from Lake Placid, soared to a double victory today in the Metropolitan Ski Jumping Championships before 9,522 fans.

TOKYO A Tokyo matron complained, after a recent holiday in Hong Kong, that she felt as if she "had never left home." Everywhere she turned in the British Crown Colony, she said, she encountered other Japanese.
AUGUSTA, Me., Feb. 8 Maine has qualified to become the first state to establish a wilderness waterway to preserve the natural characteristics of a river, the Allagash.

SAIGON, Feb. 12--South Vietnamese troops have won two important battles in what is sometimes described as "the forgotten war" in the Mekong River delta. The engage- ments were said to have taken the lives of 262 Vietcong guerrillas.
LISBON, Feb. 10 Portugal is striving to send more settlers to her African possessions as one way to curb the tide of decolonizatioon.

BANFF, Alta., Feb. 12 (UPI) Kurt Huggler, a 20-year-old hotel management student from Murren, Switzerland, won the men's giant slalom today at the Dumaurier international meet. He went through the 62 gates on 6,500-foot Mount Norquay in a time of 1 minute 50.09 seconds.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 Luci Baines Johnson and her fiance, Patrick Nugent, were toasted and cheered tonight at the first of several parties expected to be given in honor of their engagement.
CHICAGO, Feb. 12 (AP) Accidents killed 47,500 persons last year in homes or public places, excluding traffic and industrial fatalities, the National Safety Council said today.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 12 (UPI) A fleet of 44 yachts, ranging in size from 30 to 73 feet in length, moved out into the Gulf in threatening weather today at the start of the 403-mile St. Petersburg-toFort Lauderdale yacht race.

Miss Louise Lockwood Parry, daughter of Mrs. George Gowen Parry Jr. of Philadelphia and the late Mr.Parry, was married yesterday to Creighton McShane. The Rev. John Quinn performed the ceremony in the Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas More, and a reception was held at the New York Junior League.
A transparent plastic dome, 50 feet in diameter and large enough to display five automobiles, is being used as the showroom of an automobile agency in Kingston, N.Y.

HAMBURG, West Germany Hamburg, which probably suffered more from World War II and its aftermath than any other West German city, has made the most successful comeback. Not only has it re-emerged as a leading port but it has become the largest industrial center of West Germany. It has also replaced West Berlin as the nation's press capital.
With high hopes of putting two good years back-to-back, men's wear manufacturers and retailers are gathering in Dallas this week to analyze the results of 1965 and explore the potential of 1966.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 12 (AP) Penn's quintet kept its share of the Ivy League lead tonight by routing Brown, 92-64, Stan Pawlak, with 27 points, and Jeff Neuman, with 25, led the attack that gave Penn its 15th victory in 19 games and an 8-1 Ivy record.

AKRON, Ohio, Feb. 12 Mr. and Mrs. Earl B. Hathaway have announced the engagement, of their daughter, Miss Margaret Anne Hathaway, to Frederick Bowes 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Bowes Jr., of New Canaan, Conn.

LAWRENCEVILLE, N.J., Feb. 12 Princeton's indoor track team won 10 of 13 events to take the Polar Bear meet for the seventh straight year at the Alvino Fieldhouse today. The Tigers scored 90 points to 30 for Columbia and 17 for Pennsylvania.
Housewives soon may feel another pinch where it hurts in their food budgets. Last Friday the nation's major sugar refiners raised prices for sugar.

THE ballplayers will be heading south soon for the start of spring training and the fragrant Florida air, scented by orange blossoms, will be penetrated by the piteous wails at all catchers who are doomed to handle knuckleball pitchers. But they will get little sympathy from Rick Ferrell, the vice president of the Detroit Tigers. Flutterball throwers made him old before his time.
A private recreation center for residents of Strathmore at Stony Brook will be built and ready for use this season, Levitt Sons, Inc., the builder of the Suffolk County community announced recently.

THE Florida Sunshine Circuit seven horse shows offering prizes of more than $100,000 in prize money gets under way Wednesday with the Bethesda Hospital event at Delray Beach.

The marriage of Miss Elizabeth Babbott, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Frank L. Babbott of Bernardsville, N.J., to George H. Conant Jr. of Lexington, Mass., took place in the Christ Chapel of the Riverside Church yesterday afternoon. The bridegroom is a son of Dr. and Mrs. Conant of Ripon, Wis. The Rev. Jesse Lyons, minister of the church, performed the cere- mony. He was assisted by Dr. J. Seelye Bixler, former president of Colby College.
Boston College, with John Austin leading the way, scored a hard-earned 96-86 victory over Fordham at the Rose Hill gymnasium last night.
MIAMI. Feb. 12 Cuba and the Soviet Union have signed an agreement for $913-million in trade this year. The figure is 22 per cent above that of last year, the Havana radio said today.

JOHN KRIZA, who has just announced his retirement from the stage, has been one of the pioneers of American ballet. Born in 1919 in Berwyn, Ill., he joined the corps de ballet of Ballet Theater during its first season in 1940, and has been one of its principal dancers for more than 20 years.
NOROTON, Conn., Feb. 12 Miss Sheila Ewing, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Ewing, became the bride this morning of Thomas Matthew Daley, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert N. Daley of Wellesley Hills, Mass.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 Five years ago, when President Kennedy entered office proclaiming his purpose "to get this country moving again," the one objective beyond all others on which he and his domestic policy advisers fixed their sights was jobs.

LONDON, Feb. 11 "Buy European," the Society of British Aerospace Companies urges. Its statement reaches Fleet Street newspaper offices while an American corporate presidernt is quietly telling Members of Parliament of the benefits of buying in the United States.
ZERMATT, Switzerland, Feb. 12 (UPI) Swiss skiers today swept the Blauherd downhill race and combined standings in the Gorner-Grat Derby.
MIAMI, Feb. 12 Neb Ryall, an orange grower from Wabasso, Fla., sailed into a wide lead today after three races in the Shark Class catamaran midwinter Championships.

EXETER, N.H., Feb. 12 Gov. George Romney of Michigan came to New Hampshire, site of the earliest Presidential primary, today to deliver a conservatively tinged Lincoln Day speech to a luncheon crowd of 1,100 Republicans at the Phillips Exeter Academy fieldhouse.

Just two years ago today, a spindly Loyola of Chicago senior, his reddish-blond hair flowing atop a pale, 5-foot-9-inch frame, shattered the world indoor mile record with a clocking of 3 minutes 56.6 seconds at Madison Square Garden.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 President Johnson said today that in the last year the nation had made "unprecedented progress in fulfilling the ideal for which Abraham Lincoln stood."

TRIVANDRUM, India, Feb. 12 As students pelted stones at buses and public buildings here last week some of them shouted a slogan which has become almost the motto of the Kerala rice agitation: "Is not Kerala part of India?"
BANGKOK, Thailand, Feb. 12 In this extravagantly fertile section of southern Thailand, it is often said that one has only to poke a stick in the ground and a plant will shoot up.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 12 (AP) Australia's recordsmashing runner, Ron Clarke, will race in the two-mile event at the fourth annual Golden Gate invitation indoor track meet at the Cow Palace on Feb. 25, meet officials said today.

COLORADO SPRINGS, Colo--At least a million skiers are expected to use Colorado's 29 ski resorts this winter. Since early winter, heavy snows have piled up across a 100,000-square-mile-area of the Rockies from Wyoming southward.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 11 (UPI) The nation's airlines will carry more than 100 million passengers this year, a top industry official predicted yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 Rent supplements, or subsidies, have upgraded the housing and environments of 50 poor Washington families in an experiment that Government officials pronounce successful.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), Feb. 12 Israel lifted tonight the ban on "Goldfinger" and other films showing the actor Gert Frobe. He had been barred from the nation's screens because of his Nazi past.

DOES order of birth affect a child's personality? Psychology Professor William D. Altus of the University of California says it can, that a child's position in the family may influence the way his parents bring him up and thus determine his later achievement in life.

Rabbi Edward T. Sandrow, newly elected president of the New York Board of Rabbis, proposed yesterday that leaders of the Protestant, Roman Catholic and Jewish faiths organize a special joint commission to promote reform of the state's "unenlightened" divorce law.

WHITE PLAINS, Feb. 12--An all-electric office building, which will derive both light and heat from its high-intensity fluorescent lamps, will be built here by Consolidated Edison as its corporate headquarters for Westchester County.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Feb. 12 (AP) Penn State fought off a Navy rally for a 66-59 basketball victory today.

LONDON, Feb. 13 (AP) Magnifik Midget No. 15 is a free sloop once more.

MADRID, Feb. 12 International warrants for the arrest of eight men on charges of "responsibility" in the mysterious deaths last year of Lieut. Gen. Humberto Delgado, a Portuguese opposition leader, and his woman secretary were issued here last night by the Spanish magistrate investigating the case.

Alan Zuckerman tied the game with a basket and a foul shot with less than three minutes remaining in regulation time and then paced City College to a 77-71 victory over Rochester University in three overtimes last night at Wingate Gymnasium.

SOUTH WEYMOUTH, Mass., Feb. 12 Mr. and Mrs. John N. Allen have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Jane Allen, to J. Randall Williams 4th, son of Mr. and Mrs. Williams 3d, of Dover, formerly of Short Hills, N.J.

SYRACUSE, Feb. 12 (AP) Ron Bonham left the Boston bench late in the final quarter tonight and led the Celtics to an 85-83 victory over Philadelphia. It was one of the lowest-scoring National Basketball Association games in recent years.

NEW DELHI One day last fall a middle-aged American tourist sat on the terrace of a Singapore hotel and looked north toward the gathering dusk. "Vietnam's up that way, isn't it?" he nervously asked his tour guide. "Do you ever see the gun flashes from here?"

Dr. Barad, a founder and past president of the society, is a judge at the International Flower Show.

An engineering firm has designed a simple aluminum drive-in shelter to protect the homeowner's second car from the weather.

CHARLESTOWN, Nevis, B.W.I. On Feb. 22, to ward the end of their 30-day Caribbean tour, Queen Elizabeth II and Prince Philip will stop for 45 minutes on this little Leeward island. Is 45 minutes a visit, or is it a pause? No matter. To Nevis, it will be a shining hour.

New Jersey's oldest and larg- est nautical exposition, the Jersey Coast Boat Show, will open its 13th annual stand next Saturday at Convention Hall in Asbury Park. The nine-day event runs through Feb. 27.

COCKBURN TOWN, Grand Turk Island, B.W.I. "It's a crazy little island, but I think that you will find it interesting." This is frequently how a visitor is greeted upon arrival on Grand Turk, here in the British West Indies. Tourists are rare and other visitors are few, but, for those who do come, the promise is usually fulfilled.

The Federal Housing Administration's action last week in raising the interest rates for the mortgages the agency insures met with neither clamor from outraged home buyers nor any sighs of relief from lenders.

HANOVER, N.H., Feb. 12 The Dartmouth College ski team emerged from a backdrop of melting snow statues and deteriorating race courses today to end Middlebury's twoyear reign as kingpin of the Big Green's winter carnival.

ITHACA, N.Y., Feb. 13-- Four girl students from Mount Holyoke College, armed with two electric guitars, an electric piano, a set of drums, three microphones and two amplifiers, are carrying the liveliest music of the year to colleges throughout the Northeast--in a 1957 Cadillac hearse.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., Feb. 13 --The ninth Fashions-at-Luncheon, co-sponsored by the Cathedral Women of the Cathedral of the Incarnation and the Garden City Chamber of Commerce, will be held on Thursday in the Georgian Room of the Garden City Hotel. The proceeds will go to the cathedral women's missionary and philanthropic program.
Bernard Miller, active in New York civic and Jewish affairs, died yesterday in his home at 1504 Sheridan Avenue, the Bronx. He was 76 years old.

MOSCOW, Feb. 13--Two Russian writers, standing up for literary freedom against the full weight of Communist authority--which has already condemned them--will hear their sentences from the Russian Supreme Court tomorrow.

PITTSBURGH, Feb. 13--Steel men were talking last week about breaking records that were just officially posted. Mill analysts said there was a good chance this year's ship ments would exceed the 92.7 million tops of 1965. This prediction came only a short while after official statistics disclosed that new records were set last year for total shipments and for five major products.
Dr. Eugene Senior of 80 Park Avenue, a dentist here 59 years, died Friday in the New York Hospital. His age was 79.
DETROIT, Feb. 13--The Johnson Administration is expected to propose legislation this week that would permit the Government to set national standards for automotive safety.
Municipal bond sales this week are expected to more than double last week's volume, while corporate bond underwriting activity will slacken.
Spain's infant auto-parts industry is combining traditional metal craftsmanship, low costs and enterprise in a bid for export business in the United States and other countries.

DETROIT, Feb. 13 (UPI)-- Rabbi Morris Adler, 59-yearold prominent Detroit religious leader who was shot in the head yesterday during a synagogue service by a member of his congregation, clung to life today while doctors and surgeons battled to save him.
THE pedal parts of a pig may not have universal appeal, but palates that enjoy an occasional change of pace can delight in pig's feet.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), Feb. 13--An Israeli army spokesman said today that mortar and tank fire destroyed two Syrian tanks today in a brief skirmish on the northern border near Ashmura.
HANOVER, N.H., Feb. 13 --Two thousand girls, all feeling very special, descended on Hanover this weekend for Dartmouth's 56th Winter Carnival.
SOMERS, Conn., Feb. 13-- Frank Leto of Darien, Conn., piloted his bay mare, Short Change, to the open jumper championship today at the Shallow brook Hunt Club show.

LISBON, Feb. 13--On the apparent first anniversary today of the murder of the Portuguese opposition leader, Lieut. Gen. Humberto Delgado, a lawyer for the Delgado family urged Spain to make public net investigations on the mysterious case.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Feb, 13--Both sides of this drab, divided city just north of the Bronx are concerned for "the future," which, in nearly every conversation, means March 15. It is a date discussed here with fear or hope.

The Port of New York Authority has asked the New YorkNew Jersey Congressional delegation to make "an all-out effort" this year to get a more equitable allotment of Federal navigation improvement funds for the port than it has received in the Executive Budget for fiscal 1966-67.

MIAMI, Feb, 13--Neb Ryall, a 44-year-old retired outboard racing driver, took the Shark Class catamaran national midwinter championship today by logging a first and second in 24-knot winds on Biscayne Bay.

WYNCOTE, Pa., Feb. 13-- Charles Pasarell, ranked No. 5 in the United States, recovered from the loss of the first set today to win the Philadelphia invitation indoor tennis championship for the second straight year. He defeated Arthur Ashe, the second-ranked player, 4-6, 6-4, 6-1, 8-6.
GREENPORT. L.I., Feb. 13-- You can lead a farm laborer to water, but can you make him fish?
The Cross Brown Company has announced the election of Richard W. Seeler as senior vice president.

CHICAGO, Feb. 13 (UPI)-- Chico Maki scored two goals and assisted on a third tonight in sparking Chicago to a 6-1 victory over the New York Rangers that gave the Black Hawks full possession of first place in the National Hockey League.

HOLLYWOOD, Feb. 13--In a precedent-setting decision, a California judge has ruled that the film "A Place in the Sun" may not be televised if its artistic qualities are destroyed by the intrusion of commercials.
DETROIT, Feb. 13 (UPI)-- Gilles Tremblay scored the winning goal and assisted Claude Provost on two earlier scores as the Montreal Canadiens beat the Detroit Red Wings, 4-3, tonight.
CINCINNATI, Feb. 13 (AP) --The Kroger Company, one of the nation's largest food retailers, set records in both sales and profits last year.
PARIS, Feb. 13--Marguerite Long, one of France's leading pianists for half a century, died here today at the age of 91.
A good deal of controversy has been stirred by some rather sophisticated life-insurance plans that are being presented to the public as vehicles for obtaining lowcost protection.
PHOENIX, Ariz., Feb. 13 (UPI)--Gardner Dickinson Jr. held a three-stroke lead today at the 54-hole mark of the $60,000 Phoenix open golf tournament.
WELLINGTON, New Zealand, Feb. 13 (AP)--American girls broke two New Zealand records and tied two today as they continued their victorious swimming tour of New Zealand.
Governor Rockefeller will try to get legislation enacted today to permit New York City to pay its transit workers the raises they won in a strike last month.

A highly diversified Hawaiian company will build what is believed to be the largest residential housing development ever undertaken on the South American Continent.
The United States Government has been urged by the United States Trademark Association to ask Monaco authorities to cancel about 200 trademark registrations issued to a chemical consultant.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa--South Africa's white Government is about to be thrust into its first direct dealings with sovereign black states as the landlocked territories of Basutoland, Bechuanaland and Swaziland move swiftly to independence.

DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., Feb. 13--Richard Petty of Randleman, N.C., set a fivemile qualifying record of 175,165 miles an hour today and won the No. 1 starting position for the eighth annual Daytona 500mile race on Sunday, Feb. 27.

Moves are under way at Albany for getting around the courts by giving New York's transit workers retroactive absolution for last month's illegal strike. The penalties of the Condon-Wadlin Act would be ignored and the way cleared for paying the wage increases and other benefits the Transport Workers Union extorted by paralyzing the city for twelve days.
THOUSANDS of bridge players take part in New York tournaments each year, but few realize how much work is required by a small body of voluntary administrators to make such tournaments possible.

The coffin bearing the body of Billy Rose rested center stage yesterday at a funeral service in the theater named for him. There was solemnity and there were tears and laughter as a diplomat, a sports writer and a theatrical writer joined those eulogizing the showman and financier, whose coffin was covered by more than 1,200 roses.
COHOES, N.Y., Feb. 13--A policewoman deserves just as much pay as a policeman, according to the State Commission for Human Rights.

PITTSBURGH, Feb. 10-- Kaiser Steel Corporation and the United Steelworkers of America are planning a major change in their experimental labor contract because one part of it is not living up to expectations.

Ch. Taffy's Kid Benjamin, owned by william B. Snow of Hinglewood, Ohio and handled by George Rood, was picked as, best of breed yesterday at the Boston Terrier Club of New York's annual specialty at the City Squire Motor Inn.

CHICAGO, Feb. 13 (AP)-- Charles H. Percy, who is seeking the Republican nomination for the Senate, announced today he was leaving the Bell Howell Company.

Ch. Salgray's Fashion Plate, the foremost boxer in the United States and one of the five top-ranking dogs among all breeds, went best in show for the second consecutive year last night at the 23d American Boxer Club specialty in the 71st Regiment Armory. Fashion Plate, handled by Larry Downey of Libertyville, Ill., and owned by Mr. and Mrs. Daniel M. Hamilburg of Brookline, Mass., beat out 247 dogs for the top prize.

Julian Bream packed them into Town Hall Saturday night for another of his lute-guitar recitals. The British musician has gained a little weight and lost a little hair, but his playing had the same refined yet earthy style that has made his appearances and recordings so popular.

Mayor Lindsay served public notice on Police Commissioner Vincent L. Broderick yesterday that the establishment of a civilian review board in the Police Department was a policy question that must be decided "at the executive level."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13-- The index of wholesale prices, which is widely regarded by economists as the most accurate measure available of the inflationary pressures in the economy, rose sharply again in January for the third successive month.

BONN, Feb. 13--The first round in the struggle between Chancellor Ludwig Erhard and his 41-year-old challenger, Rainer Barzel, will be fought Wednesday when leading members of the Christian Democratic Union decide whom to endorse for chairman of the party.

Bausch Lomb, the manufacturer of ophthalmic products and scientific and electronic instruments, plans to spend $6.65-million on capital improvements this year, William W. McQuilkin president, reported over the weekend. $3,879,777 spent in 1965, he said.

Assemblyman Stanley Steingut, Kings County Democratic leader, declared yesterday he would help within a few days to set up a nonprofit Economic Development Corporation to coordinate job efforts in Brooklyn.

NEWARK, Feb. 13--An 18year-old youth was arrested here today for questioning after three more suspicious fires broke out in Newark, Nine persons died last December in fires the authorities called suspicious.
WESTBURY, L.I, Feb. 13-- Elma, the third-highest moneyearning trotting mare in harness racing history, will be retired tomorrow night at Roosevelt Raceway.
More than 20 hours of rain-- the heaviest downpour in more than two years--fell on the city yesterday. It started at 2:55 A.M. and when it ended at 11:10 P.M. 2.42 inches had accumulated.
PARIS, Feb. 13 (AP)--Favored Querido II caught the front-running Oscar RL at the wire and won by a nose in a photo-finish today in the $60,000 Prix de Paris trotting race.

SANTO DOMINGO Dominican Republic, Feb. 13--Juan Bosch, leader of the powerful Dominican Revolutionary party, called today for the four-dayold strike in the Dominican Republic to continue until resistant military leaders obeyed a Presidential order transferring them to diplomatic posts abroad.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 13-- Following are the votes of delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on the major roll-calls in Congress during the week ended yesterday.
Mayor Lindsay has asked Governor Rockefeller to withhold the awarding of a contract for the northern half of the Richmond Parkway in Staten Island.

An Australian terrier with a great reputation Down Under, whence she came, continued yesterday the virtual monopoly that Mrs. Milton Fox of Point Pleasant, N.J., has enjoyed since the Australian Terrier Club of America started holding specialty shows.

Charles G. Moerdler, Commissioner of the Department of the Buildings, will be the speaker at a meeting of the New York Realty Owners Association tomorrow night at the Concourse Plaza Hotel, 161st Street and the Grand Concourse, the Bronx.

While most New Yorkers sleep, a senior official of the Lindsay administration will sit by a telephone in a quiet basement office at City Hall, beginning tonight, and keep in touch with developments in the City.
Bob Scharf of Baltimore, running through a driving rain and chill wind, won the Cherry Tree marathon run through the Bronx yesterday.
John F. Curry Jr., insurance broker and son of the late leader of Tammany Hall, died on Saturday in Lenox Hill Hospital after a brief illness. He was 57 years old and lived at 775 Park Avenue.

The failure of Aldo Moro, leader of the Christian Democrats, to form a government on his first try in the present Italian political crisis is bad news for everyone but the Communists. The possibilities now are a long crisis, a caretaker government or a general election. The four-party coalition is displaying lack of unity just at the moment that the Italian Communist party (PCI) has reorganized and unified its leadership.
ROME, Feb. 13--American teen-agers are generally fat and they spend most of their money on cosmetics and snacks, an article in L'Europeo, an Italian magazine, said today.
Word has come from Bonn that West Germans are smoking more these days and the Health Ministry is enjoying it less.
TRONDHEIM, Norway, Feb. 13 (AP)--Valentina Stenina, the Soviet Union's 31-year-old star, won her third women's world speed-skating championship today at the Ice Stadium.

ATLANTIC CITY, Feb. 13-- A special commission of the American Association of School Administrators today admonished private schools against setting themselves up as havens for the socially prejudiced.
Ch. Rawburn Bracken was chosen best of breed in the Bulldog Club of America specialty show yesterday at the Hotel Edison. He is owned by Mrs. Cyril Bernfeld and Mrs. R.H. Gauthier of Altendale, N.J.

BOSTON, Feb. 13 (AP)--The Los Angeles Lakers withstood a fourth-period Boston rally and spoiled Red Auerbach Day in defeating the Celtics, 120-110, today in a National Basketball Association duel of divisional leaders.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., Feb, 13-Neither the lack of natural snow nor heavy rain can stop ski jumping here.
Dr. Carl Kaysen of Harvard was named yesterday to succeed Dr. J. Robert Oppenheimer as director of the Institute for Advanced Study at Princeton, N.J.

ROANOKE RAPIDS, N.C., Feb. 13--James Albert House Jr., 35 years old, immediate past president of the Young Democratic Clubs of America, was found dead today with a pistol shot through the temple. The coroner ruled the death a Suicide.

The heads of two major Jewish Orthodox groups yesterday urged the adoption of a bill in the Legislature that would require school boards to give special "remedial services" to parochial and private-school children.

BANGKOK, Thailand, Feb. 13 --Vice President Humphrey brought to Thailand today an assurance that the United States had no thought of pulling back in South Vietnam or of forcing Saigon to accept a weakly negotiated peace.

DARIEN, Conn., Feb. 13-- The New York Caledonian Curling Club rink, skipped by Ernest Slaybaugh, won the Nutmeg Stone event today by defeating the Hamilton, Ont., Thistle C.C., skipped by Dean Taylor, 15-10, in the 12-end final of the annual Nutmeg C.C. bonspiel.
UPPSALA, Sweden, Feb. 13 (Reuters)--A powerful underground explosion apparently caused by a nuclear test by the Soviet Union was recorded by the Uppsala Seismological Institute today.

KAMPALA, Uganda, Feb. 13 (AP)--Prime Minister Milton Obote denied today charges in Parliament that he had conspired with other Cabinet Ministers and a high-ranking Army officer to overthrow the Constitution of Uganda or that he had Shared in the proceeds of gold and ivory said to have been seized in the Congo.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13-- District of Columbia officials, faced with a virtual end to interrogations by the police and confessions by suspects, are fighting off an offer of full legal services for the poor at all police stations.

PARIS, Feb. 13--While President Johnson fights off rising steel prices, Fried Krupp is fighting off reductions.
LOS ANGELES, Feb. 13-- Bill Baillie, who looks more like a shipping clerk than a distance runner, came bounding home with a vengeance last night.
The appointment of Peter E. Pattison as a vice president has been announced by the Uris Buildings Corporation.

NEWARK, Feb. 13--Following a debate marked by some shouting and booing, Newark teachers agreed this afternoon to end a two-day strike and return to work tomorrow, although no settlement of their contract dispute has yet been reached.
SALEM, Mass., Feb. 13 (AP) --Mrs. Billie Jean Moffitt King and Kathy Harter won openinground matches tonight in the New England women's indoor tennis championships.
QUEBEC, Feb. 13--Quebec is to have secular public schools as a part of its reforms in education.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 13-- An Agena rocket engine critical to the remaining Gemini manned space flights suffered a "mild explosion" during a key test yesterday, it was learned tonight.

The GavinKennan proposals to halt expansion of American forces and persist in seeking a compromise settlement point the way to such an alternative in the opinion of many Senators, including a majority of the Foreign Relations Committee.

Counsel for this state's Republican and Democratic parties are scheduled to tell the Court of Appeals this afternoon how much progress the Legislature has made in fulfilling the Feb. 15 judicial ultimatum for drawing new Senate and Assembly district lines. There is a strong likelihood that they will report action blocked by a deadlock between the Republicancontrolled Senate and the Democratic-controlled Assembly.
SAIGON, Feb. 13--An allied offensive on the central Vietnamese coast, about 300 miles north of Saigon, moved forward yesterday and today, but only minor contact with Communist forces was reported.

PRAGUE, Feb. 13--In the cavernous, vaulted rathskeller of a medieval building in the Old Town of Prague, the five youngsters were eager to talk about themselves. They dropped their voices only when, in telling jokes they mentioned the President of the country.

MADRID, Feb. 13--Spanish authorities called tonight for volunteers to help locate a United States Air Force Globemaster believed to have crashed in a storm in the Sierra Nevada last night. It was on a flight from Seville to search for a missing hydrogen bomb in southeastern Spain.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 (AP) --The Civil Aeronautics Board said tonight it needed greater authority to deal with certain types of air charter operations and had drafted legislation to achieve it.
BOGOTA, Colombia--The man who plans to put chicken on every Colombian family table by 1967 is now head or this coffee-rich land's largest single industrial effort--brewing beer.

FAR HILLS, N.J., Feb.13-- David Ives Mackie, a special consultant and former chairman of the Eastern Railroad Presidents Conference, and former vice president and general counsel of the Delaware, Lackawanna Western Railroad, now merged into the Erie-Lackawanna, died Friday of a heart attack in St. James Hospital in Newark. He was 62 years old and lived in Spook Hollow Road.
The Protestant Council of the City of New York may soon drop the word "Protestant" from its name and become the New York City Council of Churches.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13-- Francis Keppel, Assistant Sectary of Health, Education and Welfare, will leave soon for South Vietnam with a small team of experts to help Saigon officials analyze the strengths and weaknesses of their educational System.
